questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents to his primary physician for evaluation of an “ear problem.” The patient is a retired mixed martial arts fighter and wants to know if there is anything that he can do to fix the appearance of his left ear. The patient reports he was punched in his left ear several years ago, and he was left with the deformity demonstrated in the image below. This patient’s condition was likely the result of hematoma accumulation in which of the following anatomic structures?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with cauliflower ear, or boxer’s ear, which results from accumulation of blood in the subperichondrial space. This condition is most often the result of a direct blow to the external ear – particularly the components containing cartilage, such as the helix, the antihelix, the concha, tragus, and antitragus.

The skin overlying the cartilaginous components of the ear is tightly adherent to the underlying perichondrium, which subsequently supplies nutrients to the cartilage below. When trauma occurs to the cartilaginous components of the external ear, blood can accumulate between the perichondrium and cartilage. Without proper drainage, the hematoma acts as a mechanical barrier between the cartilage and its perichondrial blood supply, ultimately resulting in necrosis, fibrosis and neocartilage formation. The result is a cosmetically deformed external ear, known as cauliflower ear.  

Option Analysis

✅ Subperichondrial space:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ External acoustic meatus  :
Incorrect: The external acoustic meatus is a short, curved tube that burrows through the temporal bone and ends at the tympanic membrane. The external acoustic meatus is not involved in the development of cauliflower ear.  
❌ Ear lobule  :
Incorrect: The ear lobule or lobe is the fleshy portion of the auricle. This component of external ear anatomy is made up of skin and fat and hence does not contribute to the formation of cauliflower ear given it is devoid of cartilage.  
❌ Tympanic membrane  :
Incorrect: The tympanic membrane, also called the eardrum, is a thin, translucent membrane that separates the external ear from the middle ear. It is responsible for transmitting vibrations to the bones of the inner ear. The tympanic membrane is not involved in the development of cauliflower ear.  
❌ The epitympanic recess  :
Incorrect: The roof of the middle ear is also called the epitympanic recess. The epitympanic recess is not involved in the development of cauliflower ear.

questions.text:
A 34-year-old woman comes to the office to evaluate pain and redness of the left eye for the past three days. The patient is a school teacher and recalls exposure to a child with “pink eye.” The patient does not have any associated fever, cough, headache, nasal congestion, or sore throat. The patient was recently diagnosed with ankylosing spondylitis after evaluating chronic back pain. She does not take any medications except for ibuprofen as needed. Family history is significant for acute-angle closure glaucoma in the patient’s mother. Vitals are within normal limits. Ocular examination findings are shown below.



Reproduced fromWikimedia Commons

During the examination, the patient could not keep her left eye open. Increased tearing is noted from the left eye. The right eye examination is within normal limits. Visual acuity is 20/50 in the left eye and 20/20 in the right eye. Which component of the eye is implicated in this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with a painful red eye, photophobia, and decreased visual acuity suggestive of anterior uveitis, which refers to inflammation of the anterior uveal tract (i.e. the iris and ciliary body). Physical examination demonstrates ciliary flush, a hazy flare in the aqueous humor, and hypopyon (exudate rich in white blood cells). This condition can be idiopathic or secondary to systemic autoimmune disorders, including ankylosing spondylitis, juvenile rheumatoid arthritis, Reiter syndrome, sarcoidosis, or Behçet disease.

In contrast, posterior uveitis, which refers to inflammation of the posterior uveal tract (choroid and retina), occurs less commonly and is often painless. Additional inflammatory conditions of the eye are summarized below:



Option Analysis

✅ Iris and ciliary body:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Meibomian gland:
Incorrect: Chalazions result from the obstruction of Zeis or meibomian glands and present with lid discomfort and a non-tender nodule. An internal hordeolum is secondary to inflammation of the meibomian gland, resulting in swelling just under the conjunctival side of the eyelid. This patient’s presentation with a painful red eye, photophobia, and decreased visual acuity suggests an alternative diagnosis.
❌ Glands of Zeis and Moll:
Incorrect: External hordeola arise from glands in the eyelash follicle or lid-margin (gland of Zeis and gland of Moll). Patients typically present with localized, painful, and erythematous swelling of the eyelid.
❌ Conjunctiva and cornea:
Incorrect: Keratoconjunctivitis refers to inflammation of the cornea and conjunctiva. Isolated corneal involvement is called keratitis, whereas conjunctival involvement is called conjunctivitis. This patient’s presentation with a painful red eye, photophobia, and decreased visual acuity suggests an alternative diagnosis.
❌ Choroid and retina:
Incorrect: Inflammation of the choroid and retina is called chorioretinitis, also known as posterior uveitis. This condition is usually painless and presents nonspecific visual changes, including floaters and reduced visual acuities. Redness of the eye is not a prominent feature of posterior inflammation without accompanying anterior uveitis.

questions.text: An 18-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by EMTs and police after a motor vehicle collision. The patient entered a highway and was struck by another vehicle at high speed. She was unrestrained and was ejected from her car. She arrives in the ED alert and oriented x3 and endorses severe pain in her neck and right axilla. Temperature is 97 F° (36.1 C°), pulse is 160/min, and blood pressure is 132/90 mm Hg. On physical examination, the right arm is internally rotated and abducted and flexed at the wrist with an extended forearm. The muscular tone of the right biceps, infraspinatus, and deltoid appears diminished. She has sensory loss along the lateral surface of the right arm, up to the thumb. Imaging of the cervical vertebrae does not reveal fractures, bleeding, or evidence of impingement. X-ray of the right upper extremity does not demonstrate dislocations or fractures. Which of the following best describes the anatomic localization of this patient’s lesion?
questions.solution:
This patient suffered from a motor vehicle accident resulting in right arm weakness and numbness. While this vignette does not describe an exact mechanism of injury for this patient, it does provide physical exam findings of a flexed wrist, extended forearm, and internally rotated arm, consistent with a waiter’s tip finding. Additionally, she has evidence of sensory loss over the lateral arm up to the thumb, suggesting a brachial plexus injury at the level of the cervical nerve roots. Collectively, these examination findings are referred to as Erb palsy.

Erb palsy occurs secondary to traumatic lateral flexion of the neck, usually during trauma or childbirth. Forced lateral flexion to the brachial plexus at levels C5-C6 results in sensory loss to the lateral arm and thumb and paralysis and atrophy of the deltoid, biceps, and brachialis muscles. Treatment involves immobilization with an abduction brace and surgery.

Other brachial plexus injuries include axillary nerve injury, which can occur due to anterior shoulder dislocation or fracture at the surgical neck of the humerus. Patients with this deficit will exhibit weakness of the deltoid and impaired arm abduction and external rotation. Sensory deficits secondary to axillary nerve injuries result in numbness over the lateral shoulder. 

Option Analysis

✅ C5-C6 nerve roots  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Radial nerve  :
Incorrect: Radial nerve injury usually occurs with midshaft fractures of the humerus or with prolonged crutch use.  
❌ Ulnar nerve  :
Incorrect: Ulnar nerve injuries are usually caused by fractures of the medial epicondyle of the humerus or by a hook of hamate fracture.  
❌ Anterior shoulder:
Incorrect: While common and often a cause of axillary nerve injury, an anterior dislocation would be evident on x-ray.  
❌ Carpal tunnel  :
Incorrect: Neither the patient’s disease etiology nor symptomatology are congruent with findings of carpal tunnel syndrome.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old woman undergoes CT angiography of the head and neck. The patient is found to have a partial occlusion of the structure indicated by the arrow:  


Image reproduced from Osmosis.org.  

Which of the following blood vessels is primarily supplied by the affected structure?
questions.solution:
This patient has a partial occlusion of the right vertebral artery. The vertebral arteries supply blood to the posterior cerebral circulation vessels, such as the anterior inferior cerebellar artery.  

The vertebral arteries arise from the subclavian arteries and travel towards the cranium through the transverse foramina of the cervical vertebrae. Afterward, the vessels pass through the foramen magnum into the cranial cavity.  

First, the vertebral arteries give off a branch called the posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA), which supplies the medulla and parts of the cerebellum. Both vertebral arteries then unite into a single vessel called the basilar artery at the medulla. As the basilar artery ascends, it first gives off the anterior inferior cerebellar artery (AICA), which supplies the lateral pons and parts of the cerebellum.  

Then, the basilar artery sends small branches called pontine arteries to supply the mid-pons. Near the midbrain above, the basilar artery gives off the right and left posterior cerebral arteries (PCA), which supply the occipital lobes of the brain. The PCAs eventually give rise to the posterior communicating arteries, which merge with the internal carotid arteries to connect the posterior circulation with the anterior circulation.  

Option Analysis

❌ Anterior cerebral artery:
Incorrect: The arrow points to the vertebral artery, which supplies blood to the posterior cerebral circulation. In contrast, the anterior cerebral arteries are part of the anterior circulation provided by the internal carotid arteries. 
❌ Lenticulostriate artery:
Incorrect: The lenticulostriate artery is a branch of the middle cerebral artery. Since the lenticulostriate artery is part of the anterior cerebral circulation, it is supplied by the internal carotid artery.
❌ Middle cerebral artery:
Incorrect: The arrow points to the vertebral artery, which supplies blood to the posterior cerebral circulation. In contrast, the middle cerebral arteries are part of the anterior circulation and supplied by the internal carotid arteries.   
❌ Ophthalmic artery:
Incorrect: The ophthalmic artery is part of the anterior cerebral circulation and supplied by the internal carotid artery. 
✅ Anterior inferior cerebellar artery:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 73-year-old person comes to a neurology clinic to establish care after a recent hospitalization for stroke. The patient sustained acute right-sided hemiparesis and was found to have a large ischemic stroke involving the left middle cerebral artery. The patient did not receive fibrinolytic therapy due to presenting eight hours following symptom onset. Muscle strength significantly improved after physical therapy. However, the patient reports that they are now unable to differentiate between the fingers in their right hand, and they are now unable to write. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows motor strength is 4/5 on the right side. When asked to elevate the left hand, the patient elevates the right hand. The patient is unable to solve a simple mathematical problem. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with inability to recognize individual fingers (finger agnosia), left-right disorientation, and acalculia (inability to solve simple math); they most likely have Gerstmann syndrome. 

The angular gyrus refers to an area located in the inferior parietal lobe of the dominant hemisphere that integrates visual, acoustic, and somatosensory information necessary for problem solving (in particular, speech and number processing). It is supplied by the angular and posterior parietal arteries, which are branches of the middle cerebral artery (MCA). Occlusion of these arteries in the dominant hemisphere can result in Gerstmann Syndrome (as in this patient), or, in rare cases, the syndrome can result from a traumatic brain injury or a brain tumor in the same region. Clinical manifestations include finger agnosia, left-right disorientation, acalculia, agraphia (inability to write), and alexia (inability to read).  



Option Analysis

❌ Kluver-Bucy syndrome:
Incorrect: Kluver-Bucy syndrome results from bilateral lesions of the amygdala and surrounding cortex of the temporal lobe. Affected patients present with hypersexuality, hyperphagia, and an urge for exploring objects by mouth (hyperorality). Some patients exhibit visual agnosia, or psychic blindness, and personality changes, like passivity or docility.  
❌ Hemispatial neglect syndrome:
Incorrect: Hemispatial neglect syndrome is caused by a lesion in the inferior parietal lobe of the non-dominant hemisphere. Clinical features associated with this syndrome include spatial neglect of the contralateral body. Examples include construction apraxia (when asked to draw a clock, the individual only draws the right half of the clock) and dressing apraxia (the individual only dresses half of their body). 
✅ Gerstmann syndrome:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Frontal lobe syndrome:
Incorrect: Frontal lobe syndrome occurs as a result of damage to the prefrontal cortex. This condition presents with disinhibition and deficits in concentration, judgment, and orientation. Early behavioral changes include socially inappropriate behavior, apathy, and compulsive behavior.
❌ Damage to the corpus callosum:
Incorrect: The corpus callosum transfers information between the cerebral hemispheres. Damage to the corpus callosum results in transcortical apraxia, wherein the patient is unable to execute learned motor movement using the side of the body supplied by the nondominant hemisphere.

questions.text:
A 47-year-old woman presents to the emergency department to evaluate a fever and cough. The patient has been experiencing ongoing fevers for the past week. She also has a productive cough that yields greenish sputum. Past medical history includes hypertension and diabetes. She smokes one pack of cigarettes per day and does not use alcohol or illicit drugs. Temperature is 38.6°C (101.5°F), pulse is 105/min, blood pressure is 100/66 mmHg, respirations are 18/min, and oxygen saturation is 94% on room air. Upright AP and lateral chest radiographs are obtained and demonstrated below. Which of the following anatomic locations is the most likely site for pulmonary auscultation of this patient’s pathology?  


Image reproduced from Radiopedia

choices.text: Right anterior mid clavicular line, 5th intercostal space
Right posterior mid scapular line, 5th intercostal space
Right anterior mid clavicular line, 2nd intercostal space
Right posterior mid scapular line at the level of the 10th thoracic vertebra
Right anterior midaxillary line, 6th intercostal space

questions.solution:
This patient presents with clinical features of pneumonia and a right middle lobe consolidation on chest radiography. The anatomic area for pulmonary auscultation of this pathology is over the right anterior midclavicular line in the fifth intercostal space.  

The lung is divided into several lobes, which are separated by fissures. In both lungs, the oblique fissure runs posteriorly at the level of T3 to the 6th rib anteriorly at the midclavicular line. The horizontal fissure, which separates the superior and middle lobes of the right lung, connects to the right oblique fissure at the midaxillary line near the 5th rib and runs anteriorly to the area of the 4th costal cartilage. Ultimately, these anatomic distinctions create an approach for pulmonary auscultation: most posterior auscultation examines the inferior lobes, whereas anterior auscultation primarily concerns the superior and middle lobes.  

Auscultation should be performed sequentially from the lung apices to the lungs bases. Auscultation should be performed on both the anterior and posterior chest, and sounds of the left chest should be compared to those of the right. Auscultating in this manner will ensure comprehensive examination and evaluation of all the relevant anatomical components of the lungs.    



Option Analysis

✅ Right anterior mid clavicular line, 5th intercostal space:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Right posterior mid scapular line, 5th intercostal space:
Incorrect: The right middle lobe is best auscultated anteriorly over the fourth or fifth intercostal space, midclavicular line. Posterior auscultation will typically only reveal abnormalities of the superior and inferior lobes of the right lung.
❌ Right anterior mid clavicular line, 2nd intercostal space :
Incorrect: This anatomic location is most effective for auscultating the superior lobe of the right lung, not the right middle lobe.
❌ Right posterior mid scapular line at the level of the 10th thoracic vertebra:
Incorrect: This anatomic location is the best space for auscultating the lung bases, not the right middle lobe.
❌ Right anterior midaxillary line, 6th intercostal space :
Incorrect: This space describes the most appropriate area for auscultation of the inferior lobe of the right lung, not the right middle lobe.

questions.text:
A 26-year-old man presents to the emergency department to evaluate right wrist pain. The patient was playing pick-up basketball when he tripped, fell, and landed on an outstretched right hand. He states, “I thought I might have a wrist sprain, but my fourth and fifth fingers started feeling numb, so I came to the ED to get checked out.” He is otherwise healthy and does not take any medication. Physical examination reveals tenderness to palpation and swelling over the hypothenar eminence. The patient’s initial right hand and wrist radiographs are unremarkable. A carpal tunnel view of the right hand is subsequently obtained and shown below. Which of the following anatomic structures is at most significant risk of injury based on this patient’s clinical presentation?  


Image reproduced from Radiopedia
questions.solution:
This patient presents after a fall on an outstretched hand. He has pain over the ulnar aspect of the wrist and numbness of the fourth and fifth digits. The carpal tunnel view demonstrates a fracture to the hook of the hamate, which carries a risk of compression injury to the ulnar nerve as it passes through the Gunyon canal.

Hook of the hamate injuries are uncommon but typically occur due to a mechanism of injury involving a fall on an outstretched hand (“FOOSH” injury). Clinically, patients will experience pain and swelling over the ulnar aspect of the wrist and hypothenar eminence with associated ulnar nerve deficits if compression is present. Careful physical examination should be performed to assess ulnar nerve and artery function to ensure that neither is injured. This evaluation can be accomplished via 1) strength and sensation testing of the fourth and fifth digits and 2) pressing down on the radial artery and assessing if sufficient blood can reach the hand via the ulnar artery.

Hook of the hamate fractures are often missed on initial evaluation and misdiagnosed as wrist sprains, as frontal and lateral radiographs are often unremarkable.  A carpal tunnel view of the wrist can be obtained for further evaluation if suspicion remains despite normal radiographs.

Option Analysis

✅ Ulnar nerve  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Extensor digitorum  :
Incorrect: The extensor digitorum is located on the dorsal aspect of the hand. Injury to this structure can occur when a direct force is applied to a digit held in extension. In contrast, this patient sustained a fall onto an outstretched hand and has imaging that reveals a hook of the hamate fracture.  
❌ Median nerve:
Incorrect: Injury to the median nerve is unlikely to occur from the hook of the hamate fractures.  
❌ Radial nerve  :
Incorrect: Radial nerve injury does not typically occur with the hook of the hamate fractures. Instead, it more commonly occurs with humeral shaft fractures.  
❌ Radial artery  :
Incorrect: Radial artery injury does not typically occur in the setting of the hook of the hamate fractures.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after falling two stories while washing windows on scaffolding. Per paramedics, the patient fell directly on his back, was helmeted, and did not suffer the loss of consciousness. On arrival, temperature is 98.6°F (37°C), pulse is 45/min, respirations are 22/min, blood pressure is 178/65 mmHg, and O2 saturation is 95% on room air. The patient’s primary survey is intact. The patient's secondary survey is notable for bruising and tenderness over the cervical and thoracic spine. A neurological examination demonstrates loss of sensation starting below the xiphoid process. The patient has 2+ triceps and brachioradialis reflexes and 5/5 strength of the upper extremities bilaterally. The patient is unable to move the bilateral lower extremities. Which of the following reflects the most likely level of spinal injury?
questions.solution:
This patient presents for trauma evaluation after sustaining an injury to the spine. The neurologic examination is consistent with preserved sensation and motor strength above the level of T7, which is best approximated at the xiphoid process level.    

Pathologies that affect the spinal cord are diverse and include trauma, ischemia, infection, autoimmune conditions, neoplasm, and hereditary-degenerative diseases. Compressive etiologies (e.g. those resulting in direct physical impingement on the spinal cord) include tumors, spinal epidural abscesses, hematomas, herniated disks, or bony disease. Spinal cord transection can also result from direct trauma such as stab wounds, gunshot wounds, or extreme shearing forces. Ischemia, particularly from the anterior or posterior spinal arteries, may also result in injury to the spinal cord.    

Regardless of the etiology, the level of injury can be determined via a focused neurological assessment, including sensation testing, motor function testing, and reflex testing. The absence of sensation below a particular dermatome in conjunction with correlating motor and reflex deficits can indicate the level of a lesion.  


Option Analysis

✅ T7:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ T4:
Incorrect: A spinal lesion at T4 would present with loss of sensation below the nipple line; this patient has preserved sensation at this dermatome.  
❌ C2:
Incorrect: A spinal lesion at C2 would result in loss of sensation below the posterior half of the skull; injuries to this spinal level are often lethal due to damage to brainstem structures.  
❌ C4:
Incorrect: Injury to the C4 level would result in loss of sensation below the collar line and possible diaphragmatic dysfunction since this spinal cord level helps innervate the diaphragm.  
❌ T10:
Incorrect: A spinal cord lesion at T10 would result in loss of sensation starting at the level of the umbilicus.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman comes to the labor and delivery unit in active labor. An hour later, she gives birth to a stillborn infant. The patient states that she did not receive consistent prenatal care. An autopsy of the infant reveals cyclopia and cleft palate. Examination of the brain shows fused cerebral hemispheres. This condition was most likely caused by failure of differentiation of which of the following anatomical structures?
questions.solution:
Holoprosencephaly is a developmental anomaly of the embryonic forebrain (prosencephalon) and is commonly seen with other midline defects (e.g., cleft palate, cyclopia). There are three main types: alobar, semilobar, and lobar.  

  •  Alobar - the most severe, in which the brain fails to separate; it is accompanied by severe facial deformities (e.g. cyclopia). This condition is incompatible with life.  
  •  Semilobar - parietal division of the brain's hemispheres   
  •  Lobar - the least severe form, in which there is a considerable separation of the brain hemispheres  
Around the 3rd week of gestation, shortly after anterior neural tube closure, the three primary brain vesicles develop into the prosencephalon, mesencephalon, and rhombencephalon. Up until the 5th week, these structures continue to develop into 5 secondary brain vesicles; the prosencephalon is divided into two hemispheres and differentiates into the telencephalon and diencephalon, while the rhombencephalon differentiates into the metencephalon and myelencephalon. Failure of the prosencephalon to divide into two hemispheres results in holoprosencephaly. On imaging, holoprosencephaly is characterized by fusion of the thalami and there is a single posteriorly located ventricle. While the exact pathogenesis is unknown, it has been linked to multiple genetic mutations (e.g, sonic hedgehog, zinc finger protein), chromosome abnormalities (e.g., trisomy 13, trisomy 18, and triploidy), and environmental factors (e.g., maternal diabetes, retinoic acid, and drug and alcohol abuse).      






Option Analysis

❌ Mesencephalon :
Incorrect: During embryonic development, the middle primary brain vesicle known as the mesencephalon (midbrain) will grow further but will not differentiate. The two major parts of the midbrain are the cerebral peduncles (anterior) and the corpora quadrigemina (superior & inferior colliculi [posterior]).   
❌ Rhombencephalon:
Incorrect: The rhombencephalon (or hindbrain) is the dorsal primary brain vesicle that gives rise to the metencephalon and myelencephalon. The metencephalon gives rise to the pons and cerebellum, while the myelencephalon develops into the medulla oblongata.   
✅ Prosencephalon:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Myelencephalon:
Incorrect: The myelencephalon, which develops from the differentiation of the rhombencephalon (hindbrain), gives rise to the medulla, not the cerebral hemispheres.  
❌ Diencephalon:
Incorrect: The diencephalon develops from the prosencephalon (forebrain) into the thalamus, hypothalamus, epithalamus and eye cup. Holoprosencephaly is caused by the failure of the entire prosencephalon to differentiate, not just the diencephalon.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man comes to the office due to leg pain for the past few months. He reports pain that is 3/10 in severity, tingling, and located on the buttocks and thighs. The pain is exacerbated with walking or standing for prolonged time. The patient noticed however, a relief in the pain when he is walking with a supermarket cart or when sitting. Medical history is notable for type 2 diabetes mellitus, for which the patient takes metformin. He has no dyspnea or chest pain. He has been smoking 1 pack of cigarettes per day for 30 years. Vitals are within normal limits. On physical examination, peripheral pulses are intact. Neurologic examination is within normal limits. Which of the following structures is most likely involved in this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with posterior leg pain and tingling which exacerbates with standing or walking erect and subside with sitting or walking with a cart (leaning forward). This presentation is consistent with lumbar spinal stenosis (LLS).  

LLS refers to narrowing of the intraspinal (central) canal at the lumbar region, which can be congenital or acquired. Compression of the spinal cord is responsible for the pain, weakness, and paresthesia symptoms during walking (termed neurogenic claudication). In general, extension of the spine (e.g., standing, going downhill) narrows the intraspinal canal and exacerbates symptoms. In contrast, flexion of the spine (e.g., sitting, walking with cart) widens the intraspinal canal and improves symptoms. This characteristic can be used to distinguish LSS from vascular claudication, which is not posture dependent.  

Spondylosis (degenerative arthritis of the spine) is the most common cause of LSS and commonly affects individuals over the age of 60 years. Some factors that may contribute to this process include disc degeneration and protrusion, loss of disc height, facet joint arthropathy, osteophyte formation, and ligamentum flavum hypertrophy. Of note, the ligamentum flavum is an elastic ligament that runs from the axis to the sacrum.  



Option Analysis

❌ Supraspinous ligament:
Incorrect: The supraspinous ligament connects the apices of the spinous processes from the cervical vertebra to the sacrum and limits spine flexion. It is not involved in the pathogenesis of spinal stenosis.
❌ Anterior longitudinal ligament:
Incorrect: The anterior longitudinal ligament is located on the anterior side of the vertebrae. Its role is to limit spine extension. It is not involved in the pathogenesis of spinal stenosis.
✅ Ligamentum flavum:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Peripheral arteries:
Incorrect: Peripheral artery disease (PAD) can cause vascular claudication, which causes symptoms due to insufficient blood supply to the peripheral tissues. Although this patient has risk factors for PAD, the peripheral pulses are intact. Moreover, the symptoms worsen while standing still and improve when walking with a cart. Patients with PAD will report exacerbation with exertion and improvement with rest.
❌ Sacroiliac joint:
Incorrect: Ankylosing spondylitis is an inflammatory autoimmune condition that affects the spine and sacroiliac joints. Patients often endorse morning stiffness that alleviates with movement, limited spine flexion, and back pain. It most commonly affects men between the ages of 30-50 years old. Extra-axial involvement such as uveitis and aortic regurgitation may also occur.

questions.text: A 17-year-old female presents to her primary care physician with worsening occipital headaches, gait disturbance, and diminished pain sensation. She recently burned herself while cooking after keeping her hand on a pan “that did not feel hot when touched.” The patient has also been experiencing worsening occipital headaches that wake her up from sleep as well as feelings of discoordination while walking. Vitals are within normal limits. Neurologic exam is notable for gait ataxia, down beating nystagmus, as well as bilateral loss of pain and temperature sensation in the upper extremities. Which of the following anatomic structures is directly disrupted by this patient's disease process?
questions.solution:
This patient has worsening occipital headaches, ataxia, nystagmus, and bilateral loss of pain and temperature sensation in the upper extremities. These findings are concerning for a Chiari I malformation with concomitant syringomyelia, which is likely compressing the anterior white commissure.    

Syringomyelia describes a cystic cavity within the spinal cord that is usually within the central canal. Most lesions are in the cervical spinal cord, but they can less commonly manifest in the thoracic or lumbar regions. These cystic malformations are associated with Chiari I malformation, which is characterized by abnormally shaped cerebellar tonsils that herniate below the level of the foramen magnum. Syringomyelia is also associated with spinal cord trauma, spinal tumors, and abscesses.    

Overtime, the syrinx can expand and compress the anterior white commissure, a structure directly anterior to the cervical canal. The anterior white commissure is the decussation site for the spinothalamic tracts, which relay pain and temperature sensation. As a result, syringomyelia causes a "cape-like," bilateral, symmetrical loss of pain and temperature sensation in the upper extremities.  

Synringomelia is diagnosed with MRI and managed surgically via posterior fossa decompression or ventricular drainage, when clinically indicated. If untreated, the syringomyelia can cause permanent neurological disability, scoliosis, and neuropathic arthropathy.  

Option Analysis

❌ Medulla:
Incorrect: The medulla is the site of decussation for the dorsal column pathway. It is rarely implicated in cases of syringomyelia, since these cystic cavities do not typically originate until the level of the cervical spine.  
❌  Cerebellar vermis :
Incorrect: The cerebellar vermis is herniated in individuals with Chiari II malformation. However, this patient has a “cape-like” loss of temperature and pain sensation in the upper extremities. These findings are likely due to a syrinx compressing the anterior white commissure, which contains fibers of the spinothalamic tract that relay pain and temperature sensation. 
✅ Anterior white commissure  :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Anterior corticospinal tract :
Incorrect: This patient has a loss of temperature and pain sensation in the upper extremities that follows a “cape-like” distribution pattern. These findings are consistent with syringomyelia, which does not typically affect the anterior corticospinal tract. 
❌ Dorsal column pathway:
Incorrect: Patients with Chiari type I malformations may present with findings of diminished proprioception or ataxia. However, these symptoms are due to abnormalities with the cerebellum, rather than the effects of a syrinx compressing the dorsal column pathway.

questions.text: A 78-year-old man is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of sudden-onset dizziness, nausea, and weakness. The patient was gardening when he suddenly felt unsteady and noted the world was “spinning” around him. Medical history includes hypertension and hyperlipidemia. The patient is an active smoker with a 35-pack-year history. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 168/104 mmHg. The left pupil is slightly constricted when compared to the right with concomitant left-sided ptosis. Rotary and vertical nystagmus is present. There is impaired pinprick and temperature sensation on the left side of the face, right trunk, and right upper, and right lower extremities. Which of the following vascular territories is most likely affected given this patient’s clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with vertigo, Horner syndrome of the left face, and impaired sensation of the left face and right body consistent with a stroke of the posterior circulation. More specifically, this patient's presentation is consistent with left lateral medullary syndrome, also known as Wallenberg syndrome.

Lateral medullary syndrome results from occlusion of the vertebral artery or one of its medullary branches, such as the posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA). A stroke in this anatomic distribution results in damage to the the following structures with associated symptoms:

  •  Vestibular nuclei: nystagmus, nausea, vertigo 
  •  Nucleus ambiguus of CN IX and X: ipsilateral laryngeal and pharyngeal paralysis, loss of the gag reflex, dysarthria, dysphagia, and dysphonia 
  •  Spinothalamic tracts: contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation from the trunk and extremities 
  •  Spinal trigeminal nucleus and tract: ipsilateral loss of pain and temperature sensation from the face 
  •  Descending sympathetic tract: ipsilateral Horner syndrome
 


Option Analysis

❌ A:
Incorrect: This area refers to the right lateral medulla, which becomes implicated in occlusions of the right vertebral artery or one of its medullary branches, such as the posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA). In right lateral medullary syndrome, patients present with ipsilateral cerebellar signs, ipsilateral loss of pain and temperature sensation from the face, and contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation from the trunk and extremities.
❌ B:
Incorrect: Right medial medullary syndrome results in left-sided hemiparesis of the trunk and extremities, left-sided loss of proprioception, tactile sensation, and vibratory sensation, as well as right-sided flaccid paralysis of the tongue.
❌ C:
Incorrect: Medial medullary syndrome results in contralateral hemiparesis of the trunk and extremities, contralateral loss of proprioception, tactile sensation, and vibratory sensation, as well as ipsilateral flaccid paralysis of the tongue.
✅ D:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 31-year-old man comes to his primary care physician after feeling a lump on his right testicle. The patient denies any associated pain. He has no significant past medical history. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals a mobile, soft, round mass superior and posterior to the right testis. The nodule transilluminates when a penlight is held behind it. An ultrasound of the mass is performed and demonstrates posterior acoustic enhancement. Which of the following is the most likely anatomic location of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
A spermatocele is a cystic structure filled with dead spermatozoa-containing fluid arising from the epididymis, rete testis, or efferent ductule.The etiology of spermatoceles is not known, although several mechanisms have been proposed including trauma, infection, or other inflammatory/autoimmune processes. It is hypothesized that the epididymal ducts become obstructed due to continual shedding of immature germ cells.

Most commonly, spermatoceles are incidental findings and do not cause symptoms. Palpation of the scrotum typically reveals a soft, round mass at the posterior and superior aspect of the testis. Similar to hydroceles, the cystic nature of the mass allows for transillumination. An ultrasound often reveals an anechoic or echolucent area with posterior acoustic enhancement. Spermatoceles do not typically require treatment, but they may require surgical excision due to pain.  

Option Analysis

✅ Epididymis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Pampiniform plexus:
Incorrect: Varicoceles are caused by impaired venous drainage and most commonly present with left-sided scrotal fullness and have the feel of a “bag of worms.”
❌ Tunica vaginalis:
Incorrect: A hydrocele is an abnormal collection of serous fluid between the two layers (visceral and parietal) of the tunica vaginalis of the testis. A hydrocele causes more generalized scrotal swelling, whereas a spermatocele, as in this patient, causes a more defined, palpable lump associated with the testis.
❌ Spermatic cord:
Incorrect: Twisting of the spermatic cord can cause ischemia and subsequent testicular torsion. Testicular torsion presents with sudden intense pain in the testicles. The torsed testicle is often swollen and edematous, which makes it difficult to distinguish normal anatomy. This patient has a nontender, palpable mass that transilluminates, making another etiology more likely.
❌ Testis:
Incorrect: Palpable testicular nodules in a young adult male should raise suspicion for a testicular tumor. However, tumors do not transilluminate (since they do not allow the passage of light). In addition, the majority of testicular tumors are not mobile.

questions.text:
A 78-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after he was found unresponsive at home. Past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes and hypertension. The patient's last medication refill was almost two years ago. Temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 109/min, respirations are 20/min and blood pressure is 240/190 mm Hg. The patient has extensor posturing and pinpoint pupils. A CT scan of the head without contrast is shown below.  


Reproduced from Radiopedia  
Despite resuscitative measures, the patient dies several hours later. Damage to which of the following structures is most associated with the depressed level of consciousness observed in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with a hypertensive hemorrhage in the posterior rostral pons, a portion of the brainstem that houses the reticular activating system (RAS).

The RAS is a network of neurons originating in the tegmentum of the upper pons and midbrain that is especially important in maintaining consciousness. The RAS sends fibers towards the cerebral cortex, ensuring wakefulness and the ability to recognize and react to stimuli. Lesions of the tegmentum of the upper pons and midbrain RAS reduce the level of arousal and consciousness, leading to lethargy, stupor, and coma.  

Option Analysis

❌ Rostral ventral medulla  :
Incorrect: The rostral ventromedial medulla refers to a group of neurons located close to the midline of the medulla oblongata. This region transmits both descending inhibitory and excitatory fibers to dorsal horn spinal cord neurons, which are characterized by their response to nociceptive inputs.  
✅ Reticular activating system:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Internal capsule:
Incorrect: Damage to the internal capsule presents with contralateral hemiparesis, dysarthria, and contralateral hemisensory loss. The internal capsule is often affected in patients with putaminal hemorrhages. This patient’s CT scan is suggestive of a pontine hemorrhage.  
❌ Posterior pituitary  :
Incorrect: The posterior pituitary releases oxytocin and vasopressin produced by the hypothalamus. These hormones do not play a role in maintaining consciousness.  
❌ Basal ganglia  :
Incorrect: The “basal ganglia” refers to a group of subcortical nuclei responsible for motor control, motor learning, executive and behavioral function, as well as emotional regulation. It is not involved in maintaining consciousness.

questions.text: A 23-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by the local paramedics after a motor vehicle collision. He was found approximately 1 hour after the accident occurred. At the scene, the patient was awake and complained of pain in his back and legs. His temperature is 35.6°C (96.1°F), his pulse is 106/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 110/88 mm Hg. Glasgow coma scale is 15. On physical examination, the patient is awake, his speech is clear and appropriate, and he has normal breath sounds over bilateral lung fields. He has palpable, equal femoral pulses. Multiple abrasions are noted over the neck, shoulders, abdomen, and legs. The chest wall is nontender. The abdomen is mildly tender. The pelvis is stable, but he has extensive swelling and tenderness of the right thigh. The patient has multiple scalp lacerations that continue to ooze. Which of the following best describes the location of the bleeding from the scalp seen in this patient?

choices.text: Between the arachnoid mater and dura mater
Between the brain and arachnoid mater
Between the scalp skin and epicranial aponeurosis
Between epicranial aponeurosis and loose connective tissue
Between the periosteum and epicranial aponeurosis

questions.solution:
The scalp is highly vascularized by the branches of the external and internal carotid arteries, which course within layer two of the scalp, the subcutaneous connective tissue layer between the skin and the epicranial aponeurosis. Most bleeding comes from the superficial temporal artery and the occipital artery.  

Scalp lacerations usually bleed profusely, primarily the result of abundant anastomosis. In addition, the severed arteries do not contract when they are cut because the vessel lumens are held open by the dense connective tissue in the second layer of the scalp.    

Scalp wounds can be classified as:  
  •  Superficial scalp wounds: Do not gape because of the strength of the underlying aponeurosis, which holds the margins of the wound together 
  •  Deep scalp wounds: The scalp is lacerated in the coronal plane. The wounds gape because of the contraction of the frontalis and occipitalis muscles in the opposite directions. This aponeurotic layer of the scalp is often tightened during cosmetic surgery (e.g., “facelifts”) to help reduce wrinkles in the face and forehead. 

Option Analysis

❌ Between the arachnoid mater and dura mater:
Incorrect: Bleeding between the arachnoid mater and dura mater is known as subdural hemorrhage. It usually results from tears in bridging veins that cross the subdural space. Patients with large bleeds may present with signs of increased intracranial pressure. External bleeding is not seen. 
❌ Between the brain and arachnoid mater:
Incorrect: Subarachnoid hemorrhage develops between the brain and arachnoid mater. External bleeding is not seen. 
✅ Between the scalp skin and epicranial aponeurosis:
 Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Between epicranial aponeurosis and loose connective tissue:
Incorrect: The nerves and arteries of the scalp course within layer two, the subcutaneous connective tissue layer between the skin and the epicranial aponeurosis. The loose connective tissue (layer four) contains the emissary veins. It is a “danger area” because it allows the spread of infection to the intracranial structures. 
❌ Between the periosteum and epicranial aponeurosis:
Incorrect: Subgaleal hemorrhage results from bleeding from emissary veins between the periosteum and the epicranial aponeurosis. It can occur in neonates during birth and presents as diffuse, progressive, fluctuant scalp and neck swelling.

questions.text: A 75-year-old man is diagnosed with age-related progressive bilateral sensorineural hearing loss of higher frequencies. Which of the following components of the auditory system detects high frequency vibrations?
questions.solution:
Presbycusis is age related progressive sensorineural hearing loss, often of higher frequencies, due to the destruction of hair cells at the cochlear base.

Normally, vibrations lead to stimulation of a specific location on the cochlea’s basilar membrane depending on the sound frequency. High-frequency sounds stimulate hair cells at the base of the cochlea, which has a thin and rigid basilar membrane. In contrast, low-frequency sounds stimulate hair cells at the apex of the cochlea near an area called the helicotrema, which has a wide and flexible basilar membrane.  

Option Analysis

❌ Apex of cochlea  :
Incorrect: Low-frequency sounds stimulate hair cells in the cochlear apex near an area called the helicotrema.  
✅ Base of cochlea  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Auditory canal  :
Incorrect: The auditory canal and tympanic membrane transfer sound waves to the inner ear. In the inner ear, the cochlea then converts the sound waves into nerve signals.  
❌ Middle ear ossicles  :
Incorrect: The ossicles conduct sound waves as they travel from the tympanic membrane to the inner ear. However, in age-related hearing loss, the underlying pathophysiology is damage to hair cells within the cochlea.  
❌ Tympanic membrane  :
Incorrect: The tympanic membrane transfers sound from the external ear to the middle ear. However, in age-related hearing loss, the underlying pathophysiology is damage to hair cells within the cochlea.

questions.text:
A 71-year-old man presents to the emergency department with sudden-onset, painless vision loss of the left eye. He describes his left visual field suddenly appearing “black.” Past medical history is significant for type II diabetes mellitus and a transient ischemic attack. The patient has a 40 pack-year smoking history. Temperature is 36.7°C (98.0°F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 154/94 mmHg. Auscultation demonstrates a left-sided neck bruit. Cranial nerves III-XII are intact. The patient cannot see out of the left eye but has 20/20 vision in the right eye. The remainder of the exam, including strength, sensation, and gait, is unremarkable. Fundoscopy is performed as seen below.  


Reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

CT angiography of the head and neck is pending. This patient most likely has occlusion of which of the following vessels?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with sudden-onset, painless monocular vision loss, a carotid bruit, and a cherry-red spot on the macula, suggestive of central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO).  

CRAO typically presents painless, monocular vision loss and a pale retina with a cherry-red spot on fundoscopy. These findings occur secondary to loss of perfusion of the retina, allowing for blood from the choroid to become apparent. In elderly patients, embolic events secondary to ruptured internal carotid artery atherosclerosis are the most common cause of CRAO. The retinal artery serves as a branch of the ophthalmic artery, receiving blood from the internal carotid artery. The retinal artery supplies the inner retina and the surface of the optic nerve as it travels along with the retinal nerve. Terminal branches of the central retinal artery serve as end arteries, meaning that a proximal occlusion causes ischemia resulting in complete vision loss. Distal occlusions can lead to segmental retinal ischemia and partial vision loss.  

 

Option Analysis

❌ Anterior cerebral artery:
Incorrect: The anterior cerebral artery is a branch of the circle of Willis that supplies blood to the midline portions of the frontal and superior-medial parietal lobes. Occlusion of this artery can lead to loss of sensation and strength in the contralateral lower extremity, incontinence, and transcortical motor aphasia.
❌ Posterior cerebral artery:
Incorrect: Occlusion of the posterior cerebral artery leads to ischemic injury to the ipsilateral striate cortex, producing contralateral homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing. Sudden painless total loss of vision is not observed with ischemic injury to this vessel.
✅ Central retinal artery:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Branch retinal artery:
Incorrect: Branch retinal artery occlusion presents with sudden onset of visual field defects (scotomas) in the affected eye. Fundoscopy may demonstrate grayish-white discoloration of the retinal quadrant supplied by the affected vessel (in contrast to the entire retinal whitening with cherry-red spots seen in this patient).
❌ Central retinal vein:
Incorrect: Blockage of the central or branch retinal vein may occur due to compression from nearby arterial atherosclerosis. Fundoscopy often reveals a few dot-and-blot and flame-shaped hemorrhages in all four retinal quadrants. Retinal whitening with cherry-red spots instead suggests central retinal artery occlusion.

questions.text: An examiner touches the forehead, cheeks, and chin of a patient with a cotton wisp to test the sensation of light touch in these regions. Which of the following cranial nerves is tested by the examiner?
questions.solution:
Cranial nerves emerge directly from the brain, including the brainstem. There are twelve pairs of cranial nerves that relay information between the brain and parts of the body. The trigeminal nerve (CN V) and its three main branches, the ophthalmic (V1), maxillary (V2), and mandibular (V3) nerves, provide sensation to the skin of the face and also control the muscles of mastication. The cranial nerves and their functions are summarized below:  



Option Analysis

✅ Trigeminal nerve:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Abducens nerve  :
Incorrect: The abducens nerve innervates the lateral rectus muscle, which is responsible for outward gaze of the eyes.  
❌ Facial nerve  :
Incorrect: The facial nerve controls facial movement, taste from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue, lacrimation, salivation (submandibular and sublingual glands are innervated by CN VII), eye closing (orbicularis oculi), and auditory volume modulation (stapedius).  
❌ Vagus nerve  :
Incorrect: The vagus nerve is responsible for taste from the supraglottic region, swallowing, soft palate elevation, midline uvula, talking, cough reflex, parasympathetics to thoracoabdominal viscera, and monitoring of the aortic arch chemoreceptors and baroreceptors.  
❌ Accessory nerve  :
Incorrect: The accessory nerve supplies the sternocleidomastoid and trapezius muscles. The sternocleidomastoid muscle tilts and rotates the head. The trapezius muscle, which connects to the scapula, acts to shrug the shoulder.

questions.text:
A 46-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician to evaluate left-sided shoulder pain and weakness for two weeks. The patient had a recent axillary lymph node dissection for breast cancer surveillance. Vital signs are within normal limits. The patient has normal sensation in the upper extremities on physical exam with 5/5 strength bilaterally. When asked to cross her arms, a notable physical examination finding is demonstrated in the image below. Which of the following anatomic structures is responsible for this patient’s symptoms?  


Image credit: wikipedia
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation with shoulder pain and weakness following an axillary lymph node dissection is highly suggestive of injury to the long thoracic nerve. The long thoracic nerve arises from the anterior rami of C5, C6, and C7 and directly innervates the serratus anterior muscle. The serratus anterior muscle functions primarily to protract the scapula (a motion used by boxers when throwing a punch, which is why the serratus anterior is also known as the boxer’s muscle). Without the ability to protract the scapula, the affected scapula protrudes, resulting in a “winged scapula.”

Other surgical procedures that damage the long thoracic nerve include radical mastectomy, thoracic sympathectomy, transaxillary thoracotomy, misplaced intercostal drains, and video-assisted thoracotomy  (VAT) port insertion. Management of long thoracic nerve injury includes physiotherapy and surgery.  

Option Analysis

✅ Serratus anterior  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Brachial plexus  :
Incorrect: Injuries to the brachial plexus often occur due to hyperabduction of the arm or neck as a result of trauma or childbirth. The long thoracic nerve is typically unaffected by these injuries.  
❌ Trapezius  :
Incorrect: The trapezius elevates the shoulders. This patient has evidence of a winged scapula–likely due to a laceration of the long thoracic nerve and subsequent dysfunction of the serratus anterior.  
❌ Radial nerve  :
Incorrect: Radial nerve compression, or “Saturday night palsy,” results in decreased sensation on the dorsoradial aspect of the hand and wrist, along with wrist drop on physical examination.  
❌ C7 nerve root  :
Incorrect: An isolated injury to the C7 nerve root is rare and low-yield for examination purposes. On rare occasions, injury to the C7 nerve root is associated with Erb palsy.

questions.text: A human cadaveric model is being studied to understand better the anatomic distribution and innervation in the upper extremity, chest, and back. A branch of the brachial plexus is stimulated with electrical impulses, which captures this impulse over the lateral aspect of the forearm. Which of the following nerves is being stimulated in the previous experiment?
questions.solution:
Five major nerves arise from the brachial plexus, including the musculocutaneous nerve,  radial nerve, ulnar nerve, median nerve, and axillary nerve. Understanding brachial plexus nerves' anatomic distribution and motor function can predict both sensory and motor neurologic deficits associated with nerve injury. The nerves of the brachial plexus are outlined in the table below.  



Option Analysis

✅ Musculocutaneous nerve  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Ulnar nerve  :
Incorrect: The ulnar nerve innervates the medial aspect of the hand, including half of digit four and all of digit five.  
❌ Radial nerve  :
Incorrect: The radial nerve innervates skin over the posteromedial aspect of the upper arm, forearm, and lateral aspect of the dorsum of the hand.  
❌ Median nerve:
Incorrect: The median nerve innervates skin over the anterolateral surface of the hand.  
❌ Axillary nerve:
Incorrect: The axillary nerve innervates skin overlying the deltoid, not the forearm. The axillary nerve arises from the posterior cord of the brachial plexus.

questions.text:
Several students are studying the peripheral nervous system in a cadaver. One nerve is identified to originate from the anterior rami of L2 to L4. This nerve then runs along with the psoas muscles. An image of the nerve is shown below:


Which of the following statements regarding this nerve is most accurate?

choices.text: It supplies sensory innervation to the lateral leg.
It mediates flexion of the knee.
It provides sensory innervation to the scrotum.

questions.solution:
The femoral nerve is one of the primary nerves in the lower extremity. It originates from the anterior rami of L2-L4 and descends in the posterior abdominal wall along the psoas muscle fibers. The femoral nerve then enters the thigh by passing underneath the inguinal ligament, lateral to the femoral sheath.  

The femoral nerve has both sensory and motor fibers. The sensory fibers supply most of the anterior compartment of the thigh and the medial leg (through the saphenous nerve, which is a continuation of the femoral nerve in the leg). The motor fibers supply muscles that flex the hip and extend the knee. Finally, the femoral nerve is responsible for the patellar (knee) reflex, and if injured, this reflex will decrease or disappear.  

 

Option Analysis

✅ It mediates the patellar reflex. :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ It supplies sensory innervation to the lateral leg. :
Incorrect: Sensory innervation to the lateral leg is supplied by the lateral sural cutaneous nerve, a branch of the common peroneal nerve. 
❌ It has only sensory functions. :
Incorrect: The femoral nerve has both motor and sensory functions.
❌ It mediates flexion of the knee.:
Incorrect: The femoral nerve supplies the muscles that extend (not flex) the knee. 
❌ It provides sensory innervation to the scrotum.:
Incorrect: The scrotum is innervated by the ilioinguinal, genitofemoral, and pudendal nerves. In contrast, the femoral nerve does not provide sensory innervation to the scrotum.

questions.text: A segment of lung tissue is examined. On the gross examination, the hilum of the lung is identified. Which of the following is true regarding the structures contained in the hilum of the lungs?

choices.text: The left pulmonary artery is located anterior to the left main bronchus.
The right pulmonary artery is located superior to the right main bronchus.
The right pulmonary artery is located anterior to the right main bronchus.
The most inferior structure in the hilum of both lungs is the main bronchus.
The azygos vein passes through the hilum of the lung.

questions.solution:
The hilum of the lung is the site where blood vessels, bronchi, nerves, and lymphatics (collectively termed lung roots) enter into the lungs. The pulmonary hilum is located on the medial side of both lungs.  

The arrangement of structures in the pulmonary roots passing through the hilum can vary depending on which lung is examined. The difference between the hilum of the left and right lung is the location of the pulmonary artery in relation to the main bronchus. The pulmonary artery is anterior to the main bronchus in the right lung hilum. In contrast, the pulmonary artery is superior to the main bronchus in the left lung hilum. In both hila, the inferior pulmonary vein is the most inferior structure.  



Option Analysis

❌ The left pulmonary artery is located anterior to the left main bronchus. :
Incorrect: In the left lung hilum, the left pulmonary artery is superior to the left main bronchus, not anterior.  
❌ The right pulmonary artery is located superior to the right main bronchus.:
Incorrect: The right pulmonary artery is anterior to the right main bronchus in the right lung hilum.  
✅ The right pulmonary artery is located anterior to the right main bronchus. :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ The most inferior structure in the hilum of both lungs is the main bronchus.:
Incorrect: The inferior pulmonary vein is the most inferior structure in the hilum of both lungs.  
❌ The azygos vein passes through the hilum of the lung.:
Incorrect: The azygos vein does not pass through the hilum of the lungs.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician for evaluation of nasal congestion. His parent reports the patient has had nasal congestion and an evening cough for two weeks. The patient’s three-year-old brother had similar symptoms that have since resolved. The patient was improving, but four days ago, he developed worsening nasal discharge and fever to 39.2°C (102.6°F). His parent has not noticed a change in appetite. The patient has not had a sore throat, ear pain, or headache. He is otherwise healthy. Current temperature is 39.0°C (102.2°F), pulse is 128/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 96/71 mm Hg. The physical exam is notable for edematous and erythematous nasal turbinates, and purulent mucus is visualized in the posterior nasopharynx. The pediatrician suspects acute bacterial sinusitis. This infection most likely spread to which of the following anatomic spaces?
questions.solution:
The nasal cavity has numerous connections to its surrounding spaces. It is important to remember the relationship between the nasal cavity and its surrounding structures because nasal congestion can cause inflammation and swelling of the mucosa close to the openings of these spaces. When the surrounding spaces are unable to drain properly, infection can develop and spread.

In particular, the maxillary sinuses are the most common site to which an infection in the nasal cavity might spread. The openings (or ostia) to the maxillary sinuses are small and can be easily obstructed when the surrounding nasal mucosa becomes congested. Also, because of the orientation of the maxillary sinuses in the skull, it is difficult for them to drain properly when the head is upright or lying on one side; the ostia are directed towards one another, so when lying on the side, only the top sinus can actually drain.  



Option Analysis

❌ Frontal sinus  :
Incorrect: The frontal sinus is located in the frontal bone and opens into the anterior part of the middle meatus via the frontonasal duct. While it is possible for an infection to reach the frontal sinuses, the maxillary sinuses are a more common site of spread from a nasal cavity infection.  
❌ Anterior ethmoidal cells:
Incorrect: Anterior ethmoidal cells drain directly or indirectly into the middle nasal meatus through the ethmoidal infundibulum. The anterior ethmoidal cells are not a common site of spread from a nasal cavity infection.  
❌ Middle ethmoidal cells  :
Incorrect: The middle ethmoidal cells open directly into the middle meatus and are called “bullar cells”  because they form the ethmoidal bulla–a swelling over the superior border of the semilunar hiatus. The middle ethmoidal cells are not a common site of spread from a nasal cavity infection.  
❌ Sphenoidal sinus  :
Incorrect: The sphenoid sinus lies inferior to the sella turcica and communicates with the nasal cavity via the sphenoethmoidal recess. It is an uncommon site of sinus infection.
✅ Maxillary sinus  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man is brought to the clinic for evaluation of abnormal eating behavior. For the past few weeks, the patient has been eating more and more. This week, the patient ate five to six meals a day and has gained 17 kg in the past two months. The patient had a craniopharyngioma surgically resected three months ago. Vitals are within normal limits. BMI is now 34 kg/m2. Physical examination is unremarkable. Serum thyroid-stimulating hormone, growth hormone, prolactin, and cortisol levels are normal. Damage to which of the following areas of the brain is the most likely cause of this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with new onset hyperphagia after a recent intracranial surgery for the resection of a craniopharyngioma. Based on these findings, the patient has most likely suffered damage to the ventromedial nucleus of the hypothalamus.  

The hypothalamus is located between the optic chiasma and the mammillary bodies and serves as the site of regulation for temperature, hunger, satiety, endocrine functions, circadian rhythm, emotion, behavior, and sexual drive. Damage to the hypothalamus occurs from tumors such as a craniopharyngiomas, radiotherapy, traumatic brain injury, infiltrative disorders,  inflammatory diseases, and surgery.  

The ventromedial nucleus of the hypothalamus regulates blood glucose. Stimulation of the ventromedial nucleus by the hormone leptin, a product of adipose tissue, induces satiety. When the ventromedial nucleus is damaged, hyperphagia from an uncontrolled voracious appetite and hypothalamic obesity result.  



Option Analysis

❌ Lateral nucleus of the hypothalamus:
Incorrect: The lateral nucleus of the hypothalamus responds to ghrelin, which is produced by the stomach to initiate hunger and increase appetite. Injury sustained to the lateral nucleus can cause loss of appetite, anorexia, and subsequent starvation. This patient has the opposite clinical presentation.
❌ Posterior hypothalamus:
Incorrect: The posterior hypothalamus increases body temperature and is activated by sympathetic input. A lesion in this region will result in poikilothermia.
❌ Suprachiasmatic nucleus of the hypothalamus:
Incorrect: The suprachiasmatic nucleus receives input from photosensitive cells in the retina and transmits this information to the pineal gland and other hypothalamic nuclei to regulate circadian rhythm.
❌ Paraventricular nucleus of the hypothalamus:
Incorrect: The paraventricular nucleus produces oxytocin, which is transported to nerve terminals in the posterior pituitary and stored for eventual release. Oxytocin promotes milk ejection and uterine contraction in females.
✅ Ventromedial nucleus of the hypothalamus:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A 57-year-old man presents to the emergency department after being found down outside a bar. Emergency medical services were called to the scene after several bystanders saw the person lying in the street. The patient is poorly responsive and unable to provide a history. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 24/min, blood pressure is 130/80 mmHg, and O2 saturation is 93% on room air. The patient’s speech is slurred, and he responds only to pain. Physical examination reveals scattered abrasions over the arms and legs and a 1 cm laceration over the right occiput. The patient is further noted to have swelling of the right hand. A radiograph of the right hand is obtained and shown below. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of injury associated with this injury?  


Image reproduced from Radiopedia

choices.text: Force applied to a clenched fist
Direct force to the fifth digit held in extension
Sudden hyperextension of the fifth digit held in flexion
Lateral force applied to the fifth digit

questions.solution:
This patient presents after being found down with right-hand swelling, scattered abrasions, and a head laceration. Given these findings, he was likely involved in a physical altercation. Imaging demonstrates a fracture of the distal end of the fifth metacarpal, which is consistent with a boxer fracture. The most common mechanism of action leading to this injury pattern is a direct force applied to a clenched fist.  

Boxer fractures are common and represent approximately 10% of all hand fractures. It is most commonly seen amongst boxers (hence the name), individuals involved in physical altercations, and athletes participating in contact sports (e.g., football, rugby). The most common mechanism of injury for this fracture involves axial pressure applied to the metacarpal bone when the fist is in a clenched position.

Clinically, patients with boxer fractures will often experience dorsal hand pain, swelling, and possible deformity over the fifth knuckle. Treatment is generally conservative and involves analgesia with closed reduction and placement in an ulnar gutter splint. Surgical referral is indicated for severe deformity or a high degree of displacement and angulation.

Option Analysis

✅ Force applied to a clenched fist  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Fall on an outstretched hand  :
Incorrect: Fall on an outstretched hand (FOOSH) represents the major mechanism of injury for many wrist pathologies, including scaphoid and distal radius fractures. However, this patient has a characteristic fracture of the fifth metacarpal, which is suggestive of a boxer fracture, most commonly caused by a direct force applied to a clenched fist.  
❌ Direct force to the fifth digit held in extension  :
Incorrect: A direct force to the fifth digit held in extension would result in a Mallet finger caused by rupture of the extensor tendon where it attaches to the distal phalanx. In contrast, this patient’s imaging shows a fracture of the fifth metacarpal bone.  
❌ Sudden hyperextension of the fifth digit held in flexion  :
Incorrect: This is the mechanism of action attributed to the Jersey finger, injuring the flexor digitorum profundus tendon as it crosses the distal interphalangeal joint. In contrast, this patient’s imaging shows a fracture of the fifth metacarpal bone.  
❌ Lateral force applied to the fifth digit  :
Incorrect: A lateral force applied to the fifth digit would likely result in a dislocation injury rather than a fracture.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman comes to the physician to evaluate dysphagia in solids and liquids. The symptoms started six months ago and have gradually worsened. She also has noticed weakness in the right shoulder for a similar period. The patient does not smoke and has no chronic conditions. Physical examination of the head and neck reveals a decreased left gag reflex, uvular deviation to the right, and atrophy of the left trapezius muscle. A head MRI is obtained, and a mass is detected. Which of the following is the most likely location of the mass?
questions.solution:
Jugular foramen syndrome is the constellation of symptoms resulting from compression of the cranial nerves emerging from the jugular foramen at the skull base.

The jugular foramen is an opening on the inferior surface of the skull between the petrous temporal bone and occipital bone. The sigmoid sinus and cranial nerves IX, X, and XI course through the jugular fossa to exit from the inferior aspect of the skull.



The glossopharyngeal nerve carries motor, sensory, and parasympathetic fibers. It aids in swallowing by supplying motor innervation to the stylopharyngeus muscle. It also carries taste and normal sensation from the posterior third of the tongue. The vagus nerve assists in palatal elevation, speech phonation, blood pressure, and heart rate regulation. The accessory nerve is a pure motor nerve that innervates the sternocleidomastoid and trapezius muscles.  

A mass extending into the jugular foramen (e.g., glomus jugulare paraganglioma, schwannoma, meningioma) can compress cranial nerves IX, X, and XI. Jugular foramen syndrome can also develop due to non-neoplastic etiologies, including penetrating trauma, congenital conditions (e.g. primary cholesteatoma), and vascular abnormalities (e.g. internal jugular vein thrombosis).  

The clinical presentation of jugular foramen syndrome involves loss of taste from the posterior one-third of the tongue (IX), vocal cord paralysis (X), and an absent gag reflex (IX, X). In addition, patients may have weakness and atrophy of the trapezius and sternocleidomastoid muscles (XI). Due to its location within the petrous temporal bone, pathologies affecting the jugular foramen can also cause conductive hearing loss and pulsatile tinnitus. If there is a significant intracranial extension of the tumor, symptoms of elevated intracranial pressure may develop.  

Option Analysis

✅ Left jugular foramen:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Left internal auditory meatus:
Incorrect: Cranial nerves VII and VIII pass through the internal auditory meatus. A mass in this location would cause compression of these nerves, resulting in facial paralysis and hearing loss symptoms. In contrast, this patient’s presentation is due to compression of the cranial nerves IX, X, and XI.     
❌ Left hypoglossal canal:
Incorrect: The hypoglossal nerve (CN XII) exits the skull through the hypoglossal canal, and compression of this nerve can cause tongue paralysis. However, this patient’s presentation is more likely due to jugular foramen syndrome, wherein cranial nerves IX, X, and XI are compressed as they pass through the jugular foramen.
❌ Left foramen spinosum:
Incorrect: The foramen spinosum contains the middle meningeal artery, middle meningeal vein, and meningeal branch of the mandibular foramen. Compression of these structures would not account for the symptoms experienced by this patient.
❌ Foramen magnum:
Incorrect: This patient’s presentation suggests compression of cranial nerves IX, X, and XI, likely at the jugular foramen. A mass in the foramen magnum would not cause compression of these cranial nerves.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman is evaluated for voice changes after thyroid surgery. The patient was diagnosed with papillary thyroid cancer and subsequently underwent thyroidectomy. Immediately after the surgery, she noticed some mild voice changes, but the doctor informed her that this is usually transient due to local edema and will likely self-resolve. Currently, the patient describes only mild voice and pitch changes but denies any dysphagia. On physical examination, sensation of the mucosa above the glottis is intact. After evaluation, the doctor suspects an isolated unilateral paralysis of the cricothyroid muscle. Which of the following nerves demonstrated in the picture below was most likely injured during the surgery?
questions.solution:
This patient has mild voice changes without dysphagia following thyroidectomy, which raises concern for iatrogenic nerve injury caused by surgery. Complications during thyroid surgery are common and may include hematoma/wound seroma, hypocalcemia due to hypoparathyroidism, hoarseness, voice changes, vocal cord paralysis, Horner syndrome, chyle fistula, tracheal and esophageal injuries, and dysphagia.  

The laryngeal nerves are at risk for injury during thyroid surgery. The vagus nerve gives rise to a branch named the superior laryngeal nerve (SLN) about 4 cm above the carotid bifurcation. The SLN then divides into the internal laryngeal nerve and external laryngeal nerve. The internal branch supplies sensory innervation to the supraglottic region, whereas the external branch carries motor innervation to the cricothyroid muscle. Damage to the external branch may occur during ligation of the superior thyroid artery. External laryngeal nerve injury impairs the cricothyroid muscle, which is responsible for abduction and opening of the rima glottis by rotating the arytenoid cartilage laterally. Patients may experience vocal fatigue and subtle voice changes.  

After branching into the SLN, the vagus nerves continue caudally and give rise to the recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN). The RLN innervates all intrinsic muscles of the larynx except the cricothyroid as well as sensation below the vocal cord. These muscles function to adduct the vocal cords and close the rima glottis. RLN injury can occur during ligation of the inferior thyroid artery. Since the RLN innervates the majority of the intrinsic laryngeal muscles, its damage results in more severe symptoms. These include respiratory obstruction, hoarseness, inability to speak, and loss of sensation below the vocal cord.  



Option Analysis

❌ A:
Incorrect: This is the superior laryngeal nerve which splits into the internal and external laryngeal nerves. Injury in this location will result in both unilateral paralysis of the cricothyroid muscle (external laryngeal nerve) and sensation deficit (internal laryngeal nerve) above the vocal cord. The patient has intact sensation.
❌ B:
Incorrect: This is the internal laryngeal nerve, a branch of the superior laryngeal nerve. Injury in that location will result in a sensory deficit above the vocal cord. The patient has intact sensation.
✅ C:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ D:
Incorrect: This is the recurrent laryngeal nerve, a branch of the vagus nerve. Injury in this location will result in severe hoarseness and dysphagia due to paralysis of the posterior cricoarytenoid, lateral cricoarytenoid, oblique arytenoid, transverse arytenoid, and thyroarytenoid muscles. This patient has only mild symptoms, which favors another diagnosis.

questions.text:
A 58-year-old man comes to the emergency department due to worsening occipital headache, difficulty walking, and blurred vision for the past two months. The patient reports associated nausea and vomiting. Past medical history is significant for hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include metformin and lisinopril. Temperature is 36.7°C (98.2°F), pulse is 40/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 140/70 mmHg. Neurologic examination demonstrates bilateral papilledema and neck stiffness. A non-contrast CT-brain is demonstrated below.  


Reproduced from Radiopedia
While awaiting reassessment in the emergency department, the patient suddenly decompensates and dies. A post-mortem autopsy reveals brain herniation as the cause of death. Which of the following mechanisms of herniation most likely lead to this patient’s decompensation?
questions.solution:
A tonsillar herniation is characterized by descent of the cerebellar tonsils through the foramen magnum, which compresses the medulla against the clivus/odontoid process. When the cerebellar tonsils herniate, they can compress the brainstem respiratory and cardiac centers, leading to coma and death. This type of herniation is often described as "coning,”  as the brain tissue coming down through the foramen is squeezed into a cone. Common causes of this herniation include tumors or bleeding in the posterior cranial fossa.  

Option Analysis

❌ Cingulate herniation  :
Incorrect: Cingulate (or subfalcine) herniation is the most common type of cerebral herniation and is characterized by displacement of the cingulate gyrus beneath the free edge of the falx cerebri due to elevated intracranial pressure. This patient has evidence of a posterior fossa mass and tonsillar herniation.  
❌ Transtentorial herniation  :
Incorrect: Transtentorial (or central) herniation is a type of cerebral herniation that results in the caudal displacement of the brainstem, rupture of the paramedian basilar artery branches and Duret hemorrhages.  
❌ Uncal herniation  :
Incorrect: Uncal herniation is a subtype of the herniation that results in compression of the innermost portion of the temporal lobe (the uncus) and direct compression of the oculomotor nerve.  
✅ Tonsillar herniation  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Transcalvarial herniation  :
Incorrect: In transcalvarial herniation, the brain herniates through a fracture or a surgical site in the skull. This type of herniation may occur during craniectomy.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old man presents to the emergency department with acute left shoulder pain. The patient was lowering himself from a pullup at the gym when he suddenly felt a “pop” followed by acute pain in the anterior left shoulder.
