The patient has a history of left supraspinatus tendinopathy that was treated with physical therapy. The patient is otherwise healthy and does not take any medications. Physical examination reveals ecchymosis, swelling, and tenderness over the anterior left deltoid. The patient's arm is pronated and flexed at the elbow to 90 degrees. The examiner attempts to supinate the arm against resistance, which elicits shoulder pain. A radiograph of the shoulder is demonstrated below:  


Image reproduced from Radiopedia  
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Rupture of the long-head of the biceps brachii
Rupture of the short-head of the biceps brachii

questions.solution:
This patient presents with anterior shoulder pain after a load is applied during eccentric contraction of the biceps brachii. Physical examination demonstrates a positive Yergason test. In combination, these findings are consistent with tendinopathy of the long-head of the biceps brachii.

Tear or rupture of the long-head of the biceps brachii is associated with an eccentric force applied to a contracted biceps tendon. Patients often recall a “snap” or “pop” followed by ecchymosis, swelling, and pain immediately after the inciting mechanism of injury. Additionally, patients will often have a bulbous mass in the upper arm due to excessive retraction of the biceps muscle belly. This finding is known as a "Popeye deformity."

Specific examination findings may include a positive Yergason test, wherein pain is reproduced at the anterior shoulder when the patient attempts to supinate the arm against resistance after the examiner places the patient's arm in pronation and 90 degree flexion at the elbow. In addition, an exam maneuver known as the Speed test may also yield a positive test. In this exam, the patient's arm is extended in full supination with the shoulder flexed, and the patient is asked to elevate the arm against a resistive force; a positive test will produce the pain.  

Option Analysis

✅ Rupture of the long-head of the biceps brachii  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Supraspinatus tear  :
Incorrect: While this patient has a history of rotator cuff injury, physical examination demonstrates a positive Yergason test. This physical examination maneuver has a high specificity for biceps injury. In contrast, a supraspinatus injury would demonstrate a positive empty can test.  
❌ Subacromial bursitis  :
Incorrect: Subacromial bursitis falls into the category of rotator cuff impingement injuries and presents with chronic shoulder pain. Patients with subacromial bursitis will demonstrate limited active range of motion but preserved passive range of motion.  
❌ Acromioclavicular joint separation  :
Incorrect: Acromioclavicular joint separation most commonly occurs due to a direct force to the lateral aspect of the shoulder while the arm is held in adduction. Clinical features include swelling and pain over the lateral aspect of the shoulder. Radiography will show widening of the acromioclavicular joint.  
❌ Rupture of the short-head of the biceps brachii  :
Incorrect: Rupture of the short-head of the biceps brachii is less common than rupture of the long-head of the biceps brachii. A common mechanism of injury involves sudden forceful extension of the person's flexed elbow when the biceps muscle is fully contracted. Physical examination findings will demonstrate swelling of the antecubital fossa and a positive hook test.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents to the emergency department to evaluate right lower quadrant abdominal pain. The pain is sharp, stabbing, and has progressively worsened. He has also had decreased oral intake and an episode of vomiting that has since resolved. Past medical and surgical history is unremarkable. Temperature is 37.4°C (99.4°F), blood pressure is 107/67 mmHg, and pulse is 106/min. The examiner passively extends the patient’s right leg with the patient lying on his left side. This maneuver reproduces pain in the right lower quadrant. Which of the following best describes the physical examination finding present in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with clinical features of acute appendicitis, including right lower quadrant pain, anorexia, and associated vomiting. Additionally, the pain is reproduced with passive extension of the right hip, consistent with a positive iliopsoas sign (also termed the Thomas test).

The iliopsoas muscle originates on the outer vertebral bodies of T12 and L1-L3. The muscle inserts on the lesser trochanter of the femur. This muscle is largely responsible for hip flexion and thus is important for standing, walking, and running. Passive extension of the hip places strain on the iliopsoas and any nearby structures or anatomically associated pathology.

Common etiologies associated with a positive iliopsoas sign include acute appendicitis, sigmoid colitis, or lymphadenopathy. Rarely, a positive iliopsoas sign may indicate a psoas abscess, which is a collection of pus in the iliopsoas compartment. When these conditions are suspected, definitive diagnosis is best achieved with a contrast-enhanced CT.  

Option Analysis

✅ Iliopsoas sign:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Murphy sign:
Incorrect: Murphy sign is performed by pressing firmly in the right upper quadrant, having the patient inspire, and then exhale slowly. A positive test indicates worsened pain with expiration and can signify underlying cholecystitis.  
❌ McBurney point tenderness  :
Incorrect: McBurney point tenderness is elicited by palpation at McBurney point, which is one-third of the distance from the anterior superior iliac spine to the umbilicus. Tenderness at this location suggests acute appendicitis.  
❌ Rovsing sign  :
Incorrect: Rovsing sign is performed by palpating the left lower quadrant. The test is positive if left lower quadrant palpation elicits pain in the right lower quadrant. A positive test can be suggestive of acute appendicitis.  
❌ Homan sign  :
Incorrect: Homan sign refers to reproducible pain with forced dorsiflexion of the foot. A positive test can be indicative of lower extremity deep vein thrombosis.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man is found to have thickening of the supraspinatus muscle on a shoulder MRI. Which of the following best describes the function of the supraspinatus muscle?
questions.solution:
The rotator cuff consists of the tendons of the supraspinatus, infraspinatus, teres minor, and subscapularis muscles. The mnemonic SITS can help in remembering these tendons. The rotator cuff contributes to the stability and motion of the glenohumeral joint.    

During abduction of the humerus, the supraspinatus initiates movement from 0-15 degrees. Subsequently, the deltoid completes abduction from 15-90 degrees. The serratus anterior and trapezius muscles then allow for the abduction of the arm above the horizontal position.  


Option Analysis

❌ Initiation of adduction:
Incorrect: Adduction of the shoulder is primarily performed by the pectoralis major. In contrast, the supraspinatus muscle is involved in the initiation of shoulder abduction. 
❌ External rotation :
Incorrect: External rotation is primarily performed by the infraspinatus and teres minor. In contrast, the supraspinatus muscle is involved in the initiation of shoulder abduction. 
✅ Initiation of abduction:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Completion of abduction:
Incorrect: The deltoid primarily performs abduction (above 15 degrees). In contrast, initiation of shoulder abduction (from 0-15 degrees) is performed by the supraspinatus muscle. 
❌ Internal rotation:
Incorrect: Internal rotation is primarily performed by the subscapularis. In contrast, the supraspinatus muscle is involved in the initiation of shoulder abduction.

questions.text: A scientist is studying the hypothalamus and discovers that damaging a specific portion of the organ leads to abnormal sleep patterns. Specifically, she finds that the sleep cycle is no longer coordinated with the light/dark cycle of the environment and instead occurs randomly throughout the day. Which structure in the hypothalamus was most likely damaged?
questions.solution:
The hypothalamus is a major center of homeostatic regulation and is divided into multiple nuclei with distinct functions. The suprachiasmatic nucleus integrates visual signals with internal clocks to control the circadian rhythm. The lateral nucleus promotes appetite, whereas the ventromedial nucleus inhibits appetite. The anterior and posterior nuclei work together to regulate thermogenesis. The supraoptic and paraventricular nuclei function as part of the endocrine system releasing vasopressin and oxytocin. The preoptic nucleus is involved in thermoregulation and sexual behavior.  



Option Analysis

❌ Lateral nucleus:
Incorrect: The lateral nucleus is responsible for promoting appetite. Damage to this hypothalamic region would result in decreased appetite and weight loss.
❌ Paraventricular nuclei:
Incorrect: The paraventricular nuclei are involved in releasing vasopressin and oxytocin. A lesion to this region would disrupt endocrine function, specifically regarding the regulation of serum osmolality.
❌ Posterior nucleus:
Incorrect: The posterior area nucleus regulates body temperature. A lesion to this hypothalamic region would result in poikilothermia.
✅ Suprachiasmatic nucleus:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Ventromedial nucleus:
Incorrect: The ventromedial nucleus is responsible for inhibiting appetite. Damage to this hypothalamus region would result in increased appetite and weight gain.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man comes to the physician complaining of visual problems in his right eye for the last six months. The patient tells the physician that he finds it difficult to see with his right eye because the eyelid is covering part of his vision. He is also experiencing double vision. Past medical history is significant for hypertension and coronary artery disease. On physical examination, the right eye is pointing down and out, and the right pupil is 9 mm. The right eyelid is drooping. Visual field examination is unremarkable except for diplopia. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with a “down and out” right eye and associated ptosis, mydriasis, and diplopia; he most likely has an oculomotor nerve (CN III) palsy.

CN III has parasympathetic and somatic components. The former component supplies the ciliary muscles, which alter the shape of the lens to allow better focus on near objects, and the sphincter pupillae muscle, which constricts the pupil (miosis). Meanwhile, the inner somatic fibers provide nerve supply to the levator palpebrae superioris, which elevates the eyelid, and four of the extraocular muscles (superior, middle, inferior recti, and inferior oblique). These muscles are responsible for adjusting the gaze superiorly, medially, and inferiorly.  A helpful way to remember the anatomy of the parasympathetic and somatic fibers in CN III is the alliteration that the Parasympathetic fibers are Peripheral.

Clinical findings of CN III palsy depend on the components that are affected by the pathology. Loss of parasympathetic function leads to mydriasis and inability to accommodate to near objects, while loss of somatic function causes ptosis and deviation of the eye down and out (due to unopposed action of the superior oblique and lateral rectus muscles, which are innervated by CNs IV and VI, respectively).

Isolated CN III palsy is most commonly due to ischemia or compression. Ischemia is mostly caused by hypertension or diabetes mellitus and preferentially affects somatic fibers. Meanwhile, compression of CN III (e.g., by posterior communicating artery aneurysm, tentorial herniation) can lead to parasympathetic loss of function. However, it is not uncommon to see involvement of both the components.



Other possible causes of CN III palsy include injury to the CN III nucleus in the brainstem (e.g. demyelination), supranuclear injuries (e.g. injuries in the cerebral cortex), or injury in the cavernous sinus, where the CN III passes (along with other nerves and vascular structures). 

Option Analysis

✅ CN III (oculomotor) palsy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ CN IV (trochlear) palsy :
Incorrect: Patients with CN IV (trochlear) palsy present with vertical diplopia that worsens when reading or going downstairs. CN IV palsy is not associated with ptosis or mydriasis.
❌ CN VI (abducens) palsy:
Incorrect: CN VI palsy is not associated with ptosis or mydriasis, and in CN VI palsy, the eye is deviated medially. 
❌ Horner syndrome :
Incorrect: Although Horner syndrome does present with ptosis, it is associated with miosis, not mydriasis. Also, diplopia is not expected in Horner syndrome. 
❌ CN VII (facial) palsy :
Incorrect: Facial nerve palsy is associated with loss of motor function in the muscles of the face. The facial nerve does not provide parasympathetic innervation to the eye (mydriasis), nor does it innervate the extraocular muscles.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man presents to the office because of pain and bulging in his groin. The patient reports that standing exacerbates the pain. The patient is otherwise healthy and has never had surgery. He does not take any medications. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a bulge in the groin that is erythematous and painful to palpation. Scrotal examination is within normal limits. After further evaluation, the patient is diagnosed with a femoral hernia and is scheduled for an endoscopic repair under spinal anesthesia. Which of the following structures is at risk of injury in this patient during the repair?
questions.solution:
This patient with pain and bulging in the groin is found to have a femoral hernia. During femoral hernia repair, sometimes an artery called the aberrant, or accessory, obturator artery can be injured. Typically, the obturator artery branches from the internal iliac artery. In up to 20% of people, however, there can be an additional branch coming from either the inferior epigastric artery or external iliac artery that either replaces the obturator artery or joins it; this phenomenon is called an aberrant or accessory obturator artery. In these patients, the artery runs in close proximity to the femoral ring and courses along the superior pubic rami; so, during hernia repair, it can be injured or stapled.  

When injury occurs, the artery retracts, making it exceedingly difficult to locate and ligate, resulting in uncontrolled bleeding. This artery has been referred to as corona mortis, which means “crown of death,” as injury to it can be fatal.  

 

Option Analysis

❌ Ilioinguinal nerve:
Incorrect: The ilioinguinal, iliohypogastric, and genitofemoral nerves are at risk of injury during inguinal hernia repair, which can lead to chronic residual neuralgia and postoperative constrictive scar tissue in the surgical area. However, this patient is undergoing repair for a femoral hernia, which poses risk to a different key structure.
❌ Iliohypogastric nerve:
Incorrect: The ilioinguinal, iliohypogastric, and genitofemoral nerves are at risk of injury during inguinal hernia repair, which can lead to chronic residual neuralgia and postoperative constrictive scar tissue in the surgical area. However, this patient is undergoing repair for a femoral hernia, which poses risk to a different key structure.
❌ Genitofemoral nerve:
Incorrect: The ilioinguinal, iliohypogastric, and genitofemoral nerves are at risk of injury during inguinal hernia repair, which can lead to chronic residual neuralgia and postoperative constrictive scar tissue in the surgical area. However, this patient is undergoing repair for a femoral hernia, which poses risk to a different key structure.
✅ Aberrant obturator artery:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Pudendal nerve:
Incorrect: The pudendal nerve is at risk of injury during sacrospinous ligament fixation or pelvic reconstructive procedures, during which sutures are placed in the arcus tendineus fasciae pelvis. However, this patient is undergoing repair for a femoral hernia, which poses risk to a different key structure.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man comes to the office of his maxillofacial surgeon for follow-up after having dental implant surgery on the lower molars. The patient has inadvertently bitten his inner cheek several times since the surgery due to reduced sensation around the gingiva. The patient also endorses persistent pain in the lower molars, gingiva, chin, and lower lip. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates diminished sensation over the lower teeth and chin. Oral examination shows well-appearing dental implants with superficial lacerations over the bilateral inner cheeks. Which of the following nerves is most likely injured given this patient’s presentation?

choices.text: Incisive branch of the nasopalatine nerve

questions.solution:
The inferior alveolar nerve courses into the mandibular canal and provides sensation to the roots of the lower teeth. This nerve exits the skull through the mental foramen as the mental nerve and provides sensation to the lower lip and the skin of the chin. Before entering the mandible, the inferior alveolar nerve gives off a motor branch to the mylohyoid muscle, innervating the mylohyoid and anterior belly of the digastric muscles.

Because of its close relation to the teeth, the inferior alveolar nerve is the most commonly injured nerve during oral surgery. It can be injured during third molar extraction, dental implant surgery, or tumor removal. Injury symptoms include paresthesias, complete numbness, or pain in the teeth, gingiva, chin, and lower lip.  



Option Analysis

❌ Buccal nerve  :
Incorrect: The buccal nerve courses into the cheek and pierces the buccinator muscle. This nerve carries sensation from the skin over the cheek and the inner mucous membrane. This patient more likely has an injury to the inferior alveolar nerve.  
❌ Lingual Nerve  :
Incorrect: The lingual nerve courses into the tongue and carries sensation from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. This patient more likely has an injury to the inferior alveolar nerve.  
✅ Inferior alveolar nerve  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Incisive branch of the nasopalatine nerve  :
Incorrect: The incisive branch of the nasopalatine nerve carries sensory information from the front of the hard palate, just behind the incisors. This patient more likely has an injury to the inferior alveolar nerve.  
❌ Lesser palatine nerve  :
Incorrect: The lesser palatine nerve carries sensation from the soft palate. This patient more likely has an injury to the inferior alveolar nerve.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man presents to his primary care physician for evaluation of new-onset hoarseness. The patient reports worsening hoarseness over several weeks without a precipitating cause. The patient has had no difficulty swallowing liquids or solids. He has a history of long-standing hypertension, mitral valve stenosis, and a twenty-pack-year smoking history. His vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates an irregular heartbeat. A screening electrocardiogram is shown below. Which of the following structures is most likely implicated in this patient’s symptomatology?  


Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
This patient with a longstanding history of hypertension and mitral valve stenosis presents with symptoms of compression of the left recurrent laryngeal nerve, likely secondary to left atrial enlargement. Left atrial enlargement often results in atrial fibrillation, as detailed on this patient’s electrocardiogram.

Left atrial enlargement can occur secondary to mitral regurgitation, left ventricular dysfunction, mitral stenosis, or volume overload. Over time, increased pressure dilates the left atrium, stretching the conduction fibers and resulting in atrial fibrillation. This enlargement can also compress nearby structures including the esophagus and left recurrent laryngeal nerve, which can manifest as dysphagia or hoarseness, respectively.  



Option Analysis

✅ Left recurrent laryngeal nerve :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Phrenic nerve :
Incorrect: The phrenic nerve is less commonly involved in cases of left atrial enlargement. Symptoms of phrenic nerve injury include exertional dyspnea, recurrent pneumonia, anxiety, insomnia, morning headache, excessive daytime somnolence, orthopnea, fatigue, or difficulty weaning from mechanical ventilation. 
❌ Esophagus:
Incorrect: The esophagus and the left recurrent laryngeal nerve may be affected in cases of left atrial enlargement. However, this patient does not have evidence of dysphagia, suggesting an absence of esophageal compression.
❌ Pulmonary vein :
Incorrect: Injury to the pulmonary vein can occur following cardiac ablation procedures, which can result in pulmonary hypertension. However, this patient has not undergone cardiac ablation, and he does not have signs of pulmonary hypertension. Hoarseness is more consistent with recurrent laryngeal nerve injury.
❌ Tricuspid valve:
Incorrect: Cardiac ablation procedures can result in direct cardiac damage, including injury to the tricuspid valve. However, this patient has not undergone a cardiac ablation, and hoarseness is more consistent with recurrent laryngeal nerve injury. Additionally, injury to the tricuspid valve would manifest with a systolic murmur, which is absent in this patient.

questions.text:
A 57-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of chest pain. The patient was walking up stairs at work when he suddenly collapsed in the stairwell. The patient describes the pain as “an elephant sitting on my chest” with associated shortness of breath. Past medical history includes hypertension, diabetes, and a twenty-pack-year smoking history. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 94/min, respirations are 22/min, blood pressure is 154/74 mmHg, and O2 saturation is 99% on room air. Initial examination demonstrates a diaphoretic male in moderate distress clutching the front of his chest. An initial electrocardiogram is demonstrated below. Which of the following cardiac vessels most likely requires revascularization?  


Reproduced from: wikipedia
questions.solution:
This patient with multiple comorbidities and cardiovascular risk factors presents with classic features of acute coronary syndrome, including exertional chest pressure not relieved with rest. His initial electrocardiogram meets the criteria for ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI), with notable elevations in the anterolateral leads of the heart with reciprocal depressions inferiorly. Given these findings, this patient most likely has occlusion of the left anterior descending coronary artery.   

Myocardial infarction is defined by irreversible necrosis of heart muscle secondary to prolonged ischemia. Clinically, this condition most commonly presents with chest pressure or pain radiating to the arm/jaw with associated dyspnea, diaphoresis, and nausea or vomiting. On electrocardiography, a STEMI can be recognized by the presence of ST-elevations in one or more contiguous leads with reciprocal depressions of corresponding leads.  

The three most commonly occluded vessels include the left anterior descending coronary artery (LAD), the right coronary artery (RCA), and the left circumflex coronary artery (LCX). These areas correspond to the anterior, inferior, and lateral anatomic regions of the heart, respectively. In most cases, the posterior descending artery branches from the right coronary artery (right dominant circulation). However, in a subset of cases, the posterior descending artery branches from the left circumflex coronary artery (left dominant circulation) or from the RCA and LCX (codominant circulation).  

 

Option Analysis

✅ Left anterior descending coronary artery:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Posterior descending coronary artery :
Incorrect: Infarction of the posterior descending coronary artery manifests with ST-depressions in V1-V3 and tall R-waves. A posterior ECG will demonstrate elevations in V7-V9, confirming the diagnosis. 
❌ Right coronary artery :
Incorrect: Infarction of the right coronary artery manifests with ST-elevations of the inferior leads and reciprocal changes in the anterior leads. 
❌ Left circumflex coronary artery:
Incorrect: Infarction of the left circumflex coronary artery manifests with ST elevations or q-waves in lead I or aVL. 
❌ Obtuse marginal artery :
Incorrect: Like infarctions of the left circumflex coronary artery, infarction of the obtuse marginal artery results in a lateral STEMI pattern on ECG–with elevations or q-waves in leads I, aVL, or V5-V6.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man is brought to a primary care clinic by his partner for evaluation of ongoing behavioral problems. The patient has a long history of aggressive behavioral outbursts and is known to be apathetic and unapologetic for his actions. Past medical history includes blunt head trauma at age 22 after being struck in the head with an iron rod. Prior to the accident, the patient was well-mannered and an excellent student; however, after the accident, he became progressively distractible, disobedient towards adults of authority, and quarrelsome. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination is unremarkable. Damage to which of the following cortical areas is the most likely precipitant of this patient’s behavioral changes?
questions.solution:
This patient exhibits abnormal behavior including aggression, distractibility, apathy, and impulsivity. These changes in behavior are reflective of damage to the prefrontal cortex.  

The prefrontal cortex is located anterior to the precentral area in the frontal lobe and includes the superior, middle, and inferior frontal gyri. It harbors both afferent and efferent pathways to and from the thalamus, hypothalamus, cerebral cortex, and the corpus striatum. The prefrontal cortex governs personality, social behavior, and executive functions, including decision making, reasoning, and emotional regulation.  

Damage to the prefrontal cortex results in disinhibition and deficits in concentration, judgment, and orientation. Early behavioral changes include socially inappropriate behavior, apathy, and compulsive behavior. Re-emergence of primitive reflexes are often observed.

Damage to the prefrontal cortex can occur secondary to trauma, cerebrovascular disease, tumors, and neurodegenerative disease (e.g. fronto-temporal dementia).  

 

Option Analysis

✅ Prefrontal cortex:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Broca’s area:
Incorrect: Broca’s area lies at the inferior frontal gyrus of the dominant hemisphere and has connections to the motor cortex – specifically to areas that control the muscles of the larynx, mouth, soft palate, and the tongue, as well as muscles of respiration. The primary function of this area includes formation, or production, of words and speech. This patient’s changes in behavior are instead reflective of damage to the prefrontal cortex.
❌ Wernicke’s area:
Incorrect: Wernicke’s area encompasses a portion of the superior temporal gyrus along with the supramarginal and angular gyri of the parietal lobe. This area of the brain is responsible for comprehending written and spoken language. This patient’s changes in behavior are instead reflective of damage to the prefrontal cortex.
❌ Frontal eye field:
Incorrect: Rostral to the premotor cortex and extending into the middle frontal gyrus is the frontal eye field, which controls voluntary eye movements. This patient’s changes in behavior are instead reflective of damage to the prefrontal cortex.
❌ Premotor cortex:
Incorrect: The premotor cortex stores and processes information regarding past activity and integrates both sensory and motor information for planning of future voluntary movements. This patient’s changes in behavior are instead reflective of damage to the prefrontal cortex.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man comes to the physician to evaluate dysphonia and dysphagia with solids and liquids. The patient’s symptoms started a month ago and have been progressively worsening. He has had difficulty drinking water and frequently experiences associated regurgitation and coughing. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals palatal deviation towards the right side and an absent gag reflex. MRI of the brain shows a mass. Which of the following structures is most likely affected by this mass?
questions.solution:
Bulbar palsy is a lower motor neuron defect that arises from injuries to the nucleus ambiguus.

The nucleus ambiguus is a group of motor neurons situated in the reticular formation of the medulla oblongata. The emerging fibers from the nucleus ambiguus give rise to cranial nerves IX, X, and XI, which travel to ipsilateral somatic muscles of the larynx, pharynx, and soft palate. These muscles are responsible for generating speech and swallowing. The glossopharyngeal nerve (IX) plays a role in swallowing by innervating the stylopharyngeus muscle. The vagus nerve innervates the palatal, pharyngeal, and laryngeal muscles. The spinal accessory nerve innervates the cranial portion of the laryngeal muscles.  

Bulbar palsy is most often caused by ischemic stroke and tumors. Other less common causes include degenerative disorders (e.g. ALS), autoimmune diseases (e.g. Guillain-Barre syndrome), and hereditary conditions (e.g. Kennedy disease).    

Clinical features arise due to isolated paralysis of the palate, pharynx, and larynx. They include dysphagia to both solids and liquids, hoarseness, aspiration of secretions, nasal regurgitation, dysphonia, dysarthria, and slurred speech. The uvula often deviates to the side contralateral to the causative lesion on examination. The gag reflex is often absent. 



In contrast, pseudobulbar palsy is an upper motor neuron defect involving cranial nerves IX, X, and XI (damage to the connections between the cortex and medulla) that presents with symptoms similar to bulbar palsy. Reflexes are normal or more prominent in pseudobulbar palsy. In addition, atrophy and fasciculations are absent. Lastly, pseudobulbar palsy is characterized by emotional lability, which is not seen in bulbar palsy.   

Option Analysis

✅ Left nucleus ambiguus:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Left cerebral cortex :
Incorrect: This patient has dysphagia, dysphonia, palatal deviation, and loss of the gag reflex. These findings are suggestive of bulbar palsy, which is a lower motor neuron lesion. In contrast, lesions in the cerebral cortex would be classified as upper motor neuron lesions.
❌ Corticobulbar tract bilaterally :
Incorrect: Pseudobulbar palsy is caused by a lesion affecting the bilateral corticobulbar tracts. However, unlike bulbar palsy, pseudobulbar palsy is not associated with an absent gag reflex. In addition, pseudobulbar palsy is associated with emotional lability, which is not noted in this patient. 
❌ Right cerebral cortex :
Incorrect: This patient has dysphagia, dysphonia, palatal deviation, and loss of the gag reflex. These findings are suggestive of bulbar palsy, which is a lower motor neuron lesion. In contrast, lesions in the cerebral cortex would be classified as upper motor neuron lesions.
❌ Right nucleus ambiguus :
Incorrect: The uvula deviates towards the contralateral side in patients with bulbar palsy. This patient has rightwards uvula deviation, which means the causative lesion is on the left side.

questions.text:
A 56-year-old man presents to his primary care physician for evaluation of difficulty swallowing. Over the past several weeks, the patient has had the sensation of “food getting stuck” as he swallows. He also has a new history of intermittent “jitteriness.” Medical history is notable for long-standing hypertension, hyperlipidemia, diabetes, and esophageal reflux. The patient’s medications include metoprolol, metformin, atorvastatin, and omeprazole. He has a history of medication non-compliance. Temperature 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 89/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 177/92 mmHg. The patient’s physical examination is unremarkable. A portion of the patient’s telemetry strip is demonstrated below. Which of the following best describes the affected anatomic site that most likely resulted in this patient’s clinical symptoms?  


Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

choices.text: Level of the left main bronchus

questions.solution:
This patient presents for dysphagia evaluation and is found to have new-onset atrial fibrillation. Although rare, atrial fibrillation and associated left atrial dilation can result in compression of the esophagus and subsequent food impaction.  

The esophagus has multiple compression sites as it courses from the oropharynx to the stomach. Superiorly, the esophagus may constrict as it enters the mediastinum, where the cricopharyngeus muscle may cause constriction. Thoracic constrictions occur where the arch of the aorta crosses the esophagus or at the levels of the left main bronchus and the left atrium. Lastly, the esophagus may constrict crossing the diaphragm.  

Pathologic insults at any anatomic site can ultimately slow the passage of solid foods and liquids. Over time, these insults can lead to esophageal stricture formation.  

Option Analysis

✅ Level of the left atrium :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Level of the cricopharyngeal muscle:
Incorrect: Food impaction and stricture formation may result at the esophageal level of the cricopharyngeus muscle. However, this patient's clinical presentation and ECG is more consistent with impaction at the level of the left atrium secondary to atrial dilation and associated compression of the esophagus. 
❌ Level of the aortic arch :
Incorrect: Aortic arch dilation from aortic dissection or aortic aneurysm may impede the esophagus at this level. However, this patient's clinical presentation and ECG is more consistent with impaction at the level of the left atrium secondary to atrial dilation and associated compression of the esophagus. 
❌ Level of the left main bronchus:
Incorrect: Impingement at the level of the left main bronchus may occur from mass effect due to associated trauma or tumor burden. However, this patient's clinical presentation and ECG is more consistent with impaction at the level of the left atrium secondary to atrial dilation and associated compression of the esophagus. 
❌ Level of the diaphragm:
Incorrect: Esophageal constriction may occur at the diaphragm level due to long-standing esophageal reflux disease and associated stricture formation. Typically, affected individuals will have evidence of untreated disease, including epigastric pain, a metallic taste in the mouth, or a history of gastritis or peptic ulcer disease. This patient's clinical presentation and ECG is more consistent with impaction at the level of the left atrium secondary to atrial dilation and associated compression of the esophagus.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man with acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) began his first cycle of chemotherapy two days ago. Today, he endorses severe nausea and vomiting. Which of the following structures is involved in the pathway responsible for this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient's nausea and vomiting are a result of stimulation of the chemoreceptor trigger zone (CTZ) located within the area postrema. This structure is found on the floor of the fourth ventricle at the caudal end of the rhomboid fossa, near the entrance of the central canal. The CTZ does not have a well-developed blood-brain barrier but rather fenestrated capillaries, allowing chemical substances to cross from the bloodstream. Thus the CTZ  can sense emetogenic substances, including chemotherapeutics, alcohol, toxins, and hormones that directly stimulate the vomiting reflex.  

Option Analysis

✅ Area postrema  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Medial geniculate nucleus  :
Incorrect: The medial geniculate nucleus is a thalamic structure that projects to the auditory cortex of the temporal lobe and is involved in processing auditory information.  
❌ Lateral geniculate nucleus  :
Incorrect: The lateral geniculate nucleus is a thalamic structure that projects to the calcarine sulcus and is involved in processing visual information.  
❌ Posterior hypothalamus  :
Incorrect: The posterior hypothalamus is responsible for the body's ability to warm itself via sympathetic output.  
❌ Ventral pons  :
Incorrect: The ventral pons contains the corticospinal tract (limb/torso movements), corticobulbar tract (face/head/neck movements), and abducens nucleus (lateral eye movements).

questions.text: A 62-year-old man presents to the emergency room with severe substernal chest pain, diaphoresis, and nausea. Imaging reveals transmural myocardial infarction in the posterior one-third of the interventricular septum. The infarcted region is normally supplied by which of the following arteries?
questions.solution:
The posterior one-third of the interventricular septum is supplied by the posterior descending artery (PDA), which most commonly branches off from the right coronary artery (RCA).

The network of blood vessels supplying the heart itself is termed the coronary circulation. The different arteries in the coronary circulation and the regions supplied by each are summarized below:  




Option Analysis

❌ Left circumflex artery  :
Incorrect: The left circumflex artery usually supplies the lateral and posterior walls of the left ventricle.  
❌ Left anterior descending artery  :
Incorrect: The left anterior descending artery normally supplies the anterior two-thirds of the interventricular septum (septal branches), anterior wall of the left ventricle, and parts of the anterior papillary muscle.  
✅ Posterior descending artery  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Right marginal artery  :
Incorrect: The right marginal artery supplies the right ventricle.  
❌ Left marginal artery  :
Incorrect: The left marginal artery supplies the left ventricle.

questions.text: An investigator is studying the embryology of the gastrointestinal tract and discovers an anatomical line called the pectinate line within the anal canal. Which of the following best characterizes the region of the anal canal above the pectinate line?

choices.text: Hemorrhoids in this region are painful
Arterial supply by the superior rectal artery
Somatic innervation by the pudendal nerve
Lymphatics drain into superficial inguinal lymph nodes
Veins drain into the inferior vena cava

questions.solution:
The anal canal extends from the anorectal junction at the pelvic diaphragm to the anal orifice. The pectinate line, also termed dentate line, divides the anal canal into upper and lower parts. Above the pectinate line, the anal canal is supplied by the superior rectal artery and innervated by the inferior hypogastric plexus. Below the pectinate line, the anal canal is supplied by the middle and inferior rectal arteries and innervated by the inferior rectal nerves, which are branches of the pudendal nerve. The differences between the two regions are summarized below:  



Option Analysis

❌ Hemorrhoids in this region are painful  :
Incorrect: Internal hemorrhoids (in the region above the pectinate line) receive visceral innervation and are typically not painful.  
✅ Arterial supply by the superior rectal artery:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Somatic innervation by the pudendal nerve  :
Incorrect: The region above the pectinate line is innervated primarily by the inferior hypogastric plexus. In contrast, the pudendal nerve innervates the region below the pectinate line.  
❌ Lymphatics drain into superficial inguinal lymph nodes  :
Incorrect: The region of the anal canal above the pectinate line drains into the internal iliac lymph nodes.  
❌ Veins drain into the inferior vena cava  :
Incorrect: The region of the anal canal above the pectinate lines drains into the portal vein. In contrast, the region below the anal canal drains into the inferior vena cava.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents to his primary care physician because of difficulty urinating and nocturia. Digital rectal examination is performed and reveals nodular enlargement of the prostate. A biopsy is obtained and confirms adenocarcinoma of the prostate. Which of the following lymph nodes are at the greatest risk of subsequent metastasis?
questions.solution:
This patient was diagnosed with prostatic adenocarcinoma. Since lymphatic fluid from the prostate drains into the internal iliac lymph nodes, the cancer cells are most likely to metastasize there first.    

The lymphatic drainage of the reproductive system varies according to each organ. In females, the ovaries drain into the para-aortic lymph nodes, whereas the body of the uterus and cervix drain into the external iliac lymph nodes. The cervix and proximal vagina also drain into the internal iliac lymph nodes. In contrast, the distal vagina and vulva drain into the superficial inguinal lymph nodes. Finally, the clitoris drains into the deep inguinal lymph nodes.    

The testes drain into the para-aortic lymph nodes in males, while the scrotum drains into the superficial inguinal nodes. The prostate and the corpus cavernosum drain into the internal iliac lymph nodes. Finally, the glans penis drains into the deep inguinal nodes.   

Option Analysis

✅ Internal iliac nodes :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Superficial inguinal nodes :
Incorrect: Lymphatic fluid from the prostate drains into the internal iliac nodes, not the superficial inguinal nodes.  
❌ Deep inguinal nodes:
Incorrect: The deep inguinal nodes receive lymphatic fluid from the deep portions of the lower limb, distal spongy urethra, and the clitoris in females and glans penis in males. The deep inguinal nodes do not receive lymphatic fluid from the prostate. 
❌ External iliac nodes :
Incorrect: Lymphatic fluid from the prostate drains into the internal iliac nodes, not the external iliac nodes.  
❌ Para-aortic lymph nodes. :
Incorrect: The para-aortic lymph nodes receive lymphatic fluid from the testes in males and ovaries in females. In contrast, the prostate drains into the internal iliac lymph nodes.

questions.text: A 24-year-old presents to your office with a complaint of left-sided scrotal mass accompanied by dull-aching pain in the scrotal area. They first noticed a small swelling in the area two months ago, which gradually increased in size, and now their left scrotum feels heavy, especially when they stand. They state “Honestly, it feels a bit like a bag of worms.” Review of systems is otherwise unremarkable. Past medical history is noncontributory. The patient is sexually active and uses condoms consistently. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a warm, non-tender, non-fluctuant left scrotal mass that does not transilluminate. The swelling increases in size with the Valsalva maneuver and disappears on lying down. Right scrotum and penis appear normal. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with a left-sided scrotal mass that feels like a “bag of worms,” does not transilluminate, and increases in size with Valsalva; varicocele is the most likely diagnosis. Varicocele is defined as dilation of the pampiniform plexus, which is the venous drainage network of the testes.

Left-sided varicocele is more common due to drainage of the left gonadal vein into the left renal vein at a perpendicular angle. The effect is compounded by the compression of the left renal vein between the aorta and superior mesenteric artery (nutcracker effect), increasing the intravascular pressure in the left gonadal vein and the dilation of the pampiniform plexus. A right-sided varicocele should always raise suspicion for retroperitoneal pathology (e.g. renal cell carcinoma), especially if it is non-diminishing on recumbent position.

Affected patients may be asymptomatic, but they can present with soft, unilateral scrotal mass that does not transilluminate, dull-aching scrotal pain, and/or infertility. A bag-of-worms-like appearance is seen on scrotal examination.

In contrast, a hydrocele is thought to result from an imbalance of fluid secretion and reabsorption in the tunica vaginalis, leading to fluid accumulation around the testes and spermatic cord. Affected patients present with a soft, non-tender fullness in the hemi-scrotum that transilluminates well. Inflammatory conditions, like epididymitis, and torsion can precipitate the development of hydrocele.



Option Analysis

❌ Bacterial sequestration in the epididymis:
Incorrect: Bacterial sequestration in the epididymis causes epididymitis. Affected patients present with a gradual onset of scrotal pain (not a mass) that is accompanied by dysuria, urgency, or frequency. It is often preceded by urethral discharge in sexually active individuals. Common organisms are N. gonorrhea and E. coli.
❌ Fluid in the tunica vaginalis:
Incorrect: Fluid in the tunica vaginalis results in the formation of a hydrocele. Affected patients usually present with a soft, non-tender fullness in the hemi-scrotum that transilluminates. This patient’s swelling did not transilluminate, making hydrocele less likely.
❌ Cystic dilation of epididymis:
Incorrect: Cystic dilation of the epididymis results in a spermatocele. It appears as a soft, round mass in the head of the epididymis that is located on the superior aspect of the testicles. Contrary to this patient’s presentation, a spermatocele does not enlarge with the Valsalva maneuver and is usually asymptomatic.
✅ Dilation of pampiniform plexus:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Neoplasia of left testes:
Incorrect: Testicular cancer is the most common cancer of young men and presents as a firm, non-tender nodule. It is discovered by the patient in most cases as a painless mass. Although similar to a varicocele in that it does not transilluminate, its size does not change with position as is observed in this patient.

questions.text:
A 66-year-old woman undergoes a cardiac ablation for treatment of symptomatic atrial fibrillation. Several weeks postoperatively, the patient reports shortness of breath with exertion and difficulty initiating a deep breath. She additionally reports a morning headache as well as daytime fatigue. She has not noted any voice changes. Past medical history includes hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Vitals are within normal limits. Diminished breath sounds are noted over the right lung. No cardiac murmurs are appreciated. A chest radiograph is obtained, as demonstrated below. Which of the following structures was most likely injured intraoperatively?  



Reproduced from: Radiopaedia
questions.solution:
This patient presents with symptoms and X-rays findings suggestive of injury to the phrenic nerve following a cardiac ablation procedure. Cardiac ablation is a standard procedure that uses radiofrequency or cryothermal energy to manage supraventricular arrhythmias non-pharmacologically.  

While this procedure is considered low risk, several structures are at risk of injury, including the phrenic nerve, right heart structures, and vascular access sites. Injury to the phrenic nerve results in ipsilateral paralysis of the diaphragm, which can be visualized on chest X-ray as elevation of the hemidiaphragm on the affected side.  Patients with a paralyzed hemidiaphragm can present with symptoms of exertional dyspnea, recurrent pneumonia, anxiety, insomnia, morning headache, excessive daytime somnolence, orthopnea, fatigue, or difficulty weaning from mechanical ventilation.  

 

Option Analysis

✅ Phrenic nerve :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Recurrent laryngeal nerve:
Incorrect: Injury to the recurrent laryngeal nerve does not commonly occur with cardiac ablation procedures. Moreover, unilateral injury to the recurrent laryngeal nerve would manifest with hoarseness.
❌ Radial artery:
Incorrect: Vascular injury would manifest with evidence of hematoma, swelling, or diminished pulses over the access site. This patient’s chest x-ray suggests injury to a different structure. 
❌ Pulmonary vein :
Incorrect: Injury to the pulmonary vein can occur following cardiac ablation procedures. This patient’s chest x-ray suggests injury to the phrenic nerve, which can result in pulmonary vein stenosis and subsequent pulmonary hypertension. 
❌ Tricuspid valve:
Incorrect: Direct cardiac damage following cardiac ablation can occur, including injury to the tricuspid valve. However, injury to this structure would manifest with a systolic murmur, which is absent in this patient.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after being assaulted at a local bar. He sustained facial trauma, including multiple lacerations and multiple punches to the face. He reports right-sided jaw pain and teeth malalignment. Temperature is 37.2°C (98.9°F), pulse is 85/min, respirations are 19/min, and blood pressure is 120/64 mmHg. CT of the facial bones demonstrates a right-sided displaced mandibular fracture. The patient is subsequently taken to the operating room for operative repair by otolaryngology. The anesthetist injects a local anesthetic agent between the coronoid notch and the pterygomandibular raphe of the right mandible. Injection of an anesthetic into this space is likely to anesthetize which of the following nerves?
questions.solution:
An inferior alveolar nerve block is the most common anesthetic procedure performed in dental surgery.  The most critical clinical landmarks used to locate the inferior alveolar nerve include the coronoid notch and the pterygomandibular raphe–the preferred needle insertion site lies between these two landmarks. Successful injection anesthetizes all mandibular teeth to the median plane, the skin and mucous membrane of the lower lip, the labial alveolar mucosa and gingiva, and the skin of the chin.


Other nerves anesthetized during dental procedures are summarized in the table below:  


Option Analysis

❌ Greater palatine nerve  :
Incorrect: The greater palatine nerve is best anesthetized by injecting an anesthetic into the greater palatine foramen. This nerve block anesthetizes the palatal mucosa and lingual gingiva posterior to the maxillary canine teeth and underlying palate. This nerve emerges between the 2nd and the 3rd molars.  
❌ Lesser palatine nerve  :
Incorrect: The lesser palatine nerves pass through the lesser palatine foramina posterior to the greater palatine foramen. This nerve supplies sensation to the soft palate, tonsils, and uvula.  
❌ Nasopalatine nerve  :
Incorrect: The nasopalatine nerve can be anesthetized via anesthetic injection into the incisive fossa. Affected tissues include the palatal mucosa, the lingual gingiva and alveolar bone of the six anterior maxillary teeth, and the hard palate.  
✅ Inferior alveolar nerve  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Anterior superior alveolar nerve  :
Incorrect: The anterior superior alveolar nerve (or anterior superior dental nerve) is a branch of the infraorbital nerve that innervates the anterior teeth and joins the middle superior alveolar nerve to form the superior dental plexus.

questions.text:
A 47-year-old man presents to the emergency department after a fall on an outstretched hand. During the fall, the patient hyperextended his right wrist and felt a “pop.” He is otherwise healthy and does not take any medications. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals ecchymosis and swelling of the volar aspect of the right wrist. A lateral radiograph of the right wrist is obtained and shown below. Which of the following anatomic structures is at risk of injury based on this patient’s clinical presentation?  


Image reproduced from ">Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
After a fall onto an outstretched hand (“FOOSH” injury), this patient presents with evidence of volar swelling and deformity. Imaging demonstrates the “spilled teacup” sign, pathognomonic for a lunate dislocation.

Lunate dislocations represent a relatively uncommon pattern of wrist injuries, but the most common mechanism of injury involves a FOOSH injury or high-energy trauma. The capitate stays in place in lunate dislocations, while the lunate is displaced. A closely related injury pattern is perilunate dislocation, in which the lunate stays, but the capitate is displaced.

Clinically, lunate dislocations present with pain on the volar-radial aspect of the wrist, with associated pain and swelling. Assessment of median nerve function is paramount in patients with this injury pattern, as lunate dislocations are often associated with compressive radiculopathy of the nerve. The most common radiographic feature associated with lunate dislocations is the spilled tea-cup sign on lateral x-rays, which represents the lunate being pushed off the radius into the palm.  

Option Analysis

✅ Median nerve:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Radial nerve  :
Incorrect: Radial nerve injury does not typically occur with lunate dislocations. Instead, it more commonly occurs with humeral shaft fractures.  
❌ Ulnar nerve  :
Incorrect: Injury to the ulnar nerve more commonly occurs due to injury to the hook of the hamate, not the lunate.  
❌ Radial artery  :
Incorrect: Radial artery injuries are uncommon in the setting of lunate dislocations.  
❌ Ulnar collateral ligament  :
Incorrect: The ulnar collateral ligament is not typically damaged in the setting of lunate dislocations.

questions.text: A 66-year-old man is evaluated for dysphagia and recurrent aspiration pneumonia. The patient has hypertension and often forgets to take his blood pressure medications. Temperature is 37.0ºC (98.6ºF), blood pressure is 162/95 mmHg, and pulse is 87/min. Physical examination reveals an absent right-sided gag reflex. Loss of function of the nerve responsible for transmitting the afferent signal of this reflex is associated with which of the following additional neurological deficits?

choices.text: Loss of sensation in the posterior one-third of the tongue.
Loss of taste sensation in the anterior two-thirds of the tongue

questions.solution:
This patient with a history of poorly controlled hypertension and recurrent aspiration pneumonia presents with an absent right-sided gag reflex. Afferent signals of the gag reflex are sent via the glossopharyngeal nerve, which is also responsible for sensation in the posterior one-third of the tongue.  

A reflex arc typically consists of sensory receptors, the afferent sensory nerve that sends an impulse to the central nervous system, and an efferent motor nerve that transmits a motor response. The gag reflex is mediated by the glossopharyngeal nerve and the vagus nerve. The gag reflex is triggered via contact with the posterior pharynx, tonsillar area, or tongue base. Afferent nerve impulses (sensory limb) are sent through the glossopharyngeal nerve (IX), which also aids in swallowing by supplying the stylopharyngeus muscle and carries taste from the posterior third of the tongue. Efferent nerve impulses (motor limb) are then sent through the pharyngeal branches of the vagus nerve (X), which also innervates muscles of the pharynx and larynx and helps regulate blood pressure.  



The gag reflex is assessed when there is reason to suspect reduced palatal strength or sensation (e.g. clinical symptoms of stroke). It is evaluated by observing the patient’s response when the posterior pharynx is touched with a cotton swab. The reflex elicited on one side can be compared with that of the contralateral side to assess for asymmetry.  

A normal gag reflex involves brisk, symmetrical elevation of the soft palate and contraction of pharyngeal muscles. If both cranial nerves IX and X are damaged, stimulation of the affected side would fail to elicit a reflex. Loss of the gag reflex makes patients susceptible to aspiration and pneumonia.  

Option Analysis

✅ Loss of sensation in the posterior one-third of the tongue.:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Loss of taste sensation in the anterior two-thirds of the tongue:
Incorrect: Taste sensation from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue is transmitted via the facial nerve, while somatosensation is transmitted via the trigeminal nerve. In contrast, the glossopharyngeal nerve, which carries the afferent signals of the gag reflex and is likely damaged here, is responsible for taste and somatosensation of the posterior one-third of the tongue.     
❌ Vocal cord paralysis:
Incorrect: The vagus nerve is responsible for the motor supply of the vocal cords. It carries the efferent signal of the gag reflex. The glossopharyngeal nerve carries the afferent signal of the gag reflex, in addition to sensation in the posterior one-third of the tongue.
❌ Tongue paralysis:
Incorrect: Most of the tongue muscles are supplied by the hypoglossal nerve. The exception is the palatoglossal muscle provided by the vagus nerve. However, this patient has an absent gag reflex, and the afferent signals of the gag reflex are transmitted via the glossopharyngeal nerve, which is also responsible for sensation in the posterior one-third of the tongue.
❌ Loss of the cough reflex:
Incorrect: The vagus nerve mediates both the afferent and efferent signals of the cough reflex. In contrast, this patient has an absent gag reflex. The afferent signals of the gag reflex are transmitted via the glossopharyngeal nerve, which is also responsible for sensation in the posterior one-third of the tongue.

questions.text:
An 80-year-old man presents to the emergency department to evaluate acute chest pain. Before obtaining a clinical history, the patient becomes unresponsive. Temperature 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 101/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 186/92 mmHg. A chest radiograph is demonstrated below. Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient’s clinical presentation?  


Image reproduced from Radiopedia

choices.text: Large cell adenocarcinoma of the lung

questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation of acute chest pain. Chest radiography demonstrates a widened mediastinum, which can be due to many possible etiologies. However, of the diagnoses listed, only a thoracic aortic aneurysm is causative of a widened mediastinum.  

The mediastinum is the central thoracic cavity that contains the heart, esophagus, trachea, thoracic duct, thymus, and lymph nodes of the central chest. Radiographically, this space is defined by the right heart border, ascending aorta, superior vena cava, aortic knob, descending aorta, and left heart border. A widened mediastinum is defined as greater than 6-8 cm and can be caused by several pathologies.  

Most importantly, the life-threatening etiologies of a widened mediastinum include aortic pathologies such as traumatic rupture of the aorta, aortic dissection, and thoracic aortic aneurysm. Additional etiologies of a widened mediastinum include hilar lymphadenopathy, mediastinal masses, mediastinitis, cardiac tamponade, and vascular anomalies.   

Option Analysis

✅ Thoracic aortic aneurysm  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Large cell adenocarcinoma of the lung:
Incorrect: The lung's large cell adenocarcinoma presents radiographically as a large radiopaque mass with irregular margins. It would not typically present with mediastinal widening.
❌ Massive pulmonary embolism :
Incorrect: A massive pulmonary embolism often demonstrates pulmonary venous congestion and prominence of the right heart border. It would not cause mediastinal widening. 
❌ Left ventricular aneurysm:
Incorrect: Left ventricular aneurysm may demonstrate an enlarged cardiac silhouette but would not cause widening of the mediastinum.   
❌ Esophageal rupture :
Incorrect: Esophageal rupture is most commonly caused by instrumentation, trauma, or forceful vomiting. Patients present with severe retrosternal chest pain that may increase with swallowing or deep breathing. While patients can have some widening of the mediastinum, patients also frequently have subcutaneous and mediastinal emphysema.

questions.text:
A 6-month-old boy is brought to the pediatrician to evaluate difficulty feeding and recurrent stridor for several weeks. The patient has been persistently regurgitating feeds and intermittently becomes stridorous while playing. The parents became more concerned when the patient started “turning blue” occasionally. His birth history was uncomplicated, but he has dropped off his growth chart trajectory since his last well child check. Vital signs are within normal limits. With attempted feeding in the clinic, the patient vomits and becomes stridorous. The patient is subsequently sent to the emergency department, where a computed tomography (CT) of the chest is obtained and shown below. Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient’s clinical presentation?  


Image reproduced from Radiopedia

choices.text: Stenosis of the left subclavian artery

questions.solution:
This pediatric patient presents for evaluation of recurrent dysphagia, vomiting, and respiratory distress. These findings are concerning for an anatomic anomaly. CT of the chest subsequently demonstrates a vascular ring of the aorta – specifically, a double aortic arch.   

Vascular anomalies of the aorta include a double arch of the aorta, a retro-esophageal right subclavian artery, and a right arch of the aorta.  

A double aortic arch occurs when two different take-offs from the aorta occur and then reform posterior to the trachea and esophagus. Ultimately this forms a ring around the esophagus and trachea, which can compress these structures and potentially result in difficulty breathing and swallowing.    

A retro-esophageal right subclavian artery refers to a right subclavian artery that arises in the left chest and subsequently courses posterior to the esophagus and trachea. This condition is most commonly asymptomatic but can result in recurrent dysphagia.  

Lastly, a right arch of the aorta represents an aorta that courses to the right of the trachea instead of its usual course to the left of the trachea. This condition represents a mirror image of normal aortic anatomy and is associated with certain genetic disorders. However, it is not pathologic in nature.    

Option Analysis

✅ Double arch of the aorta:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Right arch of the aorta :
Incorrect: A right arch of the aorta represents a mirror image of normal aortic anatomy. While this anatomic anomaly is associated with certain genetic disorders, it is not pathologic and would not account for this patient’s symptoms. 
❌ Stenosis of the left subclavian artery:
Incorrect: Subclavian steal syndrome is a phenomenon that occurs with severe stenosis of the subclavian artery proximal to the ipsilateral vertebral artery. Physiologically, this condition reverses blood flow through the ipsilateral vertebral artery, which can lead to vertebrobasilar ischemia. In addition, patients can manifest with exercise-induced ischemia of the affected limb. 
❌ Pulmonary infundibular stenosis :
Incorrect: Pulmonary infundibular stenosis is associated with Tetralogy of Fallot and is the most important marker of prognosis. While this condition could partially explain this patient’s respiratory distress, it does not explain the history of dysphagia. 
❌ Coarctation of the aorta:
Incorrect: Coarctation of the aorta refers to a discrete narrowing of the descending aorta at the insertion of the ductus arteriosus, just distal to the left subclavian artery. In severe cases, the condition can present with findings of heart failure in infancy.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old man presents to his primary care physician for evaluation of a rash on his chest. The patient had a burning pain across his right chest last week, followed by the eruption of painful blisters two days ago. The patient has a history of a kidney transplant due to underlying diabetes and hypertension. The patient is currently taking tacrolimus daily. Temperature is 37.0 °C (98.6 °F), pulse is 76/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 156/65 mmHg. Physical examination is notable for the finding as shown. Which of the following pathogens is most likely implicated in this patient’s clinical condition?

Reproduced from: Wikipedia
questions.solution:
This patient presents with herpes zoster or shingles, as manifested by the small clustered vesicular lesions in the T3 dermatome across the right chest that do not cross the midline. The organism known to induce this dermatologic finding is human-herpesvirus 3 (HHV-3).   

Shingles refers to the reactivation of a latent infection with the varicella-zoster virus, or HHV-3 – the same pathogen associated with childhood chickenpox. After the primary infection has subsided, the virus remains latent in the dorsal root or trigeminal nerve ganglia, typically for decades. Without proper vaccination, the virus harbors the risk of reactivation (especially in immunocompromised patients) within the ganglion to involve multiple sensory neurons and spread down the sensory nerve to establish infection in the skin.  

Clinically, this condition manifests with a rash that starts as erythematous papules in a single dermatome or several contiguous dermatomes. Over the next several days, the rash develops into small vesicles, which become pustular. As this process occurs, the involved sensory ganglion exhibits intense inflammation and hemorrhagic necrosis of nerve cells, resulting in post-herpetic neuralgia, the most common complication of shingles.    

Most commonly, reactivation occurs on the trunk; however, when reactivation occurs in the distribution of trigeminal V1, ocular involvement may occur. In this case, patients may also experience hearing loss, facial paralysis, or loss of taste, known as Ramsay-hunt syndrome. Less common complications include meningitis, encephalitis, myelitis, or bacterial superinfection in immunocompromised hosts.  

Option Analysis

✅ Varicella-zoster virus (Human-herpes-virus 3) :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Staphylococcus aureus:
Incorrect:  Staphylococcus aureus is a well-established cause of purulent cellulitis; however, this patient’s clinical presentation is more consistent with varicella-zoster given the findings of rash that starts as erythematous papules in a single dermatome.  
❌ Epstein Barr virus:
Incorrect:  The Epstein Barr virus, also known as HHV-4, is the most common culprit implicated in the setting of infectious mononucleosis; however, this patient’s clinical presentation is more consistent with varicella-zoster given the findings of rash that starts as erythematous papules in a single dermatome.  
❌ Human-herpes-virus 6:
Incorrect: Human herpesvirus 6 is the pathogen most commonly associated with roseola infantum in children, which typically presents with a few days of high-grade fever followed by the eruption of a blanching maculopapular rash. This patient’s clinical presentation is more consistent with varicella-zoster given the findings of rash that starts as erythematous papules in a single dermatome.  
❌ Cytomegalovirus:
Incorrect: Cytomegalovirus is the most common etiology of infectious mononucleosis in heterophile-negative patients; however, this patient’s clinical presentation is more consistent with varicella-zoster given the findings of rash that starts as erythematous papules in a single dermatome.

questions.text:
A 20-year-old man is brought to the emergency department following a motorcycle accident. The patient was struck by a car and sustained blunt head trauma with associated loss of consciousness. He quickly regained consciousness, but he did not seek care because he was “feeling fine.” Several hours later, he developed a severe headache with associated nausea and vomiting, and his partner called emergency services. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 45/min, respirations are 8/min and irregular, and blood pressure is 165/70 mmHg. On physical examination, the patient responds to painful stimuli only. Ocular examination demonstrates a dilated right pupil. A non-contrast CT is obtained and shown below. Which of the following anatomic structures was most likely injured in this patient?  


Retrieved from: Radiopaedia
questions.solution:
This patient presents with findings consistent with an epidural hematoma due to middle meningeal artery rupture. Following the accident, the patient sustained a characteristic “lucid interval,” which refers to a temporary improvement in the condition before clinical deterioration from hematoma expansion. On presentation, the constellation of bradycardia, hypertension with a wide pulse pressure, and respiratory depression with irregular breathing raises concern for the Cushing triad (reflective of elevated intracranial hypertension and brain stem compression). Lastly, the physical examination demonstrates a dilated pupil, which is concerning for uncal herniation and compression of the cranial nerve III.  

The majority of cases of epidural hematoma occur secondary to head trauma during accidents, falls, and assaults. The most commonly implicated vessel is the middle meningeal artery as it passes under the pterion–the confluence where the frontal, parietal, temporal, and sphenoid bones merge. On head CT, epidural bleeding creates a lens-shaped lesion as the collection is bordered by dural attachments at the cranial sutures. Treatment of epidural hematoma involves an emergency craniotomy and hematoma evacuation.



Option Analysis

❌ Bridging veins:
Incorrect: Rupture of the bridging veins is most commonly associated with subdural hematomas. The CT findings above demonstrating a lens shaped lesion are consistent with an epidural hematoma. The CT in a subdural hematoma would instead demonstrate a crescent-shaped hemorrhage that crosses suture lines.  
❌ Lenticulostriate arteries:
Incorrect: Rupture of the lenticulostriate arteries manifests with intraparenchymal hemorrhage. It is more commonly associated with chronic hypertension (Charcot-Bouchard microaneurysms), rather than trauma.  
❌ Carotid artery:
Incorrect: Carotid dissection may occur in young patients in the setting of trauma. More common manifestations include neck pain or stiffness, Horner syndrome, and stroke-like symptoms. Aside from trauma, this patient has no risk factors for carotid dissection (e.g. connective tissue disorder). Furthermore, carotid dissection is not associated with a “lucid interval.”  
✅ Middle meningeal artery:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Middle cerebral artery:
Incorrect: Middle cerebral artery rupture manifests in subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH), which may occur in patients with a saccular aneurysms or arteriovenous malformations. Patients often endorse the “worst headache of my life.” On CT, SAH appears as hyperdense material filling the subarachnoid space.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man was brought to the emergency department by his partner after being found unresponsive one hour ago. The patient fell down a flight of stairs the previous evening, but he appeared fine immediately afterwards, and he went to bed at his usual time. Past history is significant for mitral valve replacement four years ago, hypertension, and coronary artery disease. Current medications include aspirin, warfarin, enalapril, metoprolol, and atorvastatin. On arrival, the patient is unresponsive. Temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 59/min, respirations are 7/min and irregular, and blood pressure is 200/102 mm Hg. On examination, the right pupil is 5 mm and fixed. The left pupil is 4 mm and reactive to light. There is an extension of the extremities to painful stimuli. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination demonstrates a systolic click. The abdomen is soft and nontender. The patient is intubated and mechanically ventilated. A mannitol infusion is started. A non-contrast CT scan of the brain shows a right-sided 6-cm subdural hematoma with an 18-mm midline shift and associated cerebral edema. The patient is at increased risk of developing which of the following?

choices.text: Right eye esotropia and upward deviation

questions.solution:
This patient has a large right-sided subdural hematoma, resulting in elevated intracranial pressure (ICP) and cerebral edema, presenting as midline shift and transtentorial herniation of the uncus.

With this type of herniation, the uncus (the innermost portion of the temporal lobe) slips down towards the tentorium and compresses parts of the brain stem. The following neurologic deficits are commonly observed with transtentorial herniation of the uncus:

  •  CN III nerve palsy, where the eye is fixed in a “down and out” position with a dilated and unresponsive pupil. 
  •  Posterior cerebral artery compression leads to contralateral homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing.  
  •  Paramedian basilar artery injury results in small linear or flame-shaped hemorrhages called Duret hemorrhages. 
  •  Contralateral hemiparesis is secondary to compression of the ipsilateral cerebral peduncle of the midbrain, damaging corticospinal fibers. 
  •  Contralateral peduncle compression against the tentorium results in ipsilateral hemiparesis, known as a false localizing sign, the so-called Kernohan's notch. 

Option Analysis

❌ Right eye esotropia and upward deviation  :
Incorrect: Right eye esotropia and elevation would be caused by concomitant CN IV and VI palsies, leading to unopposed CN III activity. When CN III is unopposed, the associated extraocular muscles produce adduction and elevation or depression of the eye. Instead, uncal herniation causes CN III palsy, resulting in pupillary dilation and absent light reflex (as seen in this patient), abduction, and slight depression of the eye (“down and out” gaze).  
❌ Multifocal myoclonus  :
Incorrect: Multifocal myoclonus is associated with various neurologic disorders, including seizures. It is more frequently observed in severe cerebral hypoxia, progressive myoclonic epilepsy, neurodegenerative diseases (e.g. Alzheimer disease), or metabolic coma (e.g. secondary to glycemic disturbances). However, it is not a common symptom of uncal herniation.  
❌ Left-side vagus nerve palsy  :
Incorrect: The vagus nerve (CN X) exits the brainstem via the medulla, which lies at a position too inferior to be affected by uncal herniation. CN X can be injured via direct trauma to the neck and can also occur due to compression from an aortic aneurysm.  
❌ Bilateral vestibulocochlear nerve palsy  :
Incorrect: The vestibulocochlear nerve (CN VIII) exits the brainstem at the pons, situated too low to be affected by uncal herniation, which is seen on this patient's CT scan. CN VIII can be injured by hemorrhage or aneurysms of the anterior inferior cerebellar artery.  
✅ Right-sided hemiplegia  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician for evaluation of left ear pain and ringing. The patient reports an insidious onset of her symptoms four to five days ago. The patient states, “I tried listening to classical music yesterday to calm my nerves, and I experienced a shooting pain in my left ear.” The patient is otherwise healthy, and her vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates diminished sensation in the left ear, left sided facial droop, and inability to wrinkle the left forehead. Which of the following structures is most likely responsible for this patient’s otologic symptomatology?
questions.solution:
Bell palsy, or facial nerve paralysis, is a common cause of hyperacusis – a hearing disorder characterized by increased sensitivity to high frequency and high volume sounds. The stapedius muscle contracts in response to loud noise, thus dampening the vibrations of the ossicles and protecting the ear.

Paralysis of the facial nerve (CN VII) results in the inability of the stapedius to contract and causes sounds to be abnormally loud on the affected side.

Hyperacusis can be an incredibly debilitating condition, most commonly caused by prolonged exposure to high decibel sounds. Other common conditions associated with this condition include Bell Palsy or Meniere disease. Symptoms include pain in the affected ear when exposed to noise.  

Option Analysis

✅ Stapedius muscle  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Incus  :
Incorrect: The incus represents the anvil-shaped bone in the middle ear, which transmits vibrations between the malleus and stapes. It is not the primary anatomic site of pathology in patients with hyperacusis.  
❌ Malleus  :
Incorrect: The malleus is a hammer-shaped small bone or ossicle of the middle ear which connects to the incus and is attached to the inner surface of the tympanic membrane. It is not the primary anatomic site of pathology in patients with hyperacusis.  
❌ CN V  :
Incorrect: The facial nerve, not the trigeminal nerve, is implicated in the pathogenesis of hyperacusis.    
❌ Greater petrosal nerve  :
Incorrect: The greater petrosal nerve branches from the facial nerve to form a chain of nerves that innervate the lacrimal gland. This nerve is not implicated in patients with hyperacusis.

questions.text: A group of investigators are studying the gastrointestinal ligament and the structures housed within. They discover the hepatoduodenal ligament contains the portal triad, which consists of the proper hepatic artery, hepatic portal vein, and common bile duct. Which of the following structures form the hepatic portal vein?

choices.text: Inferior mesenteric and superior mesenteric veins
External iliac and internal iliac veins

questions.solution:
The hepatic portal vein is a short, wide vein that is formed by the superior mesenteric and splenic veins posterior to the neck of the pancreas. It ascends anterior to the inferior vena cava (IVC) as part of the portal triad in the hepatoduodenal ligament. The portal triad consists of the hepatic artery (carries oxygenated blood to the liver), hepatic portal vein (carries blood with nutrients and toxins extracted from digested content to the liver), and bile duct (carries bile products away from hepatocytes and towards the larger ducts and gallbladder).  



Option Analysis

❌ Collecting and central veins  :
Incorrect: The hepatic veins, not the hepatic portal vein, are formed by the union of collecting veins that in turn drain the central veins of the hepatic parenchyma. The hepatic veins then open into the inferior vena cava (IVC), just inferior to the diaphragm.  
❌ Inferior mesenteric and superior mesenteric veins  :
Incorrect: The inferior mesenteric vein drains into the splenic vein, which then joins the superior mesenteric vein to form the hepatic portal vein.  
✅ Superior mesenteric and splenic veins  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Inferior mesenteric and splenic veins  :
Incorrect: The inferior mesenteric vein drains into the splenic vein, which then joins the superior mesenteric vein to form the hepatic portal vein.  
❌ External iliac and internal iliac veins  :
Incorrect: The external iliac vein and internal iliac vein unite anterior of the sacroiliac joint to form the common iliac veins.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man is brought to the emergency department due to new-onset right lower extremity weakness. The patient first noticed this weakness after he had difficulty standing up from his bed this morning. He reports a mild headache but has not had blurred vision, back pain, or history of trauma.
