Past medical history is significant for a recently diagnosed primary tumor of the frontal lobe and osteoarthritis. The patient takes acetaminophen for joint pain. Temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 88/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 200/96 mm Hg. Right lower extremity examination demonstrates 0/5 muscle strength, and deep tendon reflexes are 3+ with a positive Babinski sign. Sensation is decreased throughout the right foot and leg. Left lower extremity and bilateral upper extremity examinations are unremarkable. Further imaging confirms a brain herniation syndrome at the site marked with the arrow in the image below.
 

 Which of the following is a possible complication of the type of brain herniation indicated by the arrow?
questions.solution:
There are several types of brain herniation, including subfalcine, uncal, transtentorial (upward and downward), and tonsillar herniation–all occur in response to increased intracranial pressure. The type of herniation denoted in the figure above is described as subfalcine/cingulate herniation.   

With subfalcine herniation, the innermost part of the frontal lobe, called the cingulate gyrus, herniates below the free edge of the falx cerebri toward the contralateral skull. Displaced brain can compress the anterior cerebral artery, resulting in stroke and subsequent contralateral hemiparesis (affecting lower extremities more than upper extremities). Furthermore, subfalcine herniation can lead to hydrocephalus and elevated intracranial pressure via compression of the foramen of Monro. Since subfalcine herniation is a process involving the anterior hemispheres, the patient may not experience depressed consciousness (unless the shift is extreme).    

Common causes of subfalcine herniation include either focal mass effect, such as from an arterial bleed, tumor, or abscesses, or diffuse mass effect secondary to generalized cerebral edema.  

Option Analysis

❌ Oculomotor nerve compression:
Incorrect: Herniation of the medial temporal lobe, uncus, and hippocampal gyrus through the tentorial incisura can compress the oculomotor nerve, peduncle, and posterior cerebral artery. This patient instead has evidence of a subfalcine herniation. 
✅ Anterior cerebral artery compression :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Kernohan phenomenon:
Incorrect: Kernohan phenomenon refers to an imaging finding that results from extensive midline shift secondary to mass effect, resulting in the indentation in the contralateral cerebral crus by the tentorium cerebelli. This patient instead has evidence of a subfalcine herniation. 
❌ Duret hemorrhages:
Incorrect: Duret hemorrhages can occur as a complication of central/downward transtentorial  herniation and rupture of penetrating basal arteries to the brainstem. This patient instead has evidence of a subfalcine herniation. 
❌ Cerebral aqueduct obstruction:
Incorrect: Ascending transtentorial herniation can obstruct the cerebral aqueduct, leading to hydrocephalus.This patient has evidence of a subfalcine herniation, which can obstruct cerebrospinal fluid outflow of the lateral ventricles via compression of the foramen of Monro.

questions.text: A 69-year-old man undergoes coronary artery bypass grafting. Upon extubation, the patient reports bilateral blindness. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 17/min and blood pressure is 100/50 mm Hg. Physical examination shows bilaterally equal, reactive pupils and a normal fundoscopic exam. MRI of the brain shows wedge-shaped cortical infarcts of both occipital lobes. This patient most likely sustained an infarct in which of the following vascular distributions?

choices.text: Inferior division of the middle cerebral arteries
Middle cerebral artery and posterior cerebral artery watershed area
Superior division of the middle cerebral artery

questions.solution:
This patient’s MRI demonstrates symmetrical infarcts in the occipital watershed region–at the border of the posterior cerebral artery (PCA) and middle cerebral artery (MCA) distribution of the occipital lobe. Infarction at this watershed region results in cortical blindness.  

Watershed regions are supplied by distal branches of the major cerebral arteries; they are located between regions supplied by the anterior, middle, and posterior cerebral arteries. Watershed regions are vulnerable to ischemia due to low baseline perfusion pressures, and infarcts can occur secondary to sudden decreases in blood pressure or cessation of blood flow through both vessels. Watershed zones are divided into two types:  
  •  Cortical border zones: territories between the anterior and middle cerebral arteries and between the middle and posterior cerebral arteries 
  •  Internal border zones: territories between the superficial and deep branches of the MCA 
 
Patients with watershed infarcts present with signs of systemic hypoperfusion (e.g., tachycardia, low blood pressure, pallor, sweating), diffuse neurologic deterioration, bilateral visual loss (cortical blindness with PCA-MCA watershed region), and/or proximal limb weakness with sparing of the face, hands, and feet (ACA-MCA watershed region). 

Option Analysis

❌ Anterior and posterior communicating arteries:
Incorrect: Saccular aneurysms are often found within the anterior and posterior communicating arteries in the circle of Willis. Anterior communicating artery aneurysms can compress the optic chiasm, resulting in bitemporal hemianopia. 
❌ Inferior division of the middle cerebral arteries:
Incorrect: The inferior division of the middle cerebral artery supplies Wernicke's area in the superior temporal lobe. Ischemia of this area results in aphasia characterized by normal fluency with impaired comprehension and repetition. 
✅ Middle cerebral artery and posterior cerebral artery watershed area:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Superior division of the middle cerebral artery:
Incorrect: The superior division of the middle cerebral artery supplies Broca's area in the inferior frontal lobe. Ischemia of this area leads to aphasia characterized by normal comprehension with impaired fluency and repetition. 
❌ Proximal middle cerebral artery:
Incorrect: The proximal middle cerebral artery supplies portions of the frontal, temporal, and parietal lobes. Ischemia of this area will lead to global aphasia, characterized by impaired fluency, comprehension, and repetition.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man comes to the office to evaluate right ear pain for the past three months. The pain is constant, dull, and associated with recurrent right-sided jaw pain and headache. The pain worsens throughout the day and with chewing. He hears a “cracking sound” while eating. The patient’s partner says that he grinds his teeth at night. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows limited jaw opening and muscle spasms over the lateral right face. Otoscopic examination is within normal limits. Which of the following nerves contributes to this patient’s ear pain?
questions.solution:
This patient’s ear pain, headache, and jaw pain are characteristic of temporomandibular joint (TMJ) disorder. Underlying etiologies of this condition include pathological contraction of the pterygoid muscles secondary to repeated jaw clenching or grinding, misalignment, or trauma. Patients often develop hypersensitivity of the mandibular nerve (CV V3) and subsequent otalgia, given the nerve’s proximity to the TMJ. Classic symptoms include dull, waxing and waning jaw/facial pain, clicking and popping with jaw movement, ear pain, fullness, and tinnitus.

The mandibular nerve, the largest branch of the trigeminal nerve, supplies sensation to the TMJ in addition to the floor of the mouth, anterior tongue, and the lower face. In addition, this nerve contributes to sensory innervation to the external auditory canal. Therefore, TMJ disorder can also present with referred ear pain.  

Option Analysis

✅ Trigeminal nerve  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Hypoglossal nerve  :
Incorrect: The hypoglossal nerve (CN XII) carries general motor innervation to the intrinsic and extrinsic muscles of the tongue. It is not implicated in temporomandibular joint disorder.  
❌ Vagus nerve  :
Incorrect: The auricular branch of the vagus nerve (CN X) carries sensory innervation from the external auditory canal; however, it is not the underlying cause of ear pain in this patient with temporomandibular joint disorder.  
❌ Cervical spinal nerve  :
Incorrect: The cervical spinal nerve is harmed by structural lesions to the cervical spine. More commonly, damage to this nerve results in neck pain/stiffness and arm and shoulder weakness. It is not implicated in temporomandibular joint disorder.
❌ Vestibulocochlear nerve  :
Incorrect: The vestibulocochlear nerve (CN VIII) carries auditory and vestibular information from the inner ear. It is not implicated in temporomandibular joint disorder.

questions.text: A 25-year-old right-handed man is brought to the clinic by his parent for evaluation of "abnormal behavior.” The patient’s parent reports that the patient has been eating uncontrollably. The patient has also demonstrated inappropriate sexual behavior towards family members. Also of concern to the patient’s parent is that the patient seemed indifferent to the news that the patient’s other parent had passed away a few weeks ago. The patient’s parent denies any recent head trauma sustained by the patient but does state that the patient was hospitalized two months ago for a “brain infection.” A follow-up MRI is ordered. Which of the following parts of the brain is most likely to demonstrate abnormal findings?

choices.text: Angular gyrus within the parietal lobe of the dominant hemisphere

questions.solution:
Kluver-Bucy syndrome is a neurobehavioral syndrome that results from bilateral damage to the amygdala. It is characterized by three types of disinhibited behavior: increased sexual drive (hypersexuality), uncontrollable desire to eat (hyperphagia), and an urge for exploring objects by mouth (hyperorality). Lack of emotional responsiveness, recurrent unprovoked seizures, and visual agnosia (inability to recognize objects) are other symptoms that are also seen in Kluver-Bucy syndrome.  

The most common etiology of Kluver-Bucy syndrome is viral encephalitis typically caused by herpes simplex virus type 1, which can damage the temporal lobes and the amygdala. The amygdaloid nuclei are located within the temporal lobes and supplied by the anterior choroidal arteries. They comprise a portion of the the limbic system, which is responsible for sexual drive as well as emotional and behavioral responses. Other causes of Kluver-Bucy syndrome include temporal lobe surgery and head trauma that results in temporal lobe contusions.  



Option Analysis

❌ Angular gyrus within the parietal lobe of the dominant hemisphere:
Incorrect: Gerstmann syndrome typically results from ischemic injury to the angular gyrus within the parietal lobe of the dominant hemisphere. Symptoms include finger agnosia, left-right disorientation, acalculia, agraphia, and alexia.
❌ Right subthalamic nucleus:
Incorrect: Injury to the right subthalamic nucleus could present with left-sided hemiballismus. Hemiballismus is an involuntary, large amplitude, unilateral movement of the limbs and most commonly results from a lacunar infarct sustained to the subthalamic nuclei.
❌ Hippocampus:
Incorrect: The primary role of the hippocampus includes the formation and retrieval of recent memories. Damage to this area results in anterograde amnesia.
❌ Inferior right parietal lobe:
Incorrect: Hemispatial neglect syndrome results from a lesion in the inferior parietal lobe of the non-dominant hemisphere. Clinical features associated with this syndrome include spatial neglect of the contralateral side of the body. Examples include construction apraxia (when asked to draw a clock, the individual only draws the right half of the clock), and dressing apraxia (the individual only dresses half of their body).
✅ Bilateral amygdala:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of facial swelling. Over the past several weeks, he has noticed his face has become “puffier,” particularly in the morning. In addition, he has a new cough and shortness of breath on exertion. His own past medical history is unremarkable, though his father passed away from a pulmonary embolism. The patient takes no medications. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes per day for thirty years. He does not use alcohol or illicit drugs. Temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), pulse is 111 /min, and blood pressure is 131/66 mmHg. Respirations are 18/min, and oxygen saturation is 96% on room air. Physical examination demonstrates distended neck veins and bilateral facial fullness without tenderness to palpation or erythema. Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient's clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with bilateral facial fullness, distended neck veins, and significant smoking history. Together these findings are consistent with superior vena cava syndrome, of which the most common etiology is an apical lung mass.   

Apical lung tumors, also known as Pancoast tumors, are typically non-small cell lung malignancies known for their unique clinical manifestations. Typically, initial symptoms include non-specific shoulder pain that is often misdiagnosed as osteoarthritis or musculoskeletal injury. As the tumor grows, it invades surrounding mediastinal structures and results in a classic constellation of complications.  

Invasion of the paravertebral sympathetic chain and the inferior cervical (stellate) ganglion manifests with Horner syndrome–classically described as miosis, anhidrosis, and ptosis. In addition, an extension of the tumor into the cervical ganglion results in weakness or sensory disturbance in the upper extremity.    

A less common complication is superior vena cava (SVC) syndrome, which refers to diminished return of blood to the right heart due to mass effect or direct invasion of the tumor into the superior vena cava. Patients with SVC syndrome can present with engorged neck veins and facial fullness.  

Other complications of Pancoast tumors include hoarseness from recurrent laryngeal nerve injury, dysphagia from esophageal impingement, and hemidiaphragm paralysis from damage to the phrenic nerve.    

Option Analysis

✅ Apical lung mass :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Inherited thrombophilia :
Incorrect: Inherited hypercoagulable disorders, such as factor V Leiden, do not commonly present with thrombus formation in the superior vena cava or inferior vena cava.
❌ Subclavian artery aneurysm:
Incorrect: A subclavian artery aneurysm is not a well-established etiology of superior vena cava syndrome.
❌ Facial cellulitis :
Incorrect: Facial cellulitis remains in the differential for superior vena cava syndrome. However, patients would typically present with additional signs of inflammation, including fevers, chills, or purulent drainage.
❌ Suppurative parotitis:
Incorrect: Suppurative parotitis is a severe bacterial infection of the parotid gland in patients with decreased salivary flow. It commonly presents with trismus and unilateral swelling over the parotid gland with purulence emanating from the Stensen duct.

questions.text: A 64-year-old man comes to the physician for evaluation of dysarthria and dysphagia. The patient’s symptoms started three months ago. Past medical history includes type II diabetes mellitus and hypertension, both poorly controlled. Current medications include metformin, glyburide, losartan, and atorvastatin. He has a 40-pack-year smoking history. Temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), blood pressure is 162/89 mmHg, and pulse is 80/min. Examination of the head and neck reveals atrophy and fasciculations of the tongue. Rightward deviation of the tongue is noted when the patient is asked to protrude the tongue. He has no sensory or motor abnormalities in other parts of the face or the body. Further evaluation of this patient’s clinical history will most likely reveal the following?

choices.text: History of stroke involving the right medullary branch of the vertebral artery
Lymph node biopsy from the posterior cervical lymph nodes
Thyroidectomy with superior and inferior thyroid arteries dissection
Mitral stenosis associated with left atrial dilation

questions.solution:
The hypoglossal nerve emerges from the anterior surface of the medulla oblongata and leaves the skull through the hypoglossal canal. It descends through the neck close to the internal carotid artery, internal jugular vein, and vagus nerve. The hypoglossal nerve supplies the intrinsic and extrinsic muscles of the tongue, except the palatoglossal muscle, which is supplied by the vagus nerve.    

Hypoglossal nerve injury can occur anywhere along the nerve’s course. Etiologies include tumor, cerebrovascular injury, demyelinating diseases, injury following cervical spine surgery, and traumatic injury. In addition, the hypoglossal nerve can be injured during operations involving the upper part of the anterior neck. It is especially susceptible to injury during carotid endarterectomy.   

Features of hypoglossal nerve injury include tongue atrophy and fasciculations and ipsilateral paralysis of one-half of the tongue. Moreover, when the patient is asked to stick out their tongue, the tongue will deviate towards the side of nerve injury.  



Option Analysis

✅ Right carotid artery endarterectomy :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ History of stroke involving the right medullary branch of the vertebral artery :
Incorrect: A stroke involving the medullary branch of the vertebral artery will result in medial medullary syndrome. The condition is associated with hypoglossal nerve palsy, contralateral weakness of the body, and contralateral sensory loss. In contrast, this patient has isolated hypoglossal nerve palsy, which would more likely arise as a complication of carotid surgery.
❌ Lymph node biopsy from the posterior cervical lymph nodes:
Incorrect: The spinal accessory nerve can be injured during a lymph node biopsy in the posterior cervical region. Spinal accessory nerve injury can present with shoulder pain, limited abduction of the shoulder beyond 90 degrees, and shoulder drop. However, it would not present with dysarthria, dysphagia, or tongue deviation.
❌ Thyroidectomy with superior and inferior thyroid arteries dissection :
Incorrect: The superior laryngeal nerve can be injured during dissection of the superior thyroid artery, and the recurrent laryngeal nerve can be damaged during dissection of the inferior thyroid artery. However, this patient’s symptoms are more suggestive of hypoglossal nerve injury.
❌ Mitral stenosis associated with left atrial dilation :
Incorrect: Left atrial dilation can cause compression of the left recurrent laryngeal nerve and associated hoarseness of the voice. In contrast, this patient’s symptoms suggest hypoglossal nerve injury.

questions.text:
A 33-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after a high-speed motor vehicle collision. The patient was a restrained driver when he suddenly slammed into the back of a stopped truck while traveling approximately 70 miles per hour. Upon arrival at the emergency department, the patient has a Glasgow coma scale of 4 and is subsequently intubated for airway protection. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 144/min, respirations are 10/min, and blood pressure is 67/30 mmHg. Physical examination shows bruising over the anterior chest wall, but no crepitus is felt on palpation. A chest X-ray is obtained and shown below. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s clinical condition?  


Image reproduced from Radiopedia

choices.text: Rotary force applied to the torso
Vertical compression force applied to the neck
Penetrating trauma to the left anterior chest

questions.solution:
Traumatic rupture of the aorta is a potentially life-threatening injury, with most cases occurring due to sudden deceleration related to automobile accidents.  

Approximately 80-90% of aortic tears occur in the descending aorta at the isthmus, which is just distal to the left subclavian artery and firmly tethered by the ligamentum arteriosum. The more mobile aortic arch swings forward during deceleration, producing a shearing force or “whiplash effect” on the aorta at the isthmus. This shearing force at the isthmus results in a tear. A widened mediastinum may be visible on chest radiography. Many patients will have retrosternal or scapular pain.  

Less common sites of aortic trauma include the ascending aorta, distal descending aorta at the level of the diaphragm, and the mid-thoracic descending aorta because these areas of the aorta are more anatomically fixed and thus less subject to movement in rapid deceleration.  

Option Analysis

✅ Sudden deceleration :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Direct, blunt anterior chest trauma :
Incorrect: Blunt chest trauma may result in sternal fractures, rib fractures, and cardiac or pulmonary contusions. It is not the most common mechanism of injury associated with aortic rupture. 
❌ Rotary force applied to the torso:
Incorrect: A rotary force applied to the torso is not the most common mechanism associated with traumatic rupture of the aorta. 
❌ Vertical compression force applied to the neck:
Incorrect: A burst fracture of C1 is also known as a Jefferson fracture and is considered an unstable C-spine injury. It often occurs due to a vertical compression force applied to the neck. 
❌ Penetrating trauma to the left anterior chest:
Incorrect: Penetrating trauma to the left anterior chest is a less common cause of the traumatic aortic rupture. Penetrating trauma to the left anterior chest is more likely to result in cardiac tamponade, pneumothorax, or perforation of the right ventricle.

questions.text: A 27-year-old man presents to the emergency department after sustaining a gunshot wound to the back. The patient was the victim of a robbery and was shot while attempting to flee the scene. Temperature is 98.6°F (37°C), pulse is 66/min, respirations are 19/min, blood pressure is 166/84 mmHg, and O<sub>2</sub> saturation is 97% on room air. The patient's primary survey is intact, and the patient's secondary survey is notable for a single gunshot wound at the T10 spinal level without an exit wound. An emergent MRI demonstrates complete transection of the spinal cord at the level of T10.  Which of the following neurologic deficits are most likely to be expected based on this patient's spinal cord injury?

choices.text: Complete loss of sensation at the umbilicus and loss of strength of the bilateral lower extremities
Complete loss of sensation at the xiphoid and loss of strength of the bilateral lower extremities
Complete loss of sensation at the clavicular line and loss of strength of the bilateral upper and lower extremities
Complete loss of sensation at the neckline and loss of strength of the bilateral upper and lower extremities
Complete loss of sensation at the neckline and loss of strength of the upper extremities only

questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation after sustaining a gunshot wound that results in a complete spinal cord transection at the level of T10. At this level, neurologic deficits to be expected would be a total loss of sensation at the level of the umbilicus and loss of motor function of the bilateral lower extremities.   

The spinal cord is divided into several different cross-sectional anatomic tracts and levels based on the corresponding vertebrae; an injury at any one of these levels or within the anatomic tract results in distinct neurologic deficits. During a spinal cord transection, the patient loses all sensation and voluntary movement inferior to the lesion site. For example, if a transaction occurs between C4 and C5, the patient will lose all motor and sensory functions below this level, rendering them quadriplegic.  If transection happens between C6 and C8, there’s a complete loss of lower limb function combined with a loss of hand and a variable amount of upper limb function.  

Damage to specific tracts can also occur via partial spinal cord transection. For example, Brown-Sequard syndrome is a rare asymmetrical spinal cord injury pattern that arises following a stab wound, penetrating injury, or, less commonly, fracture or blunt trauma. It results in ipsilateral loss of motor function, vibration, and proprioception due to damage to the dorsal columns and corticospinal tracts. Contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation occurs at one or two levels below the lesion due to injury of the spinothalamic tracts (which decussate at the anterior commissure).  



Option Analysis

✅ Complete loss of sensation at the umbilicus and loss of strength of the bilateral lower extremities  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Complete loss of sensation at the xiphoid and loss of strength of the bilateral lower extremities  :
Incorrect: This answer describes the neurologic deficits observed given a complete spinal cord transection at the level of T7, not T10.  
❌ Complete loss of sensation at the clavicular line and loss of strength of the bilateral upper and lower extremities  :
Incorrect: This answer describes the neurologic deficits observed given a complete spinal cord transection at the level of C5. 
❌ Complete loss of sensation at the neckline and loss of strength of the bilateral upper and lower extremities  :
Incorrect: This answer describes the neurologic deficits observed given a complete spinal cord transection at the level of C3. 
❌ Complete loss of sensation at the neckline and loss of strength of the upper extremities only  :
Incorrect: This choice is not a physically realistic possibility. Complete loss of sensation at the neckline without the involvement of lower extremity weakness would not occur.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man begins complaining of abdominal pain while recovering in the post-anesthesia care unit after undergoing surgical repair for a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm. The procedure was complicated by blood loss and hypotension. The patient states the current pain is 6 out of 10 in severity. Past medical history is notable for atherosclerosis and peripheral vascular disease. The patient has a 35-pack-year smoking history. His temperature of 37.6°C (99.7°F), blood pressure of 118/70 mmHg, and pulse of 78/min. Localized abdominal pain is elicited with light palpation over the area in question. The surgical site is dry and healing. Which of the following portions of the colon is most likely affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient has localized abdominal pain after undergoing an aortic aneurysm repair that was complicated by hypotension and blood loss. The most likely cause of his symptom is colonic ischemia, which occurs when blood flow to the large intestines is reduced to a level that is inadequate for delivery of the oxygen and nutrients required for cellular metabolism.

The condition typically affects the elderly. Watershed regions of the colon, such as the splenic flexure and distal sigmoid colon, are most often affected. These areas are watershed regions, which are defined as the vascular territories covered only by the distal reaches of major arteries; their blood supply is therefore limited, making them more susceptible to ischemia. Causes of colonic ischemia include periods of hypotension (e.g. blood loss during surgery), atherosclerosis, diabetes, and embolism.    

Acute colonic ischemia causes moderate, crampy, left-sided abdominal pain, hematochezia, and diarrhea. In contrast, chronic colonic ischemia causes recurrent postprandial abdominal pain that is usually accompanied by bloody diarrhea and unintentional weight loss.

Abdominal radiographs or CT are often the first tests ordered in patients with suspected colonic ischemia. However, a lower GI endoscopy is needed to confirm the diagnosis, which would reveal edema, cyanosis and/or ulceration of the colonic mucosa.    

 

Option Analysis

❌ Ascending colon:
Incorrect: The ascending colon receives its blood supply from branches of the superior mesenteric artery. The ascending colon is not a watershed area. It is at low risk of ischemia secondary to hypoperfusion.  
❌ Hepatic flexure  :
Incorrect: The hepatic flexure receives blood supply from branches of the superior mesenteric artery. Since it is also not a watershed area, the hepatic flexure is at low risk of ischemia secondary to hypoperfusion.  
✅ Splenic flexure:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Descending colon:
Incorrect: The descending colon is supplied by the inferior mesenteric artery. It is not a watershed region, and therefore, this portion of the colon is not at the high risk of ischemia in the event of hypoperfusion.  
❌ Rectum:
Incorrect: The rectum receives its blood supply from the superior, middle, and inferior rectal arteries. It is often the site of portosystemic anastomosis and varices. However, it is not a watershed region and therefore is not at high risk of ischemia.

questions.text:
An 80-year-old man comes to the clinic due for a follow-up after hospitalization. He was hospitalized two weeks ago for pneumonia and was treated with ampicillin-sulbactam. Medical history is notable for type 2 diabetes mellitus and aortic stenosis. Further medical history reveals 2 prior hospitalizations in the past year for pneumonia. The patient reports difficulty swallowing and regurgitation of undigested food particles. A barium esophagram is performed and shown below:  


Retrieved from: Wikimedia Commons

Which of the following areas is most likely responsible for this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient has dysphagia, regurgitation and recurrent episodes of pneumonia. Along with the barium swallow test results, the most likely diagnosis is a Zenker diverticulum.   

Zenker diverticulum is an outpouching of the mucosa and submucosa through the Killian triangle (also called the Killian dehiscence), an area in the posterior wall of the pharynx between the cricopharyngeus and thyropharyngeus (the 2 parts of the inferior constrictors). The pathogenesis of Zenker diverticulum is not entirely clear, but it is thought to be associated with altered function of the upper esophageal sphincter, esophageal dysmotility, or esophageal shortening. This dysfunction leads to impaired bolus passage and increased intraluminal pressure. As a result, the mucosa and submucosa emerge through a natural area of weakness, the Killian's triangle. In contrast to a Meckel diverticulum, a Zenker diverticulum is a false diverticula which contains only mucosa and submucosa. Patients typically present with complaints of dysphagia, regurgitation, halitosis (bad breath), and occasionally an observed neck mass. Possible complications include aspiration pneumonia, ulceration and bleeding (due to retained oral medications), fistula formation, and vocal cord paralysis (pressure buildup from retained food). Squamous cell carcinoma in the diverticulum is a rare complication.  

 



Option Analysis

❌ A:
Incorrect: This area is the junction between the superior and middle pharyngeal constrictors muscles. It is not involved in the pathogenesis of Zenker's diverticulum.      
❌ B:
Incorrect: This area is the junction between the middle and inferior pharyngeal constrictors muscles. It is not involved in the pathogenesis of Zenker's diverticulum.  
❌ C:
Incorrect: This is the thyropharyngeus part muscle, the upper part of the inferior pharyngeal constrictors muscle. However, Zenker's diverticulum occurs below this muscle.  
✅ D:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ E:
Incorrect: This is the cricopharyngeus muscle, the lower part of the inferior pharyngeal constrictor muscle. However, Zenker's diverticulum occurs above this muscle.  
❌ F:
Incorrect: This is the junction between the circular and longitudinal fibers of the esophagus. This area is not involved in Zenker's diverticulum formation.  
❌ G:
Incorrect: This is the junction between the left and right longitudinal fibers of the esophagus. This area is not involved in Zenker's diverticulum formation.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with acute epigastric pain, dark stools, and lightheadedness. The patient reports abdominal pain over the past several weeks, but today the pain acutely worsened after eating breakfast. She reports passing out in the bathroom after passing a large volume of dark stool. Medical history includes hypertension and chronic gastroesophageal reflux. Temperature is 37 °C (98.6 °F), pulse is 111/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 104/62 mmHg. Physical examination shows tenderness on palpation of the epigastrium. The patient undergoes emergent upper endoscopy which reveals active bleeding just distal to the pylorus. Which of the following vascular structures is most likely implicated as a consequence of this patient’s disease process?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with melena, syncope, and acute on chronic abdominal pain with an endoscopy demonstrating bleeding just distal to the pylorus, concerning for a bleeding duodenal ulcer. Hemorrhage is the most common complication of peptic ulcer disease, and the most commonly implicated communicating artery in this anatomic region is the gastroduodenal artery, which runs just posterior to the duodenum.  

Bleeding is more likely to occur when ulcers penetrate the posterior surface of the stomach or duodenum. The most common gastric ulcers implicated in bleeding tend to affect the left gastric artery located on the lesser curvature of the stomach. Gastric ulcers may also erode into the splenic, short gastric, or gastroepiploic arteries depending on their anatomic location. Conversely, duodenal ulcers classically erode into the gastroduodenal artery.

Bleeding ulcers usually require treatment during endoscopy, including injection therapy, thermal coagulation, hemostatic clips, or a combination of treatments. Additionally, patients should be managed with the usual treatment of upper gastrointestinal bleeding, including proton pump inhibitor therapy.  

Option Analysis

✅ Gastroduodenal artery:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Left gastric artery:
Incorrect: The left gastric artery runs along the lesser curvature of the stomach and is the most commonly implicated artery in gastric ulcers. This patient’s bleeding is post-pyloric.  
❌ Right gastroepiploic artery  :
Incorrect: The right gastroepiploic artery runs along the medial border of the greater curvature of the stomach and is more commonly implicated in gastric ulcers. However, this is an uncommon site for gastric ulcers to form.   
❌ Splenic artery:
Incorrect: The splenic artery arises from the celiac trunk and runs along the posterior border of the stomach. Ulcers that arise on the posterior border of the stomach may erode into this artery, causing bleeding. However, this patient’s bleeding is post-pyloric.  
❌ Left gastroepiploic artery:
Incorrect: The left gastroepiploic artery runs along the lateral border of the greater curvature of the stomach and is more commonly implicated in gastric ulcers. However, this is an uncommon site for gastric ulcers to form. Moreover, this patient’s bleeding is post-pyloric.

questions.text:
A 63-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her partner due to progressive lethargy and confusion. The patient was recently diagnosed with metastatic small cell carcinoma of the lung and has refused all treatment, wishing to pursue only “comfort care measures.” She has been smoking a pack of cigarettes per day for the last 45 years. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Serum studies show the following:  
 
 Laboratory value  Result 
 Sodium   108 mEq/L 
 Potassium   4.2 mEq/L 
 Chloride   95 mEq/L 
 Creatinine   0.9 mg/dL 
 Albumin   3.2 g/dL 

The patient is started on hypertonic saline. On the second day of treatment, the partner notices the patient is unable to move, but she is able to blink in response to questions. Which of the following is the most likely location of the brain lesion in this patient?

 

Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
This patient has quadriplegia with sparing of eye blinking after correction of hyponatremia using hypertonic saline. She likely experienced central pontine myelinolysis.  

This patient’s hyponatremia developed secondary to ectopic antidiuretic hormone secretion by the underlying small cell lung cancer. In patients with hyponatremia, water moves from the blood into the brain, causing brain cells (primarily astrocytes) to swell. The brain cells are able to adapt to hyponatremia by losing inorganic (e.g., electrolytes) and organic (e.g., myoinositol, taurine, glutamine) osmolytes to reestablish normal cell volume.  

When patients are treated rapidly with hypertonic saline, the hyperosmolar environment causes reversal of the initial adaptation, with water flowing from cells into the intravascular space to achieve isotonicity. This results in rapid cellular dehydration; astrocytes and oligodendroglia do not have sufficient time to actively replace osmolytes within the cell, resulting in cellular apoptosis and death.   

The pons is particularly susceptible, and cell death here causes central pontine myelinolysis (also termed osmotic demyelination syndrome). Clinical features typically appear after 2-6 days of hypertonic saline treatment. Symptoms include quadriplegia and pseudobulbar palsy (dysfunction of cranial nerves IX, X, and XI), which can manifest with dysphagia and dysarthria. Central pontine myelinolysis can also cause locked-in syndrome, in which there is paralysis of most of the body’s voluntary muscles but with preservation of vertical eye movements and the ability to blink.   

Option Analysis

❌ Location A:
Incorrect: Lesions in the frontal lobe can present with disinhibition as well as deficits in concentration and orientation. However, frontal lobe lesions would not result in diffuse paralysis with sparing of eye blinking.
❌ Location B:
Incorrect: The corpus callosum connects the left and right cerebral hemispheres, enabling communication between the two halves. Lesions due to diseases in the corpus callosum are uncommon; however, in refractory epilepsy, treatment can include surgically severing the corpus callosum. 
❌ Location C:
Incorrect: Cerebellar lesions can result in ataxia. Lateral lesions affect voluntary movement of extremities whereas medial lesions (e.g. in the vermis) can result in truncal ataxia and nystagmus. This patient is presenting with quadriplegia, which cannot be accounted for by a cerebellar lesion alone.
✅ Location D:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Location E:
Incorrect: Lesions in the medulla can result in lateral medullary (Wallenburg) syndrome, which would present as ipsilateral paralysis of cranial nerves IX, X, and XI, as well as contralateral loss of pain and temperature. Quadriplegia, as seen in this patient, would be highly unlikely.

questions.text: A 26-year-old man comes to the emergency department for evaluation of left eye pain and swelling for three hours. He was brought in by local police following an altercation at a bar, where he was punched in the left eye. He reports that he has double vision when looking upward. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 94/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 132/84 mmHg. On examination, the left orbit is ecchymotic with associated swelling. Pupils are equal and reactive to light, and visual acuity is 20/20 bilaterally. Neurologic evaluation demonstrates diminished sensation of the skin to fine touch at the left lower eyelid and left anterior cheek. A CT scan of the face reveals a fracture of the floor of the left orbit with entrapment of orbital contents in the left maxillary sinus. Injury to which of the following nerves is the most likely etiology of this patient’s sensory deficits?
questions.solution:
Orbital fractures occur when one or more of the fragile bones composing the orbit break. They are classified into several types including orbital rim fractures, orbital roof fractures, and orbital floor fractures, which are also known as blowout fractures. Patients with orbital floor fractures almost always have a history of blunt trauma to the orbit (e.g., assault, motor vehicle accident, sports-related trauma).  

Symptoms of an orbital floor fracture include unilateral periorbital pain, edema and ecchymoses, enophthalmos (a posterior displacement of the eyeball), or proptosis (anterior displacement of the eyeball). If eye movement is restricted due to entrapment of the inferior rectus muscle, diplopia and pain may occur during eye movements. An entrapped inferior rectus keeps the affected eye in a downward position, leading to diplopia with attempted upward gaze. In severe fractures, the infraorbital or supraorbital nerves can be involved, resulting in numbness below the eye or forehead respectively. Injury to the infraorbital nerve results in decreased sensation along the cheek, upper lip, and upper gingiva.


Left orbital floor fracture  
Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons 

Option Analysis

✅ Infraorbital nerve:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Buccal nerve:
Incorrect: The buccal nerve is a branch of the mandibular nerve that transmits sensory information from skin over the buccal membrane and from the second and third molars.
❌ Supraorbital nerve:
Incorrect: The supraorbital nerve provides sensory innervation to the skin of the lateral forehead and upper eyelid, as well as the conjunctiva of the upper eyelid and mucosa of the frontal sinus.
❌ Supratrochlear nerve:
Incorrect: The supratrochlear nerve is a branch of the frontal nerve, which provides sensory innervation to the skin of the forehead and upper eyelid.
❌ Zygomatic nerve:
Incorrect: The zygomatic nerve is a branch of the maxillary nerve, which provides sensory innervation to the skin over the zygomatic and temporal bones.

questions.text:
A 74-year-old right-handed woman is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of sudden onset weakness in the left upper extremity. The patient does not have syncope, dizziness, or urinary incontinence. Past medical history includes hypertension and diabetes, for which she is taking lisinopril and metformin. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 92/min, and blood pressure is 158/104 mmHg. The patient is alert and oriented. Physical examination reveals conjugate gaze deviation to the right. There is 3/5 strength in the left upper extremity and 4/5 strength in the left lower extremity. Magnetic resonance angiography (MRA) is performed and shown below:


Reproduced from: Radiopaedia  

A lesion in which of the following anatomic locations explains this patient’s ocular findings?
questions.solution:
A middle cerebral artery (MCA) stroke affects the cortical homunculus for the hands, arms, face, causing contralateral upper extremity weakness and sensory loss. Symptoms vary depending on the hemisphere affected, with language disorders seen with strokes in the dominant hemisphere, or hemineglect seen with strokes in the non-dominant hemisphere. In addition, the frontal eye fields (FEF) are located in the cerebral cortex, so associated visual defects are commonly observed. If a middle cerebral artery stroke implicates a frontal eye field, the other eye field predominates, so the eyes deviate to the side affected (eyes look toward the lesion). In this patient, a right-sided MCA lesion (depicted by the yellow arrow) caused left-sided hemiparesis and damage to the right FEF, resulting in right-sided gaze preference.


Reproduced from: Radiopaedia

Option Analysis

❌ Left frontal eye field:
Incorrect: If a stroke affects a frontal eye field, the affected eye field predominates, so eyes deviate towards the side affected; in this case, the patient’s eyes are deviated to the right, meaning that the left frontal eye field is intact.
❌ Left medial longitudinal fasciculus:
Incorrect: A left medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF) lesion results in internuclear ophthalmoplegia, characterized by impaired horizontal eye movement with slow, weak adduction of the affected eye and abduction nystagmus of the contralateral eye. This patient’s associated hemiparesis suggests damage to a different anatomic location.
❌ Left paramedian pontine reticular formation:
Incorrect: The paramedian pontine reticular formation refers to a region of the reticular formation immediately ventral to the abducens nucleus, which contains neurons critical for generating horizontal saccades. Damage to the left paramedian pontine reticular formation will prevent the movement of either eye to the left.
❌ Right medial longitudinal fasciculus:
Incorrect: A right medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF) lesion results in internuclear ophthalmoplegia, which is characterized by impaired horizontal eye movement with slow, weak adduction of the affected eye and abduction nystagmus of the contralateral eye. This patient’s associated hemiparesis suggests damage to a different anatomic location.
✅ Right frontal eye field:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Right paramedian pontine reticular formation:
Incorrect: The right paramedian pontine reticular formation refers to a region of the reticular formation immediately ventral to the abducens nucleus, which contains neurons critical for generating horizontal saccades. Damage to the right paramedian pontine reticular formation will prevent the movement of either eye to the right.

questions.text: The spermatic cord contains structures running to and from the testis and suspends the testis in the scrotum. Which of the following statements regarding the spermatic cord is true?

choices.text: Internal spermatic fascia is derived from the transversalis fascia.
Cremasteric fascia is derived from the external oblique muscle.
External spermatic fascia is derived from scarpa fascia.
Colles fascia is derived from transversalis fascia.
Dartos fascia is derived from scarpa fascia.

questions.solution:
The spermatic cord contains structures running to and from the testis and suspends the testis in the scrotum. The spermatic cord begins at the deep inguinal ring lateral to the inferior epigastric vessels, passes through the inguinal canal, exits at the superficial inguinal ring, and ends in the scrotum at the posterior border of the testis. Fascial coverings derived from the anterolateral abdominal wall surround the spermatic cord during prenatal development.

The coverings of the spermatic cord from deep to superficial are the internal spermatic fascia (derived from the transversalis fascia), cremasteric fascia (derived from aponeurosis of the internal oblique muscle), and external spermatic fascia (derived from aponeurosis of the external oblique muscle).  



Option Analysis

✅ Internal spermatic fascia is derived from the transversalis fascia.   :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Cremasteric fascia is derived from the external oblique muscle.:
Incorrect: The cremasteric fascia is derived from the internal oblique muscle.  
❌ External spermatic fascia is derived from scarpa fascia.  :
Incorrect: The external spermatic fascia is derived from the aponeurosis of the external oblique muscle. In contrast, scarpa fascia is a membranous layer in the anterior abdominal wall.  
❌ Colles fascia is derived from transversalis fascia.  :
Incorrect: The colles fascia is not a part of the spermatic cord. In contrast, the three fascial layers that make up the spermatic cord are the internal spermatic, cremasteric, and external spermatic fascia.  
❌ Dartos fascia is derived from scarpa fascia.  :
Incorrect: The dartos fascia is a layer of connective tissue within the penis. The dartos fascia is not a part of the spermatic cord.

questions.text: A patient’s arm is held in flexion, and a reflex hammer strikes the posterior aspect of the elbow, which causes a subsequent contraction in the triceps muscle. Which of the following nerve roots is/are being tested in the maneuver?
questions.solution:
The following table outlines the upper extremity reflex arcs, with their associated nerve roots.  



Option Analysis

✅ C7-C8  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ C5-C6  :
Incorrect: The C5-C6 nerve roots create the reflex arc responsible for the brachioradialis and brachialis reflexes. In contrast, the test described above evaluated the triceps reflex.  
❌ C8-T1  :
Incorrect: C8-T1 does not refer to any upper extremity reflex arc.  
❌ C7  :
Incorrect: C7 alone does not create the triceps reflex arc.  
❌ C4-C5  :
Incorrect: C4-C5 does not refer to any upper extremity reflex arc.

questions.text: The central nervous system is composed of the cerebrum, cerebellum, brainstem, and spinal cord. Furthermore, the brainstem can be divided into the medulla oblongata, pons, and midbrain. Which of the following statements regarding the brainstem is true?

choices.text: The substantia nigra is located in the tectum of the midbrain.
The superior colliculus relays voluntary and involuntary eye movements.
The inferior colliculus project to the lateral geniculate bodies.
The inferior olivary nucleus is located in the tegmentum of the midbrain.
The red nucleus forms part of the subcortical visual system.

questions.solution:
The superior and inferior colliculus are located in the tectum of the midbrain, which is posterior to the cerebral aqueduct and forms the roof of the midbrain.    

The superior colliculus relays voluntary and involuntary eye movements (e.g. saccades), facilitates optic reflexes, receives input from the retina and pretectal area, and projects to the lateral geniculate bodies.   

In contrast, the inferior colliculus is a part of the auditory pathway. It receives input from the lateral lemniscus and projects to the medial geniculate bodies.



Option Analysis

❌ The substantia nigra is located in the tectum of the midbrain.:
Incorrect: The substantia nigra is located in the tegmentum of the midbrain. 
✅ The superior colliculus relays voluntary and involuntary eye movements.:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ The inferior colliculus project to the lateral geniculate bodies.:
Incorrect: The inferior colliculus projects to the medial geniculate bodies. 
❌ The inferior olivary nucleus is located in the tegmentum of the midbrain.:
Incorrect: The inferior olivary nucleus is located in the medulla oblongata, instead of the midbrain. 
❌ The red nucleus forms part of the subcortical visual system.:
Incorrect: The red nucleus is part of the extrapyramidal motor system. In contrast, it is not part of the subcortical visual system.

questions.text:
A 64-year-old man comes to the office for the evaluation of a mass on the right side of his groin. The patient first noted the mass after helping his daughter move to a new home. He reports sharp discomfort in the right groin worsens with walking and heavy lifting. Resting supine decreases the severity of the pain. Past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include atorvastatin and metformin. BMI is 37 kg/m2. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a bulge in the right groin above the inguinal ligament which increases in size when the patient coughs. There is no overlying erythema or warmth. The patient is referred to a surgeon and scheduled for a laparoscopic repair.



Which of the following landmarks will help the surgeon to differentiate a direct versus an indirect inguinal hernia?
questions.solution:
This patient with an examination finding of a bulge in the right groin above the inguinal ligament has most likely developed an inguinal hernia. Inguinal hernias are located above the inguinal ligament. They are classified into direct and indirect hernias. The inferior epigastric vessels are easily visible during laparoscopic hernia repair and are an important landmark to differentiate between the two types of inguinal hernias.

Direct inguinal hernias result from weakness of the transversalis fascia, which makes up the floor of the Hesselbach triangle. Other boundaries include the inferior epigastric vessels laterally, the inguinal ligament inferiorly, and the rectus abdominis muscle medially.

Indirect inguinal hernias are the most common type of groin hernia and result from a patent processus vaginalis. They are bounded medially by the inferior epigastric artery. The herniated abdominal contents enter through the deep inguinal ring into the inguinal canal and exit through the superficial inguinal ring. The deep inguinal ring is an oval opening in the transversalis fascia located at the midpoint of the inguinal ligament (between the anterior superior iliac spine and the pubic tubercle).

Option Analysis

❌ A:
Incorrect: Structure A represents the inguinal ligament, which stretches from the anterior superior iliac spine to the pubic tubercle. It is an important landmark to differentiate between inguinal and femoral hernias but cannot differentiate between direct and indirect inguinal hernias.
❌ B:
Incorrect: Structure B represents the transversalis fascia, which forms the posterior wall of inguinal canal, and its weakness can result in the development of direct inguinal hernia. However, the transversalis fascia is not used for inguinal hernia differentiation.
✅ C:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ D:
Incorrect: Structure D represents the deep inguinal ring, which is the entrance site of the inguinal canal. It is found above the midpoint of the inguinal ligament, lateral to the epigastric vessels.
❌ E:
Incorrect: Structure E represents the spermatic cord. Indirect inguinal hernias follow the path of the spermatic cord via the deep inguinal ring. However, the spermatic cord is not used for inguinal hernia differentiation..

questions.text: A 67-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of visual impairment. The patient has not had headache, trauma, or difficulty with speech, swallowing, or walking. Past medical history is significant for coronary artery disease, hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 120/min (irregularly irregular), respirations are 17/min and blood pressure is 160/90 mm Hg. On neurological examination, the patient is alert and oriented to person, place, and time. Speech is fluent, and the patient follows all commands. Visual field examination findings are shown below.  The remainder of the neurological examination is within normal limits. Perfusion of which of the following regions of the brain is most likely impaired in this patient?

choices.text: Posterior limb of the internal capsule

questions.solution:
This patient presents with evidence of contralateral hemianopia with macular sparing–consistent with a stroke of the occipital lobe, supplied by the posterior cerebral artery (PCA).    

The PCA branches off the basilar artery at the level of pontomesencephalic junction and supplies CN III, IV, and midbrain structures. It also supplies the occipital lobe (which contains the primary visual cortex), thalamus, medial temporal lobe, splenium of corpus callosum, parahippocampal gyrus, and fusiform gyrus.    

The primary visual cortex of each hemisphere receives information regarding contralateral visual fields from the ipsilateral geniculate nucleus via optic radiations. Occlusion of the PCA most commonly leads to ischemic injury to the ipsilateral primary visual cortex, producing contralateral hemianopia with macular sparing. The macula is spared because of the collateral blood supply by the middle cerebral artery to the occipital lobe, which processes central visual information.  

Implication of the lateral thalamus can result in contralateral paresthesias and numbness affecting the face, trunk, and limbs. Moreover, a variety of cortical symptoms including dyslexia, visual agnosia (impaired visual recognition of objects), and prosopagnosia (inability to recognize faces) can also occur. 

Option Analysis

❌ Posterolateral thalamus:
Incorrect: A pure sensory stroke is caused by diminished perfusion of the ventral posterolateral and/or ventral posteromedial nucleus of the thalamus. This anatomic region of the brain relays sensory information regarding proprioception, pain, pressure, and temperature to the primary somatosensory cortex. Affected individuals present with unilateral-sided numbness of the face and body (contralateral to the affected side of the thalamus). 
❌ Parietal lobe:
Incorrect: Diminished perfusion of the parietal lobe results from occlusion of the anterior cerebral artery (ACA) and/or middle cerebral artery (MCA). Occlusion of the ACA or MCA may result in numbness; however, a stroke of the nondominant side more commonly manifests with symptoms of contralateral neglect. Meanwhile, infarction of the dominant side manifests with aphasia, finger agnosia, agraphia, or dyscalculia.  
✅ Occipital lobe:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Posterior limb of the internal capsule:
Incorrect: Infarction of the posterior limb of the internal capsule results in a pure motor stroke, the most common lacunar stroke (> 50%). Patients typically present with contralateral hemiparesis without sensory loss or cortical signs (e.g. aphasia).  
❌ Medial medulla:
Incorrect: Infarction of the paramedian branches of the anterior spinal artery results in medial medullary syndrome. This condition usually presents with contralateral hemiparesis (lateral corticospinal tract), decreased contralateral proprioception (medial lemniscus), and ipsilateral tongue paralysis (hypoglossal nucleus).

questions.text: A 77-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of left-sided numbness and unsteady gait. The patient was having dinner with family one hour ago when she suddenly developed numbness in the left side of her body and could no longer sense the temperature of her food. Past medical history includes diabetes mellitus type II, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia. The patient takes metformin, glipizide, amlodipine, losartan, and atorvastatin. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 102/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 190/100 mmHg. Neurological examination demonstrates deficits in touch, two-point discrimination, pain, and temperature on the left side of the body and face. Motor strength and speech are normal. Romberg sign is positive. An ischemic stroke involving which of the following areas of the brain is the most likely cause of her clinical findings?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with sudden-onset, unilateral sensory deficits (touch, two-point discrimination, pain, and temperature) without cortical signs or motor deficits. A positive Romberg test suggests an additional deficit in proprioception. This presentation is suggestive of a pure sensory stroke involving the thalamic nuclei.  

The thalamus is a component of the diencephalon that lies on either side of the third ventricle and serves as the site of integration of somatosensory information. The thalamic nuclei include the ventral posteromedial nucleus (VPM) and the ventral posterolateral nucleus (VPL). The former receives afferent neuronal fibers from the trigeminal lemniscus and the gustatory pathway, while the latter receives afferent information from the dorsal column pathway (medial and lateral lemniscus) and from the lateral spinothalamic tract. These pathways carry sensory information regarding vibration, proprioception, pressure, pain, taste, light touch, and temperature. Efferent neuronal fibers from these nuclei terminate in the primary somatosensory cortex.  

Clinical manifestations of an ischemic thalamic stroke include loss of touch, pain, temperature, vibration, proprioception, and tactile discrimination over the contralateral half of the body (including sensory loss over the contralateral side of the face without motor deficits or cortical signs). Thalamic lesions are frequently the result of a lacunar stroke (small vessel microatheroma or lipohyalinosis). Risk factors for these lesions include hypertension, diabetes, and hyperlipidemia (all of which are present in this patient).  



Option Analysis

❌ Hypothalamus:
Incorrect: The hypothalamus is the site of regulation of temperature, hunger, satiety, endocrine functions, circadian rhythm, emotion, behavior, and sexual drive. It is not involved in relaying somatosensory information.
✅ Thalamus:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Posterior limb of internal capsule:
Incorrect: Internal capsule is a subcortical white matter structure that relays sensory-motor information from the brainstem and contralateral body to the brain. Strokes involving the posterior limb of the internal capsule present with pure motor or mixed sensory-motor deficits, as opposed to pure sensory deficits. 
❌ Brainstem:
Incorrect: Stroke syndromes involving the brainstem are accompanied by signs and symptoms of autonomic, corticospinal (motor), and/or cranial nerve(s) involvement. Pure sensory deficits are not usually seen.
❌ Cerebral cortex:
Incorrect: Cortical strokes involving the somatosensory areas of the brain can be differentiated from thalamic strokes by the presence of cortical symptoms, which include aphasia, neglect, and behavioral changes.

questions.text:
A 33-year-old man presents to the emergency department after sustaining an injury to the right middle finger. The patient was outside playing baseball with his friends when he sustained the injury. He is otherwise healthy and does not take any medications. Temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), blood pressure is 115/79 mmHg, and pulse is 102/min. Physical examination demonstrates an inability to extend the right middle finger's distal interphalangeal (DIP) joint. Flexion at the DIP joint of this digit is preserved. A picture of the patient’s hand is demonstrated below. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of injury associated with this pathology?  


Reproduced from: Wikipedia

choices.text: Direct force to the third digit held in extension
Lateral force applied to the third digit
Sudden hyperextension of the third digit held in flexion
Direct force applied to a clenched fist

questions.solution:
This patient presents with evidence of a mallet finger (baseball finger), which refers to an injury to the extensor digitorum as it crosses the distal interphalangeal (DIP) joint. The most common mechanism of injury associated with this pathology is a direct force to the digit held in extension. This injury pattern results in an inability to extend the finger at the DIP joint.

Mallet finger is the most common closed tendon injury of the finger and is a common injury pattern in baseball players. The mechanism of injury involves a direct force to a digit held in extension, such as when a baseball strikes the distal end of the finger resulting in forced flexion of the DIP joint. Clinically, this manifests with pain and swelling over the dorsum of the DIP joint, DIP flexion deformity, and an inability to extend the DIP joint actively.

Treatment for a simple mallet finger (without an associated fracture) involves splinting the finger in extension for six to eight weeks. If left in flexion, the finger is more prone to developing osteoarthritis or a swan neck deformity. If the mallet finger is associated with a fracture, surgical referral, in addition to splinting, is indicated.

Option Analysis

✅ Direct force to the third digit held in extension  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Lateral force applied to the third digit  :
Incorrect: A lateral force applied to the third digit would likely result in a dislocation injury, manifesting with difficulty both flexing and extending the affected joint.  
❌ Fall on an outstretched hand  :
Incorrect: Wrist pathologies (e.g., scaphoid fracture, distal radius fracture) can arise following a fall onto an outstretched hand (“FOOSH” injury). In contrast, this patient presents with drooping and an inability to extend the fingertip, which is more consistent with a mallet finger.  
❌ Sudden hyperextension of the third digit held in flexion  :
Incorrect: This mechanism of action will result in injury to the flexor digitorum profundus tendon as it crosses the distal interphalangeal joint. Patients with this injury pattern will extend, but not flex, the fingertip.  
❌ Direct force applied to a clenched fist  :
Incorrect: A direct force applied to a clenched fist will often fracture the fifth metacarpal. This fracture pattern is termed a boxer fracture. In contrast, this patient presents with drooping and an inability to extend the fingertip, which is more consistent with a mallet finger.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman comes to the emergency room for evaluation of palpitations. An electrocardiogram is performed and demonstrates sinus tachycardia. A carotid sinus massage is completed, and the patient’s heart rate decreases from 180/min to 100/min. Which of the following is true regarding the response seen in this patient?

choices.text: Afferent signals from the carotid body are transmitted via the glossopharyngeal nerve, while efferent impulses (the response) are transmitted via the vagus nerve.
Afferent signals from the carotid body and efferent signals to the aortic arch baroreceptors are transmitted via the vagus nerve.
Afferent signals from the carotid body are transmitted via the vagus nerve, while the efferent impulses (the response) are transmitted via the glossopharyngeal nerve.
Afferent signals from the carotid body and efferent signals (the response) are transmitted via the glossopharyngeal nerve.
Afferent signals from the carotid body are transmitted via the glossopharyngeal nerve, while the efferent impulses (the response) are transmitted via the accessory nerve.

questions.solution:
Baroreceptors are sensory receptors that detect changes in blood pressure and can modulate autonomic control of the heart and blood vessels through sympathetic and parasympathetic output. Baroreceptors are located within the carotid sinus and aortic arch. The glossopharyngeal nerve carries afferent impulses from the carotid sinus, whereas the vagus nerve carries afferent signals from the aortic arch. Signals from these receptors are relayed to the nucleus tractus solitarius (NTS) in the medulla. Autonomic output from the NTS is distributed via parasympathetic fibers of the vagus nerve or the sympathetic nervous system, depending on whether the body is trying to increase or decrease blood pressure.  



Baroreceptors in the carotid sinus and aortic arch are activated and send afferent impulses to the NTS. Efferent sympathetic fibers then relay signals from the NTS to the rest of the body, causing alterations in vasoconstriction, heart rate, and cardiac contractility. For instance, in cases of hypotension, there is diminished arterial stretch, which is noted by the baroreceptors, prompting a sympathetic response.  

In contrast, hypertension causes increased stretching of the arterial walls and baroreceptors. Signals are then forwarded to the NTS. Efferent parasympathetic output is relayed by the vagus nerve to the heart, resulting in bradycardia.  

Carotid sinus massage is a maneuver that can diagnose and treat supraventricular tachycardias such as atrioventricular reentrant tachycardia (AVRT) and AV nodal reentrant tachycardia (AVNRT). Pressure on the carotid sinus stretches the carotid sinus and baroreceptor activation. These changes increase parasympathetic output via the vagus nerve, slowing sinus node impulse formation and lengthening the AV node refractory period. These changes can potentially terminate an abnormal rhythm.  



Option Analysis

✅ Afferent signals from the carotid body are transmitted via the glossopharyngeal nerve, while efferent impulses (the response) are transmitted via the vagus nerve.:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Afferent signals from the carotid body and efferent signals to the aortic arch baroreceptors are transmitted via the vagus nerve.:
Incorrect: This patient demonstrated the baroreceptor reflex, in which the glossopharyngeal nerve transmits afferent information from the carotid body to the nucleus tractus solitarius. The vagus nerve then transmits efferent signals from the nucleus tractus solitarius to the aortic arch baroreceptors.  
❌ Afferent signals from the carotid body are transmitted via the vagus nerve, while the efferent impulses (the response) are transmitted via the glossopharyngeal nerve.:
Incorrect: This patient demonstrated the baroreceptor reflex, in which afferent signals from the carotid body are transmitted via the glossopharyngeal nerve, and subsequent efferent signals (the response) to the aortic arch baroreceptors are transmitted via the vagus nerve.  
❌ Afferent signals from the carotid body and efferent signals (the response) are transmitted via the glossopharyngeal nerve. :
Incorrect: In the baroreceptor reflex, efferent signals from the nucleus tractus solitarius are transmitted to the heart via the vagus nerve, not the glossopharyngeal nerve.  
❌ Afferent signals from the carotid body are transmitted via the glossopharyngeal nerve, while the efferent impulses (the response) are transmitted via the accessory nerve.    :
Incorrect: The accessory nerve (cranial nerve XI) is a pure motor nerve with no parasympathetic input. In contrast, the vagus nerve mediates the efferent response in the baroreceptor reflex.

questions.text: A 33-year-old man presents to his primary care physician to evaluate low back pain. The patient was helping his sibling lift furniture yesterday when he experienced acute onset low back pain, requiring him to lay in bed the remainder of the day. The patient is otherwise healthy and does not take any medications. The patient has tenderness to palpation over the lumbar spine on physical examination. Strength is 5/5 with foot dorsiflexion, toe extension, and foot inversion and eversion in the right lower extremity, while 4/5 in the left lower extremity. Sensation is also diminished on the lateral aspect of the left lower extremity compared to that of the right side. Which of the following is the most likely affected nerve root responsible for this patient’s clinical findings?
questions.solution:
This patient with low back pain and loss of sensation down the lateral aspect of the leg into the foot with associated diminished foot dorsiflexion, toe extension, and foot inversion and eversion is most likely suffering from L5 radiculopathy.  

Lumbar and cervical disc herniations are common musculoskeletal back pathologies that result from herniation of the nucleus pulposus and compression of the nerve root. In general, symptoms include focal back pain with associated radiation of pain, weakness, and sensory disturbance in the anatomic distribution of the compromised nerve root. Overall, the most common site of lumbar disc herniation is the L4-L5 vertebral level, which produces symptoms of pain and loss of sensation down the lateral aspect of the leg into the foot with associated weakness in foot dorsiflexion, toe extension, foot inversion, and foot eversion.  



In the cervical spine, the most common site of disc herniation is the C6-C7 vertebral level, which compresses the C7 nerve root. Herniation at this site presents with pain in the neck, shoulder, middle finger, and hand, along with weakness with elbow and wrist extension, forearm pronation, and wrist flexion. 

Option Analysis

❌ C7:
Incorrect: A disc herniation at C6-C7 would result in C7 nerve root compression, causing pain in the neck, shoulder, middle finger, and hand, as well as weakness with elbow and wrist extension, forearm pronation, and wrist flexion.  
❌ T10:
Incorrect: Thoracic disc herniation is overall uncommon compared to lumbar or cervical disc herniation. A lesion at this site would result in pain that radiates towards the umbilicus.  
❌ L2-L4:
Incorrect: L2-L4 radiculopathy often presents with pain and diminished sensation radiating down the anterior aspect of the thigh and occasionally into the medial part of the lower leg with associated weakness of hip flexion, knee extension, and hip adduction.  
✅ L5:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ S1:
Incorrect: S1 radiculopathy presents with pain and diminished sensation that radiates down the posterior aspect of the leg, with associated weakness of plantar flexion, leg extension, and knee flexion, along with a reduced ankle jerk reflex.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician for evaluation of difficulty walking and recurrent falls. The patient states, “I’m not sure what’s wrong with me. I just can’t seem to keep my balance. I just feel like I’m in a fog all day.” The patient also has numbness and tingling in the tips of her fingers and toes. Her past medical history includes hypothyroidism, type II diabetes mellitus, and hypertension. The patient currently takes levothyroxine, amlodipine, and metformin. She works as a school teacher and drinks 3-4 glasses of wine per day. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates an ataxic gait and 3+ reflexes in the upper and lower extremities. The patient has diminished two-point discrimination in the upper extremities with preservation of pinprick sensation. This patient's clinical presentation reflects damage to which of the following anatomic sites?

choices.text: Spinocerebellar tracts, lateral corticospinal tracts, and dorsal columns
Anterior, lateral corticospinal tracts, and anterior white commissure

questions.solution:
This patient presents with multiple risk factors for developing vitamin B12 deficiency (cobalamin), including chronic alcohol use and metformin use. Additionally, the physical examination demonstrates dysfunction of the spinocerebellar, lateral corticospinal, and dorsal column pathways, consistent with subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord.    

Several spinal cord pathologies can be identified via a careful neurological examination to reveal the affected spinal cord tract(s). For example, subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord results when vitamin B12 (cobalamin) is absent or deficient. It may become deficient due to malabsorptive disease (e.g., Crohn disease, pernicious anemia), dietary restriction (e.g. veganism), or medications that interfere with cobalamin absorption (e.g., metformin, proton pump inhibitors). When physiologic stores of vitamin B12 are low, levels of methylmalonic acid increase, which causes degeneration of the myelin sheath of the spinocerebellar, lateral corticospinal, and dorsal column pathways, resulting in subacute combined degeneration (SCD). SCD manifests with symptoms of gait ataxia, paresthesias, and impaired position/vibration sense. Furthermore, SCD can cause psychiatric symptoms, including worsening depression or signs of dementia.    

Additional noteworthy patterns of spinal cord pathologies include Brown-Sequard syndrome, syringomyelia, and tabes dorsalis. Brown-Sequard syndrome is a rare asymmetrical spinal cord injury pattern that occurs following a stab wound, penetrating injury, or, less commonly, fracture or blunt trauma. It results in ipsilateral loss of motor function, vibration, and proprioception due to the dorsal columns and corticospinal tract damage. In addition, contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation occurs at one or two levels below the lesion due to injury of the spinothalamic tracts (which decussate at the anterior commissure). Brown-Sequard syndrome may also be associated with Horner syndrome (ptosis, miosis, and anhidrosis) if the lesion occurs above the T1 level and causes damage to the oculosympathetic pathway.    

Syringomyelia describes a cystic cavity within the spinal cord, usually within the central canal, that can expand over time and compress the anterior white commissure, a structure directly anterior to the cervical canal. The anterior white commissure is the decussation site for the spinothalamic tracts, relaying pain and temperature sensation. As a result, syringomyelia causes a "cape-like," bilateral, symmetrical loss of pain and temperature sensation in the upper extremities. Syringomyelia is associated with Chiari I malformation, a congenital condition characterized by abnormally shaped cerebellar tonsils that herniate below the level of the foramen magnum.  

Lastly, tabes dorsalis arises due to infection of the central nervous system (CNS) by Treponema pallidum, the spirochete that causes syphilis. Tertiary infection of the spinal cord leads to demyelination and degeneration of the dorsal column and roots, resulting in findings of gait ataxia and incoordination. The condition takes nearly 20 years to develop after the initial infection.  

Option Analysis

✅ Spinocerebellar tracts, lateral corticospinal tracts, and dorsal columns  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Anterior white commissure  :
Incorrect: Chiari I malformation is characterized by cerebellar tonsillar ectopia and is most commonly associated with a syrinx within the spinal cord. Most cases are asymptomatic. In symptomatic patients, the condition can result in a bilateral, symmetrical loss of pain and temperature sensation in the upper extremities due to impingement on the anterior white commissure.  
❌ Dorsal columns and roots  :
Incorrect: Tabes dorsalis is a manifestation of tertiary neurosyphilis and is characterized by degenerative changes of the dorsal column of the spinal cord. Tabes dorsalis would not typically present with signs of spastic paralysis. 
❌ Lumbar spinal roots  :
Incorrect: Cauda equina syndrome results from compression of spinal roots at the L2 level or below. It is usually due to a mass effect or a fracture. Cauda equina syndrome tends to present with radicular pain, urinary incontinence, and saddle anesthesia.  
❌ Anterior, lateral corticospinal tracts, and anterior white commissure :
Incorrect: Central cord syndrome commonly occurs due to forced hyperextension injury or syringomyelia. The condition results in sensory and motor deficits, with the upper extremities affected more than the lower extremities.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents to an urgent care clinic for evaluation of an ongoing nose bleed. He has been pinching his nose for approximately three hours, but the bleeding has persisted. Past medical history is notable for hypertension, and he has no known history of trauma or bleeding disorders. Upon arrival, temperature is 98.0°F (36.6°C), blood pressure is 168/85 mmHg, pulse is 75/min, respirations are 16/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Physical examination shows significant bleeding from both nostrils and draining to the back of the throat. Which of the following anatomical locations is the most likely etiology of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient has a history of hypertension and a presentation with ongoing epistaxis that has failed to stop despite applying pressure. He most likely has posterior epistaxis.  

Epistaxis can be divided into two categories: anterior epistaxis and posterior epistaxis. Anterior epistaxis makes up the majority of cases and usually causes mild to moderate bleeding. It originates from a region of the anterior nasal septum called the Kiesselbach plexus, formed via the anastomoses of the anterior ethmoidal, sphenopalatine, greater palatine, and superior labial artery. Anterior epistaxis can usually be managed by pinching the nasal alae together for at least 10 minutes while sitting upright. Vasoconstrictors (e.g. phenylephrine) and electrocautery may be needed in rare cases.
