Posterior epistaxis makes up around 10% of cases, typically presents in elderly patients and those with a history of hypertension, and manifests with more severe bleeding. It arises from bleeding from the Woodruff plexus, a vascular network formed by anastomoses between the sphenopalatine and posterior pharyngeal arteries. Treatment may involve electrocautery, nasal balloons, and posterior nasal packing. Sometimes, the internal maxillary artery and its branches must be ligated to control the bleeding.

Option Analysis

❌ Anterior ethmoidal artery:
Incorrect: The anterior ethmoidal artery is a branch of the ophthalmic artery. It gives off nasal branches that supply the lateral wall and septum of the nose. It contributes to the Kiesselbach plexus and is therefore responsible for anterior epistaxis. However, this patient has a history of persistent nasal bleeding over several hours, more consistent with posterior epistaxis.  
❌ Superior labial artery:
Incorrect: The superior labial artery is a branch of the facial artery. It gives off septal branches that supply the nasal septum and ala of the nose. It contributes to the Kiesselbach plexus and is therefore responsible for anterior epistaxis. However, this patient has a history of persistent nasal bleeding over several hours, more consistent with posterior epistaxis.  
❌ Maxillary artery:
Incorrect: The maxillary artery supplies the deep structures of the face. A terminal branch of the maxillary artery is the sphenopalatine artery, which supplies the Woodruff plexus. Bleeding from the Woodruff plexus can result in posterior epistaxis. However, the maxillary artery itself is not directly involved in posterior epistaxis. 
❌ Kiesselbach plexus:
Incorrect: The Kiesselbach plexus is a vascular network of four arteries that supply the nasal septum. Approximately 90% of nosebleeds occur in the Kiesselbach plexus. The Kiesselbach plexus is responsible for anterior epistaxis. In contrast, this patient has a history of persistent nasal bleeding over several hours, more consistent with posterior epistaxis.  
✅ Sphenopalatine artery:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man comes to the emergency department due to back pain and leg weakness. Two hours ago, the patient lifted a heavy box and suddenly felt severe back pain that radiates down to the toes. He reports chronic back pain for the past 2 years but has never experienced pain so severe. An MRI is obtained and reveals a posterolateral disc herniation at the level of the intervertebral disk between L4 and L5 vertebrae. Which of the following nerve roots would most likely be affected by this injury?
questions.solution:
Disc herniation is one of the most common causes of lumbosacral radiculopathy. The disc is composed of the inner nucleus pulposus and outer annulus fibrosus. In disc herniation, the nucleus pulposus extrudes through the annulus fibrosus into the vertebral canal, causing mechanical compression of the spinal cord and inflammation.  

The lumbosacral spine is especially susceptible to disc herniations because of its mobility. Up to 95% of injuries occur at the L4-L5 and L5-S1 levels. The lumbar and sacral spinal nerve roots exit the spinal cord at the T12-L1 vertebral level, where the spinal cord tapers as the conus medullaris. The nerves then travel down the canal as the cauda equina and exit at their respective neural foramina. The nerves can be compressed anywhere along their course depending on the type of herniation, size, and location. The most common type of herniation is posterolateral (paracentral), less common central, and rare far lateral. With the exception of C1-7 nerves, which exit above the corresponding vertebrae, and C8, which exit below C7, the rest of the spinal nerves exit below their corresponding vertebrae. Due to these reasons, a posterolateral disc herniation at the level of L4-5 vertebrae will compress the L5 nerve.




Option Analysis

❌ L3:
Incorrect: The L3 nerve root exits the spinal canal below the L3 vertebrae and therefore is spared.
❌ L4:
Incorrect: The L4 nerve root exits below L4 vertebrae and can be injured in far lateral disc protrusion but these are rare, and this patient has a posterolateral disc herniation.
✅ L5:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ S1:
Incorrect: The S1 nerve root exits the spinal canal below the L5 vertebrae at the sacral foramina. It can be compressed by L5-S1 disc protrusion rather than L4-L5 disc protrusion.
❌ S2:
Incorrect: Structural radiculopathies of the S2, S3, or S4 levels are far less common than those affecting other levels. They may occur, however, due to large central disc herniations that compress the nerve roots intrathecally at higher levels.

questions.text:
A 12-year-old boy is brought to his primary care physician to evaluate recurrent tripping and falling over the past two months. The patient states that he loses his balance easily and finds it difficult to walk in narrow spaces, such as the school hallway. He reports difficulty sleeping for the same duration. Past medical history is significant for seasonal allergies. Physical examination demonstrates bilateral papilledema, impaired upward gaze, and bilateral eyelid retraction. A brain mass is suspected, and an MRI brain is ordered.  


Reproduced from: Radiopaedia.org  
Which of the following structures is most likely affected by this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with ataxia, insomnia, downward gaze, and nystagmus consistent with Parinaud syndrome. This condition is classically associated with a tumor of the pineal gland.

Parinaud (dorsal midbrain) syndrome refers to a cluster of eye movement abnormalities characterized by limitation of upward gaze and downward gaze preference, bilateral eyelid lid retraction, and light-near dissociation (i.e. pupils react to accommodation but not to light). This combination of abnormalities manifests with a conjugate downward gaze, referred to as the "setting-sun" sign. These eye movement deficits are secondary to compression of the pretectal region of the midbrain, which in young patients often occurs due to tumors of the pineal gland.  

Option Analysis

❌ A:
Incorrect: Suprasellar germinomas are a less common cause of germinoma than pinealomas. They are more likely to present with endocrinopathies due to their proximity to the hypothalamus and pituitary gland. Moreover, suprasellar germinomas do not result in Parinaud syndrome.  
❌ B:
Incorrect: Damage to the thalamus by hemorrhage or an intracranial mass would present with contralateral hemisensory loss, behavioral changes, and language deficits.  
✅ C:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ D:
Incorrect: Pontine tumors or hemorrhage can result in ‘locked in’ syndrome, which presents with spastic quadriplegia and paralysis of most cranial nerves with preserved consciousness and eye movement.  
❌ E:
Incorrect: Cerebellar lesions usually present with limb and truncal ataxia, intention tremor, and nystagmus.

questions.text:
A 39-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of chest pain. A chest radiograph is obtained as part of the work-up and shown below:  


Image reproduced from Radiopedia  
Which of the structures represents the aortic arch?
questions.solution:
The cardiac silhouette refers to the heart’s outline as seen on frontal and lateral chest radiographs. The size and shape of the cardiac silhouette provide useful clues for underlying disease.

In the frontal view, the cardiac silhouette can be divided into right and left borders. The right border is formed by the right atrium. The superior vena cava can be seen at its upper margin and the inferior vena cava at its lower margin. The left border is formed by the left ventricle and left atrial appendage. The pulmonary artery extends superiorly. On top of the pulmonary artery is the aortic arch.

On the lateral view, the anterior border of the cardiac silhouette is formed by the right ventricle. The posterior border is formed by the left atrium (superiorly) and left ventricle (inferiorly).  



Image reproduced from Radiopedia  

Option Analysis

✅ Structure A  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Structure B  :
Incorrect: This structure is the left heart border, which is formed primarily by the left ventricle. Superiorly, it connects with the left atrial appendage.  
❌ Structure C  :
Incorrect: Structure C is the right heart border and is formed by primarily the right atrium. The superior portions of the right heart border are also formed by the superior vena cava.  
❌ Structure D  :
Incorrect: This labeled structure is the trachea.  
❌ Structure E  :
Incorrect: This labeled structure is the left main bronchus. It is formed by the division of trachea at the level of carina.

questions.text:
A 16-year-old boy comes to his outpatient provider for evaluation of exercise intolerance. His symptoms have been ongoing for many years but have recently become more bothersome after he started playing soccer for his high school team. He fatigues more easily than his friends and cannot keep up with them during matches. The patient also experiences frequent bruising after minor falls. Family history is noncontributory. In the office, his temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), blood pressure is 108/73 mmHg, pulse is 65/min, and respiratory rate is 15/min. Physical examination reveals hyperelastic skin, hypermobile joints and multiple bruises over the bilateral lower extremities. Examination of the chest reveals the following finding:  


Image reproduced from ">Wikimedia Commons  
Which of the following is the most likely underlying etiology of this patient’s symptoms?

choices.text: Reduced levels of clotting factor VIII
Reversed positioning of major visceral organs
Reduced synthesis of type I collagen

questions.solution:
This patient has pectus excavatum, hyperelastic skin, and a history of increased bruising tendency. He most likely has underlying Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, which is often caused by a mutation in type V collagen.

Pectus excavatum (also termed funnel chest) occurs when the sternal cartilage grows abnormally, leading to a caved-in or sunken appearance of the anterior thoracic wall. The condition can compress the cardiac cavities and cause symptoms including exercise intolerance, poor endurance, shortness of breath, and chest pain. Pectus excavatum can be associated with conditions such as Marfan syndrome, mitral valve prolapse, osteogenesis imperfecta, and Ehlers-Danlos syndrome.

An additional sternal abnormality is pectus carinatum (also termed pigeon chest) and is characterized by the sternum protruding outward. This condition is typically asymptomatic; however, there can be tenderness at the protrusion site, and individuals may experience tachypnea during intense exercise. Pectus carinatum can be associated with scoliosis, Marfan syndrome, Noonan syndrome, and osteogenesis imperfecta.  




Option Analysis

❌ Congenital defect in fibrillin glycoprotein  :
Incorrect: Marfan syndrome is caused by a congenital defect in fibrillin. The condition can cause pectus excavatum, hyperelastic skin, and hypermobile joints. However, Marfan syndrome does not typically cause an increased bruising tendency. Moreover, Marfan syndrome is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, whereas this patient’s family history is noncontributory.  
❌ Reduced levels of clotting factor VIII  :
Incorrect: Hemophilia A is caused by a deficiency in factor VIII, which predisposes patients to bleeding. However, hemophilia A would not account for the patient’s hypermobile joints or pectus excavatum.  
❌ Reversed positioning of major visceral organs  :
Incorrect: This answer choice describes situs inversus. However, situs inversus would not cause the sunk-in chest wall seen in this patient.  
✅ Mutation in type V collagen  :
Correct: See main explanation.  
❌ Reduced synthesis of type I collagen  :
Incorrect: Osteogenesis imperfecta is characterized by reduced production of type I collagen and can manifest with pectus excavatum. Individuals will also have blue sclera, teeth abnormalities, hearing loss, and a history of multiple fractures. These symptoms are not present in this patient.

questions.text:
A 74-year-old man presents to the emergency department to evaluate syncope and right flank pain. The patient experienced severe right-sided flank pain radiating to the groin while getting out of bed this morning. He subsequently “blacked out.” His partner found him on the ground moaning in pain and brought him to the emergency department. The patient has a remote history of kidney stones. He has not seen a physician in many years. He has been smoking one pack of cigarettes daily for fifty years. Temperature is 36.4°C (97.5°F), blood pressure is 93/67 mmHg, pulse is 102/min, and O2 saturation is 94% on room air. Physical exam demonstrates a tachypneic male in moderate pain. The remainder of the physical examination is unremarkable. An abdominal radiograph is shown below:  


Image reproduced from Radiopedia
Which of the following best identifies the anatomic location of this patient’s clinical condition?
questions.solution:
An older patient with a significant smoking history presents with unexplained syncope following severe flank pain. Abdominal radiography demonstrates calcification and ballooning of the abdominal aorta. These findings are concerning for a symptomatic abdominal aortic aneurysm with impending rupture.

The vast majority of aortic aneurysms are present in the infrarenal region and are clinically defined as dilating the aorta to greater than 50% of its normal diameter. Typically, this value is 3 cm, with large aneurysms defined as those greater than 5 cm. Known risk factors include male sex, older age, significant smoking history, uncontrolled hypertension, family history, and atherosclerotic disease. These aneurysms are due to chronic arterial wall inflammation, extracellular matrix degradation, and subsequent balloon dilation.

Clinically, most abdominal aortic aneurysms are silent and present with symptoms only at the time of rupture or impending rupture. With partial or immediate rupture, most patients present with symptoms that mimic renal colic, including back or flank pain radiating to the groin. Other findings include hypotension, abdominal pain, or a pulsatile abdominal mass (however, this finding is not always present).

In symptomatic patients, diagnosis is best achieved with CT imaging of the abdomen and pelvis. However, ultrasound can also quickly detect large aneurysms. Abdominal radiographs can detect calcifications and subsequent dilation of the aorta.  

Option Analysis

✅ Infrarenal aorta  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Suprarenal aorta  :
Incorrect: Abdominal aortic aneurysms almost always occur in the infrarenal aorta. Thoracic aortic aneurysms may occur proximal to the renal arteries and track inferiorly over time.  
❌ Ureteropelvic junction  :
Incorrect: Impacted renal stones may be present at the ureteropelvic junction. An abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) often mimics the symptoms of renal colic. However, given this patient’s history and findings on abdominal radiography, a symptomatic AAA with impending rupture is more likely.  
❌ Proximal ureter  :
Incorrect: Proximal ureteral stones often present with symptoms similar to that of an abdominal aortic aneurysm. Given this patient’s history and findings on abdominal radiography, a symptomatic AAA with impending rupture best explains his symptoms.  
❌ Terminal Ileum  :
Incorrect: The terminal ileum is the location of intra-abdominal pathologies, including colitis and Crohn disease. In addition, acute appendicitis can cause inflammation and wall thickening of the adjacent terminal ileum. However, given this patient’s history and findings on abdominal radiography, a symptomatic abdominal aortic aneurysm with impending rupture best explains his symptoms.

questions.text: A group of medical students is examining the lungs of a cadaver. The students notice a couple of differences between the right and left lungs. Which of the following is true about the gross anatomy of the lungs?

choices.text: The left lung has more lobes than the right lung
The right lung has more lobes than the left lung.
Both lungs have the same number of lobes.
The horizontal fissure in the left lung divides it into superior and inferior lobes
The apex of the right lung extends above the first rib into the root of the neck, but not the left lung.

questions.solution:
The lungs are the intrathoracic organs responsible for gas exchange. The right and left lungs are overall quite similar. However, there are a few differences between the gross anatomy of the two lungs.    

Lungs are divided by fissures into lobes. The left lung has only one fissure, which is the oblique fissure. The oblique fissure separates the left lung into superior and inferior lobes.    

On the other hand, the right lung has two fissures: the oblique fissure and the horizontal fissure. These fissures divide the right lung into the superior, middle, and inferior lobes.  


Option Analysis

❌ The left lung has more lobes than the right lung:
Incorrect: The right lung has three lobes, while the left lung has two.  
✅ The right lung has more lobes than the left lung. :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Both lungs have the same number of lobes. :
Incorrect: The left lung has fewer lobes than the right lung.  
❌ The horizontal fissure in the left lung divides it into superior and inferior lobes:
Incorrect: The left lung has only the oblique fissure, which divides the left lung into the superior and inferior lobes. In contrast, the horizontal fissure is found in the right lung.  
❌ The apex of the right lung extends above the first rib into the root of the neck, but not the left lung. :
Incorrect: Both lung apices (the right lung and left lung) extend above the level of the first rib and into the root of the neck.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man comes to the physician with diplopia. The patient tells the physician that he has fallen multiple times because of having double vision. The problem started eight months ago, and it has not improved. Past medical history of the patient includes hypertension, diabetes mellitus, and coronary artery disease. On physical examination, the left eye is pointing downwards and outwards. Both pupils are 4 mm in diameter, and reactive to light. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Ischemic injury of the oculomotor nerve
Compression of the oculomotor nerve by an aneurysm in the posterior communicating artery
Compression of the oculomotor nerve by an aneurysm in the posterior cerebral artery
Compression of the oculomotor nerve by an aneurysm in the superior cerebellar artery
Compression of CN III by the uncus of the temporal lobe

questions.solution:
This patient with diplopia and a “down and out” right eye most likely has damage to the somatic component of the oculomotor nerve (CN III). Ischemia, secondary to diabetes and hypertensive vasculopathy, is the most common cause.

CN III has parasympathetic and somatic components. The former is present in the outer region of the nerve, while the latter is found in the center of the nerve. A helpful way to remember this distinction is the alliteration that the Parasympathetic fibers are Peripheral. Clinical findings of CN III palsy depend on the components that are affected by the pathology. Loss of parasympathetic function leads to mydriasis and inability to accommodate to near objects, while loss of the somatic function causes ptosis and deviation of the eye down and out (due to unopposed action of superior oblique and lateral rectus muscles, innervated by CN IV and VI, respectively).

Isolated CN III palsy is most commonly due to ischemia or compression. Ischemia is mostly caused by hypertension or diabetes mellitus and preferentially affects somatic fibers. Compression of CN III (e.g., by posterior communicating artery aneurysm, tentorial herniation) can lead to parasympathetic loss of function. However, it is not uncommon to see involvement of both the components.



Option Analysis

✅ Ischemic injury of the oculomotor nerve:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Compression of the oculomotor nerve by an aneurysm in the posterior communicating artery:
Incorrect: Posterior communicating artery aneurysms are one of the most common causes of CN III injury. However, compression injury to CN III always affects the parasympathetic fibers because they run in the outer layer of the nerve; thus the affected patient will have dilated pupils that are nonreactive to light.
❌ Compression of the oculomotor nerve by an aneurysm in the posterior cerebral artery:
Incorrect: Compression of the oculomotor nerve by an aneurysm in the posterior cerebral artery is another cause of CN III injury. However, compression injury to CN III always affects the parasympathetic fibers because they run in the outer layer of the nerve; thus the affected patient will have dilated pupils that are nonreactive to light.
❌ Compression of the oculomotor nerve by an aneurysm in the superior cerebellar artery:
Incorrect: Compression of the oculomotor nerve by an aneurysm in the superior cerebellar artery is also a cause of compression injury of CN III. However, compression injury to CN III always affects the parasympathetic fibers because they run in the outer layer of the nerve; thus the affected patient will have dilated pupils that are nonreactive to light.
❌ Compression of CN III by the uncus of the temporal lobe:
Incorrect: Uncal herniation through the tentorium cerebelli can compress CN III. However, this is an emergency, and patients will present with other neurological manifestations (e.g., coma, spastic paresis). Moreover, compression injuries to CN III affect the parasympathetic fibers, leading to dilated, nonreactive pupils.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of nausea, vomiting, and abdominal distention for the past 12 hours. She has had vague abdominal pain for the past few months but did not seek medical care. Past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus, managed with metformin. BMI is 35 kg/m2. Temperature is 38.4°C (101°F), pulse is 89/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. Physical examination shows moderate abdominal distension. There is a 3 cm erythematous and tender palpable mass in the right groin below the inguinal ligament and lateral to the pubic tubercle. The mass is tympanitic to percussion and cannot be reduced. CT scan of the abdomen shows evidence of small bowel obstruction. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with an irreducible groin bulge lateral to the pubic tubercle and below the inguinal ligament; she most likely has an incarcerated femoral hernia. Since it is erythematous and is associated with abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and high-grade fever, it has most likely strangulated.

Femoral hernias are the result of herniation of abdominal contents through the femoral canal below the inguinal ligament, medial to the femoral vein, and lateral to the pubic tubercle. Femoral hernias are more common in females and often occur on the right side. Advanced age is the most important risk factor, as the femoral ring can widen. Because the femoral canal is small, femoral hernias often become incarcerated (irreducible), which can lead to bowel obstruction (resulting in pain, nausea, and abdominal distension). Over time, strangulation (ischemia and necrosis) can occur due to worsening edema secondary to impaired blood flow.

In contrast, inguinal hernias are associated with a comparatively lower risk of incarceration and strangulation, as the bowel contents protrude via a wider orifice.

Femoral hernias require surgical repair to decrease the morbidity and mortality associated with potentially life-threatening complications. In some patients, an accessory (or aberrant) obturator artery (a branch of inferior epigastric artery) passes medial to the femoral ring along the margin of the lacunar ligament. The surgeon must be careful to avoid its injury while cutting the lacunar ligament to enlarge the femoral ring to reduce the hernia.



Option Analysis

❌ Patent processus vaginalis:
Incorrect: A patent processus vaginalis can result in indirect inguinal hernia, which would present above the inguinal ligament.
✅ Widening of the femoral ring:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Weakness of transversalis fascia:
Incorrect: Weakness of transversalis fascia can result in a direct inguinal hernia, which protrudes medially to the inferior epigastric vessels within the Hesselbach triangle and appear in the groin. Inguinal hernias are found above the inguinal ligament.
❌ Defect in the Spigelian aponeurosis:
Incorrect: A defect in the Spigelian aponeurosis can result in a Spigelian hernia, which would be located in the "Spigelian hernia belt," a transverse, 6-centimeter-wide zone around the level of the arcuate line (the caudal-most extent of the posterior rectus sheath). This patient instead has a femoral hernia, which results from laxity of the femoral ring.
❌ Dilatation of long saphenous vein:
Incorrect: Saphenous varix is the dilatation of a long saphenous vein at its junction with the femoral vein in the groin. It appears as a bulge with bluish tinge below the inguinal ligament. It disappears on lying down and exhibits a thrill on auscultation. It is usually associated with varicose veins. This patient’s presentation is more consistent with a femoral hernia.

questions.text: A 39-year-old woman comes to the office for evaluation of a firm, nontender swelling over her right cheek for the past five months. The patient does not have a sore throat, runny nose, headache, or fever. Past medical history is noncontributory. The patient smokes one pack of cigarettes daily and drinks one glass of wine after dinner most nights. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows fullness of the right preauricular space. An MRI of the face demonstrates a 3 cm mass of the right parotid gland, which is determined to be neoplastic on a subsequent core-needle biopsy. An elective parotidectomy is performed, and an important nerve embedded within the parotid gland is accidentally injured. Which of the following clinical features is the patient most likely to develop as a result of this injury?

choices.text: Deviation of the tongue to the right when protruded
Inability to close the right eye entirely
Loss of sensation over the anterior two-thirds of the tongue
Down and out deviation of the right eye
Visual defect affecting the left half of the visual field

questions.solution:
This patient was diagnosed with a parotid gland neoplasm and underwent subsequent surgical excision of the parotid gland (parotidectomy). The facial nerve CN VII (parotid plexus) can be injured during parotidectomy or from compression by a parotid gland tumor. Damage to the CN VII or its branches will cause paralysis of the facial muscles, causing them to lose tone. The inferior eyelid can be particularly affected, resulting in an inability to close the eye entirely.

Similarly at risk during parotid pathologies, the auriculotemporal nerve, a branch of the trigeminal nerve (CN V3), is closely related to the parotid gland and passes superior to it along with the superficial temporal vessels. The auriculotemporal nerve innervates the parotid sheath as well as the overlying skin. Therefore, patients with parotitis (parotid gland inflammation) often experience external auricular pain.


Option Analysis

❌ Deviation of the tongue to the right when protruded  :
Incorrect: The hypoglossal nerve (CN XII) innervates the genioglossus, which is responsible for tongue protrusion. CN XII is most frequently injured during carotid endarterectomy, which can result in ipsilateral genioglossus weakness with a deviation of the tongue toward the ipsilateral side with tongue protrusion. CNXII does not pass through the parotid gland and is therefore unlikely to be injured in this patient.  
✅ Inability to close the right eye entirely  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Loss of sensation over the anterior two-thirds of the tongue  :
Incorrect: General sensation over the anterior two-thirds of the tongue is carried by a branch of the trigeminal nerve. This nerve does not pass through the parotid gland and is therefore unlikely to be injured in this patient.  
❌ Down and out deviation of the right eye  :
Incorrect: Oculomotor nerve (CN III) palsy causes down and out deviation of the eye. CN III does not pass through the parotid gland and is therefore unlikely to be injured in this patient.  
❌ Visual defect affecting the left half of the visual field  :
Incorrect:  Homonymous hemianopia is a defect that affects half of the visual field due to a contralateral optic nerve (CN II) lesion posterior to the optic chiasm. CN II does not pass through the parotid gland and is therefore unlikely to be injured in this patient.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department to evaluate shortness of breath. The parent is at the bedside and states, “I saw him lying on his right side putting plastic beads in his mouth. I think he swallowed one of them.” The patient is otherwise healthy, and his vaccinations are up to date. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 23/min, blood pressure is 95/50 mmHg, and O2 saturation is 95% on room air. On physical examination, the patient is intermittently tachypneic. Faint stridor is present on pulmonary auscultation. The foreign body was most likely aspirated into which anatomic lung region?
questions.solution:
This patient presents after an aspiration event while in the right lateral decubitus position. Of the anatomic sites listed above, the most likely aspiration area is the dependent region of the right upper lobe.   

Aspiration of foreign bodies, vomitus, or oral secretions is a common event. The aspiration site can be predicted based on the patient’s position when the aspiration event occurs. The right main bronchus is wider, shorter, and has a more vertical trajectory than the left mainstem bronchus. As a result, aspirated foreign bodies are more likely to enter and lodge in the right bronchus or one of its branches.  

In addition to this anatomic preference, aspirated foreign bodies follow gravity, resulting in foreign bodies in the dependent portions of the lung. In the supine position, the dependent lung segments are the posterior segments of the upper lobes and superior segments of the lower lobes. In contrast, individuals in an upright position will most likely aspirate into the basilar segments of the right lower lobe. Finally, the aspirate usually enters the right upper lobe when lying on the right side.   

Option Analysis

✅ Right upper lobe:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Right lower lobe :
Incorrect: Aspiration in the upright position is likely to result in the foreign object being lodged in the right lower lobe, not the upper lobes. However, this patient aspirated while in a right lateral decubitus position.
❌ Left lower lobe:
Incorrect: Aspiration is always less likely to occur in the left lower lobe because the right main bronchus is wider, shorter, and has a more vertical trajectory. In addition, this patient aspirated while in a right lateral decubitus position, making the right upper lobe the most likely site of aspiration.
❌ Right middle lobe :
Incorrect: Aspiration into the right middle lobe is uncommon, regardless of anatomic position. 
❌ Left upper lobe:
Incorrect: Aspiration into the left upper lobe does not readily occur. Instead, aspiration is more likely to involve the right lung since the right main bronchus is wider, shorter, and has a more vertical trajectory.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman comes to a surgeon after her primary care physician noticed a lump in her neck. A biopsy is performed, and the samples are sent to pathology for analysis, revealing follicular thyroid cancer. The patient is scheduled for a total thyroidectomy. During the operation, a nerve near the superior thyroid artery is injured. Which of the following structures was most likely injured?

choices.text: External branch of the superior laryngeal nerve
Internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve
Pharyngeal branches of the vagus nerve

questions.solution:
The external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve travels close to the superior thyroid artery and can be easily injured in thyroid surgeries.  

The superior laryngeal nerve is a branch of the vagus nerve. It subsequently divides into the external and internal branches. The external branch supplies the cricothyroid muscle and helps tense the vocal cords. This branch travels along the lateral surface of the inferior constrictor muscle of the pharynx and closely follows the superior thyroid artery. As a result, it is susceptible to injury during thyroidectomy. The resultant neurological effects include ipsilateral anesthesia of the larynx above the level of the vocal cords and paralysis of the cricothyroid muscle. Most cases of unilateral paralysis are asymptomatic. However, symptomatic patients may experience a weak voice, occasional hoarseness, and voice quality and pitch changes.  



The internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve provides sensory innervation to the mucosa of the supraglottic larynx. This branch enters the larynx through the thyrohyoid membrane and courses relatively far from the thyroid. As a result, it is not typically injured in thyroidectomy. However, the superior laryngeal nerve as a whole can be damaged during skull base surgery, resulting in a loss of sensation of the superior laryngeal mucosa.   

Option Analysis

✅ External branch of the superior laryngeal nerve :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve :
Incorrect: The internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve enters the larynx through the thyrohyoid membrane. The nerve does not course near the thyroid and, as a result, is not commonly injured during thyroidectomies. 
❌ The recurrent laryngeal nerve :
Incorrect: The recurrent laryngeal nerve can be injured during thyroidectomies when dissecting the inferior thyroid artery due to their proximity. However, the nerve injured in this patient courses near the superior thyroid artery.
❌ Accessory nerve:
Incorrect: The accessory nerve is not susceptible to injury during thyroidectomies. 
❌ Pharyngeal branches of the vagus nerve :
Incorrect: The pharyngeal branches of the vagus nerve are not susceptible to injury during thyroidectomies.

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl presents to the physician for evaluation of a neck mass. She first noticed the mass five weeks ago, following an upper respiratory infection. She has not experienced any dyspnea or dysphagia. Past medical history is unremarkable. Temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), blood pressure is 109/72 mmHg, and pulse is 68/min. On physical examination, a midline mass is observed over the anterior neck around 1 centimeter below the hyoid bone. The mass is soft and nontender to palpation. The mass moves when the patient swallows. Which of the following best describes the underlying cause of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Incomplete obliteration of the thyroglossal duct
Failed obliteration of a branchial cleft

questions.solution:
This patient has a painless, midline neck mass that moves with swallowing. These findings suggest a thyroglossal duct cyst, an embryologic remnant that forms when the thyroglossal duct fails to close after birth.  

During embryological development, the thyroid gland originates in the floor of the embryonic pharynx in an area called the foramen cecum, found on the dorsum of the tongue. The thyroid gland subsequently migrates from the tongue into the neck, passing anterior to the hyoid bone through the thyroglossal duct. This duct normally disappears after birth; however, in some cases, part of this duct remains, and a thyroglossal duct cyst can develop.  

Thyroglossal duct cysts are typically located along the anterior midline portion of the neck. They can form a visual and palpable mass. The cysts move with swallowing or tongue movement, which can help distinguish them from other neck masses (e.g. malignant tumors). Most cases are asymptomatic, but some can cause neck pain or dysphagia if they grow large or become infected. In rare cases, a thyroglossal duct cyst carcinoma can develop from ectopic thyroid tissue within the cyst. Other complications may include infections, rupture, and formation of a thyroglossal fistula.  

 

Option Analysis

❌ Granulomatous thyroid gland inflammation:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes subacute granulomatous thyroiditis, also called de Quervain thyroiditis. The condition typically presents as a painful swelling of the thyroid gland following an upper respiratory infection. In contrast, this patient’s mass is painless.
✅ Incomplete obliteration of the thyroglossal duct:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Outpouching of the cervical esophagus:
Incorrect: A Zenker diverticulum is characterized by outpouching of the esophageal mucosa through an area of muscle weakness in the posterior esophageal wall. The condition most commonly develops at Killian’s triangle and involves the cervical esophagus. The condition can present with dysphagia, regurgitation, cough, aspiration, and foul-smelling breath. However, it would not typically present as an anterior neck mass.
❌ Failed obliteration of a branchial cleft:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes a branchial cleft cyst. The condition typically presents as a nontender, lateral neck mass. In contrast, this patient has a midline neck mass that moves when she swallows, suggesting a thyroglossal duct cyst.  
❌ Malignant proliferation of thyrocytes:
Incorrect: Thyroid cancer is characterized by malignant proliferation of thyroid gland tissue. The condition presents as a firm and usually painless nodule. If the cancer invades surrounding tissue, the tumor can remain fixed and will not move with swallowing or tongue movements. In contrast, this patient has a soft and mobile neck mass, which suggests a thyroglossal duct cyst.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old woman presents to a primary care physician for evaluation of worsening voice hoarseness. Her voice has become progressively muffled and weak over the past three months. She has also experienced shortness of breath on exertion and a diminished appetite. The patient has not seen a physician in over fifteen years. She has a 40-pack year smoking history. A chest radiograph is obtained and demonstrated below. Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient’s clinical presentation?  


Image reproduced from Radiopedia
questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation of voice hoarseness, and chest radiography demonstrates increased opacities in the left lung apex. These findings are concerning for a left-sided superior sulcus, or Pancoast, tumor. Pancoast tumors are well known to invade mediastinal structures, including the recurrent laryngeal nerve, which innervates all intrinsic muscles of the larynx except for the cricothyroid muscle.    

The left recurrent laryngeal nerve, a branch of the vagus nerve, is highly susceptible to injury given its course in the mediastinum. As it branches off the vagus nerve, it passes under the aortic arch and then traverses superiorly to innervate the intrinsic muscles of the larynx. These muscles adjust the tension on the vocal cords for sound production. Thus damage of the left laryngeal nerve has the potential to result in unilateral vocal cord paralysis. Clinically, patients may experience new-onset hoarseness, changes in pitch, or noisy breathing.  

Common etiologies of left recurrent laryngeal nerve injury include lung malignancies (particularly Pancoast tumors), transection during thyroid or parathyroid surgery, left atrial enlargement, and head and neck cancers.    

Option Analysis

✅ Left recurrent laryngeal nerve injury :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Superior laryngeal nerve injury:
Incorrect: The superior laryngeal nerve supplies sensory fibers to the laryngeal mucosa and motor fibers to the cricothyroid muscle. Given the anatomic location of this nerve, it is unlikely to be injured by a Pancoast tumor. 
❌ Right recurrent laryngeal nerve injury :
Incorrect: The right recurrent laryngeal nerve would be more likely to be affected by a Pancoast tumor of the right lung. In contrast, this patient’s radiograph demonstrates increased opacities in the left lung apex, suggestive of a left Pancoast tumor.
❌ Left vagus nerve injury :
Incorrect: An injury to the vagus nerve would result in hoarseness, as the recurrent laryngeal nerve branches from the vagus. However, injury to the vagus nerve would also result in findings of autonomic dysfunction. 
❌ Bilateral phrenic nerve injury :
Incorrect: Bilateral phrenic nerve injury would result in respiratory compromise due to interrupted diaphragmatic innervation. As a result, the lungs would likely appear hypoinflated on a chest radiograph.

questions.text:
A 76-year-old man is brought to the emergency department to evaluate acute-on-chronic low back pain. Several years ago, the patient was diagnosed with prostate cancer, but he elected to forego treatment and was lost to follow-up. Today, the patient was brought in by family members after he could not get out of bed. The patient states, “I can’t lift my legs, and I woke up covered in my stool.” The patient has no other significant medical history or medication use. Temperature is 37.0 °C (98.6 °F), pulse is 105/min, respirations are 18/min, blood pressure is 176/65 mmHg, and O2 saturation is 97% on room air. Physical examination shows a cachectic male in moderate distress. The patient has diffuse lumbar spinal tenderness to palpation and 2/5 strength of the lower extremities bilaterally. The patient’s pelvic x-ray is demonstrated below. Which of the following additional clinical features most indicates this patient’s clinical condition?


Reproduced from: Wikipedia
questions.solution:
This patient with a history of prostate cancer presents for evaluation of acute-on-chronic low back pain with associated bowel dysfunction, motor deficits in the lower extremities, and a pelvic x-ray demonstrating numerous osteoblastic lesions consistent with metastatic disease. This clinical presentation is suspicious for cauda equina syndrome, and urinary retention is a particularly specific finding for this condition.    
Cauda equina syndrome refers to a spinal cord injury caudal to the conus that injures two or more nerve roots, often via direct compression of the cauda equina within the lumbar spinal canal. The disease has multiple etiologies, including ankylosing spondylitis, chemotherapy, disc herniation, osteomyelitis, spinal epidural abscess, neoplasm, hematoma, arteriovenous malformations, inferior vena cava thrombosis, or trauma.  

The most common presenting complaint is acute-on-chronic low back pain; however, the associated features vary. In general, most patients have a combination of back pain, bowel or bladder dysfunction, and symptoms of radiculopathy. Additional findings include lower extremity weakness and diminished sensation in the distribution of multiple nerve roots (L3-S1), peri-anal numbness, and loss of anal sphincter tone. This disorder, while rare, carries significant morbidity, often resulting in permanent neurologic dysfunction if left untreated. When suspected, management includes emergent MRI of the lumbar spine and neurosurgical consultation.



Option Analysis

✅ Urinary retention :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Decreased deep tendon reflexes:
Incorrect: The absence of deep tendon reflexes is often found in patients with cauda equina syndrome; however, it is not a specific feature of this condition as it may be found in simple, unilateral radiculopathy as well.  
❌ Hyperreflexia:
Incorrect: Hyporeflexia, not hyperreflexia, is more commonly found in patients with cauda equina syndrome.  
❌ Preserved perineal sensation :
Incorrect: Cauda equina syndrome usually exhibits sensory loss in the perineal area (saddle anesthesia).  
❌ Increased anal sphincter tone :
Incorrect: Decreased, not increased, anal sphincter tone is observed in patients with cauda equina syndrome.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is evaluated for visual difficulties and precocious puberty. His parents first noticed that he had developed armpit hair several weeks ago. In addition, his parents mention that he tends to lean his head backwards when walking up the stairs. His temperature is 37.2°C (99°F), pulse is 86/min, and blood pressure is 120/76 mmHg. Physical examination shows coarse pubic hair corresponding with Tanner stage 4. Eye examination reveals bilateral lid retraction and limited upward gaze. Which of the following structures is most likely to be involved in this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presenting with precocious puberty and upward gaze palsy most likely has a human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) secreting germ cell tumor in the pineal gland.   

The pineal gland is located in the diencephalon behind the 3rd ventricle; it is responsible for the secretion of melatonin and synchronization of circadian rhythm. Any tumor that arises within the pineal gland is termed a pinealoma. The main three tumors that can arise within the pineal gland include germ cell tumors, pineal parenchymal tumors, and gliomas. Germ-cell tumors can secrete hCG, which, in boys, leads to activation of LH receptors on the Leydig cells. This results in increased testosterone production and precocious puberty. In girls, hCG-secreting tumors do not cause precocious puberty, because activation of both FSH and LH receptors is required for estrogen production. In girls, however, a urine pregnancy test will be falsely positive.  

Symptoms of pinealomas may include headaches, lethargy, signs of increased intracranial pressure (e.g. papilledema), hydrocephalus and pretectal syndrome (Parinaud syndrome), in which compression of the pretectal area results in a classic constellation of neuro-ocular symptoms including upward gaze limitation, bilateral eyelid retraction (Collier sign), and light-near dissociation (“Argyll Robinson pupil”).    

Option Analysis

❌ Raphe nucleus:
Incorrect: The raphe nucleus is found in the medulla and is responsible for serotonin secretion. Deficiency of serotonin is associated with anxiety, depression and Parkinson's disease.   
❌ Nucleus basalis:
Incorrect: The nucleus basalis (basal nucleus of Meynert) is found at the base of the forebrain and secretes acetylcholine. Decreased levels of acetylcholine are associated with Alzheimer and Huntington’s disease. Increased levels are seen in Parkinson's disease.   
❌ Pituitary gland:
Incorrect: Pituitary gonadotropin-secreting tumors theoretically can cause precocious puberty, however, they are extremely rare. In addition, pituitary tumors are more likely to present with bilateral hemianopsia due to compression of the optic chiasm rather than upward gaze palsy.   
❌ Ventral tegmentum:
Incorrect: The ventral tegmentum is a group of neurons located in the midbrain which is responsible for dopamine secretion. Deficiency is associated with depression and Parkinson's disease while elevated levels with schizophrenia and Huntington's disease.    
✅ Pineal gland:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Locus coeruleus:
Incorrect: Locus coeruleus is a nucleus found in the pons which is responsible for secreting norepinephrine. High levels of norepinephrine are associated with anxiety and low levels with depression.  
❌ Sella turcica:
Incorrect: Craniopharyngiomas arise from remnants of Rathke's pouch within the sella turcica. During embryological development, Rathke's pouch gives rise to the anterior pituitary gland. Craniopharyngiomas often present with growth delay and bitemporal hemianopsia, not precocious puberty.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his partner due to dizziness, difficulty walking, and severe headache for two hours. Past medical history is significant for hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, and type II diabetes mellitus. Temperature is 37.2°C (99°F), blood pressure is 182/106 mmHg, pulse is 102/min, and respirations are 20/min. Neurologic examination demonstrates right-sided dysmetria on finger-to-nose testing and right-sided dysrhythmia with rapid finger tapping. The patient appears to have difficulty with balance and a propensity to fall to the right side. Motor strength and sensation are symmetric and preserved bilaterally, and no speech deficits are apparent. Which of the following is the most likely anatomic location of this patient’s brain lesion?
questions.solution:
This patient most likely has a lateral cerebellar hemisphere lesion resulting in ipsilateral deficits (imbalance and falling toward the side of the lesion), limb ataxia, and intention tremor.

Lateral lesions of the cerebellum affect the cortex of the cerebellar hemispheres and deep cerebellar nuclei, including the dentate, emboliform, and globose nuclei. Cerebellar efferent fibers first cross to the contralateral side and the ipsilateral side. Together, these structures assist in planning and programming movements that influence the proximal flexor muscles of the upper extremities.

Clinically, lateral cerebellar lesions result in ipsilateral limb ataxia (loss of coordination of the limb on the same side as the lesion), which can lead to intention tremor (involuntary, trembling movements that occur with voluntary movements), dysmetria (loss of coordination that presents as the overshoot or undershoot of the intended position of the extremities), dysdiadochokinesia (inability to perform fast alternating movements), decreased muscle tone of the extremities and loss of balance, with a tendency to fall towards the side of the lesion.  

Option Analysis

❌ Cerebellar vermis  :
Incorrect: Lesions that affect midline structures of the cerebellum, such as the vermis or the flocculonodular lobe, cause problems such as truncal ataxia, cerebellar gait, and the proximal muscle groups. This patient’s intention tremor and limb ataxia suggest an alternative structure.  
✅ Lateral cerebellar hemisphere  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Lateral medulla  :
Incorrect: A lateral medullary infarct can occur due to occlusion of the posterior inferior cerebellar or vertebral artery. Patients typically present with loss of pain and temperature of the ipsilateral face and contralateral body, ipsilateral bulbar muscle weakness, vestibulocerebellar impairment, and Horner syndrome.  
❌ Medial mid-pons  :
Incorrect: A medial mid-pontine infarction presents with contralateral ataxia and hemiparesis of the face, trunk, and limbs. There is a variable loss of contralateral tactile and position sense. This patient’s intention tremor and ipsilateral limb ataxia with preserved sensations suggest an alternative structure.  
❌ Medial medulla  :
Incorrect: Medial medullary syndrome presents with contralateral paralysis of the arm and leg and tongue deviation towards the lesion.

questions.text:
A 73-year-old man comes to the emergency department to evaluate severe left eye pain and loss of vision that started one hour ago. He has vomited twice. The patient takes hydrochlorothiazide and tamsulosin for hypertension and benign prostatic hyperplasia. Ophthalmic examination demonstrates left conjunctival injection and a hazy cornea. The right eye is grossly normal. Left intraocular pressure is measured at 24 mmHg (normal range 8-21 mmHg).



Reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

Which of the following anatomical structures is the primary site of pathology in this patient’s clinical condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with sudden onset vision loss, eye pain, and increased intraocular pressure consistent with acute angle-closure glaucoma. Glaucoma is a group of ocular diseases that damage the optic nerve secondary to increased intraocular pressure. The two primary types include open-angle glaucoma and closed-angle glaucoma.

Angle-closure glaucoma occurs when the iris bulges forward to narrow or block the drainage angle formed by the cornea and iris, termed the iridocorneal angle. As a result, fluid cannot circulate through the anterior chamber, which results in increased intraocular pressure.

In open-angle glaucoma, the drainage angle formed by the cornea and iris remains open, but the trabecular meshwork is partially blocked. This results in pressure in the eye gradually increasing, resulting in progressive damage to the optic nerve.

Without treatment, both conditions can result in complete blindness.  

Option Analysis

❌ Posterior chamber:
Incorrect: The posterior chamber is a narrow space behind the iris and in front of the suspensory ligament of the lens and ciliary processes. This structure is not implicated in patients with acute angle-closure glaucoma.
❌ Anterior chamber:
Incorrect: The anterior chamber is the fluid-filled space between the iris and the corneal endothelium. Aqueous humor fills the anterior chamber and flows to the trabecular meshwork. The anterior chamber itself is not involved in acute angle-closure glaucoma.
✅ Iridocorneal angle:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Ciliary body:
Incorrect: The ciliary body is the part of the eye that includes the ciliary muscle and ciliary epithelium. The ciliary body comprises a part of the uvea, the layer of tissue that delivers oxygen and nutrients to ocular tissue.
❌ Vitreous humor:
Incorrect: Vitreous humor is a transparent, colorless, gelatinous mass that fills the space between the lens and the retina.

questions.text: A researcher is currently studying the anatomy of the cranial nerve nuclei and pathways. He identifies the dorsal motor nucleus, which sends autonomic fibers to the upper gastrointestinal tract, heart, and lungs. Which of the following reflects the cranial nerve associated with the dorsal motor nucleus?
questions.solution:
The cranial nerve nuclei refer to collections of neurons in the brain stem associated with one or more of the cranial nerves. All nuclei are located in the tegmentum portion of the brainstem between the dorsal and ventral portions. The cranial nerve nuclei in each portion of the brainstem are outlined below:  

  •  Midbrain: CN III, IV 
  •  Pons: CN V, VI, VII, VIII 
  •  Medulla: CN IX, X, XII  
  •  Spinal cord: CN XI  
In addition, three vagal nuclei are associated with one or more cranial nerves that carry parasympathetic information, including the nucleus tractus solitarius (CN VII, CN IX, CNX), nucleus ambiguus (CN IX, X, XI), and the dorsal motor nucleus (CN X). The nucleus tractus solitarius mediates visceral sensory information, while the nucleus ambiguous mediates motor innervation of the throat and upper airway. Lastly, the dorsal motor nucleus sends autonomic fibers to the upper gastrointestinal tract, heart, and lungs.   

Option Analysis

✅ Cranial nerve X  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Cranial nerve VII:
Incorrect: Cranial nerve VII, or the facial nerve, provides innervation to the muscles of facial expression. The nucleus tractus solitarius is the nucleus associated with this cranial nerve.  
❌ Cranial nerve IX  :
Incorrect: Cranial nerve IX, or the glossopharyngeal nerve, is associated with both the nucleus tractus solitarius as well as the nucleus ambiguus. Cranial nerve IX is responsible for taste and sensation from the tongue, swallowing, and salivation. It does not, however, send autonomic signals to the heart, lungs, and gastrointestinal tract.  
❌ Cranial nerve XI  :
Incorrect: Cranial nerve XI is associated with the nucleus tractus solitarius but not the dorsal motor nucleus.  
❌ Cranial nerve III  :
Incorrect: Cranial nerve III, or the oculomotor nerve, originates from nuclei in the midbrain.

questions.text: A human cadaveric model is being studied to better understand the anatomic distribution and innervation of muscles in the upper extremity, chest, and back. A nerve root is stimulated with an electrical impulse, which results primarily in the contraction of the lumbricals and interossei of the hand. Which of the following accurately reflects the nerve root(s) being tested in this experiment?
questions.solution:
The brachial plexus is composed of nerve roots C5-T1, divided into the upper, middle, and lower trunks, which form the lateral, posterior, and medial cords, which become the musculocutaneous, median, and ulnar branches.  

Understanding cervical nerve roots' anatomic distribution and function can help predict both sensory and motor neurologic deficits. This knowledge becomes essential clinically when assessing for evidence of an anatomic lesion following a nerve root distribution.  



Option Analysis

✅ T1  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ C5  :
Incorrect: Primary motor function at C5 involves deltoid and elbow flexion.  
❌ C6  :
Incorrect: Primary motor function at C6 involves bicep and wrist extension.  
❌ C7  :
Incorrect: Primary motor function at C7 involves triceps and wrist flexion.  
❌ C8  :
Incorrect: Primary motor function at C8 involves the finger flexors.

questions.text:
A pathologist views cross-sectional slides of the brainstem and identifies the following structure (denoted by an asterisk):  


Which of the following best characterizes the function of the fibers passing through this structure?

choices.text: Transmission of pain signals to the brain

questions.solution:
The asterisk points to the medullary pyramids and, in particular, the pyramidal decussations. Neurons of the lateral corticospinal tract decussate within the medullary pyramids.

The corticospinal tract is a descending pathway that regulates voluntary movements of the trunk and extremities. It can be subdivided into the anterior corticospinal tract, which contains around 5-15% of the fibers and controls proximal musculature, and lateral corticospinal tract, which contains around 75-90% of the fibers and controls musculature of the extremities.

First-order neurons originate from the motor cortex and descend through the internal capsule in both cases. Neurons within the lateral corticospinal tract decussate in the medullary pyramids and descend contralaterally until they reach the ventral horn, where they synapse with lower motor neurons. The lower motor neurons then leave the spinal cord via the ventral root and travel to the musculature.

Neurons of the anterior corticospinal tract, on the other hand, descend ipsilaterally until they reach the desired spinal segment. Afterward, the upper motor neurons decussate and synapse with lower motor neurons in the anterior horn. The lower motor neurons then leave the spinal cord via the ventral root and travel to the musculature.  



Option Analysis

❌ Regulation of muscles of mastication  :
Incorrect: The corticobulbar tract provides upper motor neuron innervation to many of the cranial nerves. This tract has several functions, including helping control muscles of the face, muscles of mastication, and muscles of the pharynx and larynx. Neurons in the corticobulbar tract decussate above the levels of the relevant cranial nuclei (and not at the medullary pyramids).  
❌ Transmission of pain signals to the brain  :
Incorrect: The spinothalamic tract relays pain, temperature, crude touch, and pressure sensations to the brain. However, fibers of the spinothalamic tract decussate in the anterior white commissure, as opposed to the medullary pyramids.  
✅ Initiation of voluntary arm movements  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Conduction of temperature sensation  :
Incorrect: The spinothalamic tract relays pain, temperature, crude touch, and pressure sensations to the brain. However, fibers of the spinothalamic tract decussate in the anterior white commissure, as opposed to the medullary pyramids.  
❌ Transmission of unconscious proprioceptive sensation  :
Incorrect: The spinocerebellar tract transmits unconscious proprioceptive sensation to the brain. After entering the spinal cord, the neurons either decussate immediately and become part of the ventral spinocerebellar tract (which later decussates again in the superior cerebellar peduncle) or ascend ipsilaterally as the dorsal spinocerebellar tract. Neither the ventral nor the dorsal spinocerebellar tracts decussate within the medullary pyramids.

questions.text: A group of students is studying gluteal and thigh anatomy. The students identify the primary nerve that innervates the gluteus maximus muscle. Which of the following statements regarding this nerve is true?

choices.text: It is a pure motor nerve.
It exits the pelvis through the portion of the greater sciatic foramen above the piriformis muscle.
It exits the pelvis through the lesser sciatic foramen.
It has both motor and sensory fibers.
It provides sensory innervation to the tensor fascia lata muscle.

questions.solution:
The inferior gluteal nerve is one of the most critical nerves in the gluteal region. It originates from the L5-S2 nerve roots. The inferior gluteal nerve exits the pelvis and enters the gluteal region through the greater sciatic foramen inferiorly to the piriformis muscle.  The inferior gluteal nerve is a pure motor nerve. It provides motor innervation to the gluteus maximus muscle, which is involved in the extension and external rotation of the thigh at the hip joint.



Option Analysis

✅ It is a pure motor nerve. :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ It exits the pelvis through the portion of the greater sciatic foramen above the piriformis muscle.:
Incorrect: The superior gluteal nerve exits the pelvis through the portion of the greater sciatic foramen above the piriformis muscle. However, the gluteus maximus is primarily innervated by the inferior gluteal nerve. The inferior gluteal nerve leaves the pelvis through the greater sciatic foramen below the piriformis muscle.  
❌  It exits the pelvis through the lesser sciatic foramen. :
Incorrect: The inferior gluteal nerve exits the pelvis through the greater sciatic foramen, not the lesser sciatic foramen. 
❌ It has both motor and sensory fibers.:
Incorrect: The inferior gluteal nerve is a pure motor nerve.  
❌ It provides sensory innervation to the tensor fascia lata muscle.:
Incorrect: The sensory innervation for the tensor fascia lata muscle is supplied by the superior gluteal nerve, not the inferior gluteal nerve.

questions.text:
A 73-year-old woman develops weakness in the right hand following a stroke. Grip strength is 3/5 in the right hand and 5/5 in the left hand. The lower extremities are unremarkable. A coronal cross-section of the brain is shown below:



Which of the following regions of the motor homunculus is most likely affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient has weakness in the right upper extremity. A stroke involving the mid-lateral portions of the left motor cortex would account for this deficit.  

The proportion of neurons in the primary motor cortex utilized by each body part is represented by a humanoid figure called the motor homunculus. Starting at the superior medial part of the primary motor cortex, the lower extremities are represented first. The upper extremities and head are progressively represented as one moves laterally through the primary motor cortex.   

In addition, there is a sensory homunculus, which represents the proportion of sensory fibers in the primary somatosensory cortex received from each part of the body. Like the motor cortex, the superior medial parts of the somatosensory cortex receive signals from the lower extremities. In contrast, the more lateral portions of the cortex receive signals from the upper extremities and head.  



Option Analysis

❌ Region A:
Incorrect: The medial portion of the motor cortex is responsible for controlling the lower extremities. In contrast, this patient has weakness in the right upper extremity. 
❌ Region B:
Incorrect: The medial portion of the motor cortex is responsible for controlling the lower extremities. In contrast, this patient has weakness in the right upper extremity. 
❌ Region C:
Incorrect: The motor cortex region denoted by Region C would control movements in the left upper extremity. In contrast, the left motor cortex controls the right upper extremity, which is where the patient is experiencing weakness.
✅ Region D:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Region E:
Incorrect: The lateral portions of the motor cortex are responsible for controlling the movement of structures such as the head, neck, tongue, and larynx. This region of the motor cortex does not control upper extremity movement.
❌ Region F:
Incorrect: The lateral portions of the motor cortex are responsible for controlling the movement of structures such as the head, neck, tongue, and larynx. This region of the motor cortex does not control upper extremity movement.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents to the clinic for evaluation of intermittent pain in his lower extremities and back for the past two months. He describes these episodes as sudden, brief, severe stabs of pain that affect his legs and back, lasting for minutes to hours. Past medical history is significant for diabetes mellitus type II. He had a sexually transmitted infection in his teenage years, but he cannot remember what it was, and it resolved without treatment. He takes metformin, and he is inconsistent with clinic follow-ups. Physical examination of the lower extremities shows absence of deep tendon reflexes and impaired vibratory sensation and two-point discrimination, with normal motor strength. The Romberg test is positive. On ophthalmologic examination, the pupils fail to constrict in response to direct light, but when the patient is asked to focus on the examiner's index finger, the pupils constrict uniformly. CSF analysis shows lymphocytic pleocytosis. Which part of the pupillary light reflex pathway is affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient’s pupils are nonreactive to light with the retained ability to accommodate; this finding is consistent with Argyll Robertson (AR) pupil, most likely secondary to tabes dorsalis (tertiary syphilis) given the noted history of an untreated sexually transmitted infection. He also has the characteristic lancinating pains, physical examination findings of impaired vibratory sense, positive Romberg test, and absent deep tendon reflexes, in addition to CSF findings of lymphocytic pleocytosis, all of which are seen in tertiary syphilis.

The pupillary light and accommodation reflexes start at the retina, where sensory information travels through the optic tract. For the pupillary accommodation reflex, information goes to the lateral geniculate body, then into the visual cortex, then to the superior colliculus, before arriving at the Edinger-Westphal nucleus. For the pupillary light reflex, sensory information travels straight from the optic tract into the pretectal nucleus and then to the Edinger-Westphal nucleus.

Based on these two different pathways, we can see three possible sites of a lesion which may result in preservation of the accommodation reflex but loss of the pupillary light reflex. First, there may be a lesion along the pathway from the optic tract to the midbrain only affecting the pupillary light pathway fibers; second, there may be a lesion of the pretectal nuclei where only the pupillary light reflex synapses; and third, there may be damage to the part of the Edinger-Westphal nuclei that receives input only from the pretectal nuclei, not the superior colliculus fibers of the accommodation reflex. It is thought that neurosyphilis affects one of these areas, resulting in an AR pupil.

The AR pupils don’t constrict in response to light but are responsive to accommodation (when focused on a nearby object). AR pupils are highly suggestive of tertiary syphilis; however, they can occur in other underlying conditions, such as diabetes and multiple sclerosis.



Option Analysis

✅ Edinger-Westphal nucleus.:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Ciliary ganglion:
Incorrect: Damage to the ciliary ganglion will cause Holmes-Adie Syndrome, in which the pupils are dilated and react slowly to direct light.
❌ Optic nerve:
Incorrect: Damage or inflammation to the optic nerve (e.g. optic neuritis) causes pain with eye movements or at rest, as well as loss of vision.
❌ Superior colliculus:
Incorrect: Superior colliculus is not involved in the pupillary light reflex pathway. It is a part of the pupillary accommodation reflex pathway, which is intact in this patient.
❌ Short ciliary nerve:
Incorrect: Damage to the short ciliary nerve will lead to loss of the pupillary reflex and mydriasis.

questions.text: A 44-year-old woman comes to the physician with double vision, which started three weeks ago. She noticed that her double vision worsens when she is reading. She also has had difficulty walking downstairs. On physical examination, the patient prefers to keep her head tilted towards the right side. Ophthalmologic examination is significant for deviation of the left eye outward and upwards. Both pupils are 3 mm in diameter and are reactive to light. The physician suspects a cranial nerve palsy. Which of the following ocular muscles most likely lost innervation due to the cranial nerve palsy seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The trochlear nerve (CN IV) is a pure motor nerve that is responsible for innervating the superior oblique muscle, which is responsible for internal rotation of the eye; it is the main muscle that depresses the eye when it is adducted.



CN IV palsy results in the loss of the superior oblique muscle action. The patient usually complains of vertical diplopia, which is mostly seen when looking inward and downwards (e.g., reading a book, descending the stairs). In addition, due to the loss of internal rotation, the eye rests in the “out and up” position. This causes the patient to tilt their head toward the contralateral side in order to minimize the diplopia.



Isolated CN IV palsy is rare and is most commonly idiopathic, which is thought to be congenital and usually appears in the fourth decade of life. Other risk factors include head trauma and diabetes. 

Option Analysis

✅ The superior oblique muscle:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ The inferior oblique muscle:
Incorrect: The inferior oblique muscle is innervated by the oculomotor nerve. Oculomotor nerve palsy results in pupils deviating down and out (due to unopposed contraction of the superior oblique and lateral rectus muscles), with dilated pupils.
❌ The medial rectus muscle:
Incorrect: The medial rectus muscle is innervated by the oculomotor nerve. Oculomotor nerve palsy results in pupils deviating down and out (due to unopposed contraction of the superior oblique and lateral rectus muscles), with dilated pupils.
❌ The inferior rectus muscle:
Incorrect: The inferior rectus muscle is innervated by the oculomotor nerve. Oculomotor nerve palsy results in pupils deviating down and out (due to unopposed contraction of the superior oblique and lateral rectus muscles), with dilated pupils.
❌ The lateral rectus muscle:
Incorrect: The lateral rectus muscle is innervated by the abducens nerve. Abducens nerve palsy results in eye deviation medially, with inability to look laterally, and nystagmus on lateral gaze.

questions.text: A medical student is on her radiology rotation when the radiologist is asked to interpret a portable AP chest x-ray. While analyzing the x-ray, the radiologist begins discussing the anatomic significance of different findings on chest radiography.  Which of the following heart structures is outlined on the chest x-ray below?
questions.solution:
A standard anterior-posterior chest x-ray provides a plethora of information regarding anatomic structures of the heart. Notably, several structures make up the borders of the heart on standard chest radiography, including the right atrium, aortic arch, pulmonary artery, left auricle, and left ventricle. Derangements in these borders of the heart can aid in the diagnosis of underlying conditions (e.g. irregular aortic contour suggestive of aortic dissection). A specific finding known as the silhouette sign occurs when the normal heart borders are lost due to a pathological process in direct contact with the anatomic borders of the heart (e.g. pneumonia).  



Option Analysis

✅ Right atrium:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Right ventricle:
Incorrect: The right ventricle does not comprise the borders of the heart on a standard chest x-ray, given its more anterior position in the thoracic cavity. 
❌ Left ventricle :
Incorrect: The left ventricle comprises the left lower portion of the heart border on a standard chest x-ray. 
❌ Aortic arch:
Incorrect: The aortic arch comprises the most superior portion of the left heart border. 
❌ Pulmonary artery:
Incorrect: The pulmonary artery can be visualized as inferior to the aortic arch on chest radiography.

questions.text: A five-year-old boy is brought to his pediatrician to evaluate recurrent ear infections and sinusitis. The parent states, “He always seems to be sick with something. Every week, he is coughing or tugging on his ear. His nose runs constantly.” The patient was born full-term without complications during pregnancy or delivery. He has no other medical problems and does not take any medications daily. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates clear nasal secretions and hyperemia of the nasal mucosa bilaterally. After appropriate work-up and first-line medication trials, a nasal mucosa biopsy is performed and sent for transmission electron microscopy. Upon analysis of the specimen, the patient is found to have an absence of dynein arms on microtubule assemblies. Which of the following cardiac anomalies is most likely to be present given this patient’s clinical presentation?

choices.text: Apex of the heart located in the right chest
Displacement of the tricuspid valve leaflets into the right ventricle
Anterosuperior displacement of the infundibular cardiac septum

questions.solution:
This patient likely has primary ciliary dyskinesia (sometimes known as Karatagener syndrome), which arises due to defective dynein arms of the microtubule, resulting in impaired ciliary function. Ciliary dysfunction manifests as recurrent sinopulmonary infections, infertility (secondary to immotile sperm or immotile fallopian cilia), and bronchiectasis. This condition is highly associated with situs inversus, an embryological folding defect in which the thoracic and abdominal viscera are transposed across the midline (including the heart, a phenomenon termed dextrocardia).  

Patients with dextrocardia (whether in isolation or in association with situs inversus) will often have a palpable apex heartbeat over the right chest. On screening electrocardiogram, patients will have evidence of right axis deviation, inversion of all complexes in lead I, upright p waves in AVL, and an absent R wave progression in the anterior leads. A chest x-ray will demonstrate the apex of the heart in the right chest.  

It should be noted that when the condition occurs in isolation, dextrocardia is often associated with additional, more severe cardiac anomalies as compared to situs inversus, which is typically benign and often diagnosed incidentally.

 

Option Analysis

✅ Apex of the heart located in the right chest :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Displacement of the tricuspid valve leaflets into the right ventricle :
Incorrect: Ebstein anomaly is caused by in utero exposure to lithium. This condition is also associated with tricuspid regurgitation and isolated right heart failure. This patient likely has primary ciliary dyskinesia, which is instead associated with situs inversus.
❌ Anterosuperior displacement of the infundibular cardiac septum :
Incorrect: This answer describes Tetralogy of Fallot, the most common cause of early childhood cyanosis. This condition more commonly presents with tet-spells–episodes of cyanosis on exertion resulting from right to left shunting. This patient likely has primary ciliary dyskinesia, which is instead associated with situs inversus.
❌ Transpositioned aorta and pulmonary artery:
Incorrect: Transposition of the great vessels is a rare congenital cardiac defect that results in death within the first few months of life if untreated. It is not associated with ciliary dysfunction or upper respiratory infections. This patient likely has primary ciliary dyskinesia, which is instead associated with situs inversus.
❌ Tricuspid atresia :
Incorrect: Tricuspid atresia is the congenital absence of a tricuspid valve, with a subsequently hypoplastic right ventricle. This condition requires both a ventricular septal and atrial septal defect for survival. This patient likely has primary ciliary dyskinesia, which is instead associated with situs inversus.

questions.text:
A 70-year-old woman presents to the emergency department to evaluate left wrist pain. The patient was cleaning the bathroom when she slipped, fell, and landed on an outstretched left arm. She was subsequently unable to move her left wrist due to pain. Past medical history is notable for hypertension, and she takes amlodipine daily. She does not smoke or consume alcohol. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates swelling and deformity of the left wrist. Plain films of the left wrist are shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?  

Image reproduced from Radiopedia.
questions.solution:
This older patient presents after a fall on an outstretched hand (“FOOSH” injury). Imaging of the wrist demonstrates a distal radius fracture with dorsal angulation, which is consistent with a Colles fracture.

Colles fractures are the most common wrist fracture and typically occur after sports-related injuries in younger patients or low-energy trauma in older patients with osteoporosis. A fracture will appear on plain films of the distal radius, with varying degrees of impaction, displacement, and associated intra-articular fractures. The most common mechanism of injury involves a fall on an outstretched hand, such that the direction of force displaces the radial fragment dorsally.

Smith fractures are distal radius fractures with volar angulation. The most common mechanism of injury for this fracture pattern is falling onto flexed wrists. This contrasts to Colles fractures, wherein the wrist is held in extension during the fall. Smith fractures can be diagnosed via plain films.

Clinically, both fracture patterns will demonstrate swelling and deformity of the wrist with limited passive and active range of motion due to pain. Assessment of neurovascular status should take place before and after closed reduction.  

Option Analysis

✅ Colles fracture:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Smith fracture:
Incorrect: A Smith fracture involves volar displacement of the distal radius fracture fragment. In contrast, this patient’s radiograph demonstrates dorsal displacement of the distal radius fracture fragment.  
❌ Galeazzi fracture  :
Incorrect: A Galeazzi fracture is a transverse dorsally displaced fracture of the mid-radius with subsequent widening of the distal radio-ulnar joint.  
❌ Monteggia fracture:
Incorrect: Monteggia fractures are ulnar fractures with associated dislocation of the radial head from its articulation with the capitellum.  
❌ Bennett fracture:
