Incorrect: A Bennett fracture occurs at the base of the first metacarpal. It is an intraarticular fracture wherein the palmar ulnar aspect of the first metacarpal base is separated from the remainder of the first metacarpal.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician due to persistent right wrist pain. The patient has been experiencing pain on the thumb-side of the wrist every time she holds or grips an object. She recently delivered a healthy, full-term baby four weeks ago. Her past medical history is unremarkable, and she does not take any medications. Vitals are within normal limits. On physical examination, swelling and tenderness to palpation are noted at the radial aspect of the right wrist. Repetitive tapping over the volar part of the wrist does not reproduce the pain. While the patient is grasping the right thumb with the right four digits, the physician places the wrist in ulnar deviation. This maneuver reproduces the pain. Which of the following best describes the pathogenesis of this patient’s disease process?

choices.text: Myxoid degeneration of the abductor pollicis longus and the extensor pollicis brevis
Entrapment and compression of the median nerve
Outpouching of the synovial membranes lining tendinous sheaths
Occult fracture of the distal radius

questions.solution:
This patient presents in the postpartum period with pain over the radial aspect of the wrist and a positive Finklestein test. These findings are consistent with De Quervain tenosynovitis, characterized by myxoid degeneration of the abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis.

De Quervain tenosynovitis reflects a non-inflammatory thickening of the abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis as they cross the radial styloid process and through the first extensor compartment. Clinically, patients will experience pain at the radial aspect of the wrist. The pain is exacerbated when gripping objects or performing repetitive movements involving the thumb. Risk factors include female sex, being in the postpartum period, and prolonged abduction and extension of the thumb.

The most useful diagnostic aid in evaluating DeQuervain tenosynovitis is the Finklestein test. The thumb is flexed and held inside a fist to perform this test. Afterward, the wrist is moved in the ulnar direction. A positive test is characterized by pain at the radial styloid process or along the length of the abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis with ulnar deviation of the wrist.

Treatment is primarily conservative and involves rest, analgesia, and wrist splinting. Advanced or refractory cases are typically treated with glucocorticoids or surgery.  

Option Analysis

✅ Myxoid degeneration of the abductor pollicis longus and the extensor pollicis brevis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Entrapment and compression of the median nerve  :
Incorrect: Carpal tunnel syndrome typically presents with a positive Tinel test, which involves tapping over the median nerve and evaluating reproducible pain or paresthesia. This patient’s negative Tinel test and positive Finklestein test are more indicative of De Quervain tenosynovitis.  
❌ Outpouching of the synovial membranes lining tendinous sheaths  :
Incorrect: Ganglion cysts are clinically characterized by their round appearance and rubbery texture. No such structures are present on this patient’s physical examination.  
❌ Occult fracture of the distal radius:
Incorrect: A fracture of the distal radius is unlikely without associated trauma.  
❌ Calcium hydroxyapatite arthropathy  :
Incorrect: As the name implies, hydroxyapatite crystal deposition disease (HADD) is characterized by periarticular and intraarticular deposition of hydroxyapatite cysts. While HADD is on the differential for atraumatic swelling and pain of the wrist, this patient has a positive Finklestein test, making DeQuervain tenosynovitis a more likely diagnosis.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman comes to the physician for an evaluation of hoarseness. The patient underwent total thyroidectomy for treatment of thyroid carcinoma one month ago and subsequently developed hoarseness of the voice. Initially, she thought the symptom was just a transient side effect of the operation. However, when the symptoms persisted, she decided to seek further medical care. Vitals are within normal limits. The strength and sensation of the head and neck are intact. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal examinations are unremarkable. Direct laryngoscopy reveals paralysis of the right vocal cord. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient’s symptoms?

choices.text: Injury to the right recurrent laryngeal nerve during dissection of the inferior thyroid artery
Injury to the right recurrent laryngeal nerve during dissection of the superior thyroid artery
Injury to the right external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve during dissection of the superior thyroid artery.
Injury to the right external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve during dissection of the inferior thyroid artery
Injury to the right internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve during dissection of the superior thyroid artery

questions.solution:
This patient presents with hoarseness and unilateral vocal cord paralysis following a thyroidectomy. These findings are most likely due to recurrent laryngeal nerve injury during intraoperative dissection of the inferior thyroid artery.  

The recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN) is a branch of the vagus nerve. The RLN innervates all intrinsic muscles of the larynx except the cricothyroid muscle, which is supplied by the external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve. The recurrent laryngeal nerve also provides sensory supply to the larynx below the level of the vocal cords (subglottic sensation) and motor supply to the vocal cords.  

The right RLN descends with the rest of the vagus nerve anterior to the right subclavian artery before branching off and winding back around it posteriorly to course cranially in the tracheoesophageal groove toward the larynx. The right laryngeal nerve courses closely with the inferior thyroid artery at the junction of the lower and middle thirds of the thyroid. The left recurrent laryngeal nerve courses with the vagus nerve before branching and winding posteriorly around the aortic arch, subsequently ascending through the superior mediastinum and the tracheoesophageal groove towards the larynx. Both branches of the recurrent laryngeal nerve then enter the larynx below the inferior constrictor to supply the muscles and mucosa of the larynx.  

 


During a total thyroidectomy, patients are at risk of developing unilateral or bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve paralysis. Unilateral injury can cause paralysis to the true vocal cord and intrinsic muscles of the larynx. Clinically, patients can present with hoarseness and difficulty swallowing. Bilateral injury to the recurrent laryngeal nerve can cause stridor, airway compromise, and respiratory distress. It may necessitate a tracheostomy.  

 

Option Analysis

✅ Injury to the right recurrent laryngeal nerve during dissection of the inferior thyroid artery :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Injury to the right recurrent laryngeal nerve during dissection of the superior thyroid artery:
Incorrect: The recurrent laryngeal nerve is susceptible to injury in thyroidectomies due to its proximity to the inferior thyroid artery, not the superior thyroid artery. 
❌ Injury to the right external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve during dissection of the superior thyroid artery. :
Incorrect: The external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve is susceptible to injury in thyroidectomies due to its proximity to the superior thyroid artery. This nerve is responsible for supplying the cricothyroid muscle of the larynx. Damage to this nerve may cause changes to the pitch of a patient’s voice. However, vocal cord paralysis is more suggestive of recurrent laryngeal nerve injury.
❌ Injury to the right external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve during dissection of the inferior thyroid artery:
Incorrect: The external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve is susceptible to injury in thyroidectomies due to its proximity to the superior thyroid artery, not the inferior thyroid artery. Injury to this nerve may cause changes to the pitch of a patient’s voice. However, vocal cord paralysis is more suggestive of recurrent laryngeal nerve injury.
❌ Injury to the right internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve during dissection of the superior thyroid artery :
Incorrect: The internal branch provides sensory supply to the mucosa of the supraglottic larynx. It enters the larynx through the thyrohyoid membrane and courses relatively far from the thyroid. As a result, it is not typically injured in thyroidectomy.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman is currently postoperative day two in the surgical intensive care unit post total thyroidectomy for anaplastic thyroid carcinoma. During rounds, the patient reports a sensation of numbness around her lips and mouth and intermittent twitching of her upper and lower extremities. The patient's temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 101/min, respirations are 18/min, blood pressure is 156/67 mmHg, and O2. is 95% on room air. Physical examination demonstrates an intact incision over the anterior neck without edema or erythema.  A routine electrocardiogram is demonstrated below.  Which of the following laboratory findings is most likely to be present based on this patient’s clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient presents after total thyroidectomy with findings of circumoral numbness, tetany, and a prolonged QT interval on routine electrocardiographic screening, consistent with hypocalcemia. In the setting of a recent thyroidectomy, the most likely etiology of hypocalcemia is removal or damage to the parathyroid glands, resulting in hypoparathyroidism. The laboratory findings most reflective of this clinical condition is choice A.  

Multiple structures are at risk of injury during thyroidectomy or hemithyroidectomy, including surrounding glands, vasculature, and nerves (e.g., recurrent laryngeal nerves, external branches of the superior laryngeal nerves). Injury to the parathyroid glands can produce transient or permanent hypoparathyroidism. For this reason, many patients undergoing this procedure are empirically prescribed calcium supplementation to avoid complications associated with hypocalcemia.    

Symptoms of hypoparathyroidism and associated hypocalcemia include muscle tetany, paresthesias, seizures, and psychiatric symptoms (e.g., emotional instability, anxiety, depression). Moreover, hypocalcemia can cause cardiovascular compromise, resulting in QT interval prolongation on ECG, which can degenerate into torsade de pointes. Physical exam findings include the Chvostek sign and Trousseau sign (carpal spasms triggered by inflation of a sphygmomanometer).  

Option Analysis

✅                   Ca2+                        PO43-                                 PTH  ↓  ↑  ↓ :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌                   Ca2+                        PO43-                                 PTH  ↓  ↑  ↑:
Incorrect: Secondary hypoparathyroidism, due to chronic kidney disease, manifests with decreased levels of calcium, increased levels of phosphate, and increased parathyroid hormone. These effects are secondary to the kidney’s inability to respond to parathyroid hormone appropriately. 
❌                   Ca2+                        PO43-                                 PTH  ↓  ↓ ↑:
Incorrect: Vitamin D deficiency is characterized by decreased calcium, decreased phosphate, and increased parathyroid hormone levels.
❌                   Ca2+                        PO43-                                 PTH  ↓  ↓  ↓ :
Incorrect: These findings are not consistent with calcium, phosphorus, and parathyroid hormone homeostasis disorders. 
❌                   Ca2+                        PO43-                                 PTH  ↑  ↑  ↓ :
Incorrect: These findings are not consistent with calcium, phosphorus, or parathyroid hormone homeostasis disorders.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to his primary care physician for evaluation of persistent sciatica symptoms. The patient has had low back pain that radiates down the back of his left leg for weeks after he fell while skiing. The patient states, “The symptoms are getting so bad that I feel the leg is getting weaker. I’ve tried physical therapy, but it does not work.” The patient is otherwise healthy and does not take any medications. His vital signs are within normal limits. The patient has 4/5 strength with plantar flexion and a 1+ ankle jerk reflex on physical examination of the left leg. The right leg has 5/5 strength and full reflexes. Which of the following myotomes is most likely affected based on this patient’s clinical findings?
questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation of persistent sciatica and has evidence of S1 radiculopathy given this patient’s clinical findings of pain and diminished sensation that radiates down the posterior aspect of the leg, with associated weakness of plantar flexion and diminished ankle jerk reflex.   

Deep tendon reflexes can provide valuable information regarding the level of spinal cord involvement or damage to a particular nerve route. When this reflex is triggered, stretch receptors in the muscle-tendon send afferent impulses to the spinal cord through their cell bodies in the dorsal root ganglion, which then synapse with alpha motor neurons. Alpha motor neurons then transmit an automatic efferent signal back to the muscle leading to a contraction.    

Critical deep tendon reflexes include the brachioradialis and biceps tendon, which test myotome C5 and C6; the triceps tendon, which tests C6, C7, and C8; the patellar tendon, which tests L2, L3, and L4; and the Achilles tendon, which tests S1 and S2. Hyperactive reflexes indicate an upper motor neuron problem within the spinal cord or central nervous system, whereas hypoactive reflexes indicate peripheral nerve pathology.  


Option Analysis

✅ S1-S2:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ L2-L4:
Incorrect: L2-L4 is the myotome reflecting the knee jerk reflex, which is elicited by tapping on the patellar tendon while the knee flexes.  
❌ S3-S4:
Incorrect: S3-S4 is the myotome reflecting the anal wink reflex. This reflex may be absent in cauda equina syndrome due to compression of these nerve roots.  
❌ L1-L2:
Incorrect: L1-L2 are the myotomes associated with the cremasteric reflex, which will often be diminished in cases of testicular torsion.  
❌ C5-C6:
Incorrect: The C5-C6 myotome is associated with the biceps and brachioradialis reflexes, which are not implicated in this patient’s clinical presentation.

questions.text: A 68-year-old, right-handed man is brought to the emergency department to evaluate sudden onset weakness. The patient awoke with left-hand clumsiness that rapidly progressed to left-sided weakness, affecting the left arm more than the left leg. Past medical history is significant for hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and hyperlipidemia. The patient’s last refill of medications was one year ago. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes per day for the past 40 years. Temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 20/min and blood pressure is 200/110 mm Hg. On physical examination, the patient has slurred speech, left-sided facial weakness sparing the forehead, 2/5 muscle strength in the left upper limb, and 4/5 muscle strength in the left lower limb. Right-sided strength and sensation are normal. A right-sided infarct localized to the paramedian pontine base is seen on MRI. Which of the following additional findings will likely be observed in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient has an infarct of the paramedian pontine reticular formation (PPRF), which is located in the pons and supplied by the paramedian branches of the basilar artery.

The PPRF is the subcortical lateral gaze center, which normally receives input from the contralateral frontal eye field to stimulate the lateral rectus muscle of the ipsilateral eye via the ipsilateral abducens nucleus. This signal is also transmitted to the medial longitudinal fasciculus of the contralateral oculomotor nuclei to stimulate the medial rectus muscle of the contralateral eye. Together, these signals result in both eyes' simultaneous, conjugate movement towards the left or the right.

Common causes of lesions to the PPRF include ischemic or hemorrhagic strokes of the paramedian branches of the basilar artery. When these lesions occur, both eyes deviate toward the contralateral side, away from the brain lesion. On the contrary, the frontal eye field lesions produce similar symptoms where both eyes deviate but to the ipsilateral side, towards the brain lesion. For example, when the eyes deviate to the right, the lesion can either involve the left PPRF or the right frontal eye field.  

Option Analysis

❌ Bitemporal hemianopia:
Incorrect: The x-shaped optic chiasm serves as the point of partial crossing of fibers from the optic nerve. Damage to this structure results in bitemporal hemianopia. Common etiologies include pituitary tumors, craniopharyngiomas, and aneurysms of the anterior communicating artery.  
❌ Eye deviation to the right  :
Incorrect: Destructive lesions of the frontal eye field (e.g. middle cerebral artery stroke) cause the eyes to look toward the side of brain lesion (i.e. away from the side of hemiplegia). The middle cerebral artery does not supply blood to the paramedian pontine base.  
✅ Eye deviation to the left  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Contralateral hemianopia with macular sparing  :
Incorrect: Contralateral hemianopia with macular sparing is characteristic of posterior cerebral artery infarction. Other features include alexia without agraphia when the dominant hemisphere is affected.  
❌ Vertical gaze palsy  :
Incorrect: Parinaud (dorsal midbrain) syndrome is characterized by limitation of upward gaze with a downward gaze preference, bilateral eyelid lid retraction, and near-light dissociation (i.e. pupils react to accommodation but not to light). These findings often result from compression of the pretectal region of the midbrain (most likely from a pinealoma).

questions.text: A 39-year-old man is diagnosed with Bell palsy and has paralysis of the stapedius muscle. Which of the following is true regarding the stapedius muscle in the middle ear?

choices.text: It arises from the cartilaginous part of the auditory tube and the adjoining part of the sphenoid.
It detects low frequency sound vibrations.
Contraction of the muscle pulls the malleus medially.
It controls the amplitude of sound waves being transmitted to the inner ear.
It allows pressure to be equalized on both sides of the tympanic membrane.

questions.solution:
Contraction of stapedius muscle pulls the neck of the stapes laterally, thereby dampening the vibrations of the stapes and controlling the amplitude of sound waves being transmitted to the inner ear.

The ear is anatomically divided into 3 parts:

1) External ear: The external ear is composed of the auricle, which collects sound, and the external acoustic meatus (ear canal), which conducts sound to the tympanic membrane. The tympanic membrane forms a partition between the external acoustic meatus and the tympanic cavity of the middle ear.

2) Middle ear: The middle ear is a chamber in the petrous part of the temporal bone. It is connected anteromedially with the nasopharynx by the pharyngotympanic (eustachian) tube. It is connected posterosuperiorly with the mastoid cells through the mastoid antrum. The contents of the middle ear include:

  •  Auditory ossicles (malleus, incus, and stapes): The ossicles receive acoustic vibrations from the tympanic membrane and amplify them. They then transmit the amplified acoustic vibrations to the fluid of the inner ear via the oval window. 
  •  Eustachian tube: The pharyngotympanic (eustachian) tube controls the pressure within the middle ear and allows the pressure to be equalized on both sides of the tympanic membrane. 
  •  Stapedius and tensor tympani muscles: These muscles dampen transmission of loud noises to the inner ear. 
  •  Chorda tympani nerve: This nerve is a branch of CN VII. 
  •  Tympanic plexus of nerves 
3) Inner ear: The inner ear contains organs of hearing (e.g. cochlea) and equilibrium (e.g. vestibule).  

Option Analysis

❌ It arises from the cartilaginous part of the auditory tube and the adjoining part of the sphenoid.  :
Incorrect: The tensor tympani muscle arises from the cartilaginous part of the auditory tube and the adjoining part of the sphenoid.  
❌ It detects low frequency sound vibrations.  :
Incorrect: Low frequency sounds are detected and converted into nerve signals at the cochlear apex in the inner ear.  
❌ Contraction of the muscle pulls the malleus medially.  :
Incorrect: Contraction of the tensor tympani muscle pulls the malleus medially, whereas contraction of stapedius pulls the neck of the stapes laterally.  
✅ It controls the amplitude of sound waves being transmitted to the inner ear.  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ It allows pressure to be equalized on both sides of the tympanic membrane.  :
Incorrect: The eustachian tube controls pressure within the middle ear and allows pressure to be equalized on both sides of the tympanic membrane. This functionality is important for altitude compensation, such as when someone is traveling on an airplane.

questions.text:
An 8-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents because of a 1-day history of pain and swelling of his right eye. The patient does not have any visual changes or a history of trauma. The parents report the patient was in contact with a child at daycare who recently had an upper respiratory tract infection. The patient is otherwise healthy and does not take any medications daily. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates localized swelling along the right lower margin of the eyelid with associated erythema and tenderness. A photograph of the right eye is shown. The remainder of the physical examination is within normal limits.



Reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

Involvement of which of the following structures is implicated in this patient’s current ocular complaint?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with a hordeolum (stye), an abscess of the eyelid. External hordeolum arises from glands in the eyelash follicle or lid-margin (gland of Zeis and gland of Moll), whereas internal hordeolum is caused by inflammation of the meibomian gland. The infection is most commonly due to Staphylococcus aureus, but the hordeola can be sterile.

Chalazion, another condition of the eyelid, results from the obstruction of Zeis or meibomian glands. It typically presents with painless localized eyelid swelling and a nontender rubbery nodule on examination (see image below).



Reproduce fromWikimedia Commons

Differences between hordeolum and chalazion are summarized below:



Option Analysis

✅ Zeis/Moll glands:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Meibomian gland:
Incorrect: Chalazions result from obstruction of the Zeis or meibomian glands. This condition presents with lid discomfort and a painless nodule under the conjunctival eyelid. This patient instead has a tender nodule at the lid margin.
❌ Lacrimal sac:
Incorrect: Dacrocystitis refers to infection of the lacrimal sac and is characterized by pain and redness of the medial canthus. This patient has a tender nodule at the lid margin.
❌ Cornea:
Incorrect: The cornea serves as the site of infection in viral keratitis from herpes simplex or varicella-zoster virus. Patients present with corneal vesicles, as well as opacification and dendritic ulcers.
❌ Episcleral tissue:
Incorrect: Episcleritis refers to the infection or inflammation of the episcleral tissue between the conjunctiva and sclera. Patients endorse acute onset mild to moderate discomfort, photophobia, and watery discharge, and examination reveals diffuse bulbar conjunctival injection.

questions.text: A researcher is studying the autonomic pathways of the gastrointestinal system. Which of the following best characterizes parasympathetic innervation of the hindgut?
questions.solution:
The nerve supply to the gastrointestinal tract can be divided into intrinsic innervation, which controls digestive activity, and extrinsic innervation, which provides sympathetic and parasympathetic innervation.

The foregut and midgut receive parasympathetic innervation from the vagus nerve, whereas the hindgut receives parasympathetic innervation from the pelvic splanchnic nerves (S2-S4).  

Option Analysis

❌ Vagus nerve  :
Incorrect: The vagus nerve provides parasympathetic innervation to the foregut and midgut.  
❌ Inferior hypogastric plexus  :
Incorrect: The inferior hypogastric plexus has both parasympathetic and sympathetic components and innervates the internal pelvic viscera.  
❌ Lesser splanchnic nerve  :
Incorrect: The lesser splanchnic nerve (T9-T12) provides sympathetic innervation to the midgut.  
❌ Greater splanchnic nerve  :
Incorrect: The greater splanchnic nerve (T5-T10) provides sympathetic innervation to the foregut.  
✅ Pelvic splanchnic nerve  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A 52-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician with worsening right shoulder pain. The patient has difficulty pulling items off the shelf and can no longer do overhead weight exercises. Additionally, the pain often wakes the patient from sleep at night, especially when she lies on the right shoulder. Past medical history is notable for hypertension. On physical examination, the shoulder and elbow are placed at 90 degrees of flexion in front of the body. The patient experiences pain when the examiner internally rotates the shoulder. The left shoulder has a full range of motion. There is no reproducible tenderness on palpation or flexion of the cervical spine. A radiograph of the right shoulder is shown below:  


Image reproduced from ">Wikimedia Commons  
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with intermittent shoulder pain that worsens with overhead movements, but she has a normal shoulder radiograph. In addition, she has a positive Hawkins test, which is indicative of rotator cuff impingement or tendinopathy.

Rotator cuff impingement or tendinopathy is a common cause of shoulder pain. It often occurs due to repetitive overhead activity that results in inflammation of the rotator cuff tendons. Patients often describe pain over the lateral deltoid that is worse with overhead activity or while lying on the affected shoulder at night.

Physical examination will often demonstrate a positive Neer impingement test, wherein the patient experiences pain as the arm is passively flexed while in internal rotation. In addition, the Hawkins test can be used to diagnose rotator cuff impingement or tendinopathy. In this test, the examiner passively positions the shoulder and elbow at 90 degrees of flexion in front of the body, and patients will experience pain when the examiner passively internally rotates the shoulder.

Treatment of rotator cuff impingement or tendinopathy is centered on conservative management with physical therapy, analgesia, and rest.  

Option Analysis

✅ Rotator cuff tendinopathy  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Adhesive capsulitis  :
Incorrect: Adhesive capsulitis, also known as “frozen shoulder syndrome,” manifests with gross stiffness of the shoulder and nagging pain. Physical examination will demonstrate significant reductions in active and passive range of motion in two or more planes of movement.  
❌ Osteoarthritis  :
Incorrect: This patient’s above radiograph does not demonstrate evidence of glenohumeral joint space narrowing or bony erosion. Thus osteoarthritis is unlikely to be the cause of this patient’s symptoms.  
❌ Biceps tendinopathy  :
Incorrect: Biceps tendinopathy manifests with pain focused in the anterior shoulder with radiation distally over the biceps muscle.  
❌ Cervical spondylosis  :
Incorrect: Cervical spondylosis can mimic rotator cuff tendinopathy. However, in this condition, pain is often localized over the cervical spine, and patients can have a positive Spurling test (reproduction of symptoms when the patient’s head is turned towards the affected side, and pressure is applied to the top of the head).

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of right-sided back pain. For several weeks, the patient has had worsening, poorly localized right back pain. The pain radiates to the thigh and knee. He does not have a recent history of trauma. Past medical history includes poorly controlled HIV, chronic hepatitis C, and intravenous heroin use. The patient last injected heroin two days ago. Temperature is 37.4°C (99.4°F), blood pressure is 107/67 mmHg, and pulse is 106/min. Pain is elicited with passive extension of the right leg. Physical examination of the back is without focal tenderness, step-offs, or deformities. The patient has an antalgic gait. Neurovascular examination of the bilateral lower extremities is non-contributory, and the patient can void freely. If untreated, this patient is at risk of developing which of the following complications?
questions.solution:
This patient with a history of immunosuppression presents with poorly localized right back pain and a positive iliopsoas sign. The physical examination is negative for findings of cauda equina syndrome, epidural abscess, or other sources of infection. Together, these clinical findings are concerning for a psoas abscess, which can lead to femoral nerve damage if untreated.

A psoas abscess is a collection of pus in the iliopsoas compartment; it may result from an infection's contiguous, hematogenous, or postoperative spread. While rare, it more commonly presents in patients with underlying immunosuppression, diabetes, or intravenous drug use.

Clinically, this disease presents with fever and subacute, poorly localized back or flank pain radiating to the knee, in addition to gait disturbance or neuropathy if the femoral nerve is implicated. If the abscess becomes large enough, it may be palpable in the inguinal region and mistaken for an inguinal hernia, lymphadenopathy, or saphenous vein varix.

The femoral nerve courses anteriorly along with the iliopsoas and thus may become damaged as the disease progresses. Damage to this nerve may ultimately result in femoral neuropathy, manifesting with quadriceps weakness, decreased patellar reflexes, as well as sensory loss along the medial thigh and leg. Diagnosis is best achieved via a contrast-enhanced CT of the abdomen and pelvis. Management includes empiric antibiotics and source control via percutaneous or surgical intervention.  

Option Analysis

✅ Femoral neuropathy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Rectus sheath hematoma:
Incorrect: Injury to the inferior epigastric artery may occur with incisions or surgical procedures performed below the arcuate line (e.g. cesarean section). Failure to identify and ligate these arteries may result in rectus sheath hematoma formation. However, this patient does not have a history of recent surgeries or trauma.  
❌ Diverticulum perforation:
Incorrect: Diverticulum perforation can occur in the setting of untreated, complex diverticulitis. Diverticulitis more commonly presents in the left lower quadrant with alternating diarrhea, constipation, and fever. Diverticula typically develop in elderly individuals and thus would be unlikely in this patient, given his age.  
❌ Pyogenic liver abscess  :
Incorrect: Pyogenic liver abscesses may result from bacterial seeding or a complication from biliary tract pathology. This patient’s clinical presentation reflects a psoas abscess given his age and risk factors.  
❌ Bilateral lower extremity paraplegia  :
Incorrect: Bilateral lower extremity paraplegia is a devastating consequence of acute spinal cord compression or cauda equina syndrome. In contrast, this patient has a history of intravenous drug use, immunosuppression, and positive iliopsoas sign. Neurovascular examination of the lower extremities is unremarkable. In combination, these findings are more suggestive of a psoas abscess.

questions.text:
A pathologist views cross-sectional slides of the spinal cord and identifies the following structure (denoted by an asterisk):  


Image reproduced from ">Wikimedia Commons  
Which of the following best characterizes the function of this structure?

choices.text: Transmission of pain signals to the brain

questions.solution:
The asterisk points to the dorsal column medial lemniscus tract, one of the three main ascending tracts in the spinal cord. The other two tracts are the spinothalamic tract and spinocerebellar tract. All three tracts enter the spinal cord via the dorsal root.

The dorsal column medial lemniscus (DCML) tract transmits delicate sensations including vibration, proprioception, two-point discrimination, and touch to the brain. Neurons in this tract ascend via the ipsilateral dorsal columns and decussate (crossover) within the nucleus gracilis and cuneatus of the medulla.

The spinothalamic tract transmits sensations including crude touch, pain, pressure, and temperature to the brain. Neurons ascend ipsilaterally for 1-2 spinal segments, decussate in the anterior white commissure, and ascend via one of two tracts in the anterior or lateral spinal cord.

Finally, there is the spinocerebellar tract, which transmits unconscious proprioceptive sensation to the brain. After entering the spinal cord, the neurons either decussate immediately and become part of the ventral spinocerebellar tract (which later decussates again in the superior cerebellar peduncle) or ascend ipsilaterally as the dorsal spinocerebellar tract.  



Option Analysis

❌ Inhibition of extensor motor neurons  :
Incorrect: The rubrospinal tract facilitates flexor and inhibits extensor motor neurons. However, the rubrospinal tract is located in the lateral white column instead of the dorsal white column.  
❌ Transmission of pain signals to the brain:
Incorrect: The spinothalamic tract relays pain, temperature, crude touch, and pressure sensations to the brain. The spinothalamic tract is located within the anterior and lateral portions of the spinal cord.  
❌ Initiation of voluntary hand movements  :
Incorrect: The corticospinal tract facilitates voluntary motor control of the trunk and extremities. The fibers of the corticospinal pathway can be found in the anterior and lateral portions of the spinal cord. In contrast, the asterisk is located within the dorsal white column, which houses the dorsal column medial lemniscus tract.  
❌ Conduction of temperature sensation  :
Incorrect: The spinothalamic tract relays pain, temperature, crude touch, and pressure sensations to the brain. The spinothalamic tract is located in the anterior and lateral portions of the spinal cord.  
✅ Transmission of vibratory sensation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: During anatomy lab, a student is dissecting a cadaver and identifies the female internal reproductive organs and several surrounding ligaments. One of these ligaments is found to contain the ovarian vessels. Which of the following is true regarding this ligament?

choices.text: This ligament is the suspensory ligament.
It is made of folds of peritoneum.
This ligament is the cardinal ligament.
This ligament connects the ovaries to the uterus.

questions.solution:
The female reproductive system is made up of internal and external organs. The internal organs are the ovaries, fallopian tubes, uterus, cervix, and vagina. These organs are anchored in space by several ligaments.  

There are three ligaments attached to each ovary. The first one is the ovarian ligament, which connects the medial side of the ovaries to the uterus. The second is the suspensory ligament, which connects the ovaries to the lateral pelvic wall. The ovarian vessels (ovarian artery and vein) and the nerve plexus run in the suspensory ligament. Finally, the broad ligament, composed of peritoneal folds, also attaches to the ovaries (termed the mesovarium).



The uterus has four main ligaments. The first is the cardinal ligament, and it connects the uterus to the lateral pelvic walls and contains the uterine blood vessels. Then, there is the round ligament, which connects the uterus to the anterior abdominal wall. The uterosacral ligament extends superiorly and posteriorly from the side of the cervix to the middle of the sacrum. Finally, the uterus is also attached by the broad ligament.

 

Finally, the fallopian tubes are also anchored by the broad ligament (termed the mesosalpinx). 

Option Analysis

✅ This ligament is the suspensory ligament. :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌  This ligament is the ovarian ligament.  :
Incorrect: The ovarian ligament connects the ovaries to the uterus. However, the ovarian vessels are found in the suspensory ligament, not the ovarian ligament.  
❌ It is made of folds of peritoneum. :
Incorrect: The broad ligament is made of folds of peritoneal tissue and is responsible for anchoring the ovaries in place. However, the ovarian vessels do not run in the broad ligament.  
❌ This ligament is the cardinal ligament. :
Incorrect: The cardinal ligament contains the uterine (not the ovarian vessels) vessels. The cardinal ligament connects the uterus (and the cervix) to the lateral pelvic walls.  
❌ This ligament connects the ovaries to the uterus. :
Incorrect: The ovarian ligament connects the ovaries to the uterus. However, the ovarian vessels run in the suspensory ligament, not the ovarian ligament.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman, gravida 3, para 3, comes to the office for the evaluation of an abnormal protrusion in her abdomen. She is 6 weeks postpartum and reports that there has been a protrusion since she delivered the baby. The pregnancy was uncomplicated and ended with a normal vaginal delivery of a 7-lb. infant. Past medical history is unremarkable. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals a slight bulge in the epigastric region. The patient is asked to raise her head while being in the supine position with knees flexed. A diffuse fusiform bulge becomes prominent extending from the xiphoid to the umbilicus. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This postpartum patient presents with a midline abdominal bulge that becomes prominent on the contraction of the rectus abdominis muscle. She most likely has rectus abdominis diastasis, which refers to an abnormal separation between the two medial sides of the rectus muscles, with a laxity at the linea alba. A distance of two centimeters is usually considered abnormal in the midline abdomen above the umbilicus.



Risk factors include elevated intra-abdominal pressure, including obesity and pregnancy; conditions that weaken the abdominal wall (e.g. connective tissue disorders); and prior abdominal surgery. It most commonly affects infants (due to the partially developed rectus abdominis) and pregnant people (especially multiparous, due to repetitive stretching of the abdominal muscles). Of note, rectus abdominis diastasis is not a true hernia, as the midline fascial layer of the abdominal wall is intact; therefore, incarceration and strangulation do not occur.

Affected patients usually present with a midline abdominal ridge that becomes more prominent with straining and may disappear when the abdominal muscles are relaxed. Diagnosis is based on physical examination, and abdominal ultrasound can be performed to rule out hernia.

Option Analysis

❌ Epigastric hernia:
Incorrect: Although an epigastric hernia can present as a bulge between the umbilicus and xiphoid process, it is not usually fusiform, as it is a result of a defect in the linea alba of the abdominal wall. Moreover, it is less commonly associated with pregnancy than diastasis recti.
✅ Rectus divarication:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Rectus sheath hematoma:
Incorrect: A rectus sheath hematoma results from the disruption of one of the branches of the inferior epigastric artery. This condition presents with acute abdominal pain and a palpable abdominal wall mass that does not change during contraction of the rectus muscle.
❌ Incisional hernia:
Incorrect: An incisional hernia can develop at the site of a previous abdominal incision. Important risk factors include diabetes, immunosuppression, obesity, smoking, malnutrition, and connective tissue disorders. This patient has no surgical history.
❌ Lipoma:
Incorrect: A lipoma is a lump under the skin that results from the overgrowth of fat cells. Physical examination usually shows a mobile, painless mass with a soft consistency. This patient, with a new bulge postpartum, is more likely to have diastasis recti.

questions.text: A 74-year-old man comes to the office because of a small bulge on the right side of his groin. The patient first noted the lesion after helping his daughter move to a new home. He reports sharp discomfort in the right groin worsens with walking and heavy lifting. Resting supine decreases the severity of the pain. Past medical history is significant for hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include lisinopril, atorvastatin, and metformin. BMI is 35.5 kg/m2. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a bulge in the right groin above the inguinal ligament, which increases in size when the patient coughs. There is no overlying erythema or warmth. An ultrasound reveals that the bulge originates medial to the inferior epigastric vessels. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient’s presentation?

choices.text: Dilatation of the long saphenous vein
Failure of closure of the processus vaginalis

questions.solution:
This patient’s groin mass protruding medial to the inferior epigastric vessels is characteristic of a direct inguinal hernia in the Hesselbach triangle.

Inguinal hernias make up to 96% of groin hernias. They can be classified into direct or indirect hernias. They develop more frequently on the right in both sexes, which is thought to be due to a later descent of the right testicle in males and due to the asymmetry of the pelvis in females.

Direct inguinal hernias result from weakness of the transversalis fascia that makes up the floor of the Hesselbach triangle. Other boundaries include inferior epigastric vessels laterally, the inguinal ligament inferiorly, and the rectus abdominis muscle medially. Contents bulge through the external or superficial inguinal ring only and are covered by the external spermatic fascia. Inguinal hernias are most commonly seen in older males.



Indirect hernias are the most common type of groin hernia and result from a patent processus vaginalis. They are located lateral to the inferior epigastric artery and protrude through the internal inguinal ring, which is the site where the spermatic cord in males and the round ligament in females exits the abdomen.



Option Analysis

❌ Dilatation of the long saphenous vein:
Incorrect: Saphenous varix is the dilatation of the long saphenous vein at its junction with the femoral vein in the groin. It appears as a bulge with a bluish tinge below the inguinal ligament. It disappears on lying down and exhibits a thrill on auscultation. It is usually associated with varicose veins. This patient’s presentation is more consistent with a direct inguinal hernia.
❌ Testicular neoplasm:
Incorrect: Testicular neoplasm is a rare condition that presents a firm testicular mass that does not change with positioning or Valsalva maneuver. This patient’s presentation is more consistent with a direct inguinal hernia.
✅ Weakness of the transversalis fascia:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Failure of closure of the processus vaginalis:
Incorrect: Failure of closure of the processus vaginalis can result in indirect inguinal hernias, which present lateral to the inferior epigastric vessels (unlike this patient).
❌ Widening of the femoral ring:
Incorrect: Widening of the femoral ring can result in a femoral hernia, which protrudes in the upper thigh medial to the femoral vein (not epigastric vessels).

questions.text:
A 56-year-old man presents to his primary care physician with right ring finger pain. The patient recalls that the right ring finger has been “catching and locking” for weeks. The symptoms seem to improve throughout the day, with gradual “unlocking” as the day progresses. Past medical history is notable for type II diabetes mellitus and hypertension, for which he takes metformin and hydrochlorothiazide. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates the fourth digit of the right hand to be in a flexed position, as shown below. Passive extension of the digit is met with some resistance. There are no palpable nodules or tenderness along the flexor tendon sheath. Nonetheless, he can fully extend the digit with minimal pain. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?  


Image reproduced from Wikipedia
questions.solution:
This patient has intermittent locking and catching of the fourth digit and difficulty extending the finger from a flexed position. This clinical presentation is most consistent with trigger finger, also termed stenosing tenosynovitis.

Trigger finger is a flexor tendon that catches when it attempts to glide through a stenotic sheath, resulting in an inability to flex or extend the finger smoothly. The underlying pathology of this disease remains unclear but is thought to be due to fibrocartilaginous metaplasia of the ligamentous layer of the tendon sheath. The majority of cases are idiopathic, although some are associated with repetitive hand motions, often from occupational activities.

Clinically, patients experience a catching and locking sensation of the finger that progressively worsens over time. Patients may also experience pain localized over the volar aspect of the metacarpophalangeal joint.  

Treatment is primarily conservative and involves splinting, analgesia, and rest. Local glucocorticoid injection can also be administered. Patients who are refractory to conservative management or glucocorticoid injections may warrant the surgical release of the flexor tendon.  

Option Analysis

✅ Stenosing tenosynovitis  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Dupuytren contracture  :
Incorrect: A Dupuytren contracture is characterized by slow, progressive fibroproliferation of the palmar fascia. Patients typically have a palpable cord or nodules along the flexor tendon sheath.  
❌ Flexor tenosynovitis  :
Incorrect: Flexor tenosynovitis is a surgical emergency and refers to a deep space infection of the flexor tendon sheath. Patients can present with pain with passive extension, tenderness over the entire length of the flexor tendon sheath, symmetric finger swelling along the length of the tendon sheath, and flexed posture of the affected finger.
❌ Mallet finger  :
Incorrect: Mallet finger refers to an injury to the extensor digitorum as it crosses the distal interphalangeal joint. This injury results in an inability to extend the finger at the distal interphalangeal joint.  
❌ Jersey finger  :
Incorrect: Jersey finger refers to an injury to the flexor digitorum profundus tendon as it crosses the distal interphalangeal joint. This injury results in an inability to flex the finger at the distal interphalangeal joint.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man comes to the physician to evaluate dysphagia and hoarseness that have been ongoing for the past three days. He has dysphagia with both solids and liquids. He has a history of poorly controlled hypertension. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 160/85 mmHg, and pulse is 92/min. Physical examination reveals decreased sensation over the posterior aspect of the tongue. The uvula deviates towards the right side. The appearance of the uvula suggests loss of function of which of the following nerves?
questions.solution:
The vagus nerve carries parasympathetic motor fibers to the somatic organs. It also provides motor supply to the muscles of the larynx, pharynx and soft palate.   

The main motor nucleus of the vagus nerve is situated within the reticular formation of the medulla oblongata. It receives inputs from the corticonuclear fibers and sends motor impulses via the direct pharyngeal branches of the vagus nerve to the constrictor muscles of the pharynx and soft palate (except for the tensor palatini muscles) and intrinsic muscles of the larynx.    

The uvula is a centrally located conic projection from the soft palate. If the pharyngeal branch of the vagus nerve is injured, the uvula will deviate away from the side of the lesion and towards the contralateral (unaffected) side. This phenomenon occurs due to a combination of intact palatal muscle pull on the contralateral side and palatal droop on the ipsilateral side.  

Additional symptoms seen in high vagal injuries include dysphagia from palatal weakness and paralysis of the constrictor muscles, in addition to hoarseness from impaired sensation from the superior laryngeal nerve (another branch of the vagus nerve).  

 

Option Analysis

❌ Right vagus nerve:
Incorrect: The uvula deviates towards the contralateral side from the causative lesion. As a result, rightwards deviation of the uvula is suggestive of a left vagus nerve injury.
✅ Left vagus nerve:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Left glossopharyngeal nerve :
Incorrect: Uvular deviation is due to vagal nerve injury and subsequent loss of palatal muscle function. Glossopharyngeal nerve injury does not cause uvular deviation.   
❌ Right glossopharyngeal nerve :
Incorrect: Uvular deviation is due to vagal nerve injury and subsequent loss of palatal muscle function. Glossopharyngeal nerve injury does not cause uvular deviation. 
❌ Left hypoglossal nerve :
Incorrect: The hypoglossal nerve is responsible for the movement of the tongue. Loss of the left hypoglossal nerve function will result in ipsilateral tongue deviation. In contrast, uvular deviation is due to vagus nerve injury.

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant boy is evaluated for the first time since delivery. The patient was born at 40 weeks gestation via vaginal delivery and had a normal prenatal and postnatal birth history. He feeds 2-3 oz of breastmilk and formula every 2-3 hours. He is in the 75<sup>th</sup> percentile for height, 75<sup>th</sup> percentile for weight, and 50<sup>th</sup> percentile for head circumference. On physical examination, there is prominent head posturing. The head is tilted to the right side, and the chin is rotated to the left shoulder. A mass is palpable in the inferior portion of the neck on the right side. The mass is firm and does not transilluminate with a penlight. The rest of the physical examination, including the reflexes and muscular tone of the extremities, is normal. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
Torticollis results from a contraction or shortening of the neck muscles, such as the sternocleidomastoid or trapezius muscle. This condition typically presents with the head tilted towards the affected side and the chin rotated away from the affected side, limiting the neck’s range of motion. This posturing is because the condition mimics the action of the sternocleidomastoid, which functions to flex the head toward the side of contraction (in this case, the right) and laterally rotate the head or chin away from the side of the contraction (in this case, the left).  

Torticollis can be congenital or acquired, as described below: 
  •  Congenital torticollis is the most common type of torticollis. This postural deformity of the neck develops prenatally and is most often caused by the development of a fibrous tissue tumor in the sternocleidomastoid muscle and less often by neurological or bony abnormalities.  
  •  There is also congenital muscular torticollis, a postural deformity that is typically evident 2-4 weeks after delivery and often occurs during delivery when there is tearing of the muscle fibers of the baby's neck, resulting in subsequent fibrosis and shortening of the neck muscles.   
  •  Acquired torticollis typically appears after delivery and can be caused by various conditions that cause injury or inflammation to the muscles of the neck. These can range from trauma to infection or neurological disorders. Acquired torticollis typically occurs in children but can occur in adults as well.  
Adults usually acquire a type of torticollis referred to as spasmodic torticollis, or cervical dystonia, resulting from strenuous movement or awkward positioning for too long. Spasmodic torticollis is a chronic and painful condition characterized by involuntary contraction of the neck muscles, leading to involuntary tilting, turning, flexing, or extending the neck. In most cases, the cause of spasmodic torticollis is unknown, but more serious causes include cervical spine injuries, such as fractures and subluxations.  



Option Analysis

❌ Clavicle fracture:
Incorrect: Clinical findings of a clavicle fracture include asymmetric contour, crepitus, edema, decreased or absent movement of the arm on the affected side, and crying with passive movement of the arm on the affected side. This infant more likely has a diagnosis of congenital muscular torticollis.  
❌ Vertebral anomaly:
Incorrect: Although a radiograph was not performed on this patient, the clinical symptoms suggest congenital muscular torticollis, not a vertebral anomaly.  
❌ Central nervous system lesion:
Incorrect: Central nervous system (CNS) lesions may also cause a head tilt in young infants. However, infants with CNS lesions usually have abnormal neurologic findings (e.g., cranial nerve palsy, recurrent vomiting). This infant more likely has a diagnosis of congenital muscular torticollis.  
❌ Lymphangioma:
Incorrect: Lymphangioma (previously known as a cystic hygroma) is another cause of a neck mass in a young infant. In contrast to this sternocleidomastoid mass of congenital muscular torticollis, which is firm and does not transilluminate, cystic hygromas are soft and do transilluminate.  
✅ Congenital muscular torticollis  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old man presents to the emergency department as a level 1 trauma following a fall from scaffolding. The patient worked as a painter and slipped and fell approximately 20 ft, landing on his back. Upon arrival, the patient has a GCS of 15 and endorses pain in his lower back. Temperature is 37.0 °C (98.6 °F), pulse is 105/min, respirations are 18/min, blood pressure is 176/65 mmHg, and O2 saturation is 97% on room air. The patient's primary survey is intact, and his secondary survey is notable for a step-off and pain at the T12-L1 spinal level. An emergent MRI of the spine is demonstrated below. Which of the following additional clinical features is most specific to this patient's clinical condition?

Reproduced from: Radiopaedia
questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation following back trauma and has an MRI that demonstrates a compression fracture of the L1 vertebral body with subsequent compression on the conus medullaris. This neurosurgical emergency presents with all the clinical features of cauda equina syndrome, plus upper motor neuron deficits such as hyperreflexia.    

Conus medullaris syndrome is a rare neurosurgical emergency that refers to compression of the conus medullaris from trauma, spinal epidural abscess, hematoma, or disc herniation. This pathologic entity presents with many overlapping features of cauda equina syndrome, including acute lower back pain with associated lower extremity weakness, saddle anesthesia, and bowel, bladder, and sexual dysfunction.  

Key differentiating features of conus medullaris syndrome include the presence of upper motor neuron deficits (e.g. hyperreflexia, increased tone) and symmetric, bilateral lower extremity weakness. The latter may be mild if the lesion is restricted and spares both the lumbar cord and the adjacent sacral and lumbar nerve roots. In addition, conus medullaris syndrome is more commonly implicated in spinal lesions from T12-L1 since the spinal cord terminates as the conus medullaris at this level in most adult patients. Trauma or lesions below this spinal level are unlikely to result in conus medullaris syndrome.  



Option Analysis

✅ Hyperreflexia:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Saddle anesthesia :
Incorrect: Saddle anesthesia is present in both cauda equina syndrome and conus medullaris syndrome and is therefore not specific.  
❌ Asymmetric lower extremity weakness:
Incorrect: Symmetric, bilateral lower extremity weakness is more likely to be found in patients with conus medullaris syndrome; however, it can also be observed in patients with cauda equina syndrome and is therefore nonspecific.  
❌ Urinary retention:
Incorrect: Urinary retention is found in both conditions and is not specific to conus medullaris or cauda equina syndrome.  
❌ Decreased bulbocavernosus reflex:
Incorrect: A decreased bulbocavernosus reflex is present in both cauda equina syndrome and conus medullaris syndrome and is therefore not specific to either condition.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man comes to his primary care physician because of pain with defecation. The symptoms began 2 weeks ago. The pain is worse with straining, and the patient has occasionally noticed streaks of fresh blood on his stools. He works as a construction worker, and his diet consists mostly of fast food. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), blood pressure is 142/85 mmHg, and pulse is 73/min. Physical exam shows multiple purplish-blue sacs in the anal canal. Which of the following structures is most likely responsible for providing sensory innervation to the lesion site?
questions.solution:
Hemorrhoids arise from the cushions that line the rectum and anal canal, which are made of connective tissue, smooth muscle, and the blood-filled arteriovenous plexus. These blood vessels can become abnormally dilated and distended, causing them to become protruding masses. Abnormal distension of blood vessels typically occurs in cases of excessive straining (e.g., chronic constipation, chronic cough), prolonged sitting, and pregnancy.  

Hemorrhoids can be divided into internal and external hemorrhoids. Internal hemorrhoids are located above the pectinate line, which divides the upper two thirds and lower third of the anal canal. Internal hemorrhoids usually bleed, but they are not painful, since they receive visceral innervation from the parasympathetic pelvic splanchnic nerves and the sympathetic inferior mesenteric plexus.  

In contrast, external hemorrhoids are located below the pectinate line. They bleed less frequently, but they are painful and pruritic, because they receive somatic innervation from the inferior rectal branch of the pudendal nerve.  

Diagnosis of internal and external hemorrhoids can be made by visual inspection and digital rectal exam. Conservative management includes increased dietary intake of fiber, increased water intake, and stool softeners to prevent future constipation. Local anesthetics, such as lidocaine, can also be used. For internal hemorrhoids that persistently bleed, rubber band ligation can be done. External hemorrhoids can be treated by hemorrhoidectomy (surgical removal of hemorrhoids) if the condition is persistent or severe.  

Option Analysis

❌ Pelvic splanchnic nerves:
Incorrect: The pelvic splanchnic nerves provide parasympathetic innervation to areas above the pectinate line. However, this patient reports pain with defecation, which is more consistent with the presentation of external hemorrhoids. External hemorrhoids are below the pectinate line and therefore are not innervated by the pelvic splanchnic nerves.  
✅ Pudendal nerve:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Inferior mesenteric plexus:
Incorrect: The inferior mesenteric plexus provides sympathetic innervation to areas above the pectinate line. However, this patient endorses pain with defecation. This is most consistent with the presentation of external hemorrhoids. External hemorrhoids are below the pectinate line and therefore are not innervated by the inferior mesenteric plexus.  
❌ Medial cluneal nerve:
Incorrect: This nerve innervates the portion of the buttocks that is closest to the midline of the body. However, it does not innervate the opening of the anal canal, which is where the patient’s external hemorrhoids are located.  
❌ Genitofemoral nerve:
Incorrect: The genitofemoral nerve innervates the upper anterior thighs, as well as the scrotum in men and mons pubis in women. This nerve does not relay sensory information from the anal canal.

questions.text:
A 69-year-old man is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of a syncopal event while walking to the bathroom. The patient's past medical history includes uncontrolled hypertension and hyperlipidemia. On initial evaluation, the patient is unresponsive to verbal or tactile stimuli. There are no observable cranial nerve functions. Corneal and gag reflexes are absent on examination. The patient is subsequently intubated and admitted to the ICU. Two days later, the patient’s nurse reports the patient is able to open his eyes and respond to stimuli with vertical eye movements. A noncontrast CT of the brain is demonstrated below:

 

 Reproduced from: Radiopaedia  

A stroke in which of the following vascular structures is the most likely etiology of this patient’s clinical condition?
questions.solution:
At the base of the medulla, both vertebral arteries fuse to create the basilar artery. As the basilar artery ascends, it yields the following branches:

  •  Anterior inferior cerebellar artery, or AICA, which supplies the lateral pons and part of the cerebellum  
  •  Labyrinthine (internal auditory) artery, which supplies the cochlea and labyrinth 
  •  Pontine arteries, which supply the mid-pons and upper and lower portions of the pons 
  •  Right and left superior cerebellar arteries, which supply a part of the pons laterally and the superior part of the cerebellum  
  •  Right and left posterior cerebral arteries, or PCAs, which supply the occipital lobe 
If the basilar artery becomes occluded, damage to the pons often results in locked-in syndrome, wherein the patient becomes quadriplegic and mute. Additionally, loss of horizontal eye movements occurs due to implication of the paramedian pontine reticular formation, with preservation of vertical eye movements. Despite these devastating neurologic consequences, consciousness is preserved due to preservation of the reticular activating system, or RAS.



Option Analysis

❌ Anterior spinal artery:
Incorrect: A stroke affecting the anterior spinal artery causes infarction of the anterior two-thirds of the spinal cord with development of contralateral paralysis of both upper and lower extremities and  contralateral loss of pain and temperature.
✅ Basilar artery:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Left middle cerebral artery:
Incorrect: A left middle cerebral artery stroke would cause right-sided weakness. This patient is presenting with complete loss of motor function and sensation.
❌ Lenticulostriate arteries:
Incorrect: Lacunar strokes occur secondary to ischemia within the lenticulostriate arteries, which are  a collection of small perforating arteries arising from the anterior part of the circle of Willis. Patients with lesions in these vessels present with varying symptoms including hemiparesis or hemisensory loss; however, this patient is presenting with complete loss of motor function and sensation.
❌ Right middle cerebral artery:
Incorrect: A right middle cerebral artery stroke would cause left-sided weakness. This patient is presenting with complete loss of motor function and sensation, which suggests a stroke in a different vessel.

questions.text:
A fundoscopic examination is performed on a healthy individual as part of a routine physical examination. The following is visualized:


Source: Wikimedia Commons

Which of the following is true regarding the area marked with the arrow?

choices.text: It contains both rods and cones.
It is where the optic nerve leaves.

questions.solution:
The retina is the innermost layer of the eye which contains photoreceptors and is responsible for processing light into brain signals. When examined with a fundoscope, many of the retinal structures can be identified.    

First, in the center of the retina is the optic disc. The central disc is the exit site for the central retinal vein and optic nerve, as well as the entry site of the central retinal artery (a branch of the ophthalmic artery). The optic disc contains no photoreceptors and therefore forms a blind spot in the visual field.    

Lateral to the optic disc is the macula. The macula is the most sensitive area in the retina and contains only cones. It is responsible for high-acuity vision. In the center of the macula is an area called the fovea centralis. The fovea is more depressed than the rest of the rest of the macula, and it is the place where the highest-acuity vision is sensed.



Option Analysis

❌ It contains no photoreceptors.:
Incorrect: The macula is the most sensitive part of the retina and contains only cones.
❌ It contains both rods and cones.:
Incorrect: The macula of the retina is responsible for the acuity of vision and contains only cones.
❌ It contains only rods.:
Incorrect: The macula contains no rods and only cones.
❌ It is where the optic nerve leaves.:
Incorrect: The optic nerve leaves at the optic disc, which is medial to the macula.
✅ It contains only cones.:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man comes to the office to evaluate clumsiness and a pins-and-needles sensation in his right hand. The patient is worried that he won’t be able to participate in an upcoming road bicycle race due to his hand weakness. The patient suffered a fall while riding his bicycle four months ago. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination of the right hand demonstrates hypothenar eminence atrophy, decreased sensation over the 4th and 5th digits, diminished finger abduction, and weakness in adduction of the fingers and thumb adduction. Which of the following is the most likely site of nerve injury?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation is consistent with distal ulnar nerve injury, most likely due to a fracture of the hook of the hamate.   

The ulnar nerve originates from the medial cord of the brachial plexus (C8-T1) and courses with the brachial artery in the upper arm to enter the forearm after passing posterior to the medial epicondyle of the humerus.  



In a distal ulnar nerve injury (e.g. fracture of the hook of hamate or compression from bicycle handlebar), patients often endorse numbness and paresthesias of the medial 1½ digits of the hand, decreased abduction of the fingers (weakness in the intrinsic interosseous muscles), weakness in adduction of the fingers and thumbs, as well as hypothenar eminence atrophy. This injury often manifests as an “ulnar claw,” meaning that when the patient attempts to extend the fingers, the 4th and 5th digits remain extended at the MCP, while the DIP and PIP remain flexed.  

Common mechanisms of ulnar injury at the elbow include medial epicondyle fractures, trauma, or prolonged leaning or sleeping on an object. In addition to distal deficits, patients present with loss of function of the flexor digitorum profundus medially. When asked to make a fist, patients cannot flex the 4th and 5th digits resulting in an “OK gesture.”  In addition, the wrist will demonstrate radial deviation  with flexion (loss of flexor carpi ulnaris).  



Option Analysis

❌ Surgical neck of the humerus:
Incorrect: A fracture of the surgical neck of the humerus commonly results from a fall on an outstretched hand and is most likely to damage the axillary nerve. It typically presents with weakness of arm adduction at the shoulder and loss of sensation of the lateral upper arm.
❌ Midshaft of the humerus:
Incorrect: The radial nerve is most commonly injured with midshaft humerus fractures. Injury results in weakness of wrist, finger, and thumb extension and weakness with elbow supination. This patient most likely sustained an ulnar nerve injury at the hook of the hamate.
❌ Coracobrachialis:
Incorrect: The coracobrachialis muscle is innervated by the musculocutaneous nerve. Damage to this nerve results in weakness with forearm flexion and supination, as well as the sensory loss over the lateral forearm.
❌ Carpal tunnel:
Incorrect: The median nerve can be compressed in the carpal tunnel, resulting in pain and paraesthesias in the radial 3½ digits, weakness of the first and second lumbrical, thenar atrophy, and weakness of thumb abduction and opposition. The medial 1½ digits are spared in these patients.
✅ Hook of the hamate:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman comes to the office to evaluate intermittent painful double vision for three days. Her symptoms occur only when looking laterally. The patient has myopia and has been wearing corrective lenses for ten years. Ten days ago, the patient fell off her bike and was seen in the emergency department. During that visit, a head CT scan was performed and was unremarkable. Current medications include oral contraceptive pills. Vitals are within normal limits. On examination, the pupils are equal and reactive to light. Corrected visual acuity is 20/40 in each eye. The left eye abducts with attempted left gaze, but the right eye remains stationary. The right eye abducts and exhibits horizontal nystagmus with a rightward gaze, but the left eye remains stationary. The patient can converge both eyes without associated nystagmus. Fundoscopy reveals bilateral disc hyperemia. Injury to which of the following structures is the most likely etiology of this patient's ocular symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with characteristic adduction defects of internuclear ophthalmoplegia (INO) and hyperemia of the optic discs. Together, these findings indicate optic neuritis, one of the most common initial findings of multiple sclerosis (MS).

INO is a disorder of conjugate horizontal gaze. The affected eye cannot adduct, and the contralateral eye abducts with nystagmus; however, convergence and pupillary light reflexes are preserved. This condition is secondary to demyelination of the medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF), which normally mediates communication between the CN III (oculomotor) and CN VI (abducens) nuclei to allow for coordinated horizontal eye movements. Unilateral MLF lesions often result from lacunar strokes in the pontine artery distribution, whereas bilateral MLF lesions are typically observed in patients with MS.  



Option Analysis

❌ Oculomotor nerve  :
Incorrect: Damage to the oculomotor nerve (CN III) leaves the actions of the lateral rectus and the superior oblique muscle unopposed, resulting in an abducted and depressed eye (“down and out”). Ptosis and mydriasis are often seen as well.  
❌ Medial lemniscus  :
Incorrect: A lesion of the medial lemniscus would result in contralateral loss of vibration, proprioception, and light touch.  
✅ Medial longitudinal fasciculus  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Dorsal midbrain  :
Incorrect: Damage to the dorsal midbrain can cause Parinaud syndrome, with impaired upgaze and dilated non-reactive pupils. Moreover, Parinaud syndrome is most commonly seen in patients with hydrocephalus or posterior midbrain lesions (e.g. pineal tumors); trauma is an infrequent cause of Parinaud syndrome.  
❌ Abducens nerve:
Incorrect: Abducens nerve damage results in isolated lateral rectus palsy and an inability to abduct the eye.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents to the emergency department because of episodic, burning substernal chest pain. According to past medical records, the patient has a right-dominant circulation. A myocardial perfusion scan reveals inducible ischemia in the posteroinferior surface of the heart. This region of the heart is supplied by which of the following vessels?
questions.solution:
Coronary dominance is determined by the coronary artery that supplies the posterior descending artery (PDA). The PDA originates from one of the following:

1) Right coronary artery in approximately 70-80% of the population (right dominant)
2) Left circumflex artery in approximately 5-10% of the population (left dominant)
3) Both right coronary and left circumflex arteries in 10-20% of the population (codominant)

The posterior descending artery runs along the posterior interventricular groove and supplies the posterior one-third of the interventricular septum, as well as the posterior two-thirds of the ventricles.

In this patient with right dominant circulation, occlusion of the right coronary artery would account for the inducible ischemia in the posteroinferior surface of the heart.  



Option Analysis

❌ Left circumflex artery  :
Incorrect: The left circumflex artery usually supplies the lateral and posterior walls of the left ventricle.  
❌ Left anterior descending artery  :
Incorrect: The left anterior descending artery normally supplies the anterior two-thirds of the interventricular septum (septal branches), anterior wall of the left ventricle, and parts of the anterior papillary muscle.  
❌ Obtuse marginal artery  :
Incorrect: The obtuse marginal artery is a branch of the left circumflex artery and supplies the lateral wall of the left ventricle.  
❌ Left main coronary artery  :
Incorrect: In the approximately 10% of individuals who have left dominant circulation, the posterior descending artery branches from the circumflex branch of the left main coronary artery. However, this patient has right dominant circulation.  
✅ Right main coronary artery  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after being involved in a motor vehicle collision. He was crossing the road when a car hit him on the left side. The patient did not lose consciousness but began experiencing excruciating left-sided chest pain after the incident. Upon arrival, his temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 96/min, blood pressure is 138/77 mmHg, and respiratory rate is 17/min. Physical examination reveals bruising and tenderness to palpation along the left chest wall at the nipple line. The patient is alert and oriented. Strength and sensation are intact in all four extremities. Which of the following anatomic structures is most likely injured in this patient?

choices.text: Second rib at the posterolateral bend
Second rib at the sternocostal joint
Fifth rib at the posterolateral bend
Fifth rib at the sternocostal joint
Seventh rib at the costotransverse joint

questions.solution:
This patient has left-sided chest pain after being involved in a motor vehicle accident, which is concerning for a rib fracture. Rib fractures tend to involve the middle ribs (ribs four through ten) and most often occur at the posterolateral bend.

Rib fractures can arise in the setting of direct trauma or crush injuries. Since the ribs move during respiration, patients with rib fractures may experience pain with breathing, coughing, laughing, and sneezing. The broken rib can result in secondary pulmonary injury (e.g., pneumothorax, hemothorax), mediastinal injury (e.g., pneumomediastinum, aortic injury), and diaphragm puncture. If a lower rib is affected, the broken rib can also injure abdominal organs including the liver, kidney, or spleen.  



Option Analysis

❌ Second rib at the posterolateral bend  :
Incorrect: This patient sustained blunt trauma to the left chest after being involved in a motor vehicle accident. Physical exam reveals tenderness to palpation along the left chest, which raises concerns for a rib fracture. The posterolateral bend of the middle ribs (ribs four through ten) are most susceptible to fracture.  
❌ Second rib at the sternocostal joint  :
Incorrect: This patient sustained blunt trauma and has left-sided chest pain, which raises concerns for a rib fracture. However, ribs one through three are generally less likely to be fractured than the middle ribs (ribs four through ten).  
✅ Fifth rib at the posterolateral bend  :
Correct: See main explanation.  
❌ Fifth rib at the sternocostal joint  :
Incorrect: The middle ribs (ribs four through ten) are most vulnerable to fracture. However, fractures are more likely to occur at the posterolateral bend than at the sternocostal joint.  
❌ Seventh rib at the costotransverse joint  :
Incorrect: The middle ribs (ribs four through ten) are most vulnerable to fracture. However, fractures are more likely to occur at the posterolateral bend than at the costotransverse joint.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man is undergoing a sleeve gastrectomy. The procedure involves removing a large portion of the stomach along the middle part of the greater curvature. Which of the following major arteries supplies this region of the gastrointestinal tract?
questions.solution:
The greater curvature of the stomach is supplied by the gastroepiploic artery, a branch of splenic artery that arises from the celiac trunk.

Embryologically, the gastrointestinal tract is divided into the foregut, midgut, and hindgut. Each gut region is supplied by a distinct major artery. The arterial supply of the gastrointestinal tract is summarized below:  




Option Analysis

✅ Celiac trunk  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Superior mesenteric artery  :
Incorrect: The superior mesenteric artery is the second anterior branch of the abdominal aorta. It supplies midgut structures from the distal duodenum to proximal two-thirds of the transverse colon.  
❌ Inferior mesenteric artery  :
Incorrect: The inferior mesenteric artery is the third anterior branch of the abdominal aorta. It supplies the hindgut structures from the distal one-third of the transverse colon to the upper portion of the anal canal.  
❌ Thoracic aorta:
Incorrect: The stomach is supplied by branches of the abdominal aorta, not the thoracic aorta.  
❌ External iliac artery  :
Incorrect: The external iliac artery supplies blood to the lower extremities. It passes down along the brim of the pelvis and gives off two large branches, the inferior epigastric artery and the deep circumflex artery. These vessels supply the muscles and skin in the lower abdominal wall. The external iliac artery does not, however, provide blood supply to the stomach.

questions.text: A group of investigators is studying the pathway of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) flow in the ventricular system. Which of the following best describes the direction of CSF flow?

choices.text: Lateral ventricle → third ventricle → fourth ventricle → subarachnoid space
Subarachnoid space → third ventricle → fourth ventricle→ lateral ventricle
Fourth ventricle → lateral ventricle → third ventricle → subarachnoid space
Lateral ventricle → subarachnoid space → third ventricle → fourth ventricle
Lateral ventricle → fourth ventricle → subarachnoid space → third ventricle

questions.solution:
Choroid plexuses form cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) within the ventricles. Once formed, CSF flows from the lateral ventricles to the third ventricle via the interventricular foramen.
