It then circulates to the fourth ventricle through the cerebral aqueduct. CSF exits the fourth ventricle and enters the subarachnoid space via the two lateral apertures and single medial aperture. CSF is returned to the venous circulation via the arachnoid villi.  



Option Analysis

✅ Lateral ventricle → third ventricle → fourth ventricle → subarachnoid space:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Subarachnoid space → third ventricle → fourth ventricle→ lateral ventricle:
Incorrect: This answer choice is incorrect. Cerebrospinal fluid is produced in the ventricles and subsequently transported into the subarachnoid space.
❌ Fourth ventricle → lateral ventricle → third ventricle → subarachnoid space:
Incorrect: This answer choice is incorrect. CSF from the lateral ventricles empties first into the third ventricle and then the fourth. Finally, CSF passes from the fourth ventricle to the subarachnoid space via the medial aperture and lateral apertures.
❌ Lateral ventricle → subarachnoid space → third ventricle → fourth ventricle:
Incorrect: This answer choice is incorrect. CSF from the lateral ventricles empties into the third and then the fourth ventricle. Finally, it passes from the fourth ventricle to the subarachnoid space via the medial aperture and lateral apertures.
❌ Lateral ventricle → fourth ventricle → subarachnoid space → third ventricle:
Incorrect: This answer choice is incorrect. CSF from the lateral ventricles empties into the third and then the fourth ventricle. Finally, it passes from the fourth ventricle to the subarachnoid space via the medial aperture and lateral apertures.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman comes to the emergency department complaining of double vision and headache, accompanied by nausea and vomiting. Her symptoms started three days ago and have worsened since the onset. Past medical history is significant for hypertension, for which she takes amlodipine. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 110/75 mmHg. Ophthalmologic examination reveals bilateral papilledema and medial deviation of the right eye. Abduction of the right eye is impaired. All other eye movements are normal in both the eyes. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s double vision?

choices.text: Compression of a cranial nerve by an aneurysm in the posterior communicating artery
Stretching and injury to a cranial nerve over the petrous portion of the temporal bone
Occlusion of the posterior cerebral artery
Occlusion of the posterior inferior cerebellar artery

questions.solution:
This patient is exhibiting signs and symptoms of increased intracranial pressure (ICP) including papilledema, nausea, vomiting and headache. The ophthalmologic findings of diplopia and dysfunction of lateral gaze of the right eye are concerning for abducens nerve (CN VI) palsy. This patient most likely has a space-occupying lesion that is stretching and injuring the CN VI for which imaging (e.g. MRI) is warranted.

The abducens nerve (CN VI) is a pure motor nerve that supplies the lateral rectus muscle, which is responsible for abducting the eye. It exits the midbrain at the level of pontomedullary junction, then crosses over the petrous apex of the temporal bone, where it enters the cavernous sinus. It then travels towards the lateral rectus muscle.

CN VI palsy causes loss of lateral movement of the affected eye, leaving the action of the medial rectus muscle unopposed, which leads to medial deviation of the eye and resulting diplopia. Diplopia usually worsens when looking towards the side of the lesion and resolves when looking away from the lesion.



The most common cause of abducens nerve palsy is increased ICP, which can stretch the nerve as it crosses over the petrous apex. Common causes of increased ICP include space-occupying lesions (e.g., tumor, abscess). Other causes of CN VI palsy include head trauma, cavernous sinus thrombosis, demyelinating disorders, ischemic vascular disease and mastoiditis or otitis media, which may spread to the petrous portion of the temporal bone and damage the abducens nerve.



Option Analysis

❌ Compression of a cranial nerve by an aneurysm in the posterior communicating artery:
Incorrect: Aneurysm in the posterior communicating artery can compress the oculomotor nerve. This causes the eye to deviate down and out and the affected pupil to dilate (mydriasis). None of this is seen in this patient. Instead, this patient is most likely having CN VI palsy due to increased intracranial pressure.
✅ Stretching and injury to a cranial nerve over the petrous portion of the temporal bone:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Thrombosis of the cavernous sinus:
Incorrect: Cavernous sinus thrombosis can cause CN VI palsy, but this condition is usually associated with proptosis, orbital swelling, and other cranial nerve palsies (e.g., CN III, CN IV).
❌ Occlusion of the posterior cerebral artery:
Incorrect: The posterior cerebral artery supplies the medial midbrain. Its occlusion causes Weber syndrome, which is characterized by oculomotor nerve dysfunction with associated contralateral hemiparesis, which are not seen in this patient.
❌ Occlusion of the posterior inferior cerebellar artery:
Incorrect: Occlusion of the posterior inferior cerebellar artery causes lateral medullary syndrome (Wallenberg syndrome), which is characterized by loss of the gag reflex, dysphagia, hoarseness, and loss of pain and temperature sensation of the face and the contralateral side of the body. This patient does not have Wallenberg syndrome.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of groin pain, nausea, and abdominal distention for the past 12 hours. She has not experienced similar symptoms before. Past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus, managed with metformin. BMI is 33 kg/m2. Temperature is 38.4°C (101°F), pulse is 89/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. Physical examination shows mild abdominal distension. There is a 5cm palpable mass in the left groin that cannot be reduced and has overlying erythema. It is bounded medially by the pubic tubercle and laterally by a pulsating artery. Which of the following structures is most likely immediately superior to the bulge?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with groin discomfort and a bulge lateral to the pubic tubercle and medial to a pulsating artery (femoral artery) with associated nausea and abdominal distension; she most likely has a strangulated femoral hernia, which is a herniation of the bowel through the femoral canal below the inguinal ligament, medial to the femoral vessels, and lateral to the pubic tubercle and pectineal ligament.

Femoral hernias occur more often in females, though advanced age is the most important risk factor as the femoral ring can widen with age. Because the femoral canal is small, femoral hernias often become incarcerated (irreducible), and patients can present with signs of a bowel obstruction (pain, nausea, abdominal distension) if a bowel segment is herniated in the sac. Over time, strangulation (ischemia and necrosis) can occur due to worsening edema secondary to impaired blood flow.

In contrast to femoral hernias, direct and indirect inguinal hernias are located above the inguinal ligament. These are more common in males. Chronic increase in intra-abdominal pressure and advanced age are important risk factors. The incidence of incarceration and strangulation is low as compared to femoral hernia.



Option Analysis

❌ Pectineal ligament:
Incorrect: The pectineal ligament is an extension of the lacunar ligament and runs along the pectineal line of the pubic bone. It forms the posterior border of the femoral canal.
✅ Inguinal ligament:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Rectus muscle sheath:
Incorrect: The rectus muscle sheath is an aponeurosis that encloses the rectus abdominis muscle. It forms the medial border of the Hesselbach triangle and is medial to direct inguinal hernias. It is not related to the femoral ring or femoral hernias.
❌ Round ligament:
Incorrect: The round ligament is homologous to the spermatic cord in males. It passes through the deep inguinal ring to enter the inguinal canal. The round ligament is not associated with the anatomy of a femoral hernia.
❌ Inferior epigastric vessels:
Incorrect: The inferior epigastric vessels are an important landmark for the differentiation of direct and indirect inguinal hernias. Direct hernias protrude medial to inferior epigastric vessels, whereas indirect inguinal hernias run lateral to them before entering the inguinal canal. However, this patient has a femoral hernia.

questions.text: A 66-year-old man presents to a cardiologist for evaluation of a new heart murmur discovered at a routine health screening evaluation. The physician reads the report from this evaluation, which states that the patient was found to have a “crescendo-decrescendo systolic ejection murmur.” Auscultation at which of the following anatomic locations is most appropriate for reproducing this patient’s characteristic murmur?
questions.solution:
The characteristic crescendo-decresendo systolic ejection murmur described in the question stem refers to aortic stenosis, which is best appreciated over the second intercostal space along the right sternum. Several anatomic areas of the chest wall serve as landmarks for auscultation of different valves of the heart:  

  •  Aortic area: Right second intercostal space, parasternal. Aortic valve murmurs are heard best here, including aortic stenosis (systolic) and aortic regurgitation (diastolic).  
  • Pulmonic area: Left second intercostal space, parasternal. Pulmonic murmurs heard best here, like the systolic ejection murmur of pulmonic stenosis. Physiologic flow murmurs are also best heard here.
  • Tricuspid area: Left fourth intercostal space, parasternal. Diastolic murmurs associated with tricuspid stenosis or atrial septal defects can be heard here, as well as holosystolic murmurs from tricuspid regurgitation and ventricular septal defects. 
  • Mitral area: Left fifth intercostal space, mid-clavicular. One can hear the systolic murmurs from mitral regurgitation or mitral valve prolapse here, in addition to the diastolic mitral stenosis murmur.

Option Analysis

✅ A. :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ B. :
Incorrect: Choice B corresponds to the pulmonic area. This patient’s classic “crescendo-decrescendo systolic ejection murmur” is most likely from aortic stenosis, which is best heard over the aortic area (area A).
❌ C. :
Incorrect: Choice C corresponds to the tricuspid area.This patient’s classic “crescendo-decrescendo systolic ejection murmur” is most likely from aortic stenosis, which is best heard over the aortic area (area A).
❌ D. :
Incorrect: Choice D corresponds to the mitral area. This patient’s classic “crescendo-decrescendo systolic ejection murmur” is most likely from aortic stenosis, which is best heard over the aortic area (area A).
❌ E. :
Incorrect: Choice E does not correspond to a defined auscultatory location. This patient’s classic “crescendo-decrescendo systolic ejection murmur” is most likely from aortic stenosis, which is best heard over the aortic area (area A).

questions.text: A 75-year-old man is brought to the clinic for evaluation of memory problems. The patient has become increasingly forgetful and has trouble remembering recent events, but memory of remote events remains intact. The patient is able to cook for himself and has no trouble getting around the neighborhood. The patient does not have depressive symptoms. Past medical history is significant for hypertension, diabetes, and hyperlipidemia for which amlodipine, valsartan, metformin, insulin and atorvastatin are prescribed. The patient has been smoking one pack of cigarettes per day for 35 years. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 155/90 mmHg. Mental status examination is significant for anterograde amnesia. Pathologic involvement of which of the following areas of the brain is the most likely cause of his symptoms?

choices.text: Inferior parietal lobe of the non-dominant hemisphere

questions.solution:
This patient presents with isolated anterograde amnesia (difficulty remembering recent events) without dysfunction in performing activities of daily living; he has most likely suffered damage to the hippocampus. Past medical history of uncontrolled hypertension, active smoking, diabetes, and hyperlipidemia puts this patient at risk of having significant atherosclerotic disease.  

The hippocampus serves as a component of the limbic system, which is involved in the formation and retrieval of recent memories and in the conversion of recent memory to long-term memory. The hippocampus receives its blood supply from the terminal branches of the anterior choroidal artery and posterior cerebral artery and is in a watershed area, making it particularly susceptible to ischemic damage. Injury to the hippocampus results in anterograde amnesia (the inability to form new memories) with preservation of remote past memories.  



Option Analysis

❌ Nucleus basalis:
Incorrect: The nucleus basalis is involved in the production of acetylcholine for the cerebral cortex. Decreased production of acetylcholine is believed to play a significant role in the pathogenesis of Alzheimer disease. This patient presents with isolated memory loss without dysfunction in activities of daily living and is therefore less likely to have Alzheimer dementia.
❌ Ventral tegmentum:
Incorrect: The ventral tegmentum provides dopaminergic input, and decreased activity can be associated with Parkinson disease.
❌ Raphe nucleus:
Incorrect: The raphe nucleus provides serotonergic input, and decreased activity of this region of the brain is sometimes associated with depression.
✅ Hippocampus:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Inferior parietal lobe of the non-dominant hemisphere:
Incorrect: Hemispatial neglect syndrome is caused by a lesion to the inferior parietal lobe of the non-dominant hemisphere. It results in spatial neglect of the contralateral side of the body. Examples include construction apraxia (when asked to draw a clock, the individual only draws the right half of the clock) and dressing apraxia (the individual only dresses half of their body).

questions.text:
56-year-old woman presents to the emergency department for evaluation of chest pain. Over the past week, the patient has been experiencing persistent chest pain, worsening with deep inhalation but not with exertion. The pain is described as “sharp,” and she states that she is also experiencing similar pain in her shoulders. Of note, she is currently receiving treatment for breast cancer. Past medical history includes hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and hyperthyroidism. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 107/min, respirations are 19/min, blood pressure is 110/64 mmHg, and O2 saturation is 95% on room air. Physical examination demonstrates a thin female with moderate tachypnea. Pulmonary auscultation reveals diminished breath sounds at the lung bases bilaterally. Cardiac auscultation reveals hyperdynamic S1 and S2 without gallups, rubs, or murmurs. Musculoskeletal examination of the back and upper extremities is unremarkable. The patient’s initial electrocardiogram is demonstrated below. Which of the following is the most likely anatomic location of this patient’s pain?  


Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
This patient with breast cancer presents with pleuritic chest pain, of which the differential diagnosis is broad. Potential causes include infectious, thrombotic, and inflammatory etiologies. Given this patient’s referred shoulder pain and diminished breath sounds, her presentation is most consistent with pleuritic chest pain secondary to pleural effusions and subsequent diaphragmatic irritation.  

Pleuritic chest pain refers to pain characterized by sudden and intensely sharp, stabbing, or burning pain in the chest when inhaling and exhaling. Most lung tissue does not contain somatic pain fibers, aside from the parietal pleural and the intercostal nerves that line the inner chest wall. Disease processes that irritate these nerve endings manifest with pleuritic pain. The list of potential causes for pleuritic chest pain is broad and includes pneumothorax, rheumatologic diseases, pneumonia, empyema, pulmonary embolism, pericarditis, and pleural effusions.   

Of note, pleural effusions and hemothoraces layer on the diaphragm, irritating it and resulting in referred pain to the shoulder. This phenomenon exists because the central diaphragm is innervated by the phrenic nerve, supplied by spinal levels C3, C4, and C5. These spinal levels also provide innervation to the root of the neck and shoulder.   

Option Analysis

✅ Central diaphragm :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Pericardium:
Incorrect: Pericarditis is another common etiology of pleuritic chest pain. However, this patient’s electrocardiogram is without evidence of repolarization abnormalities or diffuse ST elevations and only demonstrates sinus tachycardia. As a result, the diagnosis of underlying pericarditis is unlikely in this patient.
❌ Superior aspect of the pleura :
Incorrect: Infection, malignancy, or thrombosis at the superior aspect of the pleura may result in pleuritic chest pain. However, this patient’s clinical presentation and physical exam are more consistent with bilateral pleural effusions and diaphragmatic irritation. 
❌ Left anterior descending artery :
Incorrect: Occlusion of the left anterior descending artery (LAD) manifests with cardiac chest pain, often described as pressure or “an elephant sitting on my chest.” It is less commonly associated with pleuritic chest pain. Most importantly, this patient's electrocardiogram does not show any anterior ST-segment changes.
❌ Pulmonary artery :
Incorrect: Pulmonary embolism is an essential diagnostic consideration in evaluating pleuritic chest pain. However, given this patient has diminished breath sounds bilaterally, her clinical presentation is more consistent with pleural effusions and diaphragmatic irritation.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old woman presents to her primary care provider for evaluation of hypertension. The patient was seen in the emergency department last week for a laceration repair, and her systolic blood pressure was noted to be over 200 mmHg. She is otherwise healthy and does not take any medications daily. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 89/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 225/102 mmHg in the right upper extremity and 210/97 in the left upper extremity. The patient has a 2/6 systolic murmur at the right upper sternal border. The patient’s lower extremities have scant hair bilaterally, and a brachiofemoral pulse delay is noted bilaterally. A portion of the patient’s chest radiograph is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient’s clinical presentation?  


Image reproduced from Radiopedia
questions.solution:
This patient has uncontrolled hypertension, which is the most common presentation for adult patients with undiagnosed coarctation of the aorta. Clues to this diagnosis include an systolic ejection murmur (indicative of a bicuspid aortic valve), brachiofemoral pulse delay, and rib notching noted in the chest radiograph above.  

Coarctation of the aorta is an overall common congenital anomaly, accounting for approximately 6-8% of all congenital heart disease. This anatomic defect refers to a discrete narrowing of the descending aorta at the insertion of the ductus arteriosus, just distal to the left subclavian artery. The degree of defect varies amongst individuals. The condition has a high association with Turner syndrome and a bicuspid aortic valve.   

Due to the stenosis, patients develop hypertension in the upper extremities, diminished blood pressure in the lower extremities, and brachiofemoral pulse delay. In the thorax, notching of the posterior one-third of the third to eighth ribs occurs due to erosion caused by the formation of large collaterals in the intercostal arteries.  

Option Analysis

✅ Coarctation of the aorta :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Peripheral vascular disease :
Incorrect: Peripheral vascular disease can result in diminished or absent hair on the lower extremities. However, this condition would not account for the rib notching noted on the patient’s radiograph.   
❌ Abdominal aortic aneurysm :
Incorrect: An abdominal aortic aneurysm more commonly presents in patients with a long history of smoking and atherosclerotic disease. This diagnosis would not explain the rib notching noted on the patient’s radiograph. 
❌ Dilated cardiomyopathy:
Incorrect: Dilated cardiomyopathy more commonly presents with signs of congestive heart failure, such as lower extremity edema, shortness of breath, and an S3 heart sound. This patient’s heart sound indicates a possible bicuspid aortic valve.
❌ Subclavian artery stenosis :
Incorrect: Subclavian steal syndrome refers to a phenomenon that occurs with severe stenosis of the subclavian artery proximal to the ipsilateral vertebral artery. It can manifest with exercise-induced ischemia of the affected limb.

questions.text:
A 59-year-old man comes to the office because of tearing and blurry vision in the right eye. The patient also reports progressive headaches and says that “I feel like the right side of my face has been getting heavier.” The patient has had no fever, runny nose, sore throat, or cough. He does not report any trauma or loss of consciousness. Past medical history is significant for hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus that are both well-controlled with medications. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows right nasolabial fold flattening and drooping of the right lower lip. The patient is unable to close the right eye. The left side of the face appears normal. The ocular examination is shown below.  


Reproduced from wikipedia

MRI of the brain reveals a well-circumscribed, homogeneously enhancing posterior fossa mass compressing the right facial nerve root. Impairment of which of the following facial muscles is most likely responsible for this patient’s ocular symptoms?
questions.solution:
The patient presents with right facial paralysis and an inability to close the right eye,  consistent with facial (CN VII) nerve palsy, likely due to compression from a meningioma in the posterior fossa.

A portion of the facial (VII) motor nucleus innervates the orbicularis oculi, closing the eyelids and wrinkling the forehead. The orbicularis oculi have three components:  

  •  Palpebral part: gently closes the eyelids (as in blinking or sleep) to keep the cornea moist 
  •  Lacrimal part: draws the eyelids medially, aiding in drainage of tears 
  • Orbital part: tightly closes the eyelids (as in winking or squinting) to protect the eyes from glare and dust.

Paralysis of the facial nerve results in loss of tone of the orbicularis oculi, resulting in the inferior eyelid eversion (or falling away from the surface of the eyeball). As a result, lacrimal fluid does not spread to the cornea, preventing adequate lubrication, hydration, and flushing. Corneal reflexes are also lost due to impaired blinking, resulting in further drying of the cornea, eventually leading to corneal ulceration (demonstrated in the photo above).  

Option Analysis

❌ Orbicularis oris:
Incorrect: The orbicularis oris closes the oral fissure and causes a phasic contraction to protrude the lips (kissing) and resist distension (when blowing). Although the facial nerve also innervates this muscle, it does not close the eye.
✅ Orbicularis oculi:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Occipitofrontalis:
Incorrect: The occipitofrontalis elevates the eyebrows and wrinkles the skin of the forehead. Although the facial nerve also innervates this muscle, it does not close the eye. 
❌ Corrugator supercilii:
Incorrect: The corrugator supercilii is a facial muscle that draws the eyebrow medially inferiorly, creating vertical wrinkles above the nose (demonstrating concern or worry). Although the facial nerve also innervates this muscle, it does not close the eye. 
❌ Risorius:
Incorrect: The risorius depresses the labial commissures to frown (expressing sadness). Although the facial nerve also innervates this muscle, it does not close the eye.

questions.text:
A 72-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician with worsening left shoulder pain. The pain has been present for years, but she now is having difficulty writing on the chalkboard during her elementary school classes. The patient was a professional soccer player in her early adulthood, and she sustained a rotator cuff injury that was repaired surgically. Medical history is also notable for hypertension and hyperlipidemia. On physical examination, the patient has marked tenderness to palpation at the glenohumeral joint and limited abduction and external rotation secondary to pain. A radiograph of the left shoulder is demonstrated below:  


Image reproduced from Radiopedia  
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with chronic left shoulder pain and a limited range of motion due to pain. The patient’s radiograph demonstrates glenohumeral joint space narrowing, sclerosis, and osteophyte formation. These findings are consistent with glenohumeral osteoarthritis.

Glenohumeral osteoarthritis is a relatively uncommon form of osteoarthritis. However, it more commonly occurs in older females with a history of prior shoulder surgery, injury, or trauma. Conditions that predispose to glenohumeral osteoarthritis include shoulder dislocation, rotator cuff tears, rheumatoid arthritis, and humeral head/neck fracture.

Most cases of glenohumeral osteoarthritis present clinically with chronic, nagging, and deep shoulder pain that is exacerbated with movement. Shoulder mobility is typically limited due to pain, especially during abduction and external rotation. Treatment involves analgesia and shoulder replacement surgery in advanced cases of the disease.  

Option Analysis

✅ Glenohumeral osteoarthritis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Osteosarcoma  :
Incorrect: Osteosarcoma arises from pleomorphic osteoid producing cells and presents as a painful mass or pathologic fracture. Radiographic features include lytic bone lesions and a sunburst pattern, which is secondary to aggressive periosteal reaction.  
❌ Supraspinatus tendinopathy  :
Incorrect: While this patient has a history of rotator cuff injury, the physical examination and radiograph are more consistent with glenohumeral osteoarthritis.  
❌ Cervical spondylosis  :
Incorrect: Cervical spondylosis can mimic disorders of the glenohumeral joint. However, in this condition, pain is more often localized over the cervical spine. In addition, patients with cervical spondylosis may have a positive Spurling test (in which symptoms are reproduced when the patient’s head is turned towards the affected side, and pressure is applied to the top of the head).  
❌ Adhesive capsulitis  :
Incorrect: Adhesive capsulitis, also known as “frozen shoulder syndrome,” manifests with gross stiffness of the shoulder and nagging pain. Physical examination will demonstrate significant reductions in active and passive range of motion in two or more planes of movement. It can be differentiated from osteoarthritis as early disease typically demonstrates a normal shoulder radiograph (unlike that of this patient) and presents subacutely over the course of days to weeks (whereas this patient’s symptoms are chronic).

questions.text: Which of the following abdominal muscles/ligaments extend to the groin to form the deep and superficial inguinal rings?

choices.text: Deep Inguinal RingSuperficial Inguinal RingInguinal ligament   Lacunar ligament
Deep Inguinal RingSuperficial Inguinal Ring   Internal oblique   Transversus abdominis muscles
Deep Inguinal RingSuperficial Inguinal RingTransversalis fascia   Conjoint tendon
Deep Inguinal Ring   Superficial Inguinal Ring   Transversalis fasciaExternal oblique aponeurosis
Deep Inguinal RingSuperficial Inguinal RingExternal oblique aponeurosisInternal oblique aponeurosis

questions.solution:
The muscles and fascial layers of the anterior abdominal wall continue inferiorly to form the inguinal ligament and parts of the inguinal canal.

The inguinal canal starts at the deep inguinal ring, which is an opening in the transversalis fascia. The deep inguinal ring is located at the midpoint of the inguinal ligament, just lateral to the inferior epigastric vessels. It ends at the superficial inguinal ring, an opening in the external oblique aponeurosis.

Structures passing through the inguinal canal enter through the deep inguinal ring except for the ilioinguinal nerve, which enters the canal distal to the ring. All structures then exit via the superficial inguinal ring.

The inguinal canal has four boundaries: the anterior and posterior walls, roof, and floor.  

  •  Roof (superior): internal oblique and transversus abdominis muscles 
  •  Floor (inferior): inguinal ligament (shelving edge of external oblique) and lacunar ligament 
  •  Posterior wall: transversalis fascia laterally and conjoint tendon medially  
  •  Anterior wall: external oblique aponeurosis and internal oblique muscle  


Option Analysis

❌ Deep Inguinal RingSuperficial Inguinal RingInguinal ligament   Lacunar ligament  :
Incorrect: The inguinal and lacunar ligaments form the inguinal canal floor. In contrast, the deep inguinal ring is formed by the transversalis fascia, and the external oblique aponeurosis forms the superficial inguinal ring.   
❌ Deep Inguinal RingSuperficial Inguinal Ring   Internal oblique   Transversus abdominis muscles  :
Incorrect: The internal oblique and transversus abdominis muscles form the roof of the inguinal canal. In contrast, the deep inguinal ring is formed by the transversalis fascia, and the external oblique aponeurosis forms the superficial inguinal ring.   
❌ Deep Inguinal RingSuperficial Inguinal RingTransversalis fascia   Conjoint tendon:
Incorrect: The posterior wall of the inguinal canal is formed by the transversalis fascia laterally and conjoint tendon medially. While the deep inguinal ring is formed by the transversalis fascia, the superficial inguinal ring is formed by the external oblique aponeurosis.   
✅ Deep Inguinal Ring   Superficial Inguinal Ring   Transversalis fasciaExternal oblique aponeurosis  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Deep Inguinal RingSuperficial Inguinal RingExternal oblique aponeurosisInternal oblique aponeurosis:
Incorrect: The anterior wall of the inguinal canal is made up of the external oblique and internal oblique aponeurosis. In contrast, the deep inguinal ring is formed by the transversalis fascia, and the external oblique aponeurosis forms the superficial inguinal ring.

questions.text: A woman presents to the physician because of pain and swelling in the right breast. The woman has been lactating for 2-weeks. Physical examination reveals tenderness, erythema, and swelling in the right breast and enlarged, tender right axillary lymph nodes. Which of the following best describes the lymphatic drainage pathway from the inflamed lymph nodes?

choices.text: Drains into the right lymphatic duct and then the junction between the right subclavian and internal jugular vein
Drains into the right lymphatic duct and then directly into the superior vena cava
Drains into the right lymphatic duct and then into the thoracic duct
Drains into the thoracic duct and then the junction between the left subclavian and internal jugular vein
Drains into the thoracic duct and then directly into the right heart

questions.solution:
The lymphatic system is responsible for returning lymph fluid into the bloodstream. It is also involved in immune surveillance and carries specific molecules (e.g. lipids) into the bloodstream.

The lymphatic system consists of vessels that drain into the major lymphatic trunks. The primary lymphatic trunks are the lumbar trunks, bronchomediastinal trunks, subclavian trunks, jugular trunks, and intestinal trunks. These trunks drain into either the right lymphatic duct or thoracic duct, returning the lymph into the bloodstream.

The right lymphatic duct receives lymphatic drainage from the right upper extremity, right side of the head, and right chest. It empties into the bloodstream between the right subclavian and right internal jugular veins. In contrast, lymphatic drainage from every other body part enters the thoracic duct and empties into the bloodstream at the junction between the left subclavian and left internal jugular vein.    

Option Analysis

✅ Drains into the right lymphatic duct and then the junction between the right subclavian and internal jugular vein  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Drains into the right lymphatic duct and then directly into the superior vena cava  :
Incorrect: The right axillary lymph nodes do drain into the right lymphatic duct. However, the right lymphatic duct then empties into the bloodstream at the junction between the right subclavian and internal jugular vein, instead of the superior vena cava.  
❌ Drains into the right lymphatic duct and then into the thoracic duct  :
Incorrect: The right lymphatic duct drains into the right subclavian and internal jugular vein junction, not the thoracic duct.  
❌ Drains into the thoracic duct and then the junction between the left subclavian and internal jugular vein:
Incorrect: The right upper extremity, right side of the head, and right chest drain into the right lymphatic duct, not the thoracic duct  
❌ Drains into the thoracic duct and then directly into the right heart  :
Incorrect: The right upper extremity, right side of the head, and right chest drain into the right lymphatic duct, not the thoracic duct. Furthermore, the thoracic duct drains into the junction between the left subclavian and internal jugular vein, instead of directly into the heart.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man is currently on postoperative day one after having an uncomplicated open appendectomy. The patient’s pain is well-controlled, but he has noticed diminished sensation and burning pain in the area just below the belly button. Vital signs are within normal limits. The patient's surgical incision appears to be healing well without extravasation of fluids on gentle palpation. The patient has diminished sensation suprapubically. Strength and sensation testing throughout the bilateral lower extremities is intact. Which of the following structures was most likely injured intraoperatively?
questions.solution:
This patient has paresthesias and diminished sensation in the suprapubic region on postoperative day one. These findings are most reflective of injury to the iliohypogastric nerve, likely due to a Lanz incision performed too far laterally or inferiorly.

Several superficial abdominal nerves are at increased risk of injury depending on the incision and surgery performed. Nerves at risk primarily include the inferior thoracic spinal nerves T7-T12, the iliohypogastric nerve, and the ilioinguinal nerve.

Specifically, any incision made too far lateral, inferior, or superior to the correct anatomic site may injure a thoracic spinal nerve, resulting in numbness and paresthesias at that level. For example, a  Kocher incision may injure the 7th and 8th thoracic spinal nerves.

Injury to the iliohypogastric or ilioinguinal nerves can arise from lower abdominal incisions. For example, a Pfannenstiel incision extended too far inferiorly or laterally may injure either nerve. Injury to the iliohypogastric nerve manifests with pain and paresthesias suprapubically, whereas injury to the ilioinguinal nerve manifests with these symptoms over the labia, scrotum, or thigh.  

Option Analysis

✅ Iliohypogastric nerve:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Femoral nerve:
Incorrect: The femoral nerve lies deep in the pelvis and is rarely injured during an open appendectomy. Injury to the femoral nerve would present with weakness in the quadriceps and iliopsoas muscles. In contrast, this patient has normal strength in the lower extremities.  
❌ Inferior epigastric artery  :
Incorrect: A pfannenstiel incision or a paracentesis performed too medially may result in injury to this artery. In addition, injury to the inferior epigastric artery would more likely result in hematoma formation, as opposed to diminished sensation in the suprapubic region.  
❌ T10 thoracic spinal nerve:
Incorrect: Injury to this nerve would manifest with paresthesias at the level of the umbilicus. In contrast, this patient has paresthesias in the region inferior to the umbilicus.  
❌ 7th and 8th thoracic spinal nerves  :
Incorrect: A right-sided Kocher incision extended too far laterally or inferiorly can injure the 7th and 8th thoracic spinal nerves. However, Kocher incisions are typically done for biliary procedures or splenectomies instead of appendectomies.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents to the physician because of a 3-month history of left shoulder pain. The pain is reproduced when the shoulder is externally rotated against resistance. He is physically active and plays baseball twice a week. The muscle injured in this patient is typically innervated by which of the following?
questions.solution:
The infraspinatus muscle, along with the teres minor muscle (components of the rotator cuff), is responsible for the external rotation of the humerus. The suprascapular nerve innervates the infraspinatus muscle.  

The rotator cuff consists of the tendons of the supraspinatus, infraspinatus, teres minor, and subscapularis muscles. The mnemonic SITS can help in remembering these tendons. The rotator cuff contributes to the stability and motion of the glenohumeral joint. The characteristics of the muscles that make up the rotator cuff are summarized in the table below.



Option Analysis

❌ Accessory nerve:
Incorrect: The accessory nerve innervates the trapezius, which works with the supraspinatus muscle in performing arm abduction. This patient likely has an injury of the infraspinatus muscle, which is innervated by the suprascapular nerve. 
❌ Median nerve:
Incorrect: The median nerve innervates muscles of the forearm and hand but does not aid in external rotation of the humerus. This patient likely has an injury of the infraspinatus muscle, which is innervated by the suprascapular nerve. 
❌ Long thoracic nerve:
Incorrect: The long thoracic nerve innervates the serratus anterior muscle, which pulls the scapula anteriorly and laterally. This patient likely has an injury of the infraspinatus muscle, which is innervated by the suprascapular nerve. 
❌ Subscapular nerve:
Incorrect: The subscapular nerve innervates the subscapularis muscle, which medially rotates and adducts the arm. This patient likely has an injury of the infraspinatus muscle, which is innervated by the suprascapular nerve. 
✅ Suprascapular nerve:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 37-year-old man develops difficulty chewing after undergoing maxillofacial surgery. Physical examination reveals deviation of the jaw to the right side when the patient attempts to open his mouth. The nerve affected in this patient exits the skull via which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
This patient’s symptoms are consistent with injury of mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve (CN V3), which exits the skull via the foramen ovale in the middle cranial fossa. The nerves and vessels that enter and exit the skull via the different structures are summarized below:

Option Analysis

❌ Superior orbital fissure:
Incorrect: The superior orbital fissure carries cranial nerves III (oculomotor), IV (trochlear), VI (abducens), and V1 (ophthalmic division of CN V). In contrast, CN V3 provides innervation to the muscles of mastication. Injury to CN V3 would cause the jaw deviation experienced by this patient. 
❌ Foramen rotundum:
 \Incorrect: The foramen rotundum carries V2 (maxillary division of CN V). In contrast, CN V3 provides innervation to the muscles of mastication. Injury to CN V3 would cause the jaw deviation experienced by this patient. 
✅ Foramen ovale:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌  Foramen spinosum:
Incorrect: The foramen spinosum carries the middle meningeal artery. 
❌ Jugular foramen:
Incorrect: The jugular foramen carries cranial nerves IX (glossopharyngeal), X (vagus), and XI (accessory). These nerves are not involved in controlling jaw movements or the muscles of mastication.

questions.text:
A 47-year-old woman sustains a brain injury after a motor vehicle accident. The patient cannot form memories of events taking place after the accident, including her hospital stay and subsequent time spent recovering at home. However, she can recall events that occurred before the accident.  

Which of the following brain structures was most likely injured in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient likely has anterograde amnesia. The condition can arise due to injury to the hippocampus, part of the limbic system.    

The limbic system is a group of brain structures located lateral to the thalamus, beneath the cerebral cortex, and above the brainstem. The limbic system regulates emotions, memory, olfaction, and autonomic functions associated with homeostasis. Although this system consists of many structures, the hippocampus, amygdala, and hypothalamus are the main ones.  

The hippocampus is involved in transferring short-term memory to long-term memory. As a result, damage to this structure would result in anterograde amnesia.  

The amygdala processes emotional responses, such as fear and anxiety. The amygdala sends outputs to multiple structures (e.g., hypothalamus, thalamic nuclei, and trigeminal and facial nerves) to increase autonomic activity and control facial expressions.  

Finally, the hypothalamus helps facilitate communication between different limbic system components and is vital in maintaining homeostasis. It helps regulate hunger and satiety, thirst, sleep-wake cycle, and sexual desire. Furthermore, the hypothalamus regulates hormone release from the pituitary gland.



Option Analysis

❌ Structure A:
Incorrect: Structure A is the hypothalamus. The hypothalamus regulates homeostasis by controlling hunger and satiety, thirst, sleep-wake cycle, and sexual desire. Furthermore, the hypothalamus regulates hormone release from the pituitary gland. Hypothalamic injury would more likely present with autonomic dysfunction (e.g., hyperthermia, poikilothermia) or endocrine abnormalities (e.g., amenorrhea, hypothyroidism) instead of anterograde amnesia. 
❌ Structure B:
Incorrect: Structure B is the olfactory bulb. Damage to this structure may cause anosmia (inability to smell) but not anterograde amnesia. 
❌  Structure C :
Incorrect: Structure C is the amygdala. Although this structure assists memory formation, it is more significantly involved in regulating the body’s response to fear. Damage to the bilateral amygdala can cause Kluver-Bucy syndrome, which manifests with a diminished fear response, hypersexuality, hyperorality, and emotional blunting. 
❌ Structure D:
Incorrect: Structure D is the part of the cerebellum involved in coordination and balance. The cerebellum is not involved in the formation of new memories. As a result, injury to this structure would not give rise to this patient's anterograde amnesia. 
✅ Structure E:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman comes to the emergency department complaining of a one-week history of eye pain and double vision. The patient also noticed swelling that started around her right eye but is now around both eyes. She says she feels “warm” but does not have a thermometer at home to take her temperature. Before her symptoms started, she had a toothache, for which she tried ibuprofen. She did not see a dentist. She has no significant past medical or surgical history. Temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 130/80 mmHg. Physical examination reveals proptosis of both eyes with periorbital edema. In addition, abduction of the right eye is impaired. All other eye movements are normal, and both pupils are 3 mm in diameter and reactive to light. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with ophthalmalgia, periorbital edema that started unilaterally and quickly progressed bilaterally, and CN VI palsy; she most likely has cavernous sinus syndrome. She also has high-grade fever in the setting of a possible tooth infection, making cavernous sinus thrombosis the most likely cause.

The cavernous sinus is a dural venous sinus that is found lateral to the sella turcica on both sides. It contains many important structures including the abducens nerve (CN VI), the internal carotid artery and associated postganglionic sympathetic fibers, the oculomotor nerve (CN III), the trochlear nerve (CN IV), and the ophthalmic (V1) and maxillary (V2) branches of the trigeminal nerve (CN V)



The abducens nerve and internal carotid artery (with its postganglionic sympathetic fibers) run in the center of the sinus, while the oculomotor, trochlear, ophthalmic and maxillary nerves run along the lateral walls of the sinus. As a result, abducens nerve (CN VI) palsy is the first and most common palsy associated with cavernous sinus syndrome, though other structures in the sinus can also be affected.

In addition to nerve palsies, patients usually develop headache, periorbital edema, proptosis, and chemosis, which start unilaterally and then progress to bilateral involvement. Horner syndrome can occur with injury to the postganglionic fibers. Fever can be present if the cause is septic, and patients can develop vision loss.

Cavernous sinus syndrome can occur due to tumors (e.g., meningioma, pituitary tumor), carotid artery aneurysm, and cavernous sinus thrombosis. Cavernous sinus thrombosis usually occurs due to an infection spreading from adjacent structures such as sinuses, ears, eyes, or teeth.




Option Analysis

✅ Cavernous sinus thrombosis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Idiopathic intracranial hypertension:
Incorrect: Idiopathic intracranial hypertension (IIH) presents with headache, nausea, vomiting, and decreased visual acuity. It is not associated with fever, proptosis, or periorbital edema.
❌ Orbital cellulitis:
Incorrect: Orbital cellulitis can cause proptosis, ophthalmoplegia, and fever. However, it is exceedingly rare to be bilateral. The bilateral nature of this patient’s symptoms favors cavernous sinus thrombosis as the diagnosis.
❌ Multiple sclerosis:
Incorrect: Although multiple sclerosis can cause demyelination of any cranial nerve (including the abducens nerve), it is not associated with acute proptosis or orbital swelling. In addition, this patient does not have a history of other neurological manifestations disseminated in place and time (e.g., lower extremity paresis, ataxia).
❌ Superior vena cava syndrome:
Incorrect: Superior vena cava syndrome is characterized by diffuse facial and neck swelling and plethora, distended neck veins, upper extremities swelling, cough, and dyspnea. This patient has orbital swelling with ophthalmoplegia, making cavernous sinus syndrome more likely.

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her daughter for evaluation of left-sided weakness for one hour. She does not have a headache or blurred vision. She has a past medical history of hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, type 2 diabetes, and coronary artery disease. She has smoked one half-pack of cigarettes daily for 45 years. Her medications include atorvastatin, amlodipine, metformin, and aspirin. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 92/min, respirations are 17/min and blood pressure is 168/90 mm Hg. Examination demonstrates a left facial droop, 3/5 left-sided strength, and 3+ deep tendon reflexes. Sensation to pinprick, light touch, and vibration, as well as two-point discrimination, is normal. Which of the following is the most likely anatomic location of the pathology in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with clinical features consistent with a lacunar stroke secondary to infarction of the genus and anterior 2/3rd of the posterior limb of the internal capsule. Specifically, lacunar strokes are non-cortical infarcts, characterized by the absence of cortical signs (e.g., no aphasia, hemianopsia, agnosia, apraxia), secondary to ischemia of lenticulostriate arteries. These blood vessels are deep penetrating branches of the major cerebral arteries that supply deep brain nuclei, including the thalamus, basal ganglia, pons, and white matter of the internal capsule. Damage and subsequent ischemia via these arteries occurs largely due to hyaline arteriolosclerosis and chronic hypertension or diabetes mellitus.  

Infarction of the posterior limb of the internal capsule is the most common type of lacunar stroke and may manifest with the following clinical features:  
  • Pure motor stroke: contralateral weakness equally affecting the face, arm, and leg 
  •  Pure sensory stroke: contralateral numbness of the face, arm, and leg  
  •  Sensorimotor stroke: contralateral weakness and numbness of the face, arm, and leg (absence cortical signs) 
  •  Dysarthria-clumsy hand syndrome: facial weakness, dysarthria, dysphagia, and slight weakness and clumsiness of one hand. 
  •  Ataxic hemiparesis: ipsilateral weakness and limb ataxia that is out of proportion to the motor deficit. 

Option Analysis

✅ Internal capsule:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Medulla:
Incorrect: Lateral medullary infarction typically occurs due to posterior inferior cerebellar artery occlusion. It is characterized by vertigo/nystagmus, ipsilateral cerebellar signs, loss of pain/temperature sensation on the ipsilateral face and contralateral body, bulbar weakness, and Horner syndrome. 
❌ Thalamus:
Incorrect: A lacunar stroke of the posterolateral thalamus typically presents with sudden-onset contralateral sensory loss involving all sensory modalities (i.e. pure sensory stroke). This patient has pure motor hemiparesis. 
❌ Midbrain:
Incorrect: Midbrain strokes present with ipsilateral oculomotor nerve palsy, ataxia (superior cerebellar peduncle), and contralateral hemiparesis (cerebral peduncle). 
❌ Postcentral gyrus:
Incorrect: Occlusion of the middle or anterior cerebral artery can result in contralateral sensory loss (due to infarction of the somatosensory cortex in the postcentral gyrus), hemiparesis (due to primary motor cortex injury), and cortical signs.

questions.text: A 72-year-old right-handed person is brought to the clinic to establish care. The patient was recently discharged from the hospital where they were admitted for the management of a stroke. The patient initially presented with left-sided hemiparesis and was found to have a large ischemic stroke involving the right middle cerebral artery. The patient did not receive fibrinolytic therapy as they presented outside of the administration window. The patient participated in physical therapy during hospitalization and reports that muscle strength has improved significantly. The patient reports that they feel like they are coming back to their baseline. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows motor strength of 4/5 on the left side. Dress and appearance on the left side of their body appears unkempt. When asked to draw a clock and copy a box and a flower, their drawings appear as shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient who presents with construction apraxia (when asked to draw a clock, they only draw the right half of the clock) and dressing apraxia (inattention to the left side of the body) most likely has spatial neglect of the contralateral side of the body. This patient also exhibits anosognosia (unawareness of neural defect). Together, these features suit a diagnosis of hemispatial neglect syndrome.

Hemispatial neglect syndrome results from injury to the inferior parietal lobe in the non-dominant hemisphere. This area houses the somatosensory association area and is supplied by the angular and posterior parietal arteries, which are branches of the middle cerebral artery (MCA). Injury to this area ultimately results in a patient who is unable to integrate somatic and visual inputs and cannot appreciate an image on the opposite side of the body.  

Clinical manifestations include spatial neglect of the contralateral side of the body and anosognosia (individual is unaware of neural defect). Affected individuals may fail to shave, wash, and dress the contralateral half of their bodies. When asked to draw a clock, the patient's drawing might only show numbers on one side of the clock or all 12 numbers might be on one half with the other half distorted (construction apraxia).  

Option Analysis

❌ Kluver-Bucy syndrome:
Incorrect: Kluver-Bucy syndrome results from bilateral lesions of the amygdala and surrounding cortex of the temporal lobe. Affected patients present with hypersexuality, hyperphagia, and an urge for exploring objects by mouth (hyperorality). Some patients exhibit visual agnosia, or psychic blindness, and personality changes, like passivity or docility.
✅ Hemispatial neglect syndrome:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Gerstmann syndrome:
Incorrect: Gerstmann syndrome is a dominant hemispheric stroke syndrome that usually results from ischemic injury to the angular gyrus within the parietal lobe. Symptoms include finger agnosia, left-right disorientation, acalculia, agraphia, and alexia.
❌ Frontal lobe syndrome:
Incorrect: Frontal lobe syndrome occurs as a result of damage to the prefrontal cortex. This condition presents with disinhibition and deficits in concentration, judgment, and orientation. Early behavioral changes include socially inappropriate behavior, apathy, and compulsive behavior.
❌ Damage to the corpus callosum:
Incorrect: The corpus callosum transfers information between the cerebral hemispheres. Damage to the corpus callosum results in transcortical apraxia, wherein the patient is unable to execute learned motor movement using the side of the body supplied by the nondominant hemisphere.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician to evaluate bilateral wrist pain. The patient has worse pain at night and is associated with paresthesias of the first, second, third, and half of the fourth finger. She states, “I need to figure out what is going on. I can barely sleep at night.” Past medical history includes hypertension, type II diabetes mellitus, rheumatoid arthritis, and obesity. She smokes a pack of cigarettes daily and drinks two to three beers nightly. She currently works as an office secretary. Vital signs are within normal limits, and physical examination does not reveal any deformity or swelling of the wrist. Which of the following will best assist in diagnosing this patient’s underlying condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with pain and paresthesias in the distribution of the median nerve, and she has multiple risk factors for the development of carpal tunnel syndrome. Of the tests listed, the Phalen maneuver is most likely to reveal the underlying diagnosis.

Carpal tunnel syndrome is a multifactorial disease that primarily results from increased pressure in the intercarpal canal and associated compression of the median nerve. Median nerve compression manifests clinically with pain and paresthesias in the first three digits of the hand and half of the fourth digit. Pain and paresthesias are then often reproduced with movements that flex or extend the wrist.

Special maneuvers that aid in diagnosis include the Phalen test and Tinel test. In the Phalen test, the patient fully flexes the palms at the wrist with the elbow in full extension to provide extra pressure on the median nerve. The Phalen test is positive if these maneuvers elicit pain or paresthesia. The Tinel test involves repetitive tapping over the carpal tunnel and evaluating for reproducible pain or paresthesia. Further diagnostic tests include nerve conduction studies and electromyography to rule out other polyneuropathies, plexopathies, and radiculopathies.

Treatment is primarily conservative, with physical therapy and wrist splinting as mainstays for mild or moderate disease. Additional therapies include oral or injection corticosteroids. Surgical release of the median nerve is reserved for cases that are refractory to conservative measures or those with advanced disease, characterized by evidence of axonal loss on nerve conduction studies.  

Option Analysis

✅ Phalen maneuver  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Finkelstein test:
Incorrect: The Finkelstein test is a physical examination maneuver used to determine if there is tenosynovitis in the abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis tendons of the wrist. In contrast, this patient has paresthesias in the median nerve distribution, more consistent with carpal tunnel syndrome.  
❌ Hook test:
Incorrect: Distal biceps tendon rupture can be diagnosed using the hook test. In contrast, this patient has paresthesias in the median nerve distribution, more consistent with carpal tunnel syndrome.  
❌ CT of the wrist  :
Incorrect: CT of the wrist is generally non-contributory in evaluating carpal tunnel syndrome unless there is a concern for a compressive mass lesion.  
❌ MRI of the wrist  :
Incorrect: Like CT, MRI of the wrist is generally non-contributory in evaluating carpal tunnel syndrome unless there is a concern for a compressive mass lesion.

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy presents to the pediatrician for a well-child visit and raises a concern for recent voice changes. The patient has noticed a deepening and hoarseness of his voice over the past eight weeks and is worried “something is wrong with my voice box.” His parent reports the patient has been sleeping 10-12 hours per day and had a “head-cold” two months ago. The patient is otherwise healthy and does not take any medications. He does not smoke, use illicit drugs, or consume alcohol. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates a tall, thin male in no acute distress with comedonal acne noted on the face. The patient’s posterior oropharynx is without evidence of edema, exudates, or erythema. There is no tenderness to palpation of the trachea. When asked to speak, the patient's voice intermittently enters higher frequency registers. Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient's clinical presentation?

choices.text: Enlargement of the larynx and longer, thicker vocal folds
Recent infection with a parainfluenza virus

questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation of voice changes consistent with normal development during puberty. During the physical examination, the patient has a characteristic “voice crack,” which refers to a person's voice suddenly and unintentionally entering a higher register.  

The hormonal changes males experience during puberty influence the anatomy of the larynx, ultimately resulting in enlargement of the larynx and the development of longer, thicker vocal folds. As these structures enlarge and change, the fundamental frequency of the vocal cords decreases, resulting in a deeper pitch to the voice.    

Option Analysis

✅ Enlargement of the larynx and longer, thicker vocal folds:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Recent infection with a parainfluenza virus :
Incorrect: Croup, also known as laryngotracheobronchitis, may cause transient changes in phonation, including deepening of the voice. This patient’s presentation is consistent with normal anatomic changes associated with puberty. 
❌ Subglottic stenosis :
Incorrect: Subglottic stenosis refers to a narrowing of the airway below the vocal cords and above the trachea. This condition is often congenital or acquired after prolonged mechanical ventilation. 
❌ Vocal fold paralysis:
Incorrect: Unilateral vocal fold paralysis results in a hoarse or breathy voice. Bilateral vocal cord paralysis causes dyspnea and potentially a complete airway obstruction. This patient’s presentation is consistent with normal anatomic changes associated with puberty. 
❌ Respiratory papillomatosis :
Incorrect: Respiratory papillomatosis is a rare disorder characterized by the development of small, wart-like growths in the respiratory tract.  Involvement of the larynx can result in voice change, most commonly a hoarse, gravelly voice. It is more likely this patient’s symptoms are related to normal anatomic changes associated with puberty.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after being involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision. The patient was a restrained driver traveling on the highway when he suddenly slammed into the back of a stopped semi-truck. Upon arrival to the emergency department, the patient reports severe substernal chest pain radiating to his left shoulder blade. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 104/min, respirations are 18/min and blood pressure is 185/100 mmHg. Physical examination shows bruising over the anterior chest wall, but no crepitus is felt on palpation. Shoulder examination shows full passive and active range of motion bilaterally. A chest X-ray is obtained (see below):  



Reproduced from: Radiopaedia  

Which of the following is the most likely location of injury?
questions.solution:
Traumatic rupture of the aorta is a potentially life-threatening injury, with most cases occurring due to sudden deceleration related to automobile accidents. Approximately 80-90% of aortic tears occur in the descending aorta at the isthmus, which is just distal to the left subclavian artery and strongly tethered by the ligamentum arteriosum. Many patients will have retrosternal or scapular pain, and a widened mediastinum is visible on chest x ray.  

During deceleration, the more mobile aortic arch swings forward, producing a shearing force or “whiplash effect” on the aorta at the isthmus, which is fixed due to the attachment of the ligamentum arteriosum. This shearing force at the isthmus results in a tear. Less common sites of aortic trauma include the ascending aorta, the distal descending aorta at the level of the diaphragm, and the mid-thoracic descending aorta, because these areas of the aorta are more anatomically fixed and thus less subject to movement.  



Option Analysis

✅ Aortic isthmus:
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Distal descending aorta:
Incorrect: While this is a potential area of trauma, it is less likely to be injured due to its relatively fixed position at the diaphragm.   
❌ Sinotubular junction:
Incorrect: This location is an uncommon site of injury and is rarely involved in traumatic aortic pathology.  
❌ Clavicle :
Incorrect: While this patient endorses shoulder pain, there is no crepitus on exam, and the patient has full range of motion of the shoulder, making a clavicular injury less likely.   
❌ Manubrium :
Incorrect: This patient does endorse retrosternal chest pain; however, no crepitus is appreciated, and there is no evidence of a fracture pattern obtained on the radiograph above.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after sustaining a traumatic head injury in a motor vehicle collision. The patient is unresponsive, and the paramedics report a witnessed generalized-tonic-clonic seizure. Past history is significant for mitral valve replacement four years ago, hypertension, and coronary artery disease. Current medications include aspirin, warfarin, enalapril, metoprolol, and atorvastatin. Temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 59/min, respirations are 7/min and irregular, and blood pressure is 170/92 mm Hg. On examination, the patient appears comatose with mispositioned and fixed pupils. The upper extremities are adducted, extended, and in hyperpronation. The lower extremities appear extended, adducted, and internally rotated with the feet in plantar flexion. A non-contrast CT scan of the head demonstrates extensive intraparenchymal hemorrhage with a horizontal shift of midline structures. Damage to which of the following anatomic structures most likely contributed to the extensor posturing observed in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with an intraparenchymal hemorrhage that is complicated by brain herniation (coma, mispositioned and fixed pupils, and rigid extension of upper and lower extremities).

Abnormal posturing secondary to brain herniation results from disruption of the descending tracts (e.g. rubrospinal and vestibulospinal tracts) involved in reflexive and postural movements. The red nucleus in the midbrain gives rise to the rubrospinal tract, which acts on the proximal flexor musculature of the upper limbs.  
 
  •  Transection or injury to the brainstem at the level of the red nucleus or below the red nucleus (pons) damages the rubrospinal tract. Spared vestibulospinal and reticulospinal tracts overstimulate extensor muscles, leading to the characteristic decerebrate/extensor posturing where the upper extremities are adducted, extended and in hyperpronation, while the lower extremities are also extended, adducted and internally rotated with the feet in plantar flexion. 
 
  •  Damage above the level of the red nucleus (e.g. cerebral hemisphere and internal capsule) over stimulates the flexor muscles of the upper extremities. The unaffected vestibulospinal and pontine reticulospinal tracts stimulate the extensor muscles of the body leading to decorticate/flexion posturing, where upper extremities are adducted and flexed with wrists, hands and fingers flexed into fists near the chest, while the lower extremities remain extended and internally rotated with feet in plantarflexion and big toes pointing medially. 


Option Analysis

❌ Locus coeruleus  :
Incorrect:  The locus coeruleus houses norepinephrine secreting neurons that participate in fight and flight responses during physical and emotional stress. It is located in the dorsal pons and does not affect the motor coordination of the upper and lower extremities.  
✅ Red nucleus  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Raphe nuclei  :
Incorrect: The raphe nuclei are located in the midbrain, pons, and medulla and project widely through the CNS. They house serotonergic neurons which play a role in sleep-wake cycle, anxiety, psychosis and mood changes. They do not affect motor coordination of the upper and lower extremities.  
❌ Substantia nigra:
Incorrect: The substantia nigra contains dopaminergic neurons, which are depleted in Parkinson disease. This disease presents with bradykinesia, involuntary tremor, and rigidity.  
❌ Nucleus basalis of Meynert  :
Incorrect: The nucleus basalis of Meynert houses the cell bodies of cholinergic neurons. Decreased acetylcholine is released from these neurons in patients with Alzheimer disease.

questions.text: A researcher is studying the structure and function of the diaphragm. The researcher notices that different structures perforate the diaphragm at different vertebral levels. Which of the following pairs of structures perforate the diaphragm at T10 level?
questions.solution:
Structures that perforate the diaphragm include:
  • At T8: inferior vena cava (IVC), right phrenic nerve
  • At T10: esophagus, vagus nerve (CN X)
  • At T12: aorta, thoracic duct and azygous vein



Option Analysis

❌ Inferior vena cava and esophagus:
Incorrect: The inferior vena cava perforates the diaphragm at the T8 vertebral level.
❌ Right phrenic nerve and esophagus:
Incorrect: The right phrenic nerve perforates the diaphragm at the T8 vertebral level.
❌ Thoracic duct and azygous vein:
Incorrect: The thoracic duct and azygous vein perforate the diaphragm at the T12 vertebral level. 
❌ Aorta and azygous vein:
Incorrect: The aorta and azygous vein perforate the diaphragm at the T12 vertebral level.
✅ Esophagus and vagus nerve:
Correct: See Main Explanation

questions.text: A partial liver resection is performed in a patient with an early stage hepatocellular carcinoma in the left lobe of the liver. During the procedure, a ligament is found that attaches the liver to the anterior abdominal wall. Which of the following structures are contained within this ligament?

choices.text: Hepatic artery, portal vein, and common bile duct
Remnant of the fetal umbilical vein

questions.solution:
The falciform ligament attaches the liver to the anterior abdominal wall. It is derived from the ventral mesentery and contains the ligamentum teres hepatis, which is a remnant of the fetal umbilical vein, and patent paraumbilical veins. Other gastrointestinal ligaments are summarized below:  



Option Analysis

❌ Hepatic artery, portal vein, and common bile duct  :
Incorrect: The portal triad consists of the hepatic artery, portal vein, and common bile duct. The portal vein is contained within the hepatoduodenal ligament, which connects the liver to the duodenum.  
✅ Remnant of the fetal umbilical vein  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Tail of the pancreas  :
Incorrect: The tail of the pancreas is contained within the splenorenal ligament, which connects the spleen to the left pararenal space.  
❌ Gastroepiploic arteries  :
Incorrect: The gastroepiploic arteries are contained within the gastrocolic ligament, which connects the greater curvature of the stomach to the transverse colon.  
❌ Short gastric vessels  :
Incorrect: The short gastric vessels are contained within the gastrosplenic ligament, which connects the greater curvature of the stomach to the spleen.

questions.text:
A 24-year-old man presents to the emergency department with left-sided shoulder pain. The patient was playing flag football when he tripped and fell on an outstretched left arm. Physical examination is notable for a gap along the lateral edge of the left acromion process. The left arm is in slight abduction and external rotation. A radiograph of the shoulder is obtained and shown below:  


Image reproduced from Radiopedia  
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with acute onset shoulder pain after falling on an outstretched arm. Physical examination is notable for a visible deformity of the left shoulder, and radiography demonstrates an anteriorly displaced glenohumeral head on the axillary Y-view. These findings are consistent with an anterior shoulder dislocation.

Anterior shoulder dislocations are a common orthopedic injury and typically occur after a fall onto an outstretched arm. Clinically, patients may present with a visible deformity of the shoulder and a “squared appearance” compared to the contralateral shoulder. In addition, patients will typically hold their arm in slight abduction and external rotation. Radiographs will demonstrate an anteriorly displaced humeral head on the axillary Y-view.

Complications include axillary artery and nerve injury. As a result, patients should be assessed for neurovascular injury both pre- and post-reduction. In addition, associated bony injuries to the glenohumeral joint include the Hill-Sachs deformity (posterolateral humeral head compression fracture) and Bankart lesions (injury to the inferior glenoid labrum).

In contrast, posterior shoulder dislocations are rare and most commonly occur due to prolonged seizures, high speed motor vehicle accidents, or lightning injuries. Clinically, they are less commonly associated with a gross deformity. However, patients may demonstrate prominence of the coracoid process or posterior shoulder. In addition, the arm is often held in internal rotation. Complications include rotator cuff/labrum tears and humeral fractures.  

Option Analysis

✅ Anterior glenohumeral joint dislocation  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Posterior glenohumeral joint dislocation  :
Incorrect: Posterior shoulder dislocations are rare but can occur in the setting of high speed motor vehicle accidents, status epilepticus, and lightning injuries. It will demonstrate a posteriorly displaced humeral head on the axillary Y-view. In contrast, this patient’s shoulder radiograph demonstrates an anteriorly displaced humeral head.  
❌ Inferior glenohumeral joint dislocation  :
Incorrect: Inferior glenohumeral joint dislocations occur due to axial loading while the arm is fully abducted. Patients will have their arm fully abducted with the elbow flexed above their head. Plain films will demonstrate the humeral head inferior to the glenoid.  
❌ Sternoclavicular joint separation  :
Incorrect: Sternoclavicular joint separation involves a tear in the sterno-clavicular ligaments and is classified as either anterior or posterior. This radiograph does not capture the sterno-clavicular joint.  
❌ Superior glenohumeral joint dislocation  :
Incorrect: Superior glenohumeral joint dislocations are a rare occurrence and are due to a force in the anterior and superior direction.

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl presents to her family medicine physician for a routine checkup after sustaining a right tibia fracture from a motor vehicle accident one month ago. She has been using crutches frequently for ambulation and endorses decreased sensation over her right dorsoradial arm and an inability to extend her right wrist, thumb, and fingers. The patient states that her symptoms subside with rest. Which of the following is most likely responsible for this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with findings of radial nerve compression (often known as “Saturday night palsy”).   Patients with this condition often have a history of persistent compression applied to the axilla, either by a physical object such as crutches or via prolonged abduction of the arm (e.g. falling asleep on an outstretched arm).

Patients with radial nerve compression often endorse absent or decreased sensation on the dorsoradial side of the hand and wrist, in addition to the inability to extend their wrist, thumb, and fingers. When the hand is placed in pronation, the wrist and hand will drop (a finding known as “wrist drop”)—approximately 92% of patients suffering from radial nerve compression resolve with observation alone.  

Option Analysis

❌ C7 nerve root injury  :
Incorrect: An isolated injury to the C7 nerve root is rare and low-yield for examination purposes. On rare occasions, injury to the C7 nerve root is associated with Erb palsy.  
❌ Carpal tunnel syndrome  :
Incorrect: This patient’s disease etiology and symptomatology are not congruent with findings of carpal tunnel syndrome, which presents with median nerve neuropathy most commonly in patients with underlying diabetes, hypothyroidism, or repetitive hand motions.  
✅ Radial nerve injury:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Ulnar nerve injury  :
Incorrect: Ulnar nerve injury presents with an ulnar claw hand, rather than complete wrist drop as observed in this patient’s presentation.  
❌ C5-C6 nerve root injury  :
Incorrect: Upper brachial plexus injuries often occur from lateral flexion of the neck, causing partial or complete laceration of cervical nerve roots C5-6. Injury to these nerve roots results in Erb palsy, wherein the wrist is flexed, the forearm is extended, and the arm is internally rotated.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old woman presents to her outpatient provider for evaluation of chronic migraines. As part of the workup, a head CT with contrast is performed. Sagittal and axial images from the scan are shown below:


Image reproduced from Radiopedia.   

The walls of the structure indicated by the arrow are composed of the following?
questions.solution:
The dura mater is the tough, thick, outermost meningeal layer. It can be subdivided into the periosteal layer, which lies closer to the bone, and the meningeal layer, which lies closer to the brain tissue. The dural layers are usually fused but separate at certain regions to form the dural reflections and dural venous sinuses.  

The dural reflections are two face-to-face meningeal layers that descend into the cranial cavity to form septa that compartmentalize the brain. The primary dural reflections are the falx cerebri, which separates the two brain hemispheres, and tentorium cerebelli, which separates the cerebellum from the occipital lobe. Smaller dural reflections include the falx cerebelli, which separates the two cerebellar lobes, and diaphragma sellae, which forms a roof over the sella turcica.  

The dural venous sinuses are channels used to drain venous blood from the cerebral veins and drain cerebrospinal fluid from the subarachnoid space. The contents of the dural venous sinuses ultimately drain into the internal jugular vein. The major dural venous sinuses include the superior sagittal, inferior sagittal, straight (indicated by red arrow), transverse, and sigmoid sinuses. Smaller ones have the cavernous, petrosal, and sphenoparietal sinuses.  

 




Option Analysis

❌ Pia mater:
Incorrect: The arrow points to the straight sinus, one of the dural venous sinuses. The walls of the straight sinus are composed of dura mater, not pia mater.
❌ Arachnoid mater:
Incorrect: The arrow points to the straight sinus, one of the dural venous sinuses. The walls of the straight sinus are composed of dura mater, not arachnoid mater.
✅ Dura mater:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Astrocyte foot processes:
Incorrect: The blood-brain barrier comprises astrocyte foot processes, capillary endothelial cells, and the basement membrane. However, the arrow points to the straight sinus, which is formed by the dura mater.
❌ Schwann cells:
Incorrect: Schwann cells are responsible for myelinating axons in the peripheral nervous system. In contrast, the structure indicated by the arrow is the straight sinus, which is within the central nervous system. The walls of this structure are formed by the periosteal and meningeal layers of the dura mater.

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman comes to the emergency department for evaluation of right lower extremity weakness. The patient awoke this morning with difficulty standing from the bed. Past medical history is significant for hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus and a myocardial infarction with drug-eluting stent placement. The patient has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past thirty years. Temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 88/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 200/96 mm Hg. Neurologic examination reveals 0/5 strength of the right lower extremity, 3+ deep tendon reflexes, and a positive Babinski sign. Sensation is decreased throughout the right foot and leg. The left lower extremity and bilateral upper extremities are neurologically intact. Which of the following labeled vascular structures is most likely implicated given this patient’s presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient likely suffered an ischemic stroke of the left anterior cerebral artery (ACA) territory. The ACA supplies the medial aspect of the frontal and parietal lobes, a region which controls the ipsilateral lower extremity motor and sensory cortices. Occlusion of the ACA results in contralateral motor and sensory deficits, with the lower limb affected more than the upper limb. Notably, bilateral ACA occlusion can cause significant behavioral symptoms (e.g. abulia) and urinary incontinence due to damage to the frontal micturition center (e.g. medial frontal lobe/cingulate gyrus). 

Option Analysis

❌ A:
