Incorrect: Saccular aneurysms are often found within the anterior and posterior communicating arteries in the circle of Willis. Anterior communicating artery aneurysms can compress the optic chiasm, resulting in bitemporal hemianopia. 
✅ B:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ C:
Incorrect: Posterior cerebral artery infarction results in contralateral hemianopia due to infarction of the visual cortex. The macula is often spared due to contralateral circulation from the middle cerebral artery. 
❌ D:
Incorrect: Occlusion of the anterior inferior cerebellar artery (AICA) can result in lateral pontine syndrome. Patients typically present with a lower motor neuron facial nerve lesion, vertigo/nystagmus, ipsilateral cerebellar signs, loss of pain/temperature sensation on the ipsilateral face and contralateral body, ipsilateral sensorineural loss, and Horner syndrome. 
❌ E:
Incorrect: Basilar artery occlusion can result in damage to the base of the pons–an area of the brainstem that houses the corticospinal and corticobulbar tracts, as well as the paramedian tegmentum. Patients typically develop quadriplegia, bulbar dysfunction (e.g., facial weakness, dysarthria), and oculomotor deficits (e.g. horizontal gaze palsy).

questions.text:
A 66-year-old woman presents to the emergency department after developing acute onset, left-sided weakness. The patient’s daughter reports she found her mother sitting in a chair, unable to lift her left arm or leg. The patient’s past medical history includes hypertension and hyperlipidemia, for which she takes hydrochlorothiazide and atorvastatin. The patient’s temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 18/min, blood pressure is 177/86 mmHg, and O2 saturation is 97% on room air. Neurologic examination demonstrates a right-sided gaze deviation and 2/5 strength in the left upper and left lower extremity. An initial electrocardiogram is shown below. Which of the following structures of the heart is the most common origin of the thrombus implicated in this patient’s clinical condition?  


Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons.
questions.solution:
This patient presents with evidence of an ischemic stroke–a major complication of untreated atrial fibrillation, which is depicted on this patient’s electrocardiogram.

Atrial fibrillation is the most common sustained arrhythmia in clinical practice and results from unpatterned depolarization of atrial tissues caused by multiple micro-reentry circuits. These reentry circuits can be caused by progressive fibrosis and atrial dilation. Electrocardiographically, atrial fibrillation is characterized by irregular QRS complexes with absent P-waves.   

Diastolic filling and subsequent cardiac output may decrease when rapid ventricular response occurs with rates >100 beats per minute. These changes can result in chest pain, shortness of breath, dizziness, and lightheadedness. In addition, hemostasis in the atria can result in thrombus formation, most commonly at the left atrial appendage, owing to its shape and internal trabeculations.  

 

Option Analysis

✅ Left atrial appendage:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Right ventricle :
Incorrect: The right ventricle is not the most common site of thrombus formation resulting in ischemic stroke. Thrombus formation and subsequent ischemic stroke do not commonly occur from the right heart unless a patent foramen ovale is present. 
❌ Left ventricle:
Incorrect: Left ventricular aneurysms following myocardial infarction can serve as the site of thrombus formation and subsequent ischemic stroke; however, it is not the most common site of thrombus formation. 
❌ Mitral valve:
Incorrect: The left atrial appendage, not the mitral valve, is the most common site of thrombus formation and subsequent ischemic stroke from atrial fibrillation. 
❌ Tricuspid valve :
Incorrect: The tricuspid valve is not the most common site of thrombus formation resulting in ischemic stroke. Thrombus formation and subsequent ischemic stroke do not commonly occur from the right heart unless a patent foramen ovale is present.

questions.text: A 85-year-old left-handed woman is brought to the emergency department with complaints of sudden involuntary body movements. The patient states that she is having a hard time controlling movements of her right leg. Symptoms started a few hours ago. Past medical history is notable for diabetes, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and a myocardial infarction five years ago. The patient takes metformin, insulin, amlodipine, valsartan, atorvastatin, and aspirin. The patient smokes one to two cigarettes per day. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 160/93 mmHg. Physical examination shows intermittent wide flinging movements of the patient’s proximal right arm and leg. Damage to which of the following parts of the brain is the most likely cause of these abnormal body movements?
questions.solution:
Hemiballismus is a form of  involuntary movement associated with diseases afflicting the subthalamic nuclei. These movements are typically unilateral, irregular, and of large amplitude (violent flinging movement of limbs) that become more prominent with action. A lacunar stroke involving penetrating branches of a large cerebral artery supplying the subthalamus is the most common etiology of hemiballismus. Risk factors for lacunar strokes include hypertension, diabetes, hyperlipidemia, and smoking. 

The basal ganglia consists of gray matter masses within the cerebral hemispheres. These include the caudate, putamen, globus pallidus, and amygdaloid nucleus. The subthalamic nuclei, substantia nigra, and the red nucleus are structures functionally related to the basal ganglia. Physiologically, the subthalamic nucleus sends excitatory signals to the globus pallidus that, in turn, inhibits the thalamus and serves as an important modulator of basal ganglia output to regulate movement.  



Option Analysis

✅ Left subthalamic nucleus:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Right subthalamic nucleus:
Incorrect: Injury to the right subthalamic nucleus presents with left-sided hemiballismus.
❌ Hippocampus:
Incorrect: The primary role of the hippocampus is the formation and retrieval of recent memories. Damage to this area results in anterograde amnesia.
❌ Inferior left parietal lobe:
Incorrect: Hemispatial neglect syndrome results from a lesion in the inferior parietal lobe of the non-dominant hemisphere. Clinical features associated with this syndrome include spatial neglect of the contralateral body. Examples include construction apraxia (when asked to draw a clock, the individual only draws the right half of the clock) and dressing apraxia (the individual only dresses half of their body).
❌ Bilateral amygdala:
Incorrect: Kluver-Bucy syndrome results from bilateral lesions of the amygdala and surrounding cortex of the temporal lobe. Affected patients present with hypersexuality, hyperphagia, and an urge for exploring objects by mouth (hyperorality). Some patients exhibit visual agnosia, or psychic blindness, and personality changes, like passivity or docility.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman comes to the physician due to slurred speech and difficulty swallowing. The patient’s symptoms started two weeks ago and have progressively worsened. In addition, she has noticed excessive drooling and difficulty chewing food. She was seen five years ago due to painful eye movements, decreased vision in the left eye, and associated left lower extremity weakness. She was started on a monoclonal antibody, which helped control her symptoms, but she later stopped using it due to the adverse effects. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals brisk jaw reflexes bilaterally and an exaggerated gag reflex. The patient bursts out into spontaneous laughter on multiple occasions during the encounter. Which of the following is most likely responsible for this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Demyelination of the bilateral corticobulbar tracts
Tumor affecting the bilateral nucleus ambiguus
Tumor affecting the right nucleus ambiguus
Demyelination of the distal aspect cranial nerve IX

questions.solution:
Pseudobulbar palsy is an upper motor neuron lesion involving the corticobulbar (supranuclear) pathways of cranial nerves IX, X, and XI. An upper motor neuron lesion occurs above the motor nuclei of the cranial nerves. Pseudobulbar palsy is caused by bilateral damage to the corticobulbar tracts. Causes of the condition include amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS), strokes, traumatic brain injury, neoplasm, and multiple sclerosis (as is the likely diagnosis in this patient).  

The clinical presentation of pseudobulbar palsy includes dysphagia, dysarthria, dysphonia, and an increased gag reflex. Patients may also show signs of emotional lability and apathy. Of note, while the gag reflex is exaggerated in pseudobulbar palsy (upper motor neuron lesion), it is typically absent in bulbar palsy (lower motor neuron lesion). This difference is a key clinical sign used to distinguish between bulbar and pseudobulbar palsy.  



Option Analysis

✅ Demyelination of the bilateral corticobulbar tracts:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Mass in the jugular foramen:
Incorrect: A mass in the jugular foramen can compress cranial nerves IX, X, and XI and result in bulbar palsy. Bulbar palsy can manifest with weakness in the muscles supplied by these nerves and an absent gag reflex since it is a lower motor neuron lesion. However, emotional lability (inappropriate laughter) is not seen in patients with bulbar palsy. 
❌ Tumor affecting the bilateral nucleus ambiguus :
Incorrect: The nucleus ambiguus contains the motor nuclei of cranial nerves IX, X, and XI. A lesion affecting this structure will lead to bulbar palsy, resembling pseudobulbar palsy. However, reflexes are diminished, and emotional lability is absent in patients with bulbar palsy. 
❌ Tumor affecting the right nucleus ambiguus:
Incorrect: The nucleus ambiguus contains the motor nuclei for CN IX, X, and XI. A lesion affecting this structure will lead to bulbar palsy, resembling pseudobulbar palsy. However, reflexes are diminished, and emotional lability is absent in patients with bulbar palsy. 
❌ Demyelination of the distal aspect cranial nerve IX:
Incorrect: This patient has an exaggerated gag reflex, suggestive of an upper motor neuron lesion. In contrast, demyelination of the peripheral portions of the cranial nerves outside the skull will result in lower motor neuron symptoms, such as decreased reflexes.

questions.text:
An 82-year-old man is hospitalized for recurrent pneumonia. This is the patient’s fourth hospitalization for pneumonia in the past six months, and bronchial lavage cultures have consistently grown Bacteroides sp susceptible to ampicillin-sulbactam. The patient undergoes a barium swallow study as demonstrated below during his hospitalization. Which of the following correctly identifies the anatomic location of this patient’s clinical condition?  


Reproduced from: Wikipedia

choices.text: Junction between the cricopharyngeus and thyropharyngeus
Junction between the middle and inferior pharyngeal constrictors muscles
Junction between the upper part of the inferior pharyngeal constrictors
Junction between the superior and middle pharyngeal constrictors
Junction between the circular and longitudinal fibers of the esophagus

questions.solution:
This patient presents with recurrent aspiration pneumonia, as evidenced by culture data growing oral flora. This patient's barium swallow study demonstrates an outpouching of the cervical esophagus, most consistent with a Zenker diverticulum.  

Zenker diverticulum refers to an outpouching of the esophageal mucosa and submucosa through Killian’s triangle (also called Killian’s dehiscence), an area in the posterior wall of the pharynx between the cricopharyngeus and thyropharyngeus (the two parts of the inferior constrictors). The pathogenesis of Zenker’s diverticulum is thought to be due to altered function of the upper esophageal sphincter (cricopharyngeus), esophageal dysmotility, and esophageal shortening. Dysfunction of these muscle groups results in impaired bolus passage, increased intraluminal pressure, and subsequent protrusion of mucosa and submucosa through Killian's triangle.  

Clinical features include recurrent dysphagia, halitosis, and cough. A common complication of this condition is recurrent aspiration pneumonia. If small, a Zenker diverticulum is treated conservatively; larger diverticula are traditionally treated with surgery to incise the cricopharyngeus muscle and resect the diverticulum.  

Option Analysis

✅ Junction between the cricopharyngeus and thyropharyngeus:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Junction between the middle and inferior pharyngeal constrictors muscles:
Incorrect: The area between the middle and inferior pharyngeal constrictors muscles is not involved in a Zenker diverticulum's pathogenesis.
❌ Junction between the upper part of the inferior pharyngeal constrictors  :
Incorrect: The thyropharyngeus muscle refers to the upper part of the inferior pharyngeal constrictors muscle, which is not the site of formation of a Zenker diverticulum.
❌ Junction between the superior and middle pharyngeal constrictors:
Incorrect: The junction between the superior and middle pharyngeal constrictors is not involved in the pathogenesis of a Zenker diverticulum. 
❌ Junction between the circular and longitudinal fibers of the esophagus:
Incorrect: The junction between the circular and longitudinal fibers of the esophagus is not involved in Zenker diverticulum formation.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man presents to the emergency department to evaluate low back pain. The patient was using the rowing machine at the gym when he felt a “pop” in his back followed by pain. He is otherwise healthy and does not take any medications daily. Vital signs are within normal limits. On physical examination, the patient has tenderness to palpation over the lumbar spine and diminished sensation over the anterior aspect of the left leg. The patient has 4/5 strength with hip flexion on the left compared to 5/5 strength on the right. Which of the following physical examination maneuvers is most likely to demonstrate a positive finding given this patient’s clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation of low back pain and findings of L2-L4 radiculopathy, including diminished sensation over the anterior aspect of the leg and decreased strength with hip flexion. Given these findings, the exam maneuver most likely to be positive is the straight leg raise, which often reproduces symptoms of sciatic nerve root compression.    

The evaluation of low back pain involves a detailed examination, beginning with inspection and palpation for tenderness, step-offs, and deformities. When radiculopathy is suspected, additional examination maneuvers include checking the lower extremities for reflexes, strength, and sensation. Special examination techniques include the straight leg raise, which is performed with the patient lying down on their back, and the examiner lifts the patient's leg while the knee is straight. Reproduction of pain with radiation down the leg indicates a positive test.



Specific sensory or motor findings can also indicate the anatomic location of radiculopathy. For example, L2-L4 radiculopathy often presents with pain and diminished sensation radiating down the anterior aspect of the thigh and occasionally into the medial part of the lower leg, with associated weakness of hip flexion, knee extension, and hip adduction. L5 radiculopathy presents with pain and loss of sensation down the lateral aspect of the leg into the foot, with associated diminished foot dorsiflexion, toe extension, foot inversion, and foot eversion. Lastly, S1 radiculopathy presents with pain and diminished sensation that radiates down the posterior aspect of the leg, with associated weakness of plantar flexion, leg extension, and knee flexion, along with a diminished ankle jerk reflex.  

Option Analysis

✅ Straight leg raise test:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Stork test :
Incorrect: The stork test, also known as the Gillet test, assesses for sacroiliac joint movement between the innominate and sacrum through the clinician's palpation of the posterior superior iliac spine during knee flexion. A positive test is an indication of sacroiliac joint hypomobility. 
❌ Thessaly test:
Incorrect: The Thessaly test, like the McMurray test, is used to detect meniscal injuries of the knee, not lumbosacral radiculopathy.  
❌ Ober test:
Incorrect: The Ober test detects tension in the iliotibial band, not lumbosacral radiculopathy.   
❌ FABER test:
Incorrect: The FABER test evaluates hip pathology by flexing, abducting, and externally rotating the hip. It is not helpful for the evaluation of lumbosacral radiculopathy.

questions.text: A 17-month-old boy is brought to the office by his parents due to behavioral concerns. The patient has been less interactive with family members and more irritable for six weeks. During his last check-up one year ago, the patient was otherwise healthy. Since then, the patient has not achieved new milestones in speech, gross motor, or fine motor development. Temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 79/min, respirations are 28/min and blood pressure is 105/55 mm Hg. The patient does not maintain eye contact. The anterior fontanelle is closed. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal examination is unremarkable. The skin is pink and well perfused. Growth charting demonstrates a rapidly enlarging head circumference. A CT scan of the brain reveals a mass lesion, enlarged lateral and third ventricles, and a normally sized fourth ventricle. Which of the following is the most likely anatomic site pathology in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with an enlarging head circumference, behavioral changes, and delayed developmental milestones, suggesting hydrocephalus.

In hydrocephalus, impaired outflow leads to an increase in cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) volume,  dilation of the ventricles, and compression of surrounding brain tissue. Normally, CSF is produced by the choroid plexus, flows from the lateral, through the third and fourth ventricles, and ultimately to the subarachnoid space for reabsorption. The narrowest portion of the ventricular system is the cerebral aqueduct, also called the aqueduct of Sylvius, where it drains CSF from the third to the fourth ventricle. The cerebral aqueduct is the most common site of obstruction that may result in hydrocephalus.

The cerebral aqueduct can be blocked by cellular debris formed from intraventricular hemorrhage, bacterial or fungal infections, as well as tumors of the midbrain or pinealomas. Clinically, hydrocephalus can present with headaches, nausea, vomiting, papilledema, behavioral changes, coma, and even death.



Option Analysis

❌ Arachnoid villi  :
Incorrect: Inflammation or fibrosis of arachnoid villi can impair CSF absorption. This results in communicating hydrocephalus with global ventricular dilation and increased intracranial pressure (ICP). This patient’s fourth ventricle is normal in size, suggestive of a distal blockage to CSF flow.  
✅ Cerebral aqueduct  :
Correct: See Main Explanation  
❌ Interventricular foramina of Monro  :
Incorrect: Obstruction at the interventricular foramina of Monro causes enlargement of the lateral ventricles, in contrast to the enlarged lateral and third ventricles observed in this patient.  
❌ Lateral foramen of Luschka  :
Incorrect: Obstruction at the lateral foramen of Luschka causes enlargement of all four ventricles. This patient’s fourth ventricle is of normal size.  
❌ Medial foramen of Magendie  :
Incorrect: Obstruction at the medial foramen of Magendie causes enlargement of all four ventricles. This patient’s fourth ventricle is of normal size.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman presents to the office for evaluation of a painful tongue sore. The sore is on the median sulcus of the tongue, located 2 cm anterior to the foramen cecum. Taste sensation in this region of the tongue is carried by which of the following nerves?
questions.solution:
Innervation of the tongue is complex, as there are motor, general sensory, and gustatory (taste) components.

Motor innervation is provided by: 
  •  Hypoglossal nerve (CN XII): hyoglossus, genioglossus, and styloglossus muscles 
  •  Vagus nerve (CN X): palatoglossus muscle 
General sensory innervation including touch, pain, pressure, and temperature is provided by: 
  •  Anterior two-thirds of the tongue: mandibular branch of trigeminal nerve (CN V3) 
  •  Posterior one-third of the tongue: glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX) 
  •  Posterior area of the tongue: vagus nerve (CN X) 
Gustatory innervation (taste buds) are as follows: 
  •  Anterior two-thirds of the tongue: chorda tympani branch of facial nerve (CN VII) 
  •  Posterior one-third of the tongue: glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX) 
  •  Posterior area of the tongue root and taste buds of the larynx and upper esophagus: vagus nerve (CN X) 


Option Analysis

❌ Vagus nerve  :
Incorrect: The vagus nerve (CN X) innervates the far posterior area of the tongue root, transmitting both gustatory and general sensory stimuli.  
✅ Chorda tympani  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Glossopharyngeal nerve  :
Incorrect: The glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX) transmits taste, pain, temperature, and touch stimuli from the posterior one-third of the tongue.  
❌ Mandibular branch of trigeminal nerve  :
Incorrect: The mandibular branch of the trigeminal nerve (CN V3) transmits pain, temperature, and touch from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue.  
❌ Hypoglossal nerve  :
Incorrect: The hypoglossal nerve (CN XII) provides motor innervation to the tongue.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician with left shoulder pain. The pain started insidiously two weeks ago and tends to be worse at night. She has also experienced decreased range of motion in the left shoulder. The patient did not sustain any recent injuries. Past medical history is notable for hypertension, type II diabetes mellitus, and hyperlipidemia. On physical examination, the patient demonstrates limited active and passive range of motion, with associated pain. A radiograph of the left shoulder is shown below:  


Image reproduced from Radiopedia  
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with insidious subacute left shoulder pain with global stiffness, as well as limited active and passive range of motion. The shoulder radiograph is unremarkable. Together, these findings suggest adhesive capsulitis (also termed frozen shoulder syndrome).

Adhesive capsulitis is a poorly understood condition that results in global stiffness and pain of the glenohumeral joint. Current research postulates the condition results from spontaneous inflammation of the joint capsule, followed by the development of adhesions and fibrosis of the synovial lining. Clinically, patients present with subacute symptoms including deep, nagging shoulder pain and associated limitations in passive and active range of motion (particularly external rotation and abduction). The condition is often idiopathic but has been associated with a history of shoulder injury, diabetes, dyslipidemia, Parkinson disease, immobilization, and antiretroviral therapy.

The disease progresses through three distinct phases. First, patients experience an acute phase characterized by severe disabling shoulder pain that worsens at night, with some associated stiffness. This phase lasts 2-9 months. Next, an intermediate phase occurs wherein pain decreases but stiffness and severe loss of shoulder motion ensues. This phase lasts 4-12 months. Finally, a recovery phase occurs, wherein patients regain shoulder mobility.

Diagnosis of adhesive capsulitis is primarily clinical, as imaging findings are generally noncontributory, and radiographs are often normal. Since most cases are self-limited, management is conservative and involves a combination of rest, analgesia, and physical therapy.  

Option Analysis

✅ Adhesive capsulitis  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Glenohumeral osteoarthritis  :
Incorrect: Glenohumeral osteoarthritis more commonly occurs in older adults with a prior history of shoulder surgery or trauma. In addition, this condition presents chronically, developing over the course of months to years. Radiographic findings of glenohumeral osteoarthritis include joint space narrowing, sclerosis, and osteophyte formation.  
❌ Subacromial bursitis  :
Incorrect: Subacromial bursitis falls into the category of rotator cuff impingement injuries and can present similarly to adhesive capsulitis. However, patients with subacromial bursitis will demonstrate limited active range of motion but preserved passive range of motion.  
❌ Anterior glenohumeral joint dislocation  :
Incorrect: Anterior shoulder dislocation is the most common form of shoulder dislocation. Patients with anterior shoulder dislocation will typically hold their arm in slight abduction and external rotation. The axillary Y-view will demonstrate an anteriorly displaced humeral head relative to the glenoid fossa.  
❌ Humeral head fracture  :
Incorrect: There is no evidence of a fracture pattern on this patient’s radiograph.

questions.text: The pampiniform plexus is part of the thermoregulatory system of the testis. The veins of each  pampiniform plexus converge superiorly to form the testicular veins. Which of the following statements regarding the drainage of the testicular veins is most accurate?

choices.text: The right and left testicular vein drains directly into the inferior vena cava.
The right testicular vein drains directly into the right iliac vein.
The left testicular vein drains directly into the left renal vein.
The right testicular vein drains directly into the right renal vein.
The right and left testicular vein drains directly into the common iliac vein.

questions.solution:
The veins emerging from the testis and epididymis form the pampiniform venous plexus, a network of 8-12 veins that lies anterior to the ductus deferens and surround the testicular artery in the spermatic cord.

The pampiniform plexus is part of the thermoregulatory system of the testis (along with the cremaster and dartos muscles), helping to keep the organ at a constant temperature. The veins of each pampiniform plexus converge superiorly to form the testicular vein. The right testicular vein empties into the inferior vena cava (IVC), whereas the left testicular vein drains into the left renal vein, which then drains into the IVC.  



Option Analysis

❌ The right and left testicular vein drains directly into the inferior vena cava.  :
Incorrect: Only the right testicular vein drains directly into the inferior vena cava (IVC). The left testicular vein drains into the left renal vein, emptying into the IVC.  
❌ The right testicular vein drains directly into the right iliac vein.  :
Incorrect: The right testicular vein drains directly into the inferior vena cava (IVC), not the right iliac vein.  
✅ The left testicular vein drains directly into the left renal vein.:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ The right testicular vein drains directly into the right renal vein.  :
Incorrect: The right testicular vein drains directly into the inferior vena cava (IVC), not the right renal vein.  
❌ The right and left testicular vein drains directly into the common iliac vein.  :
Incorrect: The right testicular vein drains directly into the inferior vena cava (IVC). The left testicular vein drains into the left renal vein.

questions.text: A human cadaveric model is being studied to better understand the anatomic distribution and innervation of the hand. The ulnar nerve is stimulated with an electrical impulse. Based on the diagram below, which area is most likely to exhibit electrical capture after stimulation of this nerve?
questions.solution:
The hand's motor and sensory function is divided into three major nerve distributions: the radial, ulnar, and median nerve. All three of these nerves arise from the brachial plexus. Understanding these nerves' anatomic distribution and motor function can help predict both sensory and motor deficits associated with nerve injury.  



Option Analysis

✅ Area A  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Area B  :
Incorrect: This area corresponds to the sensory distribution of the medial antebrachial cutaneous nerve, not the ulnar nerve.  
❌ Area C  :
Incorrect: This area corresponds to the sensory distribution of the musculocutaneous nerve, not the ulnar nerve.  
❌ Area D:
Incorrect: This area corresponds to the sensory distribution of the radial nerve, not the ulnar nerve.  
❌ Area E  :
Incorrect: This area corresponds to the sensory distribution of the median nerve, not the ulnar nerve.

questions.text:
A 39-year-old man is involved in a motor vehicle collision. A CT scan of the head is performed and reveals the following:


Image reproduced from Radiopedia

The vessel that is most likely ruptured in this patient enters the skull via which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
This patient’s CT scan reveals lens-shaped hyper-density consistent with an epidural hematoma. Epidural hematomas most commonly arise due to rupture of the middle meningeal artery, which enters the skull via foramen spinosum in the middle cranial fossa.   The nerves and vessels that enter or exit the skull via the different structures are summarized below:



Option Analysis

❌ Foramen ovale:
Incorrect: The mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve (CN V3) exits the skull via foramen ovale in the middle cranial fossa. In contrast, this patient has an epidural hematoma, which is most commonly caused by a tear in the middle meningeal artery. The middle meningeal artery enters the skull via the foramen spinosum. 
❌ Foramen rotundum:
Incorrect: The foramen rotundum carries CN V2 (maxillary division of CN V). CN V2 innervates the skin around the maxillary sinus (around the nose). In contrast, this patient has an epidural hematoma, which is most commonly caused by a tear in the middle meningeal artery. The middle meningeal artery enters the skull via the foramen spinosum. 
❌ Hypoglossal canal:
Incorrect: The hypoglossal canal is the site where the hypoglossal nerve leaves the cranial cavity. The hypoglossal nerve (XII) is responsible for tongue movement, and deficits in this nerve can cause dysarthria. 
❌ Internal auditory meatus:
Incorrect: The internal auditory meatus is the site at which both the facial nerve and the vestibulocochlear nerve leave the cranial cavity. The facial nerve (VII) controls facial movement, lacrimation, salivation, and taste from the anterior 2/3 of the tongue. The vestibulocochlear nerve (VIII) controls balance and hearing. 
✅ Foramen spinosum:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 40-year-old comes to the office for the evaluation of an abdominal lump. The patient also reports intermittent pain in the upper abdomen that gets worse when they lift heavy weights at the gym. The rest of the review of systems is unremarkable. Past medical history is noncontributory. BMI is 35 kg/m2. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a 2 cm midline bulge between the umbilicus and xiphoid process. The bulge is erythematous, tender to palpation, and increases in size when the patient is asked to cough. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient’s midline abdominal bulge in the epigastric region that increases in size with increased intraabdominal pressure is most likely an epigastric hernia, which results when there is a defect in the linea alba of the abdominal wall.

A hernia is when an organ protrudes through the body wall that normally contains it. Ventral abdominal hernias occur in the anterior abdominal wall and can be divided into:

  •  Epigastric hernia (as described above) 
  •  Umbilical (periumbilical) hernia: Occurs near the umbilicus, often associated with pregnancy 
  •  Spigelian hernia: Located in the "Spigelian hernia belt," a transverse 6-centimeter-wide zone around the level of the arcuate line 
  • Incisional hernia: Usually develops on a prior surgical incision site where the fascia never fully healed
Risk factors for ventral hernias include obesity, pregnancy, heavy lifting, genetic defects, aging, and intractable vomiting.



Reducible hernias can be pushed back into the abdomen by applying manual pressure, whereas irreducible (i.e. incarcerated) hernias are trapped within the hernia sac and cannot be reduced. An incarcerated hernia can progress to become a strangulated hernia due to the progressive edema secondary to impaired blood and lymphatic flow, leading to ischemic necrosis of the herniated contents.



Option Analysis

✅ Defect in the linea alba:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Defect in the Spigelian aponeurosis:
Incorrect: A defect in the Spigelian aponeurosis can result in Spigelian hernia, which is located in the "Spigelian hernia belt," a transverse 6-centimeter-wide zone around the level of the arcuate line, which is the caudal-most extent of the posterior rectus sheath. It is not located in the epigastric region.
❌ Patent processus vaginalis:
Incorrect: Patent processus vaginalis can result in indirect inguinal hernia, in which the abdominal contents go through the inguinal ring and protrudes lateral to the epigastric vessels into the inguinal canal and sometimes the scrotum. This patient has an epigastric hernia.
❌ Weakness of the obturator membrane:
Incorrect: Weakness of the obturator membrane can cause an obturator hernia, in which the abdominal contents protrude through the obturator foramen, which is located on the anterolateral aspect of the pelvic wall. This patient has an epigastric hernia.
❌ Weakness of the transversalis fascia:
Incorrect: Weakness of the transversalis fascia can result in direct inguinal hernia, in which the abdominal contents protrude medially to the inferior epigastric vessels within the Hesselbach triangle and appear in the groin (unlike the epigastric bulge in this patient).

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy is brought to the pediatric emergency department for evaluation of an intractable nosebleed after being hit in the face with a basketball during recess. He does not have any shortness of breath, hemoptysis, or hematemesis. There is no family history of bleeding disorders. Temperature is 37.2°C (98.9°F), pulse is 85/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 120/64 mm Hg. The physical exam is notable for clots in the nares, with moderate rebleeding when the clots are dislodged. Which of the following anatomic locations is the most likely site of ongoing bleeding in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with uncomplicated epistaxis (nosebleed) following facial trauma. The most common source of bleeding in patients with uncomplicated epistaxis is the Kiesselbach plexus–an area found in the anterior third of the nose. Anastomosis of the following blood vessels occurs in this region:  
  •  Septal branch of the anterior ethmoidal artery 
  •  Lateral nasal branch of the sphenopalatine artery 
  •  Septal branch of superior labial artery (branch of the facial artery) 

Posterior epistaxis, on the other hand, occurs from bleeding in the Woodruff plexus–a collection of arteries in the posteroinferior nasal cavity formed by the anastomoses of the sphenopalatine artery (branch of the maxillary artery) and pharyngeal artery. Posterior epistaxis often presents as difficult to control bleeding from the bilateral nostrils or hemoptysis. Posterior epistaxis is highly associated with brisk bleeding into the posterior pharynx and thus a higher risk of airway compromise or aspiration.




Option Analysis

❌ Inferior turbinate  :
Incorrect: The inferior turbinates, along with superior and middle turbinates, are involved in warming, filtering, and humidifying inspired air. They are unlikely sites of epistaxis.  
❌ Posterolateral wall  :
Incorrect: Branches of the sphenopalatine artery supply the posterolateral wall and are the most likely source of posterior nosebleeds. Epistaxis secondary to injury of the sphenopalatine artery or its branches results in brisk hemorrhage that is difficult to control with direct pressure or specific interventions.  
✅ Kiesselbach plexus  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Posterior choanae  :
Incorrect: Branches of the sphenopalatine artery supply the posterior choanae and are the most likely the site of posterior nosebleeds. Epistaxis secondary to injury of the sphenopalatine artery or its branches results in brisk hemorrhage that is difficult to control with direct pressure or specific interventions.  
❌ Middle meatus  :
Incorrect: The middle turbinate over the lateral nasal wall forms the middle meatus, a drainage pathway for the frontal, maxillary, and anterior ethmoidal sinus. It is the most common site for nasal polyps to form but is unlikely to be involved in anterior nasal bleeds.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old man presents to his primary care physician with worsening stiffness in the right hand. Over the past several months, the patient has had difficulty extending the right ring finger. He states, “I feel like my finger is under constant tension. I think my father had a similar condition.” Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination of the right hand is notable for the findings demonstrated below. Further evaluation of the patient’s medical history will likely reveal which of the following?  


 Image reproduced from ">Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
This patient presents with evidence of a Dupuytren contracture on physical examination. The condition is associated with a history of diabetes mellitus.

A Dupuytren contracture is characterized by slow, progressive fibroproliferation of the palmar fascia. The underlying etiology of this condition is unclear. However, this disease has several risk factors, including diabetes mellitus, chronic alcohol use, repetitive hand use, vibratory trauma, and smoking. In addition, there is a component of genetic predisposition, with a majority of patients being men of northern European ancestry.  

Clinically, Dupuytren contractures manifest with nodules on the palmar fascia and fingers. The nodules gradually lose flexibility and contract, resulting in the affected fingers being drawn into flexion. This condition is usually painless. However, Dupuytren contractures can become painful if the underlying tendon sheaths become inflamed.  

Option Analysis

✅ Diabetes mellitus  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Hypertension:
Incorrect: Hypertension has not been independently associated with the development of Dupuytren contractures.  
❌ Hyperlipidemia  :
Incorrect: Hyperlipidemia has not been independently associated with the development of Dupuytren contractures.  
❌ Previous hand surgery  :
Incorrect: There is currently debate as to whether prior hand trauma or surgery lends towards the development of Dupuytren contracture. In contrast, diabetes mellitus is a well-documented risk factor for the development of this condition.  
❌ Epilepsy  :
Incorrect: Epilepsy is not a known risk factor for the development of Dupuytren contractures.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is evaluated on inpatient rounds for a retropharyngeal abscess. Temperature is 102 °F, pulse is 122/min, respiratory rate is 20/min. The patient is awake and oriented and appears tired. He is not struggling to breathe and is otherwise resting comfortably. An area of erythematous inflammation is seen in the posterior oropharynx, and the patient has mild submandibular lymphadenopathy. Parenteral antibiotic therapy is initiated with clindamycin and metronidazole. The physician explains to the parents at the bedside that urgent treatment is required due to the potential spread of infection into a region called the “danger space.” Which of the following best describes the boundaries of this space?

choices.text: Buccopharyngeal fascia anteriorly and alar fascia posteriorly
Buccopharyngeal fascia anteriorly and prevertebral fascia posteriorly
Pretracheal fascia anteriorly and alar fascia posteriorly
Alar fascia anteriorly and prevertebral fascia posteriorly

questions.solution:
Posterior to the pharynx, there is a potential space called the retropharyngeal space. This space is bounded anteriorly by the buccopharyngeal fascia, the superior continuation of the pretracheal fascia, and posteriorly by the alar fascia. Infection in the retropharyngeal space can also lead to a retropharyngeal abscess, resulting in difficulty swallowing and speaking.

Another important space is the ‘danger space,’ which is posterior to the retropharyngeal space and bounded anteriorly by the alar fascia and posteriorly by the prevertebral layer of the deep cervical fascia. This space extends from the base of the skull into the posterior mediastinum and down to the level of the diaphragm, making it the most important route for the spread of infection between the neck and thorax.



Option Analysis

❌ Buccopharyngeal fascia anteriorly and alar fascia posteriorly:
Incorrect: These are the boundaries of the retropharyngeal space. The ‘danger space’ is posterior to the retropharyngeal space and bounded anteriorly by the alar fascia and posteriorly by the prevertebral fascia.  
❌ Buccopharyngeal fascia anteriorly and prevertebral fascia posteriorly:
Incorrect: The ‘danger space’ is posterior to the retropharyngeal space and bounded anteriorly by the alar fascia and posteriorly by the prevertebral fascia.  
❌ Pretracheal fascia anteriorly and alar fascia posteriorly:
Incorrect: The ‘danger space’ is posterior to the retropharyngeal space and bounded anteriorly by the alar fascia and posteriorly by the prevertebral fascia.  
✅ Alar fascia anteriorly and prevertebral fascia posteriorly:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A 76-year-old man is admitted to the hospital for a fever of unknown origin. After 24 hours, the patient's blood culture from the emergency department returns positive for Gram-positive cocci in clusters. The patient subsequently undergoes transesophageal echocardiography, which produces the image as demonstrated below. Which of the following correctly identifies the structure labeled with X?  


Image reproduced from Radiopedia
questions.solution:
This patient presents with a fever of unknown origin and undergoes transesophageal echocardiography due to concern for bacteremia and endocarditis. The above image demonstrates a 4-chamber view of the heart, with the structure labeled “X” representing the mitral valve and a superior structure suspicious for vegetation.  

Transesophageal echocardiography (TEE) is an ultrasonographic technique wherein an endoscopic transducer is advanced into the esophagus to visualize cardiac structures. TEE offers superior imaging of the heart (particularly posterior cardiac structures) compared to transthoracic echocardiography, wherein ultrasound of the anterior and lateral chest is performed. Common indications for TEE include evaluation for a potential cardiac source of an embolus, valvular endocarditis, and left atrial appendage thrombi in patients with atrial fibrillation.  

Multiple views can be obtained with TEE to help visualize the cardiac structures. Visualized structures include the ventricles, atria, mitral and tricuspid valves, atrial appendage, aortic arch, aortic leaflets, root, and pulmonary arteries and veins.  

Option Analysis

✅ Mitral valve:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Tricuspid valve:
Incorrect: On the above image, the tricuspid valve is located right and inferior to the area demarcated by the X. The tricuspid valve can be identified by first locating the right ventricle, which is smaller and has a thinner wall than the left ventricle.
❌ Aortic outlet :
Incorrect: The aortic outlet is not identified in the above image, which demonstrates a four-chamber view of the heart. 
❌ Aortic valve:
Incorrect: The aortic valve has three leaflets and is not identified in the above image, which demonstrates a four-chamber view of the heart. 
❌ Pulmonic valve:
Incorrect: The pulmonic valve has three leaflets and is not identified in the above image, which demonstrates a four-chamber view of the heart.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents for follow-up evaluation after a recent myocardial infarction. The patient had a high-grade occlusion of the left anterior descending artery with stent placement. The patient has been compliant with medications. However, he has pain and weakness in the left upper extremity with exercise. The patient states, “I know something is not right. My arm turns ghost white every time I get on the treadmill, and I feel like I will pass out.” Past medical history includes hypertension, diabetes, and hyperlipidemia. Medications include aspirin, carvedilol, amlodipine, metformin, atorvastatin, and clopidogrel. He has a twenty-pack-year smoking history. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 62/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 140/70 mmHg in the right arm compared with 121/65 mmHg in the left arm. The left radial pulse demonstrates arrival delay compared to the right radial pulse. The patient's left hand presents a brisk capillary refill. The patient’s cardiologist subsequently orders an ultrasound of the heart and upper extremities. Which of the following findings is most likely to be found on ultrasonographic evaluation?

choices.text: Reversal of blood flow in the left vertebral artery
Dissection flap of the proximal aorta
Deep vein thrombosis of the left subclavian vein
Thromboembolism of the left brachial artery

questions.solution:
This patient who recently underwent stent placement for acute myocardial infarction presents with signs of exertional ischemia in the left upper extremity. His findings are suspicious for subclavian steal syndrome, which will typically demonstrate flow reversal through the ipsilateral vertebral artery.   

Subclavian steal syndrome refers to a phenomenon that occurs with severe stenosis of the subclavian artery proximal to the ipsilateral vertebral artery – typically from underlying atherosclerotic disease. As this stenosis progresses, the pressure gradient of blood flowing through the affected subclavian artery decreases relative to the pressure gradient in the ipsilateral vertebral artery. As a result, blood flows down through the vertebral artery from the basilar vascular supply.  

Most patients are asymptomatic; however, when symptoms arise, they are typically exercise-induced. Patients can present with symptoms of ischemia to the affected upper extremity, including pain, paresthesias, pallor, and coolness to the touch. In some instances, associated neurologic symptoms may manifest, including dizziness, lightheadedness, syncope, tinnitus, or disequilibrium due to vertebrobasilar ischemia.  

Physical examination findings typically include a delayed or decreased pulse amplitude of the affected extremity and a differential brachial systolic blood pressure between the upper extremities.    

Option Analysis

✅ Reversal of blood flow in the left vertebral artery:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Dissection flap of the proximal aorta :
Incorrect: Aortic dissection typically presents with acute, sharp, “tearing” chest pain radiating to the back. While this patient is at risk for aortic pathology given his recent cardiac catheterization, his clinical findings are inconsistent with this diagnosis. 
❌ Deep vein thrombosis of the left subclavian vein:
Incorrect: Given his recent surgical procedure, this patient is at an increased risk for deep vein thrombosis. However, a deep vein thrombosis of the upper extremity is rare and universally presents with swelling and pain of the affected upper extremity. A pulse deficit is not typically associated with this condition. 
❌ Thromboembolism of the left brachial artery:
Incorrect: An acute thromboembolism of the left brachial artery would result in signs of acute ischemia, including pain, paresthesias, pallor, poikilothermia, pulselessness, and paralysis. In contrast, this patient’s symptoms are only present with exertion and hence unlikely to be secondary to arterial thromboembolism. 
❌ Widened aortic outflow tract :
Incorrect: Thoracic aortic aneurysms are most often asymptomatic. When symptomatic, they typically present with acute onset chest pain.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man comes to the clinic complaining of right leg pain for three months. The pain is characterized by a continuous cramping in the right thigh that starts after walking two blocks and goes away at rest. The patient has a history of hypertension, diabetes, and coronary artery disease. The patient smokes 1 pack of cigarettes per day. The patient’s temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min and regular, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 155/95 mmHg. Physical exam shows decreased hair growth on the right thigh and calf compared to left. The skin on the right leg is dry and shiny. There is no swelling or tenderness. Pain does not occur with bending forwards or backwards at the waist. Which of the following muscles is directly supplied by the artery most likely involved in this patient’s disease?
questions.solution:
This patient with athersclerotic risk factors is presenting with intermittent claudication in the right thigh, making peripheral artery disease (PAD) the most likely diagnosis. Claudication is characterized by cramping pain in the affected area that comes about during exercise and is relieved with rest. Peripheral artery disease, a type of peripheral vascular disease (PVD), is caused by insufficient tissue perfusion due to narrowing or occlusion of the aorta or one of the more distal branches supplying the limbs. Similar to coronary artery and cerebrovascular disease, the development of an atherosclerotic plaque that narrows or completely occludes an artery is the number one cause of peripheral artery disease, and therefore these diseases often exist together. Risk factors for atherosclerosis, such as hypertension, diabetes mellitus, smoking and hyperlipidemia, raise the suspicion for peripheral artery disease.  

The location of a patient’s pain can indicate where the occlusion is:  



This patient’s thigh pain, without pain in the hips or buttocks, suggests there is an occlusion in the femoral artery. The femoral artery gives rise to the deep femoral artery (profunda femoris) which branches to form the lateral femoral circumflex artery. The lateral femoral circumflex artery supplies blood to the rectus femoris muscle, which functions to flex the thigh at the hip joint and extend the leg at the knee joint.    

In addition to claudication, chronic limb ischemia may produce physical changes. These include decreased skin temperature (termed poikilothermia), decreased hair and nail growth, and loss of sensation. On physical exam, the pulses distal to the obstruction are weak, and there is diminished capillary refill in the affected area.  

Option Analysis

❌ Gluteus maximus:
Incorrect: The gluteus maximus (main extensor of the hip) is supplied by the superior gluteal artery, a branch of the internal iliac artery. Occlusion of the internal iliac artery would cause pain in the buttocks and hips with exertion.  
✅ Rectus femoris:
Correct: See Main Explanation below.  
❌ Quadratus femoris:
Incorrect: The quadratus femoris (external rotator and adductor of the thigh) is supplied by the inferior gluteal artery, a branch of the internal iliac artery. Occlusion of the internal iliac artery would cause pain in the buttocks and hips with exertion.  
❌ Gastrocnemius:
Incorrect: The gastrocnemius (flexor of the foot and leg) is supplied by the popliteal artery. Occlusion of the popliteal artery would cause pain below the knee but not in the thigh.  
❌ Abductor hallucis  :
Incorrect: The abductor hallucis (abductor and flexor of the great toe) is supplied by the tibial artery. Occlusion of the tibial artery would cause pain in the lower calf, ankle, and foot but not in the thigh.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man comes to the office due to an acute onset of back pain. Two hours ago, he felt a sharp, middle-back pain while lifting a heavy box. The patient describes the pain as “shooting” and burning, 7/10 in severity, and radiating from the back to the right foot. He does not have any bowel or bladder symptoms. Vitals are within normal limits. On physical examination, knee jerk and Achilles reflexes are 2+ bilaterally. Straight leg raise is positive on the right side. Motor strength for dorsiflexion is 5/5 on the left compared to 3/5 on the right lower extremity. Which of the following nerve roots is most likely affected by this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with acute onset of low back pain after heavy lifting. The presence of pain radiating from the back to the foot and weakness in dorsiflexion is consistent with lumbosacral radiculopathy of L5 spinal nerve root.  

Radiculopathy refers to any disease process that affects the function of one or more lumbosacral nerve roots as they exit the spinal cord. Lumbosacral radiculopathy is often caused by nerve root compression due to disc herniation or spondylosis (degenerative changes). The compressed nerve carries both sensory and motor fibers. The specific sensory distribution of a single nerve root is termed dermatome, while the muscles served by a single spinal nerve root are termed myotome. Due to these features, a neurological exam that includes sensory, strength, and reflex evaluation can assist in the localization of the injury.  

It is important to note, however, that if an injury occurs to the peripheral nerves which are formed by integration of multiple nerve roots, the distribution will be according to the peripheral nerve innervation rather than myotomes and dermatomes. “Sciatica” is a non-specific term often applied to various conditions of low back pain with/without radiation to the leg regardless of the cause. The use of this term is often confusing and should be avoided when describing radiculopathy.  



Option Analysis

❌ L1:
Incorrect: Lumbar disc herniation at the L1 level is rare, and therefore L1 radiculopathy is unlikely. Injury to L1 will result in pain, paresthesia, and sensory loss along L1 dermatome in the inguinal region. Rarely, minor hip flexion weakness may be seen.
❌ L4:
Incorrect: Compression of the L4 nerve will likely present as knee extension weakness (quadriceps), hip flexion weakness (iliopsoas), and loss of the knee jerk reflex. In addition, sensory impairment along the L4 dermatome from the anterior thigh down to the medial aspect of the lower leg would be expected.
✅ L5:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ S1:
Incorrect: Compression of the S1 nerve root will result in weakness in plantar flexion (gastrocnemius), hip extension (gluteus maximus), and knee flexion (biceps femoris). Sensation will likely be reduced on the posterior leg and the lateral edge of the foot. Achilles reflex loss is typical.
❌ S2:
Incorrect: Compression of S2 will result in hip extension weakness (gluteus maximus), knee flexion weakness (hamstrings), and ankle plantarflexion weakness (gastrocnemius). Sensory impairment along the S2 dermatome from the posterior thigh down to the medial plantar arch would be expected.

questions.text:
A 3-year-old boy is brought to his pediatrician for evaluation of hearing loss. The patient's mother states, “He never comes when he is called; I am not even sure if he knows his name.” The patient was born full term via an uncomplicated vaginal delivery. Medical history is notable for an episode of croup when he was 6-months-old and a femoral fracture when he was 2-years-old, which occurred after the patient fell off a couch and landed on the floor. The patient’s father has a history of multiple fractures, some of which occurred after falling from standing height. Temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), blood pressure is 98/65 mmHg, and pulse is 70/min. Otoscopic evaluation is within normal limits. When a tuning fork is struck, the patient has an improved sense of hearing when the fork is placed against the mastoid process, when compared to directly over the ear. The patient's ocular examination is notable for the following finding:  


Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons    

This patient’s disease process reflects damage to which of the following anatomic structures?
questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation of hearing loss and has a history suspicious for osteogenesis imperfecta (OI), given his femoral fracture and blue sclera on physical examination. Patients with OI are at risk for developing hearing loss.  

Hearing loss is broadly categorized into conductive, sensorineural, and mixed hearing loss. Conductive hearing loss reflects any disease process that affects the transmission of sound from the outside world to the inner ear. Anatomic structures affected in conductive hearing loss include the auricle, external auditory canal, tympanic membrane, and ossicles. Common etiologies include cerumen impaction, tympanic membrane perforation, otosclerosis, otitis media/externa, and cholesteatomas.  

In contrast, sensorineural hearing loss reflects any disease process that affects the transmission of neuronal input to the central nervous via damage to the cochlea or auditory nerve. Common etiologies include presbycusis, noise-induced hearing loss, schwannomas, and Meniere disease. Other etiologies include ototoxic medications (e.g. aminoglycosides), congenital viral infections, congenital long QT syndrome, and Alport syndrome.   

Finally, some conditions such as osteogenesis imperfecta can present with mixed hearing loss, though patients tend to have predominantly one or the other. The conductive hearing loss in OI occurs due to malformation, dislocation, or fracture of the ossicles. The sensorineural hearing loss is hypothesized to occur secondary to cochlear hair cell atrophy or bone formation within the cochlea. The patient in this vignette has OI with predominantly conductive hearing loss, since the Rinne test demonstrates bone conduction greater than air conduction.  

Option Analysis

✅ Ossicles :
Correct: See Main Explanation 
❌ Auditory nerve :
Incorrect: Damage to the auditory nerve may occur through ischemia or mass effect from a malignancy or hematoma, which would result in sensorineural hearing loss. In contrast, this patient’s Rinne test demonstrates bone conduction greater than air conduction, which is more concerning for conductive hearing loss.
❌ Ear canal  :
Incorrect: Cerumen impaction, debris, malignancy, and congenital malformations can contribute to conductive hearing loss by impairing sound traveling through the external auditory canal. However, this patient’s history of a femoral fracture after a minor fall and presence of blue sclera on physical examination are concerning for osteogenesis imperfecta. Osteogenesis imperfecta can affect the middle ear bones and cochlea, but does not typically affect the ear canal.
❌ Tympanic membrane :
Incorrect: Damage to the tympanic membrane may occur through vascular malformations, direct trauma, barotrauma, or inner ear infections. This structure is not typically damaged in patients with osteogenesis imperfecta. 
❌ Cochlea :
Incorrect: The cochlea is an inner ear structure responsible for producing nerve impulses in response to sound vibrations. Atrophy of cochlear hair cells and formation of abnormal bone within the cochlear have been proposed as mechanisms to explain the sensorineural hearing loss experienced by patients with osteogenesis imperfecta. However, this patient’s Rinne test demonstrates bone conduction greater than air conduction, which is more concerning for conductive hearing loss.

questions.text: An 81-year-old right-handed woman is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of sudden onset weakness in the right upper and right lower extremity. The patient’s partner states she fell while walking to the kitchen and several minutes later noticed that the patient urinated on herself. The partner denies shaking of the limbs or head trauma. The patient denies confusion, loss of consciousness, or tongue biting. Her past medical history includes hypertension and hyperlipidemia for which she is taking lisinopril and atorvastatin. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 92/min, and blood pressure is 158/104 mmHg. The patient is alert and oriented. Physical examination reveals full visual fields with no defects. There is 4/5 strength in the right upper extremity and 2/5 strength in the right lower extremity. Finger-to-nose testing is normal and without dysdiadochokinesia. Which of the following vessels labeled  in the diagram below is most likely implicated in this patient’s clinical condition?
questions.solution:
This elderly patient presents with several cerebrovascular disease risk factors (e.g. hypertension, hyperlipidemia), right-sided hemiparesis predominantly affecting the lower extremity, and urinary incontinence. Given these findings, this patient likely suffered from a left anterior cerebral artery stroke.

The anterior cerebral artery (ACA) supplies the medial and dorsal aspect of the frontal and parietal lobes as well as the postcentral gyrus and precentral gyrus. Therefore, an anterior cerebral artery stroke predominantly affects the cortical homunculus for the feet and legs, causing contralateral paralysis and sensory loss. Additionally, a stroke of the ACA commonly compromises the medial frontal micturition center, causing activation of the pontine and spinal micturition centers, with subsequent urinary incontinence.

  

Option Analysis

❌ A:
Incorrect: This answer is the right anterior cerebral artery, which is unlikely to be the source of this patient’s right-sided hemiparesis. A stroke in this vessel would present with contralateral symptoms (e.g. left-sided hemiparesis).
✅ B:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ C:
Incorrect: This answer is the right internal carotid artery, which bifurcates into the major arteries of the brain, including the right anterior cerebral artery, right middle cerebral artery, and right posterior cerebral artery. A stroke of the ICA is rare and manifests with severe hemiplegia, sensory disturbance, and obtundation.
❌ D:
Incorrect: This answer is the left internal carotid artery, which bifurcates into the major arteries of the brain, including the left anterior cerebral artery, left middle cerebral artery, and left posterior cerebral artery. A stroke of the ICA is rare and manifests with severe hemiplegia, sensory disturbance, and obtundation.
❌ E:
Incorrect: This answer is the basilar artery, which supplies the pons. Patients with basilar artery stroke  develop hemiparesis or quadriparesis, facial palsies, dizziness, headache, and speech disturbance.

questions.text: An experiment is performed to determine the reactions of the eye to different environments. In the first part of the experiment, an individual is kept in a dark room for 2 hours. After 2 hours, the light in the room is turned on. Which of the following best describes the changes expected to be seen in this individual?

choices.text: Increased parasympathetic stimulation of the sphincter pupillae muscle, causing miosis
Increased sympathetic stimulation of the sphincter pupillae muscle, causing miosis
Increased parasympathetic stimulation of the dilator pupillae muscle, causing mydriasis
Increased sympathetic stimulation of the dilator pupillae muscle, causing mydriasis
Increased parasympathetic stimulation of the ciliary muscles, causing miosis

questions.solution:
In order for light to reach the retina, it has to pass through different structures including the cornea, aqueous humor, pupil, lens, and vitreous humor. The lens shape and pupil size can be modified to allow for better vision in different environments.   The pupil is an opening in the iris just in front of the lens. The pupil size changes to control the amount of light reaching the retina. This process is controlled by two muscles within the iris, the sphincter pupillae and dilator pupillae, which are controlled by the autonomic nervous system.



When transitioning from a darker to a brighter environment, the parasympathetic nervous system stimulates the sphincter pupillae muscle. This causes muscle contraction and decreased pupillary diameter to prevent excess light from reaching the retina. The result is called miosis.



In contrast, when transitioning from a brighter to a darker environment, the sympathetic nervous system stimulates the dilator pupillae muscle. This dilates the pupil, allowing more light to reach the retina. The result is called mydriasis.



The ciliary body is made of blood vessels and smooth muscles. The ciliary processes attach to the lens by the suspensory ligaments of the lens. The ciliary body controls the lens’s curvature via contraction and relaxation of the smooth muscles within the ciliary body.

When focusing on distant objects, sympathetic innervation causes the ciliary muscles to relax. This results in stretching of the lens’s suspensory ligaments, thereby thinning the lens and enabling the eye to focus on distant objects.

Option Analysis

✅ Increased parasympathetic stimulation of the sphincter pupillae muscle, causing miosis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Increased sympathetic stimulation of the sphincter pupillae muscle, causing miosis:
Incorrect: The sympathetic nervous system is responsible for dilation of the pupil by stimulating the dilator pupillae muscle. In contrast, the parasympathetic nervous system is responsible for constriction of the pupil by stimulating the sphincter pupillae muscle.
❌ Increased parasympathetic stimulation of the dilator pupillae muscle, causing mydriasis:
Incorrect: The sympathetic nervous system is responsible for dilation of the pupil (mydriasis) by stimulating the dilator pupillae muscle. However, when transitioning from a darker to brighter environment, the parasympathetic nervous system instead stimulates the sphincter pupillae muscle to constrict the pupil and prevent excessive light from reaching the retina.
❌ Increased sympathetic stimulation of the dilator pupillae muscle, causing mydriasis:
Incorrect: When transitioning from a brighter to darker environment, the sympathetic nervous system stimulates the dilator pupillae muscle to cause mydriasis. However, when transitioning from a darker to brighter environment, the parasympathetic nervous system stimulates the sphincter pupillae muscle to instead constrict the pupil and prevent excessive light from reaching the retina.
❌ Increased parasympathetic stimulation of the ciliary muscles, causing miosis:
Incorrect: Parasympathetic stimulation of the ciliary muscle does not control pupil size, but alters the shape of the lens.

questions.text: A 49-year-old man is evaluated at the office for gait disturbance. A social worker referred the patient due to frequent falls. Past medical history includes alcoholic fatty liver disease. The patient has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 20 years and drinks approximately 60 oz of alcohol every week. Vitals are within normal limits. The patient is cooperative and oriented to person, place, and time. Physical examination demonstrates mild gaze-evoked horizontal nystagmus. The patient has a wide-based gait. Tapping the patellar tendons elicits persistent, slow, back and forth swinging of the legs.  Finger-to-nose testing shows no abnormalities. Romberg sign is absent. Muscle strength is 5/5 in all extremities. Sensation is intact in the upper and lower extremities bilaterally. Standardized assessment of cognitive function shows no abnormalities. Which of the following additional features is likely to be observed in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with gait and truncal ataxia in the absence of cognitive impairment and a history of heavy alcohol use, suggestive of alcoholic cerebellar degeneration. This condition is typically seen in patients with a history of heavy, long-term (> 10 years) alcohol use and is caused by the degeneration of Purkinje cells of the cerebellar vermis.

The cerebellum is divided into two symmetric hemispheres connected via the vermis. The phylogenetically old archicerebellum consists of the flocculus, the nodulus (nodule of the vermis), and interconnections (flocculonodular system). Together, these structures coordinate equilibrium via connections with the vestibular system. The paleocerebellum consists of the anterior portions of the hemispheres and the anterior and posterior vermis to coordinate propulsive, stereotyped movements, such as walking. The remainder of the cerebellum, termed the neocerebellum, coordinates fine motor movements.

Patients with midline cerebellar lesions exhibit symptoms such as gait ataxia (especially on tandem gait), truncal ataxia, and gaze-evoked nystagmus. Postural incoordination (e.g., inability to tandem walk and abnormal heel-to-shin test) and a pendular knee reflex due to hypotonia is also seen in some patients. Patients may develop a postural tremor of fingers and thighs, dysarthria, and visual disturbance at later stages.  

Option Analysis

❌ Hearing loss  :
Incorrect: Disorders affecting the inner ear and vestibulocochlear nerve can present with hearing loss and gait instability. Common causes include trauma, infection, and Meniere disease. Alcoholic cerebellar degeneration, which is not associated with hearing loss, is a more likely etiology in this case.  
✅ Postural tremor  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Homonymous hemianopia  :
Incorrect: A unilateral visual pathway lesion beyond the optic chiasm can cause homonymous hemianopia. This is often observed with intracerebral hemorrhage affecting the basal ganglia and the occipital lobe.  
❌ Hemispatial neglect  :
Incorrect: Hemispatial neglect is observed with lesions of the brain's nondominant temporoparietal or posterior parietal areas.  
❌ Bradykinesia  :
Incorrect: Bradykinesia is a hallmark of Parkinson disease (PD). Other features of PD include resting tremor, rigidity, and postural instability. Deep-tendon reflexes are typically normal.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man comes to his primary care physician to evaluate right-sided vision changes over six months. The patient also has noted an increase in swelling in his right upper arm.  Past medical history is significant for myocardial infarction and hyperlipidemia. The patient has a 30 pack-year smoking history. He has a droopy right eyelid and intact extraocular eye movements on examination. Pupils are asymmetric in dim light – 2 mm on the right and 4 mm on the left, with both reactive to light. The pupils become more symmetric in bright light. The skin on the right half of his face appears cracked and dry. Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient’s right eye droop?

choices.text: Congenital abnormality of the levator muscle

questions.solution:
This patient presents with features consistent with Horner syndrome, likely due to a Pancoast tumor. The ptosis observed in Horner syndrome results from paralysis of the Müller muscle, innervated by the sympathetic pathway. Horner syndrome is characterized by ipsilateral:

  •  Partial ptosis (drooping of the upper eyelid): due to the sympathetic denervation of the Müller muscle (superior tarsal muscle). 
  •  Miosis (constriction of the pupil): due to the interruption of sympathetic fibers to the iris dilator muscles, which leads to uncontrolled parasympathetic influence (leading to anisocoria and dilation lag on the exam).
  • Anhidrosis (absence of sweating): due to impaired sympathetic innervation to facial sweat glands.
Horner syndrome can result from a lesion on the three-neuron sympathetic (adrenergic) pathway. Neurons for this pathway originate in the hypothalamus (first-order neurons). Their axons descend caudally to the first synapse located in the cervical spinal cord (levels C8-T2, also called the ciliospinal center of Budge). Second-order neurons exit the spinal cord through the anterior nerve roots and synapse with third-order neurons located at the superior cervical ganglion. Here, the oculosympathetic pathway travels along the carotid arteries to join target tissues in the face and eyes.

Causes of Horner syndrome based on anatomic lesions and associated anatomical pathways are summarized below:



Option Analysis

❌ Paralysis of the orbicularis oculi:
Incorrect: The orbicularis oculi functions to close the eyelids and wrinkle the forehead vertically. It can be paralyzed in facial nerve palsy and usually manifests as inferior eyelid eversion, inadequate corneal lubrication, an inability of the eyelid to close, and loss of corneal reflexes. Partial right-sided ptosis suggests an alternate etiology.
✅ Paralysis of Müller's muscle:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Complete third nerve palsy:
Incorrect: This patient’s extraocular eye movements are intact; therefore, a complete third nerve palsy is unlikely.
❌ Congenital abnormality of the levator muscle:
Incorrect: Congenital ptosis is often associated with absence or reduced function of the striated levator palpebrae superioris. This condition is typically unilateral, neurologically isolated, and nonprogressive. Lid creases are absent, and amblyopia and strabismus are often observed.
❌ Dehiscence of levator aponeurosis:
Incorrect: In adults, the most common cause of acquired ptosis is spontaneous disinsertion or dehiscence of the levator aponeurosis. Associated miosis and anhidrosis make this an unlikely cause of this patient’s presentation.

questions.text: A researcher is studying human spinal cord anatomy. She identifies a tract that helps relay sensations, including vibration, proprioception, and fine touch. Which of the following best characterizes the pathway taken by this tract?

choices.text: Location of Synapse Between First and Second-Order NeuronsSite of DecussationPosterior horn of spinal cordAnterior white commissure
Location of Synapse Between First and Second-Order NeuronsSite of DecussationNucleus gracilisMedulla oblongata
Location of Synapse Between First and Second-Order Neurons   Site of DecussationAnterior horn of spinal cord   Medulla oblongata
Location of Synapse Between First and Second-Order Neurons   Site of Decussation   Posterior horn of spinal cord   Superior cerebellar peduncle
Location of Synapse Between First and Second-Order Neurons   Site of Decussation   Nucleus gracilis   Superior cerebellar peduncle

questions.solution:
The dorsal column medial lemniscus (DCML) tract transmits sensations including vibration, proprioception, two-point discrimination, and soft touch to the brain. First-order neurons of the DCML tract enter the spinal cord via the dorsal root. Afterward, the neurons ascend via the ipsilateral dorsal columns, synapse with second-order neurons in the nucleus gracilis and cuneatus of the medulla, and then decussate (crossover) into the contralateral medulla. The second-order neurons synapse with the third-order neuron in the thalamus. The third-order neurons then travel to the cerebral cortex, where they synapse with fourth-order neurons.

Another important ascending pathway is the spinothalamic tract, which transmits sensations including crude touch, pain, pressure, and temperature to the brain. As with the DCML tract, first-order neurons in the spinothalamic tract enter the spinal cord via the dorsal root. The first-order neurons ascend ipsilaterally for 1-2 spinal segments, synapse with second-order neurons in the posterior horn of the spinal cord, and then decussate in the anterior white commissure. Afterward, the neurons ascend via the contralateral anterior or lateral spinal cord to reach the thalamus. As with the DCML tract, third-order neurons in the spinothalamic tract then travel to the cerebral cortex, where they synapse with fourth-order neurons.  



Option Analysis

❌ Location of Synapse Between First and Second-Order NeuronsSite of DecussationPosterior horn of spinal cordAnterior white commissure:
Incorrect: The first-order neuron in the spinothalamic tract synapses with the second-order neuron at the posterior horn of the spinal cord. Afterward, the second-order neuron decussates at the anterior white commissure and travels upwards towards the thalamus and sensory cortex. However, the spinothalamic tract transmits crude touch, pain, pressure, and temperature sensations.   
✅ Location of Synapse Between First and Second-Order NeuronsSite of DecussationNucleus gracilisMedulla oblongata:
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Location of Synapse Between First and Second-Order Neurons   Site of DecussationAnterior horn of spinal cord   Medulla oblongata  :
Incorrect: This answer choice describes the corticospinal tract, which is a descending tract that helps regulate voluntary movements of the trunk and extremities. It is not involved in relaying sensory information to the brain.   
❌ Location of Synapse Between First and Second-Order Neurons   Site of Decussation   Posterior horn of spinal cord   Superior cerebellar peduncle  :
Incorrect: The first-order neuron in the spinocerebellar tract synapses with the second-order neuron in the posterior horn of the spinal cord. Afterward, the neurons either decussate immediately and become part of the ventral spinocerebellar tract (which later decussates again in the superior cerebellar peduncle) or ascend ipsilaterally as the dorsal spinocerebellar tract. However, the spinocerebellar tract transmits unconscious proprioceptive information and is not involved in relaying sensations of vibration or touch.   
❌ Location of Synapse Between First and Second-Order Neurons   Site of Decussation   Nucleus gracilis   Superior cerebellar peduncle  :
Incorrect: The dorsal column medial lemniscus (DCML) tract is responsible for relaying sensations including vibration, proprioception, and soft touch to the brain. While the synapse between the first-order and second-order neurons of the DCML tract is within the nucleus gracilis and cuneatus, decussation occurs at the medulla (as opposed to the superior cerebellar peduncle).

questions.text: A 68-year-old right-handed man is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of right-sided weakness and numbness. The patient woke up with right hand clumsiness that rapidly progressed to right-sided weakness, affecting the right arm more than the right leg. Past medical history includes hypertension, atrial fibrillation, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. The patient has a 20-pack/year smoking history. Temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 138/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 146/86 mm Hg. The patient speaks clearly, but his sentences are incomprehensible. Neurological examination demonstrates impaired two-point discrimination to light touch in the right arm, right facial weakness sparing the forehead, 2/5 muscle strength in the right upper extremity, and 4/5 muscle strength in the right lower extremity. Left-sided strength is preserved, and visual fields are within normal limits. The etiology of this patient's symptoms likely occurred secondary to ischemia of an artery supplying which of the following anatomic regions?
questions.solution:
This patient likely suffered an ischemic stroke involving the territory supplied by the middle cerebral artery (MCA).
