The MCA supplies the bulk of the lateral surface of the hemisphere, where the superior division supplies lateral inferior frontal lobe, inferior division supplies lateral temporal lobe, and the deep branches supply the basal ganglia as well as the internal capsule.  

Patients with an MCA stroke typically present with contralateral hemiparesis and hemisensory loss involving the face and upper limb due to infarction of corresponding motor and sensory cortices. The contralateral lower limb is less affected given the distribution of the sensory-motor homunculus (lower limb supplied by the anterior cerebral artery). If the stroke involves the dominant (usually left) hemisphere, the speech centers of the brain are often implicated as well, resulting in expressive or receptive aphasia due to infarction of the Broca and Wernicke areas, respectively.  

Other features of MCA stroke include spatial neglect of the contralateral side due to damage to the non-dominant parietal lobe and contralateral homonymous quadrantanopia due to damage to the optic radiations in the subcortical temporoparietal lobe.  

Option Analysis

❌ Cingulate gyrus:
Incorrect: The cingulate gyrus is supplied via the anterior cerebral artery. Infarction of the cingulate gyrus would present with motor and sensory deficits of the contralateral lower extremity only. 
❌ Globus pallidus:
Incorrect: The globus pallidus is supplied by the lenticulostriate artery; however, a lacunar infarct of this artery presents with contralateral weakness and sensory loss in the upper and lower extremities. This patient has relative preservation of the lower extremity motor and sensory innervation, in addition to speech impairment and facial weakness. 
❌ Lateral medulla:
Incorrect: The lateral medulla is supplied by the posterior inferior cerebellar artery; however, a stroke of this artery would present with impaired sensation of the ipsilateral face and contralateral body. 
❌ Lingual gyrus:
Incorrect: The lingual gyrus is supplied by the posterior cerebral artery; however, a stroke of this artery would present with visual defects such as hemianopsia. 
✅ Temporal gyrus:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of severe abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. A few hours ago, he was playing basketball with his friends when he first developed mild abdominal pain. The pain increased gradually, and since then, the patient had increasing nausea and three episodes of vomiting. The patient has had similar, milder episodes in the past that resolved with rest. The review of systems is otherwise unremarkable. Past medical history is noncontributory. He is sexually active and uses condoms consistently. Temperature is 37.7°C (99.9°F), pulse is 95/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 100/60 mmHg. Physical examination shows a soft, nontender, and nondistended abdomen. There is marked swelling, erythema, and tenderness of the right hemiscrotum. The pain is worsened when the right testis is elevated, and the scrotum does not transilluminate. Cremasteric reflex is absent on the right side. Physical examination of the left hemiscrotum and testis is unremarkable. Urinalysis is unremarkable. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient has acute-onset severe abdominal pain associated with nausea and vomiting, in combination with diffuse right scrotal swelling, erythema, tenderness, a negative Prehn sign (pain that does not resolve with the elevation of testicles), and an absent cremasteric reflex; this presentation is consistent with testicular torsion, which occurs as a result of the twisting of the spermatic cord.

Testicular torsion is one of the most common causes of acute scrotal pain in infants and post pubertal individuals. It occurs due to the insufficient fixation of the testis to the tunica vaginalis, leading to hypermobility, which allows for the twisting of the testis around the spermatic cord, cutting off its blood supply. Testicular torsion may occur after an inciting event (e.g., trauma, vigorous physical activity) or spontaneously.

Testicular torsion typically presents as an acute onset of scrotal pain with a negative Prehn sign. Some patients may present with diffuse lower abdominal pain associated with nausea and vomiting. Physical examination shows a tender, enlarged, high-riding testes with its long axis oriented transversely instead of longitudinally due to the shortening of the spermatic cord (“bell clapper deformity”). Cremasteric reflex is typically absent.





Diagnosis is based on physical examination and doppler ultrasound for confirmation. Treatment includes surgical correction (orchiopexy) or manual detorsion if the surgery is not possible. Delay in detorsion by a few hours may lead to testicular nonviability and infertility. If the testis is not viable, orchiectomy should be performed.

Option Analysis

✅ Twisting of the spermatic cord:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Dilation of the pampiniform plexus:
Incorrect: Dilation of the pampiniform plexus results in a varicocele. It is more common on the left side, presents with dull abdominal pain that gets worse with standing, and feels like “a bag of worms” on physical examination. Cremasteric reflex is normal in cases of varicocele.
❌ Bacterial infiltration of the epididymis:
Incorrect: Acute epididymitis can result from the bacterial infiltration of the epididymis. It is characterized by localized testicular pain with tenderness and swelling on palpation of the affected epididymis (posterior testis). The pain is usually relieved by the elevation of testes (positive Prehn sign), unlike this patient. Dysuria and/or urethral discharge can also be present.
❌ Twisting of the appendix testis:
Incorrect: Testicular appendage torsion can present with acute onset testicular/abdominal pain. The swelling and tenderness, however, is localized to the head of the affected testes (unlike diffuse tenderness/swelling). Cremasteric reflex is typically present. A “blue dot” sign is often visible on physical examination, and the scrotal skin and testicles are usually normal-appearing and minimally tender.
❌ Patent processus vaginalis:
Incorrect: A hydrocele can result from an accumulation of fluid between the layers of tunica vaginalis due to a  persistently patent processus vaginalis. Although scrotal swelling is apparent on the affected side, it does not cause acute severe testicular pain, and it transilluminates well.

questions.text:
A 70-year-old man is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of headache, nausea, and vomiting for the past 24 hours. His partner states he has been more irritable and has had trouble remembering to do routine errands. Two weeks ago, the patient fell while skiing but did not seek medical evaluation. Past medical history is significant for coronary artery disease and hypertension. Current medications include atenolol, enalapril, furosemide, atorvastatin, and aspirin. The patient has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 99/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 160/90 mm Hg. The patient is ill-appearing. He is oriented to person, but not to place or time. During the examination, the patient is unable to answer questions or follow commands. Deep tendon reflexes are 4+ on the right and 2+ on the left. Babinski sign is present on the right. There is 4/5 weakness of the right hip flexors. The patient’s non-contrast head CT is demonstrated below.

Reproduced from Radiopedia

Disruption of which of the following structures is the most likely cause of this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation of headache, nausea, and vomiting following trauma, along with head CT demonstrating a crescent-shaped lesion, is consistent with a diagnosis of subdural hematoma (SDH). The skiing accident likely induced shearing of the bridging cortical veins, with subsequent hematoma formation.    

Rupture of bridging cortical veins results in hemorrhage between the arachnoid mater and dura mater. Common causes include blunt head trauma (e.g. high-energy impact due to motor vehicle accidents), acceleration-deceleration injury, and cerebral atrophy (in older adults). Symptoms of SDH usually develop gradually 1-2 days after the initial injury and include impaired consciousness, confusion, or symptoms of elevated intracranial pressure (e.g., headache, nausea/vomiting). Patients may also develop focal neurological deficits (e.g. contralateral hemiparesis). Non-contrast CT scan will demonstrate a crescent-shaped hypodensity that crosses cranial suture lines.   

The difference between subdural, epidural, and subarachnoid hemorrhage is summarized below:



Option Analysis

✅ Cortical bridging veins :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Berry aneurysm:
Incorrect: Rupture of a berry aneurysm can result in subarachnoid hemorrhage; however, this patient’s CT demonstrates a subdural hemorrhage.  
❌ Posterior communicating artery:
Incorrect: Rupture of the posterior communicating artery can result in a subarachnoid hemorrhage, which usually manifests as a severe headache, often described as the “worst headache of my life.” This patient’s CT instead demonstrates a subdural hemorrhage.  
❌ Middle meningeal artery:
Incorrect: Fracture at the pterion can result in an epidural hematoma due to hemorrhage from the underlying middle meningeal artery. An epidural hematoma is diagnosed with a non-contrast CT scan demonstrating a biconvex, hyperdense mass confined to the suture lines between the dura mater and the skull. 
❌ Lateral striate artery:
Incorrect: The lateral striate arteries arise from the middle cerebral arteries (also known as lenticulostriate arteries). These vessels supply the internal capsule and basal ganglia. This patient’s CT instead demonstrates a subdural hemorrhage.

questions.text: A 75-year-old right-handed woman is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of right-sided weakness. Past medical history is significant for hypertension and diabetes, for which the patient takes amlodipine, chlorthalidone, and insulin. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 95/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 180/99 mmHg. On examination, right upper and lower extremity motor strength is 1/5. The patient has difficulty answering questions and appears to be frustrated by this inability to communicate. The patient is able to speak a few words, but the speech is non-fluent. She is able to comprehend 2-step instructions but is unable to repeat phrases. Which of the following best describes the type of aphasia observed in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with difficulty answering questions and frustration driven by their inability to communicate (expressive aphasia). The patient is able to speak a few words, but speech is non-fluent. The patient is able to comprehend 2-step instructions; however, they are unable to repeat phrases, making Broca aphasia the most likely cause of the language impairment.  

Broca’s area is located in the inferior frontal gyrus of the dominant hemisphere. Efferent pathways from Broca’s area connect to the muscles of the larynx, mouth, tongue, soft palate, and respiratory muscles to formulate speech. Broca aphasia most commonly results from an ischemic stroke secondary to anterior MCA branch occlusion. Other etiologies include trauma, tumors, and neurodegenerative disease. Typical clinical features include non-fluent, sparse speech as well as agrammatism, intact comprehension, and impaired repetition. Hemiparesis (as in this patient) and oral apraxia may occur due to ischemia sustained to the adjacent motor and supplementary areas.  



Option Analysis

❌ Transcortical sensory aphasia:
Incorrect: Transcortical sensory aphasia results from insults to the inferior temporal lobe of the dominant hemisphere. Clinical presentation includes fluent speech with intact ability to repeat but poor comprehension.  
❌ Global aphasia:
Incorrect: Global aphasia results from damage to the arcuate fasciculus, Broca’s area, and Wernicke’s area. Clinical presentation includes non-fluent speech, poor comprehension, and impaired repetition.
❌ Conduction aphasia:
Incorrect: Conduction aphasia results from a lesion involving the arcuate fasciculus. The arcuate fasciculus is the bundle of nerve fibers between Broca’s and Wernicke’s area. Clinical presentation includes fluent speech and preserved comprehension with impaired repetition. Speech often contains frequent phonemic errors.
❌ Wernicke aphasia:
Incorrect: Wernicke’s area is involved in processing and understanding of written and spoken language. It is supplied by the posterior MCA branch and located within the superior temporal gyrus of the dominant hemisphere. Damage to Wernicke’s area manifests with fluent speech and poor comprehension with impaired repetition. Speech sounds voluminous but without meaning, and the patient often appears unaware of the deficit. A right superior visual field defect may be present as well.
✅ Broca aphasia:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of a generalized tonic-clonic seizure that lasted 30 seconds. The patient’s partner endorses increased difficulty with ambulation for the past several days. The patient had two instances where they lost control of their bladder without seizing. The patient does not take any medications. Vitals are within normal limits. The patient appears confused but is arousable. Neurological examination is significant for motor strength of 1/5 in the lower extremities bilaterally. Motor strength in the upper extremities is 5/5. MRI of the brain is shown below. Compression of which of the following areas is the most likely cause of this patient’s symptoms?  


Reproduced from: Radiopaedia.org

choices.text: Medial aspect of the precentral gyrus (paracentral lobule)
Inferior frontal gyrus of the dominant hemisphere

questions.solution:
This patient presents with radiologic findings of a space-occupying lesion consistent with a parasagittal meningioma. In addition, there is evidence of urinary incontinence, seizures, and bilateral lower extremity weakness, which can be due to compression of the medial aspect of the precentral gyrus (paracentral lobule).   

The paracentral lobule is an area of the brain located on the medial surface of the cerebral hemispheres that lies in close proximity to the falx cerebri and surrounds the indentation produced by the central sulcus. Functionally, it is involved in cerebral control of both urination and defecation. It also houses motor and sensory innervation of the contralateral lower extremities. Thus a space-occupying lesion of this area (e.g. parasagittal meningioma) can cause urinary incontinence, seizures, and bilateral lower extremity weakness.    

The paracentral lobule is supplied by the branches of the anterior cerebral artery, so occlusion of the ACA results in hemiparesis and hemisensory loss in the contralateral lower extremity and urinary incontinence. Corresponding ischemic involvement of the anterior frontal and parietal lobes results in apathy, inability to accurately identify objects, and personality changes.    



Option Analysis

✅ Medial aspect of the precentral gyrus (paracentral lobule):
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Inferior frontal gyrus of the dominant hemisphere:
Incorrect: Damage to Broca’s area manifests with non-fluent speech with intact comprehension and impaired repetition. Bladder incontinence is not typical for a lesion in this area.
❌ Premotor cortex:
Incorrect: The premotor cortex stores and processes information regarding past activity as well as integration of sensory and motor information for planning of future voluntary movements. A lesion of the premotor cortex would not explain this patient’s presentation with lower extremity weakness, urinary incontinence, and seizure.
❌ Prefrontal cortex:
Incorrect: The prefrontal cortex is responsible for executive functions, such as decision making, judgment, and reasoning; it also regulates depth of feeling. Damage to the prefrontal cortex leads to disinhibition and deficits in concentration, judgment, and orientation. Early behavioral changes include socially inappropriate behavior, apathy, and compulsive behavior.
❌ Arcuate fasciculus:
Incorrect: The arcuate fasciculus is a bundle of nerve fibers between Broca’s and Wernicke’s area. Conduction aphasia results from injury or a lesion involving the arcuate fasciculus. Clinical presentation includes fluent speech and preserved comprehension with impaired repetition. Speech contains frequent phonemic errors.

questions.text: A 57-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician to evaluate bilateral wrist discomfort. The patient has had worsening pain and numbness over the first, second, and third digits and half of the fourth digit. She recently started working as a secretary and spends most of the day typing on a keyboard. She is currently undergoing treatment for breast cancer with anastrozole. The patient’s other medical problems include obesity, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and hyperthyroidism. She smokes half a pack of cigarettes daily and drinks one to two glasses of wine nightly. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination is notable for reproducible pain and paresthesias with a tapping of the volar aspect of the wrist. Which of the following factors most likely contributed to the development of this patient’s clinical condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with pain and paresthesias in the distribution of the median nerve and a positive Tinel test. These findings are consistent with carpal tunnel syndrome. Aromatase inhibitors have been shown to increase tendon thickness, which is thought to contribute to the development of median nerve entrapment.

Carpal tunnel syndrome is a multifactorial disease that primarily results from increased pressure in the intercarpal canal and associated compression of the median nerve. Median nerve compression manifests clinically with pain and paresthesias in the first three digits of the hand and half of the fourth digit. Pain and paresthesias are then often reproduced with movements that flex or extend the wrist.

Additional risk factors include obesity, female sex, diabetes, rheumatoid arthritis, and hypothyroidism. Workplace factors are also thought to contribute, with duties requiring repetitive hand and wrist use contributing to disease development.

Treatment is primarily conservative, with physical therapy and wrist splinting as mainstays of treatment, while surgery is reserved for advanced disease or cases refractory to conservative measures.

Option Analysis

✅ Aromatase-inhibitor use  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Hypertension:
Incorrect: Hypertension is not a known risk factor for the development of carpal tunnel syndrome.  
❌ Smoking  :
Incorrect: Smoking is not a known risk factor for the development of carpal tunnel syndrome.  
❌ Hyperlipidemia:
Incorrect: Hyperlipidemia may contribute to obesity, a known risk factor for carpal tunnel syndrome. However, the patient’s use of aromatase-inhibitors is a more significant and direct risk factor for the development of carpal tunnel syndrome.  
❌ Hyperthyroidism:
Incorrect: Hypothyroidism, not hyperthyroidism, is a risk factor for the development of carpal tunnel syndrome.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman presents to the physician to evaluate right shoulder weakness, which has been ongoing for three months. The symptom has limited her daily activities, such as brushing her hair. Vital signs are within normal limits. The patient has weakness abducting the right shoulder above 90 degrees on physical examination. In addition, there is atrophy of the right trapezius muscle. The findings are concerning for a nerve injury. Through which of the following mechanisms did this nerve injury likely occur?

choices.text: Lymph node biopsy in the posterior cervical triangle.
Thyroidectomy with superior thyroid artery dissection
Thyroidectomy with inferior thyroid artery dissection

questions.solution:
The spinal accessory nerve, or cranial nerve XI, consists of a spinal portion originating from the ventral horns of the upper four cervical segments of the spinal cord which is then joined by accessory components that arise from the nucleus accumbens of the medulla oblongata.  

These two components form the eleventh cranial nerve, and together, they exit the skull through the jugular foramen. The spinal accessory nerve then courses below the posterior belly of the digastric and upper end of the sternocleidomastoid muscle (SCM). It emerges from the posterior border of the SCM and crosses the posterior triangle before entering the trapezius. Recall, the posterior triangle of the neck is bounded inferiorly by the middle one-third of the clavicle, anteriorly by the posterior border of the sternocleidomastoid, and posteriorly by the anterior border of the trapezius.  

Cranial nerve XI is particularly susceptible to injury as it courses through the posterior triangle of the neck. Injury is most commonly caused by iatrogenic etiologies (e.g., lymph node biopsy, neck dissection) but can also be caused by trauma or tumors.  

Injury to the spinal accessory nerve can lead to paralysis of both the trapezius and sternocleidomastoid muscles. Clinical symptoms include shoulder pain, limited abduction of the shoulder beyond 90 degrees, and shoulder drop. These symptoms may impact an individual’s ability to complete daily tasks, such as combing one’s hair.  



Option Analysis

✅ Lymph node biopsy in the posterior cervical triangle. :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Thyroidectomy with superior thyroid artery dissection :
Incorrect: The external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve can be injured during thyroidectomies due to its proximity with the superior thyroid artery. Patients with this nerve injury may notice changes in voice quality but would not typically experience difficulty abducting the shoulder.   
❌ Thyroidectomy with inferior thyroid artery dissection :
Incorrect: The recurrent laryngeal nerve is susceptible to injury during dissection of the inferior thyroid artery. Patients with recurrent laryngeal nerve injury may experience hoarseness of the voice but not difficulty abducting the shoulder. 
❌ Left atrial enlargement:
Incorrect: Left atrial enlargement can compress the recurrent laryngeal nerve, not the spinal accessory nerve. 
❌ Medial medullary syndrome :
Incorrect: Medial medullary syndrome is caused by occlusion of the medullary branch of the vertebral artery. It results in a lower motor neuron hypoglossal nerve injury in addition to contralateral hemiparesis and contralateral loss of proprioception and tactile discrimination.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy is brought to an urgent care facility due to ongoing epistaxis. The patient endorses experiencing facial trauma while playing basketball. His parent states that she has been applying pressure and pinching his nose for the past 30 minutes. Past medical history is noncontributory. The patient’s temperature is 97.7°F (36.5°C), blood pressure is 110/65 mmHg, pulse is 85/min, respirations are 17/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Physical examination reveals moderate volumes of blood and multiple clots from the nostrils. Which of the following blood vessels is most likely involved in this patient’s bleeding?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with epistaxis from the nostrils after experiencing facial trauma. He most likely has anterior epistaxis.   

Epistaxis can be divided into two categories: anterior epistaxis and posterior epistaxis. Anterior epistaxis makes up the majority of cases and usually causes mild to moderate bleeding. It originates from a region of the anterior nasal septum called the Kiesselbach plexus, formed via the anastomoses of the anterior ethmoidal, sphenopalatine, greater palatine, and superior labial artery. Anterior epistaxis can usually be managed by pinching the nasal alae together for at least 10 minutes while sitting upright. Vasoconstrictors (e.g. phenylephrine) and electrocautery may be needed in rare cases.    

Posterior epistaxis makes up around 10% of cases, typically presents in elderly patients and those with a history of hypertension, and manifests with more severe bleeding. It arises from bleeding from the Woodruff plexus, a vascular network formed by anastomoses between the sphenopalatine and posterior pharyngeal arteries. Treatment may involve electrocautery, nasal balloons, and posterior nasal packing. Sometimes, the internal maxillary artery and its branches must be ligated to control the bleeding. 

Option Analysis

❌ Posterior pharyngeal artery:
Incorrect: The posterior pharyngeal artery is a branch of the external carotid artery. It anastomoses with the sphenopalatine artery to form the Woodruff plexus, which is involved in posterior epistaxis. This patient more likely has anterior epistaxis. 
❌ Woodruff plexus:
Incorrect: The Woodruff plexus is a vascular network formed by the anastomosis of the sphenopalatine artery and posterior pharyngeal artery. It is responsible for the posterior epistaxis. However, this patient’s young age and relatively mild bleeding from the nostrils are more consistent with anterior epistaxis. 
❌ Ophthalmic artery:
Incorrect: The ophthalmic artery is a branch of the internal carotid artery. It gives rise to the anterior and posterior ethmoidal arteries. While downstream branches of the ophthalmic artery (e.g. anterior ethmoid artery) contribute to epistaxis, the ophthalmic artery itself plays no direct role in the condition.  
✅ Kiesselbach plexus:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Internal carotid artery:
Incorrect: The internal carotid artery is a branch of the common carotid artery. While some smaller downstream arteries contribute to epistaxis, the internal carotid artery itself plays no direct role in developing this patient’s condition.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man is brought to the emergency department for evaluation following a motor vehicle accident. Upon arrival the patient has a Glasgow coma scale of 9. His temperature is 36.1°C (97°F), pulse is 114/min, and blood pressure is 78/48 mmHg. Chest x-ray demonstrates several fractured ribs bilaterally, and a CT brain is without signs of bleeding or hemorrhage. The patient is resuscitated with administration of type O negative blood and norepinephrine; however, he remains persistently hypotensive with a repeat systolic blood pressure of 49/25 mmHg. Which of the following anatomic structures is most susceptible to injury given this patient’s clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
Global ischemic-hypoxic brain injury can occur in the setting of profound hypotension, hypoxia, or a combination of both. In the setting of hypotension, ischemia to the brain is typically observed when systolic pressures fall below 50 mm Hg, such as in cardiac arrest or refractory shock. Patient outcomes vary directly with both the severity and duration of the hypotensive event. The most susceptible locations of ischemic injury to the brain are those with poor collateral circulation and include the following:

  •  Pyramidal cells of the hippocampus  
  •  Pyramidal cells of the neocortex 
  •  Purkinje cells of the cerebellum 

Option Analysis

❌ Posterior pituitary:
Incorrect: The pituitary gland is not as susceptible to ischemia when compared with the hippocampus;  however, in the setting of a  pituitary adenoma, apoplexy can occur, which results in massive hemorrhage of the organ.
✅ Hippocampus:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Pons:
Incorrect: The pons is not as susceptible to ischemia as the hippocampus due to collateral blood supply from the anterior and posterior spinal cord. 
❌ Anterior pituitary :
Incorrect: The pituitary gland is rarely affected by ischemia, given its central location and collateral vascular supply.
❌ Hypothalamus:
Incorrect: Like the anterior pituitary, the hypothalamus is rarely affected by ischemia given its central location and collateral vascular supply.

questions.text: A 68-year-old right-handed man is brought to the emergency department following sudden onset weakness in his right arm and dysarthria. The patient’s partner states, “He suddenly dropped his cup of coffee while walking to the kitchen table and was unable to respond to me, so I called 911.” Past medical history includes hypertension and hyperlipidemia for which he takes lisinopril and atorvastatin, respectively. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 92/min, and blood pressure is 158/104 mmHg. The patient is alert but appears frustrated by not being able to speak. The patient blinks on command. Physical examination demonstrates full visual fields without deficits. Neurologic evaluation demonstrates 2/5 strength in the right upper extremity and 4/5 strength in the right lower extremity. Pathology to which of the following anatomic structures is the most likely etiology of this patient’s clinical condition?
questions.solution:
A middle cerebral artery stroke affects the cortical homunculus for the hands, arms, and face, causing contralateral upper extremity weakness and sensory loss. In addition, symptoms vary depending on which hemisphere (dominant vs. non-dominant) is involved:

  •  The dominant hemisphere, which is usually the left hemisphere in right-handed individuals, contains the language centers: the Broca and Wernicke areas. If the Broca area is implicated, expressive aphasia may ensue--meaning patients are unable to articulate responses. If the Wernicke area becomes implicated, receptive aphasia may ensue--meaning patients lose the ability to comprehend language. 
  •  If the non-dominant hemisphere is affected, which is typically the right side, patients may develop hemineglect--wherein the patients are unaware of one side of his/her body. 

 

Option Analysis

❌ Left anterior cerebral artery:
Incorrect: A left anterior cerebral artery stroke can also cause right-sided weakness; however, the weakness predominantly affects the lower limb. Additionally, this patient’s difficulty speaking suggests a stroke in a different vessel.
✅ Left middle cerebral artery:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Left posterior cerebral artery:
Incorrect: A left posterior cerebral artery stroke causes right hemianopsia, which is absent in this patient.
❌ Right anterior cerebral artery:
Incorrect: A right anterior cerebral artery stroke causes left-sided weakness predominantly affecting the lower limb.
❌ Right middle cerebral artery:
Incorrect: A right middle cerebral artery stroke would cause left-sided weakness, not right sided weakness.
❌ Right posterior cerebral artery:
Incorrect: A right posterior cerebral artery stroke results in left hemianopsia, which is absent in this patient.

questions.text: A 71-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of sudden-onset ataxia and facial weakness. Her partner states they were eating dinner when the patient suddenly lost her ability to chew her food. The patient indicates associated numbness to the right side of her face. The patient's medical history includes uncontrolled hypertension as well as a 35-pack-year smoking history. Vital signs are within normal limits. The right pupil is constricted with associated drooping of the right eyelid. There are no visual deficits, nystagmus, or extraocular muscle weakness. The jaw is deviated to the right. There is a diminished sensation to pinprick over the right side of the face. Which of the following anatomic locations is most likely implicated given this patient’s clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with sudden-onset facial paralysis and numbness, suggestive of a stroke, particularly of the brainstem given the associated cranial nerve deficits. A stroke that affects the perforating branches of the basilar and anterior inferior cerebellar arteries (AICA) leads to lateral pontine syndrome, in which the following structures are affected:

  •  Trigeminal nuclei and nerve root 
    •  Complete ipsilateral trigeminal paralysis, manifesting in: 
      •  Paralysis of the muscles of mastication 
      •  Jaw deviation to the paretic side (due to unopposed action of the intact lateral pterygoid) 
      •  Facial hemianesthesia (loss of pain, temperature, touch, and proprioception) 
      •  Loss of the corneal reflex (afferent limb of CN V1) 
  •  Middle cerebellar peduncle 
    •  Ipsilateral limb and gait ataxia

Option Analysis

❌ Medial medulla:
Incorrect: Medial medullary syndrome results in contralateral hemiparesis of the trunk and extremities, contralateral loss of proprioception, tactile sensation, and vibratory sensation, as well as ipsilateral flaccid paralysis of the tongue.
❌ Medial pons:
Incorrect: Medial pontine syndrome, also known as Foville syndrome, results in contralateral hemiplegia (with facial sparing) due to corticospinal tract involvement, ipsilateral peripheral-type facial palsy, and inability to move the eyes conjugately to the ipsilateral side.
❌ Lateral medulla:
Incorrect: Lateral medullary syndrome, also known as Wallenberg syndrome, occurs with infarction of the lateral medulla. Clinically, this syndrome is characterized by dysphagia, hoarseness and decreased gag reflex, vertigo and nystagmus, ipsilateral decreased sensation of pain and temperature of the face,  along with contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation from the trunk and extremities.
✅ Lateral pons:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Medial midbrain:
Incorrect: Ischemia of the medial midbrain, also known as Weber syndrome, results from occlusion of midbrain branches of the posterior cerebral artery. Patients typically present with oculomotor nerve deficits, contralateral weakness of the lower face (CN VII), tongue (CN XII) and palate (CN X), along with contralateral hemiparesis of the trunk and limbs.

questions.text:
A 58-year-old hospitalized man is currently hospitalized for repair of an abdominal aortic aneurysm. He successfully underwent surgery for the repair yesterday, but today he was noted to have decreased urine output during rounds. Past medical history includes type II diabetes mellitus and coronary artery disease. He received a prophylactic antibiotic prior to the procedure. The patient has been receiving 100ml/hour of normal saline since the surgery. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 93/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 115/75 mmHg. Physical examination shows non-erythematous wound with scant serous discharge and a soft abdomen. Urine output over the past six hours is measured at 90mL. Laboratory results from this patient’s hospitalization are demonstrated below.

 
 Laboratory value  Result 
 Serum chemistry 
  Day 1  Day 2 
 Sodium  135 mEq/L  132 mEq/L 
 Potassium  4.1 mEq/L  4.0 mEq/L 
 Chloride  98 mEq/L  97 mEq/L 
 Bicarbonate  25 mEq/L  23 mEq/L 
 Blood urea nitrogen (BUN)  16 mg/dL  36 mg/dL 
 Creatinine  1.1 mg/dL  2.3 mg/dL 
   
Urine sediment microscopy is shown.


Reproduced from: Wikipedia

Which of the following anatomic regions of the nephron was most likely affected given this patient's clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with oliguria, a recent high risk surgery, and urine microscopy findings of granular casts--consistent with acute tubular necrosis (ATN).  

ATN reflects one of the most common histologic diagnoses of intrarenal acute kidney injury (AKI). This condition may arise from ischemic injury or nephrotoxic agents such as lead, ethylene glycol or myoglobinuria. Ischemic injury predominantly affects the structures found within the renal medulla due to its relatively poor blood supply. In addition, metabolically active segments of nephron are particularly vulnerable (e.g. terminal portion of proximal tubule and thick ascending limb of loop of Henle) due to their continuous need for ATP production. Several comorbidities increase the risk for ischemic ATN including diabetes mellitus, atherosclerosis and chronic kidney disease.   

Ischemic ATN typically presents primarily with oliguria. Laboratory findings demonstrate increased creatinine from baseline and a BUN/creatinine ratio <20. Urinalysis and microscopy show granular “muddy brown” casts, reflecting sloughed tubular cells, which are pathognomonic for ATN. Histologically, it is characterized by loss of tubular epithelial cells’ nuclei, tubular dilation and epithelial cell vacuolization. 

Option Analysis

❌ Afferent arteriole:
Incorrect: Afferent arterioles provide blood flow to glomeruli. Although constriction of renal arterioles can increase the risk of prerenal AKI, these are not typically damaged via ischemic injury. 
❌ Glomerulus:
Incorrect: Glomeruli are generally less susceptible to ischemic damage due to their adequate blood supply from afferent arterioles and low oxygen demand. 
❌ Collecting duct:
Incorrect: Collecting ducts have less metabolic activity than the proximal tubule. As a result, they have more resilience to ischemic damage. 
❌ Distal tubule:
Incorrect: Distal tubules have less metabolic activity than the proximal tubule.  As a result, they have more resilience to ischemic damage. 
✅ Proximal tubule:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 41-year-old man comes to his primary care physician’s office for evaluation of pain during sexual intercourse. Over the past several months, the patient has noticed worsening curvature to his penis and associated pain with erections. He does not have any history of trauma to the groin. The patient is a construction foreman and regularly works with large machinery. His past medical history includes a Dupuytren contracture treated with physical therapy. Physical examination demonstrates a curvature of the penis with a palpable nodule on the dorsal surface. Based on the anatomic image below, which of the following areas of the penis is contributing to this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with worsening abnormal curvature of the penis with associated erectile dysfunction. In conjunction with his history of Dupuytren contracture, he is likely suffering from Peyronie disease (PD). The pathophysiology of PD is not fully understood; however, it is thought to be initiated by microtrauma followed by local inflammation and collagen deposition in the tunica albuginea. PD is most common between the ages of 45–60 and is associated with conditions such as Dupuytren contracture, diabetes, and in patients following radical prostatectomy.

The most common findings of PD include penile pain, abnormal penile curvature, and indentation. Nearly 40–50% of patients present with concurrent erectile dysfunction, resulting in an increased risk of depression, relationship difficulties, and body dysmorphia. Diagnosis is clinical via patient history and penile examination, which demonstrates penile plaque(s) and penile curvature or deformity.

For patients with mild curvature and normal erectile function, observation is acceptable. If the curvature worsens or results in sexual dysfunction, medical or surgical management is advised. Initial medical management includes oral pentoxifylline, which decreases transforming growth factor (TGF) beta-1-mediated fibrosis and prevents deposition of collagen type I. In addition, the FDA approved Collagenase Clostridium Histolyticum (CCH) is the first and only agent to receive FDA approval for the treatment of PD. The collagenase produced by the bacteria Clostridium histolyticum degrades both types I and II collagen within the PD plaque.



Option Analysis

❌ A:
Incorrect: The skin of the penis becomes affected in patients with ulcerative sexually transmitted infections including herpes simplex, syphilis, and haemophilus ducreyi. This patient presents with an abnormal curvature of the penis, suggesting a different diagnosis.
❌ B:
Incorrect: The corpus cavernosum is involved in the pathophysiology of vascular erectile dysfunction (ED). In ED due to arterial insufficiency, a decrease in oxygen tension in the corpus cavernosum results in decreased blood flow to the penis and a subsequent inability to maintain an erection.
✅ C:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ D:
Incorrect: The corpus spongiosum contains the urethra. Damage to this structure can occur with penile fractures, which present with a “popping” sound, sudden-onset pain, rapid penile detumescence, penile ecchymosis, and difficulty urinating.
❌ E:
Incorrect: The urethra is often damaged in patients with blunt trauma or saddle injuries to the groin. Blood at the urethral meatus is indicative of urethral injury. Other clinical findings include difficulty voiding and perineal ecchymosis.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician for evaluation of left ear pain and facial swelling. The patient reports swelling to the left face over the past week and is worried something is “wrong with her ear.” The patient reports pain primarily at the angle of the jaw and the majority of the pinna. The patient undergoes a CT-scan of the face which demonstrates findings consistent with left sided-parotitis. Which of the nerves is most likely to be implicated as the source of the pain based on this patient’s clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
Referred ear pain, or secondary otalgia is often indicative of pathology involving structures in close proximity to the ear, based on the cutaneous innervation of the ear. In the context of parotitis, the referred ear pain is most likely subsequent to inflammation of the great auricular nerve, which supplies both the skin over the parotid gland, as well as the majority of the pinna and the angle of the jaw. Additional examples of secondary otalgia include temporomandibular joint disorder, Bell palsy, sinusitis, oropharyngeal infections, as well as auricular lymphadenopathy or lymphadenitis. A detailed anatomic understanding of the cutaneous innervation of the ear can help to clinically predict an underlying secondary otalgia.  



Option Analysis

✅ Great auricular nerve  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Lesser occipital nerve  :
Incorrect: The lesser occipital nerve supplies the posterolateral scalp, supra auricular scalp, and superior pinna. The lesser occipital nerve is not the most likely source of pain.  
❌ Auriculotemporal nerve  :
Incorrect: The auriculotemporal nerve supplies the temporal scalp, the external auditory meatus, preauricular area and tragus, and the temporomandibular joint. The auriculotemporal nerve is not the most likely source of pain.  
❌ CN X  :
Incorrect: In the context of ear anatomy, the vagus nerve supplies the lateral surface of the tympanic membrane, external acoustic meatus, and the concha. This nerve is not the most likely source of pain.    
❌ CN IX  :
Incorrect: In the context of ear anatomy, CN IX supplies the mastoid air cells, middle ear, and medial surface of the tympanic membrane. This nerve is not the most likely source of pain.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman notices the left side of her face does not move when she tries to smile. She has also experienced difficulty closing her left eye. The cranial nerve affected in this patient originates from which of the following regions of the central nervous system?
questions.solution:
This patient most likely has paralysis of the facial nerve (CN VII). The nucleus of CN VII is located in the pons. The cranial nerve nuclei are located in the tegmentum portion of the brain stem (between dorsal and ventral portions). Their locations are as follows:  

  •  Midbrain - nuclei of CN III, IV 
  •  Pons - nuclei of CN V, VI, VII, VIII 
  •  Medulla - nuclei of CN IX, X, XII 
  •  Spinal cord - nucleus of CN XI 

Option Analysis

❌ Medulla  :
Incorrect: The nuclei of cranial nerves IX, X and XII are found in the medulla. In contrast, this patient has dysfunction of the facial nerve (CN VII).  
✅ Pons  :
Correct: See Main Examination.  
❌ Midbrain  :
Incorrect: The nuclei of CN III and IV are found in the midbrain. In contrast, this patient has dysfunction of the facial nerve (CN VII).  
❌ Spinal cord  :
Incorrect: The nucleus of CN XI is found in the spinal cord. In contrast, this patient has dysfunction of the facial nerve (CN VII).  
❌ Diencephalon:
Incorrect: CN II originates as an evagination of the diencephalon. In contrast, this patient has dysfunction of the facial nerve (CN VII).

questions.text: A researcher is studying the origin and blood supply of different regions of the gastrointestinal tract. The blood vessel that supplies the hindgut originates at which of the following vertebral levels?
questions.solution:
The inferior mesenteric artery (IMA) is a branch of the abdominal aorta that originates at the L3 level and supplies the hindgut. The IMA branches into the left colic, sigmoid, and superior rectal arteries.  Other branches of the abdominal aorta are summarized below:  




Option Analysis

❌ T12/L1  :
Incorrect: The celiac artery supplies the foregut and branches off from the aorta at the T12/L1 vertebral level. The celiac artery then branches into the common hepatic, splenic, and left gastric arteries.  
❌ L1  :
Incorrect: The superior mesenteric artery (SMA) supplies the midgut. It branches off the aorta at the L1 vertebral level.  
❌ L1-L2  :
Incorrect: The renal arteries are a pair of vessels that arise from the abdominal aorta at the level of the inferior border of the L1 vertebra. Each renal artery directly supplies the ipsilateral kidney and gives rise to an inferior suprarenal artery, which supplies the adrenal gland.  
✅ L3  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ L1-L4  :
Incorrect: The lumbar arteries are a series of paired arteries (usually four pairs) that arise from the abdominal aorta at the levels of L1-L4. They supply the lumbar segments of the spinal cord and the posterior abdominal wall, but not the hindgut.

questions.text: A 36-year-old man presents to his primary care physician with worsening left shoulder pain. The patient is an avid weightlifter. However, over the past several months, he has experienced worsening left shoulder pain that is exacerbated by overhead movements. He has no history of major trauma or surgery. On physical examination, the patient has weakness in the left shoulder after downward pressure is applied while both arms are at 90° elevation in the scapular plane with full internal rotation. Which of the following anatomic structures is most likely to be disrupted given this patient’s presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with left shoulder pain that is exacerbated by overhead activities. There is reproducible weakness with the empty can test. These findings are consistent with rotator cuff injury. The most commonly injured rotator cuff muscle is the supraspinatus.

The rotator cuff muscles include the supraspinatus, infraspinatus, teres minor, and subscapularis. These muscles coordinate complex movements of the shoulder joint and are commonly injured in athletes as well as older adults, resulting in a rotator cuff injury. The etiology of injury is often multifactorial and often stems from repetitive movements against resistance, rather than a single episode of trauma or injury to the shoulder.

The majority of rotator cuff injuries involve the supraspinatus, which is responsible for abduction of the arm. Patients often describe nagging pain localized to the deltoid that worsens with overhead movements. If a full thickness tear is present, patients may have weakness or an inability to raise the arm overhead.

The empty can test (also termed Jobe test) has a high specificity for supraspinatus injuries. In this test, the patient is placed in a standing or sitting position, and the arm is raised parallel to the ground in the scapular plane with the arm rotated to full internal rotation. Once rotated, the clinician pushes down on either the wrist or elbow, and the patient is instructed to resist the downward pressure. Weakness or pain in the tested shoulder elicits a positive test.  

Option Analysis

✅ Supraspinatus  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Subscapularis  :
Incorrect: While the subscapularis muscle is a part of the rotator cuff muscle group, it is less commonly injured than the supraspinatus muscle. The patient has an abnormal empty can test, which is more consistent with the presentation of a supraspinatus tear.  
❌ Infraspinatus  :
Incorrect: The infraspinatus is less commonly injured than the supraspinatus. In addition, this patient has an abnormal empty can test, which is more consistent with the presentation of a supraspinatus tear.  
❌ Teres minor  :
Incorrect: The teres minor is less commonly injured than the supraspinatus. In addition, this patient has an abnormal empty can test, which is more consistent with the presentation of a supraspinatus tear.  
❌ Biceps brachii  :
Incorrect: The biceps brachii is not a part of the rotator cuff muscle group.

questions.text: A 23-year-old man in army training is brought to the medic station to evaluate right upper extremity pain. The patient was repelling when he lost control of his rope, forcefully grabbing it with an outstretched right hand. The patient endorses pain in the right shoulder, axilla, and right hand. Temperature is 97 F° (36.1 C°), pulse is 130/min, and blood pressure is 120/70 mm Hg. The right palm has several superficial abrasions. The sensation of all fingers is intact except for the fifth digit. He cannot extend the right fingers at the metacarpophalangeal joint or flex the fingers at the distal and proximal interphalangeal joints. Which of the following is the most likely anatomic location of this patient’s lesion?
questions.solution:
This patient has a brachial plexus injury, likely at the C8-T1 nerve roots, with characteristic features of an injury pattern known as Klumpke palsy. Klumpke palsy is the most common form of lower brachial plexus injury, with a mechanism that typically involves hyperabduction of the arm. In Klumpke palsy, patients develop a phenomenon known as “claw hand,” where the metacarpophalangeal joints (MCP) are unable to extend, and both the proximal interphalangeal joints (PIP) and distal interphalangeal joints (DIP) remain flexed. These findings result from subsequent paralysis of the intrinsic muscles of the hand and the flexors of the wrist and fingers–notably the flexor carpi ulnaris and ulnar half of the flexor digitorum profundus. Sensory deficits occur along with the 5th digit and the medial aspect of the forearm and arm.

Ulnar nerve injury is another common type of lower brachial plexus injury that presents with a sensory deficit of the 5th and medial half of the 4th digit. Motor deficit includes an “ulnar claw,” wherein the affected 4th and 5th digits cannot extend at the DIP and PIP joints, with the MCP stuck in sustained flexion. Treatment involves immobilization of the affected limb and fingers, physiotherapy, and surgery.  

Option Analysis

❌ C5-C6 nerve roots  :
Incorrect: Lesions at this level in the brachial plexus are associated with Erb palsy, not Klumpke palsy. This condition presents as a flexed wrist, extended forearm, and internally rotated arm.  
❌ Ulnar nerve  :
Incorrect: A lesion of the ulnar nerve alone would result in sensory loss to the 5th digit and half of the 4th digit.  
❌ Median nerve  :
Incorrect: A median nerve lesion would result in sensory loss to the palm and first four fingers. This patient’s pathology results in loss of function at the PIP, MCP, and DIP joints.  
❌ C7 nerve root  :
Incorrect: An isolated injury to the C7 nerve root is rare and low-yield for examination purposes. On rare occasions, injury to the C7 nerve root is associated with Erb palsy.  
✅ C8-T1 nerve roots  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 23-year-old man presents to the emergency room to evaluate severe left knee pain. An hour ago, he jumped during a football game to catch the ball and was tackled by another player. The patient felt severe left knee pain immediately afterward. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 112/83 mmHg, and pulse is 98/min. Physical examination reveals increased anterior gliding of the left tibia relative to the femur when the knee is flexed at 90 degrees. Which of the following is true regarding the ligament most likely injured in this patient?

choices.text: It connects from the lateral femoral condyle to the anterior tibia.
It connects from the medial femoral condyle to the anterior tibia.
It connects from the lateral femoral condyle to the posterior tibia.
It connects from the medial femoral condyle to the posterior tibia.
It connects from the lateral femur to the fibula.

questions.solution:
This patient has most likely injured the anterior cruciate ligament (ACL), given the anterior drawer test (increased anterior gliding of the tibia relative to the femur) is positive.    

The anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) and posterior cruciate ligament (PCL) are two ligaments that attach the tibia to the femur at the knee joint. The cruciate ligaments are major ligaments that stabilize the knee joint and prevent excessive movement of the tibia relative to the femur during joint movement.    

The ACL can be identified anteriorly, connecting the lateral femoral condyle to the anterior tibia. The function of the ACL is to prevent anterior sliding of the tibia relative to the femur. When injured, there is increased gliding of the tibia relative to the femur at 90 degrees. This physical examination maneuver is called the anterior drawer test and indicates ACL injury.    

In contrast, the PCL runs posteriorly. It connects the medial femoral condyle to the posterior tibia. The PCL prevents posterior gliding of the tibia relative to the femur. When the PCL is injured, there will be increased posterior gliding of the tibia relative to the femur when the knee is bent at 90 degrees. This physical examination maneuver is termed the positive posterior drawer test and indicates PCL injury.

Option Analysis

✅ It connects from the lateral femoral condyle to the anterior tibia.  :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ It connects from the medial femoral condyle to the anterior tibia. :
Incorrect: This patient has most likely injured his anterior cruciate ligament (ACL). The ACL connects the lateral (not medial) femoral condyle to the anterior tibia.  
❌ It connects from the lateral femoral condyle to the posterior tibia. :
Incorrect: This patient has most likely injured his anterior cruciate ligament (ACL). The ACL connects the lateral femoral condyle to the anterior (not posterior) tibia.  
❌ It connects from the medial femoral condyle to the posterior tibia. :
Incorrect: The posterior cruciate ligament (PCL) connects the medial femoral condyle to the posterior tibia. However, this patient has increased anterior gliding of the tibia relative to the femur, which indicates that the anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) is injured, not the PCL.  
❌  It connects from the lateral femur to the fibula. :
Incorrect: The lateral collateral ligament (LCL) connects from the lateral femur to the fibula. However, a positive anterior drawer test indicates that the anterior collateral ligament (ACL) is injured, not the LCL.

questions.text:
An axial view of the cerebellum is shown below:


Which of the following answer choices correctly identifies the structure represented by each number?
questions.solution:
The cerebellum is a structure located within the posterior cranial fossa. It coordinates movements, controls posture, balance, and fine motor movements, and is involved in motor learning. Within the deep white matter of the cerebellum are four nuclei, which are made up of clusters of neuronal cell bodies. The nuclei, from lateral to medial, are the dentate, emboliform, globus, and fastigial nucleus. Of note, the emboliform and globus nuclei are collectively termed the interposed nucleus.  

Information from the different functional regions that make up the cerebellar cortex are transmitted to the nuclei. The lateral zone transmits to the dentate nucleus, the intermediate zone transmits to the emboliform and globus nuclei, and the medial zone to the fastigial nucleus. Afterwards, information from the cerebellar nuclei leaves via the cerebellar peduncles and is sent to various structures including the midbrain, cerebral cortex, and spinal cord.  

Option Analysis

❌  Structure 1  Structure 2  Structure 3  Structure 4  Fastigial nucleus  Globus nucleus  Emboliform nucleus  Dentate nucleus  :
Incorrect: The four cerebellar nuclei, from lateral to medial, are the dentate, emboliform, globus, and fastigial nuclei. As a result, structure one would correspond to the dentate nucleus, structure two the emboliform nucleus, structure three the globus nucleus, and structure four the fastigial nucleus.
✅  Structure 1  Structure 2  Structure 3  Structure 4  Dentate nucleus  Emboliform nucleus  Globus nucleus  Fastigial nucleus  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌  Structure 1  Structure 2  Structure 3  Structure 4  Emboliform nucleus  Dentate nucleus  Globus nucleus  Fastigial nucleus  :
Incorrect: The four cerebellar nuclei, from lateral to medial, are the dentate, emboliform, globus, and fastigial nuclei. As a result, structure one would correspond to the dentate nucleus, structure two the emboliform nucleus, structure three the globus nucleus, and structure four the fastigial nucleus.
❌  Structure 1  Structure 2  Structure 3 Structure 4  Lateral zone  Intermediate zone  Anterior zone  Medial zone  :
Incorrect: The three functional zones of the cerebellum are the lateral, intermediate, and medial zones. These zones send signals to the emboliform nucleus, interposed nucleus (the collective term for the emboliform and globus nucleus), and the fastigial nucleus, respectively. The numbered structures in the above image correspond to the nuclei, not the functional zones.
❌  Structure 1  Structure 2 Structure 3  Structure 4  Lateral zone  Intermediate zone  Paravermal zone  Vermal zone  :
Incorrect: The three functional zones of the cerebellum are the lateral, intermediate, and medial zones. These zones send signals to the emboliform nucleus, interposed nucleus (the collective term for the emboliform and globus nucleus), and the fastigial nucleus, respectively. The numbered structures in the above image correspond to the nuclei, not the functional zones.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man is brought to the emergency department due to confusion. The symptoms began two hours ago. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 162/85 mmHg, and pulse is 87/min. On physical examination, the patient is oriented to self but not place or time. Neuroimaging reveals an occlusion of the right middle cerebral artery. Which of the following additional physical examination findings will most likely be present?

choices.text: Paralysis of the bilateral lower extremities
Reduced strength in the left lower extremity
Weakness and loss of sensation in the left upper extremity
Loss of cough and gag reflexes

questions.solution:
This patient has had a right middle cerebral artery stroke, which is part of the anterior cerebral circulation. The stroke can result in motor and sensory deficits of the left upper extremity.  

The brain’s blood supply can be divided into the anterior and posterior circulation. The anterior circulation originates from the internal carotid arteries, which travel through the carotid canal of the temporal bone and into the cranial cavity. Once within the cranial cavity, the internal carotid artery gives off two important branches.    

The first is the middle cerebral artery (MCA), which supplies blood to the lateral frontal and parietal lobes and the temporal lobes. These areas of the brain contain the portions of the motor and sensory cortex that control the face and upper extremities. As a result, patients with an MCA stroke can develop contralateral upper extremity and facial weakness and sensory loss.  

The second is the anterior cerebral artery (ACA), which supplies the medial portions of the frontal and parietal lobes. These areas of the brain contain the portions of the motor and sensory cortex that control the lower extremities. As a result, an ACA stroke can cause contralateral lower extremity weakness and sensory loss.  

Option Analysis

❌ Paralysis of the bilateral lower extremities:
Incorrect: This patient has an occlusion of the middle cerebral artery, which supplies blood to the lateral portions of the brain. In contrast, the parts of the brain that regulate the motor function of the lower extremities are located medially and supplied by the anterior cerebral artery. Additionally, this patient is more likely to have unilateral symptoms than bilateral symptoms.
❌ Reduced strength in the left lower extremity:
Incorrect: The primary motor cortex is located within the precentral gyrus. The medial portions of the precentral gyrus regulate the movement of the lower extremities and receive blood from the anterior cerebral artery. Therefore, an occlusion of the anterior cerebral artery (as opposed to the middle cerebral artery) would result in lower extremity strength deficits.
✅ Weakness and loss of sensation in the left upper extremity:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Left-sided hemianopia with macular sparing:
Incorrect: A posterior cerebral artery stroke can lead to occipital lobe infarction manifesting with contralateral hemianopia with macular sparing. In contrast, this patient has an occlusion of the middle cerebral artery, which does not supply blood to the occipital lobe.
❌ Loss of cough and gag reflexes:
Incorrect: Pathologies leading to brainstem infarction, such as a posterior inferior cerebellar artery stroke, can manifest with the loss of cough and gag reflexes. In contrast, this patient has a middle cerebral artery stroke. The middle cerebral artery provides blood supply to the lateral cerebral cortex, subcortical structures (e.g. basal ganglia), and parts of the internal capsule, but not the brainstem.

questions.text: A 21-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of jaw pain. The pain started two hours ago after yawning, and now he cannot open or close his mouth. Past medical history is unremarkable. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates tenderness over the bilateral periauricular areas with palpable indentation of the preauricular space. The patient’s mouth is open and fixed. The coronoid process of the mandible is prominent and palpable just below the maxilla. Persistent spasm of which of the following muscles contributes to this patient’s clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with an anterior temporomandibular joint (TMJ) dislocation. TMJ dislocations occur when the mandibular condyle travels anteriorly and becomes locked at the superior anterior aspect of the articular eminence of the temporal bone, preventing closure of the mouth. Anterior TMJ dislocations are associated with stretching of the ligaments surrounding the TMJ and severe spasms of the muscles that open and close the mouth (i.e., the masseter, medial and lateral pterygoid, and temporalis muscles).

Anterior dislocations are the most common type of TMJ dislocation and often result from atraumatic mechanisms that involve excessive translational movement of the mandible. Examples include excessive yawning, singing, recurrent vomiting, intubation, or dental procedures. Anterior dislocations often present with jaw pain and decreased range of mandible motion (e.g. mandibular depression or elevation). Posterior dislocations are uncommon, as posterior translation is significantly resisted by the presence of the postglenoid tubercle and the strong intrinsic lateral ligament.  



Option Analysis

❌ Buccinator  :
Incorrect: The buccinator compresses the cheek inwards and pulls the corner of the mouth laterally, which aids in swallowing, mastication, blowing, and sucking. The buccinator contributes to mandibular protrusion and retrusion but not depression.  
❌ Genioglossus  :
Incorrect:  The genioglossus is responsible for tongue protrusion rather than the movement of the mandible.  
✅ Lateral pterygoid  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Omohyoid:
Incorrect: The omohyoid travels from the hyoid bone to the clavicle and helps depress the hyoid during speech or swallowing. It is not involved in the movement of the mandible.  
❌ Zygomaticus major:
Incorrect: The zygomaticus major pulls the angle of the mouth laterally and superiorly to facilitate smiling. It is not involved in the movement of the mandible.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after sustaining a hand injury. The patient was jogging when he tripped and fell onto an area of concrete with scattered glass shards. He sustained lacerations to the left hand. He is otherwise healthy and does not take medications. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 115/78 mmHg, and pulse is 103/min. Visual inspection of the left hand demonstrates a 4 cm laceration extending from the base of the hypothenar eminence to the thenar eminence. Which of the following should be evaluated to assess for underlying nerve injury?

choices.text: Sensation to the first, second, and third digits
Sensation to the medial fourth digit and entire fifth digit

questions.solution:
This patient sustained a laceration to the palm, which may lead to injury to the recurrent branch of the median nerve that travels superficially in the palm. Among the physical examination maneuvers listed, assessment of active thumb abduction is paramount in evaluating for potential injury to the recurrent branch of the median nerve.

Assessment of hand motor and sensory function after an injury is essential for appropriate treatment, disposition, and follow-up. All patients should undergo an assessment of strength, radial, ulnar, and digital pulses characterization, and a sensory examination. Patients with evidence of deficits should be assessed for associated tendinous, vascular, or nerve injury and, if discovered, should undergo consultation with a hand surgeon.

The median nerve provides sensation to the palmar aspect of the first, second, third, and half of the fourth digit. In addition, the nerve provides motor innervation to muscles in the thenar eminence and flexor muscles of the hand and wrist.

Injury to the recurrent branch of the median nerve will manifest with pure motor deficits, as it innervates the three muscles of the thenar eminence: the abductor pollicis brevis, opponens pollicis, and the superficial head of the flexor pollicis brevis. 

Option Analysis

✅ Active thumb abduction  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Sensation to the first, second, and third digits  :
Incorrect: This patient sustained a laceration of the palm, which can result in injury to the recurrent branch of the median nerve. If the nerve is injured, patients will develop motor dysfunction without sensory deficits.  
❌ Active extension of the digits  :
Incorrect: Extension of the digits of the hand is mediated via the radial nerve, which courses on the dorsal aspect of the hand, not the palmar aspect.  
❌ Sensation to the medial fourth digit and entire fifth digit  :
Incorrect: This patient sustained a laceration of the palm, which can result in injury to the recurrent branch of the median nerve. Sensation to these digits is mediated by the ulnar nerve, not the median nerve.  
❌ Active extension of the wrist  :
Incorrect: Extension of the wrist is mediated by the radial nerve, which courses on the dorsal aspect of the wrist, not the palmar aspect of the hand.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man is brought to the emergency room after vomiting bright red blood. The patient was at home watching television when he suddenly felt nauseous and vomited. He denies any recent trauma. Past medical history is notable for chronic alcohol use disorder. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 105/60 mmHg, and pulse is 102/min. Physical exam shows scleral icterus and hepatosplenomegaly. An upper endoscopy is performed and reveals dilated veins in the distal esophagus that have ruptured. Shunting of blood and subsequent dilation of which of the following vessels is most likely to have caused this patient’s presentation?
questions.solution:
Esophageal varices are dilated submucosal veins in the lower third of the esophagus. They are most often caused by portal hypertension, which may be secondary to liver cirrhosis brought about by hepatitis or chronic alcohol use. Portal hypertension leads to increased pressure within the small vessels that connect the portal circulation to the systemic circulation. Over time, these small systemic vessels dilate, and blood is shunted through these anastomoses, which have lower resistance than the liver circulation. In particular, dilation of the left gastric and azygos veins contributes to the development of esophageal varices.  

Patients with esophageal varices can have life-threatening hematemesis if the varices rupture. This complication may occur when eating hard food or during vomiting. In severe cases, patients may develop signs of circulatory insufficiency (e.g., hypotension, tachycardia).  

Treatment of actively bleeding esophageal varices is with endoscopic band ligation, which can also prevent recurrence of hemorrhage. In patients with esophageal varices with non-active bleeding, prophylaxis with a nonselective beta-blocker (e.g. propranolol) can be used; beta-blockers reduce the portal pressure, thereby reducing the risk of future bleeding.  



Option Analysis

❌ Short gastric vein:
 Incorrect: The short gastric vein is found on the greater curvature of the stomach. The vessel does not anastomose with the esophageal veins. Hence, even if shunting were to occur in the short gastric veins, it would not contribute to esophageal vein dilation or rupture.  
❌ Hemiazygos vein:
Incorrect: The hemiazygos vein drains blood from the posterior intercostal veins on the left side of the body. Although the vessel travels in close proximity to the esophagus, it does not contribute to the development of esophageal varices.  
❌ Paraumbilical vein:
Incorrect: Shunting and dilation of the paraumbilical veins can cause the caput medusae phenomenon, which is when tortuous and dilated veins are seen on the anterior abdomen. However, the paraumbilical veins do not contribute to the development of esophageal varices.  
✅ Left gastric vein:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Right gastric vein:
Incorrect: The right gastric vein is found along the lesser curvature of the stomach. However, it does not anastomose with veins in the esophagus. As a result, shunting of blood and dilation of the right gastric vein would not contribute to the development of esophageal varices.

questions.text: A 13-year-girl is brought to the emergency department by her parent due a recent episode of unresponsiveness. The parent states the patient was playing in the yard 30 minutes ago when she started complaining of an abnormal sensation in her chest. This complaint was followed by repetitive fidgeting of the right hand, accompanied by blank staring and unresponsiveness that lasted for about a minute, after which the patient lost consciousness. She has not had any previous similar episodes. Past medical history is significant for a viral infection last month, for which the patient was hospitalized and treated with an intravenous medication. Vital signs are within normal limits. The patient appears tired but is responsive. The patient’s speech is incomprehensible. The remainder of the physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following parts of the brain is most likely involved in this patient’s episode?
questions.solution:
This patient most likely had complex focal seizure arising from the temporal lobe. Abnormal discharges in this area are typically preceded by an aura (e.g. rising sensation in epigastrium, smelling burning rubber) followed by blank staring, automatisms and post-ictal loss of consciousness, all of which are seen in this patient. Her history of a viral infection was most likely herpes encephalitis, which may have caused necrosis and subsequent scarring in the temporal lobe.  

Focal seizures are defined as seizures originating in a single cerebral hemisphere. These are usually preceded by aura, depending on the area involved in abnormal discharges, and can be subdivided into:  

  •  Simple focal seizures (also called focal seizures with retained awareness): Patients return immediately to their pre-event baseline without losing consciousness. The symptoms depend on the area of the brain that is involved, ranging from motor (frontal lobe), auditory/olfactory (temporal lobe), visual (occipital lobe), or sensory (parietal lobe). 
  •  Complex focal seizures (also called focal seizures with impaired awareness): Patients become unresponsive (blank staring) and often exhibit automatisms (e.g. lip smacking, hand fidgeting, eye blinking), along with localizing symptoms, followed by brief loss of consciousness. 


Option Analysis

❌ A:
Incorrect: Frontal lobe focal seizures are often characterized by hypermotor tonic episodes and automatisms, such as leg bicycling or pelvic thrusting (sexual automatism) and/or vocalization during the episode. Fear and anxiety can occur as auras, but rising epigastric sensation and fidgeting are atypical.  
❌ B:
Incorrect: Focal seizures arising from the parietal lobe are an uncommon occurrence and do not exhibit any distinguishing clinical features. Some studies have found that somatosensory auras can occur, followed by contralateral sensory disturbances. Common underlying pathologies include tumor, stroke, vascular malformation or nonspecific gliosis.  
❌ C:
Incorrect: Occipital lobe epilepsy is uncommon. Although it can cause focal seizures with impairment of consciousness, patients usually experience a prodrome of visual auras (flashing or colored lights) or visual distortions (metamorphopsia, micropsia). Postictal blindness can occur.  
✅ D:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ E:
Incorrect: The cerebellum is mainly involved in balance and coordination. Although temporal lobe epilepsy is associated with cerebellar atrophy in the long-term, this phenomenon usually presents with ataxia, which is not seen in this patient. Moreover, she has not had any previous similar episodes.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman comes to the office to evaluate left hand and fingers' pain, tingling, and numbness. The patient reports that the pain worsens at night and now interferes with typing while working as an office secretary. Past medical history is unremarkable. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination of the left hand shows a loss of sensation over the dorsal and palmar aspects of lateral 3½ fingers, along with weakness of thumb flexion and opposition. Sensation over the thenar eminence is intact. The patient is subsequently referred for a surgical release procedure. The affected nerve in this patient was most likely injured at which of the following locations?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with sensory loss over the lateral 3½ fingers and thumb flexion and opposition weakness, consistent with carpal tunnel syndrome (CTS).



The carpal tunnel is a deep anatomic space within the wrist formed between the carpal bones and transverse carpal ligament. CTS occurs when this space narrows and compresses the median nerve. Risk factors for this condition include repetitive wrist activity use (e.g. keyboard typing), diabetes mellitus, and hypothyroidism. Patients typically present with pain and paraesthesias in the radial 3½ digits, weakness of the first and second lumbrical, thenar atrophy, and weakness of thumb abduction and opposition. The palmar cutaneous branch of the median nerve arises proximal to and does not pass through the carpal tunnel; thus sensation in the central palm remains intact.  

In the case of median nerve injury at the wrist (e.g. wrist laceration), patients often present with “median claw,” meaning when the patient attempts to extend the fingers, the index and middle fingers extend at the MCP. Still, the DIP and PIP remain flexed due to finger flexor non-opposition.  

Proximal median nerve injury can occur due to a supracondylar fracture of the humerus. In addition to the deficits observed in a distal lesion, all finger flexors for the 2nd and 3rd digits are also affected (flexor digitorum superficialis and the lateral half of flexor digitorum profundus). Patients can only flex the 4th and 5th digits when asked to make a fist. This is referred to as the benediction sign or the “Pope’s blessing.”  



Option Analysis

✅ Carpal tunnel:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Supinator muscle:
Incorrect: The deep branch of the radial nerve can be injured as it passes through the supinator muscle secondary to repetitive pronation/supination (use of screwdrivers). Patients typically present with weakness of finger and thumb extension (without wrist drop and preserved sensations). This patient’s symptoms are suggestive of median nerve entrapment.
❌ Hook of the hamate:
Incorrect: The ulnar nerve is susceptible to injury in patients with a fracture of the hook of the hamate and results in loss of abduction and adduction of the fingers. Injury to this nerve will not result in sensory loss over the lateral half of the fingers.  
❌ Axilla:
Incorrect: The radial nerve can be injured in the axilla (Saturday night palsy) and presents with weakness in the forearm, hand, and finger extensor muscles and sensory loss over the posterior arm, forearm and dorsolateral hand. Weakness of thumb flexion and opposition is suggestive of median nerve injury.
❌ Coracobrachialis:
Incorrect: The coracobrachialis is innervated by the musculocutaneous nerve. Injury to this nerve would result in weakness in forearm flexion and supination and sensory loss over the lateral forearm.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after sustaining a traumatic head injury in a motor vehicle collision. The patient was unresponsive and subsequently had a generalized tonic-clonic seizure during transport. Past medical history is significant for hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, alcohol use disorder, and cocaine misuse. Temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 59/min, respirations are 7/min and irregular, and blood pressure is 170/105 mm Hg. The patient is comatose with downward, fixed pupils and rigid extension of the upper and lower extremities bilaterally on physical examination. A cross-sectional CT scan demonstrates complete obliteration of the perimesencephalic and premedullary cisterns and a truncated brainstem with Duret hemorrhages. Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient’s presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with a traumatic brain injury and intraparenchymal hemorrhage progressing to brain herniation. Mass effect from intracranial hemorrhage can raise the intracranial pressure (ICP), ultimately leading to the physiologic effects of hypertension, bradycardia, and bradypnea (Cushing triad). With hemorrhage expansion, central/downward brain herniation may occur.

In central herniation, the diencephalon and parts of the temporal lobes of both cerebral hemispheres herniate through a notch in the tentorium cerebelli.
