As the brainstem becomes inferiorly displaced, damage to the midbrain and upper pons results in mid-positioned and fixed pupils due to loss of sympathetic and parasympathetic innervation. In addition, paralysis of upward eye movement occurs, leading to the sunset eyes sign (eyes appear driven downward). Duret hemorrhages (due to the rupture of paramedian basilar artery branches) can be seen in central herniation. Brain herniation also results in abnormal posturing due to the disruption of the descending tract typically involved in reflexive and postural movements (which accounts for the decerebrate posturing seen in this patient).  

Option Analysis

❌ Subfalcine herniation:
Incorrect: Subfalcine herniation occurs when the innermost portion of the frontal lobe herniates under a portion of the falx cerebri. This injury does not put as much pressure on the brainstem as the other types of herniation but does compress the anterior cerebral artery manifesting in dysarthria and leg weakness. This patient’s presentation is instead suggestive of central/downward herniation.  
✅ Downward transtentorial herniation  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Upward herniation  :
Incorrect: Increased pressure in the posterior fossa can cause the cerebellum to move up through the tentorial opening and push the midbrain through the tentorial notch. Patients typically present with nausea and vomiting with rapid progression to a depressed level of consciousness and death. This patient’s presentation suggests central/downward herniation secondary to increased intracranial pressure.  
❌ Cerebellar tonsillar herniation  :
Incorrect: In tonsillar herniation, the cerebellar tonsils move downward through the foramen magnum, causing compression of the lower brainstem and upper cervical spinal cord. Decerebrate posturing is not observed with this lesion. The most common signs include intractable headache, head tilt, and neck stiffness due to tonsillar impaction.  
❌ Transcalvarial herniation:
Incorrect: In transcalvarial herniation, the brain herniates through a fracture or opening in the skull. This type of herniation may occur during craniectomy.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after a head-on motor vehicle collision. He was the restrained driver and used his arm to brace the impact. He did not strike his head or lose consciousness. Past medical history is noncontributory, and the patient does not take any medications.  Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates an inability to extend the right wrist and sensory loss over the posterior forearm and dorsolateral hand. Which of the following best describes the underlying mechanism of injury responsible for this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Fracture of the medial epicondyle of the humerus

questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation is consistent with radial nerve injury, most likely due to a midshaft fracture of the humerus. The radial nerve carries fibers from C5-T1 and serves as the terminal branch of the brachial plexus. It provides motor innervation to the forearm extensors at the elbow and most hand extensors at the wrist. Cutaneous sensory innervation includes the posterior forearm and most of the back of the hand, except for the back of the little finger and the adjacent half of the ring finger (innervated by the ulnar nerve).  


The deep branch of the radial nerve can be injured as it passes through the supinator muscle secondary to repetitive pronation/supination (use of screwdrivers). Patients typically present with weakness of finger and thumb extension (without wrist drop and preserved sensation, unlike this patient).  

Radial nerve injury by a midshaft humerus fracture results in weakness of wrist, finger, and thumb extension, as well as with elbow supination. Loss of sensation over the posterior arm/forearm and dorsal hand is also observed. Injury at this location preserves the triceps reflex.  

Finally, compression at the brachial plexus (e.g., due to crutches or sleeping with the arm over a chair i.e. “Saturday night palsy”) can induce radial nerve injury. Injury at this location results in paralysis of the triceps, leading to loss of elbow extension, in addition to the loss of wrist and finger extension.  




Option Analysis

✅ Midshaft humerus fracture:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Superficial laceration of the palm:
Incorrect: A superficial laceration of the palm can injure the recurrent branch of the median nerve, resulting in loss of thenar muscle group function (i.e., opposition, abduction, and flexion of thumb). 
❌ Fracture of the medial epicondyle of the humerus:
Incorrect: The ulnar nerve is at risk of injury as it courses posterior to the medial epicondyle before entering the forearm. Patients endorse numbness and paresthesias of the medial 1½ digits of the hand, decreased abduction of the fingers, weakness in adduction of the fingers and thumbs, as well as hypothenar eminence atrophy. Flexion, rather than extension, of the wrist is impaired with this injury pattern.
❌ Anterior dislocation of the humerus:
Incorrect: Anterior dislocations of the humerus can injure the axillary nerve, resulting in loss of arm abduction at the shoulder (> 15°) and loss of sensation over the deltoid and upper arm.
❌ Repetitive pronation/supination of forearm:
Incorrect: The deep branch of the radial nerve can be injured as it passes through the supinator muscle secondary to repetitive pronation/supination (e.g. use of screwdrivers). Patients typically present with weakness of finger and thumb extension with preserved sensation.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents to his primary care physician for evaluation of persistent left ear fullness. The patient endorses worsening fullness and pain in his left ear for six to eight weeks and states his ear feels “plugged.” During this time, the patient also endorses intermittent epistaxis from the left nostril. He and his family are originally from Hong Kong, though he immigrated to the United States many years ago. He has a twenty-pack-year smoking history. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates a bulging left tympanic membrane with serous effusion and auricular lymphadenopathy. Which of the following best describes the anatomic etiology for this patient's symptoms?

choices.text: Bony overgrowth involving the footplate of the stapes

questions.solution:
This patient presents with several features consistent with underlying nasopharyngeal carcinoma including South Chinese descent, epistaxis, serous otitis media, and associated lymphadenopathy. The primary cause of serous otitis media secondary to nasopharyngeal carcinoma is eustachian tube obstruction.

The eustachian tube is a cavity that connects the throat to the middle ear and helps with pressure regulation, protection of the middle ear, and mucociliary clearance. Obstructive etiologies often prohibit these mechanisms and produce symptoms that include ear fullness or pressure, hearing loss, and tinnitus. Patients often complain of their ears feeling “plugged.”

Obstructive etiologies are generally those that involve inflammation or mass effect. Common bilateral causes include inflammatory etiologies such as rhinosinusitis, sinusitis, and allergic rhinitis, or adenoid hypertrophy. Unilateral eustachian tube obstruction raises concern for mass effect from a compressive tumor, such as nasopharyngeal carcinoma.  

Option Analysis

✅ Eustachian tube obstruction  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Tympanic membrane perforation  :
Incorrect: Tympanic membrane perforation may occur in individuals exposed to loud noises (e.g., gunshots, explosions). However, this patient’s tympanic membrane is intact without evidence of perforation.  
❌ Great auricular nerve entrapment  :
Incorrect: Parotitis may result in referred ear pain, or secondary otalgia, due to impingement of the great auricular nerve. This patient does not have evidence of parotis (e.g. left pre-auricular edema, erythema, pain).  
❌ Impaired reabsorption of endolymphatic fluid  :
Incorrect: Meniere disease is characterized by impaired reabsorption and accumulation of endolymphatic fluid within the cochlea and vestibular organs. The condition typically presents with fluctuating unilateral hearing loss associated with tinnitus and vertigo.    
❌ Bony overgrowth involving the footplate of the stapes  :
Incorrect: Otosclerosis is characterized by bony remodeling and overgrowth of the middle ear ossicles. The footplate of the stapes is most commonly affected. The condition presents with low-frequency conductive hearing loss.

questions.text: A 75-year-old man presents with drooping of the right eyelid and diplopia. Physical examination shows the right eye is pointing downwards and outwards. Which of the following nerves is most likely affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
The movement of each eyeball is controlled by the six extraocular muscles innervated by CN III, IV, and VI. The muscles arise from a common tendinous ring in the posterior part of the orbit. The exception is the inferior oblique muscle, which originates anteriorly on the floor of the orbit and runs posterolaterally to insert in the lateral part of the sclera. The function of each extraocular muscle is as follows:  

  •  Superior rectus muscle (CN III): Elevation of the eye, with adduction and intorsion 
  • Inferior rectus muscle (CN III): Depression of the eye, with adduction and extorsion 
  •  Lateral rectus muscle (CN VI): Abduction of the eye 
  •  Medial rectus muscle (CN III): Adduction of the eye 
  •  Superior oblique muscle (CN IV): This muscle courses along the medial wall of the orbit, traverses a fibrous sling (trochlea), courses backward, and inserts on the superolateral region of the eyeball. It moves the eyeball downwards and outwards (depression and abduction) with intorsion. 
  • Inferior oblique muscle (CN III): This muscle originates on the medial wall of the bony orbit and courses laterally and obliquely to insert on the inferolateral surface of the eyeball. It moves the eyeball upwards and outwards (elevation and abduction) with extorsion. 

Option Analysis

❌ Optic nerve  :
Incorrect: Damage to the optic nerve typically causes permanent and potentially severe loss of vision, as well as an abnormal pupillary reflex. It does not innervate the extraocular muscles.  
✅ Oculomotor nerve  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Trochlear nerve  :
Incorrect: CN IV provides somatic motor innervation to the superior oblique muscle, which moves the eyeball downwards and outwards (depression and abduction), with intorsion. Its paralysis would lead to weakness of downward eye movement with consequent vertical diplopia. The affected eye would drift upwards relative to the normal eye, due to the unopposed actions of the remaining extraocular muscles. Furthermore, drooping of the eyelid is not seen with CN IV injury.  
❌ Abducens nerve  :
Incorrect: The abducens nerve provides somatic motor innervation to the lateral rectus muscle. Its paralysis will cause double vision (diplopia), due to the unopposed muscle tone of the medial rectus muscle. The affected eye would deviate medially.  
❌ Facial nerve  :
Incorrect: In the orbit, the functions of the facial nerve can be remembered with the mnemonic it “makes you cry” (parasympathetic innervation of the lacrimal gland) and “closes your eye” (branchial motor innervation of the orbicularis oculi muscle). Its paralysis would lead to an inability to close the eye and decreased lacrimation, thereby leading to corneal ulceration. Drooping of the eyelid would be atypical.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman comes to the clinic for evaluation of facial weakness. Earlier in the morning, she had trouble drinking coffee as it was drooling from the right side of her face. Her partner mentioned that her face was drooping, and she noticed that she could not move her mouth or eyebrows on that side. She has not had hearing loss, ringing sensation in the ears, or difficulty walking. She underwent a right superficial parotidectomy for the resection of a pleomorphic adenoma in the parotid gland two days ago. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows asymmetry of the face with smiling. There is also loss of the right nasolabial fold, with drooping of the eyelids and lips on the right side. The rest of the examination is noncontributory. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the findings seen in this patient?

choices.text: Upper motor neuron lesion of the involved cranial nerve

questions.solution:
This patient has new-onset right-sided facial weakness causing drooling from the right side of the face, facial droop, asymmetric smile, and inability to move the eyebrow after recent surgery involving the parotid gland. She likely suffered intraoperative facial nerve injury causing ipsilateral facial muscle paralysis.

During its extracranial course, the motor component of the facial nerve enters the parotid gland, where it forms the parotid plexus. This plexus then divides into the terminal branches to innervate the facial muscles. Injury to this area (e.g., secondary to trauma, iatrogenic, etc.) can lead to ipsilateral paralysis of the facial muscles. Since the nerves to the stapedius and chorda tympani branch proximal to this area, the patient does not experience hyperacusis or abnormalities in taste.

Patients with paralysis need to keep the eye lubricated (with artificial tears) and closed while sleeping (with a taping of the eye) to prevent corneal trauma and desiccation.  

Option Analysis

❌ Tick-borne illness:
Incorrect: Early disseminated Lyme disease can involve CN VII, leading to facial nerve palsy. However, it is usually accompanied by a macular rash, arthralgia, and aseptic meningitis. Considering the recent surgery, the temporal association of symptoms makes it a more likely cause.
❌ Upper motor neuron lesion of the involved cranial nerve:
Incorrect: Unilateral UMN lesions (e.g. stroke) only affect the lower part of the face due to dual UMN control of the upper face, thereby sparing it. This patient has paralysis of upper facial muscles, making UMN lesion less likely.
❌ Reactivation of a dormant virus:
Incorrect: The major complication of reactivation of the varicella-zoster virus is the Ramsay Hunt syndrome, which typically includes the triad of ipsilateral facial paralysis, ear pain, and vesicles in the auditory canal and auricle. This patient does not have otalgia, and physical examination of the auricle and auditory canal is unremarkable.
✅ Recent surgery:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Tumor at the cerebellopontine angle:
Incorrect: Even though a tumor at a cerebellopontine angle (e.g. schwannoma) can sometimes involve facial nerve, it is usually preceded by the symptoms of CN VIII impingement (i.e., tinnitus, ataxia, vertigo, or sensorineural hearing loss), none of which are seen in this patient.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man is involved in a motor vehicle accident. Physical examination reveals numerous ecchymoses over the trunk and flanks, as well as a tender right abdomen without a palpable mass. Focused assessment with sonography for trauma (FAST) shows no intraperitoneal fluid collections. The hemoglobin concentration is 7.6 g/dL. Which of the following organs is most likely injured in this patient?
questions.solution:
The patient has a low hemoglobin level, but the FAST exam is negative for intraperitoneal fluid collections. These findings, along with right-sided flank pain, are concerning for a retroperitoneal bleed, secondary to kidney injury.

Retroperitoneal structures are posterior to (and outside of) the peritoneal cavity. Injuries to retroperitoneal structures can cause blood or gas accumulation in the retroperitoneal space. These structures can be remembered by the mnemonic SAD PUCKER:

Suprarenal (adrenal) glands, Aorta/IVC, Duodenum (except for the first part), Pancreas (except for the tail), Ureters, Colon (ascending and descending parts), Kidneys, Esophagus, Rectum.  

Option Analysis

❌ Liver  :
Incorrect: The liver is an intraperitoneal organ. Traumatic liver bleeds should result in free intraperitoneal fluid on a FAST exam.  
❌ Spleen  :
Incorrect: The spleen is an intraperitoneal organ. Traumatic spleen rupture should result in free intraperitoneal fluid on a FAST exam.  
✅ Kidney:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Stomach  :
Incorrect: Injury to the stomach may explain this patient's physical examination findings. However, since the stomach is an intraperitoneal organ, intraperitoneal fluid collections would likely be visualized on a FAST exam.  
❌ Ileum  :
Incorrect: Injury to the ileum may explain this patient's physical examination findings. However, since the ileum is an intraperitoneal organ, intraperitoneal fluid collections would likely be visualized on a FAST exam.

questions.text:
A 17-year-old boy presents to the emergency department after sustaining a shoulder injury while playing football. The patient was diving towards the end-zone when another player collided directly with his left shoulder. On physical examination, the patient is holding the left arm adducted. Swelling is present over the lateral aspect of the left shoulder. A radiograph of the left shoulder is demonstrated below:  


Image reproduced from Radiopedia  
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with lateral shoulder pain after a direct blow to the acromioclavicular joint. The radiograph demonstrates widening of the acromioclavicular joint, which is consistent with acromioclavicular joint separation.

Acromioclavicular joint separation is a common injury. It is most often seen in young males engaged in bicycle accidents or high impact sports such as football. The most common mechanism of injury occurs due to a direct blow to the lateral aspect of the shoulder while the arm is held in adduction.

Clinical features include swelling and tenderness to the lateral aspect of the shoulder. A physical examination maneuver known as the crossover test, wherein passive cross-body adduction of the arm compresses the acromioclavicular joint, may elicit pain. Radiography will demonstrate widening of the acromioclavicular joint, superior displacement of the clavicle, and widening of the coracoclavicular ligament.

Injuries to the acromioclavicular joint are classified based on the degree of damage sustained by the acromioclavicular and coracoclavicular ligaments. In general, most injuries are managed nonoperatively via placement in a sling and immobilization.  

Option Analysis

✅ Acromioclavicular separation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Sternoclavicular separation  :
Incorrect: Sternoclavicular joint separations will often demonstrate a deformity and swelling along the medial aspect of the clavicle. They are more often anterior and without significant complications. Posterior dislocations are associated with increased morbidity due to their propensity to disrupt vascular structures.  
❌ Posterior shoulder dislocation  :
Incorrect: Posterior shoulder dislocations are rare but can occur in the setting of high speed motor vehicle accidents, status epilepticus, and lightning injuries. Plain films will demonstrate a posteriorly displaced humeral head on the axillary Y-view.  
❌ Anterior shoulder dislocation  :
Incorrect: Anterior shoulder dislocations are the most common form of shoulder dislocation and present with a squared-off appearance of the shoulder. The dislocated arm is typically in slight abduction and external rotation. The axillary Y-view will demonstrate an anteriorly placed humeral head relative to the glenoid fossa.  
❌ Clavicle fracture  :
Incorrect: There is no evidence of a left clavicle fracture on this patient’s radiograph.

questions.text:
A 44-year-old man presents to his primary care physician with worsening left shoulder pain. He can no longer do bench presses or shoulder presses at the gym due to weakness and pain. The pain is primarily located over the lateral shoulder, is worse at night, and is preventing him from obtaining adequate rest. Past medical history is otherwise unremarkable. He has no history of recent trauma or surgeries to the left shoulder. The patient subsequently undergoes a MRI of the left shoulder, which reveals the following:  


Image reproduced from Radiopedia  
Which of the following physical examination maneuvers is most likely to yield a positive test, given this patient’s clinical findings?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with worsening left shoulder pain and weakness. MRI imaging demonstrates a complete tear of the supraspinatus tendon. Of the physical examination techniques listed, the one most likely to demonstrate a positive finding is the empty can test.

The shoulder is made up of the rotator cuff muscles, the glenohumeral and acromioclavicular ligaments, and connective tissue. In the assessment of shoulder pain, several tests can aid in the diagnosis of a specific injury. For instance, the empty can test (also termed Jobe test) has a high specificity for supraspinatus injuries. In this test, the patient is placed in a standing or sitting position, and the arm is raised parallel to the ground in the scapular plane and fully internally rotated. Once rotated, the clinician pushes down on either the wrist or elbow, and the patient is instructed to resist the downward force. Weakness or pain in the tested shoulder represents a positive test result.

Another test known as the full can test also assesses for supraspinatus instability. It is performed in the same manner as the empty can test, with the only difference being that the patient's arms are not rotated to full internal rotation (e.g. thumbs are up).

Additional tests include the Neer test and Hawkins-Kennedy test, which assess for subacromial impingement syndrome. The Scarf test assesses for stability of the acromioclavicular joint and is commonly positive with partial or full tears of the acromioclavicular or coracoclavicular ligaments.  

Option Analysis

✅ Empty can test  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Lift off test  :
Incorrect: The lift off test is performed to assess for instability of the subscapularis. In this test, the patient actively lifts the dorsum of the hand off the back with resistance. This patient instead has evidence of a complete tear of the supraspinatus tendon.  
❌ Scarf test  :
Incorrect: The Scarf test is used to assess for stability of the acromioclavicular joint. It is performed by passively adducting the patient's arm across the body horizontally, approximating the elbow to the contralateral shoulder. This patient instead has evidence of a complete tear of the supraspinatus tendon.  
❌ Neer test  :
Incorrect: The Neer test is used to assess for subacromial impingement syndrome. This test is performed by stabilizing the patient's scapula with one hand and passively flexing the arm while it is internally rotated. This patient instead has evidence of a complete tear of the supraspinatus tendon.  
❌ Yergason test  :
Incorrect: The Yergason test is used to assess for tear or rupture of the long-head of the biceps brachii. In this test, pain is reproduced at the anterior shoulder as the patient attempts to supinate the arm against resistance when the arm is pronated and flexed at the elbow to 90 degrees. This patient instead has evidence of a complete tear of the supraspinatus tendon.

questions.text: A 23-year-old man comes to his primary care physician to evaluate the sudden onset of numbness and tingling in the right upper extremity following a workout. The patient was performing sit-ups when he experienced a sharp pain in his neck, followed by numbness and tingling in his right hand. He does not have any symptoms while at rest. He reports several similar episodes in the past. He is a bodybuilder. Vital signs are within normal limits. The right lateral neck appears larger when compared to the left lateral neck. The patient has no spinal tenderness to palpation. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient's presentation is consistent with thoracic outlet syndrome (TOS), a condition causing transient numbness and tingling in the upper extremity. Specifically, this patient likely suffers from neurogenic thoracic outlet syndrome due to hypertrophy of the anterior scalene, given his history of bodybuilding.

TOS is an umbrella term that encompasses compression of one or multiple of the following structures: the brachial plexus, subclavian vein, or subclavian artery. Etiologies of TOS include anterior scalene hypertrophy, cervical rib injuries, trauma, tumors, or repetitive motion injuries of the shoulder. Additional findings of various types of TOS are summarized in the table below.  



Option Analysis

✅ Anterior scalene hypertrophy  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Exogenous testosterone use  :
Incorrect: Exogenous testosterone use would not result in this patient’s neurological symptoms.  
❌ Herniated cervical disk:
Incorrect: Lower cervical neck injuries resulting in paresthesias usually occur due to trauma. This patient’s presentation is consistent with an alternative diagnosis.  
❌ Cervical rib obstruction  :
Incorrect: Cervical ribs are a cause of thoracic outlet syndrome (TOS); however, it is more likely with this patient’s history of being a bodybuilder that his TOS resulted from hypertrophy of the anterior scalene muscles.  
❌ Pancoast tumor  :
Incorrect: While mass effect from a pancoast tumor is a known cause of thoracic outlet syndrome, this patient’s presentation is suggestive of an alternative etiology.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man attends a physical rehabilitation session. One month ago, the patient had a motor vehicle accident that resulted in a posterior hip dislocation. The injury caused damage to the nerve that innervates the gluteus maximus muscle. Which of the following movements is most likely affected by this injury?
questions.solution:
The hip joint is a ball and socket joint formed by the articulation of the head of the femur with the acetabulum of the pelvis. Movements of the hip joint include flexion and extension, internal rotation and external rotation, and adduction and abduction. These movements are controlled by different groups of muscles in the hip:   
  •  Adduction: performed by actions of the adductor magnus, adductor longus, adductor brevis, gracilis, and pectineus 
  •  Abduction: performed by actions of the gluteus medius, gluteus minimus, tensor fascia lata, and sartorius 
  •  Extension: performed by actions of the gluteus maximus and hamstrings 
  •  Flexion: performed by actions of the iliopsoas, pectineus, rectus femoris, and sartorius  
  •  Internal rotation is performed by the tensor fascia lata, gluteus medius, and gluteus minimus 
  •  External rotation: performed by actions of the obturator muscle, gluteus maximus, and piriformis  

Option Analysis

✅ Extension of the thigh  :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Abduction of the thigh :
Incorrect: Abduction of the thigh at the hip joint is facilitated by the gluteus medius, gluteus minimus, tensor fascia lata, and sartorius muscles, but not the gluteus maximus.  
❌ Adduction of the thigh  :
Incorrect: Hip adductors include the adductor magnus, longus, brevis, gracilis, and pectineus. The gluteus maximus muscle is not involved in hip or thigh adduction. 
❌ Internal rotation of the thigh :
Incorrect: The gluteus maximus is involved in external rotation of the thigh, not internal rotation.  
❌ Flexion of the thigh :
Incorrect: The gluteus maximus extends, as opposed to flexes, the thigh at the hip joint.

questions.text: A 37-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of excruciating headaches. The headaches began three days ago and have progressively worsened. Temperature is 37.9°C (100.2°F), blood pressure is 152/90 mmHg, and pulse is 97/min. On physical examination, the headache is worsened with the Valsalva maneuver. No signs of trauma are present over the skull. CT imaging is obtained and reveals thrombosis within the portion of the superior sagittal sinus overlying the occipital lobe. The affected area of the dural venous system is primarily innervated by which of the following nerves?
questions.solution:
This patient has headaches secondary to a dural sinus thrombosis. The thrombosis is in the portion of the superior sagittal sinus overlying the occipital lobe, which is located in the posterior cranial fossa and innervated by the ophthalmic nerve (CN V1).

The dura mater has a nerve supply that varies between the anterior, middle, and posterior cranial fossa. All three trigeminal nerve branches innervate dura mater overlying the anterior cranial fossa. Dura mater overlying the middle cranial fossa is innervated mainly by the mandibular nerve (CN V3) and some innervation from the maxillary nerve (CN V2).

The supratentorial dura of the posterior cranial fossa and the tentorium cerebelli are innervated by the ophthalmic nerve (CN V1). In contrast, the infratentorial dura is innervated by a combination of the vagus nerve (CN X) and cervical plexus. 

Of note, signals from the dura mater travel along the sensory fibers of these nerves and can be referred to as cutaneous areas also supplied by the same nerve fibers. As a result, intracranial pathologies can present with referred pain over the face.  



Option Analysis

✅ Ophthalmic nerve (CN V1):
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Maxillary nerve (CN V2):
Incorrect: The maxillary nerve (CN V2) provides innervation to the anterior and middle cranial fossa. However, it does not provide innervation to the portion of the superior sagittal sinus overlying the occipital lobe, which is located within the posterior cranial fossa.
❌ Abducens nerve (CN VI):
Incorrect: The abducens nerve (CN VI) assists with eye movements. The abducens nerve does not provide innervation to the dural venous sinus system.
❌ Facial nerve (CN VII):
Incorrect: The facial nerve (CN VII) has a wide variety of functions. These include controlling facial movements, lacrimation, salivation, and relaying taste from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. However, the facial nerve does not innervate the dural layers. 
❌ Vagus nerve (CN X):
Incorrect: The posterior cranial fossa can be subdivided into the supratentorial and infratentorial fossas. The infratentorial fossa is innervated by the vagus nerve (CN X) and branches of the cervical plexus. In contrast, the supratentorial fossa, which contains the superior sagittal sinus, is innervated by the ophthalmic nerve (CN V1).

questions.text: During a neurology lecture, students learn that the thalamus is the central relay station for all ascending sensory information, except for olfaction. Which of the following thalamic nuclei relays auditory information?
questions.solution:
The thalamus is the central relay station for all ascending sensory information except olfaction. The medial geniculate nucleus relays auditory information from the tectum's superior olive and inferior colliculus to the primary auditory cortex. The functions of the other thalamic nuclei are summarized below:  



Option Analysis

❌ Ventral posterolateral nucleus:
Incorrect: The ventral posterolateral nucleus relays vibration, pain, pressure, conscious proprioception, light touch, and temperature information from the spinothalamic and dorsal columns/medial lemniscus to the primary somatosensory cortex.
❌ Ventral posteromedial nucleus:
Incorrect: The ventral posteromedial nucleus relays facial and taste sensations from the trigeminal and gustatory pathways to the primary somatosensory cortex.  
❌ Lateral geniculate nucleus:
Incorrect: The lateral geniculate nucleus relays visual information from the optic nerve (CN II), optic chiasm, and optic tract to the primary visual cortex (occipital lobe).
✅ Medial geniculate nucleus:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Ventral anterior and lateral nuclei:
Incorrect: The ventral anterior and lateral nuclei relay motor information from the basal ganglia and cerebellum to the motor cortices (frontal lobe).

questions.text: A 34-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after being involved in a bar fight. Per emergency medical services, the patient sustained a stab wound to the right anterior chest. Prompt physical examination demonstrates a pocket knife lodged in the anterior chest wall. It is located in the parasternal space at the level of the fourth intercostal space. Given this patient's trauma mechanism, which of the following regions of the heart is at the most significant risk of injury?
questions.solution:
Cardiac injury secondary to penetrating trauma to the thorax is a leading cause of death due to urban violence (approximately 80% mortality rate). Understanding the anatomic locations of chambers in the heart can help predict the area of injury. Most penetrating trauma to the heart is to the right ventricle (43%) compared to the left ventricle (34%), owing to its anterior anatomic location. The atria are also less commonly injured, given their more posterior anatomic location and shielding via the sternum. Following injury, patients may exsanguinate into the pleural space if the cardiac lesion communicates freely with the pleural cavity, or they may suffer cardiac tamponade if the hemorrhage is contained within the pericardium.  



Option Analysis

✅ Right ventricle:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Right atrium:
Incorrect: While the right atrium also lies anteriorly in the thorax, it is relatively protected by the sternum. Given this patient's mechanism of injury, the right ventricle is more susceptible to injury. 
❌ Left ventricle :
Incorrect: The left ventricle lies most posterior in the thorax, thus shielding it from anterior penetrating stab wounds. 
❌ Left atrium:
Incorrect: Like the left ventricle, the left atrium lies most posterior in the thorax, thus shielding it from anterior penetrating stab wounds. 
❌ Aortic outflow tract :
Incorrect: The aortic outflow tract is protected posteriorly in the thorax. Penetrating stab wounds are unlikely to injure this vessel.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old woman presents to the emergency department after having multiple syncopal episodes at home. Over several hours, the patient endorses intermittent, substernal chest pressure radiating to her right jaw. She was recently admitted to the hospital two weeks ago following an acute myocardial infarction with stent placement. Since discharge, the patient has occasionally forgotten to take her medications. She has a medical history of hypertension, diabetes, and hyperlipidemia. The patient’s medications include metformin, lisinopril, carvedilol, aspirin, and clopidogrel. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 46/min, respirations are 18/min, blood pressure is 97/66 mmHg, and O2 saturation is 94% on room air. A screening electrocardiogram is demonstrated below. Which of the following cardiac vessels is most likely implicated in this patient’s disease process?  


Reproduced from: wikipedia
questions.solution:
This patient’s electrocardiogram demonstrates complete heart block–as evidenced by dyssynchrony between p-waves, QRS complexes, and t-waves. Given this pattern of findings, the most likely implicated coronary artery is the right coronary artery, which contains branches that supply the conducting SA and AV nodes of the heart. In addition, the history of a recent myocardial infarction and medication noncompliance is concerning for in-stent thrombosis requiring revascularization.  

When the AV node is damaged secondary to ischemia, the regular conduction pattern of the heart fails, resulting in independent and asynchronous contractions of the atria and ventricles. When this occurs, bradycardia ensues (the ventricles contract independently at an average rate of 40-45 bpm), manifesting with exertional syncope, angina, or shortness of breath.    

In addition to RCA occlusion, distal left coronary artery occlusion–particularly of the anterior interventricular branch of the LCA–can also result in complete heart block, as this artery contributes to the blood supply of the AV bundle.  



Option Analysis

✅ Right coronary artery :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Posterior descending coronary artery :
Incorrect: Infarction of the posterior descending artery manifests with ST-depressions in V1-V3 and tall R-waves. A posterior ECG will demonstrate elevations in V7-V9, confirming the diagnosis. While this artery is most commonly a branch of the RCA, it is not always implicated in SA or AV node dysfunction–especially if it branches from the LCX.  
❌ Left anterior descending coronary artery:
Incorrect: Infarction of the left anterior descending coronary artery manifests with ST-elevations of the anterior and lateral leads.
❌ Left circumflex coronary artery:
Incorrect: Infarction of the left circumflex coronary artery manifests with ST elevations or q-waves in the lead I or aVL. 
❌ Obtuse marginal artery :
Incorrect: Like infarctions of the left circumflex coronary artery, infarction of the obtuse marginal artery results in a lateral STEMI pattern on ECG–with elevations or q-waves in leads I, aVL, or V5-V6.

questions.text: A 65-year-old person is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of acute onset right-sided weakness. They were eating dinner when, suddenly, they could not lift their fork. Upon standing up, the patient’s right side gave away, and they fell onto the carpet. Past medical history includes hypertension, diabetes, and hyperlipidemia for which the patient takes amlodipine, metformin, and simvastatin. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 102/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 190/100 mmHg. Physical examination shows deviation of the eyes to the left side. Motor strength is 0/5 on the right side and 5/5 on the left side. Which of the following is the most likely explanation of this patient’s ocular findings?

choices.text: Lesion involving the right medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF)
Lesion involving the right frontal eye field
Lesion involving the left frontal eye field
Lesion involving the right paramedian pontine reticular formation (PPRF)
Lesion involving the left paramedian pontine reticular formation (PPRF)

questions.solution:
This patient presents with right-sided hemiplegia and deviation of the eyes to the left. They likely have a left middle cerebral artery (MCA) territory stroke involving the left frontal eye field.  

The frontal eye field refers to an area of the frontal lobe involved in visual field perception and voluntary eye movements. It plays a crucial role in conjugate horizontal gaze and saccades (fast eye movements).  

In order to look to the right, the left frontal eye field synapses to the contralateral paramedian pontine reticular formation (PPRF) via the superior colliculus. The efferent pathway from the PPRF passes to the right lateral rectus motor neurons (via the CN VI nucleus), resulting in abduction of the right eye. Excitatory signals are also sent to the contralateral medial rectus motor neurons (CN III) via the contralateral medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF), resulting in adduction of the contralateral (left) eye.  

Horizontal gaze palsy is typically caused by either a contralateral frontal eye field lesion or an ipsilateral PPRF lesion.   

The middle cerebral artery supplies the lateral surface of the cerebral hemisphere. Strokes involving the middle cerebral artery (MCA) can lead to lesions that also involve the frontal eye field. Clinically, the eyes will deviate towards the side of the lesion (left-sided MCA stroke with right-sided hemiplegia means that eyes will be deviated to the left). In contrast, a lesion involving the PPRF results in ipsilateral gaze palsy (inability to look towards the side of the lesion).  

 

Option Analysis

❌ Lesion involving the right medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF):
Incorrect: A lesion affecting the unilateral MLF impairs adduction of the ipsilateral medial rectus, resulting in internuclear ophthalmoplegia (INO) – a conjugate horizontal gaze palsy.
❌ Lesion involving the right frontal eye field:
Incorrect: Preferential gaze is controlled by the contralateral frontal eye field. This patient presents with an inability to gaze to the right, which is consistent with a lesion in her left frontal eye field.
✅ Lesion involving the left frontal eye field:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Lesion involving the right paramedian pontine reticular formation (PPRF):
Incorrect: A lesion involving the PPRF results in an ipsilateral gaze palsy (inability to look towards the side of the lesion). A lesion in this area does not explain the patient’s right-sided motor deficits.
❌ Lesion involving the left paramedian pontine reticular formation (PPRF):
Incorrect: Lesions involving the PPRF result in ipsilateral gaze palsy (inability to look towards the side of the lesion). This patient has left-sided eye deviation (rather than the inability to look left), and a lesion in this area would not explain their right-sided motor deficits.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician to evaluate low back pain and left leg weakness. The patient has had worsening low back pain over the past three weeks, with pain radiating into her groin. The patient has also had difficulty maintaining poses due to weakness and pain during her yoga classes.  The patient recently had an upper respiratory infection six weeks ago that resolved. The patient also reports falling on her back several weeks ago while skiing in Colorado. The patient is otherwise healthy and takes oral contraceptive pills daily. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates tenderness to palpation over the lumbar vertebrae and reproduction of pain when raising the left leg to 45 degrees. Reflex testing demonstrates 1+ reflexes of the patellar tendon and 2+ reflexes of the Achilles tendon in the left leg. The patient has 4/5 strength with hip flexion and knee extension in the left leg compared to 5/5 strength with these maneuvers in the right leg. Which of the following best describes the underlying etiology of this patient’s clinical presentation?

choices.text: Posterolateral herniation of the nucleus pulposus
Post-infectious autoimmune demyelination of peripheral nerves
Collapse and loss of height of the vertebral bodies
Inflammation of the lateral corticospinal tract
Neural foraminal stenosis due to degenerative arthritis

questions.solution:
The most common cause of radiculopathy in young, otherwise healthy patients is intervertebral disc herniation of the nucleus pulposus. This otherwise healthy patient presents for evaluation of low back pain and unilateral leg weakness. The physical examination findings are consistent with L2-L4 radiculopathy, given the associated weakness of hip flexion, knee extension, and a diminished knee jerk reflex.    

The vertebral bodies are cushioned against one another by a ring of cartilage called intervertebral discs. The rounded region in its center is called the nucleus pulposus, and the nucleus pulposus is surrounded by a fibrous ring called the annulus fibrosus. Typically, the annulus fibrosus is thinner posteriorly and doesn’t receive support from the posterior or the anterior longitudinal ligaments.    

Movements that result in forward flexion of the spine can compress the anterior portion of the disc, pushing the nucleus pulposus posterolaterally. Most commonly, this occurs at the L4-L5 or L5-S1 levels. Over time, or with extreme flexion of the spine, the annulus fibrosus can degrade or break, resulting in posterolateral protrusion of the disk, which can compress motor or sensory nerve roots, producing radicular symptoms.  



Option Analysis

✅ Posterolateral herniation of the nucleus pulposus  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Post-infectious autoimmune demyelination of peripheral nerves:
Incorrect: Guillain Barre syndrome more commonly presents with bilateral, ascending symmetric leg weakness. The unilateral clinical findings in this patient make this diagnosis unlikely.  
❌ Collapse and loss of height of the vertebral bodies:
Incorrect: Collapse and loss of height of the vertebral bodies is usually a result of compression fractures uncommon in otherwise healthy individuals. Compression fractures more commonly occur in the elderly with underlying osteopenia or osteoporosis.  
❌ Inflammation of the lateral corticospinal tract   :
Incorrect: Transverse myelitis reflects an autoimmune or inflammatory process directly affecting the spinal cord. Since this pathology is directly related to the central nervous system, symptoms of hyperreflexia or increased tone are more likely to be present.  
❌ Neural foraminal stenosis due to degenerative arthritis:
Incorrect: Neural foraminal stenosis due to degenerative arthritis is a common culprit of lumbosacral radiculopathy in the elderly, not in otherwise young, healthy patients.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man presented to the emergency department for evaluation of chest pain radiating to the back. He was diagnosed with a type A aortic dissection and proceeded to the operating room for emergent open repair. Following the procedure, the patient is brought to the post-operative care unit for further monitoring. During the patient’s postoperative assessment, he reports thoracic back pain and an inability to move the bilateral lower extremities. The patient's temperature is 98.6.0 °C (37 C °F), pulse is 30/min, respirations are 24/min, blood pressure is 195/95 mmHg, and O<sub>2</sub> saturation is 97% on room air.  Pinprick testing demonstrates bilateral loss of pain sensation below the xiphoid process. The patient has preserved proprioception, vibratory sense, fine touch, and two-point discrimination. Which of the following best describes the underlying etiology of this patient’s clinical presentation?

choices.text: Ischemia of the anterior spinal artery
Ischemia of the posterior spinal arteries
Acute inflammation of gray and white matter spinal cord tracts
Expansion of a fluid-filled cavity within the spinal cord

questions.solution:
This patient who underwent surgery for repair of an aortic dissection is found to have several neurologic deficits postoperatively. Given his findings, there is a concern for damage to the corticospinal tracts and anterior spinothalamic tracts reflective of ischemia to the anterior spinal artery.    

The spinal cord receives its blood supply through three primary arteries–one anterior spinal artery and two posterior spinal arteries. The anterior spinal artery provides blood to the anterior two-thirds of the spinal cord, which houses the lateral corticospinal and spinothalamic tracts. The posterior spinal arteries provide blood supply to the posterior one-third of the spinal cord, which houses the dorsal column pathways.  

Ischemia to the spinal cord is an overall rare event but can occur in the setting of trauma, surgery, infection, embolic events, vasculitis, or malignancy. Ischemia of the anterior spinal artery most commonly occurs after aortic surgery–typically due to prolonged cross-clamping of the aorta. The most common area of ischemia is at the level of the Artery of Adamkiewicz, or T8. Clinically, this manifests after surgery with findings of acute back pain at the level of injury, bilateral flaccid paralysis, and loss of pain and temperature sensation, preserving the dorsal column pathway functions. Additional findings include autonomic dysfunction, respiratory failure, and spinal shock with higher thoracic and cervical lesions.  

Option Analysis

✅ Ischemia of the anterior spinal artery  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Ischemia of the posterior spinal arteries  :
Incorrect: Occlusion of the posterior spinal arteries would result in diminished proprioception, vibratory sense, fine touch, and two-point discrimination as these arteries supply the dorsal column pathways.  
❌ Acute inflammation of gray and white matter spinal cord tracts :
Incorrect: Transverse myelitis does not typically occur in the setting of trauma or recent surgery but rather as a post-infectious or progressive autoimmune syndrome.  
❌ Expansion of a fluid-filled cavity within the spinal cord  :
Incorrect: A syrinx may present with bilateral loss of temperature and pain sensation due to the anterior white commissure disruption. It does not typically involve the lateral corticospinal tract, and therefore, motor function is preserved.  
❌ Anterior thoracic epidural hematoma:
Incorrect: Spinal epidural hematomas rarely occur outside the setting of trauma or fracture to the vertebral bodies. This patient’s presentation is instead concerning for ischemia to the anterior spinal artery.

questions.text: A three-year-old boy is brought to the clinic due to gait disturbance. The patient’s parents have noticed that their son has been falling more frequently while running. In addition, they have observed that he appears to have “knock knees.” They deny any significant injury, and the boy has not been complaining of pain. He was born full-term via an uncomplicated vaginal delivery and is up to date on vaccinations. He can name familiar objects, climbs well, and follows instructions. On physical examination he is well-developed, well-nourished, and speaks in 3-4 word sentences. Physical examination is notable for bilateral genu valgum. His knees are nontender and he has full range of motion without pain. Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with bilateral genu valgum on physical examination. Clinically and radiographically, valgus deformity will present as “knock knees,” whereas varus deformity will present as “bow legs”. Genu valgum can be a normal finding in patients between the ages of 2-5 years. In the majority of toddlers with physiologic genu valgum, the condition will resolve with age as the long bones of the legs continue to ossify. While genu valgum may be a standard variant in toddlers, it can also represent a pathologic disturbance in the development of long bones.

Measurement of the Q-angle can be used to assess the alignment of the knee joint This angle is found by measuring the angle formed between the quadriceps muscles and the patella tendon. The normal Q angle falls between 12 and 20 degrees when the knee is extended, with males normally falling at the low end of this range and females in the high end.

Large Q-angles outside of the normal range are associated with varus deformities that can be caused by underlying nutritional deficiencies, skeletal dysplasias, growth disorders, or persistence of severe physiologic genu varus after the age of 2 years. Small Q-angles outside of the normal range are indicative of valgus deformity, which may be physiologic in toddlers, or the result of rickets or an underlying skeletal dysplasia.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Physiologic genu valgum:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Cozen fracture:
Incorrect: Cozen fractures are fractures of the proximal tibial metaphysis that can occur in children. They  typically present after an injury with pain of the affected knee. Patients with proximal tibial metaphysis fractures are at risk for developing valgus deformity secondary to medial physeal overgrowth during the healing response. In contrast, this patient has not suffered an injury, is not in any pain, and has bilateral valgus deformity.  
❌ Vitamin D deficiency:
Incorrect: Rickets from Vitamin D deficiency is a common cause of valgus deformity in countries without access to advanced medical care. The bone deformities associated with Rickets typically appear before the age of 18 months. The condition is unlikely in this child given his age and history of adequate nutritional intake.  
❌ Chondroectodermal dysplasia:
Incorrect: Chondroectodermal dysplasia (Ellis van Creveld syndrome) is an autosomal recessive skeletal dysplasia that results in short-limbed disproportionate dwarfism. This disorder is also known to be associated with cardiac anomalies. Patients can have genu valgum, but this patient does not have other features consistent with disproportionate dwarfism.  
❌ Skeletal dysplasia:
Incorrect: Skeletal dysplasia refers to a category of rare genetic disorders that affect the development of bones and joints and can lead to genu valgum. The condition causes abnormally shaped bones, especially in the head, spine, arms, and legs. This patient is without other associated skeletal anomalies on physical examination.

questions.text: A 33-year-old man presents to the clinic with worsening knee pain for the past 5 months. He is currently training for a marathon, and the pain is brought on by running. His past medical history is unremarkable, and he does not take any medications. Physical examination is notable for tenderness to palpation over the lateral knee superior to the joint line at the lateral femoral epicondyle. There is no joint swelling of the knee and no gapping at the knee with valgus or varus testing. In addition, a test is performed that results in failure of the hip to adduct and lateral knee pain when the patient is lying with the affected side up and the distal leg is held with the hip abducted and extended and then dropped until motion is restricted. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with worsening lateral knee pain while engaged in running. Physical examination is notable for tenderness to palpation at the lateral femoral epicondyle and a positive Ober test. These findings are consistent with iliotibial band syndrome.

Iliotibial band syndrome is an overuse pain syndrome wherein pain occurs at the lateral knee as the iliotibial band crosses over the lateral femoral epicondyle. It is described as a sharp or burning pain that occurs only during activity. It is a common overuse syndrome often seen in runners and cyclists. Risk factors include weak hip adductors that place increased rotational strain on the iliotibial band, as well as an inherited leg-length discrepancy.

Diagnosis is primarily clinical, and advanced imaging is not needed. Key clinical findings include pain at the lateral femoral epicondyle and a positive Ober test or Noble test. For the Ober test, the knee is flexed to 90 °, the hip is abducted and extended, and the leg is released. Failure of the knee to adduct is a positive test and pain may be noted at the lateral knee. For the Noble test, the patient is supine, and the knee is bent back and forth several times from 0° to 90° while applying firm pressure on the lateral femoral epicondyle while the patient actively extends the hip and knee. The presence of palpable snapping, crepitus, or localized pain signifies a positive test.

Treatment of iliotibial band syndrome involves providing symptomatic relief and prescribing activity restriction, and physical therapy to correct mobility deficits.  

Option Analysis

✅ Iliotibial band syndrome:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Lateral meniscus tear:
Incorrect: Pain from lateral meniscal tears occurs at the joint line which is inferior to the location of the pain associated with iliotibial band syndrome. Lateral meniscus tears are typically associated with joint pain and swelling after an injury which this patient has not had..  
❌ Lateral collateral ligament tear:
Incorrect: While iliotibial band syndrome and lateral collateral ligament tears can occur concomitantly, it is unlikely given this patient has no knee gapping with stress testing on physical examination. Lateral collateral ligament tears typically occur after a high-energy blow to the knee or with extreme varus bending, neither of which have occurred in this patient.  
❌ Biceps femoris tendinopathy:
Incorrect: In this condition, tenderness is present at the tendon insertion at the lateral aspect of the fibular head rather than at the lateral femoral epicondyle. Pain is typically at the posterior aspect of the knee and outside of the knee joint.  
❌ Fibular head subluxation:
Incorrect: In this condition, tenderness to palpation is found at the fibular head, not at the lateral femoral epicondyle as seen in this patient. Also a prominence may be visible at the area of the fibular head.

questions.text:
A 33-year-old man presents to the emergency department following a right knee injury. The patient was playing rugby when an opposing teammate tackled him. He felt a “pop” in the right knee and experienced pain after that. The patient is otherwise healthy. Physical examination demonstrates a large right knee effusion, a positive anterior drawer test, and a positive valgus stress test. Vital signs are within normal limits. An MRI of the patient's right knee is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely mechanism of injury that resulted in this patient’s condition?
 

Image reproduced from Radiopedia

choices.text: Posteriorly directed force on a flexed knee
Varus force applied to the knee
Direct force to the anterior knee

questions.solution:
After being tackled during a rugby match, this patient presents with right knee pain. Physical examination demonstrates positive anterior drawer and valgus stress tests, which are consistent with anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) and medial collateral ligament (MCL) tears respectively. MRI imaging not only reveals these findings but also evidence of meniscal injury with hyperintensity of the medial meniscus. In combination, these injuries constitute the unhappy triad or a “blown knee”.

The unhappy triad is defined as soft tissue injury to the ACL, MCL, and medial meniscus. This injury pattern is typical in contact sports (e.g., rugby, football, hockey) and occurs when the knee sustains a lateral blow while the foot is planted on the ground. Ultimately, this scenario produces an abduction and external rotation mechanism of injury.

Physical examination findings will often include joint effusion and pain with weight bearing.Injury to the ACL can be detected with a positive anterior drawer test, and MCL injury is associated with a positive valgus stress test. Meniscal injuries are often more challenging to detect, a positive McMurray test may be seen. Definitive diagnosis is achieved with MRI where all three injuries can be visualized. Most unhappy triad injuries are treated with surgical repair.  

Option Analysis

✅ Lateral force to the knee:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Posteriorly directed force on a flexed knee:
Incorrect: Posterior cruciate ligament injuries are rare and most commonly occur after high-force trauma with a posteriorly directed force on a flexed knee as in dashboard injuries.  
❌ Varus force applied to the knee:
Incorrect: Varus force applied to the knee from a high energy blow to the anteromedial knee which combines hyperextension and extreme varus force typically causes a lateral collateral ligament injury.  
❌ Twisting force at the knee:
Incorrect: Meniscus tears are often produced by a twisting mechanism applied to the knee, such as when turning rapidly or landing from a large jump.  
❌ Direct force to the anterior knee:
Incorrect: This is the most common mechanism of injury in the setting of patellar fractures. Contraction of the quadriceps aids in stabilizing the anterior and posterior ligaments of the knee.

questions.text:
A 39-year-old man presents to the clinic with worsening swelling and pain in his left knee. The pain has been ongoing for weeks and worsens with knee flexion. The patient works as a plumber and spends most of the day on his knees working in crawl spaces. He has a history of hypertension and diabetes and takes amlodipine and metformin daily. The patient smokes half a pack of cigarettes per day and drinks three beers on the weekends. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 93/min, respirations are 12/min, blood pressure is 146/75 mmHg, and O2 saturation is 95% on room air. The patient can fully flex and extend the knee and bear weight without significant pain. Physical examination is notable for the findings seen below, and a radiograph of the left knee is also shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
 
Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons
Image reproduced from Radiopedia
questions.solution:
This patient presents with anterior knee pain and evidence of significant prepatellar bursal swelling from fluid accumulation. These findings are consistent with prepatellar bursitis.

Knee bursitis is a common condition that arises secondary to inflammation of bursa sacs surrounding the knee joint. Within the knee there are multiple bursal or fluid-filled synovial sacs that help to lubricate and cushion the skin, tendons, and bones. The commonly inflamed or injured bursa includes the prepatellar, infrapatellar, suprapatellar, and pes anserine bursa. Prepatellar and infrapatellar bursitis commonly occur in patients with chronic trauma to the anterior knee, such as those involved in professions who spend most of their day on their knees (e.g. plumbers). Suprapatellar bursitis is less common and often arises due to regression failure of the transverse septum formed in embryonic life between the suprapatellar plica and knee joint. The pes anserine bursa is located medially and commonly presents as swelling and pain at the medial aspect of the knee.

Clinically, knee bursitis presents as pain and swelling of the affected bursa without significant restrictions in the passive or active range of motion. The bursae are located extra-articularly, meaning the joint space itself remains unaffected when bursitis ensues. As a result, mobility within the joint itself remains unchanged. Additional clinical features include a preference to hold the knee in extension, warmth, erythema, and tenderness to palpation. Diagnosis is primarily clinical, but definitive diagnosis may involve MRI.  

Option Analysis

✅ Prepatellar bursitis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Patellar fracture:
Incorrect: This radiograph does not demonstrate evidence of bony abnormalities and this patient’s symptoms have been going on for weeks.  
❌ Septic arthritis:
Incorrect: Septic arthritis is in the differential of unilateral knee swelling. However, it is unlikely in this case given that the patient is afebrile, is able to bear weight on the affected knee, and can fully flex and extend the knee.  
❌ Pes anserine bursitis:
Incorrect: Pes anserine bursitis typically presents with pain and swelling on the medial aspect of the knee, not anteriorly as seen in this patient.
❌ Patellar tendonitis:
Incorrect: Patellar tendonitis will often present with anterior knee pain. However, significant swelling is typically not seen.

questions.text:
A 36-year-old woman who has no significant past medical history presents to the emergency department for evaluation following a motor vehicle collision. According to emergency medical services, the patient was the unrestrained driver of a vehicle traveling approximately 45 miles per hour that hit into the back of a stationary truck. Upon arrival, the patient is boarded, collared, and states she has pain in the back of the neck. The patient states, “My neck is killing me. I slammed my chin on the steering wheel”. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 104/min, respirations are 21/min, blood pressure is 172/94 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. A cervical spine radiograph is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?  


Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

choices.text: Avulsion fracture of C3 spinous process
Vertebral body compression fracture of C2

questions.solution:
This patient presents after a motor vehicle collision wherein she likely sustained a hyperextension injury to the neck. The radiograph demonstrates spondylolisthesis of the C2 vertebra, which can be an unstable cervical spine injury. However this type of fracture typically does not cause spinal cord injury.  

Traumatic spondylolisthesis and associated fractures of the C2 vertebra are also known as “hangman’s injuries” or “hangman’s fracture”—since this was a common finding in post-mortem autopsies of criminals executed by hanging. This injury pattern now most commonly occurs from car crashes and falls. It is caused by forcible hyperextension of the head, usually with the distraction of the neck, or without distraction of the neck but with axial loading.  

The fracture typically occurs in the axis's superior and inferior articular processes, with an associated displacement of the C2 vertebra anteriorly on C3. Spinal cord or brainstem injury can occur if the fracture is unstable. Radiographically, it can be identified by anterior displacement of the C2 vertebra relative to C3 If the fracture is stable then treatment is typically conservative with external fixation or bracing.  

Option Analysis

✅ Spondylolisthesis of C2  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Burst fracture of C1  :
Incorrect: A burst fracture of C1 is also known as a Jefferson fracture. It can be an unstable cervical spine injury, but typically is not and is treated with a collar. This injury more commonly occurs after a direct compression force is applied to the top of the head, and it may be difficult to identify on radiographs.  
❌ Odontoid fracture:
Incorrect: The odontoid process, or dens, is a superior projecting bony element from the second cervical vertebrae that may become fractured during hyperextension or hyperflexion injuries. An associated fracture of the dens is not apparent on this radiograph. It is best identified on CT imaging of the head and neck.  
❌ Avulsion fracture of C3 spinous process:
Incorrect: An avulsion fracture of a spinous process, also referred to as a “clay-shoveler fracture”, is a rare fracture which is considered a stable cervical spine injury. There is no evidence of a C3 spinous process fracture in this patient’s radiograph.  
❌ Vertebral body compression fracture of C2:
Incorrect: Vertebral body compression fractures most commonly arise in patients with  underlying osteoporosis. They appear as a wedge-shaped vertebral body on radiographic imaging.

questions.text:
A 41-year-old man presents to the emergency department to be evaluated for recent-onset of sharp abdominal pain. The patient’s symptoms began during weight lifting. The patent was performing a bench press and immediately afterward felt sharp abdominal pain in the right lower quadrant. The pain has been constant and increasing in severity. Vital signs are within normal limits. Past surgical history is notable for a Roux-en-Y gastric bypass performed one year ago. There is abdominal guarding on physical examination. Palpation of the abdomen causes severe pain. A stat CT is done, revealing the finding shown below. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s symptoms?    


Image reproduced from Indian Journal of Radiology and Imaging
questions.solution:
The greater omentum is an important sheet-like curtain of vascularized fatty tissue which hangs down from the greater curvature of the stomach, draping over the intestines. The purpose of the greater omentum is threefold: 1) Fatty thermal insulation and a physical promotility agent for the intestines, 2) physical barrier to protect against infections and wounds, and 3) centralized hub for immune activity.    

Pathologies involving the omentum are rare. The greater omentum can undergo torsion, whereby the omentum pivots on its long axis and cuts off its blood supply. The greater omentum can whorl around a nidus of adhesion or tumor, as is seen in the CT above. Since the omentum is vascularized, this whorling is an acute surgical emergency as it can cause acute ischemia and subsequent necrosis of the omentum. Torsion of the greater omentum can present as an acute abdomen. The twisted segment is often localized to the right-side segment and presentation with acute right lower quadrant abdominal pain can mimic acute appendicitis. However nausea and vomiting are typically absent.    

Greater omental torsion can be primary when there is no underlying abnormality or secondary when an underlying lesion is the cause of torsion such as with post-surgical adhesions as seen in this case. It has been postulated that torsion of the greater omentum is caused by the greater length and mobility of the right side of the omentum due to the differing embyologic origins of the omentum.  

Option Analysis

❌ Developmental anomaly:
Incorrect: These findings are characteristic of omental torsion. Developmental anomalies of the omentum may cause torsion. However, they are infrequent and almost exclusively found in children.  
❌ Herniation of abdominal contents  :
Incorrect: Abdominal hernias typically cause mild pain or pressure at the site of the hernia, and patients may feel or see a bulge at the outer abdomen. This patient’s imaging,  past medical history, and severe abdominal pain suggest omental torsion, not herniation.  
✅ Post-surgical adhesions:
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Bulk-forming tumor:
Incorrect: Tumors are an important cause of secondary omental torsion. However, given this patient’s past medical history of multiple abdominal surgeries and the absence  of an intra-abdominal tumor on CT, it is more likely that post-surgical adhesions lead to omental torsion.  
❌ Intestinal perforation:
Incorrect: Perforation of the GI tract can lead to pneumoperitoneum that can present with severe abdominal pain. However the CT does not show evidence of free air in the peritoneal cavity and the patient’s last surgery was one year ago.

questions.text:
A 56-year-old man presents to the emergency department to be evaluated for severe diffuse abdominal pain. He has associated nausea and vomiting. Past medical history is notable for four months of aching and burning epigastric pain, which worsens after eating. He has been managing the epigastric pain by taking over-the-counter antacids. At arrival, temperature is 37.9°C (100.2°F), pulse is 120/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 120/66 mm Hg. Diffuse abdominal tenderness to palpation is noted on the physical examination. An upright abdominal radiograph is obtained and shown below. Which of the following best explains this patient’s underlying pathology?  


Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

choices.text: Interposed colon between the liver and diaphragm

questions.solution:
This patient presents with severe abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting in the setting of chronic peptic ulcer disease. Imaging reveals free air under the diaphragm. The air in the lungs and gas under the diaphragm show the diaphragmatic contour in the chest radiograph above. In combination, these findings are concerning for pneumoperitoneum secondary to a perforated peptic ulcer.  

Pneumoperitoneum is a severe finding warranting urgent surgical management. The most common causes of pneumoperitoneum include peptic ulcer disease (45%), followed by appendicitis (18.5%), typhoid fever (12%), tuberculosis (10%), and trauma (9%). There are also non-surgical pathologies that are associated with pneumoperitoneum. However, these are exceedingly rare.    

An erect chest x-ray is the most sensitive imaging for diagnosing pneumoperitoneum. If large volume pneumoperitoneum is present, subdiaphragmatic free gas and a continuous diaphragm sign may be seen as in the image in this case. Other signs of pneumoperitoneum on radiographic imaging include:  

  1.  Cupola/saddlebag/mustache sign-seen on a supine radiograph, refers to air accumulation underneath the central tendon of the diaphragm in the midline. 
  2.  Rigler sign-air outlining both sides of the bowel wall. 
  3.  Lucent liver sign-reduction of liver opacity due to air located anterior to the liver. 
  4.  Football sign-seen in massive pneumoperitoneum, where the abdominal cavity is outlined by gas. 
  5.  Silver sign-also called a falciform ligament sign, wherein air outlines the falciform ligament. 
  6.  Inverted V sign-air outlining lateral umbilical ligaments (inferior epigastric vessels). 
  7.  Doge cap sign-triangular collection of gas in Morison pouch. 
  8.  Telltale triangle sign-triangular air pocket between three loops of bowel. 
  9.  Urachus sign-ar outlining the middle umbilical ligament. 

Option Analysis

❌ Interposed colon between the liver and diaphragm:
Incorrect: Chilaiditi sign is the radiographic observation of a distended gaseous colon segment interposed between the liver and diaphragm. Chilaiditi syndrome may present with a range of abdominal symptoms due to this interposed segment of colon. It can sometimes be mistaken for pneumoperitoneum. This patient’s abdominal radiograph shows a well-defined diaphragmatic contour indicating pneumoperitoneum.  
❌ Congestive heart failure:
Incorrect: The radiographic signs of congestive heart failure include cardiomegaly, prominent pulmonary vascular markings, and pleural effusions. These findings are absent in this patient’s imaging and he is not presenting with shortness of breath.  
❌ Ischemic bowel:
Incorrect: Ischemia of the small intestine can lead to small bowel perforation and pneumoperitoneum. However this patient’s history of epigastric pain after eating relieved with antacids is more suggestive of a perforated peptic ulcer.  
✅ Perforated peptic ulcer:
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Perforating tumor:
Incorrect: A perforating tumor can be a cause of small bowel perforation, however in addition to acute abdominal symptoms it would present with additional symptoms that would have been ongoing and indicative of underlying malignancy such as weight loss, rectal bleeding, and night sweats. This patient’s symptoms are more suggestive of pneumoperitoneum secondary to a perforated peptic ulcer.

questions.text: A 43-year-old man presents to the clinic for a routine checkup. He has persistent hiccups but otherwise feels well. Over the past two months, he has been hiccupping almost daily despite making changes to his diet. He has tried several home remedies for this issue, but they have been ineffective in managing his symptoms. The patient had previously been hospitalized for COVID-19 pneumonia and was intubated for two weeks. As part of an accelerated clinical trial protocol, he is still receiving low-dose corticosteroids and antiviral medications. At presentation, temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg. The heart and lung examinations are noncontributory. Examination of the oropharynx is unremarkable. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient has prolonged singultus, more commonly known as hiccups.Hiccups are due to involuntary contraction of the diaphragm and intercostal muscles leading to sudden inspiration followed by closing of the vocal cords. Hiccups are an involuntary action involving a complex reflex arc composed of three units. The afferent limb of nerve conduction comprises the vagus nerve, phrenic nerve, and sympathetic visceral nerves. The nerve signals are brought to the medulla oblongata and reticular formation. The efferent portion of the reflex is transmitted by the phrenic nerve supplying the diaphragm and intercostal muscles. Any irritation along the arc can lead to hiccups.  

There are many causes for hiccups, but the most common cause is gastroesophageal reflux disease. Moreover, spicy foods, alcohol, and carbonated beverages are also known to cause hiccups. Finally, chemotherapeutic agents (e.g. cisplatin) and glucocorticoids (e.g. dexamethasone) can cause hiccups.    

Treatment of hiccups involves simple physical maneuvers such as Valsalva, carotid massage, and supra-supramaximal inspiration. For persistent and intractable hiccups, pharmacotherapy in the form of metoclopramide, baclofen, and gabapentin has been shown to provide relief.   

Option Analysis

❌ Recurrent laryngeal nerve injury:
Incorrect: Injury to the recurrent laryngeal nerve can result in vocal cord paralysis and voice hoarseness. However, this condition would not typically result in hiccups.   
✅ Corticosteroid use:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Diet:
Incorrect: Certain diets which incorporate high amounts of carbonated beverages can cause hiccups. However, this patient’s prolonged symptoms, which have been ongoing for several months, suggest another pathological process.  
❌ Viral infection:
Incorrect: Infection with COVD-19 and other respiratory viruses is not associated with prolonged hiccups lasting over 2 months.  
❌ Phrenic nerve synkinesia:
Incorrect: Synkinsea is a rare neurological phenomenon wherein voluntary muscle movements lead to simultaneous involuntary movements of other muscles. It can sometimes be seen in the facial nerves in response to corticosteroid therapy to treat Bell palsy. Synkinesia has no role in the development of hiccups.

questions.text:
A 26-year-old man is fighting in an international mixed martial arts contest. During the tournament, he sustains repeated abdominal blows from the opponent, followed by repeated blows to the left temple that render him unconscious. An on-site sports physician immediately assesses the patient. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 136/min, respirations are 25/min, and blood pressure is 130/66 mmHg. The patient’s oxygen saturation is 92%. As the patient awakens, he reflexively guards his left lower chest. An urgent chest radiograph is done on-site and is shown below. Which of the following explains why the diaphragmatic hernia seen below occurred on the left side, as opposed to the right?  


Image reproduced from Radiopedia

choices.text: Absence of floating ribs on the left
Fewer lung lobes on the left
Location of the spleen beneath left hemidiaphragm

questions.solution:
This patient sustained significant blunt force trauma to the abdomen and developed an acquired diaphragmatic hernia (ADH). ADH usually arises due to a sudden increase in pleuroperitoneal pressure resulting from blunt or penetrating trauma. Acquired diaphragmatic hernias occur at sites of weakness in the diaphragm that arise from embryonic fusion sites. They almost always occur in the left hemidiaphragm. This phenomenon occurs because the right hemidiaphragm is protected by the large size of the liver.    

Hiatal hernias also occur when gastrointestinal contents protrude into the chest cavity through an opening in the diaphragm. They protrude through the opening in the diaphragm called the hiatus. Hiatal hernias occur when the upper part of the stomach pushes up through the diaphragm into the chest cavity. There are two types of hiatal hernias: sliding hernias and paraesophageal hernias. Sliding hernias occur when the fundus of the stomach bulges directly into the thoracic cavity. In contrast, paraesophageal hernias occur when the gastric fundus bulges into the thoracic cavity adjacent to the esophagus. Sliding hernias are generally asymptomatic and more common than paraesophageal hernias. Paraesophageal hernias have the possibility of strangulation and, as a result, more often warrant surgical repair.  



Option Analysis

❌ Decreased bone mineral density:
Incorrect: This patient’s imaging reveals a left-sided diaphragmatic hernia without any evidence of fracture that could have been caused by low bone mineral density in conjunction with trauma. Moreover, this patient’s bones do not appear osteopenic on imaging.  
❌ Absence of floating ribs on the left:
