Incorrect: The floating ribs are the lower ribs (11 and 12) that do not attach to the sternum. Floating ribs are normally present bilaterally and are seen in the image above. They do not play a role in developing diaphragmatic hernias.  
❌ Fewer lung lobes on the left:
Incorrect: The left lung has two lobes, whereas the right lung has three. However, the number of lobes does not account for why patients are more likely to develop left-sided diaphragmatic hernias.  
❌ Location of the spleen beneath left hemidiaphragm:
Incorrect: The spleen is located below the left hemidiaphragm. It does not play a protective role against diaphragmatic hernias on the left side. In contrast, the large size of the liver located below the right hemidiaphragm is thought to be protective against right diaphragmatic hernias.  
✅ Unprotected embryological points of weakness:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman comes to the office for evaluation of a red rash over her right breast for the past three months. The rash is itchy and feels rough to the touch. The patient has tried applying emollients without relief. Her last menstrual period was three years ago. Past medical history includes type II diabetes mellitus. Family history is significant for ovarian cancer in the patient’s grandmother at age 40. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows redness and swelling of the right breast without palpable masses. The overlying skin appears indurated and retracted. The right nipple appears normal, and the left breast examination is unremarkable. This patient’s physical examination findings are most likely due to the involvement of which of the following breast structures?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with findings consistent with a peau d’orange rash due to the involvement of axillary lymph nodes.  This finding is highly associated with inflammatory breast cancer. Axillary lymph nodes serve as the most common site of breast cancer metastasis, and peau d'orange manifests secondary to cutaneous lymphatic edema and obstruction. Clinically, this rash is characterized by a thickened, leather-like appearance of the skin. Prominent “puffy” skin between dimpled pores gives the overlying skin the appearance of an orange peel (peau d’orange sign).  

Breast cancer often presents as a palpable breast mass that is hard, immobile, and with irregular borders. It is most commonly found in the upper outer quadrants with associated skin dimpling. Cancerous invasion of the glandular tissue and fibrosis may pull on the breast's suspensory ligaments, resulting in retraction of the nipple.  

When breast cancer invades the retro mammary space or the pectoral fascia, or when it metastasizes to the interpectoral nodes, the breast elevates when the muscle contracts. This finding usually signals advanced cancer. Furthermore, local cancerous invasion of the pectoral fascia and pectoralis major may result in deep fixation of the breast tissue.



Nipple retraction
Reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

Option Analysis

❌ Retromammary space:
Incorrect: Breast cancer cells can spread contiguously, including the retro mammary space or the pectoral fascia. Peau d’orange appearance in this patient suggests axillary lymph node invasion. When breast cancer metastasizes to the interpectoral nodes, the breast elevates when the pectoral muscle contracts.  
✅ Axillary lymph nodes:
Correct: See Main Explanation  
❌ Nipple  :
Incorrect: Involvement of the nipple occurs in patients with Paget disease of the breast, characterized by eczematous exudate over the nipple and areola.  
❌ Suspensory ligament:
Incorrect: Dimpling of the skin can result from the invasion of glandular tissue and fibrosis, which may place tension on the suspensory ligaments of the breast. This most commonly presents with retraction of the nipple and distortion of the breast contour.  
❌ Lactiferous duct:
Incorrect: The lactiferous ducts connect the nipple to the mammary lobules for lactation. Spread of ductal carcinoma through the ductal system may present with nipple discharge.

questions.text: A 76-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department following sudden onset, right-sided weakness. Past medical history is significant for hypertension and coronary artery disease. Temperature is 37.7°C (99.8°F), pulse is 83/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 156/90 mmHg. Neurological examination demonstrates flaccid paralysis of the right upper and lower extremities, tongue deviation to the left, slurred speech, hyperreflexic deep tendon reflexes on the right, as well as decreased right-sided proprioception. Sensation is intact and the patient is oriented to person, place, and time. Which of the following anatomic areas of the brain is most likely affected given this patient’s presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with complete upper and lower limb paralysis, decreased proprioception, and deviation of the tongue with protrusion, suggestive of medial medullary syndrome. This condition often arises secondary to infarction of the paramedian branches of the anterior spinal artery.  

The anterior spinal artery supplies the anterior two-thirds of the spinal cord and lower medulla at the midline. The vessel lies in the anterior median fissure of the spinal cord with both penetrating and circumferential branches. Clinical features of medial medullary ischemia include:  

  • Contralateral hemiparesis due to involvement of the lateral corticospinal tract. 
  • Sensory symptoms related to ischemia of the medial lemniscus include decreased contralateral proprioception and pressure vibratory sensation. 
  • Ipsilateral tongue paralysis is the least common but most topographically localizing sign of medial medullary infarction and is due to infarction of the hypoglossal nucleus. 

Option Analysis

❌ Dominant parietal lobe  :
Incorrect: Gerstmann syndrome results from damage to the angular gyrus of the dominant parietal lobe and is characterized by agraphia (inability to write), acalculia (inability to carry out mathematical calculations), finger agnosia, and left-right disorientation.  
❌ Dorsolateral medulla:
Incorrect: Ischemic injury to the dorsolateral medulla can result in Wallenberg syndrome, secondary to infarction of the posterior inferior cerebellar artery. Patients typically present with loss of pain/temperature over the ipsilateral face and contralateral body, ipsilateral bulbar muscle weakness, vertigo, ipsilateral limb ataxia, and Horner syndrome.  
✅ Medial medulla:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Posterior limb of internal capsule:
Incorrect: Infarction in the posterior limb of the internal capsule results in a pure motor stroke. Patients typically present with contralateral hemiparesis without sensory loss or cortical signs (e.g. aphasia). The most common etiology of a lacunar stroke is hypertension.  
❌ Dorsolateral thalamus:
Incorrect: Acute strokes of the dorsolateral thalamus typically present with contralateral hemisensory loss. Patients often develop significant pain on the side of their deficit (thalamic pain syndrome) weeks to months following the initial insult.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman comes to the office to be evaluated for recurrent episodes of epigastric bloating and crampy pain. The pain usually begins after eating and is relieved by vomiting or lying on her stomach. The patient is a dancer and joined a training program a few months ago. She has lost 30-lbs (13.6 kg) over the past two months while on a “crash diet.” Past medical history is noncontributory. Temperature is 36.7°C (98°F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 135/75 mmHg. Physical examination shows a mildly distended and tender abdomen with high-pitched bowel sounds. A plain abdominal x-ray reveals findings suggestive of proximal small bowel obstruction. The upper gastrointestinal series demonstrates a marked delay in the passage of the contrast from the duodenum into the more distal small bowel. The delay resolves when the patient takes a knee-chest position. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Selective hypersensitization of visceral afferent nerves

questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation of recurrent epigastric pain aggravated with food consumption and relieved with vomiting or lying prone, combined with the imaging findings, are consistent with superior mesenteric artery (SMA) syndrome.   

The SMA typically leaves the aorta at an angle of 45 degrees. If the angle diminishes to an angle less than 22 degrees, the transverse portion of the duodenum can get entrapped between the SMA and aorta, leading to symptoms of partial bowel obstruction.    

Acute loss of mesenteric fat (e.g., recent weight loss, low body weight, severe burns, and prolonged bed rest) is thought to permit the artery to drop posteriorly, trapping the bowel and causing an intermittent obstruction. It can also occur in patients with pronounced lordosis or after surgical correction of scoliosis, as this procedure lengthens the spine resulting in decreased mobility of SMA.  

Patients often have epigastric bloating and crampy pain, particularly after eating that may be relieved with vomiting. The symptoms may resolve with the patient in the prone, left lateral decubitus, or a knee-chest position, which increases the angle between the SMA and the aorta. It may present acutely with signs and symptoms of small bowel obstruction or chronically with recurrent episodes of abdominal pain, vague abdominal symptoms, and early satiety. Physical examination may show abdominal distension, a succussion splash, and high-pitched bowel sounds. The diagnosis is established based on clinical features and noninvasive imaging that demonstrates an abnormal angle between the aorta and the superior mesenteric artery.  



Option Analysis

❌ Transmural inflammation of the intestine:
Incorrect: Transmural inflammation of the intestine is seen in Crohn disease. Patients typically present with chronic right lower quadrant pain (not epigastric pain) and other constitutional symptoms. Moreover, the delayed passage of contrast via the duodenum suggests duodenal compression.  
❌ Intermittent increase of intra-gallbladder pressure:
Incorrect: Biliary colic occurs as the gallbladder contracts against an obstructing stone, leading to an intermittent increase of intra-gallbladder pressure. The pain is typically episodic and is located in the right upper quadrant.   
❌ Progressive pancreatic inflammation:
Incorrect: Pain accompanied by malabsorption may be due to chronic pancreatitis. It is, however, an unlikely diagnosis in the absence of risk factors (e.g. heavy alcohol use). An abdominal x-ray may show pancreatic calcification.  
✅ Duodenal compression between arteries:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Selective hypersensitization of visceral afferent nerves:
Incorrect: Selective hypersensitization of visceral afferent nerves is thought to be the underlying cause of irritable bowel syndrome. Weight loss and recurrent epigastric pain with bloating relieved with vomiting in this patient suggest an alternative underlying cause.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man comes to the office due to intermittent heaviness and paresthesias of the right arm. The patient has experienced multiple episodes over the past two months, especially while playing table tennis. Each episode is associated with nausea, dizziness, and visual disturbance. The patient has not had any falls or loss of consciousness. Past medical history includes hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include metformin, enalapril, and atorvastatin. The patient has smoked one pack of cigarettes for the past forty years and drinks alcohol occasionally. Orthostatic vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates decreased radial and brachial pulses of the right upper extremity when compared to the left upper extremity. Skin over the right upper extremity feels cooler than the left. The remainder of the cardiopulmonary and neurologic exam are within normal limits. CT angiogram is performed and reveals a condition that results in reversal of blood flow through a vascular structure. Reverse blood flow through which of the following vessels is the most likely underlying etiology of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation is consistent with subclavian steal syndrome (SSS)--a constellation of signs and symptoms that arise secondary to retrograde blood flow through the ipsilateral vertebral artery or internal thoracic artery due to stenosis and/or occlusion of the subclavian artery. In this condition, the affected arm is often supplied by blood flowing in a retrograde direction down the ipsilateral vertebral artery at the expense of the vertebrobasilar circulation.  

Given this patient's vascular risk factors (i.e., hypercholesterolemia, diabetes mellitus, hypertension), an atherosclerotic occlusive plaque in the right subclavian artery is the most likely culprit of his symptoms. Reduced blood flow through the subclavian artery results in symptoms of recurrent heaviness with exertion, paresthesias, as well as decreased pulses and cooler skin.  

Over time, stenosis of the subclavian artery increases in blood flow through the contralateral vertebral artery to the basilar artery, followed by retrograde flow through the ipsilateral vertebral artery, away from the brainstem. Ultimately, this may result in presyncopal symptoms with exertion of the affected arm including lightheadedness, nausea, and blurred vision. Other etiologies of SSS include Takayasu arteritis, Giant cell arteritis, and thoracic aortic dissection.  

Option Analysis

❌ Right subclavian artery:
Incorrect: Given this patient's vascular risk factors (i.e., hypercholesterolemia, diabetes mellitus, hypertension), he most likely has an atherosclerotic occlusive plaque of the right subclavian artery. This explains the heaviness, paresthesia, decreased pulses, and cooler skin of her right arm. Blood flow is blocked rather than reversed in this vessel.  
✅ Right vertebral artery:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Left vertebral artery:
Incorrect: Reduced blood flow to the stenosed side is compensated for by contralateral circulation (from the left vertebral artery in this case). In this case, there is increased blood flow from the unaffected side (left) to the affected side (right) via the vertebral arteries.  
❌ Left subclavian artery:
Incorrect: Although the left subclavian artery compensates for reduced blood flow in the right subclavian artery, it is not the underlying cause of this patient’s symptoms.  
❌ Left posterior cerebral artery  :
Incorrect: Reversed flow in the left posterior cerebral artery results in reduced perfusion to the left occipital lobe. This may result in contralateral hemianopia due to infarction of the visual cortex.

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman comes to the clinic due to involuntary loss of urine and chronic constipation. The leakage of urine occurs in coughing, sneezing, or lifting heavy weights. Past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and hypercholesterolemia. The patient has had two forceps-assisted vaginal deliveries. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 105/75 mmHg. Pelvic examination reveals dribbling of urine when asked to cough and a mass at the vaginal opening. Post void residual urine is 40ml. Urinalysis is negative for leukocyte esterase or nitrites. She undergoes a paravaginal defect repair. During the procedure, a nerve passing through the obturator foramen is injured. The patient is most likely to develop sensory loss over which of the following areas?
questions.solution:
This postmenopausal patient has stress urinary incontinence, constipation, and a mass per vaginum. She most likely has pelvic organ prolapse (POP) complicated by stress urinary incontinence. POP management involves pelvic floor exercises, mid-urethral sling placements, or surgery to repair the pervaginal defect.    

The obturator nerve is formed from the second, third, and fourth lumbar roots. It courses through the pelvis, posterior to the psoas major muscle, and the sacrum until it enters the obturator canal within the obturator foramen. In the thigh, it divides into anterior and posterior divisions. Both divisions supply motor innervation to the adductor muscles of the thigh. The anterior division carries sensory input from the hip joint and the medial thigh, while the posterior division carries input from the knee joint.    

The obturator nerve can be injured during surgeries that involve dissection in the obturator fossa. These include pelvic resection surgeries for endometriosis, pelvic lymph node dissection in gynecological malignancies, pervaginal defect repairs, and retropubic sling placements for pelvic organ prolapse. It can also be compressed by pelvic tumors or injured by pelvic trauma. A diagnosis of obturator neuropathy is primarily clinical. Symptoms include sensory loss over the medial aspect of the thigh and weakness in leg adduction.   

Option Analysis

✅ Medial thigh :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Anterior thigh :
Incorrect: The cutaneous branch of the femoral nerve supplies the anterior thigh. It exits the pelvis and passes along the femoral canal. It does not traverse through the obturator canal.   
❌ Medial leg :
Incorrect: The medial leg is innervated by the cutaneous branches of the saphenous nerve, a branch of the femoral nerve. It does not originate in the pelvis and is not likely to be damaged in this patient.   
❌ Medial foot :
Incorrect: The superficial peroneal nerve innervates the medial aspect of the foot. It is the branch of the common peroneal nerve and is unlikely to be injured in pelvic surgeries.   
❌ Posterior perineum :
Incorrect: The pudendal nerve provides sensory innervation to the perineum and the lower one-third of the vagina. It passes along the ischial spine and through the pudendal canal. It does not course through the obturator foramen.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman comes to the emergency room with nausea, vomiting, and severe abdominal pain. The pain began 6 hours ago and has become more severe over the last 2 hours. Past medical history includes seasonal depression and placement of a progestin-releasing IUD a month ago. Her last menstrual period was two weeks ago. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 90/75 mmHg. Abdominal examination reveals tenderness in the left lower quadrant. Bimanual examination reveals a tender, palpable left adnexal mass and visible IUD strings at the vaginal orifice. The urine pregnancy test is negative. The total leukocyte count is 8000/mm3. A transabdominal ultrasound reveals a hyperechoic adnexal mass with the decreased arterial flow. An explorative laparotomy is performed. The infundibulopelvic ligament is ligated during the procedure, and the pathological specimen is removed.  Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presented with acute onset of abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and a tender adnexal mass with the decreased arterial flow. These findings are suggestive of ovarian torsion, which necessitates urgent intervention.    

Ovarian torsion is a common gynecological emergency among women of reproductive age, although it can occur in any age group. Clinical symptoms include sudden onset abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting with or without an adnexal mass. The most important risk factor for adnexal torsion is the presence of ovarian cysts or tumors, particularly those greater than 5 cm in size. Ovarian tumors are more common amongst women of reproductive age as most benign tumors (functional cyst, corpus luteum cysts) are associated with hormonal changes and ovulation induction therapy. Pathogenesis of ovarian torsion involves rotation of the ovary around the axis of its ligamentous attachment, the infundibulopelvic ligament. The presence of a large ovarian mass increases the likelihood of torsion.    

The infundibulopelvic ligament/suspensory ligament of the ovary attaches the superior pole of the ovary to the pelvic sidewall and contains the ovarian vessels. Rotation around its axis can impair the blood supply to the ovaries, which are detected as decreased blood flow on a doppler USG. Compression of the blood vessels impairs lymphatic and venous drainage and impedes arterial supply. Ovarian edema can progressively worsen and result in ischemia, local hemorrhage, and infarction complications.   

Option Analysis

✅ Ovarian torsion :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Ectopic pregnancy :
Incorrect: An extrauterine pregnancy is unlikely to cause abdominal pain as her last menstrual period was two weeks ago, and she has a negative pregnancy test.   
❌ Tubo-Ovarian abscess :
Incorrect: A tubo-ovarian abscess would cause fever and leukocytosis, neither of which are present in this patient. In addition, an abscess usually appears as an anechoic or hypoechoic fluid collection on ultrasound.   
❌ Uterine perforation :
Incorrect: Placement of IUDs can result in complications such as uterine perforation. It may present with severe, acute onset abdominal pain as seen in this patient. However, it is more likely to occur at the time of placement or immediately after and is unlikely in this case.   
❌ Endometriosis :
Incorrect: Endometriosis classically presents with chronic pelvic pain, infertility, and dysmenorrhea. This patient's acute onset of symptoms makes this diagnosis unlikely.

questions.text: A 44-year-old woman undergoes a total thyroidectomy due to the presence of follicular thyroid cancer. On a postoperative day one, the patient develops a hoarse, breathy voice. Vital signs are within normal limits, and physical examination demonstrates an intact postoperative incision without erythema or edema over the anterior neck. Which of the following structures was most likely injured intraoperatively?
questions.solution:
Several structures are at risk of iatrogenic injury in patients undergoing thyroidectomy and hemithyroidectomy. One of the structures at risk of injury is the recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN).  Unilateral injury presents as temporary or permanent hoarseness and risk of aspiration (especially with liquids). In contrast, bilateral injury causes stridor and acute airway obstruction as the recurrent laryngeal nerve supplies the only abductor of the vocal cords, the posterior cricoarytenoid muscle.  The paired recurrent laryngeal nerves branch off the vagus nerve and travel in the tracheoesophageal groove until they enter the larynx at the cricothyroid joint. The RLN supplies innervation to all of the intrinsic muscles of the larynx, minus the cricothyroid muscles, as well as sensation to the larynx below the level of the vocal cords.

In addition to the RLN, several additional structures are at risk of injury during thyroidectomy, including the parathyroid glands, superior laryngeal nerve (SLN), vagus nerve, thyroid ima artery, and common carotid arteries (and their local branches). Injury to the vascular structures often results in hematoma/seroma formation and brisk bleeding intraoperatively. Injury to the SLN manifests as vocal fatigue and subtle changes in voice quality, pitch, and projection (in contrast to true hoarseness with RLN injury). Injury to the vagus nerve may result in the larynx's sensory and motor deficits.

Option Analysis

✅ Recurrent laryngeal nerve:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Superior laryngeal nerve:
Incorrect: Isolated superior laryngeal nerve injury only produces vocal fatigue and subtle changes in voice quality involving timbre, pitch, and voice projection. This patient presents with vocal cord paralysis.  
❌ Thyroid ima artery:
Incorrect: The thyroid ima artery is an unpaired, variable branch of the brachiocephalic artery that supplies the thyroid and the isthmus. When injured during head and neck procedures, it can be a source of brisk and difficult to control bleeding.  
❌ Common carotid artery:
Incorrect: Injury to the common carotid artery results in hematoma formation and possible neurologic deficits secondary to ischemic or thromboembolic events.  
❌ Vagus nerve:
Incorrect: Injury to the vagus nerve may result in paralysis of both the superior laryngeal nerve and the recurrent branch of the laryngeal nerve. This can result in both sensory and motor deficits of the larynx. Injury to the main trunk of the vagus nerve is rare during thyroid surgery.

questions.text: A 31-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician for follow-up regarding facial pain. The patient states, “The symptoms have become so bothersome, I can’t sleep at night and none of the medications I’m taking are working.” The patient reports intermittent stabbing pain along the left side of her face below the eye brought on by brushing her teeth or putting makeup on. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates reproducible pain with light tapping of the upper teeth. Tapping of the lower teeth does not elicit pain. Which of the following nerves is implicated in the pathogenesis of this patient’s disease?
questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation of trigeminal neuralgia, a condition characterized by recurrent episodes of pain in the trigeminal nerve distribution (CN V). This patient’s pain is localized to CN V's maxillary nerve branch (V2).

Trigeminal neuralgia is a poorly understood condition but is thought to be due to trigeminal nerve root compression. Clinically, this disease presents as recurrent, sudden onset stabbing pain along the trigeminal nerve's V2 (maxillary) or V3 (mandibular) branches, with onset triggered by minor stimuli such as touch, wind, or chewing food. Trigeminal neuralgia is a unilateral condition; however, it can occur bilaterally in usual cases, typically caused by multiple sclerosis.  

Option Analysis

✅ Maxillary nerve:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Mandibular nerve:
Incorrect: The mandibular nerve, a branch of the trigeminal nerve, provides sensory information to the lower jaw and cheek while also providing motor function to several muscles of mastication. While this branch of the trigeminal nerve may also be implicated in cases of trigeminal neuralgia, this patient’s exam suggests disease limited to the maxillary nerve branch.  
❌ Ophthalmic nerve:
Incorrect: V1 supplies sensory function to the scalp and forehead, the upper eyelid, the conjunctiva and cornea of the eye, the nose. It is not commonly implicated in cases of trigeminal neuralgia (<5% of cases).  
❌ Facial nerve:
Incorrect: The facial nerve, or cranial nerve VII, provides innervation to the muscles of facial expression and taste sensation to the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. It is not implicated in the pathogenesis of trigeminal neuralgia.  
❌ Glossopharyngeal nerve:
Incorrect: Motor function of cranial nerve IX or the glossopharyngeal nerve includes innervation of the stylopharyngeus muscle, elevating the larynx and pharynx during speaking and swallowing.

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman presents to her maxillofacial surgeon for follow-up after having her lower third molars removed one week ago. The patient states since the surgery, she has had limited sensation over her lower teeth and accidentally bit the inside of her cheek. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates diminished sensation over the lower teeth and chin. Oral examination demonstrates normal healing of the extraction sites. Which of the following nerves is most likely injured given this patient’s presentation?
questions.solution:
The inferior alveolar nerve, a branch of the mandibular nerve, provides sensation to the lower teeth and terminates as the mental nerve. This nerve is at high risk of injury during molar extractions (particularly third molars or “wisdom teeth”) as it travels through the mandible. Damage to this nerve results in sensory deficits and mental nerve distribution.  

Option Analysis

✅ Inferior alveolar nerve:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Superior alveolar nerve:
Incorrect: The superior alveolar nerve, a branch of the maxillary nerve, provides sensory information to the maxillary teeth, gums, and sinus. This patient has a sensory deficit along the mandible, not the maxilla.  
❌ Infraorbital nerve:
Incorrect: Damage to the infraorbital nerve manifests with sensory deficits over the lower eyelid, side of the nose, moveable part of the nasal septum, anterior cheek, or upper lip.  
❌ Mental nerve:
Incorrect: The mental nerve is the terminal branch of the inferior alveolar nerve and provides sensory information to the chin and lower lip. This patient’s presentation is consistent with the entire inferior alveolar nerve damage.  
❌ Zygomatic nerve:
Incorrect: The zygomatic nerve, a branch of the maxillary branch of the trigeminal nerve, supplies sensory information over the cheek and temple. This nerve is unlikely to be damaged based on this patient’s recent surgery.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of abdominal pain and confusion for the past 24 hours. The pain is stabbing in character, worse in the upper abdomen, and is associated with nausea and non-bloody vomiting. Past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include metformin and atorvastatin. Family history is noncontributory. Temperature is 38.9°C (102°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 85/55 mmHg. Physical examination shows that the patient is oriented to the person but not to time and place. Mucous membranes are dry and capillary refill is delayed. Skin and sclera are icteric. Abdominal examination shows marked tenderness in the right upper quadrant and epigastric region without rebound tenderness or guarding. Laboratory results are shown below. Ultrasound of the abdomen is suggestive of an impacted gallstone. Which of the following is the most likely location of gallstone impaction due to this patient’s symptoms?  

 Laboratory features 
 Laboratory value  Result 
 Hemoglobin  14.5 g/dL 
 Leukocyte count  150,000/mm3 
 Platelet count    230,000 mm3 
 Serum electrolytes  
 Sodium  137 mEq/L 
 Potassium  4.5 mEq/L 
 Chloride  106 mEq/L 
 Bicarbonate  17 mEq/L 
 Bilirubin   
 Total   2.8 mg/dL 
 Direct  2.2 mg/dL 
 Alanine aminotransferase (ALT, GPT  65 U/L 
 Aspartate aminotransferase (AST, GOT  30 U/L 
 Lipase  65 U/L
questions.solution:
This patient with fever, jaundice, and right upper quadrant pain (RUQ) (aka Charcot triad) most likely has ascending cholangitis, secondary to the gallstone impaction in the common bile duct (CBD). Confusion and hypotension (Reynold pentad) are also sometimes seen in severe cases.  

Gallstones can migrate from the gallbladder into the cystic duct where it can obstruct the bile outflow, causing biliary colic (intense, spasmodic pain located in the right hypochondrium) when the gallbladder contracts. The accumulation of bile can subsequently lead to the development of cholecystitis, which presents clinically as a positive Murphy’s sign, which is pain and discomfort on inspiration when the inflamed gallbladder comes into contact with the examiner's hand in the RUQ.  

Gallstone impaction at the CBD can lead to bacterial invasion of bile from the intestinal flora. This can lead to the development of ascending cholangitis, characterized by Charcot triad. Additionally, when impacted in the main pancreatic duct, it can cause pancreatitis (e.g., anorexia, malaise, and right upper quadrant pain).  

Finally, an enlarged and inflamed gallbladder can develop communications with adjacent viscera (cholecystoenteric fistula), most commonly between the gallbladder and the duodenum. The stone from here passes freely until it reaches the ileum. It is characterized by signs and symptoms of bowel obstruction.  



Option Analysis

❌ Ileum:
Incorrect: Gallstone ileus is a complication of long-standing cholelithiasis where the gallstone forms a cholecystoenteric fistula between the gallbladder and the adjoint gut (duodenum). The stone from here passes freely until it reaches the ileum (narrowest portion of the intestine). It is characterized by signs and symptoms of bowel obstruction (abdominal pain/distention, nausea/vomiting, high-pitched bowel sounds, and abdominal tenderness). This patient’s presentation is consistent with ascending cholangitis.  
✅ Common bile duct:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Main pancreatic duct:
Incorrect: Gallstones can migrate from the common bile duct and obstruct the main pancreatic duct, leading to pancreatitis, which is inflammation of the pancreas. Symptoms of pancreatitis include anorexia, malaise, and right upper quadrant pain. Serum lipase levels are usually elevated (unlike this patient). Charcot’s triad in this patient is suggestive of common bile duct obstruction.  
❌ Cystic duct:
Incorrect: Gallstones are usually located in the gallbladder but can migrate in the cystic duct, obstructing the bile’s way out of the gallbladder. When the gallbladder contracts, this further leads to biliary colic, which is an intense, spasmodic pain located in the right upper quadrant (RUQ) of the abdomen. The accumulation of bile can also lead to the inflammation and irritation of gallbladder (cholecystitis), presenting as Murphy’s sign (pain/tenderness in the RUQ sufficient to cause an abrupt halt in inspiration) on physical examination. Charcot’s triad in this patient is suggestive of common bile duct obstruction.  
❌ Duodenum:
Incorrect: The caliber of duodenum is typically sufficient to allow the passage of larger gallstones.

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman comes to the office because of weight gain and abdominal discomfort. The patient reports mild, diffuse abdominal discomfort for the past week and a weight gain of 10 lbs (4.5 kg) over the past month. She does not have nausea, vomiting, constipation, or diarrhea. The patient is a truck driver and has not seen a physician in years. She drinks a 6-pack of beer per night. Temperature is 36.9°C (98.5°F), pulse is 136/min, respirations are 10/min, and blood pressure is 82/51 mmHg. Physical examination shows jaundice, hepatosplenomegaly, a flapping hand tremor on wrist extension, and a positive fluid wave. The portal venous pressure is 5 mmHg greater than the inferior vena cava pressure. The patient is at increased risk of developing which of the following secondary to her current condition?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation with ascites, flapping hand tremor, and an elevated pressure in the portal venous system (as compared to systemic venous system) is suggestive of portal hypertension.  

Portal hypertension means increased pressure in the portal venous system. It develops when there is resistance to portal blood flow and is aggravated by increased portal collateral blood flow. It is most commonly caused by liver cirrhosis but can also be caused by vascular obstruction (e.g., portal vein thrombosis, Budd-Chiari syndrome, and schistosomiasis).  

Portal hypertension leads to the formation of portosystemic shunts, which is when blood is diverted away from the portal venous system and backs up into systemic veins at the sites called portal-systemic anastomoses/porto-caval anastomosis. These include: 
  •  Lower esophagus: leads to esophageal varices, which can rupture and lead to an upper gastrointestinal bleeding. 
  •  In the rectum and anal canal: leads to hemorrhoids, which are also enlarged veins that can bleed 
  •  The veins of the anterior abdominal wall, which anastomose with the paraumbilical veins and become varicose. This looks like small snakes radiating under the skin around the umbilicus and is called caput medusae. 
Signs and symptoms of portal hypertension include palmar erythema, petechiae, ascites, anorectal varices, caput medusae, jaundice, and esophageal varices.  



Option Analysis

❌ Splenic vein thrombosis:
Incorrect: Portal hypertension can cause blood to back up into the spleen, causing congestive splenomegaly (enlarged spleen). In contrast, pancreatic inflammation can cause blood clot in the splenic vein and can cause gastric varices.  
❌ Unilateral left-sided ankle swelling:
Incorrect: Unilateral left-sided ankle swelling can result from obstruction of left common iliac vein, left external iliac vein, left femoral vein or any other vein in the lower limbs. Portal hypertension can be associated with bilateral ankle swelling.  
✅ Hemorrhoids:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Varicocele:
Incorrect: Varicocele can occur in association with nutcracker syndrome. The pressure in the left renal vein becomes elevated due to the compression in the region where the vein crosses beneath the aorta and superior mesenteric artery. Pressure can be elevated in the left gonadal vein as well, leading to the development of varicocele. The gonadal vein is not a part of the portal system.  
❌ Mallory-Weiss tear:
Incorrect: Mallory-Weiss tear is characterized by longitudinal mucosal lacerations (intramural dissections) in the distal esophagus and proximal stomach that are usually associated with forceful retching. The upper gastrointestinal bleeding seen in association with portal hypertension is due to bleeding esophageal varices.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman comes to the office for evaluation of right anterior leg pain. She recently joined a fitness program that required resistance training and two hours of brisk walking. The pain is worse at the beginning of exercise and decreases throughout the workout. Past medical history is unremarkable. The patient does not use tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drugs. BMI is 30 kg/m2. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates diffuse tenderness along the posteromedial aspect of the right shin. The remainder of the physical examination is unremarkable. X-ray of the right lower extremity reveals no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with diffuse tenderness over the posteromedial aspect of the right shin, consistent with medial tibial stress syndrome (MTSS), also known as shin splints.  

MTSS is commonly seen in casual runners or in individuals following sudden changes in physical activity. Other risk factors include flare feet, rigid arches, or exercising with improper or worn-out footwear. MTSS is thought to result from inflammation of the anterior and posterior calf musculature and periostitis of the tibia. The most common symptoms of MTSS include diffuse pain along the posteromedial border of the tibia that worsens with running. It is important to differentiate MTSS from tibial stress fractures, which more commonly present with point tenderness, as the latter have potential complications if not cared for properly. Plain radiographs in patients with MTSS are usually normal.  



Option Analysis

❌ Exertional compartment syndrome:
Incorrect: Exertional compartment syndrome occurs in young athletes secondary to increased compartment pressures with exertion. Patients usually present with aching or burning pain in the leg within ten minutes of exercise that slowly resolves within 30-40 minutes following exercise. Diffuse shin tenderness is not typically present.  
✅ Medial tibial stress syndrome:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Stress fracture:
Incorrect: Tibial stress fractures can manifest with anterior leg pain, resembling that of medial tibial stress syndrome. This condition commonly occurs in underweight athletes and presents with point tenderness as opposed to diffuse tenderness.   
❌ Common fibular nerve compression:
Incorrect: The common peroneal nerve is susceptible to injury as it courses laterally around the neck of the fibula. Clinically, it presents with weakness of foot dorsiflexion and eversion as well as sensory loss over the dorsum of the foot and lateral shin and between first and second toe.   
❌ Interosseous ligament tear:
Incorrect: Interosseous ligament tear can occur in high ankle strains and presents with anterolateral ankle pain following a rotational force on a dorsiflexed ankle. This condition is commonly associated with fibula fractures. Diffuse tenderness along the posteromedial aspect of the shin is suggestive of medial tibial stress syndrome.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man comes to the office for evaluation of left ankle pain. He was playing soccer when he accidentally rolled his ankle. Since then, he has developed severe left ankle pain and swelling. Past medical history is noncontributory. The patient does not use tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drugs. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows an area of ecchymosis and point tenderness over the anterolateral aspect of the left ankle joint. Exacerbation of pain is noted with forced ankle inversion. The remainder of the examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient with left lateral ankle pain and significant swelling and ecchymosis, following an inversion injury, most likely suffered an ankle sprain.    

Ankle sprains are the most common ankle injury, and the majority involve the lateral ankle ligaments: the anterior talofibular ligament, the calcaneofibular ligament, and the posterior talofibular ligament. Damage to these ligaments occurs following extreme inversion of the ankle with plantar flexion. The most common ankle sprain involves the anterior talofibular ligament and patients typically present with pain and ecchymosis at the anterolateral aspect of the ankle. Eversion injuries are much less common, and can result in an avulsion fracture of the medial malleolus, leading to joint instability and possible nerve injury.  



Option Analysis

✅ Anterior talofibular ligament sprain:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Anterior tibialis tendon rupture:
Incorrect: Anterior tibialis tendon rupture is uncommon and presents with "slapping gait," as the patient is unable to actively dorsiflex the ankle, resulting in the foot slapping the ground with each step. An inversion of a plantar-flexed ankle most commonly results in anterior talofibular ligament sprain.  
❌ Syndesmotic sprain:
Incorrect: Syndesmotic sprains usually result from dorsiflexion and/or eversion of the ankle and affects the anterior tibiofibular, the posterior tibiofibular, the transverse tibiofibular ligaments, and the interosseous membrane. Affected patients present with unstable ankles and tenderness at the distal tibiofibular joints.  
❌ Deltoid ligament sprain:
Incorrect: Deltoid ligament sprain is uncommon, but can result from forced eversion of the ankle and an avulsion fracture of the medial malleolus. The pain of a deltoid ligament sprain is accentuated by eversion of the ankle, not inversion.  
❌ Achilles tendon rupture:
Incorrect: The gastrocnemius and the soleus tendon combine to form the Achilles tendon. Its rupture can occur during strenuous physical activities that involve sudden pivots or rapid acceleration. Tenderness and ecchymosis of the Achilles tendon is noted in affected patients.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after being stabbed in the right arm. Temperature is 37 C (98.6 F), pulse is 101/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 110/65 mm Hg. Physical examination demonstrates a 2 cm stab wound over the medial aspect of the cubital fossa with ongoing brisk, pulsatile bleeding. Neurologic examination demonstrates loss of sensation over the thenar eminence and dorsal and palmar aspects of the lateral 3 1⁄2 fingers. The patient also exhibits inability to flex the joints of the thumb, second and third digits, and inability to pronate the forearm. Injury to which of the following vascular structures is responsible for this patient’s ongoing bleeding?
questions.solution:
This patient’s stab wound is consistent with injury to the brachial artery and the median nerve, which lie next to each other in the cubital fossa. The cubital fossa contains four main vertical structures (lateral to medial): the radial nerve, biceps brachii tendon, brachial artery, and median nerve.   

The axillary artery terminates beyond the teres major's lower margin as it continues down the ventral surface of the arm to become the brachial artery. Once the brachial artery reaches the cubital fossa, it branches into the radial and ulnar arteries. Injury to the brachial artery  at the medial cubital fossa results in pulsatile, brisk bleeding, often with hematoma formation. Associated median nerve injury is common.    

In addition, the cubital fossa is a common site for venous blood sampling and intravenous line placement  due to its prominent and easily accessible veins. The most commonly accessed vein in this region is the median cubital vein, which connects the basilic and cephalic veins and lies superficial to the bicipital aponeurosis.  



Option Analysis

❌ Radial artery:
Incorrect: The brachial artery bifurcates at the inferior portion of the cubital fossa into the radial artery (superficial) and ulnar artery (deeper). The radial artery accompanies the superficial branch of the radial nerve in the forearm. This patient has evidence of median nerve injury, which lies close to the brachial artery in the medial aspect of the cubital fossa.  
✅ Brachial artery:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Ulnar artery:
Incorrect: The brachial artery bifurcates at the inferior portion of the cubital fossa into the radial artery (superficial) and ulnar artery (deeper). The radial artery accompanies the superficial branch of the radial nerve in the forearm. This patient has evidence of median nerve injury, which lies close to the brachial artery in the medial aspect of the cubital fossa.  
❌ Deep brachial artery:
Incorrect: The deep brachial artery courses posterior to the humerus and is vulnerable to injury with proximal humeral fractures (e.g. humeral shaft fracture).  
❌ Anterior interosseous artery:
Incorrect: The anterior interosseous artery originates in the forearm distal to the cubital fossa.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother to be evaluated for elbow pain. He was forcefully pulled onto the curb by his mother after inadvertently stepping into the street. The patient has refused to move his right arm since the incident. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows an irritable child holding his right upper limb with his left hand. The affected elbow is flexed and the forearm pronated. There is no visible erythema, swelling, or deformity. There is limited range of motion on physical examination. Which of the following structures is most likely involved in this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
Radial head subluxation (i.e. nursemaid’s elbow) is a common injury in young children (1-4 years of age). It is the most common upper extremity injury in infants and young children presenting to the emergency department. It is typically caused by axial traction on an outstretched, pronated forearm. With sudden traction on the distal radius, the annular ligament slips over the head of the radius at the level of the radiohumeral joint, where it becomes entrapped.    

Children with radial head subluxationIt typically present holding the injured arm in a flexed and pronated position and refusing to move it. Patients present with sudden, acute pain of the affected arm. Notably, pain does not always localize to the elbow and there is typically no swelling, bruising, or deformity of the arm. The diagnosis is clinical and most patients can be managed with closed manual reduction by either hyperpronation of the forearm (preferred) or supination of the forearm with flexion of the elbow.  

Option Analysis

❌ Biceps tendon:
Incorrect: Biceps tendon rupture typically occurs in older adults secondary to forceful extension of the elbow on a fully contracted biceps muscle. Patients may hear or feel a “popping” sensation.There is often a visible ‘Popeye deformity' in the mid-upper arm reflective of the shortened biceps brachii. Limited range of motion at the elbow joint as seen in this patient would not be expected.  
✅ Annular ligament:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Lateral epicondyle tendon:
Incorrect: Lateral epicondyle tendonitis can cause pain and tenderness at the lateral elbow. However with this condition there is full range of motion of the elbow joint.  
❌ Medial epicondyle tendon:
Incorrect: Medial epicondyle tendonitis can cause pain and tenderness at the medial epicondyle. However with this condition there is full  range of motion of the elbow joint.  
❌ Interosseous membrane of the forearm:
Incorrect: The interosseous membrane of the forearm is a connective tissue that lies between the radius and ulna. It is usually affected in patients with a radius or ulna fractures following a fall on an outstretched hand.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman comes to the office because of a six month history of progressively worsening headaches. She has also noticed blurred peripheral vision while driving. The patient does not report any head trauma or associated dizziness, weight changes, diplopia, or polyuria. Past medical history is unremarkable and she does not take any medications. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates a bitemporal visual field defect. Laboratory studies reveal a prolactin level that is greater than 20 times normal and cranial imaging shows a large pituitary mass. Based on the diagram below, which of the following visual pathways is most likely disrupted in this patient?
questions.solution:
The optic tracts relay visual information from the optic chiasm to the ipsilateral lateral geniculate nucleus, from where it continues to the occipital lobe and primary visual cortex. The x-shaped optic chiasm is the point of partial crossing of fibers from the optic nerve. Damage to this structure causes bitemporal hemianopsia. Common causes include pressure exerted by pituitary tumor (as seen in this patient), craniopharyngioma, as well as aneurysm of the anterior communicating artery.   

The aneurysm of the internal carotid artery can also laterally impinge on the optic chiasm and cause ipsilateral nasal hemianopia, damaging uncrossed optic nerve fibers from the temporal portion of the retina. Other visual field defects that may be seen with lesions at different points along the optic nerve pathway are summarized in the diagram below:  



Option Analysis

❌ A:
Incorrect: A partial lesion of the retina is more likely to produce a focal monocular scotoma rather than bitemporal visual field defect.  
❌ B:
Incorrect:: The optic nerve (Cranial Nerve II) transmits visual information from the retina to the optic chiasm, where it continues on in the optic tract. Damage to the right CN II can cause complete loss of vision in the ipsilateral eye (right anopsia) as well as a right relative afferent pupillary defect.  
✅ C:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ D:
Incorrect: Damage to the lateral aspect of the optic chiasm usually results from calcification or aneurysm of the internal carotid artery impinging on uncrossed lateral retinal fibers causing unilateral nasal hemianopia.  
❌ E:
Incorrect: The right optic tract transmits visual information from the left visual field and vice versa. A right optic tract lesion is likely to cause left homonymous hemianopsia rather than bitemporal hemianopia.

questions.text: A 26-year-old man is brought to the emergency department to be evaluated for severe posterior right thigh pain. He experienced sudden right posterior thigh pain with an associated popping sound while performing a high-kick during martial arts practice. He is unable to bear weight on his right leg. The pain is constant and does not radiate. The patient does not have associated back or buttock pain. Past medical history is noncontributory. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows swelling and tenderness at the posterior thigh with surrounding ecchymosis. Musculoskeletal examination reveals limited knee flexion and hip extension on the right side. Sensation of the lower extremities is intact, and deep tendon reflexes are +2 bilaterally. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with sudden onset of posterior thigh pain following a high kick which involves forced flexion at the hip with the knee and hip in extension. These findings suggest the patient has most likely suffered a hamstring tear due to an injury of the biceps femoris.  

Hamstring injuries classically occur during high-speed running and following low-speed mechanisms that involve stretching the hip and knee joints at their end ranges of motion. Hamstring strains are classified as either a pull (grade I), partial tear (grade II), or complete tear (grade III). Patients often present with sudden onset, minimal to severe pain over the posterior thigh, sometimes with an associated “popping” sound. Swelling and ecchymosis of the posterior thigh more commonly occur with complete tears. Physical examination demonstrates tenderness, loss of motion, and decreased strength with isometric contraction. An associated avulsion fracture of the ischial tuberosity may also occur with complete hamstring tears.

Option Analysis

❌ Stress fracture:
Incorrect: Prolonged strenuous activity is associated with the development of stress fractures. This condition presents dull, chronic pain of the affected region (e.g. lateral hip pain in femoral head stress fracture). Burning pain and paraesthesia over the lateral thigh suggest cutaneous nerve compression injury.
✅ Biceps femoris tear:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Lumbar radiculopathy:
Incorrect: Lumbar radiculopathy can cause posterior thigh pain; however, the pain also typically involves the low back and often radiates below the knee. This patient has evidence of tenderness over the hamstrings better explained by a biceps femoris strain. 
❌ Piriformis muscle spasm:
Incorrect: Piriformis syndrome occurs when the piriformis compresses the sciatic nerve. Symptoms include pain in the buttock area, accompanied by sciatica-like pain, numbness, and weakness that travels down the back of the thigh, calf, and foot.
❌ Hip adductor muscle strains:
Incorrect: Hip adductor strains can occur while sprinting or performing explosive hip movements. This condition typically results in focal pain in the groin or the medial thigh and pain with resisted hip adduction.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman comes to the office for evaluation of left foot pain. The patient recently joined a fitness program that requires her to walk two to three miles daily. The pain begins with her first steps and worsens throughout her daily walks. The pain improves with rest and does not recur with normal daily activities. Past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include metformin and atorvastatin. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a normal left and right foot arch. Direct pressure applied to the bottom of the left heel elicits a sharp pain. Mediolateral squeezing of the heels does not elicit pain. There is tenderness to palpation between the left heel and forefoot when the left toes are dorsiflexed. The remainder of the bilateral lower extremity examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Entrapment of the posterior tibial nerve
Inflammation and degeneration of the plantar aponeurosis

questions.solution:
This patient’s heel pain is most likely due to the inflammation and degeneration of plantar aponeurosis, resulting in plantar fasciitis. 

Plantar aponeurosis is a thick fibrous band that extends from the calcaneus of the foot to the toes, which functions to support the longitudinal arch of the foot. Plantar fasciitis results from chronic overuse and repetitive trauma to aponeurosis near its insertion point at the calcaneus. Risk factors include obesity, excessive foot pronation, excessive running, and prolonged standing. Patients typically present with stabbing heel pain that worsens with walking and may worsen after activity or at the end of the day. Physical examination often demonstrates tenderness at the insertion of the plantar fascia on the calcaneus, especially with toe dorsiflexion. 

The diagnosis is based on clinical findings, but plain radiographs may reveal heel spurs, which are of little diagnostic significance. Plantar fasciitis is a self-limited condition with most resolution of symptoms within twelve months. Initial treatment consists of ice, heat, massage, stretching, and elimination of exacerbating activities.   

Option Analysis

❌ Entrapment of the posterior tibial nerve :
Incorrect: Injury or compression of the posterior tibial nerve at the tarsal tunnel may result in numbness or paraesthesias over the sole of the foot. Pain is reproduced with percussion of the tarsal tunnel (Tinel sign) and not by the palpation of the heel. 
❌ Neuropathic degeneration of interdigital nerves :
Incorrect: Neuropathic degeneration of interdigital nerves can result in a Morton neuroma, which presents with pain between the third and fourth toes on the plantar surface and a clicking sensation upon squeezing the metatarsal joints. Tenderness of the heel with dorsiflexion of the toes is typical of plantar fasciitis. 
✅ Inflammation and degeneration of the plantar aponeurosis :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Overuse injury of the calcaneus :
Incorrect: Calcaneal stress fractures can occur following the initiation of high-impact exercise programs or overuse. It causes pain at the heel that worsens with weight bearing. Pain is often elicited by firm palpation at the lateral and medial aspect of the heel. Tenderness of the heel reproduced on dorsiflexion of toes is more typical for plantar fasciitis. 
❌ Neurogenic arthropathy :
Incorrect: Neurogenic arthropathy (charcot joint) presents with deformity and sensory deficits of the foot due to trauma, secondary to imapired proprioception and pain sensations. Therefore, pain is typically mild in these patients.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman comes to the office for evaluation of difficulty wearing her shoes due to medial eminence of the right big toe. She is a dancer which requires her to work for twelve hours a day wearing specially fitted, tight closed shoes. The patient also reports pain worse with weight-bearing and when wearing her shoes. Past medical history is noncontributory. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows lateral deviation of the right great toe and enlargement of a medially deviated first metatarsal head. Skin over the enlarged toe is hard, warm, and red. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s toe pain?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with lateral deviation of the great toe and enlargement of the medially deviated first metatarsal head, suggestive of hallux valgus (bunion).

Hallux valgus is a progressive foot deformity that occurs when the first metatarsal head deviates medially, producing a painful bump causing the hallux to compensate with lateral deviation. Patients usually present with a prominent bump at the medial side of the metatarsophalangeal joint (MTP) joint.

Common risk factors include gender (women), footwear (tight pointed shoes), congenital deformity, or chronic achilles tension. Symptoms can range in severity from mild to severe discomfort, aggravated by standing, walking, or wearing narrow or stiff shoes. Examination and radiographs reveal the diagnosis.    Pressure and friction from prolonged hallux valgus deformity can lead to the development of corn(s), which are hyperkeratotic localized overgrowths.    

Option Analysis

❌ Gout :
Incorrect: Patients with gout often report a relatively sudden onset of severe symptoms including pain, swelling, and redness. This patient’s deformity developed insidiously. 
❌ Hallux rigidus :
Incorrect: Patients with hallux rigidus will typically present with pain, stiffness, and swelling in the first MTP joint, aggravated by repetitive dorsiflexion at the MTP joint. Physical examination will reveal limited and often painful range of motion of the big toe, along with crepitus. Prominent osteophytes on the dorsal aspect of the joint are usually visible and palpable. Lateral deviation of the great toe with enlargement of the medially deviated first metatarsal head is seen in hallux valgus. 
✅ Hallux valgus :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Charcot arthropathy :
Incorrect: Charcot joint presents with deformity and sensory deficits of the foot due to trauma and impaired proprioception and sensation of pain. Patients often have underlying diabetes mellitus.  
❌ Turf toe :
Incorrect: Turf toe refers to an acute injury at the MTP joint when the great toe is forced superiorly injuring the plantar plate. A classic mechanism is an athlete jamming his or her foot against a hard surface. Prominent enlargement on the medial foot is suggestive of hallux valgus deformity.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man comes to the office for evaluation of right inguinal swelling that he first noticed today while showering. The patient reports mild discomfort. Past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. Current medications include metformin, atorvastatin, and lisinopril. Family history is significant for prostate cancer in the patient’s father. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows enlarged, tender right inguinal and popliteal lymph nodes. Which of the following conditions, if found, would most likely explain this patient’s symptoms?

choices.text: Painless ulceration on the glans penis
Old laceration of the right lateral foot with purulence

questions.solution:
Lymphadenopathy is characterized by an abnormality in size, number, or consistency of any lymphatic nodes and usually occurs in response to infection, malignancy, or an auto-immune condition.

The lower extremity lymphatic system gets divided into both superficial and deep lymphatic vessels, which follow the path of the venous and arterial system. The superficial lymphatic vessels drain lymph from the skin and subcutaneous tissues, whereas the deep lymphatic system drains lymph from both the superficial vessels and deep muscles. The superficial system is further divided into both medial and lateral tracks.
 

Therefore, an infected lesion on the lateral foot would result in the enlargement of both popliteal and inguinal lymph nodes, in contrast to medial foot lesions (only inguinal lymphadenopathy). 

Lymph from the superficial and deep inguinal lymph nodes traverses the external and common iliac nodes before entering the lateral lumbar (aortic) lymph nodes and the lumbar lymphatic trunk.       

Option Analysis

❌ Firm nontender right testicular mass :
Incorrect: Lymph from the testes drains directly into the para-aortic lymph nodes, not the inguinal lymph nodes.  
❌ Asymmetric firm prostatic nodules :
Incorrect: Lymph from the prostate drains into the internal iliac lymph nodes, not the inguinal lymph nodes.  
❌ Painless ulceration on the glans penis :
Incorrect: The glans penis is drained by the deep lymphatic system into the deep (not superficial) inguinal lymph node.  
❌ Exudative pharyngitis  :
Incorrect: Infectious mononucleosis results in cervical (not inguinal) lymph node enlargement. 
✅ Old laceration of the right lateral foot with purulence :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A 21-year-old man presents to the emergency department after an injury to the left knee. The patient was running during a football game when he was suddenly tackled and struck in the lateral side of the left knee. The patient heard a “pop” and then felt pain at the medial aspect of his left knee. He was able to walk following the incident but noticed his left knee felt “wobbly”. On physical examination the left knee is swollen and there is medial joint line tenderness. The patient subsequently undergoes an MRI of the left knee, and the findings are shown below. Which of the following physical examination maneuvers is most likely to support this patient’s diagnosis?
 

Image reproduced from Radiopedia
questions.solution:
This patient presents to the emergency department following an injury that involved a valgus force to the lateral aspect of the knee. Knee MRI demonstrates evidence of injury to the medial collateral ligament. When a valgus stress test is used and valgus force is applied at the knee medial gapping and pain would indicate a positive test in the case of a medial collateral ligament injury.

Medial collateral ligament (MCL) and lateral collateral ligament (LCL) injuries are common injuries in athletes. These injuries often occur in isolation--without the involvement of concomitant ligamentous injuries. Injury to the medial collateral ligament most often is caused by a valgus force applied to the knee from forceful turning or twisting or from a direct blow to the lateral aspect of the knee. In contrast, lateral collateral ligament injuries occur due to a varus force to the knee from forceful twisting or turning or from a direct blow to the medial aspect of the knee.

Diagnosis of either injury is often clinical. In MCL injuries, patients will have increased gapping and pain at the medial knee when valgus force is applied. In LCL injuries, patients will have increased gapping and pain at the lateral aspect of the knee when varus force is applied. MRI is the definitive diagnosis and will demonstrate increased signal intensity at the ligaments with partial tears or visible full-thickness tears.  

Option Analysis

✅ Valgus stress test:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Varus stress test:
Incorrect: Varus force applied at the knee joint would demonstrate increased gapping in the setting of a lateral collateral ligament injury. This patient's clinical presentation is more consistent with a medial collateral ligament injury.  
❌ Lachman test:
Incorrect: Lachman test is used to assess for anterior-cruciate ligament injury. It is not used to evaluate for medial collateral ligament injury. This patient’s medial knee pain and mechanism of injury are more consistent with a medial collateral ligament injury.  
❌ Thessaly test:
Incorrect: Thessaly test is used to assess for meniscus injury. However, the MRI does not show evidence of meniscal injury.  
❌ Posterior drawer test:
Incorrect: The posterior drawer test identifies injury to the posterior cruciate ligament which usually occurs from an anterior force applied to a bent knee, not a lateral blow as seen in this case. The posterior drawer test is not used to evaluate for medial collateral ligament injury which this patient likely has.

questions.text: A 27-year-old man presents to the emergency department with emergency medical services after a high-speed motor vehicle collision. The patient was the front-seat passenger of a vehicle that rear-ended another car while traveling at 45 miles per hour. The patient's primary survey is intact, and the secondary survey is notable for left knee swelling and ecchymoses. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination of the left knee demonstrates a large joint effusion and ecchymoses. A “soft” end-feel and increased posterior translation of the left tibia is noted when the examiner applies a posterior force anteriorly to the upper tibia. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of injury resulting in this patient's clinical condition?

choices.text: Force applied to the anterior aspect of a flexed knee
Valgus force applied to the knee
Varus force applied to the knee
Valgus force applied to the knee

questions.solution:
This patient presents after a high-speed motor vehicle collision with evidence of trauma to the left knee and a positive posterior drawer test. These findings are consistent with a posterior cruciate ligament (PCL) injury. The most common mechanism of injury in PCL injuries involves a posteriorly directed force applied to the anterior aspect of a flexed knee.

Of all the ligaments in the knee, the PCL is injured least often since it is the knee's largest and strongest intra-articular ligament. Most injuries to the PCL occur via high force trauma, such as when a passenger slams their knee on the dashboard in a motor vehicle crash. PCL injuries rarely occur in isolation and often involve concomitant injury to the other intra-articular ligaments of the knee. Clinically,  the patient will experience instability of the knee, pain, and will have a knee effusion and a positive posterior drawer test.

Definitive diagnostic testing involves magnetic resonance imaging. PCL tears are more commonly partial rather than complete. In the sagittal plane, partially torn PCLs often demonstrate a “stretched” appearance with thickening and intrasubstance signal changes.  

Option Analysis

✅ Force applied to the anterior aspect of a flexed knee:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Valgus force applied to the knee:
Incorrect: Medial collateral ligament tears are often a result of a valgus force applied to the knee, such as when a football player is tackled from the side. This patient’s physical exam indicates a posterior cruciate ligament (PCL) injury and cause is typically and posteriorly directed  force applied to the anterior aspect of a bent knee.  
❌ Varus force applied to the knee:
Incorrect: Lateral collateral ligament tears occur due to varus forces applied to the knee. This patient has a positive posterior drawer test which indicates PCL injury.  
❌ Twisting force at the knee:
Incorrect: Meniscal tears are often produced by a twisting mechanism applied to the knee, such as when an individual is turning rapidly or landing from a large jump. This patient had a dashboard injury and has a positive posterior drawer test indicating a PCL injury.  
❌ Valgus force applied to the knee:
Incorrect: When a knee injury involves a valgus force applied to the knee, medial meniscal injury can result, as can a triad injury involving the medial meniscus, the anterior cruciate ligament, and the medial collateral ligament.

questions.text: A 21-year-old man presents to the clinic to be evaluated for right knee pain. The patient was playing basketball three weeks ago when he suddenly pivoted while running and dribbling to the basket and felt pain in the right knee. Since then, he has experienced pain that worsens with running. In addition, he feels like his knee is “catching” and “giving out”. He is otherwise healthy and does not take any medications. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination of the bilateral knees does not demonstrate effusions or deformities When the examiner grasps the patient's thigh and pulls the tibia forward with the knee at 20° of flexion, there is no anterior translation of the tibia or “soft” end-feel. When the examiner attempts to translate the lower leg posteriorly, there is no “soft” end-feel or excessive posterior translation.. There is tenderness to palpation over the medial right joint line. No pain is elicited when the examiner flexes the right knee to maximal flexion beyond 90° and then extends the knee with internal rotation of the tibia and a varus stress. When the examiner returns the knee to maximal flexion and extends the knee with external rotation of the tibia and a valgus stress  pain and clicking are noted. Radiograph of the knee shows no fracture. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents after sustaining an injury involving a twisting force applied to the knee. Physical examination demonstrates a positive McMurray test with external rotation of the right knee and valgus stress applied. These findings are consistent with a medial meniscus injury.

Meniscal injuries are a common injury in athletes. This injury often arises from a twisting force applied to the knee while the foot is planted. Patients experience varying degrees of pain following the injury, with some patients seeking care immediately while others seek care weeks to months after the inciting event. Patients often recall a sensation of the knee “popping,” “clicking,” and a feeling that the knee “gives way” with specific movements. Additionally, movements that involve twisting, such as pivoting while running, often exacerbate the pain.  

Clinically, patients may have joint line tenderness, inability to squat or kneel, loss of smooth passive knee motion, and joint effusion if presenting soon after the injury. In addition, patients may have a positive McMurray test. This test is performed when the examiner flexes the knee to maximal flexion beyond 90° and then extends the knee with internal rotation of the tibia and a varus stress, then returns the knee to maximal flexion and extends the knee with external rotation of the tibia and a valgus stress. Pain or catching/locking with internal rotation and varus stress indicates a lateral meniscal tear, whereas pain or catching/locking with external rotation and valgus stress as seen in this patient indicates a medial meniscus tear. An additional physical examination maneuver to test for meniscal tears is the Thessaly test. The patient stands on the affected leg with the knee flexed at 5° and then 20° while the patient actively rotates the knee and the whole body externally and internally using the knee as the pivot point. Joint line pain or discomfort or clicking indicates a positive test.  

Option Analysis

✅ Medial meniscus injury:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Lateral meniscus injury:
Incorrect: A lateral meniscus injury would be suspected if the McMurray test reproduces pain or clicking with internal rotation of the right knee and varus stress not external rotation and valgus stress as seen in this patient.  
❌ Anterior cruciate ligament injury:
Incorrect: This patient has a negative Lachman test making it unlikely that he has an underlying anterior cruciate ligament injury. He has a positive McMurray test which indicates a meniscal injury.  
❌ Posterior cruciate ligament injury:
Incorrect: Posterior cruciate ligament injuries are an uncommon injury overall as it is the largest ligament of the knee. The posterior cruciate ligament is more commonly injured in the setting of high-speed motor vehicle collisions and this patient has a negative posterior drawer test making it unlikely.  
❌ Tibial plateau fracture:
Incorrect: This patient’s knee radiograph shows no evidence of a tibial plateau fracture.

questions.text:
A 16-year-old boy presents to the clinic for evaluation of low back pain. The patient is participating in gymnastics training and has had difficulty preparing for an upcoming competition due to persistent low back pain that is worse with movement and relieved with rest. The patient is otherwise healthy. He has not had any recent injury or trauma. Vital signs are within normal limits. On physical examination, the low back is noted to be hyperlordotic. Pain is elicited with passive extension of the back. The straight leg test is negative bilaterally. A radiograph of the lumbar spine is shown below. Which of the following best describes the etiology of this patient’s clinical presentation?  


Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

choices.text: Repetitive stress on the pars interarticularis

questions.solution:
This adolescent patient presents for evaluation of low back. Imaging reveals grade 1 L4 on L5 spondylolisthesis. Spondylolisthesis refers to anterior displacement of the vertebral body with respect to the adjacent vertebral bodies. Spondylolisthesis can be caused by degenerative changes in the spine in adult patients. It can also be congenital and seen in children. In both adolescents and children, pars defects can be caused by overuse of the low back, mainly from sports that involve repetitive back bend-like motion. This can lead to fracture of the pars interarticularis (spondylolysis) which may progress to anterior subluxation of one vertebral body with respect to an adjacent vertebral body (spondylolisthesis).  

Lumbar spondylolisthesis can present with intermittent localized low back pain. The pain is typically worsened with  flexing and extending at the affected segment of the vertebrae. There may be pain with direct palpation on physical examination. Patients can also have radicular pain if the exiting nerve roots become compressed.  

Radiography is the initial test for diagnosing spondylolisthesis. CT of the spine has the highest sensitivity and specificity for diagnosis and may be performed after spinal radiographs are completed.  

Option Analysis

✅ Repetitive stress on the pars interarticularis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Compression of L4 nerve root:
Incorrect: Lumbar radiculopathy most commonly results from bulging intervertebral discs. The symptoms often include low back pain with associated radiation down the lower extremities. A straight leg raise is often positive with this condition. This patient’s signs and symptoms are not consistent with lumbar radiculopathy.  
❌ Lytic bone lesions:
Incorrect: The above lumbar film does not demonstrate lytic bony lesions, which often appear as punched-out areas of bone.  
❌ Lumbar erector spinae weakness:
Incorrect: Weakness of the lumbar erector spinae can lead to low back pain.  However this would not increase the risk of spondylolisthesis seen in this patient’s radiograph.  
❌ Narrowing of the intraspinal canal:
Incorrect: Spinal stenosis is an uncommon condition in adolescent patients. It most commonly presents in elderly patients with pain that is worsened with walking or activity and is relieved by sitting, lying down, or bending forward at the waist.

questions.text: A 71-year-old man presents to the clinic for evaluation of worsening low back pain with walking. The patient's symptoms have been ongoing for over 8 months. The pain is worsened with standing  upright and walking  and relieved with sitting. There is no relief when he continues standing upright but stops walking. He sometimes experiences pain and tingling into the buttocks and legs. Past medical history is notable for hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and fifteen-pack-year smoking history. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination does not reveal any bony tenderness or defects of the lumbar spine. Neurologic assessment demonstrates 5/5 strength of the lower extremities bilaterally and a normal sensory examination. Straight leg raise is negative bilaterally. A digital rectal exam demonstrates an enlarged prostate without bogginess or asymmetry and adequate rectal tone. A radiograph of the lumbar spine shows only osteophytes. Further history is most likely to elicit which of the following regarding this patient’s clinical condition?
questions.solution:
This older patient presents for evaluation of low back pain and buttocks and leg pain worsened with walking and standing and relieved with sitting but not when he stops walking but continues to stand. These findings are consistent with spinal stenosis. A characteristic feature of spinal stenosis is pain relief with bending forward at the waist, as it helps offload pressure and widens the spinal canal. Which is in contrast to leg pain seen in vascular claudication which is worse with walking and relieved when the patient stops walking even when they remain upright.
