Spinal stenosis refers to narrowing of the vertebral foramen in one or more vertebrae, typically in the lumbar region. Most commonly, this is an age-related condition due to osteoarthritis and progressive disk degeneration that results in facet joint arthropathy, osteophyte formation, and hypertrophy of the ligamentum flavum. These processes ultimately result in the narrowing and impingement of the central spinal canal.  

Clinically, spinal stenosis results in “neurogenic claudication”, which refers to worsening pain with walking or standing upright, and relief with sitting where there is forward flexion at the waist. lying flat, or bending forward. In more severe cases, impingement on the central canal can compress spinal nerves, resulting in numbness, weakness, or tingling in the extremities. In most cases, the physical examination is non-contributory unless associated neurologic deficits are present.

Option Analysis

✅ Pain relief with bending forward:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Twenty-pound weight loss:
Incorrect: The diagnosis of primary or metastatic bone malignancy, especially prostate cancer in men, should always be considered when evaluating older men with low back pain. However, this patient’s prostate exam demonstrates only an enlarged prostate. Spinal stenosis which this patient has signs and symptoms of is commonly caused by arthritic changes in the spine and not metastases.  
❌ Loss of lower extremity hair:
Incorrect: Loss of lower extremity hair is commonly found in patients with vascular claudication from peripheral artery disease. Leg pain in this condition is worsened with walking and improved when the patient stops walking which is not seen in this patient.  
❌ History of osteoporosis:
Incorrect: Compression fractures result from underlying osteoporosis. This patient’s imaging does not show evidence of a vertebral body compression fracture.  
❌ Urinary retention:
Incorrect: Cauda equina syndrome is a neurologic emergency that arises from compression of the spinal cord at the level of the cauda equina. Associated symptoms include urinary retention, loss of bowel or bladder control, poor rectal tone, and weakness of the lower extremities. In rare cases spinal stenosis can lead to cauda equina syndrome.

questions.text:
A 66-year-old woman presents to the clinic for evaluation of chronic back pain. The patient has been experiencing worsening back pain over the past five months which is what brought them into the clinic. The patient has not experienced any sensory changes or bowel or bladder loss of control. She has no difficulty walking. Past medical history is notable for hypertension, type II diabetes mellitus, obesity, and osteoporosis. Vital signs are within normal limits, and physical examination is notable for anterior pelvic tilt, and increased curvature of the lumbar spine without abnormalities in the rest of the spine. The patient has full range of motion of the lumbar spine without pain. A radiograph is obtained and shown below. Which of the following best describes this patient’s findings?  


Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation of worsening chronic back pain and is found to have an anterior pelvic tilt and excessive curvature of the lumbar spine on physical examination. Furthermore, radiography demonstrates excessive lumbar lordosis or an increase in inward curvature of the lumbar vertebrae.  

The spine's normal curvature typically follows four normal curvatures, which can be seen on a lateral view radiograph. These include thoracic and sacral kyphosis. Kyphosis is an increased front to back curve of the spine giving a convex curve in the spine (i.e., convexity towards the back of the spine). in those areas. There is also a normal cervical and lumbar lordosis giving a gently concave curve in those areas (i.e, concavity towards the back of the spine). Two common spinal abnormalities include excessive thoracic or thoracolumbar kyphosis and excessive lumbar lordosis.  

Excessive kyphosis typically occurs in the thoracic region and leads to a hunchback appearance. This process can be postural or due to vertebral compression fractures from osteoporosis, osteoarthritis, or spondylolisthesis. Additional etiologies include genetic disorders such as Scheuermann kyphosis, osteogenesis imperfecta, or metabolic or congenital disabilities like spina bifida.  

Excessive lumbar lordosis results in the presence of an anterior pelvic tilt or swayback posture on physical examination. It is most often due to poor posture, obesity, weak hamstrings, tight hip flexors, or osteoporosis. Like excessive kyphosis, excessive lumbar lordosis is also associated with several genetic disorders, including Ehlers-Danlos syndrome and achondroplasia. It can lead to lumbar pain and if untreated, excessive lumbar lordosis may result in slippage of intervertebral discs, radiculopathy, and spondylolisthesis.

Option Analysis

✅ Excessive lumbar lordosis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Excessive thoracolumbar kyphosis:
Incorrect: Thoracolumbar kyphosis refers to excessive thoracic/lumbar convexity seen in the sagittal plane.. This finding is  not present in this patient’s radiograph or examination. Patients with thoracic or thoracolumbar kyphosis have exaggerated forward rounding of the upper back on physical exam  
❌ Scoliosis:
Incorrect: Scoliosis refers to an abnormal curvature of the spine in the coronal plane, resulting in lateral displacement of the spine. It is difficult to evaluate for scoliosis on a lateral spinal radiograph, however this patient does not have abnormal lateral curvature of the spine on physical examination.  
❌ Spondylolisthesis:
Incorrect: Spondylosis refers to an anatomic defect or fracture of the pars interarticularis. Spondylosis may progress to spondylolisthesis, characterized by anterior displacement of the vertebral body. This patient’s radiograph does not demonstrate spondylolisthesis.  
❌ Vertebral body compression fracture:
Incorrect: While this patient has a history of osteoporosis, the radiograph does not demonstrate evidence of a compression fracture. It shows excessive curvature of the lumbar spine.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man with Klinefelter syndrome comes to the office to evaluate a painless left breast mass he first noticed while bathing last night. The mass is not associated with pain, discharge, or erythema. The patient feels well and does not have any chronic medical conditions. He smokes two packs of cigarettes daily but does not use alcohol or illicit drugs. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination 4 cm subareolar left breast mass and enlarged left axillary lymph nodes. Mammography demonstrates irregular microcalcifications. A fine-needle aspiration biopsy is performed and is suggestive of infiltrating ductal carcinoma. Which of the following best differentiates breast cancer in men and women?

choices.text: Breast cancer typically presents at an earlier age in men.
Breast cancer typically presents in more advanced stages in men.
Lobular histology is less common in women.
Inherited breast cancers due to BRCA1 mutations present more commonly in men.
There are higher rates of hormone receptor expression in women.

questions.solution:
Breast cancer primarily affects biological females and is the most commonly diagnosed malignancy in women in the United States; however, up to 1.5% of cases occur in biological males. Breast cancer in males differs from breast cancer in females in the following aspects:  

  • Presents in more advanced stages with retro areolar location and chest wall involvement 
  • Higher rates of hormone receptor expression 
  • BRCA2 > BRCA1  
  • Lobular histology is less common

Unfortunately, breast cancer in men frequently goes undetected until metastatic symptoms present.

In males, breast cancer usually metastasizes to the axillary lymph nodes in addition to the bone, pleura, lung, liver, and skin. Breast cancer infiltrates the pectoral fascia, pectoralis major muscle, and apical lymph nodes in the axilla. 

Option Analysis

❌ Breast cancer typically presents at an earlier age in men.:
Incorrect: As with women, the incidence of breast cancer in men rises with age. Men tend to be 5 to 10 years older than women at the diagnosis.  
✅ Breast cancer typically presents in more advanced stages in men.  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Lobular histology is less common in women.  :
Incorrect: Most women's histologic subtypes of breast cancer are also present in men. Lobular carcinomas are rare in men (not women).  
❌ Inherited breast cancers due to BRCA1 mutations present more commonly in men.:
Incorrect: Most inherited breast cancers in women are due to BRCA1 mutations, which rarely present in men.  
❌ There are higher rates of hormone receptor expression in women.:
Incorrect: This is true for breast cancer in men, not women. Excessive estrogen stimulation may occur due to hormonal therapies (e.g., estrogen-containing compounds or testosterone), hepatic dysfunction, obesity, thyroid disease, or an inherited condition, such as Klinefelter syndrome.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman comes to the office for evaluation of a left breast mass. She has no associated symptoms. Her last menstrual period was one year ago, and she does not have any significant medical history. Family history is essential for breast cancer in the patient’s mother. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination of the breast shows a 2-cm firm, irregular round mass over the upper outer quadrant of the left breast. Mammography demonstrates a spiculated soft tissue mass with microcalcifications. If left untreated, this patient’s tumor is most likely to spread to the following locations first?
questions.solution:
Breast cancer usually spreads via lymphatic vessels, especially to the axillary lymph nodes (the most common site of metastasis). This patient presents with an irregular, palpable breast mass. This, in combination with her mammographic findings, is concerning for underlying breast cancer.  

Most lymph, especially from the superolateral quadrant and center of the breast, drains into the axillary lymph nodes, emptying into the subclavian lymphatic trunk. On the right, the lymphatic trunk drains into the venous system via the right lymphatic duct, whereas lymph from the left breast returns to the venous system via the thoracic duct.  

Breast cancer may spread to the vertebral bodies and central nervous system. Breast cancer cells can also spread from the breast via the venous system. The posterior intercostal veins drain into the azygos/hemi-azygos system of veins, which subsequently communicate with the internal vertebral venous plexus surrounding the spinal cord.



Option Analysis

❌ Azygos/Hemi-azygos veins:
Incorrect: Cancerous cells can spread from the breast through venous routes. For example, the posterior intercostal veins drain into the azygos system of veins; however, the axillary lymph nodes are the most common site of metastasis for breast cancer cells.  
✅ Axillary lymph nodes:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Pectoral fascia:
Incorrect: Breast cancer cells can invade the pectoral fascia; however, axillary lymph nodes remain the most common spread site for metastatic breast cancer.  
❌ Retromammary space:
Incorrect: Breast cancer cells can invade the retro mammary space; however, axillary lymph nodes remain the most common spread site for metastatic breast cancer.  
❌ Brain:
Incorrect: Breast cancer cells can spread from the breast via the azygos/hemi-azygos system of veins to the brain. Axillary lymph nodes remain the most common initial site of metastasis for breast cancer.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old man comes to the dermatology clinic for evaluation of a skin lesion. He does not have pain, itching, or discharge from the lesion. He states that it has been present since birth, and he has not noted any significant changes in its appearance. Past medical history includes testicular cancer treated with orchiectomy five years ago. Family history is unremarkable. Vital signs are within normal limits.  Physical examination shows a 0.5 cm, single, well-demarcated reddish-brown papule inferior to the left breast. Both breasts and axilla appear normal. Which of the following best describes the underlying cause of this patient’s presentation?  


Reproduced from Wikipedia

choices.text: Obliteration of the milk line during embryogenesis
Inflammation of the sebaceous glands of Montgomery
Failed involution of the mammary ridge

questions.solution:
The most common congenital breast condition in males and females is polythelia (supernumerary nipples), which results from the mammary ridge's failure to involution. The most common site for accessory nipples lies just inferior to the normal breast. Accessory nipples are usually asymptomatic, and excision is not required.  

Another related condition is polymastia (supernumerary breasts). This condition refers to more petite than usual breasts that consist of only a rudimentary nipple and areola (often mistaken for a mole). Supernumerary breasts can appear anywhere along a line that extends from the axilla to the groin along the milk line (location of embryonic mammary crest cells from which the breasts develop). The most common site for polymastia is the lower axilla.  



Option Analysis

❌ Obliteration of the milk line during embryogenesis:
Incorrect: Obliteration of the milk line during embryogenesis can result in athelia, for example, the absence of a nipple or amastia (i.e. absence of breast tissue). This patient’s presentation is consistent with an accessory nipple.  
❌ Inflammation of the sebaceous glands of Montgomery:
Incorrect: Inflammation of the sebaceous glands of Montgomery presents with tender, palpable abscesses over the periphery of the areola. This patient’s breast examination is unremarkable.  
❌ Abnormal response to gonadal hormones:
Incorrect: Abnormal response to gonadal hormones results in spontaneous overgrowth of breast tissue. Overgrowth may be unilateral or symmetric (more common) and begins around puberty. This patient’s breasts appear normal.  
✅ Failed involution of the mammary ridge  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Clonal proliferation of benign melanocytes:
Incorrect: Benign melanocytic nevi result from the clonal proliferation of benign melanocytes. They are usually small or medium-sized, solitary, and may occur anywhere on the skin. This patient’s examination findings are suggestive of an accessory nipple.

questions.text:
A 70-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of abdominal distension. The patient has had abdominal pain, nausea, and decreased appetite associated with progressive abdominal distension for the past three days. His last bowel movement was five days ago. The rest of the review of systems is unremarkable. Past medical history is significant for chronic constipation, hypertension, type II diabetes mellitus, and hypercholesterolemia. The patient had an open cholecystectomy several years ago. Temperature is 37.6°C (99.8°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 140/70 mmHg. Physical examination shows a distended and tympanitic abdomen with diffuse tenderness to palpation, but no rigidity, rebound tenderness, or guarding. A supine abdominal x-ray is shown below. Which pathophysiological process most likely contributed to this patient’s condition?  



Reproduced from Radiopedia

choices.text: Circumferential laxity of the phrenoesophageal membrane
Twisting of the sigmoid colon about its mesentery
Intestinal obstruction due to paralytic ileus
Telescoping of the proximal intestine into distal intestine
Inflammation of the sac-like protrusion of the colonic wall

questions.solution:
This patient’s clinical presentation is typical of intestinal obstruction (e.g., abdominal distention, abdominal pain, nausea, and constipation). This, together with a history of chronic constipation, is suggestive of sigmoid volvulus.   

Sigmoid volvulus occurs when an air-filled loop of the sigmoid colon twists about its mesentery, forming a closed-loop obstruction. The symptoms of volvulus are those of acute bowel obstruction. Patients present with progressive abdominal distention, nausea, and vomiting (secondary to continuous gas production by the intraluminal bacteria). This can rapidly progress to generalized abdominal pain and tenderness.    

Factors that can precipitate the development of sigmoid volvulus include: 
  •  Long redundant sigmoid colon with a narrow mesenteric attachment 
  •  Chronic constipation 
  •  Hirschsprung disease 
  •  Colonic hypomotility (e.g., neurogenic bowel in neurogenic diseases and diabetic enteropathy) 
  Sigmoid volvulus produces a characteristic bent inner tube or coffee bean appearance, with the convexity of the loop lying in the right upper quadrant (opposite the site of obstruction) on plain abdominal x-ray. The coffee bean appearance of the colon is created when the sigmoid colon distends with gas and the medial walls of the dilated bowel loop oppose one another and form the cleft of the coffee bean or an inverted U shape.  



Option Analysis

❌ Circumferential laxity of the phrenoesophageal membrane:
Incorrect: Sliding hiatal hernias occur due to the laxity of the phrenoesophageal membrane leading to the herniation of the gastroesophageal junction and proximal stomach into the thoracic cavity. Patients usually present with reflux symptoms (e.g., heartburn, regurgitation, and chest pain). This patient’s presentation is suggestive of intestinal obstruction.  
✅ Twisting of the sigmoid colon about its mesentery:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Intestinal obstruction due to paralytic ileus:
Incorrect: Paralytic ileus results when there is a nonmechanical decrease in flow of intestinal contents. It can lead to intestinal obstruction which is seen on abdominal x-ray as generalized distension of small and large bowel. A coffee-bean sign as seen on this patient’s plain radiograph suggests sigmoid volvulus.  
❌ Telescoping of the proximal intestine into distal intestine:
Incorrect: Intussusception (telescoping of the proximal intestine into the distal intestine) can cause intermittent, colicky abdominal pain and currant jelly stools. It typically occurs in infants aged 6-36 months. Plain abdominal radiographs may show a “target sign”, not the coffee bean sign seen in this patient.  
❌ Inflammation of the sac-like protrusion of the colonic wall:
Incorrect: Diverticulitis (inflammation of the sac-like protrusion of the colonic wall) can present with left lower quadrant pain. It usually does not cause mechanical intestinal obstruction or a coffee bean sign on x-ray.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man is currently postoperative on day two following a cervical lymph node dissection. The patient reports feeling well but states his shoulder seems “droopy.” Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates a laterally displaced scapula and weakness with shoulder abduction. Which of the following structures was most likely injured intraoperatively?
questions.solution:
The spinal accessory nerve (CN XI) provides motor function to the sternocleidomastoid and trapezius muscles of the neck and upper back. Injury to this nerve often manifests with pain and weakness about the shoulder. Specifically, patients have an asymmetric neckline, drooping shoulder, laterally displaced scapula, and weakness with overhead abduction of the shoulder.

The most common mechanism of injury involves iatrogenic injury via radical neck dissections, cervical lymph node biopsies, and posterior and lateral cervical triangle surgeries. Additional injury causes include blunt or penetrating trauma; however, these are significantly less common.  

Option Analysis

✅ Spinal accessory nerve:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Superior laryngeal nerve:
Incorrect: Isolated superior laryngeal nerve injury produces vocal fatigue and subtle voice quality, pitch, and projection changes. This patient presents with evidence of trapezius dysfunction.  
❌ Vagus nerve:
Incorrect: Injury to the vagus nerve may result in paralysis to both the superior laryngeal nerve and the recurrent branch of the laryngeal nerve. This can result in both sensory and motor deficits of the larynx.  
❌ Long thoracic nerve:
Incorrect: Injury to the long thoracic nerve more commonly occurs following chest wall surgeries. Clinical manifestations include a “winged scapula” due to the serratus anterior muscle weakness.  
❌ Supraclavicular nerve:
Incorrect: The supraclavicular nerve is a superficial sensory nerve originating from the superficial cervical plexus's C3 and C4 nerve roots. This patient presents with evidence of motor deficits.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy is currently undergoing an adenotonsillectomy secondary to sleep-disordered breathing and recurrent tonsillitis. Intraoperatively, brisk bleeding is noted from the lateral pharyngeal wall after removing the right palatine tonsil. Attempts at cauterization and hemostasis are unsuccessful with continued pulsatile bleeding. The patient’s current vital signs are temperature is 37 C° (98.6 F°), respirations are 18/minute, pulse is 116/minute, and blood pressure is 90/65 mmHg. Which of the following structures was most likely injured intraoperatively?
questions.solution:
Removal of the tonsils is a common procedure performed secondary to recurrent tonsillitis or sleep-disordered breathing. When the palatine tonsils alone are removed, the procedure is referred to as a tonsillectomy; when both the palatine tonsils and the pharyngeal tonsils (adenoids) are removed, it is referred to as an adenotonsillectomy. Typically, some surrounding connective tissue is also removed during these procedures.

During this procedure, several structures are at risk of injury, including the internal carotid artery, glossopharyngeal nerve, and tonsillar artery. The internal carotid artery lies posterior-lateral to the palatine tonsils and is a source of brisk and difficult to control bleeding when injured intraoperatively. The superior constrictor muscle lies lateral to the palatine tonsil and immediately deep to these muscles. Damage to this nerve can result in referred otalgia and temporary or rarely permanent alteration in taste.  

Option Analysis

✅ Internal carotid artery:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Thyroid ima artery:
Incorrect: The thyroid ima artery is an unpaired, variable branch of the brachiocephalic artery that supplies the thyroid and the isthmus. It is more commonly injured during procedures involving the anterior neck due to its more inferior position in the neck.  
❌ External carotid artery:
Incorrect: The external carotid artery branches from the common carotid artery at the fourth or fifth cervical vertebrae level. This structure is not at risk of injury during a tonsillectomy or adenotonsillectomy.  
❌ Common carotid artery:
Incorrect: The common carotid artery is not at risk of injury during this procedure, given its inferior location in the neck relative to the pharyngeal and palatine tonsils.  
❌ Internal jugular vein:
Incorrect: The Internal jugular vein is a potential source of injury during this procedure; however, it lies lateral to the internal carotid artery. Moreover, this patient presents with evidence of brisk bleeding consistent with an arterial source.

questions.text:
A 26-year-old man presents to the emergency department after being struck with a baseball bat. The patient reports pain in the left eyebrow but does not have vision changes or pain with eye movements. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates a hematoma and tenderness to palpation over the supraorbital rim. A CT scan of the face is shown below. Which of the following nerves is at risk of injury based on this patient’s traumatic mechanism?
   

Reproduced from: radiopaedia
questions.solution:
This patient presents with a supraorbital rim fracture after being struck with a blunt object. Given this mechanism and location of the injury, the supratrochlear nerve is at the highest risk of damage.

The trigeminal nerve branches into the frontal nerve within the orbit, dividing into the supraorbital nerve and supratrochlear nerve as they traverse via a bony recess called the supraorbital notch. These nerves provide sensory information to the skin of the forehead and scalp and are at risk of injury as they course superiorly from the orbit.  

Option Analysis

✅ Supratrochlear nerve:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Infraorbital nerve:
Incorrect: The infraorbital nerve, a branch of the maxillary branch of the trigeminal nerve, supplies sensory information to the lower portion of the orbit. This patient’s injury is at the superior aspect of the orbit.  
❌ Zygomatic nerve:
Incorrect: The zygomatic nerve, a branch of the maxillary branch of the trigeminal nerve, supplies sensory information over the cheek and temple. This nerve is unlikely to be damaged based on this patient’s injury pattern.  
❌ Facial nerve:
Incorrect: The facial nerve, or cranial nerve VII, provides innervation to the muscles of facial expression and taste sensation to the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. This nerve is more likely to be damaged with injury to the lateral face.  
❌ Nasociliary nerve:
Incorrect: The nasociliary nerve, a branch of V1, is less likely to be implicated given this patient’s injury due to its course within the orbit. This patient does not have evidence of damage to orbital structures.

questions.text:
A 44-year-old man presents to his ear, nose, and throat surgeon for follow-up after having a parotidectomy due to an invasive mucoepidermoid tumor. The patient reports feeling well, but he has noticed intermittent redness and pain over the area of surgery. In addition, the patient says the site “sweats profusely” every time he becomes hungry or is preparing to eat. Vital signs are within normal limits, and physical examination is notable for the finding demonstrated below. Damage to which of the following nerves is most likely implicated in this patient’s disease process?
 

Reproduced from: wikipedia
questions.solution:
This patient presents with characteristic features of Frey syndrome, a rare neurologic disorder that most commonly occurs following parotid gland surgery. This disease is due to damage and improper regeneration of the auriculotemporal nerve--a branch of the mandibular nerve (V3).

The auriculotemporal nerve contains secretomotor, somatosensory, and vasomotor fibers. The superior component of the nerve provides sensation to the tragus and helix of the ear, the external portion of the tympanic membrane, the posterior temporomandibular joint, and the temple. The inferior component provides autonomic parasympathetic innervation to the parotid gland.

During parotid gland surgery, the auriculotemporal nerve can become damaged with subsequent aberrant reinnervation of postganglionic parasympathetic neurons of denervated sweat glands and cutaneous blood vessels. When this occurs, flushing and sweating can occur in response to mastication and salivation, resulting in Frey syndrome. Pain, numbness, or anesthesia may also occur in the distribution of the auriculotemporal nerve.  

Option Analysis

✅ Auriculotemporal nerve:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Zygomatic nerve:
Incorrect: The zygomatic nerve, a branch of the maxillary branch of the trigeminal nerve, supplies sensory information over the cheek and temple. This nerve is unlikely to be damaged based on this patient’s recent surgery.  
❌ Superior alveolar nerve:
Incorrect: The superior alveolar nerve, a branch of the maxillary nerve, provides sensory information to the maxillary teeth, gums, and sinus. This patient does not have evidence of a sensory deficit.  
❌ Facial nerve:
Incorrect: The facial nerve, or cranial nerve VII, provides innervation to the muscles of facial expression and taste sensation to the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. This patient does not have evidence of facial motor deficits.  
❌ Frontal nerve:
Incorrect: Diminished sensation over the left forehead and scalp may occur with injury to the frontal nerve or its branches. This is likely to occur with a supraorbital rim fracture.

questions.text:
A 26-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by the local paramedics after a motor vehicle collision. He was wearing a seat belt while driving, and his car was hit by a truck from the left side. The patient reports severe abdominal pain radiating to the left shoulder, nausea, and dizziness. Temperature is 36.7°C (98°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 20/min and blood pressure is 85/50 mmHg. Physical examination shows an area of ecchymosis over the left lower chest wall, diffuse abdominal tenderness, and dullness to percussion over the left upper quadrant. Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. Focused assessment with sonography for trauma (FAST) reveals intraperitoneal free fluid. CT scan with contrast of the abdomen and pelvis is performed, as shown below. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s presentation?  


Reproduced from: Radiopedia
questions.solution:
This patient suffered a blunt abdominal trauma (BAT) during a motor vehicle accident, has diffuse abdominal tenderness, left shoulder pain (Kehr’s sign), and signs of shock (hypotension, tachycardia). This together with free intraperitoneal fluid on Focused assessment with Sonography for Trauma (FAST), left lower chest ecchymosis, and left upper quadrant dullness to percussion is consistent with splenic laceration.   

The spleen lies within the intraperitoneal cavity in close proximity to the stomach (intraperitoneal), colon (transverse: intraperitoneal, descending: retroperitoneal), left kidney, and pancreas (both retroperitoneal). It is one of the most commonly injured intra-abdominal organs following blunt trauma. In most adults, the spleen does not extend inferiorly past the rib cage, unless it is otherwise enlarged. The spectrum of its injury can range from contusion or subcapsular hematoma to laceration and intraperitoneal bleeding (due to high vascularity).  

Patients can present with abdominal pain, tenderness in the epigastrium, pain in the left flank, and sharp left shoulder pain in cases of minor injury. Whereas, a ruptured spleen may result in massive intra-abdominal bleeding and should therefore be treated as a medical emergency.  

Option Analysis

❌ Duodenal hematoma:
Incorrect: Rapid compression of the abdomen against the vertebral column can crush the duodenum, potentially causing duodenal hematoma. It does not cause free intraperitoneal fluid as the bleeding remains confined to the duodenal wall. Moreover, this patient suffered trauma from the left side of his vehicle.  
❌ Abdominal aortic rupture:
Incorrect: Abdominal aortic rupture is frequently fatal due to the profuse bleeding that results from the rupture, and many patients die of examination before reaching the hospital. The minority of the patients who survive is most likely due to the containment of the blood in the retroperitoneal space. Moreover, a blunt trauma from the left side is less likely to cause aortic rupture.  
❌ Liver laceration:
Incorrect: Blunt force mechanisms such as motor vehicle accidents are a common cause of liver laceration, and FAST may show free intraperitoneal fluid. Tenderness, however, is located over the right upper quadrant (rather than LUQ as seen in this patient).  
❌ Diaphragmatic injury:
Incorrect: Diaphragmatic injury can occur after blunt trauma due to a sudden increase in intra abdominal pressure. Chest auscultation may reveal bowel sounds. Free intraperitoneal fluid on FAST in this patient is suggestive of splenic laceration.
✅ Splenic laceration:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after being involved in a motor vehicle collision. The patient complains of pain on the left side of the chest that gets worse on deep breathing. Temperature is 36.7°C (98°F), pulse is 104/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 110/60 mmHg. Physical examination shows bruising and tenderness over the left posterior chest wall. The spinal range of motion is normal, and there is no midline tenderness. The gross motor and neurological examination is within normal limits. Plain chest radiograph reveals a left-sided 12th rib fracture. This patient is at increased risk of injury to which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
This patient with a left 12th rib fracture is at risk of left kidney laceration.   

The chest comprises 12 rib bones on each side of the body. Each rib attaches to the spine at the back of the body and then travels around to the front of the chest. The top 7 ribs attach to the sternum, the 8th to 10th ribs attach to the ribs above via cartilage, and the 11th and 12th ribs are known as ‘floating’ ribs as they are unattached at the front of the chest.   

Rib fractures are the most common injury sustained in blunt thoracic trauma. Fractures may cause localized pain, crepitus, pain with inspiration, dyspnea, and may even cause pneumothorax or hemothorax. The left 12th rib overlies the parietal pleura medially and the left kidney laterally. Therefore, the distal tip of the left rib can displace into the retroperitoneum and lacerate the left kidney.   

Option Analysis

❌ Brachial plexus:
Incorrect: The brachial plexus extends from the spinal cord, through the cervicoaxillary canal in the neck, over the first rib, and into the armpit. It is susceptible to injury in cases of 1st-3rd rib fractures.  
❌ Subclavian artery:
Incorrect: The subclavian artery travels laterally, passing between anterior and middle scalene muscles, with the anterior scalene on its anterior side and the middle scalene on its posterior. As the subclavian artery crosses the lateral border of the first rib, it becomes the axillary artery. It would not be affected by 12th rib fractures.  
✅ Left kidney:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Pancreas:
Incorrect: The pancreas is a retroperitoneal organ that stretches from behind the stomach to the left upper abdomen near the spleen. It overlies the body of the second lumbar vertebrae. It is most susceptible to injury with a crushing abdominal trauma.   
❌ Spleen:
Incorrect: The spleen is underneath the left part of the diaphragm and the ninth, tenth, and eleventh ribs on the left side. It is less likely to be injured in 12th rib fracture.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of left flank pain radiating to the groin. The pain started two hours ago, is sharp, and is rated by the patient as a 10/10. The patient has hematuria but no dysuria or urgency. The rest of the systemic review is unremarkable. Past medical history is noncontributory. Temperature is 36.7°C (98°F), pulse is 84/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mmHg. Physical examination shows no costovertebral angle tenderness. Plain radiograph of the abdomen and pelvis shows a 4 mm calcified density at the level of the lower left sacrum, just above the level of the vesicoureteric junction. This patient’s groin pain is most likely referred from the involvement of which of the following nerves?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation with flank pain radiating to the groin and radiographic evidence of an opacity in the pelvis, along the course of ureter, is consistent with ureteric colic/calculus.    

A ureteric calculus is the presence of a solid stone in the urinary tract, formed from minerals within the urine. These can obstruct urinary flow, causing renal colic (an acute and severe loin pain) and haematuria. There are three locations where the ureters are at their narrowest and, therefore, where a stone is more likely to become stuck: 
  •  Ureteropelvic junction 
  •  Pelvic brim 
  •  Where the ureter enters the bladder 
Nervous supply to the ureters is delivered via the renal, testicular/ovarian, and hypogastric plexuses. Sensory fibers from the ureters enter the spinal cord at T11-L2 with ureteric pain referred to those dermatomal areas. 
  •  Pain from upper ureteral stones tends to radiate to the flank and lumbar areas.  
  •  Mid-ureteral calculi cause pain that radiates anteriorly and caudally.  
  •  Distal ureteral stones cause pain that tends to radiate into the groin or testicle in the male or labia majora in the female because the pain is referred from the ilioinguinal (L1) or genitofemoral nerves (L1-L2). 


Option Analysis

❌ Subcostal :
Incorrect: The subcostal nerve is the anterior division of the twelfth thoracic nerve. It communicates with the iliohypogastric nerve and gives a branch to the pyramidalis muscle. It also gives off a lateral cutaneous branch that supplies sensory innervation to the skin over the hip. Its involvement would not cause groin pain.  
❌ Iliohypogastric :
Incorrect: The iliohypogastric nerve originates from the lumbar plexus and supplies sensation to skin over the lateral gluteal and hypogastric regions and motor to the internal oblique and transverse abdominal muscles. It’s involvement would not cause groin pain seen in this patient.  
✅ Ilioinguinal :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Sciatic :
Incorrect: Sciatic nerve pain typically affects one or more regions in the low back, thigh, leg, and foot but not the groin.  
❌ Pelvic splanchnic:
Incorrect: Pelvic splanchnic nerves are splanchnic nerves that arise from sacral spinal nerves S2, S3,  and S4 to provide parasympathetic innervation to the hindgut, urinary bladder, and sphincter.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after he slipped and fell from a 14-foot ladder onto his right lower extremity. Radiographs reveal a right-sided complete transverse fracture of the distal tibia and fibula diaphysis. Past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus. The patient has a 25-pack-year smoking history. The patient is subsequently managed with external fixation and discharged home. The patient returns to the clinic seven months later for evaluation of persistent pain and a clicking sensation at the level of the fracture. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates a visible deformity of the right lower extremity. Sensation is intact bilaterally. A current x-ray of the right lower extremity is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s presentation?  


Reproduced by Radiopedia
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation of persistent pain at the fracture site and x-ray findings of callus formation around the fracture margins and anterior and internal angulation is suggestive of fracture nonunion.  Fracture nonunion manifests with x-ray findings that demonstrate persistent radiolucent lines at the fracture site, with or without callus formation. Complications of malunion included degenerative joint disease, persistent pain, as well as deformity.  

The tibia, particularly its distal third, is more prone to delayed union or nonunion due to lower blood supply and muscle coverage. In addition, compartment syndrome is a frequent concern in tibia fractures and can occur in crush injuries without fractures and in open fractures. The hallmark of compartment syndrome is severe pain out of proportion to the injury.  

Option Analysis

❌ Complex regional pain syndrome:
Incorrect: Complex regional pain syndrome (CRPS) is a rare chronic pain complication of unknown cause following trauma. CRPS is characterized by pain out of proportion to the original injury with swelling, pain, and vasomotor disturbances as the hallmarks of this syndrome. X-ray often shows patchy demineralization of bone.  
✅ Fracture nonunion :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Common peroneal nerve compression:
Incorrect: The common peroneal nerve is susceptible to injury as it courses laterally around the neck of the fibula. Injury at this location presents with weakness of foot dorsiflexion and eversion as well as sensory loss over the dorsum of the foot and lateral shin and between first and second toes. This patient’s injury occured in the distal tibia/fibula.   
❌ Skin and soft tissue infection:
Incorrect: Skin and soft tissue infections usually present with erythema, swelling and pain, often associated with fever, leukocytosis, and elevated inflammatory markers. It would not explain this patient’s prominent callus formation surrounding the tibial non union.  
❌ Myositis ossificans:
Incorrect: Myositis ossificans occur when calcifications develop within muscle tissue. It can occur as a complication of fractures, especially supracondylar fractures of the humerus. It would not explain this patient’s prominent callus formation surrounding the tibial non union.

questions.text:
A 27-year-old woman comes to the office for evaluation of right ankle pain. The patient was playing football when she was struck by an opposing player causing her ankle to evert. She immediately felt an intense, sharp pain about the ankle and heard a “snap.” The patient was unable to ambulate off the field. Past medical history is noncontributory. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows swelling around the right ankle and tenderness over the medial malleolus. Sensory examination is within normal limits. Peripheral pulses are equal bilaterally. A right ankle x-ray is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?  


Reproduced from Radiopedia
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation of ankle pain following an eversion injury, in combination with radiographic evidence of a right distal fibula and medial malleolus fracture is consistent with a bimalleolar fracture (Pott’s fracture).  

Ankle fractures most often result from a twisting mechanism of injury to the ankle. Inversion injuries typically result in distraction (stretching) of the lateral ankle structures with compression of the medial structures. In contrast, eversion injuries result in medial distraction with lateral compression. The structures that are distracted during the injury tend to fracture or tear before the compressed structures.    

A Pott’s fracture is a bimalleolar fracture (injury to both the medial and the lateral malleolus) that results from a combined abduction external rotation from an eversion force. A Pott's fracture often occurs in combination with a dislocation of the ankle or other fractures of the foot, ankle, or lower leg.  

Another type of fracture, called a trimalleolar fracture, occurs when a bimalleolar fracture occurs in conjunction with a fracture of the posterior malleolus. They have a higher risk of complications than bimalleolar fractures and more result from high energy mechanisms of injury. Both bimalleolar and trimalleolar fractures are considered unstable and require operative fixation.  


Trimalleolar fracture 
Reproduced from Radiopedia 

Option Analysis

❌ Anterior talofibular ligament tear:
Incorrect: Ankle sprains can have a similar clinical presentation to that of an ankle fracture such as swelling and pain about the ankle. Plain radiographs in these patients are typically normal.   
❌ Fifth metatarsal fracture:
Incorrect: Pain, swelling, and tenderness over the lateral border of the forefoot is consistent with a fifth metatarsal fracture. This patient has medial malleolar tenderness and swelling.   
✅ Bimalleolar fracture:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Acute compartment syndrome:
Incorrect: Compartment syndrome is an orthopedic emergency that results from increased pressure within an enclosed fascial space. Patients present with severe pain that worsens with passive stretching of the affected muscles, paresthesias, as well as sensory and motor deficits. This patient’s medial malleolar tenderness and x-ray findings is suggestive of a bimalleolar fracture.  
❌ Achilles tendon rupture:
Incorrect: The gastrocnemius and the soleus tendon combine to form the Achilles tendon. Its rupture can occur during strenuous physical activities that involve sudden pivots or rapid acceleration. Tenderness and ecchymosis of the Achilles tendon is noted in affected patients.

questions.text:
A 66-year-old man comes to the emergency department to be evaluated for left shoulder pain after a fall. The patient was skiing when he was accidentally hit from the right side and fell on his left shoulder and outstretched left hand. The patient did not strike his head or lose consciousness. Past medical history is noncontributory. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a man supporting his left arm with his right hand. There is tenderness and swelling at the proximal humerus. An x-ray of the left shoulder is shown below. Axillary nerve injury is suspected. Which of the following actions will be impaired due to this nerve injury?  


Reproduced from Radiopedia:

choices.text: Abduction and adduction of the fingers

questions.solution:
This patient’s left arm x-ray is consistent with a fracture of the surgical neck of the humerus, which is an injury pattern that occurs below the greater tubercle and lesser tubercle, and above the deltoid tuberosity.  

The surgical neck is fractured much more frequently than the anatomical neck of the humerus and commonly results from a fall on the outstretched hand. It is a fracture seen in older patients particularly those with osteoporosis. Symptoms include pain over the proximal shoulder that radiates the arm's length and swelling. The axillary nerve and posterior circumflex humeral artery are at the structures that are at most risk of injury with this fracture pattern.    

The axillary nerve carries fibers from the C5-C6 branch of the brachial plexus, where it courses deep to the axilla below the shoulder joint and the surgical neck of the posterior humerus. Patients with injury to this nerve present with loss of sensation over the lateral upper arm and weakness with shoulder abduction (due to denervation of the deltoid muscle). Damage to the posterior circumflex humeral artery can lead to avascular necrosis of the humeral head.  

Option Analysis

❌ Elbow, wrist, and finger extension:
Incorrect: Elbow, wrist, and finger extension are functions of the radial nerve (C5-T1), which can be injured with midshaft fractures of the humerus. This patient has a fracture of the neck of the humerus.  
❌ Abduction and adduction of the fingers :
Incorrect: The ulnar nerve is susceptible to injury in patients with fractures of the hook of hamate of the hand which can be seen in athletes. Ulnar nerve injury can cause inability to abduct the index and little fingers and inability to adduct the thumb. This patient’s presentation and radiograph are consistent with a fracture of the surgical neck of the humerus.   
❌ Wrist flexion and thumb opposition:
Incorrect: Proximal median nerve injury can result from supracondylar fractures of the distal humerus at the elbow and can lead to the inability to flex the wrist and oppose the thumb. This patient has a fracture of the surgical neck of the humerus.  
✅ Arm abduction at the shoulder :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Forearm flexion and supination :
Incorrect: Upper nerve trunk compression can injure the musculocutaneous nerve. Patients typically present with loss of arm abduction at the shoulder (>15 degrees) and loss of sensation over the lateral arm. Compression of the musculocutaneous nerve lower in the arm at the coracobrachialis muscle, can lead to weakness with forearm flexion and supination and sensory loss over the lateral forearm.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man comes to the emergency department for evaluation following a fall and associated right arm pain. The patient was rock climbing when he lost grip and fell approximately 3 m (6.5 ft) onto boulders below. The patient landed on his right arm and heard a snapping sound upon impact. He did not strike his head or lose consciousness. Past medical history is noncontributory, and the patient does not take any medications. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates swelling and bruising of the right upper arm and inability to extend the right wrist and the fingers of the right hand, and sensory loss over the posterior forearm and dorsolateral hand. Nerve injury at which of the following locations is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation is consistent with radial nerve injury, likely due to a midshaft fracture of the humerus.  

Midshaft humerus fractures in young patients commonly result from a direct blow or a bending force applied to the humerus. Older patients can experience this type of injury with a fall onto an outstretched hand. Patients typically present with severe pain in the mid-arm but may also have referred pain to the shoulder or elbow. Swelling and ecchymosis are often apparent shortly after the injury. The radial nerve and deep brachial artery are two structures that can be injured with this injury pattern.  

The radial nerve carries fibers from C5-T1 and serves as a terminal branch of the brachial plexus. It provides motor innervation to the forearm extensors at the elbow and most hand extensors at the wrist. Sensory innervation includes the posterior forearm and most of the back of the hand, except for the back of the little finger and the adjacent half of the ring finger (innervated by the ulnar nerve).Injury to the radial nerve results in weakness of wrist, finger, and thumb extension and elbow supination . A wrist drop can often be seen with this type of injury.  



Option Analysis

❌ Carpal tunnel :
Incorrect: Repetitive hand and wrist use can lead to compression of the median nerve at the carpal tunnel. This typically results in pain and paraesthesias of the first 3½ digits of the affected hand. This patient neurologic deficit is suggestive of radial nerve injury.   
✅ Mid-shaft of the humerus:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Surgical neck of the humerus:
Incorrect:  Fractures of the surgical neck of the humerus typically result from a fall on an outstretched hand. This fracture pattern is most likely to damage the axillary nerve and posterior circumflex humeral artery rather than the radial nerve. Axillary nerve injury leads to loss of sensation and abduction at the shoulder.  
❌ Hook of hamate :
Incorrect: The ulnar nerve can be injured at the hook of hamate from a fracture there. The ulnar nerve enters the wrist via Guyon’s canal bordered by the hook of the hamate. Patients typically present with sensory loss over the medial 1½ digits, hypothenar eminence, and weakness with wrist flexion/adduction, finger adduction/abduction, and flexion of fourth/fifth digits.  
❌ Coracobrachialis muscle:
Incorrect: The coracobrachialis muscle is innervated by the musculocutaneous nerve. The nerve pierces the coracobrachialis muscle and can be injured by a compression injury of this muscle (e.g., from weight lifting). Injury to this nerve results in weakness with forearm flexion and supination and sensory loss over the lateral forearm.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man comes to the office to be evaluated for right elbow pain for several weeks. The pain has limited his productivity at work as a plumber and worsens with extensor movements such as swinging his hammer. He has tried ibuprofen and over-the-counter pain medications with minimal pain relief. Past medical history is noncontributory. Vitals are within normal limits. On physical examination the patient has full range of motion of the elbow. There is tenderness to palpation at the lateral epicondyle, and pain is elicited at the right lateral elbow with resisted wrist extension, digit extension, and forearm supination. There is no swelling, warmth, or redness over the right elbow joint. Examination of the distal forearm, wrist, and hand is noncontributory. Which of the following best describes the etiology of this patient’s presentation?

choices.text: Overuse of extensor muscles of the forearm
Overuse of flexor muscles of the forearm
Degenerative joint changes at the elbow

questions.solution:
This patient’s elbow pain is reproduced with resisted wrist extension, digit extension, and forearm supination. This, in combination with tenderness over the lateral epicondyle, suggests a diagnosis of lateral epicondylitis (tennis elbow) due to overuse of the forearm extensor muscles (extensor carpi radialis brevis and extensor digitorum communis). Overuse leads to noninflammatory angiofibroblastic tendinosis at the common extensor origin of the lateral epicondyle. This condition is typically seen with repetitive wrist extension activities (such as a backhand stroke in tennis).    

In contrast, pain over the medial epicondyle with resisted finger and wrist flexion suggests medial epicondylitis. Overuse of the wrist and hand flexors and forearm pronators can lead to medial epicondylitis. If left untreated, patients may develop ulnar neuropathy, given the proximity of the ulnar nerve to the medial epicondyle. Treatment options for both conditions include a combination of rest, anti-inflammatory medications, bracing, and physical therapy.  



Option Analysis

❌ Inflammation of the olecranon bursa:
Incorrect: Olecranon bursitis occurs secondary to repetitive pressure or friction over the elbow joint. Patients present with posterior elbow pain and swelling of the bursa.  
❌ Radial nerve entrapment:
Incorrect: The most frequent site of radial nerve entrapment lies in the proximal forearm over the supinator and posterior interosseous branch at the radial tunnel. It can lead to numbness and decreased sensation in the hand and weakness in the hand and wrist. 
✅ Overuse of extensor muscles of the forearm:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Overuse of flexor muscles of the forearm:
Incorrect: Overuse of flexor muscles of the forearm can result in medial epicondylitis, which presents with tenderness over the medial epicondyle.   
❌ Degenerative joint changes at the elbow:
Incorrect: Degenerative joint disease of the humeroulnar joint is uncommon but can present following an injury. Patients present with chronic pain, limited range of motion, and crepitus with flexion and extension at the elbow. This patient has full range of motion at the elbow joint.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man comes to the office to be evaluated for right-hand weakness. He works as a mechanic, which involves frequent screwdriver use. He does not report any trauma to his hand. Past medical history is unremarkable. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates weakness with extension of the thumb and fingers of the right hand. There is no weakness with adduction and abduction of the fingers. The patient reports mild pain with resisted middle finger extension. The sensation is intact and reflexes are +2 and symmetrical bilaterally. This patient most likely has an injury to a nerve that courses through which of the following structures?

choices.text: Flexor carpi ulnaris and flexor digitorum profundus muscles
Olecranon and medial epicondyle of the humerus
Superficial and deep portions of the supinator muscle
Humeral and ulnar heads of pronator teres muscle

questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation is consistent with a radial nerve (deep branch) injury as it passes through the supinator muscle–likely due to repetitive pronation/supination (use of screwdrivers). The radial nerve enters the forearm anterior to the lateral epicondyle, where it branches into terminal superficial and deep branches. The deep branch pierces the two heads of the supinator, where it becomes the posterior interosseous nerve (PIN) and innervates the posterior compartment of the forearm. This nerve provides motor control to the wrist and finger extensors but does not provide cutaneous sensory innervation.    

Injury to the deep branch of the radial nerve at the supinator muscle often results from repetitive pronation/supination, direct trauma, or dislocation of the head of the radius. Patients usually present with finger and thumb extension weakness from loss of the extensor digitorum communis, extensor indicis proprius, and extensor digiti quinti function. Patients with this injury pattern will have preservation of cutaneous sensory function.   



Option Analysis

❌ Biceps and coracobrachialis muscles:
Incorrect: The musculocutaneous nerve courses through the biceps and coracobrachialis muscles. Injury to this nerve at that level can result from shoulder dislocation or humeral fracture and presents with sensory loss over the lateral forearm and loss of arm abduction at the shoulder (>15 degrees).   
❌ Flexor carpi ulnaris and flexor digitorum profundus muscles:
Incorrect: The ulnar nerve courses between the flexor carpi ulnaris and flexor digitorum profundus muscles after traversing through the cubital tunnel at the elbow. Injury to this nerve would result in loss of flexion of the hand and digits rather than loss of extension.  
❌ Olecranon and medial epicondyle of the humerus:
Incorrect: The ulnar nerve courses through the olecranon and medial epicondyle of the humerus (i.e. cubital tunnel) before passing into the forearm. Compression of this nerve will result in weakness of the hand/digits with abduction and adduction and loss of sensation or paresthesias in the ulnar half of the palm and dorsum of the hand over the fourth and fifth digits on both the palmar and dorsal aspects of the hand.  
✅ Superficial and deep portions of the supinator muscle:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Humeral and ulnar heads of pronator teres muscle:
Incorrect: Compression of the median nerve as it courses between the humeral and ulnar heads of the pronator teres muscle presents with diminished sensation in the lateral thenar eminence and the palmar aspect of the first 3 1⁄2 digits.

questions.text:
A 22-year-old woman comes to the emergency department for evaluation of throbbing headaches for three weeks. Yesterday, the patient had blurry vision in both eyes and an episode of double vision lasting minutes. The patient has been taking over-the-counter analgesics with only mild improvement in her symptoms. Past medical history is significant for polycystic ovarian syndrome, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and facial acne. She has not had any trauma, weakness, or changes in sensation. Current medications include metformin and isotretinoin. BMI is 36 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows decreased peripheral vision field testing. Fundoscopic findings of the left eye are demonstrated below, with similar findings in the right eye. Which of the following is the most likely etiology of the observed fundoscopic findings in this patient?  


Reproduced from Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation is consistent with idiopathic intracranial hypertension (IIH), which typically presents in young obese females with daily headaches, bilateral symmetric papilledema, and transient visual disturbance. The fundoscopic findings of optic disc swelling (elevation of the optic disc with blurred disc margins) are suggestive of papilledema.  

Papilledema is a term exclusively used to describe optic disc swelling, secondary to increased intracranial pressure (ICP). The optic nerve is surrounded by subarachnoid space containing cerebrospinal fluid, so any condition that raises ICP will compress this nerve. Prolonged compression also occludes the central retinal vein, resulting in venous engorgement and peripapillary hemorrhage. Additional conditions that can manifest with papilledema include central nervous system infections or tumors.   

Option Analysis

❌ Macular degeneration:
Incorrect: Degeneration of the macula can be observed in age-related macular degeneration (AMD), which is subdivided into dry and wet AMD. This condition results in the gradual loss of central vision and metamorphopsia in affected eyes.   
✅ Elevated intracranial pressure:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Impaired retinal perfusion:
Incorrect: Impaired retinal perfusion occurs with central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO), often secondary to cardiac emboli in young patients and carotid atherosclerosis in geriatric patients. CRAO presents with acute painless visual loss in the affected eye.   
❌ Elevated intraocular pressure:
Incorrect: An acute elevation intraocular pressure is characteristic of acute-angle closure glaucoma, which typically presents with painful monocular vision loss, headache, vomiting, conjunctival injection, and a mid-dilated non-reactive pupil.  
❌ Middle cerebral artery embolism:
Incorrect: Embolic occlusion of the middle cerebral artery can lead to the development of contralateral homonymous hemianopia. However, owing to the extensive area of the brain that the MCA supplies, other signs of stroke, such as contralateral limb weakness and sensory loss, would also be apparent.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman comes to the office because of a two week history of cough, fatigue, impaired vision, and worsening headache. Past medical history is significant for hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. The patient recently recovered from bacterial pneumonia two months ago. Current medications include metformin and lisinopril. The patient has smoked two packs of cigarettes daily for the last thirty-eight years. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. After a thorough diagnostic workup, a diagnosis of metastatic small cell cancer of the lung is made. A schematic overview of the patient's visual fields is shown below. This patient is most likely to have a metastatic lesion in which of the following locations of the visual pathway?
questions.solution:
The visual pathway transmits visual information from the retina to the visual cortex through the optic nerve, optic chiasm, optic tract, lateral geniculate nucleus, and optic radiations. The superior bundle of right optic radiations (right dorsal optic radiation) relays information from the left inferior quadrants of the visual field (i.e. from the right superior quadrant of both retinas). Therefore, damage to the right superior bundle of optic radiations would produce left lower homonymous quadrantanopia (“pie on the floor”).    

Other visual field defects that may be seen with lesions at different points along the optic nerve pathway are summarized in the diagram below:  



Option Analysis

❌ Right macula:
Incorrect: The right macula transmits visual information from the center of the right eye's visual field. Damage to the right macula (e.g. due to macular degeneration) results in right central scotoma.   
❌ Optic chiasm:
Incorrect: The optic chiasm is where the optic nerve fibers of the nasal side of the retina cross the midline. Damage to this structure would result in bitemporal hemianopsia.   
❌ Right optic tract:
Incorrect: The right optic tract transmits information from the left half of each eye's visual field (i.e., from the nasal half of the left retina and temporal half of the right retina). Damage to the right optic tract would result in left homonymous hemianopsia.   
❌ Right Meyer loop:
Incorrect: The inferior bundle of right optic radiations (right Meyer loop) is located in the right temporal lobe and transmits visual information from the left superior quadrants of the visual field (i.e. from the right lower quadrant of both retinas). Therefore, damage to the right Meyer loop would result in left upper homonymous quadrantanopia (“pie in the sky”).  
✅ Right dorsal optic radiation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man comes to the office for evaluation of left leg pain and black discoloration of the left toes. The pain occurs with walking and resolves with rest. He first noticed a black discoloration of the toes two days ago and it has progressively worsened since then. He does not have any chest pain or shortness of breath. Past medical history is significant for diet-controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. He does not take any medications. The patient’s father died of a myocardial infarction at 60 years of age. The patient has a 35-pack year smoking history and does not use alcohol or illicit drugs. Temperature is 37.2 C (98.9 F), pulse is 78/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 135/90 mmHg. Which of the following additional clinical findings will likely be observed on further evaluation?

choices.text: Bruit on the auscultation of popliteal fossa
Reproduction of pain with passive dorsiflexion of the toes
Lack of femoral vein compressibility on doppler ultrasound

questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation of intermittent leg pain and black discoloration of toes in the presence of multiple risk factors (smoking, hypertension, and type 2 diabetes mellitus), is suggestive of peripheral arterial disease (PAD). Further physical examination is likely to demonstrate diminished posterior tibial artery pulsations. 

Examination in patients with PAD commonly reveals diminished or absent pulses below the level of arterial stenosis as well as evidence of poor wound healing in the area(s) of poor perfusion. 

Pimenta's Point refers to an anatomical landmark to easily palpate the posterior tibial artery. This landmark is described by the midpoint on the imaginary line drawn between the bony prominences of the medial malleolus and the insertion of the Achilles tendon. Similar to posterior tibial artery pulsations, the dorsalis pedis pulse can also be decreased or absent in patients with PAD. This artery can be readily palpated lateral to the extensor hallucis longus tendon (or medially to the extensor digitorum longus tendon) on the dorsal surface of the foot distal to the dorsal most prominence of the navicular bone.       

Option Analysis

❌ Bruit on the auscultation of popliteal fossa :
Incorrect: A bruit of the popliteal fossa can be seen in patients with popliteal artery aneurysms. Patients typically present with edema and pain in the popliteal fossa. The aneurysm may compress adjacent nerves leading to referred pain overlying the medial aspect of the calf, ankle, or foot.  
✅ Diminished posterior tibial pulse :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Osteophytes on lateral foot x-ray :
Incorrect: Osteophytes on lateral foot x-ray are suggestive of osteoarthritis. Osteophytic pain may not disappear following exercise and varies in intensity from day-to-day (usually worse in the morning or upon waking). 
❌ Reproduction of pain with passive dorsiflexion of the toes :
Incorrect: Reproduction of pain with passive dorsiflexion of the toes can be seen in compartment syndrome. Patients present with severe pain that worsens with passive stretching of the affected muscles, paresthesias, as well as sensory or motor deficits. This patient’s intermittent leg pain is suggestive of peripheral arterial disease. 
❌ Lack of femoral vein compressibility on doppler ultrasound :
Incorrect: Doppler ultrasound of the lower extremities is used for the diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis (DVT). Patients typically present with leg swelling, pain, warmth, and erythema in the presence of significant risk factors (e.g., history of immobilization or prolonged hospitalization, recent surgery, or trauma). This patient has multiple atherosclerotic risk factors and claudication.

questions.text: A 24-year old man presents to the emergency department after injuring his right knee during a pick-up basketball game. The patient was running and dribbling toward the basket when he suddenly changed direction and felt a “pop” in the knee. The patient subsequently had intense pain, significant swelling of his knee, and felt like his knee would “give out” on him when ambulating. Currently he is able to bear weight without pain but still feels unsteady when ambulating. Physical examination is notable for a small right knee effusion. There is full range of motion of the knee without locking or clicking. Which of the following physical examination maneuvers is most likely to aid in diagnosing this patient’s clinical condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with an effusion, pain, and joint instability after a rapid deceleration mechanism of injury. Together, these findings are concerning for an anterior cruciate ligament tear, best confirmed on physical examination with the Lachman test.

The knee's anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) is the most anterior ligamentous component of the knee joint. It prevents the tibia from sliding out in front of the femur and provides rotational stability. The ACL is the most commonly injured ligament in the knee and typically occurs in sports during moments of rapid deceleration, direction changes, or pivoting on a lower extremity with the foot planted. Symptoms include the sensation of a “pop” or “tear” during the injury as well as significant effusion, pain, and sensation of joint instability immediately after the incident.

Two physical examination techniques with high sensitivity for detecting ACL tears are the Lachman test and the anterior drawer test. The Lachman test involves flexing the knee at 20°with the patient supine. At the same time, the examiner places one hand behind the tibia and the other hand grasps the patient's thigh and pulls the tibia forward. A positive test is indicated by anterior translational of the tibia or a “soft” end feel. The anterior drawer test involves the examiner grasping the proximal lower leg below the tibial plateau with the knee in 90°of flexion and attempting to translate the lower leg anteriorly with the patient's foot planted on the examination table. Definitive diagnosis of ACL tear is achieved with MRI. Signs of ACL tear on MRI include swelling, increased signal intensity, fiber discontinuity and abnormal ACL orientation. An empty notch sign which is a fluid signal at the site of femoral attachment at the intercondylar notch may be seen and it denotes avulsion at the femoral attachment.  

Option Analysis

✅ Lachman test:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Ober test:
Incorrect: The Ober test is used to evaluate tension in the iliotibial band. This test would not help assess for an anterior cruciate ligament injury which is present in this case..  
❌ McMurray test:
Incorrect: The McMurray test is used to detect a meniscal injury, which is less likely given this patient’s decreased effusion size and the presence of full range of motion of the knee without locking or clicking..  
❌ Thessaly test:
Incorrect: The Thessaly test, like the McMurray test, detects meniscal injuries. A meniscal tear is less likely in this patient, given that the swelling happened immediately and is subsequently subsiding and he has full range of motion of the knee without locking or clicking.  
❌ Posterior drawer test:
Incorrect: The posterior drawer test detects excessive posterior translation or a “soft” endpoint of the proximal tibia when the posterior cruciate ligament is injured. Posterior cruciate ligament injury commonly occurs with a direct blow to the front of the knee such as when a bent knee hits the dashboard in a motor vehicle collision. Based on this patient’s mechanism of injury, an anterior cruciate ligament injury is more likely.

questions.text:
A 24-year-old man is brought to the emergency department to be evaluated for head trauma following a dive into a shallow swimming pool. Upon extrication, the patient was found to have profuse bleeding from the scalp. Reflexes in the upper and lower extremities were intact, there was good sphincter tone and no Babinski sign. He was subsequently brought to the nearest emergency department in a cervical collar and sent to the CT scanner for further evaluation. A CT of the cervical spine is shown below, as is the lateral cervical radiograph. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of injury resulting in these imaging findings?



Images reproduced from Radiopedia

choices.text: Vertical compression to the neck from axial loading
Hyperflexion and internal rotation of the neck
Lateral force applied to the neck

questions.solution:
This patient presents with imaging findings of anterior and posterior arch fractures or a burst fracture of the C1 vertebra (atlas), also known as a Jefferson fracture. The most common mechanism of injury associated with this fracture pattern is a vertical compression force applied to the neck from axial loading.  

Jefferson fractures often result from motor vehicle accidents, shallow-water diving injuries, or falls from extreme heights. This fracture pattern involves a fracture of the anterior and posterior arches of C1, most commonly due to axial loading transmitted through the occipital condyles to the lateral masses. Jefferson fractures are not typically associated with spinal cord injuries unless a bone fragment injures the spinal cord. However they are often associated with other cervical spine injuries. They are considered stable and treated conservatively with cervical spine collar immobilization unless the transverse atlantal ligament is disrupted which is an unstable injury.  

Imaging of the vertebral arteries with CT angiography or MR angiography is an important part of the evaluation due to concerns for the rare complication of late-onset neurologic deficits from cerebellar infarction caused by blood flow disruptions to the vertebral arteries. When an injury occurs to the vertebral arteries, patients are at risk for developing stroke syndromes such as lateral medullary syndrome, Horner syndrome, ataxia, or the inability to sense pain or temperature.

Option Analysis

✅ Vertical compression to the neck from axial loading  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Hyperextension of the neck:
Incorrect: A hangman fracture refers to a fracture of both pedicles, or pars interarticularis, of the C2 vertebra which can lead to traumatic spondylolisthesis of C2. The most common mechanism of injury associated with this traumatic injury is hyperextension of the neck. The lateral cervical radiograph does not show fractures of the C2 pedicles. In contrast, this patient has a fracture of the C1 vertebra on CT.  
❌ Hyperflexion of the neck  :
Incorrect: Hyperflexion of the neck is the most common mechanism of injury associated with a fracture of the spinous processes of the lower cervical or upper thoracic vertebrae. This injury is also known as a “clay-shoveler fracture”. The lateral cervical radiograph does not show fracture of the spinous processes.  
❌ Hyperflexion and internal rotation of the neck:
Incorrect: Hyperflexion and internal rotation of the neck is the most common mechanism associated with an atlanto-axial dislocation. There is no evidence of the on lateral cervical radiograph of atlanto-axial dislocation, and the patient has none of the neurologic symptoms that are typically seen with atlanto-axial dislocation.  
❌ Lateral force applied to the neck  :
Incorrect: A lateral force applied to the neck is more likely to injure the vertebral transverse processes. The CT does not demonstrate transverse process fractures.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old man presents to the emergency department after a fall down the last step of a flight of stairs. The patient drank several beers earlier during the day and slipped as he was going down the staircase. He landed face first and hyperextended his neck. The patient has facial pain and pain in the posterior cervical spine. Past medical history is unremarkable. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 92/min, respirations are 18/min, blood pressure is 162/84 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. The patient is placed in a cervical spine collar. A CT of the cervical spine is obtained, and the coronal and sagittal views are shown below. Which of the following best describes this pattern of injury?  



Image reproduced from Radiopedia
questions.solution:
This patient presents following a fall down the last step of a flight of stairs and associated neck hypertension. CT imaging demonstrates a fracture through the base of the odontoid process, which is consistent with a type II odontoid fracture.  

Odontoid fractures are the most common type of cervical spine injury seen in older patients and refer to fractures of the odontoid process (dens of C2 vertebra). They often occur in older patients as a result of low-energy falls. This injury pattern most commonly occurs secondary to forced hyperextension of the neck. Less commonly, it can arise via forced hyperflexion of the neck. These fractures can be recognized by bone discontinuation in the dens on an open mouth radiograph or CT scan.  

Odontoid fractures are classified into three distinct injury patterns. A type I odontoid fracture refers to an avulsion fracture of the tip of the odontoid process and represents a stable cervical spine injury. Type II and type III odontoid fractures represent unstable cervical spine injuries and refer to a fracture through the base of the odontoid process and a fracture through the C2 vertebral body, respectively. In particular, type II injuries are at risk of avascular necrosis and nonunion due to poor blood supply. Type III injuries may heal faster due to adequate blood supply to the cervical body but are at higher risk of causing neurologic injury secondary to mechanical instability.

Option Analysis

✅ Type II odontoid injury:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Type I odontoid fracture:
Incorrect: A type I odontoid fracture occurs when only the rostral tip of the odontoid process is avulsed. It is most often a stable cervical spine injury. This CT shows that there is a fracture through the base of the odontoid process not the tip..  
❌ Burst fracture of C1:
Incorrect: A burst fracture of C1 is also known as a Jefferson fracture. Jefferson fractures typically occur after a direct compression force from axial loading to the top of the head, not from a hyperextension injury of the neck as seen in this patient.  
❌ Type III odontoid injury  :
Incorrect: A type III odontoid fracture is a fracture through the body of the C2 vertebra. In contrast, this patient’s CT demonstrates a fracture through the base of the odontoid process.  
❌ Spondylolisthesis of C2:
Incorrect: Traumatic spondylolisthesis and associated fracture of the C2 vertebra are known as “hangman’s injuries” or “hangman’s fracture”. This type of injury typically results from forced hyperextension of the neck. Spondylolisthesis can be identified by anterior displacement of the C2 vertebra relative to the surrounding cervical vertebrae which is not seen in the sagittal view of this CT.

questions.text:
A 72-year-old woman presents to the emergency department after falling at home. The patient typically gets around using a walker. However, she was not using it today, tripped, and fell from standing height. The patient is experiencing low back pain. She was otherwise in good health and had no weight loss, fevers, or increased fatigue. She has never smoked cigarettes. Vitals are within normal. Body mass index is 30 kg/m2. The patient is lying supine on a gurney and in moderate distress on initial evaluation. On physical examination, tenderness is elicited with palpation of the lumbar spine. An initial radiograph of the lumbar spine is demonstrated below. Which of the following is the greatest risk factor predisposing the patient to her current condition?  


Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
This older patient presents for evaluation of low back pain after a fall from a standing height. Physical examination demonstrates tenderness over the lumbar spine, and radiography demonstrates an L3 lumbar compression fracture.
