The most significant risk factor for developing vertebral compression fractures in this patient is underlying osteoporosis.  

Osteoporosis is a disease primarily of older patients, most often seen in post-menopausal women. It results from an imbalance between bone resorption and bone formation resulting from osteoclastic bone resorption not compensated by osteoblastic bone formation. Risk factors for osteoporosis include estrogen deficiency, chronic steroid use, smoking, alcohol use, malnutrition, low BMI, and certain medications such as anticonvulsants.  

Patients with osteoporosis can have vertebral body compression fractures secondary to falls, but they can also experience them with everyday activities like twisting, coughing, and reaching. With osteoporosis, the horizontal trabeculae of the vertebral body becomes weak and the remaining vertical trabeculae are less able to resist compression. With minor falls, such as falls from standing height, compression fractures can occur, resulting in the appearance of short and wedge-shaped vertebrae on radiography.  

Option Analysis

✅ Advanced osteoporosis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Obesity:
Incorrect: This patient sustained a compression fracture of the L3 vertebra body. Advanced osteoporosis is a significant risk factor for developing compression fractures. Having a low body mass index, not obesity, increases the risk of osteoporosis in women.  
❌ Falling from standing height:
Incorrect: Falling from a significant height increases the risk of vertebral body compression fractures even in patients without underlying osteoporosis. In older patients falls from standing height and sitting positions can lead to vertebral compression fractures especially in patient with underlying osteoporosis.  
❌ Nonsmoking history:
Incorrect: Smoking is a risk factor for developing osteoporosis. This patient’s nonsmoking history would decrease her risk of developing osteoporosis and subsequent compression fractures.  
❌ Spinal metastases:
Incorrect: Osteoporosis is the most common cause of compression fractures, but spinal metastases can also be a cause. This patient's radiograph does not show bony metastases, and the patient has no systemic signs or symptoms of malignancy.

questions.text:
A 46-year-old man presents to the emergency department to be evaluated for low back pain. The patient has had right-sided, persistent low back pain that is worse with the movement since falling off a six-foot ladder last week. The patient states, “I could not get out of my chair, the pain was so bad”. Past medical history is notable for nephrolithiasis, obesity, and hypertension. He smokes one pack of cigarettes daily and consumes alcohol occasionally. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates tenderness to palpation over the right flank and right lumbar paraspinal area with limited range of motion of the back secondary to pain. He has no spinal tenderness. No hip or groin pain is elicited with flexion, internal, and external rotations of the hips bilaterally. Straight leg raise is negative bilaterally. A plain film of the spine is shown below along with initial laboratory findings. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?  


Image reproduced from Radiopedia
questions.solution:
This patient presents with right-sided low back pain, for which the differential diagnosis is broad. In the absence of associated systemic symptoms, the most common etiology of low back pain is a lumbosacral strain of the paraspinal muscles.  

Strains, sprains, and spasms represent the majority of musculoskeletal back injuries, which largely occur in the setting of recent trauma, injury, or heavy lifting. Risk factors for these injuries include occupational hazards, such as heavy lifting and frequent back movement. Additional risk factors include advanced age, obesity, lack of exercise and stretching, and smoking.  

Back strains refer to injury of the muscles or ligaments of the back. Back sprains refer to injury of the ligamentous tissue or their attachment sites to the bone. Finally, spasms refer to involuntary muscle contractions in response to inflammation.  

Management of these injuries is largely supportive, including applying ice or heat packs and taking over-the-counter analgesia or antiinflammatory agents.  

Option Analysis

✅ Lumbosacral strain:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Nephrolithiasis:
Incorrect: Nephrolithiasis should be in the differential for this patient, given the flank pain and history of recurrent kidney stones. However, his urinalysis shows no evidence of hematuria making nephrolithiasis less likely. Instead, this patient’s symptoms can be better explained by lumbosacral muscle strain.  
❌ Lumbar radiculopathy:
Incorrect: Lumbar radiculopathy most commonly results from the bulging of intervertebral discs. Symptoms often include low back pain and associated pain radiating down the lower extremities. Straight leg raise is typically positive with this condition. This patient is not experiencing radicular pain.  
❌ Osteoarthritis of the hip:
Incorrect: Osteoarthritis of the hip more commonly occurs in older patients. Pain is typically experienced in the groin area with hip motion. This patient does not have any reproducible pain when the hip is moved, and he does not complain of groin pain.  
❌ Vertebral body compression fracture:
Incorrect: While this patient sustained a recent fall, the lumbar film does not show evidence of fracture making vertebral body compression fracture unlikely in this patient.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman presents to the emergency department due to severe abdominal pain. Three months ago, the patient underwent uncomplicated abdominal surgery to resect a large uterine fibroid. Past surgical history is notable for a C-section and cholecystectomy. Temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 110/60 mm Hg. On physical examination, high pitched bowel sounds are heard on auscultation and there is guarding and diffuse abdominal tenderness with palpation. A CT of the abdomen and pelvis shows dilated loops of the small bowel with a transition point. What is the cause of this patient’s current disorder?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with diffuse abdominal pain, guarding, and pain with palpation in the setting of a history of multiple abdominal surgeries. Furthermore, physical examination reveals high-pitched bowel sounds, and CT imaging demonstrates dilated bowel loops with a transition point. In combination, these findings indicate a small bowel obstruction (SBO).    

While SBO can be caused by several factors, such as a space-occupying malignancy, infection, trauma, or irradiation, the vast majority are caused by peritoneal adhesions. Peritoneal adhesions form in 93 to 100% of patients following abdominal surgery. Adhesions are fibrous connective tissue bands analogous to scar tissue on the skin that form between two or more intra-abdominal organs and/or the inner abdominal wall. These adhesions can cause a lattice of dense connective tissue throughout the abdominal cavity, making future surgical operations difficult. The adhesions can lead to strangulation of small bowel loops and SBO. They can lead to other complications including female infertility and chronic abdominal pain.  

Option Analysis

❌ Malignancy:
Incorrect: Malignancies can cause small bowel obstruction. However, given this patient’s history of multiple abdominal surgeries, peritoneal adhesions are more likely the cause of SBO in this patient.  
❌ Paralytic ileus:
Incorrect: Paralytic ileus occurs in the days following an abdominal operation. In contrast, this patient is several months out from her most recent abdominal surgery.  
✅ Peritoneal adhesions:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Uterine lLeiomyomata :
Incorrect: Large uterine fibroids can potentially cause bowel obstruction, and while this patient has a history of uterine leiomyomata or fibroids, the mass was resected 3 months ago. Recurrence of uterine fibroids after surgery can occur within the first few years after removal, but they do not typically recur within months after surgery.  
❌ Abscess from previous surgery:
Incorrect: While an intra-abdominal abscess can lead to SBO, it  would present with an air-fluid level on imaging as well as systemic signs such as fever, nausea, and vomiting. Most intra-abdominal abscesses occur within 1-3 weeks of surgery. It is rare for them to develop several months after surgery.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man is brought to the clinic for recent onset of severe nausea, vomiting, and disorientation. The patient has a history of severe hypertension, congestive heart failure, and chronic kidney disease. Temperature is 37.0 (98.6°F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 180/110 mm Hg. The patient is sent by ambulance to the emergency department. Brain imaging is negative. He is subsequently admitted to the hospital. Urinalysis is performed and reveals broad and waxy casts. There are no granular muddy brown casts present on urinalysis. The patient’s glomerular filtration rate (GFR) is 10 mL/min/1.73 m2. A decision is made to initiate urgent peritoneal dialysis. Which of the following is a complication of this method of dialysis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with hypertensive urgency without evidence of end organ damage, and he is in renal failure with a GFR of 10 mL/min/1.73 m2. In addition, he suffers from congestive heart failure. . Urinalysis does not show evidence of acute renal injury. He likely has late-stage chronic kidney disease secondary to long-term uncontrolled hypertension. In addition to antihypertensive therapies, a core component of this patient’s treatment is urgent dialysis.     

Dialysis comes in two main forms: hemodialysis and peritoneal dialysis (other subtypes also exist, such as automated peritoneal dialysis). In the case of hemodialysis, the patient needs to have a compliant cardiovascular circuit to handle the large volume of fluid exchanged during the procedure. However, this patient's congestive heart failure is a contraindication to hemodialysis.    

Instead, this patient needs to receive peritoneal dialysis (PD). PD involves inserting a large indwelling catheter into the peritoneal space. This catheter is often a nidus of infection since it directly communicates with the skin and can be manipulated by the patient, improperly maintained, or irritated. Dialysis solution can be injected into the peritoneum via the catheter, which draws (via microfluidic forces driven by solute concentration gradients) toxic solutes into the peritoneal space. The dialysis solution is then voided, and the cycle can be repeated if needed. This procedure capitalizes on the peritoneum’s distensibility and large surface area, essentially creating “artificial ascites,” whereby detoxification can occur in a more natural albeit slow manner.   

Option Analysis

❌ Hypotension:
Incorrect: This is a common complication of hemodialysis. However, given this patient’s history of congestive heart failure, peritoneal dialysis would be a better treatment option. Hypotension due to peritoneal dialysis is rare.  
❌ Hyperkalemia:
Incorrect: This is a common complication of hemodialysis. However, given this patient’s history of congestive heart failure, peritoneal dialysis would be a better treatment option. Patients on chronic peritoneal dialysis often develop hypokalemia, but hyperkalemia is not commonly seen.  
❌ Dialysis disequilibrium syndrome:
Incorrect: Dialysis disequilibrium syndrome (DDS) is a common complication of hemodialysis. Osmotic fluid imbalances cause DDS in the brain. In contrast, it does not typically occur with peritoneal dialysis.  
✅ Indwelling catheter infection:
Correct: See main explanation.   
❌ Air embolism:
Incorrect: Air embolism is a rare complication of hemodialysis. This patient’s history of congestive heart failure makes peritoneal dialysis the best treatment option. Air embolism is not a complication of peritoneal dialysis.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents to the emergency department after being tackled during a football match. The patient was knocked to the ground by another player. He experienced sudden-onset sharp pain in the abdomen and left shoulder. He subsequently lost consciousness. Before the incident, the patient had been experiencing fatigue and sore throat for two weeks. He has no significant past medical history and was screened with an ECG prior to playing football. At arrival, temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 90/60, and pulse is 110/min. Physical examination reveals diffuse abdominal guarding and rigidity. Elevation of the legs leads to the patient grimacing in pain and grabbing his left shoulder. Palpation of the left upper abdominal quadrant also causes the patient to grimace in pain. The bilateral tonsils are swollen and erythematous, and there is bilateral posterior cervical lymphadenopathy. Which of the following best explains this patient’s shoulder pain?

choices.text: Shoulder dislocation due to excessive force

questions.solution:
This patient presents with acute-onset abdominal pain and hypotension after being tackled during a football match. In addition, he likely has concurrent infectious mononucleosis given his symptoms of fatigue, sore throat, and findings of swollen, erythematous tonsils bilaterally with posterior cervical lymphadenopathy. In combination, these findings are concerning for a splenic rupture and associated internal bleeding.    

The patient experienced left shoulder pain after the tackle and grimaces from left shoulder pain when the legs are elevated. This finding of left shoulder pain from irritation of the left diaphragm is known as the Kehr Sign. It is a classic example of referred pain. The pathophysiology of Kehr Sign is the same as that of other types of referred pain: visceral pain in one location of the body is interpreted as somatic pain in another due to effects of temporal and spatial summation of nerves arising from the same spinal level.    
In this case, splenic rupture and filling of the abdominal cavity with blood irritates the inferior surface of the left diaphragm. Irritation of the underside of the diaphragm is signaled by the phrenic nerve which carries pain signals up to spinal nerve levels C3 and C4. The supraclavicular nerve, which innervates the skin over the shoulder, also inserts at cervical levels C3 and C4. As a result, there is referred pain to the left shoulder from splenic rupture.  

Option Analysis

❌ Shoulder dislocation due to excessive force:
Incorrect: Shoulder dislocation does not explain this patient’s abdominal symptoms, head and neck findings, and hypotension. Splenic rupture associated with trauma in a patient with mononucleosis infection is more likely the cause of this constellation of findings.  
❌ Undiagnosed tumor:
Incorrect: An undiagnosed intra-abdominal malignancy would  likely present with insidious and chronic pain. This patient has acute onset abdominal pain and hypotension after a traumatic tackle and signs of mononucleosis which would indicate splenic rupture.  
❌ Impingement of the supraclavicular nerve:
Incorrect: Impingement of this nerve would cause pain in the shoulder area. However, it would not account for the patient’s abdominal pain, hypotension, and head and neck findings.  
❌ Atypical myocardial infarction:
Incorrect: Although an atypical myocardial infarction can present with abdominal pain, it would not account for this patient’s symptoms of acute abdomen (e.g., diffuse guarding, rigidity), hypotension, and head and neck findings. Myocardial infarction would be unlikely in this young man with no prior medical history who had a screening ECG prior to playing sports.  
✅ Irritation of the diaphragm:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman comes to the office because of a three-month history of epigastric pain, weight loss, and nausea. Over the last three months, the patient has lost 30-lbs (13.6 kg). She says, “My pants are fitting looser than usual.” She also reports that food is not as appetizing as it used to be. Past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. Current medications include metformin, atorvastatin, and lisinopril. Family history is noncontributory. Biopsy from an upper endoscopy reveals an adenocarcinoma of the gastric antrum, of intestinal-type. Which of the following additional findings could be present on physical examination if the gastric carcinoma has metastasized?
questions.solution:
Malignancy of the stomach can reach an advanced stage before becoming clinically symptomatic. One of the first spots where these tumors metastasize is to the left supraclavicular lymph node through the thoracic duct (Virchow node).   

Visible enlargement of Virchow node (Troisier sign) results from the carcinomatous involvement of the supraclavicular nodes at the junction of the thoracic duct and the left subclavian vein. It can be an early sign of gastric cancer. Usually, Troisier sign is caused by metastatic gastric carcinoma, although supraclavicular nodal involvement can also be seen in other gastrointestinal, thoracic, and pelvic cancers. Gastric cancers tend to metastasize to this region through migration of tumor emboli through the thoracic duct, where subdiaphragmatic lymphatic drainage enters the venous circulation in the left subclavian vein.



Option Analysis

❌ Courvoisier sign:
Incorrect: Courvoisier sign is the presence of a palpably enlarged gallbladder in patients with mild jaundice unlikely to be caused by gallstones. This sign indicates possible malignancy of the gallbladder or pancreas.  
✅ Enlarged Virchow node:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Murphy sign:
Incorrect: Murphy sign is inspiratory arrest with deep palpation of the upper right quadrant while the patient takes a deep breath. Inspiratory arrest is a positive Murphy sign and indicates an inflamed gallbladder. It is useful for differentiating pain in the right upper quadrant and is specifically seen in acute cholecystitis. This patient has signs and symptoms consistent with gastric malignancy.  
❌ Right supraclavicular adenopathy :
Incorrect: Right supraclavicular adenopathy is associated with cancer in the mediastinum, lungs, or esophagus, but not typically gastric cancer.  
❌ Chvostek sign:
Incorrect: The Chvostek sign is a clinical sign of hypocalcemia which consists of twitching of muscles innervated by the facial nerve. It refers to an abnormal reaction to the stimulation of the facial nerve. It is not commonly seen in gastric malignancy.

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman comes to the emergency department for evaluation of stroke-like symptoms. The patient states, “My face appeared twisted this morning.” She also reports persistent vertigo, difficulty walking, and impaired hearing from the left ear. Temperature is 37.7°C (99.8°F), pulse is 99/min, respirations are 20/min and blood pressure is 166/90 mmHg. The patient falls to the left when asked to sit without support. Physical examination demonstrates drooping of the left face and loss of the left nasolabial fold. The patient is able to wrinkle the forehead. Further neurologic examination demonstrates partial ptosis and miosis of the left eye, nystagmus, reduced pain and temperature sensation on the left side of the face and right side of the body, and sensorineural hearing loss on the left. Hearing on the right side is intact. Which of the following vascular structures is most likely implicated given this patient’s clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation is consistent lateral pontine syndrome most likely due to the occlusion of anterior inferior cerebellar artery (AICA). Clinical features of lateral pontine syndrome include:
  
  • Vestibulocerebellar symptoms such as nystagmus, vertigo, and difficulty sitting upright without support (falling to the side of lesion) 
  • Loss of pain and temperature sensation of the ipsilateral face (spinal trigeminal nucleus and tract) and contralateral trunk/limbs (spinothalamic tract) 
  • Paralysis of the face (LMN lesion vs UMN lesion in cortical stroke), ↓ lacrimation, ↓ salivation and ↓ taste from anterior two-thirds of the tongue 
  • Ipsilateral Horner (miosis, ptosis, and anhidrosis) due to damage of sympathetic fibers innervating the head and neck 
  •  Ipsilateral ataxia and dysmetria due to the involvement of middle and inferior cerebellar peduncle 
  • Ipsilateral sensorineural deafness due to the occlusion of labyrinthine arteries, a branch of AICA 

Option Analysis

❌ A:
Incorrect: Saccular aneurysms are often found in both the anterior and posterior communicating arteries of the circle of Willis. Anterior communicating artery aneurysms often compress the central optic chiasm, resulting in symptoms of bitemporal hemianopsia.  
❌ B:
Incorrect: Ischemia of the anterior cerebral artery often results in contralateral motor and sensory deficits, with the lower limbs affected more than the upper limbs.  
❌ C:
Incorrect: Posterior cerebral artery infarction typically results in contralateral hemianopia, secondary to infarction of the visual cortex. The macula is often spared due to contralateral circulation from the middle cerebral artery.  
✅ D:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ E:
Incorrect: Basilar artery occlusion usually damages the base of the pons, which houses the corticospinal/ corticobulbar tracts and the paramedian tegmentum. Ischemia to these structures results in quadriplegia, bulbar dysfunction (e.g., facial weakness, dysarthria), and oculomotor deficits (e.g. horizontal gaze palsy).

questions.text: An 85-year-old man is brought to the emergency room after being found on the floor in his home. Past medical history is significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Temperature is 37.7°C (99.8°F), pulse is 101/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 188/94 mmHg. The patient appears conscious, but does not demonstrate spontaneous movement of the extremities and is unable to respond to voice or painful stimuli. The patient is able to blink and eye movements are restricted to the vertical plane. Magnetic resonance angiogram will most likely reveal ischemia of which of the following vascular structures?
questions.solution:
This patient's inability to move the extremities, loss of horizontal eye movements with preserved consciousness, and loss of mouth, tongue, and facial movements, is consistent with locked-in syndrome (LIS), due to the occlusion of the basilar artery. The most vulnerable territory associated with this condition lies at the paramedian base of the pons.  

Clinical features consistent with locked-in syndrome include:  

  • Quadriplegia and inability to speak or swallow due to the involvement of corticospinal and corticobulbar tracts 
  • Preserved consciousness due to the sparing of the reticular formation 
  • Loss of horizontal eye movement due to the involvement of ocular cranial nerve nuclei and paramedian pontine reticular formation 
  • Voluntary blinking and vertical eye movements remain intact, which are controlled in the rostral portion of the brainstem  

Option Analysis

❌ Posterior inferior cerebellar artery:
Incorrect: Posterior inferior cerebellar artery occlusion results in lateral medullary (Wallenberg) syndrome characterized by vertigo/nystagmus, ipsilateral cerebellar signs, loss of pain/temperature sensation on the ipsilateral face and contralateral body, bulbar weakness, and Horner syndrome.  
❌ Anterior spinal artery:
Incorrect: Infarction of the paramedian branches of anterior spinal artery results in medial medullary syndrome, which typically presents with contralateral hemiparesis (lateral corticospinal tract), decreased contralateral proprioception (medial lemniscus), and ipsilateral tongue paralysis (hypoglossal nucleus).  
❌ Anterior inferior cerebellar artery:
Incorrect: Lateral pontine syndrome occurs secondary to occlusion of anterior inferior cerebellar artery (AICA). Patients typically present with signs of a lower motor neuron facial nerve lesion, vertigo/nystagmus, ipsilateral cerebellar signs, loss of pain/temperature sensation on the ipsilateral face and contralateral body, ipsilateral sensorineural loss, and Horner syndrome.  
✅ Basilar artery:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Posterior cerebral artery:
Incorrect: Posterior cerebral artery infarction typically results in contralateral hemianopia due to infarction of the visual cortex. The macula is often spared due to contralateral circulation from the middle cerebral artery.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man undergoes a surgical repair for a large abdominal aortic aneurysm. His surgery was complicated by hypotension, immediately managed with intravenous fluids. A few hours postoperatively, the patient complains of abdominal pain, followed by an episode of bloody diarrhea. Past medical history is significant for coronary artery disease, type II diabetes mellitus, and hypertension. Temperature is 37.6°C (99.8°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 140/75 mmHg. Physical examination shows a mildly distended abdomen with no significant tenderness or guarding and normal bowel sounds. Laboratory evaluation reveals metabolic acidosis and a leukocyte count of 10,000/mm3. Which of the following areas will most likely show abnormal findings on a CT scan?
questions.solution:
This patient with abdominal pain followed by an episode of bloody diarrhea most likely has nonocclusive ischemic colitis, secondary to repairing the abdominal aortic aneurysm which resulted in an episode of hypotension. Ischemic injury to the colon usually occurs due to a sudden and transient reduction in blood flow, resulting in a low-flow state and most commonly affects the watershed areas.   

Watershed areas refer to body regions that receive dual blood supply from the most distal branches of two large arteries. In the intestine, these include the splenic flexure at the area between the territory of the superior mesenteric artery (SMA) and inferior mesenteric artery (IMA) and the rectosigmoid junction at the area between the sigmoid artery (IMA) and the superior rectal artery.   

Patients with ischemic colitis usually present with crampy abdominal pain, followed by hematochezia or bloody diarrhea. Physical examination often reveals abdominal tenderness of variable severity over the location of the affected portion of the bowel. A CT scan with intravenous contrast may show a thickened bowel wall. Colonoscopy confirms the diagnosis and shows pale mucosa with petechial bleeding, bluish hemorrhagic nodules, and cyanotic mucosa with hemorrhage.  



Option Analysis

❌ Hepatic flexure:
Incorrect: The hepatic flexure is the sharp bend between the ascending colon and the transverse colon and lies in the right upper quadrant of the abdomen. It receives blood supply from the SMA and is unlikely to undergo ischemia secondary to hypotension.  
✅ Splenic flexure:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Rectum:
Incorrect: Ischemia is less common in the rectum as it receives collateral blood supply via rectal arteries.  
❌ Ascending colon:
Incorrect: Ascending colon is supplied by branches of the superior mesenteric artery and is less commonly affected by hypotension.  
❌ Mid-transverse colon:
Incorrect: Mid-transverse colon is supplied by branches of the superior mesenteric artery and is less commonly affected by hypotension.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man comes to the office because he noticed rectal bleeding. He has occasionally noticed a few streaks of bright-red blood on the toilet paper after wiping, but today he saw blood dripping in the toilet at the end of defecation. The patient also reports mild itching around the perianal opening but no pain. The rest of the review of systems is unremarkable. Past medical history is significant for chronic constipation and type II diabetes mellitus. Current medications include atorvastatin and metformin. Family history is noncontributory. Vitals are within normal limits. On physical examination the abdomen is nontender and nondistended. The digital rectal examination does not demonstrate an abnormal mass or tenderness. Anoscopy is significant for bulging purplish-blue veins above the dentate line. Which of the following best describes the cutaneous innervation of this region above the dentate line?

choices.text: This region is not innervated by a cutaneous nerve.

questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation with painless rectal bleeding and bulging purplish-blue veins above the dentate line is consistent with internal hemorrhoids. Hemorrhoids are swollen and inflamed veins in the rectum and anus that can cause discomfort and bleeding. They can be classified based on their location relative to the dentate line.  

Internal hemorrhoids are subepithelial vascular cushions consisting of connective tissue, smooth muscle fibers, and arteriovenous communications between terminal branches of the superior rectal artery and rectal veins and are located proximal to the dentate line. They have autonomic innervation from the inferior hypogastric plexus (sensitive to stretch only) and are devoid of cutaneous innervation. Internal hemorrhoids may prolapse or bleed but rarely become painful unless they develop thrombosis and necrosis.  

External hemorrhoids arise from the inferior hemorrhoidal veins located below the dentate line. They are covered with the squamous epithelium of the anal canal, and have cutaneous innervation from the inferior rectal nerve, a branch of the pudendal nerve.  



Option Analysis

❌ Pudendal nerve:
Incorrect: External hemorrhoids originate below the dentate line, are covered by squamous epithelium, and have cutaneous innervation by the pudendal nerve. This patient with bulging veins above the dentate line most likely has an internal hemorrhoid.  
❌ Ilioinguinal nerve:
Incorrect: Ilioinguinal nerve is a sensory nerve that carries sensations from the upper and medial part of the thigh, the root of the penis, and the upper part of the scrotum in the males and mons pubis and labia majora in the females. It does not innervate the mucosa of the gastrointestinal tract.  
❌ Inferior gluteal nerve:
Incorrect: The inferior gluteal nerve is a motor nerve that innervates the gluteus maximus muscle.   
✅ This region is not innervated by a cutaneous nerve. :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Pelvic splanchnic nerves:
Incorrect: Splanchnic nerves (S2-S4) provide parasympathetic (not cutaneous) innervation to the pelvic and genital organs.

questions.text: A 26-year-old primigravida at 39 weeks gestation comes to the emergency room in active labor. She has had routine prenatal care. Medical history is significant for gestational diabetes mellitus. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 105/75 mmHg. She delivers a 4kg male baby. A 2nd-degree perineal tear is noted. Which of the following structures is most likely involved in this injury?
questions.solution:
This patient has a second-degree perineal tear following a difficult childbirth. A second-degree perineal tear involves injury to the perineal body.    

Perineal tears are a common obstetric injury following difficult vaginal childbirth. They are distinct from an episiotomy, an intentional enlargement of the vaginal introitus to facilitate delivery.  

An episiotomy is a surgical incision that involves the perineum and the posterior vaginal wall during the second stage of labor. Episiotomies are done to minimize perineal injuries caused by overstretching the perineum by the fetal head; however, they are not routinely indicated.  Possible indications for an episiotomy include conditions when the physician anticipates a perineal tear, elderly primigravida, macrosomia, face to pubis delivery, forceps/ventouse delivery, breech delivery, or shoulder dystocia.    

There are two common approaches to an episiotomy; a mediolateral approach and a median approach.  In a mediolateral episiotomy, the incision is made at an angle and proceeds from the vaginal opening diagonally downwards to the left or the right in a straight line that runs an inch away from the anus.  During a mediolateral episiotomy, structures incised include the posterior vaginal wall, superficial and deep transverse perineal muscles, bulbospongiosus, part of the levator ani, subcutaneous tissue, and skin.  

In the median episiotomy, the incision proceeds from the vaginal opening downwards. Median episiotomies bifurcate the perineal body, which supports the female pelvic organs, particularly the posterior vaginal wall. Incision of the perineal body poses a risk of pelvic organ prolapse and urinary incontinence. Midline episiotomies can also extend into the anal sphincter and cause sphincter dysfunction and fecal incontinence.  





Option Analysis

✅ Perineal body :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Anal mucosa:
Incorrect: Fourth-degree perineal tears involve the anal sphincter complex and the anal mucosa. Second-degree perineal tears are limited to the perineal skin and the perineal body.   
❌ Ischiocavernosus muscle :
Incorrect: The ischiocavernosus muscle is a component of the urogenital triangle and the superficial perineal pouch. It arises from the ischial tuberosity and inserts into the crura of the clitoris. It is unlikely to be involved in second-degree perineal tears.   
❌ Internal anal sphincter :
Incorrect: The anal sphincter complex (internal anal sphincter and the external anal sphincter) are damaged in fourth-degree perineal lacerations.   
❌ External anal sphincter :
Incorrect: Severe perineal lacerations of the third and fourth degrees tend to involve the external anal sphincter and result in fecal incontinence.

questions.text:
A 56-year-old woman comes to the clinic with flank pain. The pain began insidiously a month ago. She has not had nausea, vomiting, hematuria, dysuria, fever, or altered bowel habits. Past medical history is significant for a subtotal abdominal hysterectomy two months ago for uterine fibroids. She does not smoke, drink or consume alcohol.  Family history is noncontributory. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 110/75 mmHg. Abdominal examination reveals tenderness to palpation over the lower back. Urinalysis is negative for leukocyte esterase and nitrites. Abdominal CT is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?  

 

  
Reproduced from radiopedia.org   
Case courtesy of David Puyó

choices.text: Hydronephrosis due to a ureteral stone

questions.solution:
This patient developed flank pain of insidious onset, and a CT revealed dilated, renal calyces and a benign urinalysis. She most likely has a ureteral injury due to her recent abdominal hysterectomy.  The uterine and ovarian arteries provide blood supply to the uterus, fallopian tubes, and ovaries.    

Hysterectomies require ligation of the uterine artery in the broad ligament. Conditions like malignant ovarian tumors may require the ligation of the ovarian arteries in the infundibulopelvic ligament. The course of the ureter in the female pelvis is close to the uterine and ovarian vessels. Ligation of the uterine or ovarian vessels poses the risk of accidental ligation of the ureter.    

The ureter lies anterior to the internal iliac artery and then continues posteriorly to the ovary in the ovarian fossa along with the uterine vessels. At this point, the ureter is at risk of injury during an oophorectomy and should be appropriately identified before ligation of the ovarian vessels.    

The ureter then descends, crossing the ischial spine until it lies in the inferomedial portion of the broad ligament. In the broad ligament, the uterine artery is anterosuperior to the ureter (“=the bridge”) until it crosses the ureter in the lateral portion of the broad ligament. During a hysterectomy, the uterine artery is identified at the junction of the lower uterine segment and the cervix and ligated at the lateral border of the uterus. At this point, care should be taken to ensure that the clamps are placed on the uterine vessels and not the ureters.  

 

Option Analysis

✅ Hydronephrosis due to ureteral injury :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Polycystic kidney disease :
Incorrect: Adult polycystic disease is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern. Patients may present with flank pain, hematuria, and hypertension. CT scan is likely to reveal multiple cysts instead of dilated renal calyces.    
❌ Hydronephrosis due to a ureteral stone :
Incorrect: A ureteric stone causes an acute onset of abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and hematuria in addition to crystals on urine analysis. The insidious onset of this patient’s symptoms indicates the need for an alternative cause for her hydronephrosis.    
❌ Renal cell carcinoma :
Incorrect: RCC is suspected in patients with a history of smoking or those with a positive family history. Classically, symptoms include abdominal mass and hematuria, neither present in this patient.   
❌ Wilms tumor :
Incorrect: Wilms tumor is a common renal malignancy in children and classically presents with an abdominal mass. Considering this patient’s age, this diagnosis is unlikely.

questions.text:
A 16-year-old girl comes to the clinic with a lump near her vagina. She first noticed the bump three days ago, making sitting and walking uncomfortable. The patient has not had a fever, vomiting, or dysuria. She plays soccer and is an active gymnast.  Past medical history includes schizophrenia and generalized anxiety disorder. Her last menstrual period was two weeks ago. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 90/75 mmHg. Abdominal examination is unremarkable. Focused physical examination reveals a nontender, cystic mass distending the right labia and obstructing the vaginal introitus. Total leukocyte count is 7,000/mm3. Which of the following is the underlying cause of this patient’s symptoms?  

 
By Medimage - Own work, CC BY-SA 3.0,  
Reproduced from Wikimedia commons

choices.text: Ductal obstruction of the paraurethral glands

questions.solution:
This patient has vaginal discomfort and a mass in the region of the Bartholin gland (also called the greater vestibular gland).  She most likely has a Bartholin’s cyst. Most cysts are asymptomatic and resolve on their own. Management with antibiotics and incision and drainage is only indicated if the cyst is infected.   Bartholin’s glands drain out to ducts present at the four o’clock and eight o’clock positions of the vaginal orifice. The gland's primary function is mucous secretion to increase vulvar and vaginal lubrication. If the ducts are obstructed at the orifice, mucous production accumulates, and a cystic swelling can form at the position of the ductal opening. This is known as a Bartholin’s cyst. If the fluid in the cyst gets infected, a Bartholin’s abscess develops.    

Bartholin’s cysts are asymptomatic and frequently present with a nontender, cystic swelling at the position of the Bartholin's duct in the posterior aspect of the vaginal orifice. Bartholin’s abscesses tend to be painful, erythematous, fluctuant, and tender. Patients are often febrile and complain of dyspareunia and difficulty walking and sitting down. Bartholin’s abscesses are treated with incision and drainage.  

Option Analysis

✅ Ductal obstruction of Bartholin’s glands :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Human papillomavirus infection :
Incorrect: HPV infection typically causes exophytic, sessile, or pedunculated growths in the perineum. It does not cause cystic masses.   
❌ Ductal obstruction of the paraurethral glands:
Incorrect: Skene’s glands are paraurethral glands that can form cysts due to ductal obstruction. The position of the cyst in this patient is not consistent with a Skene’s gland cyst, which forms adjacent to the urethral meatus. Symptoms of a Skene’s gland cyst include painful urination and urinary tract infections.  
❌ Hematoma due to local trauma :
Incorrect: A hematoma would present with pain, erythema, and swelling within 24 hours of injury. This patient does not have a history of trauma to her genital region.   
❌ Poxvirus infection  :
Incorrect: Molluscum contagiosum is caused by a poxvirus and classically presents as small, painless, umbilicated papules distributed in the genital region. Cystic lesions are not common.

questions.text:
A 22-year-old man presents to the emergency department after being involved in a fight at a bar. The patient was punched in his left eye and reports double vision when looking upward. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates periorbital swelling and ecchymosis and an inability of the left eye to gaze upward. A CT of the face is shown below. Which of the following neurologic deficits is expected on further physical examination?
   

Reproduced from: Radiopaedia

choices.text: Diminished sensation over the left lower eyelid
Jaw deviation to the left with the opening of the mouth
Diminished sensation over the left forehead and scalp
Diminished sensation along the left mandible

questions.solution:
This patient presents with evidence of an orbital floor fracture, including inferior rectus muscle entrapment (diplopia and limited upward gaze). Orbital floor fractures are commonly associated with injuries to the infraorbital nerve, given its course along the inferior aspect of the orbit. Maxillary sinus surgeries also place this nerve at high risk of injury.

The infraorbital nerve is a branch of V2 of the trigeminal nerve and supplies sensation to the skin of the lower eyelid, side of the nose, anteroinferior nasal septum, cheek, and upper lip. Damage to this nerve often manifests sensory deficits in these areas. Thus, maxillary sinus infections and sinusitis often result in pain in the upper teeth.  

Option Analysis

✅ Diminished sensation over the left lower eyelid:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Jaw deviation to the left with the opening of the mouth:
Incorrect: Jaw deviation to the left with the opening of the mouth would be expected with complete injury to the V3 branch of the trigeminal nerve or injury to the nerve root/ganglion. Orbital floor fractures are unlikely to damage the entirety of V3.  
❌ Diminished sensation over the left forehead and scalp:
Incorrect: Diminished sensation over the left forehead and scalp may occur with injury to the frontal nerve or its branches. This is more likely to occur with supraorbital rim fractures, not orbital floor fractures.  
❌ Diminished sensation along the left mandible:
Incorrect: Diminished sensation along the left mandible would reflect injury to the inferior alveolar nerve, which is more commonly injured during lower molar extractions--not orbital floor fractures.  
❌ Left eye blindness:
Incorrect: Left eye blindness may occur with damage to cranial nerve I. Significant damage to this nerve is unlikely with orbital floor fractures.

questions.text:
A 70-year-old man comes to the office of his primary care physician because of progressive weight loss and yellow discoloration of skin. The patient reports that he had lost approximately 8 kgs (17.6 lb) over the past 3 months. The patient also complains of dark urine and pale stools. Review of systems is positive for heartburn and mild upper abdominal pain for the past few months. Past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus diagnosed five years ago. The patient has a 30-year history of smoking two packs of cigarettes a day. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows scleral and cutaneous icterus. The lungs are clear to auscultation and no abnormal heart sounds are heard. CT scan of the abdomen is shown below. Which of the following additional findings can be seen in this patient?  



Reproduced from Radiopedia

choices.text: Dark rings that encircle the iris of the eyes
Palpable nodule bulging into the umbilicus

questions.solution:
This patient with obstructive jaundice and a mass of the head of pancreas, most likely has pancreatic cancer.    

The most common type is the cancer of the pancreatic head, which accounts for the most cases of hepatobiliary obstruction. Because of the posterior relationships of the pancreas, cancer of the head often compresses and obstructs the bile duct and/or the hepatopancreatic ampulla. This causes obstruction, resulting in the retention of bile pigments, painless enlargement of the gallbladder (Courvoisier sign), and obstructive jaundice. Courvoisier’s law states that an enlarged and non-tender gallbladder accompanied by mild jaundice is unlikely caused by gallstones and rather caused by pancreatic or gallstone cancer. Weight loss can occur due to high tumor metabolism or to pancreatic insufficiency.  

Among others, pancreatic cancer can invade major arteries, like the superior mesenteric artery, which lies posterior to the neck of the pancreas. When the superior mesenteric artery is invaded, it usually means that the cancer cannot be surgically resected. On the other hand, cancer of the neck and body of the pancreas may cause hepatic portal or inferior vena caval obstruction because the pancreas overlies these large veins.  



Option Analysis

❌ Renal artery bruit:
Incorrect: Renal artery bruit can be heard in patients with renal artery stenosis, which is characterized by resistant hypertension. This patient’s vitals are within normal limits, and the CT scan abdomen is significant for the mass of the head of the pancreas.  
❌ Increased liver span:
Incorrect: Increased liver span is a nonspecific finding that can be seen in a number of infectious (e.g., hepatitis and infectious mononucleosis), biliary (e.g., biliary sclerosing cholangitis) and neoplastic (e.g., hepatocellular carcinoma) conditions. This patient’s yellow skin and sclera and association with a mass of the pancreatic head is suggestive of pancreatic cancer.  
❌ Dark rings that encircle the iris of the eyes:
Incorrect: Kayser–Fleischer rings, characterized by dark rings that encircle the iris of the eyes, are pathognomonic of Wilson disease, which results from accumulation of copper in the liver and decreased excretion in bile. It is characterized by fatigue, abdominal pain, and uncontrolled or poorly coordinated movements. Pancreatic head involvement, as seen in this abdominal CT scan, is not a feature of Wilson disease.  
✅ Palpable non-tender gallbladder:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Palpable nodule bulging into the umbilicus:
Incorrect: The Sister Mary Joseph sign, characterized by a palpable nodule bulging into the umbilicus, is typically seen in patients with gastric cancer. Although it can cause weight loss and abdominal pain, a pancreatic mass in this patient is suggestive of pancreatic carcinoma.

questions.text:
A 43-year-old woman comes to the office because of blood in her urine. The patient reports intermittent painless hematuria associated with mild to moderate left lumbar pain and nausea for the last three months. She does not have dysuria, urinary frequency, or urinary urgency. Past medical history is significant for major depression, and the patient reports that she has lost a lot of weight over the past few months. Family history is unremarkable. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a nontender, nondistended abdomen. Lungs and cardiovascular examination are within normal limits. Urinalysis shows 15–20 Er/Hpf and no proteinuria. An abdominal CT is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s presentation?  


Reproduced from Radiopedia
questions.solution:
This patient presents with a recent history of significant weight loss presents with intermittent gross hematuria and lumbar pain. The abdominal CT scan demonstrates left renal vein compression at its distal segment between the aorta and the superior mesenteric artery with mild proximal dilatation. In combination, this presentation is consistent with nutcracker syndrome (NCS).  

NCS occurs when the left renal vein, which drains blood from the left kidney, becomes squeezed between the superior mesenteric artery (SMA) and abdominal aorta. Normally, the aortomesenteric angle (between SMA and aorta) is around 45 degrees, with the renal vein cushioned by a bit of fat in the mesentery. If there is significant weight loss which shrinks the mesenteric fat, this angle is reduced, and the arteries begin to pinch the left renal vein, causing renal hypertension. Over time, the high pressures cause small breaks in the renal blood vessels. Patients typically present with gross hematuria and left flank pain that may improve or worsen depending on positioning.  

Since the left gonadal vein drains via the left renal vein, nutcracker syndrome can also result in left testicular pain in males or left lower quadrant pain in females, especially during intercourse and during menstruation. An unusual manifestation of NCS includes varicocele formation and varicose veins in the lower limbs.  



Option Analysis

❌ Ureteric stone:
Incorrect: Ureteric stones lie within the ureter at any point from the ureteropelvic junction (UPJ) to the vesicoureteric junction (VUJ). They are the classic cause of renal colic-type abdominal pain. Although it may cause hematuria and flank pain, CT scan would show an opacity in the ureter, rather than left renal vein compression.  
❌ Pelvic congestion syndrome:
Incorrect: Pelvic congestion syndrome in women is believed to be due to enlarged veins in the lower abdomen secondary to blood flowing back into pelvic veins.The condition may cause chronic pain, such as a constant dull ache, which can be worsened by standing or sexual intercourse. Gross hematuria is typically absent.  
❌ Superior mesenteric artery syndrome:
Incorrect: Superior mesenteric artery (SMA) syndrome occurs when the transverse portion of the duodenum is entrapped between the SMA and aorta, causing symptoms of bowel obstruction. Gross hematuria is not typically seen.  
✅ Nutcracker syndrome:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Renal artery stenosis:
Incorrect: Renal artery stenosis is the narrowing of one or both of the renal arteries, most often caused by atherosclerosis or fibromuscular dysplasia. Patients typically present with elevated blood pressure that is not controlled by medications. Physical examination may show a bruit over the renal artery on auscultation. This patient’s vitals are within normal limits.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man comes to the office for evaluation of right foot pain. The patient describes the pain as “burning” and located on the sole of the foot and the toes. The pain radiates to the calf and is exacerbated by prolonged standing and running. The patient has not suffered any trauma to the right foot. The patient currently runs 10 to 20 miles daily for an upcoming marathon. Past medical history is noncontributory. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows pain with passive dorsiflexion and eversion of the right ankle. Sensation to light touch and pressure are reduced over the plantar surface of the right foot. Tapping posterior to the right medial malleolus produces a tingling, electric shock sensation. Deep tendon reflexes are within normal limits. Compression of which of the following nerves is the most likely etiology of this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with a sharp, burning pain and reduced sensation over the sole of the feet and a positive Tinel sign (shock-like sensation on tapping the tibial nerve behind the medial malleolus), consistent with tarsal tunnel syndrome, secondary to the compression of tibial nerve.   

The tibial nerve is a branch of the sciatic nerve and traverses through the popliteal fossa and posterior compartment of the leg. It then enters the foot through the tarsal tunnel inferior and posterior to the medial malleolus where it innervates the plantar surface of the foot. Injury or compression of the tibial nerve at the tarsal tunnel results in sensory loss over the sole of the foot. Plantarflexion and inversion of the foot remains intact, as fibers innervating these muscles branch proximally to the tarsal tunnel. Common risk factors for tarsal tunnel syndrome include benign tumors/cysts, bone spurs, overuse injury, inflammation of the tendon sheath or swelling from a broken or sprained ankle.  

In contrast, injury to the nerve at the popliteal fossa (e.g., deep penetrating trauma or knee surgery) results in loss of plantar flexion, loss of flexion of toes and weakened inversion. Consequently, patients often present with feet held in the calcaneovalgus position (everted at rest with loss of inversion and plantar flexion).  



Option Analysis

❌ Femoral:
Incorrect: The femoral nerve can be compressed during prolonged maintenance in the dorsal lithotomy position or from pelvic fractures or hip dislocations. Patients present with sensory loss over the anterior thigh and medial leg, weakness of knee flexion and hip extension, and decreased patellar reflexes. A positive Tinel sign posterior to the medial malleolus is suggestive of tarsal tunnel syndrome.  
❌ Common peroneal:
Incorrect: Compression of the common peroneal nerve occurs at the proximal fibula due to prolonged hyperflexion of the knee or from leg casting. Sensory symptoms occur at the posterolateral leg and dorsolateral foot and are often associated with foot drop.   
✅ Tibial:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Ilioinguinal :
Incorrect: The Ilioinguinal nerve provides innervation to the upper medial thigh and perineum. Injury to this nerve can occur during pelvic surgery, and presents with chronic suprapubic or groin pain. The ilioinguinal nerve does not innervate the sole of the foot.  
❌ Lateral femoral cutaneous nerve :
Incorrect: Injury or impingement of the lateral femoral cutaneous nerve results in decreased anterior and lateral thigh sensation. Women who wear tight clothes are especially predisposed to impingement of this nerve. A positive Tinel sign, posterior to the medial malleolus, is suggestive of tibial nerve compression.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department after injuring his left knee in a bicycle accident. Physical examination shows significant knee swelling with abrasions of the overlying skin. Distal motor and sensory function are intact. No other signs of trauma are present. X-ray of the left knee reveals a nondisplaced patellar fracture. The patient is subsequently referred to an orthopedic surgeon and placed in a leg cast. On a follow-up visit one week later, the patient endorses difficulty moving his left foot. Physical examination demonstrates limited dorsiflexion and eversion of the left foot, as well as limited extension of the left toes. Deep tendon reflexes are +2 bilaterally. The remainder of the examination of the left and right lower extremity are within normal limits. Which of the following additional findings is most likely to be seen in this patient?

choices.text: Loss of sensation over the medial surface of leg
Loss of sensation over the dorsum of the foot
Loss of sensation over the sole of the foot
Decreased sensation over the medial thigh
Decreased sensation over the anterior and lateral thigh

questions.solution:
This patient presents with loss of eversion and dorsiflexion of the foot, following placement of a leg cast, consistent with common peroneal nerve compression at the femoral neck.   

The common fibular nerve serves as a terminal branch of the sciatic nerve and arises proximal to the popliteal fossa. From here, it courses laterally around the head and neck of the fibula and divides into:  

  • Superficial branches: foot eversion (lateral compartment of leg) and sensory innervation of dorsum of foot (except webspace between hallux and 2nd digit). 
  • Deep branches: dorsiflexion (anterior compartment of foot and leg) and sensory innervation of the webspace between hallux and 2nd digit. 
 The nerve is susceptible to injury (e.g., fibular neck fractures and tightly applied plaster cast) due to its superficial location at the neck of the fibula. Patient’s with injury at this location typically present with foot drop (difficulty dorsiflexing the foot against resistance or gravity), eversion and paresthesias, and/or sensory loss over the dorsum of the foot, lateral shin, and between first and second toes. Gait examination often shows a “steppage gait,” where the knees raise higher than normal with each step due to the weakness of foot dorsiflexion.  



Option Analysis

❌ Loss of sensation over the medial surface of leg:
Incorrect: Loss of sensation on the medial surface of leg results from the saphenous nerve injury.  
✅ Loss of sensation over the dorsum of the foot:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Loss of sensation over the sole of the foot:
Incorrect: Loss of sensation on the sole of the foot is characteristic of tibial nerve compression in the tarsal tunnel. The common fibular nerve does not innervate the plantar surface of the foot.  
❌ Decreased sensation over the medial thigh:
Incorrect: The obturator nerve is responsible for the medial thigh sensation. Its injury can result from surgeries of the pelvis (e.g. hysterectomy).  
❌ Decreased sensation over the anterior and lateral thigh:
Incorrect: Injury or impingement of the lateral femoral cutaneous nerve can result in decreased anterior and lateral thigh sensation. Women who wear tight clothes are predisposed to this injury.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man comes to the office for evaluation of right heel pain. He was playing tennis with his son when he experienced a sharp, stabbing pain of his right heel with an associated “popping” sound. The patient has been unable to ambulate since the injury occurred. Past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus which is adequately managed with metformin. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates a palpable gap two centimeters proximal to the right heel. The right leg does not yield plantar flexion with squeezing of the calf. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation of sudden onset sharp heel pain, inability to bear-weight, positive Thompson test (absence of plantarflexion when squeezing the gastrocnemius muscle), and a palpable gap is consistent with Achilles tendon rupture.    

The soleus and the gastrocnemius muscles converge to form the Achilles tendon, which inserts posteriorly on the calcaneus. Rupture of this tendon usually occurs while performing actions requiring sudden changes in acceleration, such as pushing off, jumping, or changing direction while running. Most cases occur in male patients aged 30–40 years old, with associated risk factors of obesity, fluoroquinolone use, or systemic corticosteroid use. Patients typically present with a sharp pain and an inability to bear weight, in cases of a complete rupture. Physical examination may show a swollen heel, a palpable defect in the Achilles tendon two to six centimeters proximal to the calcaneus, an inability to stand on toes, and a positive squeeze test (Thompson test).   

Achilles tendon rupture may be diagnosed solely by clinical examination, but a bedside ultrasound can confirm the diagnosis. All complete tendon ruptures require surgical consultation.  


Reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

Option Analysis

❌ Posterior tibial tendon dysfunction:
Incorrect: Posterior tibial tendon dysfunction is caused by chronic overuse injury of the tendon, impairing its ability to support the arch of the foot. Patients typically develop swelling and tenderness along the course of the tendon, accompanied by weakness with foot inversion. A positive squeeze test is suggestive of achilles tendon rupture.  
❌ Ankle sprain:
Incorrect: Ankle sprains present with pain and swelling about the ankle joint, not heel, as seen in this patient. Moreover, a palpable gap directly proximal to the heel and a positive squeeze test is highly sensitive for achilles tendon rupture.  
✅ Achilles tendon rupture:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Calcaneal stress fracture:
Incorrect: A calcaneal stress fracture can result from repetitive stress to the foot. Patients present with generalized pain in the heel that develops over several days to weeks. The pain usually increases with activity and improves with rest. Sudden sharp heel pain with a palpable posterior heel defect is suggestive of achilles tendon rupture.  
❌ Calcaneal apophysitis:
Incorrect: Calcaneal apophysitis refers to inflammation of the heel’s growth plate. This injury pattern results from repetitive microtrauma due to strain on the Achilles tendon at the apophysis. Patients often present with heel pain that worsens while running or jumping. This patient has a positive Thompson test, suggestive of Achilles tendon rupture.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old man comes to the office to be evaluated for left elbow pain and swelling. The patient is an air conditioning technician, which requires him to move through tight spaces while resting on his knees and elbows. He did not sustain any recent trauma. Past medical history is noncontributory. Vitals are within normal limits. Upper arm exam is noncontributory. The patient has swelling at the posterior aspect of the left elbow as shown below. He has full range of motion of the elbow. He reports improvement in pain with full elbow extension and worsening with flexion. The swollen area is mildly tender to touch but is not warm. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?  


Reproduced from: wikipedia
questions.solution:
This patient presents with posterior elbow swelling and tenderness consistent with olecranon bursitis. The olecranon bursa is a superficial bursa that overlies the triceps tendon and olecranon. Normally, the olecranon bursa is flat, but it can swell when it is irritated or inflamed due to direct trauma, prolonged pressure, or friction (leaning on the elbow or as part of an occupation such as laying carpet). As the bursa does not directly involve the joint, flexion/extension does not typically cause pain. Although if significantly swelling or inflammation is present, patients may experience increased pain with stretching of the bursa with flexion at the elbow.  

In addition to direct trauma, friction, and pressure, olecranon bursitis can be caused by septic bursitis or by underlying inflammatory conditions of the joint space (e.g. gout or osteoarthritis). If these are a concern, a bursal aspiration and analysis should be performed.  

Option Analysis

❌ Triceps tendinopathy:
Incorrect: Triceps tendinopathy results from repetitive elbow extension against resistance. Patients typically report pain at the posterior elbow with resisted elbow extension and tenderness at the triceps insertion at the olecranon. Swelling at the elbow would not be consistent with triceps tendinopathy.   
❌ Distal biceps tendon rupture:
Incorrect: Distal biceps tendon rupture presents following forceful lifting with sudden pain deep in the antecubital fossa. Physical examination often reveals tenderness over the radial tubercle and pain aggravated with resisted flexion and supination of the forearm. There can be swelling at the anterior elbow and a bulge can be seen or palpated at the upper arm which is the recoiled biceps muscle. However, posterior elbow swelling is not seen and is suggestive of olecranon bursitis.  
❌ Medial epicondylitis:
Incorrect: Medial epicondylitis (i.e. golfer’s elbow) is caused by overuse of the wrist, hand flexors, and forearm pronators. Patients typically present with pain over the medial epicondyle with resisted finger and wrist flexion. Posterior elbow swelling would not be expected.  
❌ Lateral epicondylitis:
Incorrect: Lateral epicondylitis (i.e. tennis elbow) is characterized by overuse of wrist extensors. It presents tenderness over the lateral epicondyle and pain with resisted wrist extension, digit extension, and forearm supination. It does not present with posterior elbow swelling.  
✅ Olecranon bursitis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 26-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after a motor vehicle collision, stabilized, and admitted for further evaluation and pain control. His initial physical examination demonstrated diffuse contusions and multiple lacerations of the face. Throughout his hospital stay, the patient refuses advanced imaging and is discharged home after two days. Subsequently, the patient returns to the emergency department five days later with continuous rhinorrhea. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates clear rhinorrhea from the right nostril as well as anosmia of the right nostril with the left nostril occluded. Sensation of smell via the left nostril is intact. This patient’s presentation results from injury to which of the following cranial structures?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with loss of smell (anosmia) and clear rhinorrhea following head trauma suggestive of cerebrospinal fluid leak and olfactory nerve injury, secondary to the fracture of the cribriform plate.   

The olfactory nerve transmits olfactory impulses from the olfactory epithelium of the nose to the brain. The central processes of the olfactory nerve make up the numerous nerves which pass through the cribriform plate of the ethmoid bone. In severe head injuries, the olfactory bulbs may be torn away from the olfactory nerves. Olfactory nerve fibers may be torn as they pass through a fractured cribriform plate. If the nerve bundles on one side sever, a complete loss of smell will occur on that side; consequently, anosmia may be a clue to a fracture of the cranial base and cerebrospinal fluid rhinorrhea (leakage of the fluid through the nose).  

Option Analysis

❌ Skull base:
Incorrect: Basilar skull fractures can damage CN VIII within the internal acoustic meatus, leading to symptoms of sensorineural hearing loss, vertigo, and horizontal nystagmus.  
✅ Cribriform plate:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Superior orbital fissure :
Incorrect: The abducens nerve (cranial nerve VI) passes through the superior orbital fissure. Fractures at this location result in an abducens nerve palsy and loss of lateral gaze on the left.   
❌ Jugular foramen:
Incorrect: The jugular foramen is the site of exit for cranial nerves IX, X, and XI; however, these nerves are involved in swallowing, visceral organ function, and trapezius elevation rather than smell.  
❌ Inferior orbital rim:
Incorrect: Fracture of the inferior orbital rim or maxillary fracture can result in the injury to the maxillary nerve (cranial nerve V2), which normally carries the sensory innervation of the left cheek.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother for evaluation of disturbed smell sensation. Yesterday his mother found the gas stove turned on, and the patient was unable to smell the odor. He had a bilateral orchiopexy due to cryptorchidism in infancy. The patient takes no medications daily and does not use tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drugs. Height is at the third percentile for age, with 4.8 cm (1.9 in) of growth noted in the last year. Visual fields are intact. There is no breast tissue, axillary, or pubic hair. The genitals are at Tanner stage 1. Which of the following is the most likely underlying etiology of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with delayed puberty and anosmia consistent with the diagnosis of Kallmann syndrome, which results from the impaired migration of GnRH neurons from the olfactory placode to the hypothalamus.   

During fetal development, two groups of neurons emerge from a region of the brain called the olfactory placode. The first group of neurons migrate down from the olfactory placode, embed in the cribriform plate, and assist with sensing smell. The second group of neurons migrate through the cribriform plate to settle in the hypothalamus, where they release gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH). GnRH further stimulates luteinizing hormone (LH) and follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) secretion from the pituitary gland, inducing the gonads to produce sex specific hormones (i.e., estrogen and progesterone in women and testosterone in men).  

Kallmann syndrome results from a defect in the migration of the neurons from the olfactory placode including the olfactory neurons (CN I) and GnRH neurons which results in a ↓ in GnRH, FSH, LH and testosterone/estrogen, and progesterone. As a result, patients present with under-developed primary and secondary sex characteristics, delayed onset puberty, anosmia/hyposmia, and midline defects (e.g., cleft lip or palate).  



Option Analysis

❌ Sex chromosome trisomy:
Incorrect: Klinefelter syndrome is a sex chromosome trisomy (XXY) that presents with delayed puberty in a male patient. However, these patients characteristically have a tall, slender frame and gynecomastia. Moreover, the features in this adolescent (anosmia and history of cryptorchidism) are not explained by Klinefelter syndrome.  
❌ Compression of pituitary stalk:
Incorrect: A craniopharyngioma can delay the onset of puberty by compressing the pituitary stalk and interfering with normal pituitary function. This patient has none of the classical symptoms associated with this diagnosis including visual field defects, hyperprolactinemia, or central diabetes insipidus.  
❌ Hyperprolactinemia:
Incorrect: Hyperprolactinemia can present with hypogonadism in men, which could explain this patient's Tanner 1 genital development. However, lack of testosterone typically causes gynecomastia, which is not observed in this patient. The most common cause of this condition is a prolactinoma that presents with additional symptoms of mass effect (e.g., headache, bitemporal hemianopsia, diplopia).  
✅ Impaired migration of GnRH neurons:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Use of exogenous androgenic substances:
Incorrect: Anabolic steroid use can lead to impaired testicular function with decreased testicular size and lowered sperm count. It does not lead to sparse facial/body hair or anosmia.

questions.text:
A 75-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of inability to bear weight on her right leg. The patient fell onto her right hip after a trip over the curb a few hours ago. Past medical history is significant for osteoporosis and type II diabetes mellitus. Current medications include metformin and atorvastatin. Family history is noncontributory. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates shortening of the right leg with associated external rotation. There is swelling and bruising around the right lateral hip and limited range of motion at the right hip joint. The patient has a 2+ dorsalis pedis pulse in the right lower extremity. A right hip joint X-ray is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?


Reproduced from Radiopedia

choices.text: Posterior dislocation of the femoral head

questions.solution:
This patient’s radiograph, mechanism of injury, and exam findings are consistent with a femoral neck fracture–one of the most common hip fracture patterns. Femoral neck fractures are common in older patients, especially those with underlying osteoporosis. They can occur with low energy falls and have a high morbidity and mortality rate.  

Hip fractures get divided into intracapsular (femoral head and neck) or extracapsular (intertrochanteric or subtrochanteric). Specifically, a femoral neck or head fracture is an intracapsular, displaced fracture that typically occurs following a fall onto the lateral hip. Patients with a displaced femoral neck fracture are generally unable to bear weight on the affected side and present with a shortened leg with external rotation of the affected hip (due to the psoas and iliacus muscle contraction without acetabular counterforce). Notably, intracapsular fractures can be associated with disruption of the blood supply from the medial circumflex artery, resulting in avascular necrosis. Femoral head fractures are often associated with posterior dislocation of the hip and are at increased risk of sciatic nerve injury. Because of the potential for avascular necrosis with intracapsular fractures arthroplasty with hip replacement is typically the procedure of choice.  

In contrast, an intertrochanteric fracture is an extracapsular fracture that occurs between the greater and lesser trochanters. A subtrochanteric fracture which is defined as a fracture within 5 cm distal to the lesser trochanter is also considered an extracapsular fracture. Clinical presentation is similar to femoral neck fractures. Both fracture patterns require surgical correction (e.g. open reduction with internal fixation) unless the patient is not a good surgical candidate. With extracapsular fractures the blood supply is usually intact and fixation is the procedure of choice.  



Option Analysis

❌ Posterior dislocation of the femoral head:
Incorrect: Posterior dislocation of the femoral head occurs secondary to high-velocity motor vehicle collisions. Clinical examination often reveals a shortened, adducted, and internally rotated lower extremity with the hip and knee held in flexion. This patient has radiographic evidence of a femoral neck fracture.
❌ Greater trochanter fracture:
Incorrect: A fracture of the greater trochanter can result from forceful contraction of the hip abductors with a fall onto the lateral hip. It presents with an exacerbation of hip pain with abduction and localized tenderness over the greater trochanter. This patient has radiographic evidence of a femoral neck fracture.
✅ Femoral neck fracture:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Greater trochanteric pain syndrome:
Incorrect: Greater trochanteric pain syndrome (GTPS) results from gluteus medius and minimus tendinopathy. It presents with chronic lateral hip pain worse with repetitive hip flexion or direct pressure. Physical examination demonstrates point tenderness over the greater trochanter. Radiographs are usually unremarkable.
❌ Intertrochanteric fracture:
Incorrect: Intertrochanteric fractures present with hip pain, swelling, and ecchymosis. Physical examination demonstrates local tenderness over the trochanteric area and an externally rotated and shortened extremity. Radiography shows cortical discontinuity between the two trochanters. This patient’s radiograph demonstrates a femoral neck fracture.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by paramedics after a high-speed motor vehicle collision. The patient is currently experiencing severe right hip pain. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows an alert man, oriented to time and place. The patient is lying on his left side with an internally rotated and shortened right leg with a large hematoma at the lateral right hip. The right hip is held in a flexed and adducted position. An x-ray of the pelvis and hip is shown below. A detailed neurologic examination will likely reveal which of the following findings?  


Reproduced from Radiopedia

choices.text: Decreased sensation over the medial thigh
Decreased sensation over the anterior and lateral thigh
Loss of sensation over the dorsum of the foot

questions.solution:
This patient has evidence of a posterior hip dislocation following high-velocity trauma. Motor vehicle collisions (knee-to-dashboard) are the most common mechanism for this type of injury. Clinical examination often reveals a slightly shortened extremity with adduction and internal rotation of the hip with the knee held in flexion.    

Anteroposterior and lateral radiographs of the pelvis and hip identify posterior dislocations. The sciatic nerve is especially vulnerable to injury as it traverses the posterior aspect of the hip joint. Injury can result in weakness of knee flexion (sciatic nerve), ankle dorsiflexion (common fibular nerve), and decreased ankle reflex (tibial nerve), as well as decreased sensation in the distribution of the affected nerve (e.g. dorsum of the foot).   

Other associated complications of posterior dislocation of the hip include avascular necrosis of the femoral head (due to compromised blood supply), femoral head or acetabular fracture, and tear of the labrum.  



Option Analysis

❌ Absent cremasteric reflex:
Incorrect: The genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve helps form the cremasteric reflex pathway. Injury to this nerve can result from laparoscopic surgery; however, posterior hip dislocation is not associated with genitofemoral nerve injury. 
❌ Decreased sensation over the medial thigh:
Incorrect: The obturator nerve is responsible for medial thigh sensation. Injury to this nerve often results from surgeries of the pelvis (e.g. hysterectomy). A posterior hip dislocation does not affect this nerve.
❌ Decreased sensation over the anterior and lateral thigh:
Incorrect: Injury or impingement of the lateral femoral cutaneous nerve can decrease anterior and lateral thigh sensation. Posterior hip dislocations do not affect this nerve.
✅ Loss of sensation over the dorsum of the foot :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Decreased patellar reflex:
Incorrect: The femoral nerve is involved in the motor pathway of the patellar reflex, and it can be injured  from pelvic fractures. This patient’s radiograph suggests a right posterior hip dislocation without evidence of pelvic fracture.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to the office because of left thigh pain and numbness. The patient’s symptoms started two days after a 12-hour tech rehearsal for a Shakespearen play. She was wearing her costume, which includes a corset, and noticed numbness and burning sensation over the lateral side of her left thigh following the rehearsal. Past medical history is noncontributory. BMI is 35 kg/m2. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates loss of light touch and pinprick sensation over the upper lateral thigh. Lower extremity strength is 5/5 bilaterally, and deep tendon reflexes are +2. Straight leg raise is negative bilaterally. Pain is reproduced with tapping immediately below the anterior superior iliac spine. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
Meralgia paresthetica is a mononeuropathy resulting from the compression of the lateral femoral cutaneous nerve (LFCN) which travels from the lumbar plexus, through the abdominal cavity, under the inguinal ligament, and into the subcutaneous tissue of the thigh. Commonly identified risk factors include pregnancy, tight-fitted clothes/seat belts, obesity, and diabetes mellitus. Affected patients present with pain, paresthesias (numbness and tingling), and hypoesthesia (diminished sensation) over the upper outer thigh. Muscle strength, however, is normal as the LFCN does not carry motor fibers. Symptoms may be reproduced with tapping over the lateral aspect of the inguinal ligament (Tinel's sign).    

Diagnosis is clinical, and most patients are managed with weight loss and avoidance of exacerbating factors (e.g. avoiding tight-fitted clothing). Anticonvulsants (e.g., carbamazepine, phenytoin, or gabapentin) can help reduce neuropathic pain in patients with refractory symptoms.   

Option Analysis

❌ Compression of the ilioinguinal nerve:
