Incorrect: The ilioinguinal nerve innervates the medial thigh, inguinal region, and lower abdomen. Compression or injury of this nerve can occur during pelvic or hernia surgery. 
✅ Wearing tight fitting clothes:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Stress fracture:
Incorrect: Prolonged strenuous activity is associated with the development of stress fractures. This condition presents as dull, chronic pain of the affected region (e.g. lateral hip pain in femoral head stress fracture). Burning pain and paraesthesia over the lateral thigh is suggestive of cutaneous nerve compression injury.
❌ Femoral neuropathy:
Incorrect: The femoral nerve innervates the anteromedial skin of the thigh (via the medial femoral cutaneous branch) as well as medial lower leg via the saphenous nerve. Femoral neuropathy is associated with diminished or absent knee jerk reflexes. 
❌ Increased intracompartmental pressure:
Incorrect: Increased intracompartmental pressure occurs in patients with acute compartment syndrome, which more commonly develops following a severe injury–such as a car accident or long bone fracture. It typically causes severe pain, paresthesia, and weakness of the affected limb.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old woman presents to the office for evaluation of foot pain. She started hiking recently to lose some weight. The patient reports dull, achy pain at the left medial ankle. Past medical history is unremarkable. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates pain with palpation posterior to the medial malleolus. Upon weight bearing and gait analysis, the physician notes a collapse of the medial longitudinal arch, outward tilted heels, valgus hindfoot deformity, and forefoot abduction, as shown below. The rest of the examination is within normal limits. Which of the following is a common etiology of this patient’s presentation? 
 

Image obtained from Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
This patient presents with foot pain during increased activity and collapse of the medial longitudinal arch on weight-bearing, suggestive of posterior tibial tendon dysfunction (PTTD). Over time, this condition results in an acquired flat foot (pes planus). 

Flatfoot is a progressive deformity characterized by the collapse of the medial longitudinal arch with forefoot abduction and hindfoot valgus. The most common etiology of acquired flatfoot is PTTD. Other causes include congenital ligamentous laxity (e.g., Marfan syndrome and pregnancy), degenerative or inflammatory arthropathies, and rheumatoid arthritis. 

Flatfoot may or may not be symptomatic. Patients may endorse dull, achy arch pain, medial ankle or heel pain, and a sensation of “muscle weakness” or fatigue with exercise. Physical examination demonstrates collapse of the medial longitudinal arch with weight bearing, the ‘too many toes’ sign (examiner can see all four toes when looking at the foot from behind), valgus hindfoot deformity, and forefoot abduction.       

Option Analysis

❌ Plantar aponeurosis inflammation :
Incorrect: Plantar fasciitis results from inflammation and degeneration of plantar aponeurosis, secondary to chronic overuse and repetitive trauma at its insertion site. Patients typically present with sharp and stabbing heel pain that is worse when walking and with tenderness at the insertion point of the plantar fascia on the calcaneus. Collapse of the medial longitudinal arch on weight-bearing is suggestive of posterior tibial tendon dysfunction.  
✅ Posterior tibial tendon dysfunction :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Neuropathic Charcot changes :
Incorrect: Charcot joint presents with deformity and sensory deficits of the foot due to trauma and impaired proprioception and sensation of pain. Collapse of the medial longitudinal arch on weight-bearing is suggestive of posterior tibial tendon dysfunction.  
❌ Fibularis tendon tendinopathy :
Incorrect: Patients with fibularis tendon tendinopathy present with pain, and occasionally, swelling and warmth of the posterolateral aspect of the ankle. 
❌ First metatarsophalangeal joint sprain :
Incorrect: First metatarsophalangeal joint sprains result from an injury to the big toe secondary to forced hyperextension. This patient does not have evidence of an isolated digit injury.

questions.text:
A 47-year-old man presents to the emergency department with left lower extremity pain and swelling. The patient was outside jogging when he suddenly felt a “pop” with associated pain behind the left knee. The left lower extremity has become progressively more swollen and painful over the past few hours. The patient recently traveled to the United States from London. Past medical history is notable for hypertension. Vital signs are within normal limits. Bilateral lower extremity pulses are normal and equal. Physical examination reveals a swollen and tender calf and ecchymosis at the popliteal region. Anterior and posterior drawer tests are negative. An ultrasound of the left calf is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
 

Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
This patient presents with acute onset of pain and swelling of the calf after jogging. Ultrasound reveals a hypoechoic fluid collection. These findings are consistent with a ruptured popliteal (Baker) cyst.

Popliteal cysts are common and reflect an enlargement of the gastrocnemius-semimembranosus bursa that extends into the adjacent knee joint space. Popliteal cysts are commonly associated with osteoarthritis, inflammatory arthritis, and a history of knee trauma (e.g. meniscus tears). They are typically asymptomatic unless rupture occurs.

Clinically, a popliteal cyst often presents as a swollen mass on the posterior aspect of the knee that can cause knee stiffness and difficulty with range of motion during exercise. Occasionally, popliteal cysts can rupture, causing acute pain and swelling of the calf that can mimic deep vein thrombosis. Management of a ruptured popliteal cyst should include ruling out a deep venous thrombosis. The fluid from a ruptured popliteal cyst will gradually be reabsorbed, therefore treatment is typically pain management, rest, and elevation.  

Option Analysis

✅ Ruptured popliteal cyst:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Deep vein thrombosis:
Incorrect: While this patient has recently been on a long-distance flight, his physical examination and ultrasound findings are consistent with a ruptured popliteal cyst. Ultrasound findings associated with a deep vein thrombosis include an incompressible vein and the absence of Doppler flow if the vessel is completely occluded.  
❌ Lymphedema:
Incorrect: Lymphedema often presents as chronic swelling and induration of the lower extremities due to cardiovascular disease, previous radiation, malignancy, infection, or trauma.  
❌ Femoral artery occlusion:
Incorrect: Femoral artery occlusion will often manifest with a pulseless lower extremity with associated acute pain and swelling. Risk factors include atrial fibrillation and thrombophilia.  
❌ Posterior cruciate ligament tear:
Incorrect: Posterior cruciate ligament tears are associated with positive posterior drawer testing. This finding is not present in this patient.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman presents to the emergency department to be evaluated for severe sharp right upper quadrant abdominal pain that radiates toward the right lower thoracic back. The pain began that morning. The pain in the back is not improved or worsened with movement. Her symptoms are accompanied by nausea and vomiting. Temperature is 38.3°C (101°F), blood pressure is 150/78 mmHg, and pulse is 110/min. On physical examination, pain is elicited upon deep palpation of the right upper quadrant. Which of the following nerves is most likely responsible for this patient’s referred back pain?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with right upper quadrant abdominal pain, fever, nausea, and vomiting. These findings are concerning for acute cholecystitis. This patient’s pain in the right upper quadrant is due to irritation of the gallbladder and is considered somatic pain, which refers to pain located directly at the site of injury (e.g. pinprick on the skin).    
The patient is also experiencing referred pain to the back due to visceral referred pain. Referred pain is located away from or adjacent to the organ involved. Patients with acute cholecystitis often experience referred pain in the right lower thoracic spine, ribs, and right shoulder.   

Referred visceral pain occurs due to spatial and temporal summation of general visceral afferent (GVA) pain fibers. GVA pain fibers follow sympathetic nerves back to the preganglionic sympathetic fibers. As these preganglionic sympathetic fibers route to the spine and central nervous system (CNS), the CNS is unable to perceive the spatial location of the pain since it is lost at the level of the nerve ganglion. As a result, the pain is poorly localized and often referred to the dermatomal areas innervated by the same spinal level as the autonomic nerve supply. Consequently, when there is abdominal pathology, foregut pain is usually referred to the epigastrium, midgut to the umbilicus, and hindgut to the pelvis or hypogastrium.  



Option Analysis

✅ Greater thoracic splanchnic nerve:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Lesser thoracic splanchnic nerve:
Incorrect: This nerve provides sympathetic innervation to the midgut
❌ Lumbar splanchnic nerve:
Incorrect: This nerve provides sympathetic innervation to the hindgut
❌ Sacral nerve roots S2-4:
Incorrect: Sacral nerve roots S2, S3, and S4 provide parasympathetic innervation to the hindgut. In contrast, pain fibers typically travel along sympathetic nerves.  
❌ Vagus nerve:
Incorrect: The vagus nerve provides parasympathetic innervation to the foregut and midgut. In contrast, pain fibers typically travel along sympathetic nerves.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department to be evaluated for severe abdominal pain. The pain started approximately eight hours ago and was initially located in the periumbilical region. The pain increased in severity and became more localized to the lower right abdomen. Temperature is 38.1°C (100.6°F), pulse is 125/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 120/66 mm Hg. Using the image below, which of the following best identifies the location where this patient will be most tender with deep palpation?
questions.solution:
This young patient presents with abdominal pain that originated in the periumbilical region and subsequently became more severe and migrated to the right lower quadrant of the abdomen. These findings are concerning for acute appendicitis.     

Appendicitis occurs due to obstruction and inflammation of the appendix. Initially, the visceral afferent fibers are stimulated and poorly localized abdominal pain or pain around the umbilicus is seen. As the appendix becomes more inflamed, the adjacent parietal peritoneum is irritated, and the pain becomes more localized to the right lower quadrant. On examination maximal tenderness with deep palpation at McBurney point will be seen. McBurney point is located two-third of the distance between the umbilicus and the right anterior superior iliac spine. Pain with deep palpation in this region is highly concerning for acute appendicitis and is called McBurney sign. Follow-up imaging (e.g., ultrasound, CT) should be obtained for further evaluation.  

Option Analysis

✅ Location 1:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Location 2:
Incorrect: Appendicitis can initially manifest with referred pain in the periumbilical area, represented by location 2. However, the pain will often localize to the right lower abdominal quadrant. Maximal tenderness will be experienced with palpation at McBurney point, represented by Location 1, which corresponds to the base of the appendix  
❌ Location 3:
Incorrect: Pain and tenderness around the anterior superior iliac spine is not commonly associated with an intra-abdominal or intrapelvic process. Instead, pain in this location is more likely due to a musculoskeletal etiology.
❌ Location 4:
Incorrect: Pain and tenderness in the suprapubic region indicated by Location 4 can be due to processes affecting the pelvic organs (e.g., cystitis, endometritis). In contrast, this patient’s history and physical examination are concerning for acute appendicitis, which may present at first with referred periumbilical pain that migrates to the right lower abdominal quadrant. In acute appendicitis, maximal tenderness with deep palpation is typically seen at McBurney point, represented by Location 1.  
❌ Location 5:
Incorrect: Pain around the anterior superior iliac spine is not commonly associated with an intra-abdominal or intrapelvic process. Instead, pain in this location is more likely due to a musculoskeletal etiology. Left anterior superior iliac spine pain or tenderness is not typically seen with acute appendicitis.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman is diagnosed with stage IV cholangiocarcinoma, for which she is receiving chemotherapy. Periodically, the patient develops ascites, for which abdominal paracentesis is performed. However, the patient was lost to follow-up. The patient is brought to the emergency department by her daughter with diffuse abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and altered mental status. On admission, temperature is 38.6°C (101.5°F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 120/66 mm Hg. On physical examination, the abdomen is distended and shifting dullness and a fluid wave are present. There is diffuse guarding with abdominal palpation. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with fever, nausea, vomiting, and diffuse abdominal pain in the setting of large-volume ascites due to end-stage liver failure caused by cholangiocarcinoma. These findings are concerning for spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP).    

SBP develops when enteric bacteria translocate from the intestinal lumen and infect the ascitic fluid. This occurs as a complication of liver disease due to increased permeability of the small intestinal wall and impaired immune defense mechanisms. SBP is a common cause of peritonitis which is defined as widespread inflammation of the inner abdomen wall and covering of the abdominal organs (the peritoneum). In addition to SBP, other causes of peritonitis include gastrointestinal tract perforation, infection due to surgical interventions, systemic infection, and pelvic inflammatory disease. Key signs and symptoms of peritonitis include fever, diffuse abdominal pain, guarding, abdominal rigidity, and paralytic ileus.   

Option Analysis

✅ Bacterial infection of ascitic fluid:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Accumulation of nitrogenous metabolites:
Incorrect: Accumulation of nitrogenous waste products, such as ammonia, can occur secondary to liver failure and may cause altered mental status or hepatic encephalopathy. However, hepatic encephalopathy does not cause fever and abdominal pain in the presence of ascites as seen in this case. A better explanation for this patient’s constellation of symptoms is SBP.  
❌ Dehydration:
Incorrect: Large fluid shifts can be seen in patients with end-stage liver disease and they can result in symptoms of dehydration and even nausea and vomiting. However, dehydration would not account for the patient’s fever, abdominal pain, and ascites.  
❌ Tumor lysis syndrome:
Incorrect: Tumor lysis syndrome causes metabolic abnormalities (e.g., hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia, hyperuricemia), leading to acute kidney failure, seizures, and cardiac arrhythmias. This patient’s fever, abdominal pain and distension, and altered mental status are more likely caused by spontaneous bacterial peritonitis..  
❌ Small bowel obstruction:
Incorrect: Small bowel obstruction can lead to perforation and subsequently peritonitis. However given the presence of shifting dullness and fluid wave indicating ascites and the history of end-stage liver disease in this patient, spontaneous bacterial peritonitis is the most likely cause of peritonitis

questions.text: A 30-year-old man comes to the office with his wife for evaluation of infertility. They have been married for two years and have attempted to conceive without success. The patient’s wife has a child from her previous marriage. The patient reports decreased libido but finds it challenging to maintain an erection. Past medical history is unremarkable. He takes no medications besides a multivitamin daily. Family history is noncontributory. The patient’s height is 185cm (6ft 1inch), and weight is 66 kg (145.5 lb). Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows sparse facial and body hair and enlarged breasts. Olfactory sensation and visual field testing are within normal limits. Genital examination shows normal male external morphology and firm testes with a volume of 6 ml (normal 18-25 mL). Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient’s breast enlargement?
questions.solution:
This patient’s infertility associated with tall stature, decreased virilization, small testes, and gynecomastia is consistent with Klinefelter syndrome, the most common cause of hypogonadism.  

Gynecomastia refers to a benign proliferation of the breast tissue in biological males, and it is typically caused by an imbalance between estrogenic and androgenic hormones. It differs from the proliferation of breast tissue in females in that there is no terminal alveolar development in response to progesterone.  

Gynecomastia is age-dependent, and it most frequently affects males progressing through puberty. Adolescents with pubertal gynecomastia usually complain of a mass or lump behind the nipple.    

Gynecomastia affects older males less frequently. This population can be caused by liver cirrhosis or testicular cancer, medications like spironolactone, cimetidine, ketoconazole,  and conditions such as Klinefelter syndrome.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Medication adverse effect:
Incorrect: Medications that inhibit testosterone synthesis and action (e.g. ketoconazole), enhance endogenous estrogen production (e.g. clomiphene), or have estrogen-like activity (e.g. oral contraceptive pills) can result in gynecomastia.
❌ Physiological enlargement  :
Incorrect: Pubertal gynecomastia refers to physiological enlargement of the glandular breast tissue that occurs in some boys during puberty. This patient’s presentation suggests an alternative explanation.  
✅ Hypogonadism:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Testicular cancer  :
Incorrect: Hormone secreting testicular cancer (e.g. Leydig or Sertoli cell tumors) can cause gynecomastia and present with a palpable testicular mass on physical examination (in contrast to this patient’s firm small testes).  
❌ Congenital adrenal hyperplasia  :
Incorrect: Congenital adrenal hyperplasia can present with gynecomastia due to increased production of estrogen precursors. It is characterized by increased virilization (e.g. increased body hair), unlike this patient with sparse body hair.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of abdominal pain and nausea for the past several hours. The patient vomited once and saw a small amount of blood in the vomitus. His past medical history is unremarkable, and the patient has not experienced similar symptoms before. He is not prescribed any medications, but he routinely takes multiple ibuprofen tablets for headaches. He took several tablets for a severe headache this morning that would “not go away.” He has a 10-pack-year smoking history and does not consume alcohol or other recreational drugs. Temperature is 36.7°C (98°F), pulse is 99/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 110/75 mmHg. Physical examination shows mild epigastric tenderness with no guarding. A complete blood count shows a hemoglobin level of 10.5 g/dL. Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy shows a deep, bleeding ulcer on the posterior wall of the duodenal bulb. Bleeding from which of the following arteries is most likely responsible for this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient’s clinical presentation (abdominal discomfort, nausea, and hematemesis) in combination with endoscopic findings of a bleeding ulcer on the posterior wall of the duodenal bulb, is consistent with the erosion of the ulcer into the gastroduodenal artery, which perfuses both pylorus and the proximal part of the duodenum. Risk factors for bleeding duodenal ulcers include Helicobacter pylori infection, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) use, and smoking.  

Posterior duodenal wall ulcers are more prone to bleeding than anterior duodenal ulcers due to the posterior relationship of the gastroduodenal artery. In contrast, anterior duodenal ulcers involve the anterior wall, and are prone to perforation but not bleeding. Duodenal ulcers are more likely to bleed than are gastric ulcers.  

Gastric ulcers commonly involve the lesser curvature of the stomach at the junction of the body and antrum. The left and right gastric arteries run along the lesser curvature of the stomach and can bleed from gastric ulcers. The splenic artery arises from the celiac trunk, passes posterior to the stomach (separated by the pancreas), and is rarely eroded by posterior gastric ulcers.  



Option Analysis

❌ Splenic artery:
Incorrect: The splenic artery arises from the celiac trunk, passes posterior to the stomach (separated by the pancreas) and is rarely involved in bleeding posterior gastric ulcers. Posterior duodenal wall ulcers with bleeding do not involve the splenic artery.  
✅ Gastroduodenal artery:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Left gastric artery:
Incorrect: The left gastric artery runs along the lesser curvature of the stomach and is at risk of bleeding from a gastric ulcer. However, a posterior duodenal wall ulcer is not likely to involve the left gastric artery.  
❌ Right gastric artery:
Incorrect: The right gastric artery runs along the lesser curvature of the stomach and is at risk of bleeding secondary to gastric ulcers. However, a posterior duodenal wall ulcer is not likely to involve the right gastric artery.  
❌ Left gastroepiploic artery:
Incorrect: The left and right gastroepiploic arteries run along the greater curvature of the stomach. They will not bleed with posterior duodenal wall ulcerations.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man comes to the office to be evaluated for abdominal pain, loss of appetite, and early satiety for the past three months. His clothes are looser than usual. Past medical history is significant for hypertension managed with lisinopril. Family history is noncontributory. The patient has a 40-pack-year smoking history, drinks alcohol occasionally, and does not use other recreational drugs. Temperature is 36.7°C (98°F), pulse is 89/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 120/75 mmHg. Physical examination shows a thin, pale, and cachexic man. Abdominal examination is significant for an enlarged spleen on palpation. CT scan abdomen shows an irregular mass arising posteriorly from the greater curvature of the stomach and compressing the splenic vessels. If the mass continues to enlarge, tissue supplied by which of the following vessels is most likely to be compromised in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation suggests a gastric tumor compressing the splenic vessels posteriorly. The splenic artery originates from the celiac artery and courses superiorly to the pancreas, giving off branches to the stomach and pancreas before reaching the spleen. These branches include: 
  •  Greater pancreatic artery and dorsal pancreatic artery 
  •  Short gastric arteries 
  •  Left gastroepiploic artery 
  •  Posterior gastric artery 
The short gastric arteries supply the fundus of the stomach along the proximal greater curvature where they have very poor anastomoses if the splenic artery is blocked. Therefore, this area is vulnerable to ischemia in the case of splenic artery blockage. In contrast, the left gastroepiploic artery which supplies the body of the stomach at the greater curvature forms strong anastomoses with the right gastroepiploic artery, and this region is usually spared from ischemia if the splenic artery is blocked.  



Option Analysis

✅ Short gastric arteries:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Left gastric artery:
Incorrect: The left gastric artery arises from the celiac artery and runs along the superior portion of the lesser curvature of the stomach. It anastomoses with the right gastric artery, which runs right to left. Splenic vessel compression would not involve the lesser curvature.  
❌ Gastroduodenal artery:
Incorrect:  Gastroduodenal arteries (branch of the common hepatic artery) supply the pylorus of the stomach and the duodenal bulb. This region would not be affected by splenic artery obstruction.  
❌ Proper hepatic artery:
Incorrect: Proper hepatic artery is a branch of the common hepatic artery, which supplies blood to the liver and gallbladder. Splenic artery obstruction would not affect these structures.  
❌ Left gastroepiploic artery:
Incorrect: The left gastroepiploic artery is a branch of the splenic artery that supplies blood to the body of the stomach along the greater curvature. It forms an anastomosis with the right gastroepiploic artery (branch of the gastroduodenal artery). Therefore, this region of the stomach would not be at risk for ischemia with splenic artery blockage.

questions.text: A 78-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with sudden onset vertigo, gait disturbance, and a stabbing pain on the right side of her face. The patient does not have fever, weight loss, chest pain, palpitations, or shortness of breath. Past medical history includes type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia. Temperature is 37.7°C (99.8°F), pulse is 83/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 156/90 mmHg. The patient falls to the right when asked to sit without support. Neurological exam is significant for partial ptosis and miosis of the right eye, nystagmus, and reduced pain and temperature sensation on the right face and left body. The patient’s voice sounds hoarse and she does not gag with oral tongue blade insertion. Hearing is intact bilaterally. Which of the following anatomic structures is the most likely site pathology given this patient’s presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient’s neurological findings are consistent with lateral medullary (Wallenberg) syndrome. This condition involves reduced blood supply to some (or all) of the following structures of the dorsolateral medulla including the inferior cerebellar peduncle, vestibular nuclei, fibers or nuclei of nerve IX or X, spinal nucleus and tract of V, spinothalamic tract, and sympathetic pathway. The dorsolateral medulla receives its blood supply from the posterior inferior cerebellar artery.  

Clinical features of lateral medullary syndrome include:
 
  • Dysphagia, hoarseness, diminished gag reflex, and hiccups due to the involvement of nucleus ambiguus (CN IX, X, XI)
  • Vomiting, vertigo and nystagmus, attributable to vestibular nuclei involvement
  • Diminished pain and temperature sensation of the contralateral body and ipsilateral face due to involvement of lateral spinothalamic tract and spinal trigeminal nucleus 
  • Ipsilateral Horner (miosis, ptosis, and anhidrosis) due to involvement of sympathetic fibers innervating the head and neck 
  • Ipsilateral ataxia and dysmetria due to the involvement of inferior cerebellar peduncle 

Option Analysis

✅ Lateral medulla  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Posterolateral thalamus  :
Incorrect: A pure sensory stroke often occurs secondary to malperfusion of the ventral posterolateral and/or ventral posteromedial nucleus of the thalamus–a key cerebral structure that relays sensory information regarding proprioception, pain, pressure, and temperature to the primary somatosensory cortex. Affected individuals present with numbness of the face and body (contralateral to the affected side of the thalamus).  
❌ Medial medulla:
Incorrect: Infarction of the paramedian branches of the anterior spinal artery results in medial medullary syndrome. This condition typically presents with contralateral hemiparesis (lateral corticospinal tract), decreased contralateral proprioception (medial lemniscus), and ipsilateral tongue paralysis (hypoglossal nucleus).  
❌ Basal pons:
Incorrect: Hypoperfusion of the basal pons results from occlusion of penetrating arteries, leading to the development of dysarthria (clumsy hand syndrome). Affected individuals present with facial weakness, dysphagia, dysarthria, and weakness of the hand ipsilateral to the lesion. Sensory deficits are absent in patients with this condition.  
❌ Parietal lobe:
Incorrect: Diminished perfusion of the parietal lobe results from occlusion of the anterior cerebral artery (ACA) and/or middle cerebral artery (MCA). Malperfusion of the parietal lobe may result in numbness; however, a stroke of the nondominant hemisphere manifests with contralateral neglect, while infarction of the dominant side manifests with aphasia, finger agnosia, agraphia, or dyscalculia.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman comes to her primary care physician’s clinic due to involuntary loss of urine and chronic constipation. She has leakage of urine with coughing, sneezing, or lifting heavyweights. Past medical history includes type II diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and a hysterectomy (six months ago) for uterine fibroids. The patient had two forceps-assisted vaginal deliveries. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 105/75 mmHg. Pelvic examination reveals dribbling of urine when the patient coughs. Post void residual urine is 40 ml. Urinalysis is negative for leukocyte esterase or nitrites. Which of the following best describes the anatomic site of pathology responsible for her symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient with a history of recent hysterectomy and two forceps assisted vaginal deliveries presents with urinary incontinence that worsens with maneuvers that increase intraabdominal pressure. She most likely has stress urinary incontinence secondary to pelvic organ prolapse. This condition results in the herniation of pelvic organs, including the bladder, rectum, or uterus, into the vaginal canal. Symptoms include a sensation of a mass in the perineum, urinary symptoms (stress incontinence, difficulty voiding, and retention), and bowel dysfunction (constipation or fecal incontinence). The perineal body is often implicated in pelvic organ prolapse.    

The perineal body is a fibromuscular node formed from the convergence of muscles of the perineum, including the levator ani, bulbospongiosus, superficial and deep transverse perinei, external anal sphincter, and the longitudinal muscle coat of the anal canal. It is located centrally in the perineum between the lower part of the vagina and the anal canal. It may be damaged during labor and delivery or abdominal surgeries such as hysterectomy.    

Specific risk factors that lead to perineal injury during childbirth include nulliparity, macrosomia (weight >3kg), shoulder dystocia, instrumental delivery, and precipitate labor. The perineal body remains important for supporting female pelvic organs, specifically the posterior wall of the vagina. A complication that arises from inadequate repairs of perineal body injury (second-degree perineal tears) is pelvic organ prolapse and urinary stress incontinence.    

Treatment of pelvic organ prolapse includes weight loss, kegel’s exercises, and placement of a vaginal pessary or surgery. Kegel exercises refer to pelvic exercises that strengthen the pelvic floor muscles.  



Option Analysis

✅ Perineal body    :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Obturator nerve    :
Incorrect: Obturator neuralgia usually occurs secondary to pelvic surgery, trauma, or tumors and presents with weakness in hip adduction and sensory loss over the medial aspect of the thigh. Urinary incontinence is not observed.   
❌ Pudendal nerve  :
Incorrect: Pudendal neuralgia can occur as a complication of pelvic surgery or obstructed labor. Injury to this nerve is clinically characterized by pain and paraesthesias involving the sensory distribution of the pudendal nerve, which includes the perineum and the lower third of the vagina. Urinary incontinence and constipation are not commonly observed with this condition.   
❌ Vaginal wall:
Incorrect: Vesicovaginal fistulas are aberrant communications between the genital tract and bladder that often form a pelvic complication surgery. They are characterized by continuous involuntary dribbling of urine without exacerbation by coughing, sneezing, or lifting heavy objects. Examination often reveals a vaginal wall defect or pooling of urine in the vault.   
❌ Bladder wall :
Incorrect: A urinary tract infection (UTI) can cause polyuria due to incomplete bladder emptying; however, UTIs typically present with dysuria and positive leukocyte esterase and nitrites on urinalysis.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman comes to the clinic for her postpartum visit.  She complains of significant pain around the vagina that worsens during sexual intercourse and when sitting down. Medical history during pregnancy is significant for gestational diabetes mellitus treated with NPH insulin. Six weeks ago, she delivered a 4.5 kg male baby after a prolonged, forceps-assisted vaginal delivery that resulted in a second-degree perineal tear. Past medical history includes depression treated with venlafaxine and escitalopram. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 105/75 mmHg.  The perineal laceration is intact.  Perianal wink reflex is absent.  Pain is not reproducible on speculum examination, and vulvar examination is non-tender. The vagina has a scant clear discharge. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient has generalized vulvodynia and long, forceps-assisted delivery history. She most likely has a pudendal nerve injury due to compression of the nerve fibers during delivery.    

The pudendal nerve arises from the sacral plexus's S2, S3, S4 ventral rami. It originates in the pelvis, courses through the greater foramen to enter the gluteal region, then enters the perineum through the lesser sciatic foramen. It is related to the ischial spine, which serves as the bony landmark for transvaginal pudendal nerve block for episiotomies during the second stage of labor. The perineum courses through the pudendal canal and terminates into its branches in the ischioanal fossa. The pudendal nerve carries sensory, motor, and autonomic fibers and supplies the skin of the perineum (including the anal canal below the pectinate line) and the clitoris with muscular branches to the anterior external anal sphincter and the urogenital muscles.    

In the second stage of labor, the descent of the fetal head causes significant compression and stretching of the pudendal nerve, resulting in pudendal neuralgia. This is especially prevalent in cases of difficult or prolonged labor. It is more likely to be encountered following an operative delivery or an extensive perineal tear. Symptoms of pudendal neuralgia include pain, numbness, and paresthesias in the distribution of the pudendal nerve in addition to urinary and anal sphincter dysfunction resulting in urinary and fecal incontinence and dyspareunia.   

Option Analysis

✅ Pudendal nerve injury :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Hypoestrogenism due to prolactinemia :
Incorrect: Patients who breastfeed have elevated prolactin levels that suppress GnRH release from the hypothalamus.  This results in low levels of estrogen, FSH, LH, and vulvovaginal atrophy.   Atrophic vulvovaginal changes can cause dyspareunia. However, this patient’s vaginal examination was normal, making this diagnosis unlikely.   
❌ Adverse effect of antidepressants  :
Incorrect: SSRIs and SNRIs cause sexual dysfunction. This generally manifests as depressed libido. Dyspareunia is unlikely.
❌ Vestibular hypersensitivity:
Incorrect: Vestibular hypersensitivity/vulvodynia is characterized by localized vulvar pain elicited with touch. This patient's vulvar examination was non-tender.   
❌ Vaginismus :
Incorrect: Vaginismus, also known as genito-pelvic pain/penetration disorder, is characterized by pain on sexual penetration due to involuntary contraction of the pelvic floor. Pelvic examination with a speculum would elicit pain not present in this patient making this diagnosis unlikely.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman comes to the clinic for follow-up after a radical abdominal hysterectomy for endometrial cancer a month ago. Over the last two weeks, the patient has noticed continuous urine leakage that soaks two to three pads a day. She has not experienced difficulty passing urine, urinary retention, or incomplete emptying. Past medical history includes depression treated with venlafaxine and escitalopram, and multiple sclerosis. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 105/75 mmHg. Abdominal examination is unremarkable. The vagina has a scant clear discharge. Pelvic examination reveals a granular mass on the anterior vaginal wall. Post void residual urine is 50 ml. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Aberrant connection between the bladder and vagina
Overflow incontinence from bladder outlet obstruction

questions.solution:
This patient has continuous leakage of urine, a vaginal wall defect, and recently underwent a radical abdominal hysterectomy. She most likely has a genitourinary fistula.    

A fistula is a pathological communication formed between two epithelialized surfaces. Genitourinary fistulas form between the urinary and genital tracts. The transmission can occur between the bladder (vesicovaginal) or urethra (urethrovaginal) and the genital tract. Fistulas in the genital tract can result from obstetric trauma to the vaginal wall (instrumental vaginal delivery), ischemia to the vaginal wall from prolonged and obstructed labor, malignancies of the genital tract, operative injuries (eg, abdominal hysterectomies), or radiation therapy.    

In developing countries, the most common cause of fistulas is obstetric trauma. Prolonged compression of the bladder wall between the fetal head and symphysis pubis can cause ischemia, necrosis, and sloughing to form a fistula.    

Vesicovaginal fistulas are aberrant communications between the bladder and the vagina. Clinical symptoms include the continuous passage of urine from the vaginal opening. A visible vaginal defect and pooling of clear fluid in the vagina are noted on clinical examination. Rectovaginal fistulas are pathologic communications formed between the lower gastrointestinal tract and the vagina and most commonly result from obstetric trauma, including inadequately healed perineal lacerations. They can also occur as a complication from Crohn’s disease. Clinical symptoms include malodorous, brown vaginal discharge and a posterior vaginal defect noted on physical examination.   Treatment involves surgical repair.   

Option Analysis

✅ Aberrant connection between the bladder and vagina :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Neurogenic bladder dysfunction :
Incorrect: Diabetic neuropathy can cause neurogenic bladder dysfunction and result in incomplete bladder emptying and overflow incontinence. Most patients will have a high void residual urine volume. This patient’s post-void urine volume is normal.  
❌ Overflow incontinence from bladder outlet obstruction :
Incorrect: Patients with bladder outlet obstruction have high post-void residual urine and a distended bladder on abdominal examination. This patient’s post-void urine volume is normal.   
❌ Postmenopausal hypoestrogenism :
Incorrect: Estrogen deficiency after menopause can result in a genitourinary syndrome of menopause which can cause vulvovaginal atrophy, recurrent urinary infections, and incontinence. However, incontinence is usually intermittent and not continuous.   
❌ Urethral hypermobility :
Incorrect: Stress urinary incontinence is caused by urethral hypermobility and results in intermittent loss of urine, particularly with increased abdominal pressure.

questions.text: A patient is currently being evaluated for a massive pulmonary embolism in the cardiac intensive care unit. As part of the patient’s evaluation, the jugular vein is assessed to measure jugular venous pressure.  Which of the following anatomic landmarks are best used to identify the internal jugular vein for the performance of this measurement?

choices.text: Between the medial and lateral heads of the sternocleidomastoid
1 cm inferior to the junction of the middle and medial third of the clavicle
Midline between the thyroid cartilage and cricoid cartilage

questions.solution:
In the neck, the sigmoid sinus exits the jugular foramen and continues in the neck to form the internal jugular vein (IJV).  The IJV travels within the carotid sheath, lateral to the internal carotid artery, with the vagus nerve sitting between the two vessels.  It joins the subclavian vein to form the brachiocephalic vein at the clavicle level.

Surgical landmarks are used to identify the jugular vein. The anterior triangle of the neck is bound inferiorly by the clavicle by the head of the sternocleidomastoid muscle and laterally by the lateral head of the sternocleidomastoid. The internal carotid artery (ICA) is isolated by palpation. Lateral to the ICA lies the internal jugular vein.

JVP ( jugular venous pressure) reflects the right atrial pressure. It is frequently used clinically to assess whether the RAP is elevated (Right-sided congestive heart failure) or low (hypovolemic shock). It can also diagnose pericardial disease, tricuspid valve stenosis, and superior vena cava obstruction.

The right IJV is generally preferred to examine the jugular venous pulse as it is in line with the superior vena cava.  While examining the JVP in a patient, the examiner stands on the patient's right side with the optimal degree of upper body elevation. The degree of upper body elevation refers to the angle at which the venous meniscus is best appreciated. In most cases, it is 45 degrees.

The patient’s head is then turned away, and the head and jaw are tipped slightly upwards. Two rulers are required to assess the JVP. One ruler is placed horizontally from the highest visible pulsation point of the internal jugular vein while the other ruler is crossed at the sternal angle. The RAP is determined by adding the height of the jugular venous column above the sternal angle to the vertical distance from the right atrium to the sternal angle (5cm).  

Option Analysis

✅ Between the medial and lateral heads of the sternocleidomastoid:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ 1 cm inferior to the junction of the middle and medial third of the clavicle:
Incorrect: This answer describes the access route and anatomic landmarks for subclavian vein central venous access. The stem above describes central venous access obtained through the internal jugular vein.  
❌ Second intercostal space, midclavicular line:
Incorrect: This anatomic site references the site for thoracic needle decompression, not central venous access. A needle and catheter should be placed on the superior aspect of the rib to avoid damage to intercostal vasculature and nerve.  
❌ Fourth intercostal space midaxillary line:
Incorrect: This stem describes one of the anatomic sites for tube thoracostomy (chest tube placement), not central venous access.  
❌ Midline between the thyroid cartilage and cricoid cartilage:
Incorrect: These anatomic landmarks are used for palpation of the cricothyroid membrane--the site of access for emergent cricothyrotomy and tracheostomy placement.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with COPD is undergoing repair of a torn shoulder labrum. The patient develops tachypnea and respiratory distress as the orthopedic surgeon prepares for surgery. While in the preoperative suit, the anesthesiologist performs an interscalene nerve block. Vital signs are temperature is 37 C° (98.6 F°), respirations are 26/minute,  pulse is 109/minute, blood pressure is 101/67 mmHg, and SPO<sub>2</sub> is 81% on 2L nasal cannula.  Physical examination demonstrates a frail man with increased work of breathing and faint end-expiratory wheezing. The patient subsequently undergoes rapid sequence intubation with the demonstration of bilateral breath sounds following endotracheal tube placement. Which anatomic structures were most likely implicated in this patient’s abrupt change in respiratory status?
questions.solution:
An interscalene nerve block anesthetizes most of the territory innervated by the brachial plexus and is generally performed on patients undergoing shoulder, upper arm, or elbow surgery.  Landmarks used to perform this procedure include the interscalene groove, which is found between the middle and anterior scalene muscles at the level of the sixth cervical vertebra, which is approximately at the level of the cricoid cartilage.

Nerves anesthetized during this procedure include most of the brachial plexus, sparing the ulnar (C8-T1) nerve.  In addition, the phrenic nerve is often anesthetized during this procedure, resulting in ipsilateral hemidiaphragmatic paralysis. Therefore, patients with underlying respiratory conditions (e.g. COPD) should not undergo this procedure. In addition, the recurrent laryngeal nerve is often anesthetized--resulting in temporary paralysis of the ipsilateral vocal fold. Additional complications include iatrogenic pneumothorax, as well as hematoma/seroma formation.  

Option Analysis

✅ Phrenic nerve:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Visceral pleura:
Incorrect: A pneumothorax may occur secondary to an interscalene nerve block; however, this patient is noted to have bilateral breath sounds following intubation.  
❌ Vagus nerve:
Incorrect: Injury to the vagus nerve may result in paralysis to both the superior laryngeal nerve and the recurrent branch of the laryngeal nerve and digestive issues and slowed heart rate.  
❌ Long thoracic nerve:
Incorrect: Injury to the long thoracic nerve more commonly occurs following chest wall surgeries. Clinical manifestations include a “winged scapula” due to the serratus anterior muscle weakness.  
❌ Spinal accessory nerve:
Incorrect: The spinal accessory nerve (CN XI) provides motor function to the sternocleidomastoid and trapezius muscles. Injury manifests with shoulder/neck pain and a drooping shoulder, and weakness with overhead abduction.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman presents to the emergency department for evaluation of a foreign body sensation in the throat. The patient reports she was eating fish soup when she felt a small bone “get stuck in my throat.” After topical lidocaine is applied to the posterior pharynx, a fishbone is retrieved from the piriform recess under video-assisted laryngoscopy. At her follow-up visit several days later, the patient reports she has noticed a slight change in the quality of her voice. Which of the following anatomical structures was most likely injured during removal of the foreign body?
questions.solution:
The piriform recess (or sinus) is a subsite of the hypopharynx. It is a recess on either side of the laryngeal inlet, bounded laterally by the thyroid cartilage and thyrohyoid membrane and medially by the aryepiglottic folds.  It is a common area for foreign bodies to become lodged during swallowing.

The superior laryngeal and its branches lie deep to the mucosa of the piriform recess and may be damaged during lodging or retrieval of foreign bodies from this space. Superior laryngeal nerve damage often manifests with vocal fatigue and subtle changes in voice quality in timbre, pitch, voice projection, and decreased sensation to the laryngeal mucosa.

Damage to the internal laryngeal nerve may result in altered sensation to the laryngeal mucosa, as this nerve only carries sensory information. In contrast, damage to the external laryngeal nerve manifests with changes in voice quality, as this nerve carries motor fibers to the cricothyroid muscle.  

Option Analysis

✅ Superior laryngeal nerve:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Recurrent laryngeal nerve:
Incorrect: The recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN), when damaged, often presents with new-onset hoarseness, changes in vocal pitch, and noisy breathing.  
❌ Thyroid ima artery:
Incorrect: The thyroid ima artery is an unpaired, variable branch of the brachiocephalic artery that supplies the thyroid and the isthmus. When injured during head and neck procedures, it can be a source of brisk and difficult to control bleeding.  
❌ Common carotid artery:
Incorrect: Injury to the common carotid artery results in hematoma formation and possible neurologic deficits secondary to ischemic or thromboembolic events.  
❌ Vagus nerve:
Incorrect: Injury to the vagus nerve may result in paralysis to both the superior laryngeal nerve and the recurrent branch of the laryngeal nerve. This can result in both sensory and motor deficits of the larynx.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy presents to his pediatrician with nasal congestion, fever, and throat pain complaints. His parent reports the patient had an upper respiratory tract infection last week, which seemed to improve, but his symptoms worsened over the past three days. The patient's current vital signs are temperature is 38.9 C° (102 F°), respirations are 16/minute,  pulse is 90/minute, and blood pressure is 105/70 mmHg. Physical examination demonstrates purulent rhinorrhea. A flexible nasal endoscope is inserted, which confirms the diagnosis. Which of the following correctly describes the anatomic structure implicated in this patient’s presentation?
questions.solution:
The tonsils consist of a group of lymphatic tissues in the posterior pharynx/oropharynx and include pharyngeal, palatine, tubal, and lingual. When the pharyngeal tonsils, or adenoids, become inflamed, the condition is called adenoiditis.

The pharyngeal tonsils typically regress by early puberty; therefore, the majority of patients that present with adenoiditis are prepubescent. A typical history includes a child with a recent viral upper respiratory infection that progresses to fevers, purulent rhinorrhea, nasal obstruction, mouth breathing, and halitosis. Diagnosis is primarily clinical, and direct visualization of the inflamed pharyngeal tonsils can be achieved via a laryngeal mirror or nasal endoscope.

Commonly implicated pathogens include those responsible for other upper respiratory tract infections, including Haemophilus influenzae, Streptococcus pneumoniae, Streptococcus pyogenes, and Staphylococcus aureus. In addition, environmental allergens and caustic irritation secondary to gastric reflux are known to precipitate adenoiditis.

Option Analysis

✅ Pharyngeal tonsils:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Palatine tonsils:
Incorrect: The palatine tonsils are tonsils located on the left and right sides at the back of the throat, which can often be seen as flesh-colored, pinkish lumps. The palatine tonsils are not the lymphatic tissue associated with acute adenoiditis.  
❌ Thyroid gland:
Incorrect: The thyroid gland lies inferior and anterior to the pharyngeal tonsils--at the level below the cricoid cartilage. The thyroid gland may become enlarged and inflamed for various reasons; however, it is not implicated in cases of acute adenoiditis.  
❌ Tubal tonsils:
Incorrect: The tubal tonsil is located posterior to the Eustachian tube's opening on the nasopharynx's lateral wall. This tonsil may become implicated in cases of eustachian tube dysfunction.  
❌ Parotid gland:
Incorrect: The parotid gland serves as the largest salivary gland and lies on the lateral aspects of the face. The parotid glands cannot be visualized with nasal endoscopy.

questions.text: After a high-speed motor vehicle accident, a 45-year-old woman presents to the emergency department. The patient was restrained when her vehicle was struck from the passenger side by another vehicle traveling approximately 60 mph (97 km/h). The patient’s primary survey is intact. A secondary survey demonstrates a bleeding laceration and a palpable depression over the temporal bone. The patient reports diminished sensation over her left forehead, nose, mouth, and jaw. The patient’s jaw deviates towards the left when asked to open her mouth. Which of the following cranial nerves is most likely damaged based on this patient’s clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with clinical features consistent with a trigeminal nerve injury (CN V)--likely at the trigeminal root or ganglion. The trigeminal nerve carries both sensory and motor innervation to the face and is divided into three major branches: the ophthalmic branch (V1), maxillary branch (V2), and mandibular branch (V3).

The V1 supplies sensation to the scalp and forehead, the upper eyelid, the conjunctiva and cornea of the eye, and the nose. The V2  provides sensation to the area over the maxilla, nasal cavity, sinuses, palate, and mid-face. Lastly, V3  provides sensory information to the lower jaw and cheek while also providing motor function to several muscles of mastication. Thus, patients with injury to the trigeminal root will have absent sensory information over the entire ipsilateral face and weakness or wasting of the muscles of mastication. Weakness of these muscles will result in ipsilateral deviation of the jaw when opened. In addition, V1 provides sensory input regarding the reflex arc for the corneal reflex. Thus damage to this branch or the trigeminal root will result in an absent corneal reflex.  

Option Analysis

❌ CN  I:
Incorrect: The optic nerve, or cranial nerve, provides sensory information regarding sight to the brain.  
✅ CN V:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ CN VII:
Incorrect: Cranial nerve VII, or the facial nerve, provides innervation to the muscles of facial expression and taste sensation to the anterior two-thirds of the tongue.  
❌ CN IX:
Incorrect: Motor function of cranial nerve IX, or the glossopharyngeal nerve, includes innervation of the stylopharyngeus muscle, elevating the larynx and pharynx during speaking and swallowing.  
❌ CN X:
Incorrect:  The vagus nerve innervates several of the striated muscles of the larynx and pharynx. Damage to this nerve does not result in jaw deviation. Moreover, damage to this nerve would result in autonomic dysfunction.

questions.text:
A 66-year-old woman presents to the emergency department to evaluate rash and right eye pain. The patient states she first noticed a rash over her right forehead five days ago, and it has become more painful over time. The patient says she began having worsening pain in her right eye today with associated light sensitivity and redness. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination is notable for the findings demonstrated in the image below. Which of the following nerves is implicated in the pathogenesis of this disease?
 

Reproduced from: wikipedia
questions.solution:
This patient presents with vesicular lesions over the forehead, eye, and nose--with evidence of corneal involvement--consistent with herpes zoster ophthalmicus. The pathogenesis of this disease begins with reactivation of the varicella-zoster virus (VZV) in the trigeminal nerve ganglion, which subsequently results in lesions in distribution following the ophthalmic nerve (V1 distribution of the trigeminal nerve).

Herpes zoster ophthalmicus, a potentially sight-threatening condition, typically presents with vesicular lesions in distribution following V1--over the forehead and scalp (frontal nerve), nose (nasociliary nerve), or eye that eventually involve the cornea and associated eye structures. Patients often endorse a prodrome of headache and low-grade fevers, followed by pain and eruption of a vesicular rash. Associated signs include the Hutchinson sign--which refers to cutaneous involvement of the tip of the nose, indicating nasociliary nerve involvement. Vesicular lesions in this distribution carry a high risk of ocular involvement. Without treatment with antiviral agents (acyclovir, valacyclovir), lesions may progress to erode ocular structures, resulting in blindness.  

Option Analysis

✅ Ophthalmic nerve:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Maxillary nerve:
Incorrect: The maxillary nerve (V2) is not often implicated in the pathogenesis of herpes zoster ophthalmicus. This nerve provides sensation to the area over the maxilla, nasal cavity, sinuses, palate, and mid-face.  
❌ Mandibular nerve:
Incorrect: The mandibular nerve (V3), another branch of the trigeminal nerve, provides sensory information to the lower jaw and cheek while also providing motor function to several muscles of mastication.  
❌ Facial nerve:
Incorrect: The facial nerve, or cranial nerve VII, provides innervation to the muscles of facial expression and taste sensation to the anterior two-thirds of the tongue.  
❌ Optic nerve:
Incorrect: The optic nerve, or CNI, provides sensory information to the brain regarding sight. This nerve can become involved in the late stages of herpes zoster ophthalmicus, resulting in total blindness.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old woman comes to the office for the evaluation of recurrent episodes of urinary tract infection. She has had five episodes of cystitis and an episode of pyelonephritis over the last year. The rest of the history is unremarkable, and she does not have any other medical conditions. Family history is noncontributory. She has not been sexually active for the last six months. Temperature is 37.7°C (99.9°F), pulse is 84/min, respirations are 17/min and blood pressure is 110/70 mmHg. Physical examination shows mild suprapubic tenderness. CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis is shown below. Which of the following structures is involved in the pathophysiology of this patient’s findings on the CT scan?  


Reproduced from Radiopedia
questions.solution:
This patient’s CT scan shows both renal lower poles pointing medially and seen fused across the midline by an isthmus of functioning renal tissue. This abnormality is known as horseshoe kidney and affects about 1 in 500 people.  

Normally, the kidneys rest in the retroperitoneum between the T12 and L3 vertebrae after ascending from the pelvis. In some patients, the kidneys are fused mechanically at the poles where the central isthmus of the horseshoe kidney lies anterior to the aorta and posterior to the inferior mesenteric artery (IMA). During fetal development, its ascent is arrested by the IMA.    

Most patients are asymptomatic, and for these patients, the horseshoe kidney is diagnosed incidentally. It, however, increases the risk of ureteropelvic junction obstruction, recurrent infections, urolithiasis, and renal tumors.  



Option Analysis

❌ Superior mesenteric artery:
Incorrect: The superior mesenteric artery arises from the anterior surface of the abdominal aorta between the celiac trunk superiorly and inferior mesenteric artery inferiorly at the level of L1 vertebrae and does not serve as an obstacle for the ascend of the kidney.  
✅ Inferior mesenteric artery:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Inferior vena cava:
Incorrect: The inferior vena cava is a large vein formed by the joining of the right and the left common iliac veins, usually at the level of the fifth lumbar vertebra. It does not prevent the normal ascent of the kidneys.
❌ Third part of the duodenum:
Incorrect: The third part of the duodenum begins at the inferior duodenal flexure and passes transversely to the left, passing in front of the inferior vena cava, abdominal aorta, and the vertebral column. The superior mesenteric artery and vein are anterior to the third part of the duodenum.  
❌ Urachal fistula:
Incorrect: A urachal fistula is a congenital disorder caused by the persistence of the allantois (later, urachus), the structure that connects an embryo's bladder to the yolk sac. It is usually diagnosed earlier in life.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department to be evaluated for right elbow pain. He is bracing himself and making sure not to move his arm at the elbow. The patient tripped while running and fell onto his outstretched right arm, holding his elbow in hyper-extension. Past medical and surgical history is noncontributory. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows diffuse swelling and tenderness at the right elbow with a limited range of motion. X-ray of the right elbow shows a supracondylar fracture with postero-lateral displacement of the distal humerus. Based on this fracture pattern, which of the following actions is likely to be compromised?

choices.text: Adduction of the third and fourth digits

questions.solution:
This patient presents with a supracondylar fracture and postero-lateral displacement of the distal humerus. This injury pattern is commonly associated with median nerve injury. Thus, the patient will most likely present with impaired thumb opposition due to thenar eminence paralysis   

Supracondylar fractures are the most common type of elbow fracture in pediatric patients. An extension-type supracondylar fracture (most common) is caused by a fall on an outstretched hand with the elbow hyperextended. The median nerve and brachial artery run anteromedially over the elbow and are most often injured with postero-lateral displacement of the distal humerus .    

In contrast, the radial nerve runs anterolaterally over the elbow. It is more commonly injured when the distal humerus is displaced postero-medially. This injury can lead to inability to extend at the wrist and hand.  



Option Analysis

✅ Thumb opposition:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Adduction of the third and fourth digits:
Incorrect: Adduction of the third and fourth digits is controlled by the deep branch of the ulnar nerve. This patient has postero-lateral displacement of the distal humerus which will most likely lead to medial nerve injury which will affect thumb opposition.  
❌ Elbow, wrist, and finger extension:
Incorrect: Elbow, wrist, and finger extension are functions of the radial nerve (C5-T1), which can be injured in cases of postero-medial displacement of the distal fragment of the humerus. This patient has postero-lateral displacement with subsequent injury to the median nerve which will affect thumb opposition.  
❌ Sensation over the posterior forearm:
Incorrect: Loss of sensation over posterior arm/forearm and dorsal hand occurs in patients with radial nerve injury. This nerve can be injured with postero-medial displacement of the distal humerus not with postero-lateral displacement as seen in this case.  
❌ Supination of the forearm:
Incorrect: The forearm supinators at the elbow are innervated by the musculocutaneous nerve, which can be injured in patients with upper nerve trunk compression.

questions.text:
A 12-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department for evaluation following a fall and associated right elbow pain. The patient reports hearing a sudden "pop" in his right elbow immediately after falling to the ground with an outstretched hand. Past medical and surgical history is noncontributory. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates ecchymosis and pain to palpation over the medial epicondyle. He has full range of motion of the shoulders bilaterally. Peripheral pulses are full and symmetric bilaterally. A plain radiograph of the right elbow is shown below. Based on this patient’s injury pattern, he will most likely have weakness with which of the following actions?  


Reproduced by Radiopedia

choices.text: Flexion of the fourth and fifth digits

questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation is consistent with a medial epicondyle avulsion fracture, which can  injure the ulnar nerve as it passes posterior to the medial aspect of the elbow. Fractures of the medial epicondyle tend to occur in children between the ages of 10 and 14 following injuries involving falling on an outstretched hand, repeated valgus stresses such as throwing a baseball, or via a direct blow. Medial epicondyle avulsion fractures can also be associated with elbow dislocations. Patients present with swelling and tenderness over the medial elbow and pain exacerbated with supination and flexion of the forearm, wrist, and digits.    

The ulnar nerve originates from the medial cord of the brachial plexus (C8-T1). It is commonly injured at the elbow from cubital tunnel syndrome, fractures of the medial epicondyle of the humerus, or fractures of the lateral epicondyle of the humerus (causing cubitus valgus with tardy ulnar nerve palsy). Patients typically present with discomfort and loss of sensation/paraesthesias over the fourth and fifth fingers, weakness with wrist flexion/adduction, finger abduction/adduction, and flexion of fourth/fifth digits. Together, these findings are referred to as a “claw deformity.”   

Option Analysis

❌ Supination of the forearm:
Incorrect: The forearm supinators are innervated by the musculocutaneous nerve, which can become injured from upper nerve trunk compression. Injury to this nerve is not commonly observed in patients with medial epicondyle avulsions.  
❌ Thumb opposition:
Incorrect: Thumb opposition can become impaired in patients with underlying median nerve injury secondary to a supracondylar fracture of the humerus and lack of innervation to the thenar muscle.   
✅ Flexion of the fourth and fifth digits:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Wrist extension:
Incorrect: Elbow, wrist, and finger extension are functions controlled by the radial nerve (C5-T1), which can become damaged with supracondylar or midshaft humerus fractures. Weakness of wrist extension and a wrist drop can be seen with injury to the radial nerve.  
❌ Shoulder abduction:
Incorrect: Impaired shoulder abduction occurs with axillary nerve injury secondary to shoulder dislocation or proximal humerus fracture.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman comes to the emergency department for evaluation of difficulty seeing out of her left eye. The patient began having painful eye movements and blurry vision two days ago and recalls two similar episodes that self-resolved several years ago. Each episode was associated with deficits in color vision. The patient does not have any recent trauma, loss of consciousness, or speech changes. Vitals are within normal limits. Examination demonstrates left optic disc atrophy and a relative afferent pupillary defect. There is impaired adduction of the right eye with left lateral gaze. Convergence shows normal adduction of both eyes. MRI of the brain demonstrates abnormal enhancement of the left optic nerve. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of preferential involvement of the optic nerve in this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Spirochete protein cross-reactivity in the meninges
Antibody binding at the neuromuscular junction

questions.solution:
This patient presents with features of optic neuritis and multiple sclerosis–an immune-mediated demyelinating disease, thought to result from immune-mediated damage to myelin basic proteins (oligodendrocytes) via Th1 cells.    

In the optic nerve, myelin is produced by oligodendrocytes and may be affected in demyelinating diseases such as multiple sclerosis. This is not true for other cranial nerves in which myelin is created by Schwann cells. Acute demyelinating injury to the optic nerve causes optic neuritis, which commonly present with vision loss and eye pain.   

The relative afferent pupillary defect (aka Marcus Gunn pupil) results from an impaired direct pupillary reflex in the affected eye and indirect pupillary reflex in the normal eye. It can be tested via the swinging flashlight test.  

  •  While the patient fixates on a point in the distance, swing a light back and forth from one eye to the other and observe the size of the pupils. 
  •  Normally, both the illuminated pupil and the non illuminated pupil constrict. 
  •  If the optic nerve of one eye is damaged, both pupils will dilate when light shines in the affected eye. 


Option Analysis

✅ Destruction of oligodendrocytes by T-cells:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Osmotically-mediated Schwann cell damage:
Incorrect: Osmotically-mediated Schwann cell damage is observed in diabetic neuropathy due to chronic hyperglycemia. Diabetic neuropathy presents with a stocking-glove distribution and is associated with dysesthesias and loss of sensation. The optic nerve is sheathed by the myelin of oligodendrocytes (not schwann cells).  
❌ Lymphocytic infiltrate of the endoneurium:
Incorrect: Lymphocytic infiltrate of the endoneurium is observed with Guillain-Barré syndrome. This syndrome manifests with polyneuropathy and ascending flaccid paralysis following a bacterial or viral infection .  
❌ Spirochete protein cross-reactivity in the meninges:
Incorrect: Spirochete protein cross-reactivity in the meninges is characteristic of aseptic meningitis, secondary to late-stage Lyme disease (neuroborreliosis). This patient has no history of a tick bite or erythema migrans to suggest Lyme disease.  
❌ Antibody binding at the neuromuscular junction:
Incorrect: The pathophysiology of myasthenia gravis involves binding of antibodies to postsynaptic acetylcholine receptors, resulting in impaired neuromuscular transmission. Although this patient has visual changes often seen in patients with myasthenia gravis, they do not present with ophthalmoplegia.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man comes to the emergency department to be evaluated for retrosternal chest pain. The pain started four hours ago while playing soccer with his grandchild. The pain radiates to his left arm and jaw and is not associated with breathing or position changes. Past medical history is significant for type II diabetes mellitus and hypertension. Cardiac catheterization is performed via the femoral artery and demonstrates stenosis of the following arteries: 70% left main coronary artery, 90% proximal left anterior descending artery, and 80% right coronary artery. Six hours following catheterization, the patient states that he is experiencing generalized weakness and back pain. Temperature is 37.1℃ (98.8℉), pulse is 120/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 96/60 mmHg. Physical examination demonstrates cold and clammy extremities. A 5 cm area of ecchymosis is noted surrounding the femoral puncture site. Palpation and auscultation of catheter access sites are unremarkable. The patient has palpable, thready dorsalis pedis pulses bilaterally. Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation of sudden onset back pain, generalized weakness, and hypotension with cold and clammy extremities after cardiac catheterization is consistent with retroperitoneal hemorrhage. This patient’s condition likely occurred secondary to accidental puncture of the posterior wall of the common femoral artery.   

The common femoral artery serves as the continuation of the external iliac artery as it crosses the inguinal ligament and is often used as a site for vascular access. Retroperitoneal bleeding is frequently related to artery puncture above the inguinal ligament, as this portion of the vessel lies directly inferior to the peritoneum. Accidental puncture of the posterior wall of the common femoral artery can cause blood to track along the vascular fascial sheath into the retroperitoneum or rectus sheath.  

Due to the size of the retroperitoneal space, significant hemorrhage can occur before the development of any clinical signs or symptoms. Back pain, hypotension, and a significant drop in hemoglobin after a procedure are signs of a retroperitoneal hemorrhage. Diagnosis is confirmed via computed tomography imaging.  

Option Analysis

❌ Pseudoaneurysm:
Incorrect: A pseudoaneurysm is associated with clinical findings of pain at the access site combined with ecchymosis and subcutaneous hematoma. It is often recognized by the presence of a pulsatile mass with a systolic bruit overlying the catheter insertion site. This patient does not have symptoms or signs on physical examination of a pseudoaneurysm. Pseudoaneurysms do not typically lead to loss of a large volume of blood and hypotension. 
❌ Arteriovenous fistula:
Incorrect: Bleeding from the arterial puncture site may fistulize into the adjacent femoral vein. It may be recognized clinically by the presence of a thrill or continuous bruit. The time of symptom onset ranges from two days to several months after catheterization.
❌ Allergic reaction to iodinated contrast:
Incorrect: An allergic reaction to iodinated contrast typically presents with urticaria, pruritus, facial edema, as well as transient warmth or chills. Allergic reactions usually occur within twenty minutes of exposure. Anaphylaxis from contrast media occurs within minutes of exposure.
✅ Retroperitoneal hemorrhage:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Arterial thrombosis:
Incorrect: Patients with lower extremity arterial thrombosis present with pain or paresthesias in the affected leg, as well as reduced or absent distal pulses.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman comes to the clinic because of bilateral leg “heaviness and aching pain” with prolonged standing. The patient reports that the pain worsens at the end of the day and is relieved by walking or elevating her feet. Past medical history is significant for type II diabetes mellitus and obesity. Family history is noncontributory. The patient smokes two packs daily and does not use alcohol or other recreational drugs. BMI is 35 kg/m2. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination of the lower extremities demonstrates dilated, tortuous veins at the calves and ankles bilaterally, without surrounding erythema, edema, or ulceration. A bluish non-tender lump is noted in the right upper thigh, inferior to the inguinal ligament, that disappears with continuous, direct pressure and with lying supine. No pulsations are felt and no inguinal defect is palpated. Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient’s groin swelling?
questions.solution:
This patient's presentation is consistent with lower limb varicosities, most likely due to prolonged standing and obesity, as well as a bluish-tinged, nontender, reducible groin lump suggestive of a saphena varix.   

Saphena varix is a dilated, saccular swelling of the great saphenous vein at the saphenofemoral junction in the groin below the inguinal ligament. They arise from incompetent valves, which permit blood flow from the deep venous system to the superficial venous system. Thus the leg of the affected side almost always has obvious varicose veins as well which are tortuous dilated segments of a vein associated with valvular incompetence. This results in venous hypertension and dilatation of the superficial venous system. Valvular incompetence of the deep and superficial veins can be determined by performing a Trendelenburg test. The affected leg is raised emptying the veins, then a tourniquet is applied to constrict only the superficial veins. The test is positive, if upon standing with the tourniquet in place for 30 seconds, the varicosities remain collapsed and when the tourniquet is removed, the internal saphenous vein rapidly fills with blood from above. This indicates that the valves of the saphenous vein at the saphenofemoral junction are incompetent, but the valves of the communicating veins are still intact.  



Option Analysis

❌ Femoral hernia:
Incorrect: A femoral hernia results when the abdominal viscera passes through the femoral ring. The inguinal defect can typically be palpated. This condition manifests as a tender or non-tender bulge on the upper thigh, inferior to the inguinal ligament, and can often be mistaken for a saphena varix..
❌ Femoral artery aneurysm:
Incorrect: A femoral artery aneurysm refers to dilation of the common femoral artery just below the inguinal ligament. Pain is typically absent in femoral artery aneurysms and the palpable mass is typically pulsatile. 
✅ Saphena varix:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Direct inguinal hernia:
Incorrect: Inguinal hernias are located above the inguinal ligament and medial to the pubic tubercle. This patient’s groin lump is located below the inguinal ligament.
❌ Inguinal lymphadenopathy:
Incorrect: Enlarged inguinal lymph nodes vary in consistency, number, presence of pain, and size depending on the pathological cause. Lymph nodes are not reducible.

questions.text: A 54-year-old man comes to the office for a follow-up appointment after having a recent right total hip arthroplasty due to long-standing osteoarthritis. His postoperative course was unremarkable. Past medical history is significant for hypertension and osteoarthritis. Vitals are within normal limits. With standing the patient is able to comfortably bear weight on each leg. He leans towards his right side with ambulation. The patient’s left pelvis tilts downwards when asked to stand on the right leg. The surgical site over the lateral hip appears to be healing well, and there are no signs of infection. Hip range of motion does not cause pain and is as expected at this post-operative stage. The remainder of his physical examination is within normal limits. Which of the following best explains these findings?

choices.text: Septic arthritis of the hip joint

questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation is consistent with a Trendelenburg gait and abductor weakness from injury to the superior gluteal nerve. The superior gluteal nerve (L4-S1) can be injured in patients undergoing total hip arthroplasty where the gluteus medius is split and retracted.  

The superior gluteal nerve is responsible for innervating the gluteus medius and maximus which abduct the thigh when a person is standing on one foot or during normal ambulation. Weakness of these muscles results in sagging of the pelvis to the unaffected side while standing on the affected leg (positive Trendelenburg sign). When ambulating, the patient will lean toward the affected side to compensate for the hip drop (gluteus medius march).



Common causes of Trendelenburg gait include superior gluteal nerve injury, tendinitis or penetrating injury of the lateral glutei, greater trochanteric avulsion, or fracture of the femoral neck.  

Option Analysis

✅ Superior gluteal nerve injury:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Adductor muscle strain:
Incorrect: Adductor strains can occur while sprinting or performing explosive hip movements. This condition typically results in focal pain in the groin or the medial thigh and pain with resisted hip adduction. This patient has evidence of a Trendelenburg gait and abductor weakness suggestive of superior gluteal nerve injury.  
❌ Piriformis muscle spasm:
Incorrect:  Piriformis syndrome occurs when the piriformis muscle spasms and irritates or compresses the sciatic nerve. Hip flexion, external rotation, or passive internal rotation exacerbate pain. A Trendelenburg gait suggests gluteus muscle weakness.
❌ Septic arthritis of the hip joint:
Incorrect: This condition presents severe joint pain (especially with range of motion), erythema, warmth, and tenderness over the affected joint. Patients are almost always unable to bear weight. A Trendelenburg gait suggests an alternative etiology.
